title: Stack It High
text: We're talking about food here.Â  Since the debt ceiling bill passed and no doubt will be signed, reports indicate that we ain't seen nuthin' yet as far as food inflation is concerned.Â  We have always said, "Stack it to the rafters."Â  Now might be the time to go beyond.Due to physical restraints and just plain old age, I have my groceries delivered.Â  This service makes life much easier for me as well as many others of my vintage who find mobility to be a problem.Â  But once in a while they get it wrong.Â  Just a minor thing.Â Right now I am concentrating on dehydrating food.Â  Four bags of frozen hash browns dried overnght and are cooling down so I can package them for storage.Â  Hash browns are really handy to have.Â  I just soak enough for a meal in water for about 20 minutes, drain and fry.I had ordered 6 bags of frozen corn to dehydrate.Â  What I got was 6 cans of corn.Â  Sigh.Â  The corn is still food and the cans will go on the shelf.Â  The corn to dehydrate will be ordered for the next devery.Â Â Frozen veggies are my favorite for dehydrating.Â  They have already been blanched for freezing, so all I need to do is spread them out on dehydrator trays and dry them.Â  Many vegetables do not rehydrate well enough to use as a side dish.Â  I mostly add them to soups I make in the crockpot where they do rehydrate over time or I turn them into powders to add as flavor to many dishes.Corn, however rehydrates wellÂ  But mostly I grind it up in my mini food processor and add it to my cornbread recipe.Â  Adding the corn gives cornbread a wonderful corn flavor.And now I am off to my kitchen where I wil cry for a time.Â  No, I am not sad.Â  But I do have onions to peel and chop for drying.A question before I go.Â  Has anyone ever dehydrated meat?Â  I have seen videos on the subject, but still am not sure about trying it.Â  I am thinking mostly chicken or hamburger, as I use those two more often.Â  If anyone has any thoughts on this, please share.Please, my friends, do not slack off on your preparations.Â  The current administration will gladly provide illegales with cell phones, housing, food stamps, medical care and anything else they need.Â  However, you - American citizen - are on your own.Â  Do whatever you can to make it through hard times.And by all means - pray!

title: What Happened...
text: There was a time when I could walk the street in front of my building, day or night, without fear.Â  Not any more.There was a time when there was no question about which locker room or bathroom to use.Â  Not any more.There was a time when children could go to 'story hour' at the public library without encountering men dressed as grotesque women.Â  Not any more.There was a time when sex education did not include elementary school children.Â  Not any more.There was a time when the language I hear coming from some kids would have earned them the experience of learning what a bar of soap tastes like.Â  Not any more.What happened?Â  How did we reach the place where the question of the day is, "What is a woman?"Â  News flash - just take a peek inside your knickers.Â  Indoor pumbing belongs to women.Â  Outdoor plumbing indicates a man.Â  Easy peasy.I am so very tired of all the foolishness.Â  Common sense seems to have left the building.Â  At what point did so many Americans buy into the culture of 'woke.'Seems to me we need to pay attention to the ways of our parents and grandparents.Â  They didn't waste time on silly things like defining a woman.Â  In my family they were too busy tending the crops, milking the cows, working in the lumber mills or, in the case of my Dad, holding down two and sometimes three jobs to feed his family and care for his invalid wife.It is my opinion that the downward spiral mostly began when our government decided that God has no place in our schools or our office buildings or in our lives.Â  The war against religion has escelated.I am thinking that as we watch our nation sink deeper into the mud and mire, perhaps now might be a good time for prayer before that is banned as well.

title: Potato Experiment
text: A number of years ago, my oldest son would go to the large Farmer's Market in St. Paul, Minnesota.Â  He would bring me all sorts of fresh produce for canning or dehydrating or freezing.Â  One time he showed up with 100 lbs. of russet potatoes.Â  And because at that time I wasn't all that familiar with the process of dehydrating potatoes, I canned most of them.What I later discovered was that the top inch or so of the potatoes in the jars turned gray.Â  They weren't rotten.Â  They were just gray.I'm pretty sure that nobody is fond of eating gray potatoes.Â  I know that the persnickety members of my family would surely go "EEEWW" at the sight of them.Â  They haven't as yet been truly hungry.Sometimes I am tempted to relate what I saw on a program about a high school class visiting a German concentration camp.Â  At that time, a number of years ago, the camp had lush, green lawns.Â  A student asked the guide, who had been imprisoned at that camp, who mowed the lawn when he was there.Â  His reply was, "Nobody mowed lawns.Â  If we saw a blade of grass, we ate it."Back to the potatoes.Â  I decided to try dehydrating some of the potatoes, thus eliminating the gray pieces.Â  So I opened several jars, drained and rinsed the pieces, spread them out on dehydrator trays, picking out the gray pieces and tossing them.During the dehydrating process, the potato pieces took on a dark brown color that didn't go away when rehydrated.Â  And the potato pieces did not rehydrate well enough to be useful.Â  This experiment was a total failure.So what will I do with the 75 lbs. of potatoes I still have in jars?Â  Use them.Â  Just like I have been using them.Â  I pick out the gray pieces.Â  Then I fry them up for a breakfast potato.Â  Or use them in a potato salad.Â  Or heat them and pour gravy over them.Â  Or make mashed potatoes from them.These days it seems prudent to use up what we have, even if we might want something else.Â  Grocery prices, in my area anyway, continue to rise.Â  I can not afford to waste food.Â  Or anything else, for that matter.Â I don't see things getting better any time soon.Â  Perhaps now would be a good time to concentrate on the old ways of doing things.Â  At least that way, we will be able to continue on while others are wondering what happened.

title: My Son Was Right
text: He told me that if I didn't have a place to rant, my head would explode.Â  And I have to admit that the explosion is getting close.This morning I watched a video by our bumbler and chief.Â  He again wants to take our guns.Â  And if he can't get his hands on them, he wants us to keep our guns under lock and key.Â  Now I can understand that perhaps households with small children might want to keep their guns out of reach.Â Â Just for the record, my four children were raised around firearms.Â  They were taught about safety and respect for the tools, for that is what they are.Â  That tool brought home venison to feed them.Â  Â That tool chased off someone who might have done them harm.Â  They, unlike many today, were raised to have respect for their parents and for the rules.Picture a 77 year old woman who lives alone in an apartment located in the downtown area of a rather large suburb.Â  When I first moved here about 25 years ago, I knew the neighbors.Â  Even though I am surrounded by bars, I had no fear of walking my dogs after dark.Â  I worked in the neighborhood and had no fear of walking a few blocks home after 10 PM.That has changed.Â  I wouldn't consider going out after dark now.Â  The neighborhood has changed in that there seem to be more people who are angry most of the time compared to the friendly neighbors of years past.Â  My building is over 100 years old.Â  The cheapest of doors were used when the upper floor was converted to apartments.Â  A good swift kick could open my door.I don't move fast at all any more.Â  The pace of a herd of turtles is an apt description!Â  So someone kicks in my door.Â  What am I supposed to do.Â  Ask the intruder politely to please wait to hurt or kill me while I go unlock my gun safe?Â  Or without any protection, perhaps if I throw a can of tomatoes at him, that might just keep me alive.Â  (snark)I want to peacefully live out my remaining years.Â  And that includes avoiding any violence.Â  We all know that violence is becoming more prevalant in our society.Â  I pray the time never comes when I need to protect myself from the bad guys.Â  Who have guns.Â  Who will never give up their guns.And because our government is only going after the good guys with guns, mine will stay within reach.Â  And will not be locked up.Â  And will not be turned in no matter what fraudulant laws the state or federal boneheads come up with.Â  After all, the Second Amendment is there to protect the citizens from a tyranical government.Looks like we may need them sooner than later.

title: The End
text: It has been a good run.Â  Nearly 14 years of posting here.Â  I have written about everything I know concerning preparedness.Â  I have ranted about our useless politicians and other crimes against humanity.Â  I have shared the death of my son and the births of my great grandchildren.Â  But now I am tired.After careful consideration and soul searching, I have made the decision to bow out of this arena.I am truly grateful to all of you who have stuck with me for so long.Â  I have learned much through your comments.Â  I have enjoyed our conversations.Everything in our country seems to be swirling down the drain.Â  I can no longer keep up.Â  Perhaps I don't want to keep up any more.Â  I will be 77 years old soon.Â  Before I join my son at the throne of our God, there are things I really want to do for my family.Â  I am working on my extensive family tree.Â  It is important that my children and grands know where they came from.Â  I have a large box of photos that needs to be labeled and put into albums.Â  There are more quilts to sew and afghans to crochet.Â  I am never bored and I am always busy.If anyone wants to stay in touch, I welcome the opportunity.Â  My email is vickimiller63@gmail.com.Â  I check it daily as I already am in touch with friends made here.Â  If you so desire - feel free.I have no words to express just how much I have come to thinking of all of you as friends.Â  Stay safe.Â  Stay prepared.Â  And above all, continue to pray.

title: Down Time
text: I have decided to take some time off from blogging.Â  There are several things that need my attention before Spring finally arrives.Â  With any kind of luck, I should be back in several weeks.Â  Stay safe and pray.

title: It can happen to you...
text: There are so many who are under the assumption that bad things can happen, but if they do, it will not be in their backyard.Â  If that's where you are, chances are pretty good you do not join the rest of us here in our way of thinking and preparing.Â  But if by some chance you stumbled upon this blog, I highly recommend the following video.ðŸš¨ He WARNS it's Gonna Get Bad SOON! ðŸš¨ - YouTubePatara at 'Appalachia's Homestead' is a common sense video creator, unlike many who run around, hair on fire with each and every bad thing that happens.Â  I trust what she says.I have had a small break to refresh and recharge.Â  My adult children have agreed to haul some food in jars to their homes.Â  So today I am up to my elbows in canning hamburger.Â  My son kindly brought me 40 lbs. of it yesterday.Â Buckle up.Â  Looks like the road ahead is full of potholes.Pray.

title: Reaching the Rafters
text: Everywhere we look, we see those with the preparedness mindset talking about 'stacking it to the rafters.'Â  I have often said that myself.Â  And I have meant it, for I believe things in our country are likely to be worse before getting any better.Â  If we are paying attention at all, we can see the signs all around us.But what happens when our food and supply storage reaches the rafters?I am guessing that there are many - particularly those of my vintage - living in small apartments.Â  Not everyone can have a homestead.Â  Not all of us are physically able to keep a garden.Â  Those of us living on a fixed income can not afford to pay for the maintenance and taxes on a house, upkeep and fuel for a vehicle and buy groceries, too.Â Â I have spoken before about living in a very small three-room apartment.Â  I live here for several reasons.Â  I can afford it.Â  It is close to my children and grands and great-grands.Â  That is important to me.Â  And I need to be where I can get the care I need for a couple of medical conditions.I have now reached the place where I literally have no more room to store anything.Â  Several shelving units are full.Â  Cases of home canned food are stashed in every conceivable corner.Â  Boxes holding dehydrated foods and other dry goods are stacked as high as I can stack them.Â  I am now in serious jeopardy of looking like a candidate for the TV show about hoarders.I am done.Â  Well, almost.Â  My son is bringing me 40 lbs. of hamburger to can.Â  And I still have stuff in my freezer that needs to go into jars before freezer burn sets in.Â  But after that I will just be replacing what I use and that is all.My adult children have agreed to take home with them some cases of food in jars and God bless them for that.Â  After all, this has been done for the sole purpose of making sure my family will be alright should the worst happen.Â  And I might have convinced them that it will be easier to remove stuff from my apartment a little at a time rather than all at once when I leave this earth to join my oldest son in Heaven.Â  That being said, I plan to stick around for a good, long while to annoy my kids.Â  :)Â Â I am not saying that stacking it is not important.Â  It is very important.Â  But sometimes we need to decide to either continue stacking or move on to other things.Â  Right now, I am going through and getting rid of things that just are not necessary in order to make my apartment a home again and not just a storehouse..Â  And using time to make quilts or crochet afghans or to work on my family history so my kids and grands will know about the good, hard-working ancestors that came before us.Â We all have different priorities.Â  We do what works best for us.Â  I am just saying that we need to decide for ourselves where we are headed and what each of us needs to do.My one constant is prayer.Â  Always.

title: Still Busy
text: Slowing down is not an option.Has anyone seen what the geniuses in the WEF (World Economic Forum) have decided?Â  Klaus Schwab, Bill Gates, Al Gore, et al, have decided that our food needs to be rationed and we no longer need to eat meat.Â  Because, of course, climate change.Bastards!So if you will excuse me, I need to put away the 20 pints of pork loin and 10 pints of sweet potatoes that I canned a couple of days ago.Â  And slice 10 lbs. of potatoes to dehydrate.Â  And work on my next grocery order that will, I believe, contain lots of hamburger to can and freeze, and whatever else I can find to add to my food storage.Think those who believe they are better than me are going to tell me what I can feed my family?Â  Nope.Â  Not hardly!

title: Busy Again
text: I am guessing that many of you know about that little voice in the back of our heads that tends to shove us in the direction we need to go.Â  That's the same one that lets us know when danger is near.Â  Some call it a gut feeling.Â  Whatever it is called, we do well to listen.I have this nagging feeling that things are about to go head over heels off the cliff.Â  I don't know if it is the big balloons in the sky or the chemical spills from derailed trains or the many food processing plants going up in flames or the possibility of the Chinese marching over the hill.Â  Whatever it is, now is not the time to slack off.I am storing more water.Â  My grocery order for Thursday includes 6 of the half pork loins that are on sale.Â  And 10 lbs. of russet potatoes and 5 lbs. of sweet potatoes.Â  The pork and sweet potatoes will be pressure canned.Â  The russet potatoes will be sliced and dehydrated.The top of my kitchen table is covered with quart bags of frozen strawberries.Â  Tomorrow morning I will add a little sugar and can them for use as ice cream topping or in baking or just to eat as sauce.Â  And after that I will can up whatever is below the berries.Â  We here in Minnesota have a forecast of up to 20 inches of snow in the next few days.Â  Snowstorms sometimes take out our power.Â  I also ordered a bunch of extra kitchen matches to have on hand for lighting candles and a propane camp stove (really don't want to do without my coffee) and a propane heater.I am not saying that we will go to war tomorrow.Â  I am saying that anything is possible.Â  We are now living in a country whose leader thinks it is more important to visit Ukraine than Ohio.Â  Which shows me that the powers that be do not give a rodent's behind about our citizens.We are on our own.Â  Keep stacking.Â  The reason I do this is so that when push does come to shove, those I love will be taken care of as best I can.Pray.Â  Often.

title: What's Next?
text: It doesn't seem to matter where we look. There is chaos and confusion everywhere.Â Â The latest insanity is the speculation about the objects in our skies that are being shot down.Â  Are they weather balloons?Â  Are they spy capsules?Â  Or are little green men from Mars going to parachute down and demand to see our leader?Â  If it is the latter, I do believe they will be sorely disappointed.The headlines are full of other events that promise to destroy us all.Guess what.Â  I simply no longer care.Those in charge who think they are so smart - let them deal with it all.Â  Most of the problems originated with them anyway, to distract us from whatever criminal, stupid or mean thing they are trying to hide.Â  They are going to do exactly what they want to do, including lying, stealing and cheating.Â  And we know that no matter how much the congress critters fuss and fume and pontificate, nothing will change.I will still glance at the headlines so I know when to duck and cover.Â  And I will continue to fill my pantry to feed and take care of my family should the worst happen.Â  But no longer will I wade through the layer of bull crap they are spreading.Â  I have better things to do.I have adult children and grandchildren and great grandchildren that I love more than my life.Â  I have close friends that I love as well.Â  They deserve my time and attention way more than do some lying critters in DC who wouldn't recognize the truth if it bit them on the bum.So yesterday I sorted out some of my fabric stash, looking for and finding enough fabric suitable for the backs of a couple of quilts.Â  And I found enough leftover yarn for another crocheted afghan.Â  Tomorrow I plan to bake bread and chocolate chip cookies.Â Â It is raining here today.Â  Raining hard.Â  The snow that fell earlier this year is gone.Â  We are having 40 degree days.Â  Normally we are up to our elbows in snow and shivering in sub zero temps.Â  I am enjoying this while I can.Â  This is Minnesota, after all, and we can expect at least one more snowstorm before the lilacs bloom in the spring.And all of the above makes more sense to me than laying awake at night, worrying about how our government is going to screw us next.We have lives.Â  It is time to live them the way we want and with the blessing of God.

title: Paying Attention Yet?
text: Have you noticed just how much bad stuff is going on all around us these days?Doesn't matter in which direction we look, there is something on the horizon that can hurt us - we the people.Â  And our elected officials are doing nothing to stop the madness.I want things to get back to a normal that we can live with.Â  It is those who are in control who do not give a rodent's behind what I think.Â  They continue to do what they can do to enrich their bank accounts and ignore the fact that many can no longer afford to take care of their families.Â So what do we do?I am not in a position where I can bug out to some secret location deep in the northern Minnesota woods and 'live off the land.'Â  No matter what happens, I will be right here in my little apartment, as will many of us be in our homes.Â Â Even so, it is possible for me to do everything I can to prepare for whatever happens next.Â  My every-other-week grocery order arrives tomorrow.Â  The weekend will be spent dehydrating frozen corn, mixed vegetables and hash browns plus 10 lbs. of onions.Â  Yes, they are expensive, but I am pretty sure that they will cost more next month.Â The room where I store most of my food and supplies has been organized, everything sorted and labeled, so I know at a glance what I have and what I yet need.Â  Because I was blessed with a mother who taught me to sew, I am working on sewing together quilt tops to make warm blankets that are necessary in my cold climate.Â  And I have collected recipes for making many of the food items I would normally buy, like cream soups, Bisquick, other soups using dehydrated vegetables and pasta, and seasonings, to replace some of the items I might need to buy.Â  Jennifer over at 'Prep School Daily' is a wealth of information on all things preparedness and is the source of much of my information.Â  Her blog is listed in my side bar.Â This isn't a brag session but is a suggestion or two to give others an idea of what we can do to get ready for whatever our 'betters' have in mind for us which is absolutely nothing good.Â  You know, I am sure, that everything that is happening now is all about control.Â  As those close to me know by now, I do not do well with some trying to control me.Â I think those things that can make life even tougher than it is are accelerating at breakneck speed.Â  The wide-open southern border, the flight of a Chinese data gathering balloon flying across the breadth of our nation, the out-of-control inflation, are but a few examples.Get ready.Â  Don't wait.Â  Do the very best you can to take care of your families, especially since it is likely that some of them think you are nuts for doing so.Â  We do not want even the nay sayers to starve.And pray.Â  All the time.Â  God is our only hope.

title: As you know...
text: if you have followed along here for a while, I am easily distracted.Â  Sort of like a dog when it spots a squirrel.Â  :)While digging through some boxes and baskets, I came across a partially finished granny square afghan that I had completely forgotten about.Â  How a person can forget about a green and purple afghan is beyond me, yet there it is!Â  And because the weather here has been bitterly cold, it occurred to me that an extra blanket might be a good idea.I have been working to finish the afghan to the exclusion of everything else.Â  Partly because I wanted another warm blanket and partly because I was feeling a bit of burn out concerning my food storage.Â  Sometimes, we just need a break.The afghan will be finished today, for all I have left to do is to crochet one row around the edge for a border.Â  After that, it is back to stacking food and supplies to the rafters, starting with several quart bags of strawberries in my freezer that need to go into jars before freezer burn finds them.So far I have not heard of empty grocery store shelves here in my neck of the woods.Â  But I am noticing that substitutions as far as brand names or types of some goods are becoming more frequent.Â  For instance, my grocery order last week included 4 rolls of parchment paper.Â  I got 2 rolls because that was all that was on the shelf.Â  I also ordered 4 large bags of shredded hash browns to dehydrate.Â  What I got was 4 bags of potato dices, marked 'hash browns' on the bag.Â  We preppers are nothing if not flexible, so the diced potatoes went into the dehydrator anyway.Â  I know I will find a use for them.Â Keep stacking it, my friends.Â  We are going to need every crumb.

title: Looking Back
text: I don't know where to turn any more.Â  If I agree with the propaganda of the left, I am just as bad as they are, but I will not be harassed or 'cancelled.'Â  And if I continue to believe in God and the Constitution, I am labeled every nasty name in existence.I have to wonder what happened.Â  How did we as a nation get to this point?Â  Are we so incredibly stupid that we no longer see bs for what it is?Â  Seems like it.I remember a time when my kids could go outside to play without needing adult supervision.Â  I remember having friends of all shapes, sizes and colors and nobody thought anything about it.Â  I remember a time when people could have conversations about political differences without the hate and discontent we see now.Â Â A generation or maybe two back in time, people were vastly more prepared to fend for themselves and handle hardship than current generations.Â  Not only did they have the skills to do things like build stuff and care for livestock or raise their own food, they did these things as a matter of course.During the Great Depression, money was tight for a farmer in northern Minnesota like my Grandfather.Â  But he would not even consider asking for help.Â  One of his daughters went to teaching school.Â  A couple of his sons went to work in logging camps.Â  My Dad and a brother hopped a freight train headed west.Â  They worked on grain thrashing crews.Â  They found jobs going behind the machines that dug potatoes and they picked potatoes off the ground and filled sacks.Â  They sent every penny they could home to help the family.Â  The rest of the kids stayed home and milked cows, fed hogs and cared for the chickens and the huge garden.Â  They all worked to take care of the family.Now folks just get in line to sign up for food stamps and welfare benefits.Â  And have meltdowns if they can't get exactly what they want.Most times I think we should be looking backward for inspiration instead of looking to see what we can get for free.Â  The day may come when all we have left is the knowledge gleaned from our ancestors.Â  Grandma and Grandpa survived because they knew stuff.Â  Because they relied on their own selves instead of relying on government individuals who couldn't find their own backsides with both hands and a flashlight.Â Â Nobody is coming to save you.Â  You could at some point have to depend on yourself and on the knowledge you have.Â  Never stop learning.Â  It could save your life.

title: Question...
text: Is anyone else but me noticing how often the F-bomb is being dropped?Â  Doesn't seem to matter where or under what circumstances.I am not a prude.Â  I know there have been times when provoked that I have been guilty of unleashing language more becoming to a drunken sailor than to a lady.Â  But it is not language in the heat of the moment that I am talking about.Many of my evenings are spent with computer videos and yarn and a crochet hook.Â  I watch many preparedness YouTube channels and sometimes other channels just for the etertainment value.Â  It is on the latter channels that I have noticed a serious uptick of ugly language.Â  It seems like folks have lost the ability to talk without dropping those bombs.Â Â Thing is, those words are no longer bombs.Â  They now seem to just be part of everyday conversation.Â  So I have to wonder if words that years back were not uttered in polite society are now just part of the program to bring the population down to the level of some crawling creature.Â  Like the insistance that men can be women if they wear a skirt.Â  Like the insistance that abortion is not really murder.Â  Like the insistance that white people have some sort of privilege and are automatically racist.Â  Like that.When we let all those things go by without question, we are agreeing that all of it is just dandy.Â  I do not think these ideas are dandy.Â  I think they are dangerous.Â  And to not acknowledge them is to agree with having our lives turned backwards and upside down.Nope.Â  Not gonna do it.Â  Not gonna agree.Â  Not gonna allow that kind of foolishness under my roof.Â  So there!Â  End of rant.Â  For now.

title: One Size Does Not Fit All
text: Over the years I have watched many preparedness videos.Â  Many of them have really good information.Â  But very few fit my lifestyle.Â  And I am pretty sure there are many of my vintage who are in the same boat with me.I would love to have a homestead and raise chickens and other meat animals and grow a big garden.Â  And I admire those who can sustain that kind of lifestyle.Â  But I am not one of those people.There are all sorts of videos about what one should pack into a bug out bag.Â  Good information for those who plan to cut and run when things get dicey.Â  But many of us can not even consider leaving our homes due to age or physical problems.I do what I do in order to make sure my family is fed should things get really bad.Â  I am able to defend myself should it come to that, but I can not move all of my stored food and supplies.Â  It does me no good at all to can, dehydrate or buy food and supplies if I can not use them as intended or if I leave them behind.I also pay no attention to those who tell me I must have 10 specific food items or that I can not survive unless I have the gear they are selling.Â  Some of those 10 items are often things I don't use.Â  And the idea of needing 'gear' is ridiculous for me as most times they are talking about things like night vision goggles or tools to build a shelter in the woods.Â  Don't need much in the way of gear here in my little apartment.Â The point to all of this is that each of us has specific needs.Â  What works for one person doesn't necessarily work for everyone.Â  In preparedness, one size doesn't fit all.Â  We need to take what we can use and let the rest go.Â Â Finding alternative ways to do what we need to do is helpful.Â  We can't garden or raise animals, so we visit Farmer's Markets in season and take advantage of grocery store sales.Â Â Keep stacking what we know will be used.Â  And most definitely keep on praying.

title: Looking Back
text: Most people, at the beginning of a new year, look forward to whatever it brings.Â  I find myself looking back.Some time ago, someone close to me had a look at the room in my apartment where much of my food storage is located.Â  Their reaction to the shelves and boxes full of food was to ask why.Â  Clearly they were under the assumption that nothing will ever change, that the stores will always be completely stocked and nothing bad will ever happen - at least not in their back yard.Generations younger than mine do not seem to realize that for us, being prepared is not just some trendy thing to do.Â  It is a lifestyle.Looking back, I remember the huge garden my Dad planted every year.Â  And how summer and fall we canned and froze as much food as possible to get our family through the long, cold Minnesota winters.Â  Dad didn't farm, but he did rent out our 9 acre field to the neighbor to grow corn or soy beans in exchange for beef.Â  That same neighbor milked cows, so we got our milk from him, and our eggs from another neighbor who raised chickens.My grandparents raised milk cows and hogs and chickens for meat to feed their family of nine children.Â  Dad told me about loading a wood burning stove onto a hay wagon, along with boxes of canning jars.Â  The family would go to the blueberry bogs of northern Minnesota, where they would camp.Â  The kids would pick blueberries and Grandma would fire up the stove and can blueberries until all the jars were full.Â In addition to canning vegetables from their huge garden, Grandma made butter from the cream separated from the milk, and traded the butter in town for flour and sugar.Â  They dug a root cellar in the side of a hill near the house for keeping potatoes, carrots, cabbage and rutabagas over winter.Â Â Families then did not depend on anyone to take care of them.Â  My Dad consdered it shameful to accept any kind of government help.Â  They did as much as was humanly possible to take care of their families.All of this was common to families older than my generation.Â  They were preppers but didn't know it.Â  Neither did I until I saw some websites about preparedness.Â  This is just what we did to feed or families.Even if we can no longer raise vegetables or meat animals, we can still be prepared.Â  If you think some government agency is going to bring you a ham sandwich and a bottle of water, you are sadly mistaken.Â  Nobody is coming to help.Â  We need to be as self sufficient as possible.Â  Look to the old ways.Â  Those people survived without all the gadgets.Most importantly, continue to pray.

title: There comes a time...
text: when perhaps it is a good idea to put everything on hold and spend time with loved ones or just doing other things.Â  That's where I am.Â  So I will be here resting, reading, sewing or whatever I decide to do until after the new year.Â Â Here in the Great White North, everything is frozen solid.Â  The temp this evening is minus 8 degrees.Â  Snow and wind are headed our way.Â Â We don't need to prepare for the end of the world.Â  Preparing for cold and snow and wind is just important.Â  While others are lining up in the grocery stores, stocking up on whatever they need to get through the storm, I will be sitting on my cozy apartment with a cup of hot chocolate, watching the storm from the comfort of my recliner.Â  Your neck of the woods may have different weather related difficulties, but being well prepared is the same no matter where we are.Stay safe.Â  Enjoy the holidays as much as possible.Â  Wishing each and every one of you a very Merry Christmas and a better New Year.

title: Just Checking In...
text: There hasn't been much activity here in the Great White North lately.Â  I haven't been canning or dehydrating, but am more concentrating on basics like rice and pasta and sugar.Â  My groceries are delivered Thursday afternoon and there will be things to repackage and put away.Â  I repackage in Ziploc bags anything that comes packaged in cardboard or thick paper, like sugar bags.Â  I haven't had a problem with bugs here, but past experience tells me bugs like paper or cardboard - plastic, not so much.I am nearly finished writing out the old family recipes and some of the stories associated with them, for my kids.Â  I still need to dive into my recipe box and find Mother's recipes for apple pie and peach pie.Â Â Each summer Mother would make at least a dozen apple pies using apples from our very small orchard.Â  Dad would bring home lugs of peaches from the grocery store and she would make about the same number of peach pies using part of the peaches and would can the rest.Â  She stored the raw pies in the freezer, stacking them one on top of the other, forming towers of pies.Â  We would bake them, one at a time, throughout the winter months.Â  When her hands became too crippled from arthritis to be able to continue this practice, she turned that task over to me.Â  To this day I love apple and peach pies.Â  Making them - not so much.Â  :)Â Here in Minnesota, for the last day or so, we have had rain, sleet, snow - rinse and repeat.Â  It is in times like these that I am more than happy I do not need to go outside.Â  That will be especially true come the weekend when temps here are supposed to drop to single digits.Â  Times like this I envy my friend in California who is picking oranges and grapefruit from the trees.Â  :)That's all I've got for now.Â  Stay safe and warm.

title: The Holidays for Old Folks
text: This time of year can be a bit stressful for those of us with large families and limited income.Â  We worry about Christmas gifts for our kids and grands, without wrecking our budgets.Â  Here is how I solve that problem.I have six grands, one grand-in-law and two great grands.Â  Because I don't know what gift would make each one happy, they get cash.Â  Teens in particular seem to like having extra spending money.Â  The little ones have something for the piggy bank that will eventually add up to a fair amount for them when they are older.Â  In order not to break the bank, I save a little here and a little there all year so I have enough set aside by December.One year everyone got jars of my hot chocolate mix along with bags of homemade caramel corn.Â  But this year because health issues prevent me from doing large projects, my kids are getting hand written recipe cards that contain recipies from their grandmothers and a couple of aunts, all of whom are no longer with us.Â  There are stories connected to some of the recipies and I am including those, too.Whenever there was a family gathering, my mother would make a cold shrimp salad.Â  At one of those gatherings I was fixing a plate for her and I asked if she wanted some shrimp salad.Â  She wrinkled her nose and said "Absolutely not.Â  I can't stand the stuff."Â  When I asked why she made it, she replied that it looked pretty in the bowl!Â  And that was Mother.Â  She loved 'pretty.'Included is Dad's recipe for peanut brittle that he made every Christmas season.Â  His children called it "Dad's World Famous Peanut Brittle."Â  He almost always cooked it a bit too long so it had a slightly scortched taste, which distinguished it from other peanut brittle.Â  And that is how we liked it.Mother's recipe for gingersnap cookies is there, too.Â  When growing up, my family lived in a big, old farmhouse with a large screened in porch.Â  We often had visits from relatives.Â  In the summer, Mother would serve her gingersnaps along with ice cold lemonade, all enjoyed on our front porch.There are all sorts of ways to enjoy the Christmas season without spending a fortune.Â  All we need is a little imagination and to remember the reason for the season.

title: Anyone besides me completely fed up?
text: Here's the thing...I don't care what was on Hunter's laptop.Â  Nor do I care what percentage of ill gotten gains went to the 'Big Guy.'Â  I have no interest in who dines with Trump.Â  Who is banned from Twitter and who is not is of no interest to me either.Every day one politician or another is bellowing about the wrongs being done by those in the opposing political party.Â  The next day those opposing are screaming a rebuttal to the accusations of the accusers.Nobody seriously tries to change anything.Â  They would rather get their faces on TV and their pockets lined by special interest groups.Â  There is not even one politician I would trust.Â  If they were honest people they would not be politicians.I will not be marching in the streets to protest anything.Â  ThatÂ  changes nothing and these days is more likely to get me run over or shot.Â  Write or call my congress critters?Â  Nope.Â  Whatever makes anyone think the politicians care what we the people think.I have come to a place where most of my alloted time on this earth has past.Â  There are not all that many days left.Â  I can think of no good reason to waste time worrying about what government types are doing.Â  They are going to do what they want no matter what I say.What it comes down to is that many of us just want to be left alone.Â  Not by friends and family, but by those in power who think it is just fine to tell us how we need to live when they have not a single clue about what it takes to live a normal, everyday life.Â I intend to live out my days spending time with kids and grands and great-grands.Â  My pantry is full enough to feed my family for a long time if necessary, but I will continue to add to it.Â  There are quilts to sew and afghans to crochet and genealogy research to be done.Â  Those things make me happy.Â  The government has not even once thought about my happiness or that of the rest of us.Â  So they can just scream and holler all they want.Â  I am not impressed.Â  Nor do I care any more.I am just done.Â  I refuse to comply with their silly edicts and mandates.Â  I refuse to bow and scrape.Â  I have only one Lord and Master and He doesn't live in DC!We know they will not leave us alone.Â  Continue to prepare.Â  Continue to pray.Â  And perhaps if enough of us just say "No," that might at least slow them down a bit.

title: Yeah.  I know...
text: I managed to disappear for a while.Â  I'm sorry.Â  No excuses - my bad.I have been adding to my stores.Â  My son did a Sam's club run for me.Â  I canned 10 lbs. of boneless chicken thighs and froze 10 lbs. of apples.Â  My grocery order arrives tomorrow and there should be some canned goods included for my food storage.Some of you are of retirement age.Â  I think whoever coined the phrase "Golden Years" must have been in their 20's and never had to deal with all the fun - and often painful - stuff that comes with old age.I mention this only because I completely understand the frustration that goes along some of the 'delights' of old age.Â  My arthritis flare-up doesn't seem to be going away this time.Â  I tell you this not to whine or feel sorry for myself, but to illustrate the fact that sometimes we need to adjust how we do things.I am pretty much done canning unless there is an emergency reason for doing so.Â  Lifting a heavy pressure canner isn't working for me.Â  But I have other options.Â  I can freeze or dehydrate most fresh foods.Â  And so far, the stores in my area don't have much for bare shelves, even if their prices have reached ridiculous heights.Â  So I am buying more canned goods.For some products that have outrageous prices, making my own is an option.Â  I like to have boxed scalloped potatoes on hand for an easy meal.Â  But not at the price they want now.Scalloped Potato MixSauce:Â  1/3 C. +Â  2 Tbsp. dry milk - 2 Tbsp. each flour and cornstarch -Â  1 Tbsp. crushed dry onions - 1/4 tsp. pepper.Â  This equals one batch.The dehydrated potatoes are thicker than the ones in store bought mixes, so cooking works better in a crock pot.3 C. dehydrated potato slices - 3 Tbsp. butter - 3 C. hot water - one batch sauce mix.I just let it cook on 'medium' all day and about an hour before supper I might toss in a cup of either diced ham or cooked and crumbled bacon.Â  With a vegetable or a salad, this makes an easy meal.Here's the thing.Â  Don't give up.Â  There are some who are in far worse shape than me and yet are able to carry on.Â  Nobody said life would be easy.Â  We just do what we can, which is more important than ever these days.Pray and prepare, my friends. Pray and prepare.

title: Busy Time of Year
text: This past week I made up a dozen batches of my dry soup mix, using vegetables that I had canned some years back and now have dehydrated them.Â  If someone wants to use dehydrated foods they already have in stock, here is the recipe.Soup Mix1/3 Cup each of dehydrated corn, green beans, carrots and diced potatoes3 bouillon cubesÂ  (may add more dry bouillon to taste)1 tsp. garlic powder and 2 tsp. dry parsley1/4 Cup dry onionsI added a couple of Tablespoons of dry, shredded cabbage just because I like it.This soup can be made in a crock pot.Â  Add 2 quarts of water - a little more depending on how much broth you like in your soup or if you add additional dry veggies.Â  I just let it simmer all day.Â  An hour before serving, I add a pint of canned meat - usualy beef or chicken.Â  The meat may be eliminitated if just a good veggie soup is desired.My grocery order arrives tomorrow.Â  My bill is outrageous for the amount of food I am getting.Â  I am incredibly thankful that I started stocking up years ago when prices were at a more reasonable rate.As a result of prices at the grocery store rising nearly to the completely unaffordable rates, I am going through the recipes I have collected over the years, looking for home made substitutes for some of the products I normally buy.Â  I have stocked ingredients.Â  I can make a variety of mixes to replace some of the convenience foods I have been using.Â I am not hurting financially - yet.Â  But I probably will be if I don't change the way I do some things.Â  I am also looking through my mother's recipe box.Â  She cooked before convenience foods or microwaves.Â  I really need to remember how she stretched meals.I doubt this inflation will end any time soon.Â  We can either pretend everything is alright or we can adjust the way we do things accordingly - in the real world.Â  Nobody - at least nobody connected with the government - is coming to save us.As always - pray and prepare.

title: Follow Up
text: Having received an email from our friend, CW, I want to let all the Prayer Warriors know what she said.CW has a cancerous tumor that will require about 6 months of treatment along with surgery.Â Â Cancer in any form is difficult at best.Â  I can hardly imagine what she must be going through with everything else she has on her plate.Â  I know her to be one who is strong in her faith and believes in the power of prayer as we do.We will not forget about her and I know that she is thankful for your concern and prayers.I am amazed and humbled by the response to the call for prayer for one of our own.Â  It renews my faith in the basic goodness of people.Â  Thank you from the bottom of my heart.

title: Prayer Warrior Alert For One Of Our Own
text: Over the years I have come to regard you who come here regularly as family.Â  One of our own is in need of prayer.I have been in touch with "CW from Iowa" via email for quite some time.Â  Her husband was diagnosed with terminal pancreatic cancer a while back.Â  His struggle is nearly over.Â Â Tomorrow CW goes for tests to determine to what stage her colon cancer has developed and what treatment she will need to undergo.These fine people have an adult son who is devoted to his parents and is doing everything he can to make life easier for them.Â  He, too, has a lot on his plate and could use prayers for strength and courage.I strongly believe in the power of prayer and I am asking those of you who are of a mind to do it, to pray for this family.Â  When CW's email arrived this afternoon, she asked if perhaps I could call upon our Prayer Warriors.Â  And I have no doubt that you will heed the call.Thank you.Vicki

title: Finally...
text: An experiment that actually works.While browsing through videos, I found one at "The Purposeful Pantry" about dehydrating canned vegetables.Â  Darcy, the lady who puts out so many helpful dehydrating videos, was using cans of vegetables from the grocery store.Â  As most of mine are home canned in jars, I thought I would try dehydrating some of them that have been on the shelf for quite some time.I dehydrated one pint each of corn, carrots, green beans and diced potatoes.Â  Then I tossed the dry veggies into the crock pot along with a handful of dry onions, 4 chicken bouillon cubes, a half teaspoon of garlic powder and 2 quarts of water.Â  About an hour before suppertime, I added a pint of shredded chicken and 1 tablespoon of beef bouillon, as I thought the broth could use just a bit more flavor.The result was a really good chicken veggie soup that went well with some cornbread.I have some home canned veggies that have been sitting on the shelf for several years.Â  I think I will dry them and store them with the bouillon, onions, garlic and maybe a handful of dry parsley to make a soup mix that needs only water and canned shredded meat to make an easy meal.It is really nice when a plan comes together.Â  :)

title: Summer Sausage Made With Hamburger
text: As has happened many times, arthritis has reared its ugly head in the form of a flare-up.Â  This is nothing to worry about.Â  It has been part of my life since age 15.Â  It will go away in a few days.Â  But until then the flare-up is a realy good excuse to baby myself and order pizza.I will be away for a few days.Â  Until I return, I leave you with this recipe for one of my favorite ways to use hamburger.Summer Sausage from Hamburger2 lbs. hamburger2 Tbsp. mustard seed1 Tbsp. garlic powder2 Tbsp. Liquid Smoke2 Tbsp. Morton Tender Quick1 tsp. black pepperMix together thoroughly.Â  Divide mixture in half and form two even rolls.Â  Wrap in aluminum foil and refrigerate for 24 hours.Â  Preheat oven to 325 degrees.Â  Poke holes in the bottom of each roll.Â  Place on a rack in the oven with a pan underneath to catch any grease.Â  Bake for 90 minutes.This is good sliced for sandwiches or used with crackers and cheese.Â  I generally make about 6 lbs. at a time, keeping a couple of rolls in the fridge and freezing the rest.Enjoy.

title: Changes
text: I am old.Â  I am not fond of change.Â  But this Recession we are in that seems headed toward a Depression has me rethinking my options.I like convenience foods.Â  And I have occasionally been buying premade mixes.Â  Not so much for the flavor and certainly not for the health aspects.Â  It is mostly because those of us who have joints that don't work very well any more tend to go for 'easy and quick' as opposed to time consuming 'from scratch' foods.Â  If I can microwave something instead of standing for a length of time stirring a pot on the stove, I will do it.Â  Or if I can just add water or milk to a mix instead of mixing from scratch, I will do that, too.Â  It hurts less.So this afternoon I have been putting together some of my favorite homemade mixes.Â  Not only do I know what is in each one, but I find it is much less expensive to make than to buy.Â Swiss Mocha Mix (from the YouTube Channel, "Little Village Homestead.")Â 1/2 C. instant coffeeÂ  -Â  2 Tbsp. cocoa powder1/2 C. sugar - or to tasteÂ  -Â  1/4 tsp. vanila1 C. powdered milkBlend well.Â  To use:Â  2 large Tbsp. in a mug of hot water.Hot Cocoa Mix (from the YouTube Channel "katzcradul")5 C. dry milkÂ  -Â  3 C. powdered sugar1 1/2 C. cocoa powderÂ  -Â  1 C. Creamorapinch saltMix well.Â  Add to hot water in a mug, to taste.Â  (Note:Â  This tastes less like Swiss Miss and more like the old fashioned cocoa Mom used to make.Â  It is also really good if one bottle of malt powder is added.)Gravy Mixes (from "Suttons Daze" YouTube Channel)Chicken or Beef Gravy3/4 C. flourÂ  -Â  1 tsp. pepper3 Tbsp. either beef or chicken bouillonCountry Gravy3/4 C. flourÂ  -Â  1/2 tsp. salt1 1/2 tsp. pepperÂ  -Â  1 tsp. onion powderTo use:Â  Melt 1 Tbsp. fat (butter, margarine, bacon grease, etc.)Â  Stir in 2 Tbsp. mix.Â  Whisk in 1 C. water.Â  Whisk until thick to make 1 C. gravy.Brownie MixÂ  ( Don't remember where I found this.)4 C. flourÂ  -Â  4 1/2 C. sugar1 C. cocoa powderÂ  -Â  1 1/2 C. dry milk powder1 1/2 Tbsp. baking powderÂ  -Â  1 1/2 tsp. saltSift together 3 times.To use:Â  Combine 1 3/4 C. mix, 1/4 C. warm water, 1/4 C. oil, 1 tsp. vanilla and 1 egg.Â  Beat well.Â  Pour into a greased 9-inch pan.Â  Bake 20 miutes or until done - 350 degrees.Â I expect to be adding more convenience type mixes this fall.Â  I highly doubt that prices are going to drop.Â  I can add to my food storage this way while saving a bit on the already outrageous grocery bill.We need to keep stacking to the rafters however we can.Â  And most important, keep praying.Â  We need all the non governmental help we can get.

title: Listen and Learn
text: My young nurse is a wealth of information.Â  All I need do is listen.She is a nice girl.Â  Does a good job.Â  But her way of thinking is far removed from mine.She came in one day last week, grousing about having to work the weekend.Â  Just for reference, there are some patients who need daily care.Â  The nursing staff takes turns on the weekend shift.She said she didn't think the human body was made to work so hard.She said that.Â  And was serious about it.The girl obviously has never followed a farmer around on one of his sunrise to past sunset working days.Â  Nor has she known anyone like my Dad who worked a 40 hour a week job climbing in and out of train boxcars, taking samples of grain for testing.Â  And then working his second job cleaning a church or anÂ  office building.Â  And working weekends taking care of two large barns of turkeys.Don't misunderstand.Â  I like the girl.Â  But I fail to understand that while the rest of us are working to stack food and water and supplies as high as we possibly can stack it all, are not spending our money frivolously and are paying attention to events around us, she is going on vacation twice in as many months and flew to Chicago on a weekend to party with friends.Priorities.Â Â Mine are to feed my family should it become necessary.Hers are to have as much fun as possible.I understand that the young often think they are 10 feet tall and bulletproof, but the reality is that there may come a time when she will be wondering where her next meal is coming from.Â Â I find that incredibly sad.Â Â And she is not alone.Â  There are a couple of generations of folks who believe nothing bad will ever happen and even if it does, it won't happen in their back yard.I sincerely pray that God will help them.Â  For I will not.

title: You All Are Amazing
text: "Prayer is not a gentle knock on the door.Â  It is a FERVENT EFFECTUAL POUNDING on the doors of Heaven."When I posted the request for prayer, I was a mother who feared losing another son.Â  Things have changed.My son had a scan of his heart that showed no damage and normal function.Â  He had a stent put in one blocked artery.Â  He has a few restrictions and diet changes.Â  He goes home to his family tomorrow.No one will ever convince me there is no power in prayer.I can not even begin to properly thank all of you for your kindness, your caring and your prayers.Â  But mostly I thank God for listening and answering.May that same God bless you all.

title: Prayer Warriors Alert
text: My friends, I am again reaching out to you with a request for prayer.A short time ago I got a phone call from my sweet daughter-in-law.Â  It seems that my youngest son had a heart attack this afternoon.Â  Fortunately he paid attention to his symptoms and went directly to the hospital.Â  He has had a stent put in.Â  His wife says he is awake and talking and is very tired.We will know more tomorrow after the doctors see him.Prayers for my son and his family would be greatly appreciated.Â  Thank you in advance.

title: Canning - Yes and No
text: While going through the shelves I use for my home canned jars of food, I found a few jars of fruit that I had canned as an experiment a couple of years ago.Â  I decided to open one jar of each to see how they held up.The first was a jar of those little oranges - mandarin oranges or as they are sometimes called, Clementines.Â  They had been canned in a light sugar water syrup.Â  They had turned a kind of brownish color.Â  That could be due to the fact that the shelving unit holding them is located in my living room and isn't in the dark.Â  The fruit had turned to mush.Â  Others may have successfully canned these, but as for me, I will use the mandarin oranges in a can from the grocery store.About the same time I saw where some were canning grapes, so I gave that a try.Â  This time I just covered the grapes with water.Â  They stayed fairly firm, but had nearly no taste at all.Â  I can think of no good reason to waste jars on tasteless fruit.I will still can some fruits, but these two are not among them.It is fun to experiment with canning new foods.Â  But at this time when grocery prices are headed skyward, I believe I will be sticking to what I know works.Â  For me, that is mostly meats, soups, stews and vegetables.After all, the point of this whole food storage thing is to make sure my family has food when things get really bad.Â  In my area, jars and lids are a hit or miss situation.Â  I will be spending time getting rid of the experiments that failed and filling those jars with what will fill the bellies of hungry family.As always, pray and prepare.

title: Things don't always...
text: go according to plan.Â  At least, not in my house.The fellow who usually does the shopping and delivery with the grocery service I use, had today off.Â  The one who did the shopping and delivering is a very nice guy.Â  But he has no clue about how I shop.The plan was to buy a turkey, a couple of chickens and vegetables in order to can quarts of chicken/turkey vegetable soup.Â  I got the chickens.Â  The turkey turned into a rather small frozen turkey breast.Â  Four pounds of carrots turned into two small bags of baby carrots.Â  My regular delivery guy knows that when I order cabbage, I want large heads.Â  The one I got was slightly bigger than a softball.Â So, the soup isn't going to work out.Â  But there is always a Plan B.The chickens and turkey breast are in the freezer and will be used for meals later on.Â  The veggies are all chopped and tomorrow morning they will be blanched and frozen.Â  It is all still food.Â  And it doesn't matter if I open a jar to use it or if I thaw out a package.Â  Food is food, no matter how it is preserved.Sometimes we have an idea of what we want to do and then Old Murphy shows up and tosses a monkey wrench into the works.Â  The trick is to be flexible.Â  If one thing doesn't work, we just try something else.But I kind of wish Murphy would find somewhere else to hang out.Â  :)

title: Call It Whatever You Want
text: Gut instinct.....That little voice in the back of your head.....God leading us.Â  Whatever name we put to it, most of us have experienced the feeling that we need to do something in particular - or to not do it.Â  I have learned over the years to listen.Â  When I don't, chances are pretty good I will find myself knee deep in yucky doo.So this week, plans have changed.Â  I had thought I didn't need to do any food preservation just now.Â  I scrubbed out my pressure canner and put it away.Â  And I washed all the dehydrater trays and the plastic liners.Â  They are neatly stacked out of the way.So when I went to figure out my next grocery order, that little voice in the back of my head was yelling at me.Â  Chickens and turkeys are being killed off and destroyed by the hundreds of thousands.Â  Probably reached millions by now.Â  Better order some while you can.Â  So I did.If they are in stock, I ordered two whole chickens and a turkey.Â  Along with that I ordered cabbage, carrots, onions, celery and frozen peas.Â  I have a couple of cases of quart jars left.Â  Groceries are delivered Thursday.Â  Over the weekend I hope to can quarts of chicken/turkey soup.Â  This soup has many uses.Â  It can be heated up as soup.Â  Rice or pasta can be added to stretch it to feed more people.Â  It can be made into stew to serve over biscuits.Â  It can be thickened for use in pot pies.Â  There are possibilities limited only by imagination.I seem to be more aware of using every bit of food lately.Â  The "waste not - want not" of my parent's teachings comes back to memory.Â  So any leftover meat will be canned in smaller jars.Â  Any leftover vegetables will be dehydrated.I am not telling you that you have to rush out and buy poultry.Â  That's not the point.Â  The point is to listen to whatever small voice speaks to you.Â  Bad things are coming, even though many are convinced bad things can never happen - especially not in their back yards.Â  Whatever you need to do to be as ready as possible, do it.Â  And pray.Â  That's the most important thing.Â  Pray.

title: Paying Attention
text: When I talk with people who are not in the preparedness community, I quickly learn why we are in such a mess.Fairly new nurse.Â  Young.Â  Cute.Â  Does a very good job with her duties here.I thought today I would see if she was aware of a potential railroad workers strike.Â  Might happen.Â  Might not.Â  But if the strike happens, the repercussions could affect us all.Â  So I asked her if she paid any attention to the news reports.Â  Her answer was no, she didn't because she was way too busy dealing with her personal life.I believe this is a response that is way too common.Â  Granted, we all have personal issues to deal with.Â  The difference is that we are still able to see beyond the personal and see what is going on in the world around us.Â  And prepare accordingly.I wonder of those who think the world revolves around them are going to be able to handle it when they find out it doesn't.Pray and prepare.Â  Now more than ever.

title: New Normal...
text: I really dislike the term 'New Normal.'Â  I rather liked the old normal.Â  The following showed up in my email.Â  Thanks, Deb.Â I am sharing this with you as for the next couple of days I will be busy canning up as much as possible from my freezer.Â  So far here in Minnesota, we have heard no threats of blackouts as are happening elsewhere.Â  But I am willling to take no chances with losing what I have.Â  Prices are way too high to replace it all.Â  So here you go.Â  I shall return in a few days.Â  Â  Â  Â I Used To Be A Pretty Normal Person .......I used to think I was pretty much just a regular person, but I was born white, into a two-parent household which now, whether I like it or not, makes me privileged, a racist, and responsible for slavery.I am a fiscal and moral conservative, which by today's standards, makes me a fascist because I plan, budget, and support myself.I went to Grammar School and have always held a job. But I now find out that I am not here because I earned it, but because I was "advantaged".I am heterosexual, which according to gay folks, now makes me a homophobe.I am not a Muslim, which now labels me as an infidel.I am older than 70, making me a useless eater who doesn't understand Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, or Snapchat.I think, and I reason, and I doubt most of what the 'mainstream' media tells me, which makes me a Right-wing conspiracy nut.I am proud of my heritage and our inclusive culture, making me a xenophobe.I believe in hard work, fair play, and fair reward according to each individual's merits, which today makes me an anti-socialist.I believe our system guarantees freedom of effort - not freedom of outcome or subsidies which must make me a borderline sociopath.I believe in the defense and protection of my nation for and by all citizens, now making me a militant.I am proud of our flag, what it stands for, and the many who died to let it fly, so I stand during our National Anthem - so I must be a racist.Please help me come to terms with the new me because I'm just not sure who I am anymore!Funny - it all took place over the last 7 or 8 years!If all this nonsense wasn't enough to deal with, now I don't even know which toilet to use... and these days I gotta go more frequently!

title: Taking  a Break...
text: to let my sewing machine cool down.Â  Just kidding, but it has been in nearly constant use for a few days.Â  Each of my six grands has a 'Grandma Made' rag type quilt, as does the first great grand.Â  So it is only fitting that the second great grand has one too.Â  It should be finished in a day or so.Â  There are also several quilt tops that need to be finished and turned into usable, warm quilts.Â  I hear the winter promises to be long and cold.I have also taken a break from canning and dehydrating, mainly because I simply have no space left in my little apartment to stack any more food in jars without being in danger of tripping over them.Â  However, I am still stacking foods like rice and oatmeal and pasta.Â  And I am filling in gaps in my medicine chest.I suppose I could go on another rant, but there are so many things happening right now that it might be hard to pick one.Â  I think I will just keep an eye on what is happening and continue to get ready for when the insanity comes to my town.Â  As far as I can tell, there is no stopping the left from working overtime to tear our country apart.Â  I can't stop them.Â  But I can do my best to be ready for them.Until then, I will enjoy the sunny fall day, continue to sew like crazy and pray while doing so.Pray and prepare, my friends.Â  Pray and prepare.PS...I just took the time to watch 'Appalacian Homestead with Patara.'Â  In this video, she says what the rest of us are thinking.Â  It is well worth your time.Farmers! Veterans! Elderly! Abused! Used! Displaced! - YouTube

title: Coming Up For Air
text: Contrary to popular belief, I haven't fallen off the edge of the earth.Â  I have just been busy.Ten lbs. of onions have been dried.Â  My son stopped at a small Farmer's Market on the other side of town and brought me a few carrots, cucumbers and tomatoes.Â  I sliced the cukes, sprinkled them with coarse salt and dehydrated them.Â  I had done this once before and liked the flavor of them as a snack.I still have the carrots and plan to shred them to use in making a few loaves of carrot bread.Â  Haven't decided to use the recipe that calls for raisins or the one that has crushed pineapple.Â  I am leaning toward the one with pineapple.The tomatoes were a delight.Â  It has been a long time since I had home grown tomatoes.Â  They reminded me of a time as a young girl when Dad and I would grab a salt shaker from the kitchen and head for the tomato patch in the garden to eat our fill of fresh tomatoes.Â  One of the simple pleasures in life is a tomato sandwich for lunch.My groceries will be delivered tomorrow.Â  So far I have received everything I have ordered, but not always the brand ordered.Â  The choices are becoming limited as far as brands go.Â  I am having to cut back on the size of my orders due to skyrocketing prices.Â  Frozen chicken breast has gone from a little over $3 per pound to over $5 per pound.Â  My delivery guy tells me about a few bare shelves that once held items I don't buy.Â  I am grateful to have shelves full of home canned meat that was put up well before inflation hit us so hard.I believe those who have ignored what is happening around us are going to have a much tougher time as the food shortages increase and prices continue to climb.Â  Especially those like me who can no longer plant a garden or raise meat animals.Â  If they are just now realizing what we have known all along, they are nearly out of time and it will be way more expensive to buy the food they need.Â Â I am off to work on finishing a quilt for my new Great Grand.Â  I want to get as much done on that as possible before my groceries arrive.Â  The order includes a boneless ham to dice and can in half pint jars for adding to dishes like scalloped potatoes or to use as sandwich meat, and potatoes and celery to dehydrate.It would be so easy to say "I told you so" to those who haven't prepared, but as tempting as that might be, I think they could use prayer more than ridicule.Â  Continue to prepare.Â  Continue to pray.Â  Keep on stacking.

title: Get It Done
text: Does anyone else feel the need to get things done before our world falls apart?Â I am not in panic mode just yet.Â  But I feel as though if I don't do what needs to be done, it could very well be too late.Â Â I have onions in the dehydrator to be followed with dehydrating cooked rice to make instant rice.Â Â The pieces for my great grandson's quilt are cut out and pinned together, ready to sew.I have acquired enough canning jars to clean out my freezer and can as much as possible before freezer burn sets in and before storms cut off our electricity as they sometimes do.Â  We have thunderstorms summer and fall and blizzards in the winter, both of which have been known to knock out the power.Â  Thankfully, tornado season is nearly over without much damage.I try to keep up here but I can make no promises.Â  Those in the side bar are better at posting regularlyÂ  than I am.Â  Sorry.Â  That is just the way it is.Â  When a person moves at the speed of a turtle, it takes time to do what needs doing.Keep stacking it high and work on those chores you have been putting off.Â  I really do hope I am wrong and soon we will be frolicking through fields of daisies.Â  But I have my doubts.Â  So I work as hard as I can.Keep preparing.Â  Keep praying.Â  We need all the help we can get.

title: Busy
text: Today was a busy day.Â  My groceries were delivered this afternoon.Â  Part of the order was frozen vegetables.Â  Carrots and corn are in the dehydrators.Â  Tomorrow green beans and mixed vegetables will follow.Â  After that there are 10 lbs. of onions to dry.9 lbs. of chicken breast are thawing to be canned tomorrow.Â  9 lbs. of hamburger will follow.I was able to get 2 cases of pint jars this time.Â  A year ago the jars would have cost me under $10 per case.Â  Today I paid $18 per case.A year ago my entire order would have been under $150.Â  My bill today was $352.Looks like I am going to have to cut back on my food orders if I want to pay my rent.And that is precisely what those in DC - the ones who don't give a rodent's behind about the people who put them there and who pay their salaries - want.Well, guess what.Â  I will not slow down.Â  I will not give in or give up.Â  I will find ways to keep preparing anyway.Â  We didn't get to be this old by being stupid.Brandon and Company - stick that in your pipe and smoke it.

title: Take time...
text: to stop and smell the roses or the coffee or whateverpleases you.Everywhere we look, we see warnings about what the 'elite' aredoing to gain complete control over the rest of us.Â  And theyseem to be doing just that.Â  High gas prices.Â  Risinggrocery prices.Â  Shortages of products needed by farmers toprovide the rest of us with food.Â  Hoards of illegal alienswashing over our borders like a tidal wave.Â  The list isendless.Many of us who are preparing to keep our families fed duringwhatever disaster or plandemic happens next, are feeling like time isrunning out.Â  And we are wearing ourselves out doing everythingpossible to stay afloat.Â  This can lead to burnout or feelinglike our efforts are not enough to make a difference.Â  And hereis where taking time for rose and coffee sniffing comes in.We need to take time to enjoy whatever makes us happy.Â  In mycase, a morning spent with a daughter, a granddaughter and a coupleof great grands provided me with enough 'happy' to last a while.My grocery delivery thiscoming Thursday includes chicken breast and hamburger to be frozenuntil I can find enough jars to can it.  And a variety of frozenvegetables to dehydrate.  But until then, I am thoroughly enjoyingmyself with sewing a quilt for the young gentleman with all that darkhair.  :)We have enough bad stuffgoing on. And we will keep on doing our best for our families.Â  But now and then, we need to take time to enjoy whatever makes ushappy.Â  Sometimes we get so wrapped up in preparing that we forget we still have lives to live.Those who keep trying to make us miserable are going to hate the fact that even after they do their dirty deeds, we are still happy in our faith, our families and with life in general.Go sniff a rose.

title: Let the Stacking Continue
text: Everywhere I look - particularly on the preparedness and homesteading YouTube channels - the main theme is to continue stacking food and supplies to the rafters.Â  I don't pay too much attention to the ones who spend time trying to sell me freeze dried food or to the ones peddling the gear they say I can not live without.Â  I have no notion of being the next Rambo.Â  Nor do I have the funds to buy over priced food.So what I do is figure out what I need to feed my family and what I need to take care of emergencies.Canning jars are still scarce, but the guy who delivers my groceries every two weeks has promised to bring me jars when available.Â  So before prices go much higher, I am buying frozen chicken breast, hamburger and ham to freeze now and can later.Â  A variety of frozen vegetables are on the list for dehydrating, along with onions, carrots and potatoes.Â  Each grocery order includes staples like sugar, flour, pasta, rice, oatmeal, tuna, Spam, and a variety of canned foods, depending on what is on sale that week.Contrary to popular belief, it is possible to build up a food storage pantry without completely wrecking the budget.Â  We are living in perilous times and it doesn't look like things will change any time soon.Â Â If you believe that nothing bad will ever happen and even if it does, it won't happen in your back yard, you are delusional.Â  And if you believe the government will help you in times of trouble, you are sadly mistaken.Â  Who do you suppose is responsible for the state of affairs in our country today.If you can, buy food.Â  History has shown that starvation has killed millions of people.Â  In case you have forgotten, here is a reminder."How Much is Enough?  The Seige of Leningrad."Keep prepping.Â  Keep praying.Â  We are on our own.

title: No You Are Not!
text: I have been busy.Â  What was once my bedroom is now a store room for my food storage and supplies.Â  And it was an unorganized mess.Â  And because it was an unorganized mess, I found I was ordering more of some items I needed and not enough of others.Â  And at the rate grocery prices are increasing, I just can not afford to spend needlessly.Due to physical limitations, it has taken me a considerable amount of time to set things to rights, but most everything is now in containers or on shelves, sorted and labeled.Â  I now know that I need to get another 25 lbs. of rice and that I have enough cans of tomatoes for now.I still need to do some organizing of the large shelves that hold my home canned foods.Â  I have three sets of shelves, each about 6 ft. high, 4 ft. wide and 2 ft. deep - six shelves on each unit.Â  Two units are in my store room and one unit is in my living room.Â  All are full of food in jars.Here is where the title of this post comes in.Many of you know that I have home health care nurses that come to my home three days a week to do what is necessary to keep my lower legs as healthy as possible.Â  At one time I was hospitalized for two weeks due to open sores and draining fluid on my lower legs.Â  Thanks to the nurses, that problem has not reoccurred.I usually have one nurse to deal with, but lately a second nurse arrives on Wednesdays, to give the regular one a break, I suppose. This past Wednesday a nurse arrived that I had never seen before.Â  When she finished her duties, she got up to leave.The store room door is close to the entry-exit door in my kitchen.Â  I keep the store room door shut so visitors, with the exception of family, can not see what I have in that room.Â  When I saw the nurse was reaching for the store room door, I told her she needed to use the other door.Â  But instead of stopping, she went ahead, opened the store room door, took a good look around and said, "Oh my!Â  You sure do have a lot of food in here.Â  If things get bad, I'm just going to come here."Â  To which I replied, "NO YOU ARE NOT!!"I am completely amazed at how many people, at least in my area, are completely clueless as to what is happening around them.Â  And the mindset that others will be happy to take care of them when they are too lazy to prepare for themselves, is astonishing.There was a time when I thought that I would help people other than my family, but that time has past.Â  The question has to be, which one of my grandchildren should I let go hungry in order to feed someone who couldn't be bothered to do for themselves. Not gonna happen.Prepare.Â  Pray.Â  If you are paying attention, you know it is getting worse every day.Â  And we are on our own.

title: Scammers
text: A couple of times each month I get a phone call from some sincere sounding guy who wants me to donate to a police/firefighter fund.Â  I usually just hang up on them.Â  But this time I let him get through his script that ends with him telling me I can donate whatever amount I want.Â So this time I asked if I could just donate to my local police.Â  He didn't seem to like that idea.Â  So I said that my uncle and my cousin were both officers on our local police force and it would be much more convenient for me to just write a check and give it to my uncle.Â  (He lied to me so I lied to him.)Â  The caller didn't like that idea either.I spent another few minutes coming up with ways to avoid sending him any money until he finally hung up on me.Â  Made my day!More serious information will follow in a day or two.Â  Right now I have broccoli in the dehydrator.Â  I have a couple of experiments I want to try involving dehydrating cooked pasta and rice.Â  So when that is done, I will be back with the results.Keep on prepping!
