title: Always Have a Plan - B
text: So here's the deal.Â  I talked with Youngest Son last evening.Â  He has been scouting around for a new pressure canner for me since a part on the lid of mine broke.Â  He has found none.Â  He says there are no canning jars or lids to be had, either.I could go online and order all the supplies.Â  Thing is, when you are on a fixed income, choices have to be made.Â  I am not destitute.Â  I can pay my rent and my bills, pay for groceries and meds, do what I need to do to live relatively comfortable.Â  But I have just so much cash set aside for extras.Â  And at this point, I have decided that the extra cash needs to be spent on food.Things are getting dicey out there, folks.Â  Weather destroyed a good bitÂ  of the corn crop in Iowa.Â  Many migrant farm workers are now being tested for the virus and when the tests come back positive as they all do, farms are being shut down.Â  China is in the middle of a food crisis which then has an effect on our food supply.Â  Ice Age Farmer has several good videos out about these things, but I have also seen other similar reports.Now maybe these reports are all just fearmongering hype.Â  But then again, maybe they aren't.Â  The question is, am I willing to listen to those who think I have taken a swan dive off the edge of sanity with my preparations, or do I pay attention to my gut instinct that tells me I had better kick it into high gear because time is running out.Bottom line.Â  I will not risk the welfare of my family by doing nothing.So onward with Plan-B.I like having home canned meat in jars because it is fully cooked and often it makes meal preparations easier for me due to my physical limitations.Â  But there is no reason I can not have the same product in my freezer.I have a FoodSaver.Â  Oldest Daughter is picking up several rolls of FoodSaver bags for me at Target this week.Â  The plan is to cook up the pork that is in my freezer along with what comes on my grocery order this week and what Youngest Son is picking up for me at Sam's Club next week.Â  All of that can be divided into meal sized portions, vacuum sealed and frozen.My grocery order this week includes lots of frozen vegetables that can be dehydrated.Â  There is a sale on fresh vegetables, so I am ordering cabbage, carrots, celery, bell peppers and onions.Â  I am not sure yet what I will do with those.Â  I am still able to water bath can, so I might can some relish or pickle some of the vegetables or some can be dehydrated.Â  It is all food to add to the stores.Â  It is all food that will sustain my family if things really do get bad.Flexibility is necessary in these uncertain times.Â  If Plan-A doesn't work, move on to Plan-B.Â  Or Plan-C or Plan-D.Â  Whatever it takes to do what we need to do.Maybe everything will work out.Â  Maybe the rioters will go back to their Mama's basements and play computer games again.Â  Maybe those governors and mayors who are drunk on power will back off from their virus mandates and defund the police initiatives and be sensible again.Â  Maybe life as we knew it will come back.Or maybe not.Pray and prepare, my friends.Â  Right now, that's all we've got.

title: Plans - Sigh
text: So the plan was to take some time off from blogging to do a serious amount of canning.Â  That was a great plan right up to the time a part on my pressure canner lid broke.Â  After checking on the cost of sending the lid in for repairs, I found that buying a new pressure canner would cost less.Â  So Youngest Son went on a quest for a new canner.Â  And guess what - apparently pressure canners are becoming as scarce as hen's teeth.Â  He has a couple more places to check and if none can be found in the stores, he says he will order one for me.Â  As luck would have it, I had not yet thawed the pork in the freezer that I planned to jar up.Pressure canners aren't the only items that seem to be in short supply.Â  Every two weeks I add canning lids to my grocery order.Â  I order six boxes of each size.Â  I am lucky if I get three boxes total.Â  And I ordered two cases of pint jars and got none.Â  Thankfully, one of my dear readers sent me a link to order jars and I may need to do that soon.Canning supplies are not all that I am finding in short supply.Â  As some of you know, due to health issues, I rely on a grocery delivery service, so I am not in stores to see the condition of the store shelves as far as shortages go.Â  But I am noticing that substitutions within my orders are increasing.Â  The service I use does not substitute items unless the particular item is not on the shelf at all.Â  Last week apparently at the store where the service shops, there were no bags of frozen chicken breast, no Dawn dishwashing liquid, no DelMonte sliced peaches and no store brand bowl cleaner in addition to no canning lids or pint jars.Â  Others that I am in touch with tell me the shortages they see in their areas are different, but are shortages nonetheless.Â  Methinks the time to seriously stock up is coming slowly to a close.This time away has not been a total loss.Â  I have been working on an inventory of my food storage.Â  It is much easier to consult a notebook when doing my grocery order than it is to dig around in my store room to see what I need.Â  Plus, there is a flaw in my character.Â  Or in my memory.Â  At any rate, I have been known to put something away for safe-keeping, only to lose it for all time.Â  Yep.Â  I do that.Â  So now, at the very least, I know what is in the buckets and I know what is stashed under the bed.I have dehydrated home canned tomatoes for turning into powder.Â  If canning jars continue to be hard to get, I may do more, just for the empty jars.Â Â I have been researching Do-It-Yourself projects to replace some of the items I may not be able to get, should the shortages get worse.Â  I have found instructions for several that I will tell you about as I give them a try.And I have been getting some sewing done, particularly a baby quilt for my soon to be born Great Grandbaby.Â  That job is just fun.Â  And Lord knows, we all could use a little fun in our lives to counter all the insanity around us.Â  I will post a picture when it is finished - probably next week.That's all I know today.Â  I pray all of you are well.Â  Take good care and continue to pray and prepare.

title: Taking Time Off
text: I am taking a couple of weeks off from blogging to concentrate on food preservation.Â  There is pork from a good grocery sale to thaw and can.Â  There are hashbrowns and tomatoes to dehydrate.Â  There is close to 100 lbs. of flour to repackage and store.Â  And that is just for starters.Â Â I have a quarter beef coming this fall from a local farmer, so the freezer needs to be cleaned out and anything that can be canned or dehydrated needs to be taken care of.Â  And my sons are planning another Sam's Club run.Â  And I have another grocery delivery in a week and a half.If you think for one little bitty minute that things are going to go back to what we considered normal, think again.Â  We are told we have to 'social distance' and wear masks, but the riots continue unabated.Â  No social distancing there.I read in the local news that shootings are a nightly occurrence in Minneapolis.Â  There was a time not all that long ago that as far as large cities go, Minneapolis was one of the more decent ones.Â  Now that the 'defund the police' movement has reared its ugly head and law enforcement is no longer allowed to do the job we pay them to do, anything goes and the criminals are deliriously happy with that.Â  Citizens - not so much.Between the riots and mayhem that Democratic leaders are allowing to happen and the fear being perpetuated by the left over a virus with a 99% recovery rate, the normal world we grew up in is fading fast.If you think the Dems will not use every dirty trick in the book and will make up a few more in order to gain power over us, you are delusional.Â Â Time is short.Â  If we are not now doing all we can to take care of our families, then shame on us.Â  That is why I am taking time to can and dehydrate and stock up on other supplies necessary to see my family through what is ahead.Â  I will be back when I am caught up on what needs doing.Churches have been closed but so far as I know, there is not a ban on prayer - yet.Â  Pray and prepare like never before.

title: Experiment Fail - Sort Of
text: Whenever I experiment with my food storage and the experiment works, I am quick to pass the information on to you.So when an experiment doesn't work so well, the only fair thing to do is to let you know what happened.I had this grand idea.Â  I often have grand ideas.Â  Some work.Â  Others don't.Â  This one sort of worked but not really.Â  I will explain.I have one shelf full of mostly home canned tomatoes and some cans of commercially canned tomatoes.Â  I also have a box full of bags of dehydrated tomatoes.Â  Toss into the mix several recipes for using tomato powder.The grand idea was to use dehydrated tomato powder to make often used tomato products, thus saving shelf space.Â  If the experiment worked, a good deal of the canned tomatoes could be dehydrated and the shelf space used for those cases of food sitting on the floor for want of space to put them.So I spent an afternoon running dried tomatoes through my handy, dandy little electric coffee grinder, reducing them to powder.Â The next day I made up a batch of each recipe.Â  And each recipe worked just like advertised.Â  The down side was the taste.Â  I expected them to taste just like the tomato products from the store shelves.Â  They didn't.The reasons are numerous.Â  Perhaps I left the tomatoes in the dehydrator too long and that had an effect on the taste.Â  Or maybe my expectations were too high.Â  I was ready to scrap the whole thing.But after thinking about it for a day or so, it occurred to me that the ketchup made with tomato powder might not taste just like bottled ketchup, but what if bottled ketchup was no longer available.Â  Anything is possible in our troubled times and with the food shortages happening across the country.Â  Ketchup that isn't exactly like bottled is still useful should it be all I have.So I will continue with the experiment.Â  Most of my home canned tomatoes are going into the dehydrator.Â  Shelf space gained will be put to good use.Â  Below are the recipes.Â  You can decide for yourself if this alternative to tomato products is right for you.Tomato Paste6 Tablespoons tomato powder1/2 Cup waterEquals one 6 oz. can.Tomato Sauce2/3 Cup tomato powder2 Cups waterEquals a bit more than one 15 oz. can.Tomato Juice1 Cup tomato powder8 Cups waterEquals one 64 oz. bottle.Ketchup1/2 Cup water6 Tablespoons tomato powder1/4 Cup cider vinegar1/2 teaspoon each salt, oregano, cumin1/8 teaspoon pepper1 teaspoon dry mustardBBQ Sauce6 Tablespoons tomato powder3/4 Cup water1-1/2 Cups brown sugar1/2 Cup vinegar1 Tablespoon Worcestershire sauce2-1/2 teaspoons dry mustard2 teaspoons paprika1-1/2 teaspoons Kosher salt1 teaspoon pepper1/2 teaspoon oregano1/2 teaspoon cuminBring to a simmer.Â  Cool and refrigerate.Tomato Soup6 Tablespoons water + 4 Tablespoons flour1/4 Cup water + 3 Tablespoons powdered milk4-1/2 Cups water2/3 Cup tomato powder4 Tablespoons brown sugar2 teaspoons saltMix four and water until smooth.Mix water and dry milk until smooth.Heat 4-1/2 Cups water until almost boiling.Whisk in tomato powder and heat on medium low to a simmer.Whisk in flour/water mix.Add brown sugar and salt and mix well.Heat to almost boiling.Turn off heat and stir in milk/water mix.Spaghetti Sauce1/2 Cup tomato powder1 Tablespoon onion flakes1-1/2 teaspoon each dry parsley, basil, oregano and Italian seasoning1-1/2 teaspoon each salt and garlic powder1/4 Cup brown sugarSimmer 1 hour.So there you are.Â  If anyone gives this a try, please let me know how it works for you.Â  And as always, pray and prepare.

title: Way To Go, Maddie
text: I have been getting phone calls now and then from my son and granddaughter, Maddie Mae.Â  They would call while they were out driving so Maddie could practice for her driving test.Â  Speaker phone enabled me to talk to both of them and there were some fun conversations.Â Yesterday was the big day.Â  There was another phone call on their way home, telling me Maddie passed her test with flying colors.Â  I was not surprised.Â  Maddie is a hard working girl, determined to do well at whatever she sets out to do.Time flies by.Â  I have no idea where the time went between thisand this.Congratulations, Miss Maddie Mae!Â  You do me proud in so many ways.So this one is just for you.Love, Grandma.

title: Another Scam
text: A few days ago a small storm went through my town.Â  About three miles south of my location there were some small trees uprooted and trash cans were tossed about.Â  My immediate are was untouched.Â  The storm wasn't bad enough to rate even a mention in the local newspapers.Yesterday I received a phone call from someone with a thick accent who told me his company was checking the area for storm damage.Â  They would be at my building the next day to check our roof.Â  I hung up on him.Â  A phone call to my landlord confirmed that no request for storm damage assessment had been made.Â  He was unaware of any storm at all.This morning I got another call.Â  The first tip-off was that he asked for Alberta.Â  Alberta was my neighbor who died a couple of years ago.Â  The caller sidestepped that error and proceeded to try to convince me that access to the building and to my apartment was necessary to check for damage.Â  I told him that unless my landlord accompanied him, access would be denied.Â  What I know and he doesn't know is that my landlord is currently out of town.We also had a very short discussion about the close proximity of my building to the police station.Â Makes my day when I can get a scammer to hang up on me.Â  :)

title: I will just come to your house...
text: How many times have those of us who prepare heard similar words from folks who can't be bothered to set aside extra food for emergencies.Â  My standard answer is, "No, you won't."Jennifer over at Prep School Daily has an excellent post dealing with this subject.Â  Go read it.Â  It is worth your time.I will add only two things.Â  The first is that I keep doing all I can do to prepare because I never, ever want to be in a place where I have to look into the eyes of a hungry grandchild and tell them I have nothing to feed them.The second is that in spite of the current notion among younger generations, nothing is free.Â  Someone always has to pay.Â  The best advice I ever received came from my Dad who said, "If you want it, work for it."Pray and prepare.

title: The Bat Bike
text: Some time ago my oldest son ordered an electric bike.Â  Duane says it looks like something out of a Batman movie, so he calls it the 'Bat Bike.' Due to shipping delays, it finally arrived this week.Â  It is painted a flat black color and has a removable battery pack that can be recharged.Â  Information on this kind of bike can be found by searching 'ecotric'.The bike required some assemblyÂ  The owner of the local bike shop put the seat and handle bars on it and checked it out.Â  It was good to go.Duane did a test ride to the Target store about two miles away, where he bought a backpack to hold necessities for mostly fishing expeditions.The bike performed perfectly.On his way home, Duane passed the Sheriff's office that is close by his apartment.Â  There were three deputies outside and they called Duane over.Â  Turns out none of them had ever seen a Bat Bike before and were curious about it.Â  Duane showed them the bike and explained how his stroke had left him unable to drive a car.Â  The numbness in one of his legs makes riding a regular bike difficult, so he found the Bat Bike online and thought it might be the answer to his transportation problems.Â  The battery takes over so pedaling is unnecessary.One of the deputies asked if he could take the bike for a spin around the block and Duane said he could.Â  Duane had a good test run and a nice conversation with the local law.But all cops are supposed to be bad - at least that is what we are expected to believe.Â  I guess our local sheriff deputies didn't get that memo.

title: Heads Up
text: As if there isn't enough crazy in our world, I have had some odd phone calls so far this week.There have been the daily calls advising me to consolidate my credit cards.Â  This would be tough to do considering I own zero credit cards.Â  Sometimes I just play along and waste their time and sometimes I remark on their obvious lack of proper parentage and hang up.Â  Depends on my mood.But this week I have received two calls from someone with an accent claiming to be from the Social Security Administration.Â  The first one I hung up on.Â  The second I played along with to see what the scam was.Â  Aparently my Social Security Number was used in connection with a crime in Texas.Â  They could not recite my number to me for verification and they could not tell me the nature of the supposed crime and they did not know the name of the police officer in charge of the case.Â  Then we had a short discussion about recording my calls and of attorney generals prosecuting fraud cases and they hung up on me.Â  I may be old but that doesn't necessarily make me stupid.Todays call was from someone who said they were from a fancy sounding law firmÂ  They tried three times to get me to say "Yes."Â  They kept asking if I was agreeing to accept the call, to which I replied three times, "What is the nature of this call."Â  Finally they told me that the call concerned a settlement of a lawsuit in which I was to receive a cash payout.Â  We then had a short discussion about phone call recording and fraud.Â  They hung up on me, too.Â  Don't know why.:)Sadly, there are lonely elderly folks who believe that the SSA is calling them and that a law firm really has money to give them.There has to be a special place in Hell for those who prey on the vulnerable elderly.

title: I've Been Busy
text: My groceries were delivered this past Thursday.Â  I am concentrating on food storage, so there were bags of sugar and flour and rice.Â  There were some odds and ends of canned tomatoes and fruit to fill in some gaps on the shelves.I ordered 4 lbs. of carrots thinking I would cube them and dehydrate.Â  I keep much of my dehydrated food in freezer Ziploc bags stored in cardboard banker's boxes.Â  When I checked the box of dry carrots, I found it was full to the brim, so I cut the carrots into chunks and canned 7 pints.Next were 4 bunches of celery.Â  I have never been able to successfully rehydrate celery.Â  It doesn't seem to matter if I blanch it or not, I always wind up with rock hard bits.Â  So now I just slice it and dehydrate.Â  When dry, I run it through my small coffee grinder, turning those hard pieces into powder.Â  I get the taste of celery without the unwanted rock hard crunch.Next was 4 lbs. of pinto beans.Â  I soaked them overnight, filled each pint jar about 2/3 full, added a teaspoon of onion flakes made from my home dried onions and a beef bouillon cube for flavor.Â  This was topped off with a scant 1/3 cup of shredded ham.Â  I added broth from cooking the ham and processed the jars for 75 minutes.Â  I had one jar that didn't seal, so I used that for a taste test.Â  I like it.The first canner load held 16 pints of ham and beans.Â  I had three pints leftover, so I sorted and washed 2 lbs. of Great Northern beans, put 1/2 cup of the dry beans in each pint jar along with the rest of the shredded ham and seasonings.Â  I used water for the liquid and processed them as for the first load.All totalled, I got 19 pints of pinto beans and ham and 14 pints of Great Northern beans and ham.Â  Not exactly gourmet fare, but it will certainly fill empty stomachs!I still have 10 lbs. of potatoes to dehydrate, but that will keep for another day.Many of us grow gardens that provide us with vegetables and fruit to preserve.Â  I love the pictures folks post and the articles they write about their gardening efforts.Â  Takes me back to a time when I could do the same.Â  But there are also many of us who are not in a place where we can garden.Â  That doesn't mean we can not build up a deep pantry.Some who were raised in the country like I was, tend to scoff at those who do not garden, home can and preserve.Â  I'm pretty sure we would all prefer home grown, organic.Â  But I'm here to tell you that in the end, it doesn't matter.Â  If the only means available to store food is to buy extra cans of food at the grocery - do it.Â  If your only source for meat is the grocery - buy it and freeze it. Take a good, hard look around.Â  See those meat processing plants shut down due to the virus?Â  See those truckers who refuse to go into those areas where they do not have police protection?Â  See those thugs who are burning and looting?Â  What makes you think you will not be affected?I don't care what the reason is for preparing.Â  But prepare we must.Â  For if this assault on our country continues to escalate, what you have on your shelves may be all there is.Pray and prepare.

title: This Girl...
text: turned 16 years old yesterday.Â  I am a day late with this post, but I think she will probably forgive the error.Miss Maddie Mae is a busy girl.Â  She excels in school.Â  She danced in competitions for several years before deciding to get into gymnastics.Â  She plays a mean game of tennis.But those are not the reasons I love her so much.Â  She is kind and caring.Â  She already is planning a career of helping others.Â  She has a delicious sense of humor.Â  And she is determined to do her very best in whatever challenges come her way.Â  But most importantly, she never fails to hug her Grandma when given the opportunity.Happy Sweet 16, Maddie Mae.Â  This one is just for you.Love, Grandma

title: We Are Back...
text: sort of.Â  Bars and restaurants in my area are finally being allowed to open for indoor service.Â  Of course, there are still restrictions.Â  The restrictions have nothing to do with the virus and everything to do with control.Â  Nobody seemed too worried about 'social distancing' during the protests and riots.Â  But a restaurant owner had better make sure there are six feet between tables.I knew the bar next door was open on Wednesday evening when I heard loud voices and the sounds of a scuffle outside my windows.Â  Looking out, I saw two young men rolling about in the middle of the street, doing their drunken best to smack each other upside their heads.Â  A few feet off to one side stood a little bit of a young lady, hands on hips, watching the proceedings.Â  After a couple of minutes, she said in a voice louder and more commanding than I expected to hear from someone who likely didn't weigh much over 100 lbs., "If you two don't stop being stupid, I am going to quarantine you both."The young men stopped trying to bash each other, got up, dusted themselves off and meekly followed the young lady back into the bar.Sometimes it is necessary to for me to concentrate on whatever humor can be found.Â  I keep track of what is going on around me, but if I concentrate only on the total insanity that is sweeping our nation, I will find myself in a pit of depression and I just do not have time for that.Â  So as I relax in my recliner with my Kindle, I hear voices from the street below.Â  Two or three young men discussing the attributes of their motorcycles.Â  A couple of sweet young things discussing the attributes of the boys with the motorcycles.Â  And the voice of a young man, using his very best pick-up lines on a young lady who obviously is going nowhere with him.Yep...things seem to be getting back to some sort of normal.

title: Graduation Under Lockdown
text: Several years ago, this little darlin' graduated from Kindergarten.Â  Her parents, my son and his lovely bride, were so proud.This week, that same girl graduated from High School.Â  And her parents are still proud of her.Â  So is her Grandma.Circumstances surrounding the two graduation ceremonies are vastly different.Â  At the time of Boston's Kindergarten graduation, life was good.Â  The only restrictions were those placed on children by their parents.Â  "Look both ways when crossing the street."Â  "Play nice with your sister."Â  "Eat your broccoli."Things have changed.Â  A virus swept in.Â  People were confined to their homes.Â  Boston spent the last few weeks of her school year taking her classes online.Â  There was no Senior Prom.Â  Her graduation party had to be postponed until later this summer.Â  The traditional graduation ceremony was cancelled.Boston's school, however, did a great thing.Â  They found a way to have a memorable graduation for the kids in spite of the virus and all the restrictions still in place.My son drove his family to the school.Â  Lining the driveway were signs about the size of the political signs we see in yards - 380 of them - one for each graduate, with their photo and the word "Congratulations."Â  On a tall fence hung a huge banner honoring the school sports teams who could not compete this season.Â  Further on a stage had been erected.Â When it was her turn, Boston got out of the car and walked across the stage to the strains of "Pomp and Circumstance" to receive her diploma.Â  Further down the stage, pictures were taken to commemorate the event.Â  Her family remained in the car but were able to watch their daughter receive her diploma.The teachers who were taking part in the ceremony remained on the stage from 9 AM until the last diploma was given at 8 PM.Â  Those school officials have my utmost respect for doing everything they could under the circumstances, to give the Class of 2020 a graduation ceremony to remember.But most of all I am so proud of this girl.She kept up her grades while holding down one and sometimes two part time jobs.Â  And come fall, she is off to the University.Â  We feared that the U of M would hold classes online only, but I just heard today that the decision has been made to open the doors for regular classes for the fall semester.Boston, this one is for you.Â  You make me proud.Â  Congratulations!Love, Grandma

title: Go With the Flow
text: Someone - I don't know who - once said, "We make plans.Â  God just laughs at us."Â  This is very true.I had planned on discontinuing canning for a while to concentrate on other areas of preparation.Â  But my youngest son asked me to email him my wish list for Sam's Club.Â  He said he will pick up part of it for me soon and the rest when he and his brother go shopping in June.Â  Makes sense.Â  Less for him to have to haul up the stairs to my apartment at one time.Much of my list is stuff for the freezer.Â  My chest freezer was nearly full, so something had to change in order to find room for the Sam's haul.My kitchen table is now covered with 4 venison roasts, 2 pork roasts, 5 boneless pork chops, 18 lbs. of hamburger, 2 large turkey breasts and 2 grocery bags full of quart freezer bags of slaw/relish.Â  I had to stop there because my table is the only space available to let some of this start to thaw.Â  I'm kind of scared to find out what is lurking at the bottom of the freezer.I believe my weekend is now taken up with the canning I wasn't going to do.Â  But there are times when we just have to go with the flow.Â  I need the freezer space.Â  Haven't a clue where I will store the jars of canned meat and slaw, but I am not about to let any of it go to waste. In these uncertain times, it doesn't matter that there were other things I wanted to do this weekend.Â  What matters is that I need to do whatever is necessary to feed my family.Â  And if you think things will be just fine, you really need to take a look at the two videos posted over at "Thoughts from Frank and Fern."Â  If they don't wake us up to what is in store for us, I doubt anything will.Pray and prep, my friends.Â  We need a whole lot of both.

title: Ode to a Ramble
text: There has been very little going on here in my little slice of heaven.Â  It is quiet - way too quiet - in my neighborhood.Â  The sound of another voice has me scurrying to a window to get a glimpse of another human being.Â  I am told there are a couple of small shops in town that are finally open.Â  The bicycle shop beneath my apartment is open a few days per week now.Â  Our governor is dragging his feet on opening Minnesota up for business.Â  There is an effort afoot to have him recalled.Â  Minnesotans want to work.Those of us who prepare usually have a plan.Â  We know what we would like to have on hand for a given period of time and we work toward that goal.Â  Sometimes we find the need to be flexible.I have 12 lbs. of hamburger in the freezer.Â  I have another 12 lbs. in the fridge.Â  The plan was to brown all of it and can it.Â  Until I noticed that I could maybe get half a dozen jars on my shelves.Â  They are that full.Â  So - change of plans.Â  Tomorrow I will be making meatloaves, meatballs and taco meat.Â  Once cooked and cooled down, they will be vacuum sealed and stashed in the freezer.Â  The only thing I will be canning for a while is some venison that has been frozen.Â  Duane and I have had a couple of meals of venison, but we both like it canned, so canned it shall be.Â  There isn't a lot of it so I think I can find room for a few jars on the shelf.Â  Maybe.My youngest son orders beef every year from a farmer he knows.Â  The price is reasonable, even with the processing at a local butchers.Â  So I have ordered a quarter beef for this fall.Â  I like the idea of supporting local buinesses.Â  The plan is to fill in with pork and chicken as it goes on sale at the grocery where my delivery service shops. My boys are planning an excursion to Sam's Cub in the not too distant future.Â  They won't let me go.Â  When I was exposed to the virus, Duane was checking up on me often and David was calling every day wanting to know what my temperature was.Â  No way will they take me to a big box store full of people.Â  Just as well, I suppose.Â  But it grates on me to have to admit that I am in the 'elderly and vulnerable' catagory.Â  Sigh.However, I am going through Sam's website and making a list.Â  The plan is to break down the large containers of frozen food and vacuum seal individual portions. And I trust them both to make good choices as to what I would like to have.Â  Bless all four of my kids.Â  They always come through when I need something done.That's about all I know today.Â  I truly hope you all are able to be out and about enjoying some sort of normalcy.Â  We so badly need to just get on with our lives.

title: Nope.  Won't do it.
text: While perusing YouTube last evening, looking for something fun to watch before going to bed, I instead ran across this video.Â  It was put out there by Ammon Bundy who, you may recall, was involved in a scuffle with government entities in a land dispute.Â  Whether you agree with Mr. Bundy's politics or not, he points out what lies ahead for us.Â  It is worth your time.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RWQMx4HxWIwI am not for even a minute downplaying the seriousness of COVID-19.Â  The question is, am I willing to allow government representatives into my home to test me against my will and to take me or my family away to quarantine camps?Â  Am I willing to be tracked to restaurants or on the street or anywhere I go on the off chance I might be near someone with the virus?Â  How much of my personal freedom am I willing to give up for the sake of a virus that has a recovery rate of 98%?Speaking as one who has indeed been exposed to COVID-19, (I am fine, by the way) I can say with absolutely no reservations, No!Â  And Hell, No!So listen up, those who would try to scare me into being paralyzed with fear.Â  I will not take your tests.Â  I will not allow you to keep tabs on my every move.Â  I will not allow your 'just following orders' people into my home.Â  And I sure as hell will not comply!Oh, it is for my own good?Â  It is 'for the children?'Well, that's different.Â  (Snark)

title: Happy
text: In these times of fear and lockdowns and a crumbling economy, we desperately need some happy.Â  Finding a bag of Chinese take-out outside my apartment door, left there by my son, makes me happy.Â  The upcoming birth of my Great-Grandchild as noted in the previous post, makes me extremely happy.Â  The daily phone call from my youngest son, checking up on his Mom, makes me happy. (All is well.Â  No symptoms.)Â  Last evening he emailed me this video of my Granddaughter performing her solo dance competition tap dance.I feel bad for Boston.Â  She graduates from high school this year and may miss out on both Prom and the graduation ceremony.Â  She has been dancing in competitions for several years and this her last year before college.Â  It seems that the competitions are cancelled due to the virus.Â  She made this video at the dance studio she attends and it is possible that it could be sent to the various competitions for judging in a virtual competition.Â  Not the same as dancing in front of a real, live audience, but I am glad she may still be able to compete in this way.Â  She worked hard on her routine and deserves some recognition for that.So Boston...this one is for you.Â  You made me very happy.

title: Amazing Technology
text: This is a photo of my Grandparents.Â  My Mother always claimed that was the first photo taken of herself because she was born a couple of months later in July of 1924.Things have changed over the years.Â  These pictures of my Granddaughter's ultrasound were emailed to me by my daughter.Â  May I present (drumroll please) my first Great Grandbaby!And the tiny little feet!We have a few months to go before learning if the baby is a boy or a girl.Â  Nicki and Chris have decided they don't want to know until he/she is born.Â  I guess that is OK.Â  I didn't know the gender of any of my kids until their births.Â  But I have this really cute girl fabric in my stash for a baby quilt.Â  Guess I had better get busy and order some boy themed fabric and make two quilts.Â  I am not fond of gender neutral baby quilts.I am simply amazed at how the technology has advanced so that I can actually see my Great-Grandbaby.Â  The only thing better will be when I can actually hold that child in my arms.

title: Interesting Turn of Events
text: So Wednesday this week one of the nurses arrived to deal with my legs.Â  She was feeling a bit under the weather and said she thought she had walking pneumonia.Â  She was wearing a mask and gloves.Â  I didn't think too much about it as I have the pneumonia shot that works well, keeping me free from even a bad cold.Turns out she was wrong.Â  The company she works for sent her to be tested for COVID-19.Â  She tested positive.I emailed my grocery delivery service to let them know that I have been exposed.Â  It is only fair that I tell them.Â  Whether they will continue to deliver groceries remains to be seen.Â  It is no big deal if they don't.Â  I have enough food put back to last a very long time.I have called Duane to tell him to stay away for a while.Â  He starts a new full-time job tomorrow and the last thng he needs is to get sick.I feel fine.Â  Today has been a rest day for me due to nothing more than arthritis that has decided to kick my backside.Â  My own fault. I should know better than to move furniture by myself.Maybe I will get the virus.Â  But maybe I won't.Â  That's in God's hands.Â  Being under quarantine is nothing new.Â  I have been pretty much housebound for the past 5 years.Â  A few more weeks are nothing at all.This in no way changes my belief that we need to open up our country again.Â  More harm is being caused with people hiding in their homes and not being out in fresh air and sunshine.Â  And not being at their jobs.Keep on prepping.Â  I would not want to be stuck with nothing to eat.Â  And if I didn't have extra coffee stored, then you would see really cranky!!

title: COVID - 19 in a Nutshell
text: This is the best analysis of the lockdown that I have seen and well worth the few minutes it takes to view it.We have been duped.Â  We need to take our country back if it isn't already too late.

title: Keep on Prepping
text: "For those new to prepping there's a rule: when you have twice as much as you need, double it. It may barely be enough."Ol' Remus - The Woodpile Report21 Apr 2020 (624)With this in mind I am spending today canning.My grocery order included the following:Â  12 lbs. of boneless, skinless chicken breast, 6 lbs. of carrots. 2 bunches of celery, 10 lbs. of potatoes and 4 lbs. of onions.The chicken was cut into bite-sized pieces.Â  The vegetables were cut into 1/2 inch dices.Quart jars were filled with layers:1 Cup chicken1 Cup potatoes1 Cup carrots1/2 Cup celery1/2 Cup onionsThis was topped off with 1 Tablespoon of powdered chicken bouillon and the jars were filled with water to 1 inch of the rim.Â  The jars were processed in the pressure canner for 90 minutes at 10 lbs. pressure for my altitude.Â  I got 21 quarts of chicken/vegetable base.This can be used as a soup with added broth.Â  It can be thickened for chicken pot pies or served over rice or with biscuits.Â  I think it might also be used as the base for some casseroles.The idea here was to get the most mileage possible from the meat.Â  Meat processing plants across the country are closing.Â  If things don't straighten out soon, it is entirely possible that some meats will not be available and those that are will have a hefty price on them.We tend to forget that before this virus hit, there were concerns among those who pay attention that the possibility of food shortages were very real.Â  Now due to the virus panic, other food processing plants are closed or about to close.Â  My grocery delivery guy tells me that there isn't much of a selection in the canned fruit and soup aisles of the store.Â  Some stores are already either low on or out of some staples like flour.Â  I admit to becoming a little bit lazy when it comes to canning and dehydrating.Â  No more.Â  The plan is to can everything I can lay my hands on that will fit in a jar and to dehydrate the rest.Â  I can't let circumstances stand in the way of making sure my family is fed.So tomorrow the 12 lbs. of hamburger in my fridge will be canned.Â  So will the leftover potato dices from today's canning session.Â  And the leftover onions will go into the dehydrator.The times are way too uncertain to wait until tomorrow to prep.Â  History shows the best way to control the population is by controlling the food.Â  It would not surprse me at all if that is the road we are headed down now.Pray and prepare.

title: Prayers Please
text: LindaG is a frequent and welcome commenter here.Â  She and her husband survived a tornado that destroyed their home.Â  Rev. Paul has details here.Â  We thank God that their lives were spared and ask for prayer as they move forward from this devastating event.There is power in prayer, people.Â  Now would be the time.

title: OK.  Here's the Deal.
text: I haven't asked anyone's permission to do anything since I left my parent's home at age 17.Â  I really would like to know just why some government official thinks I now need to ask permission to live my life as I see fit, within the law.I have a simple solution to the problems facing us all.Â  Open everything back up.Â  Now.Â If I decide to go to a ball game, I go.Â  If I fear catching a virus, I stay home.Â  If a ball player wants to play ball, he does.Â  If he fears catching a virus, he doesn't.Those business owners who want to open their businesses back up - do it.Â  If they fear catching a virus, don't.Those who have lost their means of employment, go back to work.Â  If they fear catching a virus, find another means of employment.If I want to shop at a department store, I shop.Â  If I fear catching a virus, I order online.If I want to see a movie, I go to the theatre.Â  If I fear catching a virus, I stay home.There is talk of forcing those who are vulnerable to stay home.Â  That would be me.Â  I am nearly 74 years old with health issues.Â  If I choose to spend time with family or walk the dog or sit on a park bench, that is my choice.Â  If others want to join me, that is their choice.It really is quite simple.Â  We are grown-ups.Â  We make choices every day and we live with the consequences of those choices.Â  We know how the virus spreads and if we decide to risk contracting it, that is up to us - not some bureaucrat.I will not comply.Â  I will not live the days I have left in fear.Â  Should my decisions cause me to catch the virus I will do everything I can to avoid spreading it to others.Â  But I absolutely refuse to ask permission of anybody to live the way I choose.Besides, I already have my permission slip.Â  It is called the Constitution.

title: Good Day, Fellow Inmates
text: I know I live like this all the time, but even so, this whole 'shelter in place' thing is getting really old.Â  I see my oldest son and I am glad of it, but I have three more kids that I can't hug.Â  To say nothing of grandkid hugs.Â  You know it is getting bad when the highlight of my week is a warmer day when I can open a window next to my dehydrator and dry some onions.Â  When you live in an apartment building, you need to be mindful of your neighbors.Â  Not everyone is pleased with the smell of drying onions.Â  Nevertheless, tomorrow is the day.Â  I am excited!The construction of an apartment building across the street continues.Â  The workers don't seem to be too concerned about masks and social distancing.Â  They are just busy doing the job they were hired to do.Â  It is good to see the work continue.Â  There are so very many that wish they could do their jobs as well.Our governor has opened golf courses, marinas and parks, but no camping and no picnics.Â  We are now allowed to go fishing as long as we fish in a body of water close to home.Â  If your fishing rod breaks, good luck.Â  No opening of sporting goods stores.Minnesotans are getting cranky.Â  There have been protests outside the governor's mansion, with more planned.Â  There are many who worry more about being able to feed their families while unemployed than worry about catching the virus.Me...I baked two loaves of banana bread, one of which just left my apartment with my son.Â  I will continue to add to my food storage as much as is possible.Â  There are quilts to sew and afghans to crochet and books to read.Â  And I will continue to pray that the light at the end of this tunnel is not a freight train headed our way.

title: Just a short post about food.
text: I have been seeing accounts about meat processing plants across the US that are shutting down.Â  Ice Age Farmer in his latest post tells the story much better than I can.I can not speak for anyone else, but I have made the decision to order as much meat as possible in my next few grocery delivery orders.Â  Some stores are already setting limits on meat products. It is not only the meat industry that is suffering.Â  Vegetable farmers are finding that with the shutting down of schools and restaurants, they no longer have sufficient markets for their produce.Â  Another Ice Age Farmer video uploaded a few days ago discusses this at length.Today I am canning ham and yams.Â  Last week I canned 16 pints of peas and carrots.Â  I wish I had ordered more foods to be canned. While our country is being held under house arrest, our farmers are facing the devestating conseqences of a virus.Â  I understand that this virus is serious and people die from it.Â  But I also understand that if we don't do something positive soon, we will not have much of a country left.

title: Cabin Fever, Anyone?
text: I can't honestly say the 'shelter in place' orders have affected me very much.Â  I am housebound anyway.Â  My sister called to see how I was doing.Â  We decided that we didn't mind staying home as much as we minded being told we HAD TO stay home.Â  We, of course, blamed our Dad, who never liked being told he had to do something, no matter what it was.Â  :)Duane and I have ordered Easter dinner from the restaurant where he works.Â  The biggest reason for doing this is to support local business in these trying times and the second reason being that this way, neither of us have to cook.Â  We had two choices - individual meals and a meal for four - both with all the trimmings.Â  We chose the meal for four with the idea of having enough leftovers so that neither of us would need to cook dinner for a few days.Â  After doing the math, I found it would have cost more to buy the ingredients for dinner than we paid to order.Â  Win - win!I have been seeing videos and articles about food shortages.Â  Some are due to last year's bad weather that had an effect on the harvest as well as meat animals lost to flooding.Â  Others are due to Covid-19.Â  Tyson just closed a pork processing plant in Iowa because some workers have the virus.Â  Other meat processing plants across the country have done the same, giving farmers and ranchers nowhere to ship their meat animals for processing.Other warnings are being heard from the grocery industry.Â  It seems now that restaurants are closed with minimal take-out orders still in effect, many are now having to cook their meals at home.Â  This has resulted in 'panic buying' at the grocery stores, leaving some shelves empty.Â  Some stores are putting limits on the number of certain items that can be purchased, while others are limiting the number of shoppers in their stores at one time.So far, aside from the lack of toilet paper after the 'Great TP Stampede' last month, the store where my delivery service buys my groceries has had little if any shortages.Â  I will find out if that is still true when my order is delivered Thursday this week.Ham and turkey are on sale and I saw no notice of purchase limits, so I ordered two of each.Â  The plan is to cook one of each, divide the meat into meal sized portions and freeze those for easy meals.Â  I haven't decided if I will can the rest or just freeze them whole for later use.Â  I also have ordered frozen peas and fresh carrots to can together in pint jars for an additional vegetable option.Â  I like peas and carrots as a vegetable for a meal or in casseroles or cold macaroni salads.Â Until the canning starts again, I have been spending time doing what I love to do - reading, sewing, crocheting, etc.Â  I found myself feeling guilty for not being productive, but as a dear friend pointed out, "You are retired.Â  You don't have to do anything, so do what makes you happy."Â  Good advice.Â Although I am sure there are other newsworthy things going on in our world, the news broadcasts are filled with little except the latest dire reports on the virus.Â  I wish the newscasters would report on the number of recoveries as often they do on the number of deaths.Â  We desperately need good news.Â Here in my little corner of the world, I am keeping track of the latest developments, but I am also working really hard to stay positive.Â  We need to get our people back to work.Â  I find it astounding that all those years ago we could successfully send men to the moon and get them back home unharmed, but we haven't been able to figure out a way to get our citizens safely back to work.Â Hang in there.Â  Do something that makes you happy. Pray.Â  We might be in a long, dark tunnel, but I have to believe there is a light at the end of it.Â  And never, ever give up.

title: How Much is Enough
text: I look at my shelves full of food and think I must have enough to last a year.Â  But do I really?Danny over at Deep South Homestead put up a video this morning entitled "Breakfast For a Year - Reality Check."I believe I will need to get out the calculator and do the math.Â  I have a sneaking suspicion I am not as prepared as I think I am.

title: If someone wanted to bring America to its knees...
text: they are doing a fine job of it.I understand this virus is no laughing matter.Â  It is insidious in how it is spread and heartbreaking in the way it takes lives.Â  It has ground our great nation to a halt in a way that nothing else could.I have come to believe there is much we are not being told.Â  Frank and Fern have posted an article that mirrors the conclusions I have found.Â  Please go read it, for it tells the story much better than I can.I was wrong to set aside preparing simply because it may be more difficult now with all the restrictions that have been put into place.Â  We may need every jar of canned vegetables, every bag of rice and every every can of tuna we have set aside before this thing goes away, if it ever does.Â  We need to learn everything we possibly can in order to survive.Â  There are videos and articles out there to teach us how to bake bread, how to fix things instead of buying new, what herbs to use when medicines are no longer available.Â  Watch a movie once in a while, for we do need distractions, but the ones who are most apt to survive hard times are the ones who know how to do stuff.In this time of isolation, staying in touch with friends and family is important.Â  My family calls to check on me.Â  I email back and forth with friends.Â  It all helps to keep our spirits up.Â  We can not let all of this bring us down.Â  We are a strong people and we will survive.Keep on prepping.Â  Keep on praying.Â  We are all in this together.

title: So Now What...
text: Now that we are officially a shelter in place, social distancing nation, what are we doing to cope.First off, my oldest son who lost both his jobs when restaurants were closed here in Minnesota, has been called back to work three days a week.Â  It seems the carry-out business at the bar & grill is booming.Â  He was pleased, as three days a week are far better than no days a week!I talked with my oldest daughter over the weekend.Â  She is working from home. Her son is home from college and will be taking his classes online.Â  I am relieved he is home rather than still at school.Â  They have a table set up with a huge jigsaw puzzle on it.Â  My family for the most part are avid readers, so books play an important part in passing the time.Â  Jill said if I need anything, she will get it for me and leave it outside my aprtment door.Â  She is taking this virus thing seriously.My youngest granddaughters, both teens, called me.Â  Both will be happy when they are no longer under "house arrest."Â  Being teens, they miss spending time with their friends, but are able to stay in touch via phone and computer.Â  Apparently their Dad is keeping them busy with some household chores and they are seriously considering shredding his 'To Do' list.Â  :)My youngest daughter is in Montana where her boyfriend is doing some construction work.Â  They are just fine, but I hope they are able to get back home to Minnesota fairly soon.Â  I have heard rumors of travel bans between states.Â  I hope that is just rumor, but those two are well equiped to cope with whatever comes their way and for that, I am grateful.Me...aside from limiting access by others to my apartment, life continues as it has the past couple of years when I have been mostly housebound.Â  I have decided to put a hold on canning and dehydrating for a time.Â  I don't want to be one of those people who selfishly clears a store shelf, leaving nothing for others.Â  I had become lazy about baking bread but the baking will commence this week.Â  The bread on the store shelves can be used by those who don't know how or can't, for one reason or another, bake their own bread.Â  I am keeping my grocery order as close as possible to the items on sale, with only minimum amounts of staples like milk and eggs.Â  Luckily, I have enough food stored that if I am unable to get groceries, we will be just fine for a long time.I find that although I am a bit of a news junkie, I am in danger of being overwhelmed by the virus news everywhere, all the time.Â  So I read enough to keep myself informed, but then move on to other things. I do think there are some positive effects of this shelter in place thing.Â  Families are spending time with each other rather than everybody going off in oppposite directions.Â  Meals together as a family that had nearly become a thing of the past, are now happening.Â  I wonder if some will find the benefits of online classes outweigh the costs of physically attending a university.Â  Homeschooling of younger kids might see an upturn. In my travels through cyberspace, I have noticed that there are those who thought preparedness was something to laugh at, have now had a 'come to Jesus' moment when they were caught without enough food or water.Â  Granted, grocery stores are still open, but there are shortages on all levels and no guarsntees that supplies will reach their intended destinations.Â  And those who relied on restaurants for most of their meals are finding life has changed considerably for them.My street is still very quiet.Â  There are only two cars parked on a street that is usually full.Â  At the construction site across the street, I saw one construction worker walking about.Â  All the cranes and other equipment are parked in a row.Â  Even the kids on skateboards have vanished. That being said, we will get through this.Â  We are Americans and Americans are some of the most resiliant, determined and resourceful people on the planet.Â  We didn't forge this nation of ours by curling up in a corner and sucking our thumbs when things got bad.Â  We met each crisis head on and we will do so again.One thing that gives me hope is how some are reaching out to help those who are the most vulnerable.Â  My grocery service that is run by volunteers, will continue to see to it that their clients get what they need to stay healthy and survive.Â  I have heard of individuals who are quietly and without fanfare, preparing and delivering meals to neighbors who need help.Â  Others are volunteering their services to pick up much needed medicines at pharmacies and deliver them to those who need them. We can do this.Â  We are all in this together.Â  God bless.

title: Things Seem Surreal
text: I have always known that life can change in a heartbeat, but I have never seen it up close and personal until now.Have you noticed the news headlines are no longer about the upcoming election or about the latest Biden gaf or the newest Bernie plan for Socialism?Â  Instead, it is Coronavirus everywhere.With one stroke of our governor's pen, my son lost two jobs.Â  He was working pretty much full time at one restaurant and one night a week at another, both within walking distance from his apartment.Â  Both are closed.Â  He has applied for unemployment online but like most in my family, he would rather be working than not.I live in the original downtown area of my town.Â  There are two neighborhood type bars and one Mom and Pop restaurant in my block, with another bar and another bar/restaurant in the next block.Â  Those bars have not been rowdy enough to cause me any problems living here, but now the streets are eerily quiet.Â  There hasn't even been any construction work going on across the street where a new building is going up, but that may be due to the rainy weather.Â  We shall see.About the only activity I have seen in the street in front of my apartment has been a couple of teenage boys with their skateboards.The cleaner I had was obtained through a county program.Â  I left messages concerning cancelling the service for my caseworker, but received no call back.Â  Finally I emailed and heard back within the hour.Â  It seems government workers are now working from home.It will be interesting to see if the store shelves are restocked next week when I get my twice monthly grocery delivery.Â  Stores that have been open 24 hours a day are now closing overnight and reserving the first hour open in the mornings for the elderly and most vulnerable to the virus to do their shopping.Â  After the Great Toilet Paper Stampede, limits on the number of certain items have gone into effect.The health clinic where I go for appointments with my regular doctor is now closed to walk-in patients and is doing online appointments only.Â  My appointment is not due until the middle of April, so I shall find out then if things have changed.Â  Personally, I would rather do an online appointment than sit in a waiting room full of sick people.My grands are home from school.Â  Boston is bummed because she thinks both Prom and Graduation could be cancelled and that is a distinct possibility.Â  My college student grandson is home for Spring Break, but has been told that online classes are the norm for now.Â  I am relieved that my family is, for the most part, working from home and sheltering in place.Â Life has changed for so many.Â  This may be over in a matter of weeks or it may last for months.Â  We just don't know.Â  Whatever happens, I pray you all stay safe and well.Â  We are all in this together.

title: Self-Quarantined
text: I am among the group of people being described in all the news reports as the 'vulnerable elderly.'Â  I prefer to think of myself as a 20 year old with 53 years of experience, but as much as I like to pretend I am not old - I am.Â  And I have health issues that place me directly into that category of 'vulnerable.'Â  In order to have a fighting chance at staying alive much longer so I can continue to annoy my children, some changes needed to be made.Self-quarantining isn't much of a stretch, for circumstances make it very difficult for me to leave my apartment even on the best of days.Â  But I needed to limit the comings and goings of others.I use a cleaning service to help keep my apartment clean.Â  The cleaner has another job in a fairly large group home that has the potential to become a virus petri dish as have nursing homes across the country.Â  Another cleaner would still have outside contacts with the general population, so tomorrow I am cancelling that service.Â  My son will haul my trash out for me and I think I can manage the rest.The nurses who deal with my legs call me the day before a visit to set up the time they will arrive.Â  The nurse who called yesterday is the one I have known the longest and trust the most.Â  She asked if I wanted a Monday visit.Â  I told her that would depend on what precautions she was willing to take.Â  She will do the hand washing, glove and mask wearing while here.Â  She also suggested that I have only one nurse see me for the duration and she is setting that up with her manager.Â  This is a service I can not do without, for if the treatment of my legs is not done properly, chances for infection and the resulting hospitalization are nearly a given.Â  The procedures are something I can not manage on my own.I will continue using the grocery delivery service every two weeks.Â  The same person does the deliveries each time and this is the only way I can continue to get fresh fruit, vegetables and other essentials, although if this service were eliminated, I could still live nicely on what I have stored.My oldest son will still have access to my apartment.Â  Living in the apartment next door, he is in the habit of checking up on Mom from time to time and that gives me a sense of security, knowing that if something bad happens, he will be there to help.Youngest Son called me yesterday.Â  He was doing his weekly grocery shopping.Â  He said the people at the store were going crazy.Â  Oldest Son went to the store where my delivery service shops and came back telling me there was no TP or paper towels on the shelves and very limited amounts of flour and sugar.Â  Lucky for me, there still was some Easter candy available and I now have a small stash of chocolate.Â  Chocolate makes everything better.Â  :)If nothing else good comes from this whole virus thing, it is my hope that just maybe some will finally see the wisdom of stocking up ahead of a crisis.Â  Those who have been saying they don't need to prepare because there will always full grocery store shelves are finding out there is no truth in that statement.Â  I know that my family will be fed for a long time due to my shelves full of food.Â  I am not inclined to gloat over the situation and feel real compassion for those who are now having to put themselves and their loved ones at risk by needing to enter crowded stores in order to keep their families fed.The coronavirus is not the flu.Â  It is an insidious disease that can be passed from one person to another long before the infected know they have it.Â  It is bad enough that many will contract this virus, but it is even worse that those infected can unknowingly pass it on to their older friends and relatives and put them in grave danger.Â  Literally.I can take precautions but I can not guarantee that I will not become infected.Â  All I can realistically do is to keep on prepping.Â  And pray.

title: When a person leads a quiet life...
text: sometimes it is a stretch to find anything to write about.Â  When that happens, you get little snippets of what is going on in my little corner of the world.Bella the dog (see last post) spent the better part of the day with me while Oldest Son was at work.Â  She made absolutely certain that anything she perceived as a threat was kept at bay with a sharp bark or two.Â  She supervised the crews that are working on a building across the street.Â  This was done from the back of my couch, looking out the window.Â  We had some good conversations (Yes.Â  I talk to animals.) but when Duane arrived to collect her, she forgot I existed.Duane told me that Bella's owner is on a cruise.Â  I don't think that would have been my choice in vacations just now.Â  We hope she will be able to come home afterwards without needing to spend two weeks in quarantine.Â  We wouldn't mind keeping Bella longer, but I wouldn't wish a quarantine on anybody.I have been waiting for a good sale on meat to can, but no luck so far.Â  So instead I ordered for Thursday delivery the ingredients for my favorite relish/slaw to can.Â  I suppose the person who does the shopping will think I have slipped into senility when they see I have ordered 6 large cabbages.Â  What doesn't go into the slaw will go into the dehydrator.I think a while back I posted the recipe for Amish coleslaw to can.Â  That is a good recipe, but I like this one even better.Coleslaw to Can or Freeze1 medium head cabbage1 large carrot1 green pepper1 small onion1 tsp. saltSyrup1 cup vinegar1/4 cup water2 cups sugar1 tsp celery seeds1 tsp mustard seedsShred together vegetables. Add the salt. Let stand 1 hour.Drain water from vegetables. Boil syrup ingredients together for 1 minute. Cool.Add syrup to vegetables. Pack into pint jars and process in a boiling water bath for 15 minutes, or put into freezer containers and freeze.Â  (I have canned this in half pint jars for single servings.)This slaw may be drained before use and mayonnaise added, or used as is.I am making lots of it this time as it is a favorite addition to a meal and mostly because cabbage is on sale.I am spending some time this week on various crochet and sewing projects, mostly to avoid the news, which is depressing.Â  I still check the headlines as I refuse to be totally ignorant of what is going on around us, but I am on information overload and need a bit of a break.Â  I can't ignore it completely, especially when I learn that there is a family here in my town who is self-quarantined due to contact with a virus case just across the river from my apartment.Â  That's a bit too close to home.Just wanted to let you know I hadn't fallen off the edge of the earth.Â  Life continues at it's quiet pace.Â  Well, except for an early warning system named Bella.Take care and keep on prepping.

title: This is Bella
text: Bella is a guest in my oldest son's home for the next ten days while her owner is on vacation.Â  But while he is at work, I get to spend time with her.Bella likes snuggles and ear scratches.Â  She likes to lay on the back of the couch and watch the world go by, occasionally expressing her opinion of those passing by on the street.Â  And she likes it when I sit in my recliner because then there is a lap to curl up on.But Bella is silly in love with my son, so she can occasionally be found in the kitchen, staring at the door, waiting for his return.Bella has kept me company before, so the first thing I had to do upon her arrival this morning was to open a pint jar of cubed chicken.Â  I think she may have remembered, for she danced around in excited circles, waiting for me to fish out a piece of her favorite chicken treat.It's gonna be a fun 10 days!!

title: DIY Hand Sanitizer
text: Just a quick post about hand sanitizers.Â  I have been hearing that hand sanitizers have been flying off the shelves due to the virus outbreak.Â  A friend confirms this as she has had trouble finding some in Canada. I stumbled onto this video this morning that shows how to make your own.Â  The lady in the video is a bit chatty, but eventually gets to the part on how to make it.Â  It is a simple process using 1/3 Cup of Aloe Vera Gel and 2/3 Cup of at least 70% rubbing alcohol, both of which I think are still available.Â  At least they are still in the stores in my area.Just wanted to pass this along to anyone who might be interested.Â  I plan to give it a try.Time for me to get back to work.Â  Later....

title: I Shall Return
text: When I counted the cases of home canned food sitting on the floor and came up with an even dozen awaiting shelf space to put them, I decided I had procrastinated long enough on doing some much needed rearranging to accomodate them.Â  And Oldest Son (better known as my partner in crime when it comes to food storage) and I discussed yesterday on how to make the best use of the six cases of quart jars now stacked against a wall in my kitchen.Â  I have lots of pint jars full of beef, pork and chicken that was cut into one-inch pieces, but have very lttle canned in large pieces to use as roasts.Â  So the plan is to watch the grocery store sale ads and fill at least half of the quarts with meat.Â  Which will also need shelf space to store.Considering that I move with the speed and grace of a herd of turtles and considering that at the same time I need to do an inventory to see just what I do have already and what I need to fill in the gaps, this project will likely take me the rest of the week.Â  I shall return Monday.I still plan to do the experiments with dehydrating rice and pasta, but that has been postponed until next week.Until then, pay attention.Â  There is so much going on around us these days and not much of it good.Â  Contine to pray and prepare, my friends.

title: Your Possible Future Nightmare
text: A friend and reader here sent me this video.Â  It is well worth watching and within the 7 minute 16 second time frame, tells you what you need to know about our possible future.Â  I'll wait.The video was done by 'Jerry Rye Productions' and was uploaded 4 years ago, but the message is as true today as it was then.Those running for the office of President from the Democratic Party seem to be using the methods tried in Venezuela as their playbook.Â  If you can not or will not see the striking similarities and if you believe the same outcome can't possibly happen here, then you just are not paying attention.Â  And if enough of the voting public do not get out and vote to stop this madness, then God help us all.

title: Chicken Noodle Soup
text: One of my parent's remedies for nearly anything that ailed us as kids, was chicken noodle soup.Â  It is still my 'go to' soup for times when I am feeling a bit under the weather.Â  Or for when I just want a bowl of soup.The price of a can of soup has increased considerably since I was young.Â  When a person is living on a fixed income, price often matters.Â  The ingredients matter as well, and I am getting more and more interested in the chemicals included in processed foods.Â  I would rather know for sure what I am consuming.So I made my own soup and canned it.Frozen boneless, skinless chicken breast was on sale so I got nine pounds.Â  The easiest way for me to cook that amount was to spread the meat out on parchment paper lined cookie sheets and bake until they were cooked through.Â  After the meat cooled, I cut it into about 1/2 inch dices.Each pint jar got 1/2 cup of chicken, 2 chicken bouillon cubes, a 1/2 teaspoon each of celery powder and onion powder (both made by grinding up my dehydrated celery and onions) and water enough to leave about 1 inch of headspace.Â  The soup was processed in my pressure canner for 65 minutes at 10 lbs. pressure for my elevation.Â  I got 36 pints of soup and have enough chicken left over to mix with the leftover BBQ sauce from canning BBQ pork and can that for BBQ chicken sandwich filling.Pasta doesn't can well, so when the jars of soup had cooled overnight and had been washed and labeled, I broke angel hair pasta into about 1 inch pieces, put a heaping 1/4 cup of pasta into snack sized ziploc bags and taped the pasta bags to the outside of each jar.I taste tested a jar of the soup, adding the pasta to cook while the soup heated.Â  I have to admit, it is some really good chicken noodle soup.Â  Unlike commercially canned chicken noodle soup, this soup has plenty of chicken pieces and even using the bouillon cubes, it doesn't have a salty taste.Comfort food in a jar.Â  Doesn't get much better than that.

title: Upcoming Experiments
text: One experiment has already beencompleted.  Some time ago I bought three pork roasts on sale, bakedthem and froze them.  Yesterday I shredded the thawed roasts andstirred in BBQ sauce, packed the mixture into half pint jars andprocessed them for 65 minutes at 10 lbs. pressure for my altitude.  Igot 24 half pints in the first canner load.  There is still a largebowl of the mixture in the fridge that I will can up tomorrow.  Onejar didn't seal, so I heated that up for my lunch and found to mydelight that it made a really good BBQ pork sandwich.My grocery order went in today.  Onepound bags of rice were on sale, so I ordered 6.  I had seen a coupleof videos showing how to make instant rice.  According to theinstructions, the rice is rinsed, cooked and spread on mesh lineddehydrator trays and dried.  To use, it is said that when boilingwater is added, it rehydrates quickly.  I'll let you know how itworks.Another dehydrating experiment I havebeen wanting to try is dehydrated pasta.  Jennifer over at 'PrepSchool Daily' has instructions to do this.  Her article on thesubject tells us why we would want to have dehydrated pasta inour food storage.  She also has recipes for instant meals using thedehydrated pasta.  As I have some other things I am working on thisweek, I likely will give dehydrating pasta a go this coming weekend.I just love trying new foodie things. It is nice to have a variety of heat and serve foods on the shelves. I will post the results of the experiments a week from today.  Untilthen, keep on prepping.

title: Another Conversation
text: I have a home health care service that sends nurses to my apartment three times weekly to treat my legs.Â  I have nothing but good things to say about the care I receive.Â  Thanks to their expert care I have few problems with a condition that has previously put me into the hospital.I don't always see the same nurse due to their scheduling of patient care throughout the Twin City area, which is likely a logistical nightmare.Â  This morning the nurse who just left my apartment was the one who manages the rest of the nurses.Â  Because of my previous conversation with another nurse described in the last post, I asked her to tell me everything she knows about the Coronavirus (COVID-19).Her reply..."Oh, it's just the flu."She must have noticed the astonished look on my face because she then asked me what did I know about it.So I told her.When I finished, she remarked that the news broadcasts weren't reporting any of that.Â  I replied that she must get her news from CNN. I also told her that if the virus spreads much further here in the States, there would be a list of protocols that I would expect to be precisely followed upon each nurse's visit.Â  She didn't look pleased, so I reminded her that at age 73, my lungs are wrecked and that I am on oxygen 24/7 and use a nebulizer 3 times daily, just to be able to breathe normally.Â  A virus like this one for which there is no cure is apt to kill me off.Folks, I am absolutely astounded that people working in the health care field are so completely oblivious to the known details of this virus.Â  I am not saying it will reach epidemic proportions.Â  But it could.And one of the reasons it could is that people are not paying attention.

title: I had a typical prepping conversation...
text: with the nurse who was here today to treat my legs.Â  I asked her if she had heard anything new about the Coronavirus (COVID-19).Â  Her response was that it was nothing to worry about.Â  So, because I just couldn't help myself, I asked her what would she do if it is real and if it spread and if quarantines were put into effect.Â  Could she feed her family for a minimum of two weeks on what she had in her pantry?Â  She said it didn't matter because she could just get whatever she needed at the store.Â  So I asked her what would she do if quarantines kept the delivery trucks out of the quarantine areas.Â  And her answer was sadly typical - "Oh, that will never happen here."I have had similar conversations over the years.Â  I am done. What prompted my conversation with the nurse was an email I received today from my best source of information.Â  The following was published by the American Trucking Association.Â  There could be any number of reasons for the trucks to stop running, but right now the threat of the virus spreading, quarantines being put into effect and trucks being kept out of the quarantined areas is what is on the minds of many.Â  Here is what I found in my friend's email."When Trucks Stop, America StopsA Timeline Showing the Deterioration of Major Industries Following a Truck StopageThe first 24 hours:*Delivery of medical supplies to the affected area will cease.*Hospitals will run out of basic supplies such as syringes and catheters within hours.*Radiopharmaceuticals will deteriorate and become unusable.*Service Stations will begin to run out of fuel.*Manufacturers using just-in-time manufacturing will develop component shortages.*U.S. mail and other package delivery will cease.Within one day:*Food shortages will begin to develop.*Automobile fuel availability and delivery will dwindle, leading to sky-rocketing prices and long lines at the gas pumps.*Without manufacturing components and trucks for product delivery, assembly lines will shut down putting thousands out of work.Within two to three days:*Food shortages will escalate, especially in the face of hoarding and consumer panic.*Supplies of essentials - such as bottled water, powdered milk, and canned meat - at major retailers will disappear.*ATM's will run out of cash and banks will be unable to process transactions.*Service stations will completely run out of fuel for autos and trucks.*Garbage will start piling up in urban and suburban areas.*Container ships will sit idle in ports and rail transport will be disrupted, eventually coming to a standstill.Within a week:*Automobile travel will cease due to the lack of fuel.Â  Without autos and busses, many people will not be able to get to work, shop for groceries, or access medical care.Within two weeks:*The nation's clean water supply will begin to run dry.Within four weeks:*The nation will exhaust its clean water supply and water will be safe for drinking only after boiling.Â  As a result gastrointestinal illness will increase, further taxing an already weakened health care system.This timeline presents only the primary effects of a freeze on truck travel.Â  Secondary effects must be considered as well, such as inability to maintain tellecommunications service, reduced law enforcement, increased crime, increased illness and injury, higher death rates, and likely, civil unrest."The full report can be viewed Here.I'm not saying this virus is going to turn into a pandemic.Â  But what if....

title: I Have a Secret
text: Well, actually, I had a secret.Â  I am now allowed to share it.A couple of weeks ago my daughter Jeri, granddaughter Nicki and Nicki's fiancee Chris came to see me.Â  We had a nice visit.Â  And Nicki brought me a gift.But I had to promise to keep the news secret.Â  There were other relatives that needed to be told of the upcoming event.Â  Do you have any idea how hard it is to keep such good news a secret?Â  Thought I was going to burst!Well today they made the announcement via Facebook.So there it is.Â  I'm gonna be a Great-Grandma!!Â  Let the bragging begin!Life is so very good. Love, Great-Grandma to be.

title: On "New Normals"
text: My Grandmother cooked all the family meals from scratch.Â  She kept an immaculate household.Â  She canned produce from her garden and fruit from local fruit trees and fruit that grew wild in the surrounding woods.Â  She baked her own bread.Â  She sewed dresses for her daughters and shirts for her son.Â  She did all this while raising seven children.Â  She passed this knowledge and way of life on to my mother who in turn, passed it on to me.Those of us who were raised in the old ways had a tendency to carry on as those before us had.Â  We worked from dawn to dusk.Â  And if our home was on a farm, the days were even longer and the work, harder.Â  But we didn't think about that, for we were young and would undoubtedly live forever.And now we are old.Â  Now we know better.I have a dear friend with whom I exchange frequent emails.Â  We both have chronic health issues.Â  Because neither of us feels sorry for ourselves or for the other, we occasionally discuss the 'new normals' of our lives.Â  It sometimes helps to talk with another person who understands.Last week I came to the realization that I have reached another 'new normal.'Â  Having been a home canner since the age of 12 when I helped my mother with that activity as she became the victim of dibilitating rheumatoid arthritis, it is hard for me to accept the fact that canning has become difficult at best.Â  Lifting the heavy canner, standing at the sink preparing some foods to can, lifting the jars of food from the canner, all are no easy tasks these days.Â  My 'new normal.'The point of this post, however, is not to whine about my limitations.Â  I know there must be others out there who are going through their 'new normals.'Â  And I am here to offer encouragement.We were raised to believe we could do it all.Â  And many of us did, for years.Â  But life happens.Â  We thought it shameful to use food from a can or a box rather than cook from scratch.Â  The shameful thing is if we use our limitations as an excuse not to prep.Â  Here are some of the things that can be found in my deep pantry:boxes of Mac & Cheesescalloped potato mixescans of fruitcans of vegetablesboxes of Bisquickcans of corned beef hashcans of Spampackets of rice and pasta mixespackets of muffin mixesboxes of pancake mixTrue, I did can up a ton of food while I still could, but these days my canning is limited mostly to canning meat.Â  And that is due to the cost of commercially canned meats.Â  And meat is easy to can.Â  And often my son is willing to give up his day off to help.Here's the deal.Â  We may have limitations.Â  We have to adjust to our own 'new normals.'Â  But that doesn't mean that we have to give up on preparing.Â  With everything that is going on in the world around us, failing to prepare could mean the
