difference between surviving or dying.Me...I'm going to do whatever it takes to live long enough to be a problem to my children.Â  It has been said by a somewhat cheeky daughter that I have acheived that goal, but I don't think so.Â  Not yet!

title: A Quiet Day
text: Now and then we of a certain age and with a few body parts that seem to be failing us, need a quiet day to recoup and revive.Â  Today is such a day.Not that I am sitting, staring out the window.Â  Nope.Â  There are still things I can do on a quiet day.Oldest Son was here yesterday and we went through my canning shelves and deep pantry, making decisions on what was needed and what we have plenty of.Â  I've got lots of home canned meats and vegetables and soups/stews along with some fruit.Â  I have more canning to do before spring.Â  The shelves are more than full, with several cases of bacon, baked beans and ham and bean soup sitting on the floor in front of the shelves.Â  Duane has already taken several cases of home canned food over to his apartment, but he said he would swamp out another area where he can store more.Â  That will really help.Â So we decided to concentrate on the staples like sugar, flour. powdered milk, etc.Â  And we really need to ramp up the first aid supplies, for we don't have nearly enough.So I spent part of the day making lists of what is needed so I will have a handy reference for my grocery orders and a future Sam's Club adventure.Â  I am no longer foolish enough to rely on memory alone.Â  After all, I can go from one room to another and forget why in the process.Â  :)I also spent time transferring recipes from my computer to index cards.Â  It occurred to me that should we lose power, the recipes - especially the ones for canning or for dry mixes - would be lost.Â  I do have a printer but am out of printer paper.Â  Index cards take up less space than do binders filled with paper.Â  I also have an external hard drive, but without electricity, that becomes a doorstop.I also checked out some web sites dealing with the Coronavirus.Â  There are a number of 'hair on fire - we're all gonna die' sites, but there are some that are taking a common sense approach to the problem.Â  While the virus doesn't seem to be spreading here as quickly as in China, officially we have doubled in the past two days the number of known cases here in the States, to 12.Â  One of those is in Wisconsin, which is too close to me for comfort.Â  I am still of the opinion that the truth is not being told to the public, world wide.All in all, it was a fairly productive quiet day and with any luck at all, I will be back to my normal turtle racing speed in the morning.Â  :)Take precautions to stay healthy and keep on prepping.

title: I Don't Want To Adult Today
text: As I sit here at my desk this morning, looking at my checkbook and a stack of bills, it occurs to me that I just don't want to adult today.Â  I would much rather go back to when I was about 8 years old.If it were summertime, the 8 year old me would be playing a game of Jacks with my best friend.Â  Or maybe Hopscotch on the sidewalk.Â  Or I might be found hiding among the branches of the crab apple tree reading a Nancy Drew Mystery or a Bobsey Twins book, with the added pleasure of having some of the best tasting crab apples on the planet within easy reach.Or I might be found knee deep in the creek, sailing pieces of wood and pretending they were boats sailing off to distant exotic lands.Â  Or maybe at the lake practicing my swimming strokes.If it were wintertime, there were snowmen to be built, complete with coal for eyes and a carrot nose.Â  Or the building snow forts where epic snowball battles raged.If I were at my Grandma's house, there would be sledding with my cousins down the hill in the cow pasture, made all the more exciting by having to dodge the large rocks and tree stumps.But the best part of winter was ice skating.Â  There was the outdoor ice rink down by the elementary school where an 8 year old girl could practice to be an Olympic champion.Â  Those hopes were dashed with the realization that I probably would never skate backwards without falling down.Then there was the small ice covered lake near Grandma's house where Dad had skated as a young boy.Â  He told me of skating on a very windy day.Â  He opened the front of his coat and held the fronts out like airplane wings.Â  The wind caught his 'wings' and propelled him across the lake.Â  Having tried that myself, I learned he was right when he said the ride across was fun, but skating back against the wind was a bugger.So here I am.Â  Bills and checkbook in front of me.Â  I am not 8 years old any more.Â  If I want a roof over my head I suppose I had better write that rent check and if I want my life to continue without bill collectors bothering me, I expect I had better be the adult and take care of business.But oh, the memories.Â  They are sweet.

title: The Time is Now
text: There is no good time to slow down on the preps.Â  With all that's going on in the world now, we need to be as prepared as possible.Â  The cold, hard fact is, when disaster strikes, we are on our own.Â  Take a look at China.Â  Millions of people are locked in their homes under quarantine from the virus that has spread all across China, with no way to get food when theirs runs out.Â  If you think that can't possibly happen here, I envy your ability to happily live in a land of fairy dust and unicorns.Â  But most of us here live in the real world.Â  We take precautions.Â  We prepare.Â  And because we do, our chances of survival are better than most.Â  But if you think you can start preparing tomorrow, you will find that once the crisis hits, supplies will be gone from the store shelves within a couple of days.Earlier this week I canned 12 quarts of Great Northern beans.Â  The reasoning behind doing this is that in a situation where I would need to cook on my camp stove, it takes much less fuel to heat beans than it does to cook them from scratch.Â  And cooking dry beans from scratch takes more water which also might be at a premium.Â  I used the easy method which is putting 1 cup of dry beans in each quart jar and then filling the jar with water.Â  I also dropped one chicken bouillon cube in each jar to add a little bit of flavor, and processed the beans for 90 minutes at 10 lbs. pressure for my altitude.Â  When I can dry beans in pint jars, a half cup of dry beans go in each jar and the time is 75 minutes.Â  They came out perfect.My grocery order arrived yesterday.Â  Included were 8 lbs. of fresh carrots.Â  I have lots of sliced or diced carrots on the shelf, but I like larger chunks of carrots for making candied carrots or stew.Â  So I peeled the carrots to get rid of any chemicals that commercially grown carrots were probably sprayed with to prevent them from sprouting.Â  Garden fresh carrots would only need to be well scrubbed.Â  The carrots were cut into about 1 1/2 inch pieces and they filled 14 pint jars, which are happily bubbling away in my pressure canner.Â  If I were canning quarts they would need 30 minutes in the pressure canner.I have a couple of items on the canning 'to do' list to work on over the weekend before deciding what to include in the next grocery order for my food storage.Â  I'm thinking it might be a good idea to can up some kidney beans.Â  It is cheaper to can them myself than to buy them already canned and I know what's in them.Â  I could use more dehydrated potato slices so I will order potatoes as well.Â  It's all good.

title: Coronavirus
text: Every day brings more and more videos and articles concerning the Coronavirus that had it's beginnings in China.Â  What to believe.Â  Do governments tell us the truth or do they withhold information to prevent panic among citizens.Â  Do those reporting on the virus know what they are talking about or are they just guessing like the rest of us.Â  I don't know.Yesterday one of my blog friends (thanks, Red) left this link in the comment section.Â  Turns out it is the most informative video I have seen to date, without all the sensationalism of other videos. Â  It is worth your time to view.Â  I'll wait.Me...I am taking a 'wait and see' attitude, but I don't intend to wait too long.Â  I am vulnerable due to my age and health issues.Â  The one thing I have going for me is that I am housebound.Â  I go out once a year in April to visit my doctor and get prescriptions renewed.Â  If this virus seems to be spreading here I will take steps to severely limit visitors.Â  My goal in life, after all, is to live long enough to be a problem to my children.Â  Some declare I have achieved success in that area already.Â  :)I don't think anyone on the planet really knows how this all will play out.Â  Mostly we need to pay attention and take common sense precautions.And pray.

title: She Is Back...
text: The bacon is canned and 38 half pint jars await washing and labeling.Â  There probably would have been a couple more jars, but Oldest Son took home about a pound of bacon and I, of course, had to do some taste testing.Â  I am really glad to have those jars to add to my food storage.Yesterday was sort of a 'rest day.'Â  I have those once in a while in between days of much activity.Â  Today is 'catch up' day for all those small chores that were left undone while canning.I have been reading about the Coronavirus that began inÂ  China.Â  As of this morning Chinese news is reporting 81 deaths and about 2,500 known cases.Â  I am skeptical of the numbers.Â  China has quarantined several cities with a total population of at least 50 million people.Â  Stores and schools are closed.Â  Public transportation and flights from the area have been halted.Â  Citizens are being told to stay in their homes.Â  Hospitals are overrun.Â  Thousands of medical workers are being brought in.Â  A normal flu season has thousands of casualties every year without quarantines or lock downs of the population.Â  Just saying.As of this morning there are five cases of the virus being reported in the United States with others sparsely scattered world wide.Â  I do not believe there is any reason to panic.Â  But there is sufficient reason to avoid crowds and take precautions, for this virus is reported to be airborne.Â  And it is communicable before the symptoms surface.I have to wonder what will happen to those people who are confined to their homes when their food runs out.Â  Stores are closed.Â  Exits from the cities are blocked.Â  They have no way to get more food.Â  I don't know if the people in China or elsewhere are into food storage, but if they aren't, they are in deep trouble and not just from the virus.I know very few people who take food storage seriously.Â  I am in no way saying a pandemic will happen here.Â  But, what if...

title: Going AWOL Again
text: This afternoon 25 lbs. of bacon landed on my kitchen table.Â  The next couple of days will be devoted to cutting the slices into 1-inch pieces, browning them and canning them up in half pint jars.Â  I amÂ  really glad to have the bacon, but the process is time consuming.Â  So I will return when the job is finished. Take good care and keep on prepping.Â  :)

title: Ode to a Bus Driver
text: I saw this photo among the memes Gorges over at Gorges' Grouse that he posts daily and which I thoroughly enjoy.Â  So I stole it.Â  Gorges says it is OK with him.The bus reminded me of a couple of stories told me by my Dad.Â  He had, in the late 1930's or early 1940's, driven a school bus in the wilds of northern Minnesota.Â  Dad had his own methods ofÂ  dealing with problems that can arise among students on a bus ride.Dad said there were two teenage boys on his bus route who couldn't seem to get through the ride home without fighting with one another.Â  When "Don't make me come back there" no longer worked, Dad pulled the bus off to the side of the road, hauled both boys out of the bus and onto the grass along side.Â  Then he told them to fight.Â  When they just stood there looking dumbfounded, Dad proceeded to show them how to stand and how to position their arms in order to sock one another in the nose and repeated his order to fight.Â  All the while, the rest of the kids on the bus were at the windows, laughing at the two would be fighters.Â  Dad said the two boys, thoroughly humiliated, both climbed back on the bus, quietly sat down and never after gave him another minute's worth of trouble.There was one bus rider who seemed to enjoy being a bully.Â  He would do things like pick on the little girls until they cried or pinch the younger boys until they yelled.Â  He would knock books from the hands of older students or taunt them with nasty remarks.Â  And one afternoon, my Dad had just about enough of this kid.After another bullying incident, Dad stopped the bus and set the kid off on the side of the road, telling him that because he wouldn't behave on the bus, he could walk the three quarters of a mile to his house.Dad knew this kid's father and as he got to their farm, Dad stopped and had a word with the him, explaining why his son was walking and suggesting that he might want to wait for his son at the end of the driveway.Now in those days, a trip to the woodshed was the usual punishment for an errant son, but Dad said he later heard that in addition to the woodshed, that kid spent all of his free time doing the nastiest chores on the farm.Â  He mucked out the chicken house and the pig barn.Â  He pulled weeds in their large garden.Â  He hauled and stacked firewood.Â  And when he next rode the bus and thereafter, he was the best behaved kid there.Dad had a way of working out problems.Â  I know.Â  I spent many hours as a young girl, scrubbing and cleaning and weeding and pushing a lawnmower to pay for my transgressions.Â  As an adult, I am grateful to have had a Father who cared enough to see to it that I understood right from wrong, even though at the time I wasn't exactly happy about the lessons.I think if we had more parents willing to find solutions to their children's bad behavior, we wouldn't be adrift in a sea of precious little snowflakes today.

title: Canning and Cookies
text: On this past Friday I got out my big electric roaster and dumped in the 6 lbs of Great Northern dry beans that had soaked in water overnight, 2 lbs. of diced carrots, 2 lbs. of diced onions, 5 lbs. of diced boneless ham and the left over ham from a nice ham bone that I had simmered the day before.Â  The broth from the ham bone plus enough water to generously cover all the ingredients went in next along with a small jar of ham soup base plus a couple tablespoons each of garlic granules and celery powder.Â  The soup slow cooked all day until the beans were nearly tender.Saturday morning I started canning the soup and when all was said and done, there were 14 quarts and 9 pints of seriously good ham and bean soup. In the same canner load of pints of soup went 4 pints of chicken breast that I found while cleaning out the freezer in my fridge.Â  I really need to pay better attention to what I have in the freezer.Â  Occasionally I will find a surprise that I forgot was in there.Â  :)Sunday was devoted to putting my kitchen to rights as it sort of looked like someone had set off a bean bomb in the middle of it.Â  I had several bags of beef scraps left over from the last time I canned beef.Â  I thawed the beef and it went into a stock pot with the peels from the carrots and onions I put into the bean soup along with plenty of water.Â  That simmered all day and then I strained off the broth.Â  The broth is in the fridge keeping cool so I can skim off the fat.Â  I will go through the meat scraps and salvage any pieces of meat big enough to can with the broth.But today I need a bit of a break from canning.Â  The aroma of chocolate chip cookies is wafting through my apartment.Â  Soon that will be replaced with the smell of peanut butter cookies and possibly a batch of sugar cookies.Â  Sometimes cookies are just necessary to a person's well being.Â  At least, that's what floats my boat today!Now that I have half pint jars I will can bbq pork tomorrow.Â  The meat is thawing and the bbq sauce is ready.Â But for today, it's all about the cookies.Â  :)

title: The Kitchen Table
text: A friend with whom I share frequent emails remarked that our email chats feel like coffee and conversation at the kitchen table.Â  Which, of course, got me to thinking about life at the kitchen table.Growing up, everyone in my family was expected to be seated at the kitchen table at 6 P.M., hands and faces washed, ready for supper.Â  We actually talked to one another.Â  Of course, there were no cell phones then.Â  We talked about Dad's day at work, about our days at school, about what Mother had done that day.Â  We talked about Mother's phone conversation with her sister, about the letter from Grandma and about what we would like to do on the weekend.Â  There was never a time when there was nothing to talk about...until Dad brought home a set of TV trays and then supper at the kitchen table faded off into memory.Before my family had a TV set, the evening entertainment was often held around the kitchen table.Â  A radio often played in the background while rousing card games of Rook, Old Maid and Go Fish were played.Â  Sometimes board games were brought out and we would challenge each other to Sorry or Parcheesi or Yahtzee.Â  The older ones often played Scrabble and many years later my Dad could be found playing the game in Mothers' room at the nursing home.Â  Mother nearly always won and Dad nearly always, with a twinkle in his eye, accused her of cheating.Â  :)In rural Minnesota, neighbors often dropped in for a visit, which always took place with coffee at the kitchen table.Â  And in rural Minnesota, it is almost a sin not to have cookies or brownies or cake to go with the coffee.Â  I would save the plastic buckets that ice cream came in and fill them with cookies and freeze them, just so I would have something sweet to go with coffee.The kitchen table at my Grandmother's house was the scene of several two-day Monopoly games between my cousin and me.Â  And when it was time to leave after a weekend visit with Grandma, both of us would argue that we could have won, given another day.Homework these days is mostly done on a computer, but way back then, workbooks, three-ring binders, lined paper and pencils were the tools used and nobody had a desk.Â  The kitchen table worked just fine for solving math problems and writing book reports.Â  And Mother was conveniently close at hand to help if needed.Once in a while, usually on those long, cold winter nights in Minnesota, someone would commandeer the kitchen table with a 1,000 piece jigsaw puzzle, leaving the family to its own devices for meals and homework.Â  Every now and then, someone would sit at the table and fit more puzzle pieces together and after a few days, it would be complete.Â  We would have to admire the completed puzzle for a day and then the kitchen table was back for business as usual.Even now when my family gets together, the conversation is best around the kitchen table.Â  When my kids or grands stop in, we sit at my kitchen table and talk.Â  Sometimes I think this silly little blog is kind of like sitting with friends at the kitchen table, preferably with a cup of coffee.Â  I write about something and you all chime in with comments.Â  That has the feel of kitchen table conversation to me.I sort of feel sorry for those who don't take the time to join others around a kitchen table.Â  Our busy, hectic, crazy world could use more kitchen table time.

title: Nothing Much
text: It is the middle of January and here in the wilds of Minnesota suburbia, that means there isn't much going on.We had a couple inches of snow with more predicted for the remainder of the week.Â  Some years January finds us somewhat frozen with sub-zero temps, but so far it has been relatively mild.Â  And some years we have been up to our hips in snow by now, but this year - not so much.Â  No complaints here.Â  :)The store where my grocery delivery service shops has fresh coleslaw mix on sale for 10 packages for $10.Â  I have ordered 15 packages to dehydrate.Â  Drying this mix is easy.Â  Just spread the mix out on mesh lined dehydrator trays and it is good to go.Â  It doesn't take long to dry and this stuff makes a good filler for soups, plus it adds flavor.Â  Win - win.Youngest Son brought me 2 tubs full of canning jars.Â  There were 35 quart jars and 53 pints.Â  Score!Â  I have two cases of half-pint jars ordered so I am back in business for canning.Â  Up to now, the stacks of jars were getting pretty small.Â  Thank you, Son!I have the ingredients all prepped for canning ham and beans.Â  Thursday is grocery delivery day, so canning will take place over the weekend.Â  Because I move at the pace of a herd of turtles, putting groceries away and canning are not compatible on the same day.Â  My days of multi-tasking have come and gone these days.However, just so I won't be accused of lounging on the sofa, remote in hand, I spent time last evening going through boxes of quilting fabric and supplies.Â  I found several Ziploc bags of already cut out quilt pieces - some already pinned together ready for sewing, that my aging brain had forgotten about.That's one really nice thing about getting old.Â  We put things away for safekeeping and when we find them again, it is like getting surprise gifts.Â  Who says aging can't be fun!So I think I will spend the rest of today and tomorrow playing with fabric, which is one of my favorite things to do.Â  Plus, when the lights go out, we in the Minnesota tundra will need all the quilts we can lay our hands on, just to keep from freezing.Â  Food is important, but there are many other things to consider.Â  So keep on prepping!

title: Ice Age Farmer
text: One of my commenters passed this video on to me.Â  I find it important enough to pass on to you.Â  Thanks to 'Red.'https://www.youtube.com/watch?time_continue=1&v=_0kAeJ_X1Ok&feature=emb_titleI have to say that I have found Ice Age Farmer to be a good source of information, particularly about our food supply and the Grand Solar Minimum we are now experiencing.Â  He has both a YouTube channel and a web site.Â  Both contain information that includes documentation.Â  It is all well and good to impart information to viewers and readers, but to extensively back up claims is unusual in this age of digital information.There are many who believe life will continue as it always has, with store shelves holding every conceivable food known to man being available at all times.Â  To those folks, I am happy for you, living in a world of rainbows and unicorns.Â  Must be lovely there.However, there are those of us who stay aware of conditions around the world.Â  Our food supply depends not only on what happens here in our homeland, but also depends on conditions world wide.Â  And taking those conditions into consideration, I, for one, intend to continue to put back as much food for my family as is humanly possible.Anyone who is familiar at all with history knows that there have been periods in history when weather has had a dramatic effect on the food supply.Â  We have gone through times of drought and times of excess rain, snow and the resulting flooding.Â  This has nothing to do with the ever popular 'climate change' hoax, but with the natural cycles in our weather patterns.Throughout history there have been tyrannical governments who chose to control their citizens through limiting their food.Â  The resulting deaths due to starvation was horrendous.Â  If you think that just because we live in America, those who wish to maintain power won't use some of those same tactics to keep us in line, think again and pay attention to all the rules and regulations that now exist concerning food production.Procrastination is not an option.Â  Pay attention.Â  Stay aware.Â  And keep on prepping!

title: Back At It
text: Having taken some time off over the holidays, I am back at the preparations, full force.I was able to score two pork shoulder roasts on sale for 99 cents per pound.Â  The ones that arrived with my grocery order totaled 18.25 lbs.Â  I slow baked one of them today and will cook the other tomorrow.Â  Both will go in the freezer until I get my hands on the BBQ sauce preferred by my family.Â  My son said he would pick up a gallon of Sweet Baby Ray's sauce for me next week.Â  The shredded pork in sauce will be canned in half pint jars, which is just the right amount for sandwiches for one.This afternoon I transferred 20 lbs. of sugar and 35 lbs. of flour from the paper bags they come in to ziploc bags.Â  Bugs and mice like paper but are less likely to get into plastic.Â  I have never had a bug or rodent problem here in my apartment, but I am not willing to take a chance.Â  The ziploc bags are safely stashed away.To my delight I found that my grocery delivery service will allow three items each order that are not listed in the catalog.Â  Since the store where they do the shopping carries canning supplies, I do believe cases of jars are in my near future.Â  This will be welcome news to my kids who have before carried countless cases of jars up the stairs to my apartment!I was pleased when Oldest Son told me that he was also buying extra food each time he shops.Â  This week it was more coffee.Â  In my opinion, one can never have too much coffee.Â  Or chocolate.The past few days have included rearranging shelves in order to make space for more canning jars of food.Â  When I described the process to a friend, she remarked that it sounded like a game of Tetris.Â  Move this here - fit something else in there.Â  I think she is right.Â  Thankfully Oldest Son helps me with storage. That's pretty much what is happening in my little corner of the world.Â  Things around us look somewhat dicey.Â  Keep on prepping!

title: New Year's Resolutions
text: There are some who use the new year as an opportunity to make lifestyle changes by making resolutions.Â  I am not one of those people.I have tried over the years.Â  I really have. But I think the longest time that elapsed between making the New Year's Resolution and breaking it was maybe a week.Â  I guess I am more of a 'go with the flow' kind of person.That's not to say that one should not have goals.Â  Goals are a good thing.Â  I have goals.Â  One goal is to increase my food storage to have two years worth stashed away.Â  Another goal is to make sure I have enough of other essentials that may be needed within that time frame.The New Year is nearly upon us.Â  I have seen 73 of them.Â  Some good - some not so much.Â  But I am thankful to God for allowing me to see each and every one of them.Â  I pray He will give me a few more.None of us knows for sure what 2020 will bring.Â  Those who are oblivious of the world situation are convinced all is well.Â  Those of us who pay attention know better.Â  But whatever happens, we would do well to be as ready as possible.Hope for the best - prepare for the worst.Â  And pray.

title: Small Town Answer to the Christmas Grinch
text: In 2015, the city government officials were forced to remove a Nativity Scene that had been a tradition for over 40 years in the small north central town of Wadena, Minnesota.Â  The reason?Â  The Freedom From Religion Foundation, an atheist group that hates all forms of religion, threatened to sue the town. Wadena with its population of under 5000 souls, could little afford a court battle.What happened next was quite remarkable.It seems the law indicates that religious scenes may not be displayed on public property.Â  However, they are perfectly acceptable on private property.The City sold the offending Manger Scene to the local Catholic Church for mere pennies on the dollar who then displayed it on their property.The shop owners displayed Nativity Scenes in their shop windows.Â  Some did decorative painted Nativity Scenes on their store windows.The good citizens of Wadena set out Manger Scenes on their front lawns.Word got out and other good folks drove hundreds of miles to this little town to donate Nativity Scenes to be displayed.By the time all was said and done, there were at least 1,000 Nativity Scenes displayed throughout the town.Take that, atheists!!May the Spirit of one small town in Minnesota be an example to the rest of us to stand up and be counted for our beliefs.This is me...Wishing each and every one of you a very Merry and most importantly, a Blessed Christmas.

title: Surprises
text: Anyone who visits here regularly knows that I use a grocery delivery service due to physical limitations.Â  Here is how it works:The company issues a catalog once a year, listing all the groceries I can order.Every other Monday a volunteer calls me and takes my order that is delivered, for a small fee, to my kitchen table on the following Thursday.Most times the groceries I order on Monday are the same as the ones I receive on Thursday.Â  This time, however, I ordered 4 bags of frozen cut green beans - and received 4 bags of frozen collard greens.Â  Surprise!What does a woman born and raised in the tundra of Minnesota know about collard greens.Â  I have never even tasted collard greens.Â  Spinach - yes.Â  Collard greens - no.I suppose I could have called the delivery guy and he would have come back and picked up the bags of collard greens and given me credit on my bill, but I thought, "What the hey.Â  Live dangerously."So I put them on dehydrator trays along with 2 bags of frozen spinach and 4 bags of frozen hash browns.Â  All of the veggies are now dry, packaged, labeled and added to the shelf of dehydrated food.Â I had also ordered 2 bags of frozen sweet potatoes to dehydrate.Â  I thought they were sweet potatoes cut into chunks or slices.Â  What I got was 2 bags of sweet potato fries.Â  Surprise!Â  Because the fries are cut fairly thin, I am not sure how well they would rehydrate, so into the freezer they went and I will have an occasional meal that includes sweet potato fries.A week or so ago I experimented with dehydrating raisins.Â  The reasoning behind this was that raisins we buy at the store still have moisture in them and likely would not be a good item for long term storage.Â  But dehydrated, they could last a very long time without going bad.Â  Dried, they resembled small wrinkly pebbles.Â  I put some of the raisins in water and let them sit on the counter overnight.Â  In the morning I had nice, plump raisins that can be used however I wish.Â  I will dehydrate more raisins.Â  Variety is good.I had another experiment that was a dismal failure.Â  I have several quart bags of shredded zucchini in the freezer.Â  I thawed out two of them, drained off the water and dried them.Â  When I soaked them in water, they rehydrated alright, but somewhere in the process, two quarts became about a pint total of shredded zucchini.Â  I don't know if that was because they were frozen before dehydrating.Â  Freshly shredded zucchini might work better, but for now, I will keep the remaining bags in the freezer, and if I get my hands on more zucchini, I will slice and dry rather than shred.Life seems to be full of little surprises. I wasn't happy about the collard greens, but if nothing else, they can always be used as a filler in soup.Â  They won't go to waste.Â  Now when we can afford an occasional failure is the time to experiment, rather than further down the road when every ounce of food will be needed.Â  Learning to roll with the surprises and learning to make do with what we have will make the hard times just a bit easier.Keep on prepping.

title: Wake Up Call
text: I may have mentioned before that I have an old school mate who keeps me informed as to what is going on in this crazy world of ours.Â  He is a Vietnam vet and retired cop.Â  I trust his word.Â  Completely.Yesterday I emailed him, asking him if his 'good old boy cop network' had any notion of how law enforcement would react to the gun grabbing laws like Virginia and Washington State are pushing for.Â  He said the out state officers are pro gun, but the administration in the city areas are totally anti-gun.Â  He went on to say that here in Minnesota, the State Senate is only two votes away from enacting the same laws as VA and WA.He went on to elaborate that he thinks Washington will not wait until the 2020 election but will keep trying to remove Trump regardless.Â  By any means necessary.Â  He is looking at food shortages and gun grabs.Â  He just ordered 1800 servings of freeze dried products.Â  He has alternate places to go when things get really bad.My friend says he is scared for his kids and grands who don't see the threat he sees.Â  This man has had a life of service and still at the same age as me, teaches conceal carry classes and is involved in martial arts.Â Â  I will tell you true - if he is scared, I am terrified.The time to get the ducks in the row is now.Â  We may still have time.Â  Or we may not.Â  The hatred from the left is so completely insane that I wouldn't be surprised at anything they would do now to grab the power they so desperately seek and to push their socialist/globalist agenda.Â  Trump is about all that stands in their way.Every extra can of food, every extra jar we home can, every extra pound of flour we set aside means one more day we can survive when it all goes south.Pray and prepare.

title: Arthritis...
text: is an insidious disease.Â  Those of us who have it will have good days where the joint pain involved is at a minimum and we will have days where it pretty much kicks our butts.Â  These last few days where Mother Nature has decided that Minnesota needs to be a deep freeze have been of the butt kicking variety.Those days will often find me curled up in my recliner, wrapped in my green fuzzy blanket, reading murder mysteries from my Kindle.Â  Other times I can be found at my computer, working on organizing my family tree or maybe sorting out the vast number of family photos I have saved.Â  But sometimes I just stroll through cyberspace, reading articles and viewing videos that catch my interest.One such article caught my eye.Â  Portland, Oregon has a very large homeless population.Â  Now I have the deepest sympathy for those who find themselves in that situation.Â  There have been a couple of times in my life where I was just a few dollars away from finding myself in the same situation.Â  But today's homeless also include drug addicts, alcoholics and the mentally ill.One would think that the solutions might be found in finding ways to treat the underlying problems.Â  But Portland's Commissioners are working on another solution.Â  They propose that when a new building is built, the property owners will be required to provide 'safe spaces' for the homeless to camp out.Political Correctness has definitely run amok.Â  Instead of looking to provide services for those in need, their solution is to let the problems continue, but at the expense of property owners and the expense of those who will live in those buildings with the required safe spaces for the homeless.There is an apartment building going up across the street from where I live.Â  If that building were to include space for the homeless to pitch their tents, I would not be pleased.Â  I have already over the years watched drug deals go down in the alley across from my living room windows.Â  I live next door to a bar.Â  I see the effects of excessive boozing.Â  Every community has its share of untreated mentally ill.Â  To live in a building that welcomes these problems on the grounds is unsafe and unhealthy at best and horrific at worst.Â  And it does nothing to help those in need.We spend billions of tax dollars in aid to foreign countries.Â  Seems to me that using some of that money to find ways to actually help these people rather than just shuffle them off to another area of the city would make sense.I guess common sense does not exist in government any more, be it on the national or local level.The temps here are rising.Â  This flare-up of arthritis seems to be ebbing.Â  I have hope that within a day or so I will be able to resume regular activities.Â  Until then, an Agatha Christie novel is calling my name.Â  :)

title: Catching Up
text: Today was grocery delivery day.Â  After putting groceries away, I started peeling 15 lbs. of potatoes and 2 lbs. of carrots.Â  In the morning they will be diced into 1/2-inch dices, blanched and set to dehydrating.Â I am experimenting with dehydrating raisins.Â  I know that others have made their own raisins by dehydrating grapes, but grapes are a bit pricey here and it is more cost effective to dry store bought raisins for a longer term storage.Every two weeks I get two 5 lb. bags of flour and two 4 lb. bags of sugar.Â  I had fallen behind on repackaging these into Ziploc bags and stored in 5 gallon buckets, so that was my next project.Â  Into the pantry closet they went.I found two large bags of pancake mix still in their paper packaging that I had forgotten about.Â  Bugs like paper packaging, so into Ziplocs went the pancake mix.Â  I have been big on making my own mixes or making foods like pancakes from scratch.Â  That's fine under ordinary circumstances.Â  But I got to thinking that in an SHTF situation I might not be able to get eggs to make pancakes.Â  Cans of powdered eggs are not within my budget, so having pancake mix that requires only water makes sense to me.I have found that in my area, instant powdered milk has gone way up in price.Â  I use powdered milk for many of the mixes I make, but with the increase in price, it is becoming cheaper for me to buy some ready made mixes rather than make my own.All we need do is watch about a half hour of news to see how completely crazy our world has become.Â  I don't know about the rest of you, but I plan to continue to add as much food to my preps as I can before we go completely off the rails.

title: Back to Busy
text: It was lovely to have a week off, but the insanity surrounding us seems to take no time off at all, so it is back at it for me.Â I have 2 lbs. of carrots ready to go into the dehydrator.Â  My grocery order goes in today for delivery on Thursday and I have ordered 10 lbs. of potatoes to go with the 5 lbs. I have left over from the last order.Â  So Friday I will cut the potatoes into 1/2-inch cubes and dehydrate them as well.Â I am ordering a canister of raisins.Â  I saw where raisins can be dehydrated so they can be stored for long term, so I am going to give that a try to see how well that works.Â  If the experiment is successful, I may dry more.Each order includes sugar and flour.Â  I read somewhere that one of the first food items rationed during wartime was sugar.Â  I haven't the space in my small apartment to store wheat, but have had success in repackaging flour in heavy duty Ziploc bags, filling buckets with the bags and keeping them in the coolest room.Â  It takes a considerable amount of flour just to keep me supplied with bread.Â  If I am feeding several family members, I don't want to run out of flour should I be unable to get more.I also have another can of coffee coming.Â  One just can not have too much coffee stored.Â  :)I haven't just been sitting on the couch eating bon bons and watching soaps while I have been on time off.Â  As tempting as that might have been, I did manage to finish one window quilt top.Â  Here it is.Â  Not a very good photo, but I think you can get the general idea.The others are nearly done, and then it is just to add the flannel batting and the backing, and they can go up on curtain rods. I know these are not your standard window treatments.Â  But I like them.Â  They are bright and cheerful and they make me happy.Â  I can just tie them back during the day to let the sunshine in.That's pretty much all I know today.Â  Evil has not been on vacation so it is time to press on with the prepping. Â  We may need it sooner than we think.

title: Time Off
text: I am taking this week off to get ready for the holiday.Â  I'll be back Monday with bells on.Â  Well, maybe the bells are a bit too much, but I will see you all then.Â  Wishing all of you a Happy Thanksgiving.

title: Tired Of It All
text: First our President was accused of being an agent for Russia.Â  Nearly three years and many millions of tax dollars later, the special council in charge of the investigation and his band of attorneys could find no basis for the accusation.Now our President is undergoing an impeachment investigation over a phone call to the President of Ukraine.Â  A phone call that was made public and contains nothing even close to 'crimes or misdemeanors.'And yet the dog and pony show in the House committee continues.Â  They call it an 'Impeachment Inquiry.'Â  That is not what it is.Â  It is just the latest effort by those left leaning politicians to oust our duly elected president.Â  To tell those whose votes elected him that their votes really do not matter.Â  And if this effort fails, you can bet your bottom dollar they will try something else.I am tired of it.Â  I am tired of it all.Â  President Trump is the only thing standing in the way of those who would shred our Constitution and initiate their socialist ideals.Â  Those same socialist ideals that brought us those freedom loving leaders in China, Vietnam, Cuba, North Korea and Venezuela.Â Seems to me those House of Representative Democrats have forgotten just who they work for.Â  They are the People's House, but they have done very little to benefit 'We the People.'Â  Instead they waste time and our money feeding their hatred.Â If they can do this to a duly elected President, imagine what they can do to you.

title: It snowed.
text: Again.Â  So I made a big bowl of potato salad and a ham sandwich and went on a picnic by the lake in my mind.Â  Sometimes when the world around me has gone completely bat guano crazy, a little voyage through fantasy land is all that keeps me sane.Work on the quilts is coming along slowly but surely.Â  Today I should be able to get most of the quilt tops finished and with any kind of luck at all, I hope to hang them in the windows by the first part of next week.I bought a bag of oranges that turned out to be too sour for my taste, so I sliced them thin and they are now in the dehydrator.Â  I have no idea what I will use dried orange slices for, but it seemed a shame to waste them.Baked another loaf of bread.Â  Using the bread machine, it takes very little time or effort and I am liking the homemade bread so much better than store bought.Â  I really don't know why I haven't been doing this all along.Â  I suppose it is like Dad used to say, "Too soon old, too late smart."Â  :)There is a sewing machine and a stack of fabric pieces calling my name.Â  Best get back at it.Â  Pictures to follow when they are done.

title: How Did They Cope
text: While on R & R, I watched two British TV series found on YouTube - 'Wartime Farm' and 'Wartime Kitchen and Garden.'Â  Both series dealt with the way the people of England coped with the trials and tribulations of WWII, focusing on how farmers had to increase food production and how the average family dealt with restrictions and rationing.A couple of things caught my attention.Â  One was how the people were able to find ways of doing things when the normal solutions to problems were unavailable to them.Â  They went to the farm scrap heap for materials to make the tools they needed.Â  The gardeners found ways to use every available square inch of space to grow the much needed food.Â  Homemakers came up with ways to stretch the meager rations to feed their families and other ways to do what needed to be done in the home under difficult circumstances.Another thing that caught my attention was that one and all were not only willing but happy to "do their bit" in the war effort.Â  They dealt with most circumstances, many of them difficult even in the best of times, without complaint.Â  They were more concerned about their 'boys on the front line' than they were for their own comforts.Â  They were patriotic.I'm not sure we here in the States, at this time in history, could manage so well.Â  We did cope similarly during that wartime, but we have become spoiled and way too dependent on gadgets for every purpose.Â  We have mostly lost the knowledge our ancestors had that enabled them to make do in dire situations.Â  And I don't think we have come together asÂ  nation, leaving our political viewpoints and prejudices behind, since 9/11.Â  We can do better.So I am off to run bits of fabric through my sewing machine.Â  We had an inch or two of snow last week and a dusting of the white stuff yesterday.Â  Today is clear and cold with temps close to single digits.Â  Quilts need to be finished.Â  And I think a pot of soup is in my future.Stay warm and keep on prepping.

title: Those of us who have physical limitations...
text: have learned over time to pay attention to what our bodies tell us.Â  We know when we can forge ahead and we know when we need to back off and rest.Â  The next day or two I believe I will be in 'rest mode.'I mention this not because I am in a 'poor, pitiful me' place, but as an encouragement to others who may be facing similar circumstances.Â  You see, there are those who tell us it is all just in our heads.Â  Or we want sympathy.Â  Or it is just an excuse to avoid something we do not want to do.Â  It is none of these things.The people who say these things to us are, for the most part, still able to hike up a mountain or go for a run or do the weekly housework in just a couple of hours.Â  Because they don't have to deal with shortness of breath or pain in joints or any number of symptoms that plague the elderly,Â  they don't understand what it is like for those who deal with these things on a daily basis.Â  And I hope they never have to deal with limitations.All things considered, I have accomplished quite a bit this week.Â  I have drawn around a plastic template 810 times and cut out that many fabric rectangles.Â  The 2-inch x 4-inch rectangles have been pinned and mostly sewn together giving me 4-inch x 4-inch squares.Â  I have maybe 50 left to sew.Â  When that is done, the squares will be sewn into rows of nine squares each.Â  15 rows will make one window quilt top.In keeping with the theme of using what is on hand, I found I may have enough flannel left on the bolt I used for bandages and family cloths to use instead of regular quilt batting.Â  I think that will be enough to make the window quilts thick enough to keep out the drafts.Â  By using old sheets for the backs of the quilts, the only things I need to buy are curtain rods to hang them.Â  I love it when a plan comes together.Today was grocery delivery day.Â  As I am not going to be doing any canning until after the holidays, the order was mostly canned goods like fruit and corned beef hash.Â  The rest was staples like flour, sugar, cornmeal.Â  We won't mention the package of Oreos - Double Stuff.Â  :)It was after I put everything away that my body said, 'OK.Â  That's enough.Â  Rest time coming up.'I will be back at it in a day or two.Â  Those of us who have limitations don't like it much.Â  We wish those around us understood this is not by choice.Â  My kids and grands get it.Â  They see me often enough to understand.Â  Others - not so much.Â  But we learn to cope as best we can.Â  And we find that even with limitations, life can be really grand!

title: Back to Basics
text: This morning I had a bit of a wake up call.Â  Nearly two weeks ago I had put a loaf of bread in my refrigerator and then promptly forgot about it.Â  I found it this morning.Â  When I took it out and looked at it, I was amazed to see there wasn't even one spot of mold on it and the slices were still soft.Â  That scared me just a little bit.Â  When I looked at the ingredients on the bag, most of them had names I can't pronounce.The list of ingredients was lengthy.Â  The bread recipe I use contains seven.Â  And I can pronounce all of them.Â  Granted, at my age I probably could use all the preservatives I can get, but this list on the bag was a bit much.Thing is...I had become lazy and had stopped making my own bread.Â  I don't even have the excuse of physical limitations because it takes very little effort to dump ingredients into a bread machine.Â  And even without the machine I believe I could still turn out a respectable loaf of bread.So it is back to the basics for me.Â  Jennifer over at 'Prep School Daily' - listed in my side bar - has a recipe for a Soup and Sauce Mix that I am planning to try in order to use in place of condensed cream soups and basic sauces and she has several recipes for it's use.Â  Considering the price of a can of 'cream of' soups now, it makes sense to find cheaper and more healthy alternatives.Grandma managed to feed a family of nine children without the use of convenience foods.Â  I expect I can manage a meal for one without them.

title: Drowning in Fabric...
text: It is amazing to me just how many yards of fabric scraps one person can accumulate.Â  I discovered I not only had plenty of scrap fabric for the window quilts, there is more than enough for at least one full sized quilt.Â  As long as I was making a mess with little snippets of cloth, I decided to cut out enough pieces for the quilt along with the window quilt pieces.Years past it would have been a quick and easy job of cutting quilt pieces for patchwork, using a heavy plastic ruler and a rotary cutter.Â  However, as with many of my vintage, arthritis in the hands is causing problems.Â  I have tried every trick in the book, but I am unable to keep the cutter straight and the ruler as firmly in place to be able to cut precise pieces.Â  So I have reverted to the method I used many years ago before the newer cutting methods were available.Â  I made a template of plastic and draw around it for each patchwork piece, cutting them out with a scissors, giving each piece about a quarter inch seam allowance, using the pencil line as my sewing guide.Â  Time consuming - yes.Â  But I was wasting too much fabric when the ruler would slip or when my fingers couldn't control the direction of the rotary cutter.Â  Using a template is an old time method, but it works. I am spending today cutting fabric.Â  A friend mentioned the British TV series, 'Wartime Kitchen and Garden.Â  I found it on YouTube and am watching that today as I work.Â  It is about how cooks and gardeners coped with the food rationing in England during WWII.Â  So far I am finding lots of useful information that may be needed right here at home, if things continue to slide downhill.I hope to start sewing by the weekend.Â  Until then, back at it.Â  Only about 500 more pieces to go.Â  Sigh.

title: A New Project
text: My son walked in the other day with news that the construction that has begun across the street will be a seven story apartment building.Â  I have three windows in my living room that face the street and the construction.Â  Granted, I doubt there will be much construction before spring, but like my son said, when the building is occupied, unless I get some curtains on the windows in my second floor apartment, I will be living in a goldfish bowl.Minnesota gets a bit nippy in the winter.Â  Blizzards are not uncommon.Â  Below zero temps for days on end are the norm.Â  I have found that even though my windows are new, they still can be a little bit drafty when the wind is strong.Â  Many people use plastic to keep out the winter cold, but I don't much care for that solution. I decided to make three window quilts to fit the windows.I am making scrap quilts, using the fabric scraps I have leftover from other projects.Â  I also have a number of cream colored sheets that can be used for the backs of the quilts.Â  I can use tie backs to let in light during the day.Â  There are enough sheets to also make curtain panels to use in the warmer months.I suppose I could have just purchased thermal drapes, but I really like the idea of using what I have on hand.Â  My bank account likes it, too.Â  The only thing I need buy is the batting for the window quilts.Â  This is good practice for a time when we may have to learn to make do with what we have.I will post pictures when the quilts are finished, but don't hold your breath.Â  Making quilts take time.Â  I do hope to finish them by the time the temperatures head downward. It is not unusual to have snow by Thanksgiving, so I had better get busy.Â  :)

title: Food as a Weapon
text: Most of us who are into prepping have heard a slacker or two say, "Well, if things ever get really bad, I will just come to your house."Â  Or they ridicule us for stockpiling food.Â  Or they tell us we are wasting our time by canning and dehydrating because we can buy whatever we want at the grocery store.We have heard it often enough.Â  Mostly from those whose priorities are big screen TVs, new vehicles and vacations in exotic lands.Â  The same ones who run up their credit cards to own the latest gadget or buy the designer clothes in order to impress their friends. They have no earthly idea what is happening right here in our own country because they either aren't paying attention or they believe what they hear from lying politicians and the main stream media.There is no way to sugar coat the truth.Â  We are in trouble.Â  America is deeply divided in every way.Â  Some say a civil war has already begun.Â  Senseless violence is becoming the norm.Â  And in Washington, there are those who are doing their level best to remove our duly elected president from office.Make no mistake.Â  What is happening is nothing less than a coup de tat.Â  Have you thought about what could happen if it is successful?Â  What life will be like if we refuse to comply?Ol' Remus over at the Woodpile Report gives us examples of what has happened when socialism has reared its ugly head.Â  You might want to take a look.Â  I'll wait.This is why we spend hours and hours canning and dehydrating food.Â  This is why we buy extra food with each grocery shopping trip.Â  This is why we prepare.If you don't think something similar could happen here, you are sadly mistaken.My thanks to CW in Iowa for the 'heads up' on the article in the Woodpile Report.Â  And as she often says, "Keep on prepping."

title: Nuthin'
text: Occasionally my mind goes on vacation and leaves me here all by myself.Â  That seems to be the case today.Â  After several false starts on a blog post, I have come to the conclusion I have nuthin'.Â  So rather than bore you, I am going to spend this cold, rainy day at my sewing machine.Â  Perhaps my mind will return tomorrow with something worth writing about.Â  Until then, those folks in the side bar have lots of good things to say.

title: Common Sense Prepping
text: When I first realized the need to be prepared for bad times, I did some online research.Â  I watched videos.Â  I read blogs.Â  I looked up statistics.I found there was a vast amount of information out there.Â  There were sites that told me about the gear that every prepper had to have.Â  There were lists of foods that were absolutely necessary to store.Â  Other sites showed me how to survive out in the woods.I dutifully made lists of the recommended items.Â  I searched online for the best prices on various items.Â  I worked out scenarios of what would constitute a SHTF moment and what would be needed in those situations.And then my common sense side said, "Hold on.Â  How much of this stuff really applies to you."First off, I am not going to be building any shelters in the middle of the forest.Â  I am an old woman with health issues.Â  I am connected 24/7 to an oxygen machine, fondly referred to as R2D2, due to it's size and shape.Â  I would be hard pressed to make it to the end of the block, to say nothing of heading to the hills.Â  Having knowledge of bushcraft skills might be fine for someone young and healthy, but for me...not so much.These facts eliminated the need for specialized gear.Â  My gear consists of a variety of flashlights, oil lamps and candles.Â  It includes a propane camp stove and a propane space heater.Â  It also includes two pressure canners and two dehydrators.Â  The dehydrators will be useless if the lights go out, but in the meantime they have made it possible to stock up on dried food.Â  The rest of my gear is the normal household tools and utensils.Most of those of my vintage are on a fixed income.Â  We can't justify spending large amounts of money on the recommended freeze dried foods or the pre-packaged ready to eat meals.Â  My solution to this problem is home canning of a variety of meats and vegetables and fruits along with lots of soups and stews that only need to be heated or, in a pinch, can be eaten right out of the jar.Not everyone has the skills or equipment for home canning.Â  But by adding a few extra cans of food every time one shops for groceries, a deep pantry can be a reality over time.Â  Some of you are aware of the fact that due to health issues, I use a grocery delivery service.Â  Each delivery includes a couple of items I can not make at home, like sugar, flour, powdered milk, rice, etc.Â  These are stored away for future use. I use what I store, so food is rotated out and replaced regularly.I once watched a video of a woman who had a full sized chest of drawers completely filled with health and medical supplies.Â  She had everything from leg splints to neck braces to several kinds of over the counter pain killers to vitamins of every kind. There were medications for every possible situation.Â  I was impressed.But I can not afford to do the same.Â  What I have done is to stock up on the basics - aspirin, burn cream, peroxide, alcohol, band-aids, cough drops, etc.Â  I add to the stash from time to time - items like diarrheaÂ medication, multi vitamins, antibiotic salves.Â  And I found a good First-Aid book that covers the common medical and injury needs.If a person has the wherewithal and the storage space for a full compliment of prepping items, good for them.Â  But most of us tend to pinch a penny or two in our daily lives, so we do the best we can with what we have to work with.The main point is that we do something.Â  Sitting idly by, waiting for the government to rescue us in times of disaster isn't going to cut it.Â  The way things are going, I doubt that rescue will be on the minds of 'our betters.'Â  Seems more likely they will be the ones we have to watch out for.Â  The better prepared we are, the better our chances.Keep on prepping.

title: Proud Grandma
text: A week or so ago I received a phone call from granddaughter Maddie Mae.Â  She was letting me know that she had been accepted into the National Honor Society.Â  I made her promise to send me pictures of her induction into the Society.This is my Maddie Mae, showing her induction certificate.Â  She works hard to maintain a very high grade average and I am really glad that her hard work has been rewarded.Â  She has earned the honor.I got a bonus picture of Maddie with her family - my son, his son and daughters and his lovely wife.I am so very pleased with the way David and Staci are raising their children.Â  They are being taught the values that seem to be going by the wayside in our country.Â  They know how to work and they know that not everyone gets a trophy - it has to be earned.Â  Family time is important to this group.Â  And the result is three good kids.Maddie Mae - I am so very proud of you and your accomplishments.Â  And it makes me happy that you called to share your news about your induction into the National Honor Society with me.Â  This post is for you, Sweetheart.Love, Grandma

title: Civilized Behavior Is a Thing of the Past
text: My youngest son planned to go to the Trump Rally in Minneapolis Thursday.Â  As it turned out, the friend he planned to go with couldn't make it and David decided not to go alone.Â  I am glad he didn't.I am not glad he missed the rally for I think he would have enjoyed it.Â  But I am glad and relieved he missed the aftermath.The animals were protesting in the streets outside the venue. And the four legged kinds of animals are better behaved than those sorry excuses for human beings.They carried signs filled with vulgarity.Â  They screamed obscenities.Â  They harassed the police.Â  They threw rocks and bottles at the police.Â  They threw rocks and bottles at the horses of the horse patrol.Â  They started fires in the streets.Â  They harassed and bullied innocent people leaving the venue who were just trying to get to their vehicles to go home.Â  They threw rocks and bottles at the cars leaving.Â  They threw jars of urine on supporters of our President.Â It saddened me to see the behavior of these thugs here in my home state.Â  We are supposed to be a state where nice, friendly people live.Â  And for the most part, we are.Â  But when people act like this over just a political rally, what do you suppose they will do when the sh** really does hit the fan?This was a wake-up call for me.Â  It not only showed me that my efforts to get ready for whatever happens are spot on, it was a lesson on how low humans can sink when they don't get their way.Â  The attempt to shut down the rally ahead of time failed and this was their answer.Â  The mayor of Minneapolis didn't help the situation.Â  He declared it "Love to Hate Trump Day."I don't care what the political leanings are as long as we can treat each other with respect.Â  They can protest all they want.Â  It is their right.Â  But when they become a mob of thugs trying to physically hurt those on the other side, that is where I draw the line.This mob showed me what to expect in the future - maybe sooner than we think.Â  I believe that 'keep on prepping' and 'keep your powder dry' both fall under the category of Good Advice.

title: Minnesota Cops Fight Back
text: I love my home state of Minnesota.Â  It is a beautiful state, from the rolling farmlands in the southern and central parts of the state to the pine forests of the north, to its '10,000 lakes.'Â  It is true that winters are interesting with occasional blizzards and massive snowfalls, but if you have ever walked through woods so quiet you can hear the snowflakes touch the ground, you will understand true beauty.Â  I have sat on the deck of my brother's home and watched a small black bear up a tree on the other side of his driveway.Â  I have watched yearling fawns running and jumping and playing in the first snowfall of the year.Â  I have heard the haunting songs of the loons calling to one another across the waters of some of the most beautiful lakes anywhere.Â  I have spent hours, rod and reel in hand, catching the best tasting fresh water fish.You may have heard the term 'Minnesota Nice.'Â  If you get away from the hustle and bustle of the cities, you will find it in abundance.Â  The people are for the most part, friendly.Â  Neighbors help neighbors.Â  They get together for summer barbecues and winter snowmobile rides.Â  People you don't know will wave in passing.Â  They will go out of their way to help someone in need.There are good folks living in the cities, but sadly, the political climate is decidedly left leaning, complete with the current Trump Derangement Syndrome.Â  President Trump is holding a rally in Minneapolis this week.Â  The mayor of Minneapolis has decreed that police officers appearing at the rally are not allowed to wear their uniforms even though officers have traditionally been at events in uniform.Â  He has also decided to charge the Trump campaign way more for security than has ever been charged for an event before.Â  The hope was that Trump would cancel the rally.Â  The mayor obviously doesn't understand the concept of 'fighting back.'He also doesn't understand what it does to morale when officers are told they can not wear a uniform they are proud to wear.Â  So the officers in the Minneapolis Police Department fought back and they designed this:The officers will be wearing this shirt to the rally.Â  They have offered it for sale on their website.Â  (Note:Â  When I tried to post a link to the MPD Federation website, I found a notice that the website has been suspended.Â  I don't know if that is just temporary or permanent.Â  Odd, that.).Â Â Â  All proceeds go to charity.Â  A spokesman for the Department said in an interview that they would like to flood the audience with red shirts.My goal here is not to sell t-shirts.Â  I have no connection to this effort.Â  But I do love the fact that these police officers, who put their lives on the line for us every single day, have decided to fight back against tyrannical politicians.Â  God bless them for having the courage of their convictions.Â  If more of us did what we could to fight back against those who would try to take our freedoms from us, we might not be so close to losing them to those who think they know better than we do how we should live our lives.

title: Everyday Stuff
text: The leaves here in southern Minnesota are beginning to turn colors.Â  The daytime temps are now in the 50's and 60's and the northern part of the state has already had a hard frost.Â  It is the time of year when we in the north begin to prepare for massive amounts of ice and snow and sub-zero temperatures.I taste tested the chicken vegetable soup I canned last week.Â  That is some seriously good soup.Â  I had layered 1/2 cup chicken, 1/3 cup each corn, carrots and peas and 1/4 cup each of celery and onions in each pint jar.Â  On top of that went a chicken bouillon cube and the jars were filled with water.Â  They were processed for 75 minutes.Â  This has become my new favorite go-to soup.I am running low on canning jars again, so it is time to concentrate on other items for my food storage.Â  I transferred four containers of cornmeal to zip lock bags and stashed them away.Â  Bugs seem to like the cardboard and paper containers, but I have had no problems with keeping dry food in zip lock bags.Â  I also have been ordering extra sugar and flour with each grocery order, and need to get more molasses to use in making my own brown sugar (1 Tablespoon molasses to 1 Cup of sugar).I had bought 10 lbs of potatoes, thinking I would use some of them in the soup, but decided instead to dehydrate them.Â  So later today I will be peeling, slicing and blanching and getting them into the dehydrators.Yesterday I made up several more of my cookie mixes - chocolate chip and oatmeal - which are my favorites of the cookie mix recipes HERE.Â  I need to make up some brownie mixes and more hot chocolate mix.Â  The hot chocolate mix seems to disappear quickly these days.Winter is my time for needlework.Â  I have picked up where I left off on my youngest grandkid's graduation afghan and have been spending evenings with a crochet hook and usually a movie.Â  I am sick to death of the dog and pony show that is Washington these days and am back to reading headlines only.Â  Keeps my blood pressure on an even keel.Â :)That's about it for me here in my little corner of the world.Â  Hope things are going well with all of you and that your pantrys are filling up.Â  I am hearing rumors that a long, cold winter is coming, at least for us here in the tundra.Â  Keep on prepping.

title: Sheâ€™s Back
text: Knowing his mother was likely going through withdrawal withouta working computer, Youngest Son took pity on me and delivered a new one today.Â  And, bless his heart, he got it up andrunning for me as well.Â  Later on I willtake both laptops to the computer doctor to see if they can be salvaged forbackups.Â  Thankfully, I have an externalhard drive so I didnâ€™t lose anything important.The end of last week and the weekend were taken up withcanning.Â  I wound up with 54 pints ofchicken vegetable soup, 32 half pints of chicken and 24 half pints of theleftover veggies.Â  I will be concentratingon other preps as I am nearly out of canning jars and definitely out of shelfspace.The weather here is weird.Â We have been having beautiful, cool fall temps.Â  But today the thermometer reads in the mid 80â€™swith 75% humidity.Â  But tomorrow promisesto be back down to the 60â€™s.Â  I like thatmuch better.So I believe the rest of the afternoon will be spentinstalling programs and figuring out a new operating system.Â  Not my most favorite thing to do, but I wonâ€™tcomplain.Â  I have a computer that works,and that makes me a very happy, chubby granny.Â ðŸ˜Š

title: Dead Computer
text: My main computer went belly up this morning.Â  The old one I am on right now heats up within minutes.Â  So I will be off line until Youngest Son brings me a new computer, hopefully over the weekend.Â  Other than learning some not so nice words while dealing with the dead computer, all is well here in my little corner of the world.

title: More Canning
text: Last evening my long, tall son dragged the last eight chickens from my freezer.Â  This morning I cooked three in stock pots on top of the stove, baked two in a roasting pan in the oven and cooked another three in my electric roaster.Â  All eight are cooling in bowls and pans on the kitchen table.Â  As soon as they are cool enough to handle, the meat will be removed from the bones and stored in the fridge.Â  Tomorrow some of the meat will be canned, part of it in half pint jars, which is a good size for sandwiches like a can of tuna, and more in pints.My Thursday grocery delivery includes frozen peas and corn, potatoes, onions, carrots and celery.Â  Lots of them.Â  These will be chopped and added to chicken in pint jars with a bit of chicken bouillon on top for flavor.Â  This will be canned as chicken vegetable soup.Â  If there are any vegetables left over I will use them for vegetable bean soup.So if things are quiet here, you know that I haven't run away from home.Â  I am just up to my neck in chicken.Â  :)

title: Stand Up For What Is Right
text: The 'Freedom From Religion Foundation,' an atheist group that is notorious for doing everything they possibly can to eliminate religion from the public square, has been bested by a group of school kids.A high school in Alabama traditionally offered a prayer over the loudspeakers before football games.Â  This, of course, caused the atheists to get their knickers in a twist and they pressured school officials to eliminate the prayer and replace it with a moment of silence.The kids were having none of it.Â  At the next football game the students stood en masse along with the rest of the fans and loudly recited The Lord's Prayer.Â  The full article is HERE.We hear about students who are woefully ignorant when it comes to their grasp of the Constitution and the Bill of Rights.Â  We hear of kids who blindly follow along with whatever is the latest stupidity preached by the lunatic left.Â  But these kids made a decision to literally stand up for their beliefs.I applaud this group of students as well as their parents who obviously raised them right.

title: A Drama Free Life
text: There have been a couple of days of R & R going on here.Â  That is par for the course when one has been going nuts with canning.Â  Now fully rested, it is time to get busy again.I have eight more whole chickens in the freezer and hopefully my long, tall son will drag four of them out tomorrow so they can thaw and I will then cook them up and can the meat.Â  I have plans for the last four chickens that include ordering a variety of fresh and frozen vegetables that will be delivered Thursday next week to layer in jars along with the chicken for chicken vegetable soup to can.Other than plans for the next few days, life just goes quietly on.Â  There is enough crazy and drama in the news, so I don't need to create any here.Â  The biggest thing happening will be the arrival of my daughter tomorrow, who has promised to show up with bags of shredded zucchini for my freezer.Â  I may have to keep some out for a loaf of zucchini bread.Most times a quiet life and zucchini bread is far preferable to the insanity around us.

title: Beans, Beans, the Musical Fruit...
text: Yesterday I cooked up a double batch of baked beans.Â  The link to the recipe is in the previous post.Â  Because I got a late start, I didn't get them jarred up and canned until today.I used half pint jars.Â  That works out well as a serving for one or two people.Â  I put a couple of pieces of cooked bacon on top of the beans in each jar.Â  Â The last canner load is processing as I write.Â  A double batch gave me 60 half pint jars of baked beans.In about an hour this canner load will be done.Â  And then I do believe a nap is called for.Â  :)Keep on prepping.

title: Bacon Update
text: Over the weekend I turned 25 lbs. of bacon into 38 half pints to add to the shelves.Â  A general rule of thumb is that 1 lb. of meat equals one pint canned.Â  Considering the amount of bacon I set aside for eating and to add to baked beans, along with the amount I consumed for 'quality control,' (Come on.Â  It is bacon.Â  The temptation was just too great.) the amount canned was just about right.Last evening I set 4 quarts of white beans to soaking and they are now in my big electric roaster, cooking.Â  Later this afternoon I will jar them up, add a little cooked bacon to each jar and process them.Â  The recipe can be found HERE.This recipe is kind of fussy and time consuming, what with the pre-cooking, but I have tried several recipes and methods over the years and found this one to be really good.Â  It is worth the time and trouble.I have a long list of food I need to can up before prices become too outrageous.Â  Â I hope my kids won't be too unhappy with me if I wind up needing them to lug more jars up the stairs.Â  Â :)

title: If you had any doubt...
