title: Going AWOL Again
text: Yesterday 25 lbs. of bacon arrived in my kitchen via my son whom I often refer to as my pack mule for all the supplies he has huffed up the stairs to my apartment over the years.Â  After we appropriated several slices each for further use, I sliced the rest into one inch pieces, filling roughly six one-gallon bags plus about 3/4 of a quart bag to be used when canning baked beans.Â So I am off to the kitchen to start browning the bacon, packing it into half pint jars and running it through the pressure canner.Â  I have no clue how long this process will take, but I hope to resurface by Monday.Have yourselves a lovely weekend.

title: We Said We Would Never Forget
text: Those of us who are old enough to remember, know exactly where we were when we heard the news about a plane crashing into the first tower.Â  We watched in horror as the second plane hit the second tower.Â  The news of the plane crashes at the Pentagon and in a field in Pennsylvania came later.Eyes glued to TV screens, we watched the first tower come down, followed by the second.Â  We saw people running in terror, trying to escape the devastation.Â  We later learned that over 3,000 lives were lost that terrible day.That day we came together as a nation.Â  In New York, strangers clung to each other, eyes wide in fear and horror or with tears streaming down grief stricken faces.Â  In small towns all across America, folks gathered on street corners, looking up at a sky empty of planes and wondering how on earth something like this could happen here.Before 9/11, we were a patriotic people.Â  But the day after, Old Glory flew everywhere.Â  When the body count came in, we grieved as one.Â  We gathered in churches and prayed for the souls of the dead and for the families left behind.Â  We said we would never, ever forget.But we have forgotten, haven't we.Â  Oh, we remember during the week that marks each anniversary.Â  But during the other 51 weeks of the year, we are more divided than we have been since the Civil War.Â  Many of us are still patriotic.Â  But too many have forgotten what a truly marvelous nation we live in.Â  They would rather turn it into something totally unrecognizable.Â On that day of terror, the first responders ran toward the horrors, the saving of lives their first priority.Â  Over 400 of those brave men and women died in the process.Â  Today firemen, police, emergency medical personnel still rush to the scene in times of trouble.Â  But more and more often, they are exposed to hostile actions from those who have absolutely no respect for their bravery and their willingness to stand between us and evil.I don't ever want to see anything as horrible as we saw on that day.Â  But I sure wouldn't mind seeing seeing a glimpse of the coming together of our country that existed when we all felt wounded and when we all became angry when we discovered the plot to destroy us and when we felt the pride as one nation that even though evil tried to destroy us, we did not break.Â  Yeah, I wouldn't mind seeing that again.

title: How Much Home Canned Food is Enough
text: The other day I was looking at my shelves full of home canned food, feeling all smug and superior - right up to the point where I actually did an inventory.Â  Turns out I don't have enough full jars to feed two of us for a year.Â  And in a crisis situation where I was feeding several family members, the food in jars would be gone quickly.Â  So much for smug superiority.When I figured the amounts needed to feed two people, I went with pint jar size.Â  Figuring one jar each of meat and vegetables daily for the main meal, it would take 365 pints of each for one year.Â  If we had soup for lunch 3 times weekly, I would need 312 pints of soup, as one pint is a meal for one person.Â  If we added fruit to our diet, dividing one pint between two people twice a week, I would need 104 pints.Â  That's over 1100 pints of food.Â  And that's not counting foods like tomatoes, pasta sauce, chicken broth and other foods used to make different dishes.Granted, there are other foods in storage like pasta, rice, beans, cornmeal and oatmeal, along with flour and yeast for making bread.Â  And there are cans of tuna and salmon along with other store bought food in cans.Thing is...it is easy to fool ourselves into thinking we have enough - to become complacent.Â  I have 15 family members, including grands and spouses.Â  I doubt that all of them would come knocking on my door in an emergency situation, but even if half a dozen of them did, I would be hard pressed to be able to feed them for any length of time.Â Now is not the time to slack off.Â  The world around us grows more insane by the day.Â Keep on prepping.

title: Just a Quick Note...
text: first, to say just how awesome I think you all are.Â  I tell you about people who mean something to me who are hurting and you are right there with words of comfort and most importantly, with your prayers.Â  I can not begin to find the words to express my thanks and gratitude.Â  I have had no further word on either of the ladies, but I will update when I do.I will be away from my computer for a couple of days.Â  Yesterday I browned 12 lbs. of hamburger and chopped 2 lbs. of onions that went into my electric roaster today, along with other ingredients for chili.Â  The chili needs to cook a bit longer and then I will start the canning process.Â  That roaster holds a lot of chili!!Â  In between canner loads I am dehydrating frozen hash browns and bags of slaw mix.Â  And there are bags of flour, sugar and rice that came with my grocery order that need to be re-packaged and stored away.Â  Considering I move at the speed of a herd of turtles, I expect I will be busy most of the weekend.Â  :)Hope you all can get out and enjoy the last hurrah of summer.Â  See you next week.

title: Life Can Change in a Heartbeat
text: Most of you who come here regularly are aware that I have a condition that requires nursing services to care for my legs.Â  They do for me what I can not manage to do for myself.Â  They clean the affected areas, apply antibiotic salve and bandages where needed and wrap my legs from toes to knees in Ace bandages to help control fluid build-up.Â  Thanks to their kind and expert care on their three times a week visits, my legs are in better shape now than they have been since this all started.I mention this only to tell you how much I admire and how grateful I am to these ladies who take such good care of me and of many others who need their help.Â  They have chosen careers that are not easy, and yet they are always cheerful and professional.Â  Over time I have gotten to know some of them quite well.Yesterday I learned that the nurse I see most often, the sweet little lady who is expecting her first child in November, had fallen down some stairs.Â  She wasn't badly hurt, but the fall had an effect on her pregnancy.Â  She was hospitalized for 24 hours and is now home, apparently on bed rest, doing everything possible to see to it the baby goes full term.Then I found that the nurse I saw on Monday has suffered a tragic loss.Â  Her grandbaby was found in her crib, non-responsive.Â  The baby was rushed to the hospital and in spite of the best efforts of the doctors, the child couldn't be saved.Â  I can imagine nothing more heart wrenching than to lose a child or grandchild.I don't know what I can do for these ladies who take such good care of me, except to lift them both up in prayer.Â  I hope those of you who are so inclined will join me.

title: I'm Still Here...
text: I haven't fallen off the edge of the earth just yet.Â  I have just been busy.I have had some time between canning sessions so I decided I needed to do some organizing.Â  I am not good being organized.Â  But a friend of mine was telling me about re-organizing her living quarters and that kind of lit a fire under me to get busy and do the same.Â  (It is all your fault - you know who you are.Â  :) )I worked on the organizing project over the weekend and today, getting mostly everything I wanted to done.Â  A couple of hours tomorrow should finish it up except for the 'closet of terror.'Â  That's the closet where everything I don't know what to do with gets stuffed.Â  I'm kind of afraid to open the door.Â  I think something growled at me the last time I did.My regular grocery order will be delivered Thursday.Â  I have food coming for both canning and for dehydrating.Â  Sometimes it is awfully tempting to just say, "Heck with it.Â  I have enough."Â  Thing is, I don't think I will ever have enough.Â  I don't know what is coming.Â  I just know it is not good.Â My morning routine is to drink a couple of cups of coffee while checking out my favorite blogs and the news of the day.Â  I think for a little while I may skip the news.Â  It just gets more stupid by the day.Â  I know I need to keep an eye on what is happening in the world around me, but sometimes I just need a break from the insanity.Â So this evening it is just me, some hand sewing on a quilt top and a movie.Â  With maybe a piece of the wonderful fudge Duane brought me from the State Fair yesterday.Â  Â I had never tasted cherry chocolate fudge before, but I really hope to again.Â  (That's a hint, Son!)

title: Social Security Scam
text: Yesterday my phone rang.Â  Often I let calls go to voice mail, but as I was expecting a call, I answered.Â  The voice on the other end informed me that he was from the Social Security Administration.Â  He further stated that there was a criminal complaint against my Social Security number.Now in all the years I have been dealing with the Social Security Administration, never even once have they called me.Â  If I wish to speak to them, I am the one who initiates the call.Â  If they wish to get in touch with me, they do so via the US Mail.So I told the gentleman that in all fairness and full disclosure, I was informing him that the call was being recorded and would he please clearly state his name, his title and the phone number at which my attorney could reach him to discuss the matter.He hung up.Â  I don't know why.Â  :)We are old.Â  We didn't get to be old by being stupid.

title: Why Prep
text: If we should be foolish enough to announce to friends and family that we are preppers,Â  the most common reaction is that look we get like we have just sprouted another eye on our foreheads or maybe have suddenly grown a third arm.Â  And if we garden or can or dehydrate, the astonishment of those in our circles is increased.The first remarks are usually, "Why would you go to all that work when you can just go to the grocery and buy what you want?"Â  Then we are called conspiracy theorists because nothing bad will ever happen.Â  And then they want to know what on earth will we do with all that food.Â  Or all those medical supplies.Â  Or all of those candles, flashlights, whatever.Â  Followed by the inevitable. "Well, if anything bad ever does happen, I will just come to your house."No.Â  You won't.Like many who are into preparedness, my main concern is my family.Â  A few of them are on board and understand why I do what I do.Â  The rest - not so much.Â  But that doesn't mean that I will turn any of them away should things go south.Â  I couldn't live with myself if I denied any of them food and shelter in hard times.I have had some who want to know what I am preparing for.Â  There are many reasons to be prepared.Â  It doesn't need to be an end of the world apocalypse.Â  Job loss, illness, accident, weather events, anything can cause life as we know it to change.Â  It just makes sense to have something put away for whatever rainy day happens.Some of us look at those who homestead, who tend large gardens and raise livestock, who can, freeze and dehydrate vast quantities of food and who are as close to being self sufficient as a person can be these days.Â  We become discouraged because we are not in a place where we can do all those things.The good news is that we still can prepare.Â  A few extra cans of tuna or green beans can be purchased with our regular grocery shopping and stashed away.Â  If we have the means to home can, there are Farmer's Markets that yield an astounding array of fresh fruits and vegetables.Â  Frozen vegetables from the store can be canned or dehydrated to extend their shelf life.Â  When chicken goes on sale at the grocery store, a couple of extra packages can be canned up and added to our food storage.Â  By watching the store sales, all sorts of items can be purchased at a lower cost.Â  We don't have to do it all at once.Â  But little by little we can build up a deep pantry or a stash of medical supplies without having to spend all of our savings to do it.Some in the prepping community espouse 'bugging out' when things get bad.Â  That's all well and good if you are young, healthy and have somewhere to go.Â  I will be staying right where I am.Â  Here is where the food and supplies are.Â  With my health and mobility issues, I would be lucky if I made it to the end of my block.Â  Others say if we are in a city environment, we need to move.Â  For some of us that is not possible for various reasons.Â  What we can do is maintain a low profile and stay as inconspicuous as possible. and be prepared to defend our lives and the lives of those with us.Â  And that may be the best we can do.Some say that building a community of like minded people is necessary.Â  I agree that is a good idea, but for many of us, those like minded folks don't live in our neighborhoods.Â  My community consists of a couple of my kids.Â  Nobody else in my area would even consider putting forth the effort to prepare.Many of us feel totally alone in our efforts.Â  But we are not completely alone.Â  We have built a community of blogging friends and if the Internet goes away, we still have our faith and nothing or nobody can take that away from us.Â  Just knowing there are folks all over the country who believe in taking care of themselves, who refuse to count on government solutions to problems, who areÂ  ready, willing and able to defend themselves and their families, goes a long way to keeping us focused on what we need to do to survive any situation.We are all in this together.

title: Lessons From the Great Depression
text: While on self imposed R & R, I spent some time reading articles and watching videos about the Great Depression of the 1930's.Â  I have very little understanding of the Stock Market nor do I care much about the politics of the time.Â  My focus is on how the average citizen managed to keep body and soul together through those hard times.One reoccurring theme was having cash on hand.Â  Banks closed their doors and folks could not access the money in their accounts.Â  People lost their entire life savings, not to mention their homes.Â  Renters were evicted because they had no money to pay their rent.Â  Those who had stashed cash in their mattresses probably didn't have enough cash to last for years but chances were pretty good they had enough to at least give them time to make rational decisions on what to do before the cash ran out.Those who lived in the country fared better than the city dwellers.Â  They planted gardens, kept chickens for meat and eggs, had a cow for milk and butter and raised hogs for meat.Â  Many of those interviewed who lived through the Depression said they didn't know there was a Depression because they had plenty to eat.Â  And they had products to barter for what they couldn't buy.Â  They would trade eggs and butter for sugar and coffee.Â  They sometimes paid the doctor bills with vegetables from their gardens.Â  They were cash poor but they had the means to work around that.Those in the cities felt the effects of the Depression sooner and to a greater degree than the country folks.Â  Jobs disappeared.Â  Food became scarce.Â  In February of 1931, desperate to feed their families, citizens of Minneapolis rioted, smashing the windows of closed grocery stores and running off with whatever food they could carry.Â  This was repeated over time in many areas of the country.In the cities, soup kitchens run by churches and private charities were opened to feed the masses of hungry people.Â  Bread lines formed as people stood in lines for hours in hopes of being given a loaf of bread or other food to feed starving families.Those who had a variety of skills were better off than those who knew only the skills required to do the jobs that no longer existed.Â  A man who knew how to shingle a roof, clean a chimney, do maintenance work on a vehicle could earn cash or barter his services for food.Â  Women provided laundry services, baked bread and cakes to be sold, did sewing for those who didn't know how.Â  The more skills a person had, the better their chances of survival.People learned to 'make do.'Â  Lacking money for new clothes, holes were patched, seams were taken in or let out as needed to make a piece of clothing fit, holes in stockings were darned.Â  Mothers used whatever they had on hand to fashion clothing for their children - old sheets, flour sacks, etc.Â  Old cloth coats were taken apart and turned inside out to sew new coats or jackets for the children.Â  Scrap fabric was saved and turned into quilts.Â  Nothing was wasted.Broken tools, appliances, furniture were not thrown out but were repaired until they could no longer be fixed.Â  People glued soles back onto worn boots.Â  Others lined the insides of their shoes with cardboard to cover the places where holes were worn through the soles.Â  Children wore shoes only in the winter, for there was no money to buy new shoes and they weren't to be worn out in the warmer months when kids could go barefoot.Today we live in a disposable society.Â  We break the Mr. Coffee, we buy a new one.Â  We have more shoes than any one person can ever wear out.Â  We have clothing hanging in the closets that aren't worn because the fashion of the day dictates these items to be 'out of style.'Â  We firmly believe that the supermarkets will always be open, filled with every imaginable product to eat.Â  We rarely carry cash, choosing rather to whip out our credit cards to pay for nearly everything.Â  And we no longer know how to can tomatoes or sew a seam or bake a loaf of bread.If we ever have another set of circumstances resulting in another Depression, I fear most of America will be in a world of hurt due to a total lack of knowledge needed to survive.

title: Off Kilter
text: I am just a tad bit under the weather.Â  Nothing serious enough to worry about, but enough so that rest is needed.Â  I will return shortly, when I can get my brain cells to function.Â  All they do right now is yawn.Â  :).

title: Canning Report
text: I had about 45 lbs. of beef that was cut into one inch cubes, packed raw into pint jars and processed in my pressure canner for 75 minutes.Â  I got 37 pints of beef cubes.There was a certain amount of waste in trimming fat and gristle from the beef.Â  I suppose I could have been more precise in trimming, but I wasn't, with the result was that there is a considerable amount of red meat in with the scrap fat.Â  Not wanting to waste anything, I bagged up the scraps and froze them.Â  I'm thinking maybe I can boil them up later with some onion and carrots, skim the fat, strain out everything else and wind up with some decent beef broth.Â  Worth a try.I had two packages of brats that together held a total of 36 brats.Â  Common sense flew out the window and rather than test just one jar, I ran 7 jars through, each containing 3 brats, only to find when I did a taste test that I didn't care for the results.Â  The brats held together during canning but the texture changed, becoming more like the meat had been very finely ground.Â  Somebody else might not mind this change, but I didn't like it.Â  That being said, I'm sure I can find a use for the canned brats, perhaps cutting them into small pieces for use in casseroles.Â  I froze the remaining brats.And then I ran out of jars.I messaged my kids on Friday saying, "I am in desperate need of canning jars.Â  I am begging here.Â  Any takers?"Almost immediately daughter Jeri messaged me back saying she could do the deed but not until Monday.Â  She asked if that would work.Â  I said I would make it workÂ  I browned the burger over the weekend and canned some Monday evening and the rest this morning.Â  40 lbs. of hamburger got me 54 pints.Â The plan was to use part of the hamburger toÂ  make and can chili, but plans often change.Â  It is hot and humid outside.Â  Not a good time to be cooking pots of chili, so that will wait for cooler days.Â  The chickens will also stay in the freezer for a while.All in all, I am pleased with the amounts of canned meat that are headed for the shelves - and for Duane's apartment, because I am pretty much out of storage space.Â  Having a kid living next door comes in handy now and then.Â  Â Lucky for me, he is always willing to help when needed, as are the rest of my kids.Â  I would have a tough time doing what I do without their help.

title: Going AWOL
text: Just a quick post to let you know I will be AWOL for a few days.Â  Youngest son, David, did some shopping at Sam's Club for me today.Â  He brought me 40 lbs. of hamburger, about 45 lbs. of beef, 18 whole chickens and 2 boxes (18 each box) of brats.Â  We figured it out and he hauled nearly 200 lbs. of meat up the stairs to my apartment.Â  He never complained even once.Â  All he said was, "Do you suppose the next time we could spread this out over a couple of days.?"Â  Â :)The chickens are in the freezer.Â  The hamburger and brats are in the fridge.Â  I still have another 12 lbs. of beef to cut into one inch cubes to be canned tomorrow.Â  Some of the hamburger will be used in chili to can and the rest will be browned and canned plain.Â  I am going to run one jar of brats through with the hamburger just to see if I like them canned.Â  If not, they will be repackaged and frozen.I think I will be busy through the weekend and likely not at my computer.Â  When I finish, I'll be back.Â  Until then, the folks on my sidebar have some really good things to say.Later...

title: A Wealth of Information
text: Yesterday someone named Jennifer left a comment on my Food Shortages post.Â  Within the comment was the request to leave what she called a 'shameless plug' for her blog.Â  Normally I ignore comments like this, but I took the time to check out her blog and wound up spending a considerable amount of time there.Her blog is an absolute wealth of information.Â  She had information about everything from preparedness to canning to medical.Â  This blog is well written, well laid out so it is easy to navigate and is full of common sense.Â So many blogs and videos I find about preparedness are the macho types who tell us we are all going to die unless we buy the right gear or know how to make a shelter from twigs and vines or brag about how they will just go 'live off the land up in the mountains' when the nearing crisis arrives.Â Jennifer, on the other hand tells us how to use our food storage, how to use herbs and how to preserve food and much more.Check out Prep School Daily.Â  And take notes.Â  You will be glad you did.

title: Food Shortages?
text: I have been hearing rumors of food shortages caused by the rains and floods this past spring.Â  Several folks have told me about Walmart stores posting signs about shortages in their canned vegetable aisles.Â  So I decided to do my own research.I have seen several pictures posted of the Walmart signs.Â  I have read many articles about the flood damage to farms, fields, livestock and grains that were stored in grain bins that are now ruined.Â I have watched opinion videos and read blogs on the subject.Â  Opinions range from "We're all gonna die!" to "Move along.Â  Nothing to see here."Me...I go by facts.Â The fact is that millions of acres were flooded in the middle of planting season.Â  Some farmers were able to finally get into their fields to plant and others could not.Â  Whether we have a decent harvest is going to depend on the weather come fall.The fact is that many, many cattle, sheep, hogs and poultry were killed by the flood waters and much of the reserved livestock feed was lost.Â  Whether the livestock industry can recover remains to be seen.Â  But I do expect meat prices to go up.Â  It takes longer to build up a herd of cattle than it does to raise a field of corn.Â  I would guess that eggs and dairy prices may also be affected.As far as the shortages in the vegetable aisles of Walmart, it could be that the company is actually unable to keep their shelves full.Or there could be a clever person in the corporate office marketing department who knew that if the stores posted signs alluding to shortages, people would rush to stock up 'while they still could.'Â  I was reminded of the 'Great Toilet Paper Scare of 1973' when Johnny Carson, host of the then popular Tonight Show, made a joke about a toilet paper shortage.Â  Within a week the store shelves were empty of TP.So how will I handle these rumors?Â  Well, I do not believe we are headed into famine territory.Â  I do believe that we may see real shortages and more likely, corporations taking advantage of the rumors to raise prices.Â  I will not dash out, hair on fire, to grab what I can from store shelves.Â  I have, however, asked my youngest son to do some shopping at Sam's Club for me, picking up fairly large quantities of chicken, hamburger and beef roast to be canned in various ways.Â  I may add to the list some link breakfast sausage and brats, as I want to can those as well.Â  With what I already have on my shelves, that will give me plenty of meat to use in making all sorts of meals.Many of you who visit here often know that due to physical limitations, I use a grocery delivery service every two weeks for my normal grocery shopping.Â  My order that will beÂ  delivered this coming Thursday includes twelve 1 lb. bags of dry Great Northern beans, half of which will be used to make and can another batch of baked beans.Â  The rest will be saved for ham and bean soup to can later.Â  I also am ordering 6 bags each of frozen whole kernel corn and cut green beans, both to dehydrate.Â  And 10 lbs. of potatoes to slice and dehydrate.My crystal ball is broken, so I have no real way to know what the future holds.Â  So on the chance that the predictions come true, it makes sense to me to go ahead and get food now while prices aren't through the roof.Â  And if nothing happens, I am still ahead with more food added to my food storage.For the life of me, I just can not understand why so few refuse to plan ahead when it comes to food.Â  We saw pictures and video on the news showing the devastation the floods caused.Â  Even the main stream media carried interviews with farmers who lost everything.Â  And long before that, there were the pictures of people digging in dumpsters looking for food after a hurricane.Â  When will it occur to some that after a disaster, someone from the government is not going to show up with a sandwich and a bottle of water.Â  The government is in charge of politics.Â  We are in charge of feeding our families.Keep on prepping.

title: Bits and Pieces
text: I moan and groan when it is hot and humid and I complain when it is too cold, so it is only right I mention the two perfectly fine days in a row here in the hinterlands of Minnesota.Â  Sunshine for those who are out and about and for those of us indoors, windows open with a lovely summer breeze flowing through my apartment.Â  Glorious!As you know, my life is filled with drama and excitement.Â  OK. I lied.Â  There is very little going on here at present.Â  I am deciding what I need to can or dehydrate next and think I really need to do another batch of baked beans.Â  They are really good and the half pint jars are perfect for one person.Â  Duane hinted that more beans might be a good idea.Â  I sent a case of them home with him and I have a sneaking suspicion they won't last too long.Has anyone noticed that grocery shelves, particularly the canned vegetable aisles, have been not nearly as full as they normally are?Â  I have a high school friend who is a Vietnam vet and retired cop, and who keeps me informed about news that I might miss.Â  I joke that he is plugged into the 'good old boy cop network,' but that may not be so much of a joke.Â  He knew about the Somali riot at the local amusement park last summer before I did.Â  He lives 100 miles away.Â  I live just a couple miles from the park.Â  Recently he emailed me about several people reporting signs hung on the canned veggie aisles of Walmart stores in various parts of the country, stating that due to the bad spring weather, Walmart was experiencing shortages of vegetables.Â  I don't get out to check on that myself and I have not heard of that happening in my area, but it is curious.Â  I know that some food shortages have been predicted due to the wet spring and the flooding that happened.Â  I do know that most grocery stores would, in an emergency situation, have their shelves emptied within three days.Â  I don't think I am willing to take a chance.Â  Personally, I will continue to add as much as possible to my food storage - just in case.After taking stock, I find I am all out of home canned chili, so that is definitely on the list.Â  I think more half pint jars of meat for making sandwiches would be good as well.Â  I think it might be a good idea to dehydrate more potato slices before the price of potatoes goes up.This morning I heard an awful racket in the street outside my building.Â  Turns out the city was removing half a dozen of the small trees that were planted along the boulevard.Â  They had died over the winter and are now mulch.Â  I hope the city replaces them.Â  They attracted the small birds that I like to listen to in the spring and summer.Later in the afternoon I heard a strange sound outside my living room windows.Â  When I looked I saw a man at the window.Â  This was something new.Â  I live on the second floor of the building.Â  Seeing someone at my window is not an every day occurrence.Â  On closer inspection, I found he was on a ladder, painting the trim on the outside of my window.Â  I haven't been anywhere to buy curtains, but decided then and there to just make some.Â  I have several bed sheets of a cream color that I am sure contain enough fabric to cover all three windows.Â  The frugal (read 'cheap') part of me likes the notion of curtains without spending any money.Â  I come by the frugality honestly.Â  My parents, children of the Great Depression era, were the king and queen of 'making do.'Â That's enough blathering for now.Â  Hope your day was as nice as mine was, in spite of the racket and pseudo 'peeping tom."Â  :)Keep on prepping!

title: Canning Beef Stew
text: Last week I made beef stew for supper one evening.Â  I opened jars of potatoes, carrots, beef and tomatoes to make it.Â  Duane came over to help me eat it, took some home with him and I ate off the leftovers for a couple of days.Â  I had several canning jars that needed to be washed.Â  If I had a dishwasher, I wouldn't mind so much, but my dishwasher consists of my two hands located at the ends of my arms.Â  I am not fond of washing jars.About that time I got to wondering if it would work to can all the stew ingredients together in one jar.Â  I already can all sorts of soups, so why not stew.Â  With that in mind I ordered 8 lbs. of chuck roast, 10 lbs. of potatoes, 4 lbs of carrots, 4 lbs of onions and 2 bunches of celery.Â  So then I got to thinking that if I was going to can beef stew, why not can chicken stew, too.Â  So I added 6 lbs. of frozen chicken breast and 2 lbs. of frozen corn to the order.My groceries were delivered early afternoon Thursday.Â  I peeled the potatoes and onions and washed the carrots and celery.Â  Then I sat at my kitchen table and cut everything into bite sized pieces.Â  The potatoes went into a bucket of water to keep them from turning black overnight and the rest went into the fridge in zip lock bags.Â  The beef and chicken were cut into bite sized pieces and the meat went into the fridge in zip lock bags as well.This morning I got my jars and pressure canner ready and proceeded to layer the ingredients into quart jars.Â  Each jar got a cup each of potatoes and carrots, and half a cup each of celery and onions.Â  I topped off each jar with beef cubes, adding 1/2 teaspoon each of garlic powder and thyme and 3 tablespoons of crushed tomatoes along with two beef bouillon cubes per jar, then filled them with water..Â  I processed the quart jars of stew for 90 minutes.Â  To use the stew it just needs to be heated and thickened.Â  It might need a bit more liquid, depending on how you like it.While the first seven jars were processing and when I had filled the next seven jars was when I realized I had screwed up.Â  I had not ordered nearly enough carrots.Â  Stew just doesn't taste right without carrots.Â I thought about either freezing or dehydrating the rest of the vegetables, but both require blanching.Â  Did I mention that today was the hottest day of the year so far with the temperature this afternoon at 96 degrees and a heat index of 110 degrees?Â  There was no way I was going to heat water on the stove for blanching.Â  The pressure canner was generating enough heat, but my apartment was staying tolerable.Â  I wanted to keep it that way.So I started filling jars.Â  In addition to the 14 quarts of beef stew, I got 10 pints of cubed potatoes, 2 pints of carrots and 9 half pints each of celery and onions.Â  Tomorrow promises to be cooler - back in the mid 70's - so I will fill half pint jars of the rest of the beef and the 6 lbs. of chicken.Â  I have lots of beef and chicken canned in pint jars, so I thought perhaps the half pints would be nice to have on hand for sandwiches.Things don't always go according to plan.Â  In my case, they often go awry.Â  Being flexible and refusing to panic are a big plus, no matter what the situation.Â  None of the food was wasted and I will can more beef stew and chicken stew another (cooler) day, keeping better track of the amounts of ingredients I will need.Keep on prepping, even if you have to change course in the middle.Â  :)

title: No More Plastic
text: I had ordered 4 bottles of ketchup in my last grocery order to use in making Barbecue sauce to can, knowing I had another 4 bottles in my closet pantry to add to them for the amount of sauce I wanted to can.Â  However, when I brought the ketchup from the pantry out into the light of day, I found it had turned a dark brown in color.Â  Granted, it was a year past it's 'best by' date.Â  But when I opened the bottles I found they had an off smell to them.Â  Into the trash they went.The new plan for ketchup is to buy #10 cans of ketchup at Sam's Club and re-can it.Â  I have done this before with good results even several years after canning.Â  Apparently, storing food like ketchup or salad dressing in plastic bottles for long term isn't working, at least not for me.Â  After checking prices on Sam's website, I find it is very cost effective to buy the large cans as opposed to bottles at the grocery store.Last post told you about canning baked beans.Â  I got 8 pints and 19 half pints from four 1 lb. bags of dry beans.Â  I haven't done an exact figuring of cost, but an educated guess tells me I would be surprised if I had used over $7 worth of ingredients total.Â  And considering an 8 ounce can of baked beans was costing me $1.38, I think it was well worth the time and effort.Â  A taste test told me I will can these again.Unless something really ticks me off and I decide to write a rant, I likely will be AWOL until the end of this coming week.Â  It is hot.Â  It is humid.Â  I am doing small, quiet things right now because heat and humidity are not kind to me.Â  However, I am ordering ingredients to be delivered Thursday to can beef stew.Â  I'll tell you all about that when the stew is in the jars.I whined so much last winter about the snow and cold that I don't dare complain about hot weather.Â  So I will make another batch of iced tea and patiently wait for fall.Â  :)

title: Today We Are Canning Baked Beans
text: Many of you know that because of physical limitations, I use a grocery delivery service for my grocery shopping.Â  The service is geared toward Senior clients and I am very satisfied with it.Â  The service puts out a yearly catalog of grocery items that I use to put together my twice monthly orders and the catalog is extensive.Â  The only down side is that prices are not listed, which is understandable since the catalog is published yearly and prices change.Â  So when I looked over my receipt a few weeks ago and discovered that I had paid $1.38 for an 8 ounce can of baked beans, I decided it was time to can my own.I have canned pork and beans before, using a method where you measure the dry beans into jars, add the sauce and pressure can.Â  That method worked, but the beans didn't turn out quite as tender as I would have liked.Â  So this time I am using Jackie Clay's (Backwoods Home Magazine) recipe.Â  There is more work involved than the first method, but I think the results will be more to my liking.Here is the recipe I am using:2 quarts. dried navy or other smaller beans1 lb. thickly sliced bacon or salt pork (or ham)6 large onions, diced1 1/2 cups brown sugar4 tsp. salt4 tsp. dry mustard1 1/3 cups molassesSort beans, rinse, then cover with 6 quarts fresh water; let stand overnight in a cool place. Drain. Cover beans with 6 quarts water in large stockpot. Bring to boil; reduce heat. Cover and simmer until skins begin to crack. Drain, reserving liquid. Pour beans into turkey roaster or other very large baking dish. Add bacon, ham, and remaining ingredients and 8 cups reserved liquid. Ladle sauce over beans and bake, covered, at 350 degrees for about 3 hours. Add water or cooking liquid to keep wet enough; you donâ€™t want them dry but watery. Pack hot beans and sauce into hot jars, leaving 1 inch of headspace. Process pints for 80 minutes and quarts for 95 minutes at 10 pounds pressure.I don't have any bacon or ham on hand so I will not be adding meat and I am adding fewer onions.Â  Â My roaster pan is too small (I am making 1 1/2 times the recipe) so I am using my electric roaster instead of the oven.I am using some pint jars and some half pint jars.Â  The half pints are just right for a single serving.Â  I am using 4 - 16 oz. bags of dry beans.Â  I haven't done the math on all of the ingredients, but one bag of beans cost less than one 8 oz. can of prepared beans, so I don't think I can go wrong on the price.The beans are now in the first stage of cooking.Â  I will do a follow up tomorrow to let you know how it all turns out.There is nothing wrong with buying prepared pork and beans, but when living on a fixed income, it seems well worth the time and trouble to can my own.Â  That money will be better spent on items I can't preserve myself.Keep on prepping.

title: Let's Can Hamburger and Sausage Patties
text: I have lots of hamburger and sausage canned up - all of it in the crumbled form.Â  But let's say that whatever is going to happen has happened, the stores are empty and my freezer is now just a place to store blankets.Â  Beans and rice have been consumed for the past three weeks and more than anything in the world I really, really want a cheeseburger.Â  What do I do?I go to my shelves and grab a jar of hamburger patties that I canned.Â  And if I want a sausage patty with my eggs for breakfast, I have those in jars, too.I got 4 lbs. of bulk sausage and 6 lbs. of hamburger with my grocery order this time.Â  I shaped all of it into patties, using a wide mouth jar ring to get them the right size and thickness.Â  To do this, turn the ring upside down on parchment paper, fill the ring with ground meat and press it down to fill the ring, skimming off any excess so the meat is level with the edge of the ring.Â  Turn the ring right side up and the patty will pop right out.I put the patties, both hamburger and sausage, onto parchment lined cookie sheets and put them into a 375 degree oven, baking them just until they were somewhat browned on the outside and firm enough to handle.Â  They don't need to be completely cooked as they will cook in the pressure canner.Â  They can be fried in a frying pan or on a griddle, too.I drained the patties on paper towels, blotting the tops of each with paper towels to sop up any excess grease.Â  Then they were packed into wide mouth pint jars.Â  The sausage didn't shrink much so only three patties fit into each jar - the hamburger was packed four per jar.Â  They could be packed into quart jars if desired.Â  I made up some beef bouillon and added that to each jar up to one inch from the top.Â  The jar rims were wiped clean, lids and rings added and into the pressure canner they went.Â  I still had room in the canner and I had made more broth than I needed, so I jarred up four pints of the broth and canned that, too.Â  I will have beef broth for the next time I can meat patties or it is good in soup.The pints were processed for 75 minutes.Â  Quarts are processed for 90 minutes.I had one jar that didn't seal.Â  I haven't eaten those hamburger patties yet, but I did check them to see how well they held together, and they were just fine.Â  When I go to use them, I think I will just put them in a frying pan with just a bit of fat and heat them through.Â  I don't season the hamburger but will add seasonings when I heat them up.I will can up more of these meat patties.Â  In an SHTF situation, or even on a day when I really don't want to cook, I think these sausage and hamburger patties will come in really handy.I love caramel.Â  It is good on ice cream.Â  It is good for dipping with apple slices.Â  It is good spread on cake.Â  It is good for lots of things.Making caramel from scratch involves ingredients like heavy cream that I never have on hand.Â  So when I saw several videos of making caramel by boiling a can of sweetened condensed milk for three hours, I had to try it.Â  It worked.Â  The result was delicious.Yesterday I opened 4 cans of sweetened condensed milk and filled 6 half pint jars.Â  I wiped the jar rims really well, added lids and rings and set them into a stock pot.Â  I poured in enough water to cover the jars by at least two inches, turned on the burner and brought the pot to a boil.Â  I turned the heat down a bit and let the jars cook at a slow boil for 3 hours, adding more water about half way through to keep the water level over the jars.When the caramel was done and after it had cooled a little bit, I called Duane and said, "There be caramel." to which he replied. "I'll be right over."Â  We opened one jar for a taste test.Â  That jar is in the fridge and I hear it calling my name.Â  Duane made off with two jars.Â  Another jar went home with my nurse and two more are on the shelf.I will be making more of this.Â  :)

title: Independence Day
text: School days were begun by standing, placing hands over hearts and reciting this pledge.Â  But it wasn't until fairly recently that the true meaning of these words hit home.It is a time when enemies without and those within threaten our very freedom, our loyalty to our country and our patriotism is being challenged from all sides.Â  Suddenly it is considered racist to wear sneakers with a picture of the Betsy Ross flag on them.Â  Others are offended by our flag pictured on clothing.Â  Still others shame themselves by refusing to stand for our national anthem.Strangely enough, in this country where some find it necessary to trash our flag and our way of life, I have yet to see caravans of Americans forming to march to another country.Â  Hollywood should be a ghost town if all those who vowed to leave our country when Trump was elected had really done so.Do we not realize that nowhere else in the world could those who protest our flag do so without deadly consequences?Â  Try voicing criticism of the leaders in North Korea or China or many of the Middle Eastern countries and see how long you last.We are not perfect as a country, mostly because we are filled with less than perfect human beings.Â  We don't pretend to be perfect.But we are by far the very best place on the planet to live.Â  I can voice my opinion here without fear of being thrown in jail for it.Â  I can live anywhere within our borders that I choose to without having to ask permission to do so.Â  I can travel anywhere within our 50 states I want to.Â  I can worship whatever God I believe in freely, even though there are those who try to prevent me from doing so.It is true we have restrictions.Â  Probably more than we would like.Â  But even with those restrictions, we still have way more freedoms than do so many citizens of other countries.For me and mine, we will continue to celebrate this marvelous country of ours.Â  And we will continue to pray that those who wish to destroy everything our predecessors fought and died for, will fail.So go grill those hamburgers.Â  Go watch that parade.Â  Go enjoy those fireworks.Â  Rejoice.Â  We have more reason to celebrate than any other citizens on earth.Â  And we do so because on this date all those years ago, brave men declared us a nation of free and independent people.Happy 4th of July !!

title: Let's Can Crackers
text: So I decided to do another experiment.Â  I saw several videos on dry canning crackers.Â  That appealed to me because let's say I open a box of those little cheesy crackers.Â  By the time I work my way through the entire box, they taste old and stale.Â  So it seemed worth a try to keep them fresh.In all of the videos I saw, quart canning jars were used.Â  Because there is only one person living here, pint jars seemed like a better choice.Â  I filled 6 wide mouth pint jars with crackers - 2 with cheesy crackers - 2 with oyster crackers - 2 with Ritz crackers.Â  I wiped the rims to remove any crumbs and added lids and rings.The majority of the directions said to put the jars in a cold oven, using a cookie sheet to hold them.Â  Then turn on the oven and set it for 250 degrees.Â  When the oven gets up to the correct heat, set the timer for 30 minutes.Â  When the time is up, turn off the oven and leave the jars in it until cool.So I did.Â  Five jars sealed and one did not.Â  Only time will tell if the seals will hold.Â  I'm going to set the sealed jars aside and check the seals now and then.Â  If they hold, this is an excellent way to store crackers.Â  I can't say yea or nay on this one yet.Â  If any of you have used this method to store crackers, please let me know.Â My grocery order today included several items for a few more food preservation experiments.Â  I will let you know how the next one turns out.

title: Food Memories
text: The night before last two storms roared through my town, one right after the other.Â  They brought wind and rain and lightning strikes that caused a fire inÂ  a garage and another in a house.Â  Thankfully nobody was injured.Â  And thankfully, the storms brought our heat wave temperatures down to a tolerable level.So what does one do when it is cool enough to run the oven?Â  In this house, one bakes cookies.I dug out two of my cookie mixes, stirred them up and after I put the second batch into the oven I called my son who is also my next door neighbor and said, "There be cookies."Â  He replied, "I'll be right over."We sat and talked of many things and I was reminded of when my kids were young children.Â  They delighted in sneaking cookie dough from the bowl whenever I was baking cookies.Â  I would fuss at them as Mom's are prone to do and they would think they were getting away with putting one over on Mom.Â  In reality, I had a hard time keeping a straight face and I always stirred up extra dough, knowing what would happen.Later that evening I heard the sound of my son's key in the lock of my apartment door.Â  He soon stuck his head through the doorway of the living room and followed with a big strawberry malt made with fresh strawberries.Â  He knows how I dearly love ice cream in any form and it was a real treat as well as a nice surprise.I was reminded of a time when the kids were small.Â  If we would visit my parents of a morning, my Dad would fix my kids chocolate malts for breakfast.Â  Mother would always fuss at Dad, telling him that chocolate malts were not a proper breakfast.Â  Dad would always counter by telling her the malts were healthy because he used Carnation Instant Breakfast Mix for the flavoring and ice cream was, after all, a dairy product that was good for kids.Â  And the kids would listen to them and grin, knowing that the next time they visited in a morning, they would again be treated to chocolate malts for breakfast.The other day my son surprised me with a bag of fresh cherries.Â  I love cherries.Â   I have been nibbling on them, using every bit of my will power to keep from eating them all at once.I was reminded of a time when Dad needed to travel for his job from our home in west central Minnesota to the capitol city of St. Paul, a journey of 100 plus miles.Â  Sometimes he would look at me and ask, "Do you want to go for a ride, Sis?"Â  (He often called me 'Sis.')Â  When those trips occurred in the summertime, Dad would stop at a roadside fruit stand on the way and buy a paper sack full of cherries.Â  The trip would then proceed while we ate cherries from the sack, spitting the pits out the open car windows.Â  I was never allowed to spit cherry pits out the window when Mother was in the car, for it wasn't lady like and she had high hopes of making a lady out of me.Â  But with Dad, I could get away with most anything that wasn't really bad or illegal.It is funny how certain foods can trigger memories.Â  Potato salad reminds me of family picnics at the lake.Â  Gingersnap cookies remind me of visiting relatives on hot summer days, eating Mom's freshly baked gingersnaps and drinking ice cold lemonade on the wide front porch of our house.Â  Pancakes remind me of a time of eating little else for a week because that was all we had.Lot of things trigger memories, but different foods seem to do it more for me.Â  There are good memories and some that are not so good.Â  The good memories mostly of times past when life was much more simple.Â  And the less than good memories remind me to keep adding to my food stash because I never want to go through another time like that.

title: Reality
text: I think it is safe to say that most of those who read and comment here are not kids.Â  I don't blog about fashion trends or make-up tips.Â  I may have a tube of lipstick somewhere in my apartment, but it would take me some time to find it.Â  Instead I write about the world around us, about my grands once in a while, but mostly about the importance of being prepared.I read many blogs.Â  I have the greatest admiration for those who homestead, raising their own food, preserving their own food, cooking from scratch and who are much more self sufficient than I will ever be.There was a time when I did many of those same things.Â  I was 30 or 40 years old and under the assumption as are many of that age, that I would likely live forever.Â  I now know better.If you are one of those 75 year olds who still run marathons or climb mountains, good for you.Â  And I mean that sincerely.If you are one of those who have become spoiled by the abundance of America and lazy by thinking nothing bad will ever happen and if it does, the government will rush in to take care of you, shame on you.But if you are one of us who has found the need to slow down due to age or infirmity or both, this post is for you.Â  We have spent our lives working hard, raising our families, paying our bills and expecting nothing to be just handed to us.Â  We have done everything we know how to do to keep our families safe and secure and fed in troubled times.Â And now we find ourselves unable to do many of the things we once did.Â  I occasionally like to think I am still Wonder Woman who can do it all.Â  The reality is that I am a 73 year old granny with health issues.Â This reality has been brought home to me this week.Â  I have always bought fruit by the crate to home can.Â  I spent time checking all the grocery stores and markets in my area to see if they sold fruit by the crate.Â  Apparently city folks don't home can any more, for I found none.Â But what really surprised me was that I was relieved.Â  Reality time.I still can vegetables and meat.Â  Those require not much effort on my part.Â  But to can peaches, for instance, I need to stand at the stove and blanch the fruit to loosen the skins, then stand at the sink to peel the peaches and remove the pits, then stand at the stove again to cook the syrup used in canning them.Â  That's way more standing than my body will allow.I will be buying canned fruit for my food storage.Â  I know the taste won't be as good as home canned and I realize there are issues with added preservatives and such in commercially canned fruit.Â  But do I want my family to do without fruit just because I am unable to home can it now?Â  No.Sometimes we who have done for ourselves for a lifetime without asking for help, feel a twinge of guilt when we find we have limitations.Â  I am here to tell you that it is OK to use and to stock up on products that are available to us now that can make life just a bit easier for us.Â  The reality is that for me, when I am in one of my Wonder Woman modes and overdo my capabilities, I spend a day or two being completely useless in recovering.Â  Sometimes the pain is worth it, but most times it is not.It is OK to use a cake mix instead of baking a cake from scratch.Â  It is OK to keep a stash of frozen meals for those days when we hobble instead of walk.Â  It is OK to let the crockpot or microwave do the cooking now and then.Â  Â And it is OK to open a can of peaches when we can no longer can them ourselves.The thing is, I may not wake up tomorrow morning.Â  Or I may follow in the footsteps of my Dad and live to age 93.Â  Only God knows which it will be.Â  But as long as I wake up here on earth each morning I will continue to do what I can and I will continue to encourage others to do what they can.Â  If we are unable to do things the way we would like, then we have the imagination and ability to find other means to an end.Â Never give up.Â  Learn to adapt.Â  We are all in this together.

title: Nuttin'
text: I've got nothing.Â  It is hot.Â  It is humid.Â  The air conditioning is working - not so much.Â  Read the folks over in the side bar.Â  I'll be back when my brain starts working again.Â  :)

title: Mow the Lawn
text: A couple of weeks ago I watched a documentary where a Holocaust survivor went with a group of high school Seniors on a tour of Auschwitz.Â  Â The children were respectful and listened attentively to the survivor's descriptions of what life was like for him as a prisoner there, obviously moved by what he said.At one point the group was walking across a grassy area and one young man pointed at the luxurious lawn and asked who had mowed the lawn at that time.The survivor replied, "Mow the grass?Â  Nobody mowed the grass.Â  If we were lucky enough to find a blade of grass, we ate it."Keep on prepping.

title: Another Milestone
text: I got a phone call the other day.Â  It seems that my youngest granddaughter had passed the test for her driving permit.Â  My son had posted this picture on Facebook."Way to go, Maddie Mae!Â  She passed her permit test today and is already asking for the keys."David, Maddie Mae and grandson Jacob were in the car on their way to Jacob's Little League ballgame right after she took the test.Â  They had waited in line for 2 1/2 hours!Â  David said he wasn't sure it was worth the wait.Â  Maddie declared it was well worth it.I asked Maddie if she was behind the wheel.Â  In the background I heard her Dad say, "I'm not ready to turn her loose on the freeway just yet!"Â  He should be conditioned to it - he now has two daughters of driving age.Â  :)My brother saw the picture and left a comment:Â  "Congratulations, Maddie Mae!Â  (I am keeping you in my prayers, Davey.)"Congratulations, Maddie Mae.Â  You said you weren't sure you could pass the test, but I knew you would.Â  And if your Dad won't let you drive once in a while, you just give me a call.Â  I have ways of getting my son to listen to reason.Love, Grandma

title: Do You Remember...
text: Do you remember a time when you could ride your bike all over town and leave it on the grass while you played catch with a friend or prop it up against the outside wall of the drug store while you went in for an Eskimo Pie and you didn't have to lock up the bike because you knew nobody would steal it?Do you remember conversations where you voiced your opinion and your friend voiced his opinion and you could agree to disagree and nobody was called a racist or a Nazi?Do you remember Sunday mornings in church where the minister didn't care about your 'feelings' or about being politically correct but actually preached from the Word of God and let you know in no uncertain terms that if you didn't repent of your sinful ways that you would spend eternity in the fiery depths of Hell?Do you remember a time when right was actually right and wrong was wrong and the difference was clearly spelled out by our parents and was clearly spelled out in the Bible and if we chose wrong over right, there were consequences?Do you remember a time when the worst name a person could be called was 'Liar' and the person who lied to you was never again trusted and a person was respected whose word was his bond?Do you remember a time when people could look at a monument in the shape of a cross or at a Christmas Nativity scene or at a Civil War statue or at the name of one of our founding fathers on a building and not be so offended and so vocal about it that these things had to be removed?And do you remember when families gathered to celebrate a holiday or Grandma's birthday or Junior's graduation and everybody got along and nobody checked their cell phones every 5 minutes and when there were disagreements, we kept quiet out of respect for the holiday and out of love and respect for Grandma and out of a desire not to ruin Junior's party?And do you remember a time when you had more rights than someone who broke the law by sneaking across our borders and when those laws were enforced and when we weren't expected to pay for all the services for those law breakers?And do you especially remember when men were expected to be the head of the household and earned a living to provide for their families and weren't considered 'toxic' and when women weren't shamed and disrespected for raising their children and being the heart of the home and when children said 'Yes, Ma'am' and 'No, Sir' and got their mouths washed out with soap when they dared use a vulgar word within the hearing of their parents?Not everything in times past was sunshine and unicorns.Â  But I just don't remember those times as being so mean and nasty and scary as they are now.Â  I don't remember havingÂ  to double check to make sure my door is locked all the time.Â  I don't remember being afraid to walk outside after dark.Â  And I don't remember living with the knowledge that we are, beyond the shadow of a doubt, headed into truly dark times.Â I know I can't go back and live in the past and I know that I can not change the horrible realities of today where those who wish to be in power believe killing babies is OK and where killing police officers has become a sport and where the Antifas of the country are tolerated rather than jailed.I can only hope that when the time comes, enough folks will remember what life was once like here in our beautiful country and will find the courage to do whatever can be done to find those times again.And because I am also a realist - keep on prepping.

title: A Granny on a Mission
text: Every morning the first thing I do is swallow a handful of pills.Â  Every night at bedtime I swallow a couple more.How am I going to deal with the medical issues these pills address when I can no longer just go to the drugstore and buy them.Lately I have been spending some time online researching alternative herbal remedies.Â  I am finding that many require exotic herbs or plants that do not grow in our climate.Â  No problem...I can just order ...... no, wait.Â  If there are no prescription medicines available, if the lights are out, if the Internet has gone away.....what then?I live in a small, downtown apartment.Â  There is no space for a garden to grow my own herbs .Â  So my focus has changed to learning all I can about herbal remedies that can be made from either herbs that can be grown in pots on a window sill or foods that are readily available now that can be dehydrated and stored for future use.Â Blueberries are good for many ailments.Â  If I can lots of blueberries or dehydrate them to be ground into a powder, will they retain their usefulness?Â  Strawberries and their leaves have properties beneficial to good health.Â  If dried, do they retain their benefits?Â  What vegetables can be dried and powdered for use in medicinal teas or salves or in other ways to treat medical issues.The answer is...I don't know.Â  But I am on a mission to find out.Â  My prepping focus has been on food and water.Â  Still is.Â  But having shelves full of stored food will do me no good at all if I die from a condition I can no longer treat with prescription meds.Â And I have way more living to do to allow that to happen if I can prevent it.

title: I got to thinking...
text: the other day.Â  What if we were in a situation where we were living off just our food storage.Â  And what if the electricity had gone away so the freezer wasn't freezing any more.Â  That would mean there was no frozen meat left.Â  All of my hamburger in jars is browned and canned - not in patty form.Â  Just what would I give after a while for a hamburger patty or a cheeseburger on a bun.Â  I have seen videos about canning hamburger and sausage patties.Â  I think I need to give that a try.Â  I will order some hamburger in two weeks and see what happens.I have four family sized packages of chicken legs ordered for delivery tomorrow.Â  Usually when I can chicken legs or thighs, I raw pack them in wide mouth jars and can them without liquid.Â  That works well except when the meat doesn't make enough of its own juices and the parts that are not covered in liquid turn really dark in color.Â  They aren't bad or spoiled - just ugly.Â  This time I think I will lightly brown the legs first and then pack them in jars, adding a chicken bouillon cube to each jar and then hot water.Â  I think that will solve the problem of ugly chicken legs and add flavor at the same time.Sometimes we need to think a little bit outside the box.Â  For instance, among preppers we always hear about storing rice and dry beans.Â  That is a good thing to do, but what happens when we want beans for a meal and water is at a premium and so is cooking fuel.Â  Even with soaking beans overnight, it takes considerable time to cook them.Â  I have been running a load of various kinds of beans through my pressure canner now and then, or if I don't have a full canner load of meat, I will add jars of beans to make a full load, as the canning times are similar.Â  Then when I want beans for a meal, there they are on the shelf, fully cooked and just need to be added to soup or heated for a meal.Â  Â So far I have navy beans, great northern beans, kidney beans and some of those 15 bean soup mixes canned and on the shelf.Â  Â I need to can up other varieties.Â If I could figure out a way to successfully can rice, I would do it.Â  But so far it hasn't worked for me.Â  Rice added to chicken soup all but disappeared during the canning process.Â I have done some experimenting with canning various kinds of meat.Â  Ground beef for Sloppy Joe's didn't turn out well.Â  The taste changed in the process and the change wasn't good.Â  It had sort of a scorched flavor. The taste convinced me not to do that again.Â  Taco meat, however, was a success as was barbecued pork for sandwiches.Â  Although I usually can ingredients rather than the finished dish, once in a while it is nice to be able to open a jar, heat it up and have a meal.Â I think that in an SHTF situation, variety in food will be welcome.Â  I know that if all I had to eat was beans and rice, I would soon be much more grumpy than I am now.Â  :)

title: Dad
text: Dad was a small man, being only 5 feet 5 inches tall, but within him was one of the biggest hearts I have ever known.He was born on a sandy, rocky farm in northern Minnesota in 1911, the youngest of nine children.Dad and his sister, Clarice.The family was poor, but I'm not sure they knew it, for I never once heard him complain about being deprived as a child.Dad at the top of the ladder and his brother Bruce.He would rather tell the stories of growing up in a loving family, of the shenanigans he and his brothers would pull, of what it was like to plow a field behind a team of horses.Â Dad in his twenties.Dad was 33 years old when he married Mother.Â  When asked why he married later in life than most, he remarked that he had to wait for Mother, who was 13 years his junior, to grow up.Mom and Dad the day after their wedding in 1945.Many years later when Mother's rheumatoid arthritis had crippled her so badly that she could no longer do anything for herself, he spent his time with her, feeding her, brushing her hair, cleaning the trach tube she breathed through and taking care of every one of her needs.Â  I once asked him how he could do all of this, day in and day out.Â  He said simply, "I love your Mother."Mother and Dad - early 1990's.Dad was not a highly educated man.Â  At that time it was common practice for farm boys to attend rural schools through the eighth grade and then to work on the farm, and this is what he did.Dad is the little boy on the end, looking at his hands.Â  The picture includes some of his siblings and neighbor children at the little White Pine School.His lack of formal education didn't mean he wasn't smart.Â  He loved to read and I would often find him sitting at the kitchen table, completely absorbed in the contents of a book.Â  He loved Zane Grey stories and would read the Reader's Digest, cover to cover, but more often than not, I would find him with the Bible open in front of him.This man had a work ethic second to none.Â  As Mother's disease required more visits to the doctor and then several hospitalizations, he worked two and sometimes three jobs to pay the bills.Â  Never once did I hear him complain, nor did our family ever go hungry, thanks to his ambition and determination.Dad was of the opinion that just because his firstborn was a girl didn't mean that she had to grow up expecting someone else to take care of her.Â  He didn't just tell me how to do things, but showed me.Â  I got my love of gardening from him, working with him to plant, weed and harvest our garden every year.Â  Â With him I learned to paint a house, to change a tire, to use tools.My sister and me with Dad in the garden.He taught me how to drive by taking me out on a local frozen lake in wintertime, where I couldn't run into anything, and turned me loose to get the feel of driving.Â  Our family car had an automatic transmission, but he insisted we sometimes take his old work car that had a stick shift.Â  He said I might not always have access to an automatic and I had better learn to drive both.With my shiny, new driver's license in my pocket, Dad and I set off for the big city - Minneapolis.Â  Â Right through the busy, traffic clogged and sometimes confusing downtown area we went.Â  Other than giving me directions of what street to take and where to turn, Dad never said a word.Â  When I asked him later why he had been so quiet, he replied, "I knew you could handle it."I come from a long line of people with working senses of humor.Â  When Dad's family would gather together, the air was filled with laughter.Â  The siblings would tell stories on each other about the silly things they did as children.Â  They would delight in playing harmless pranks on one another, like swiping a forkful of someone else's pie when they weren't looking.Â  Dad once told me that his cutting up as a child earned him many hours sitting in the root cellar at the farm, cutting up rutabagas for horse and cattle feed.Dad being silly while swimming at the lake, bringing Mother some flowers.In later years when we lived a couple of hundred miles apart, I would call him every few days, to check up on him but mostly to hear his voice.Â  He would tell me that he had been fishing or that a cousin had been to visit with him or that it had snowed the night before.Â  Sometimes he would tell me that he had a beautiful apple pie cooling on the counter, so that I could ask him to mail me a slice, so he could tell me he tried to get a slice in the envelope, but it just wouldn't fit.Â  My phone calls always ended with these words, using his nickname for me, "I sure love you, Sis."Dad wasn't perfect by any means.Â  None of us are.Â  But I could not have asked for a better Dad.Dad and me - winter of 1947-48.He passed on in December of 2004 at the ripe old age of 93.Â  I was so very blessed to have had him in my life for so many years and I still really, badly miss him.

title: Sam's Club Trip
text: So late Tuesday morning my youngest son, David, showed up to take me and his brother to Sam's Club.Â  But before we left, he and Duane hauled in four of those square plastic milk crates full of canning jars.Â  Bonus!!Â  He didn't want the crates back, so I found space where I can stack them two high with the open tops facing outward and use them as shelf cubbies to hold more food storage, which is good because I have little space left on my regular shelves.Â  Thank you, son!There were conditions connected to this outing.Â  If my boys were going to take me out in public, I had to behave myself.Â  There would be no popping wheelies with the electric cart I used to get around in the store, nor was I allowed to organize drag races with the same carts.Â  I reluctantly agreed and we were off to shop.I needed hamburger to can, so I got two 10 lb. chubs along with a whole pork loin.Â  The hamburger will be canned in pint jars and the pork loin will be cut into a couple of small roasts to fit into my small crock pot with the rest sliced into boneless chops and frozen.Â  That's a whole lot of meals and I am sharing some of the chops with Duane.I only have a couple pints of dill pickles left and these days, getting my hands on cucumbers for canning is difficult.Â  So I bought a gallon jar of dill spears, 2 half gallon jars of baby dills and 2 quarts of small, stuffed olives.Â  Sometimes it is necessary to find a way around a problem and this works for me.Â  The pickles will be re-canned into pint jars and the olives into half pint jars.Â  And when that is done, I will have several large jars to store other things.I use a lot of butter.Â  I not only use it on bread and toast, but use it for frying some foods and in baking.Â  The price of butter in the grocery store has gone up considerably, so I was able to find butter in 4 lb. packs for considerably less per pound.Â  I got 20 lbs. of butter.Â  I put it all into the freezer.Â  I can always can up some of it later, but I figured I had enough food to process right now.Days before this shopping trip I had gone through Sam's website and made a list of what I wanted along with the prices.Â  I got things like large containers of lemonade and iced tea mix along with huge containers of Nestle's Quick chocolate milk mix.Â  Because of the medication I take daily, staying hydrated is imperative and the flavored mixes make it more appetizing than drinking plain water.Â  The chocolate milk mix is just because.Â  :)I picked up 8-packs of Rice-a-Roni, Spam and 4 jars of Miracle Whip along with 3 huge boxes of instant mashed potatoes.Â  An 18-pack of Mac & Cheese and 2 large boxes of Velveeta went into the cart.Â  Yes, I know.Â  The dreaded processed food.Â  But in times of crisis, especially when food is scarce, I doubt anyone would turn their nose up at food, processed or not.Â  And when you are an old lady with mobility issues, making up a box of Mac & Cheese is much easier than making the same dish from scratch.I found trash bags and freezer bags at a good price, so I stocked up on those. And I saw a 24-pack of washcloths and a 12-pack of flour sack dishtowels.Â  They came home with me as well, to be set aside for future use.David had another surprise for me.Â  He told me that because he and his family had not bought me anything for Mother's Day or my birthday, he was going to pay part of my Sam's bill.Â  I said that this shopping trip was my gift, but being slightly more stubborn than his mother, he won the argument.Â  So with a considerable amount of wiggle room above and beyond my budget, we added more to the cart.David talked me into getting a rotisserie chicken.Â  He said he buys one every time he shops at Sam's and they are really good.Â  He was right.Â  I ate off it yesterday and there is still plenty left for a couple more days.There were 2 quart containers of the best tasting strawberries I have had in years.Â  Three quarts went into the freezer and I have been slowly snacking on the rest.I believe that in times of stress and crisis, a sweet treat now and then helps keep depression at bay.Â  With that in mind, I have been wanting to stock up on assorted candies to have on hand.Â  Plus, I have this sweet tooth that needs to be dealt with now and then.Â  So we headed to the candy aisles.Â  The boys were delighted to toss a tub o' peppermints, a tub o' M & M's and a huge bag of assorted mini Reecse's Peanut Butter Cups into my cart.Â  David added a box of single serve Pringles and Duane found a box of 30 microwave bags of popcorn.Â  Most of that went into storage.Â  I make no promises about the Reese's.Â  :)My boys became pack mules when we arrived home, huffing all my purchases up the stairs.Â  There were several other items I haven't mentioned that I got to try out like a biscuit mix, big jars of chicken bouillon, etc., and by the time they were finished my kitchen table was covered as well as a considerable amount of floor space.Â  I spent the rest of the day and part of yesterday putting it all away.The best part of all was spending time with my sons.Â  I so enjoy their company.Â  Duane came by later to bring me a different kind of kiwi he had bought (it was wonderful) and David called me yesterday to ask if I had found my kitchen table top yet.Â  He said he had fun taking us to Sam's and suggested we make it a semi-annual event with possibly another trip when the weather cools down in the fall.Â  I readily agreed.I didn't write about this to brag about how much I bought.Â  It took me months of saving to be able to do this.Â  And hopefully, it will give others an idea of what is available for adding to their food storage.Â  Sam's charges a yearly fee for the privilege of shopping at their stores.Â  For David, it is worth it because his family shops there often.Â  For someone like me who goes only once or twiceÂ  year, the fee would likely eat up the savings.So now that this post is written and I have had my second cup of coffee, it is time to head to the kitchen and start browningÂ  hamburger to can.Â  I will be back when it is all in jars, processed and on the shelves.Â  And after that, of course, there will be nap.Â  :)

title: Canning Weekend
text: Thursday my grocery order was delivered.Â  Thanks to the lady taking my order having added several notes for the shoppers concerning the amounts ordered, I received everything.Â  So here are the results of my canning weekend.Five lbs. of grapes gave me 8 pints of the fruit.Â  I just filled the jars and added a light syrup of 2 cups of sugar to 10 cups of water and water bath canned them for 15 minutes.Â  I opened a jar this morning, and found the grapes are fairly soft like the ones in a can of fruit cocktail, but the flavor is still good.Â  I put some in the fridge to chill and I like them even better cold.Â  I won't can lots of them, but they make for variety in my canned fruit.Â  Variety is important.Â  If I just had canned peaches, I would get tired of them in short order.Next on the list was slaw/relish.Â  The recipe is in the comments section of the previous post.Â  This recipe is forgiving, so I used everything I had ordered - 10 lbs. of cabbage, 2 lbs. carrots, 1 lb. onions and 6 large green bell peppers.Â  I made 6 times the amount of syrup in the recipe.I used my food processor to shred the vegetables and next time, I think I will use the shredding blade rather than the regular blade that fits in the bottom.Â  The vegetables turned out a little more finely chopped than I usually do them, but the taste isn't affected.Â  I sprinkled the vegetables with canning salt and mixed the salt in, draining them after a couple of hours.Â I heated the syrup until the sugar was dissolved, let it cool and stirred it into the shredded vegetables.Â  I filled 16 pint jars with slaw/relish and processed them for 15 minutes in a water bath canner.There was some left over, so I filled 6 pint sized freezer bagsÂ  and put them in the freezer.Â  I will use them first, as the canned slaw stays good much longer than does the frozen.I had 12 lbs. of boneless, skinless chicken breasts that I spread out on cookie sheets and baked until they were cooked through.Â  Then I cut them into about 1/2 inch cubes and filled 13 pint jars.Â  Other chicken breast I have canned is rather bland tasting, so this time I added 1/2 teaspoon of chicken bouillon to each jar and then filled the jars with water.Â  I canned these at 10 lbs. pressure for my elevation, for 65 minutes.Last on the list were 4 lbs. of bacon.Â  This I cut into 1 inch pieces, lightly browned and drained them, and filled 9 half pint jars that I processed the same as the chicken.So that was a good start on replenishing my home canned food shelves.Â  I still have more I need to do, but right now, I believe I will just take a nap.Â  :)

title: Getting ready...
text: for a busy weekend.Â I have been watching the reports of storms and flooding across the country.Â  Here in Minnesota a couple of thunder storms rolled through last night with high winds and rain, knocking out power in some areas.Â  Thankfully my town was on the edge of the worst of it and power remained on. Farmers here and in many other areas are behind in planting due to the wet weather.Â  Many of those who did get their crops in the fields have had them drowned out.Â  And many along the rivers have their entire farms under water and have lost everything - their homes, their crops, their livestock.Â  Our hearts go out to those farmers who are struggling against the forces of nature.Â  And I am sure this will have an adverse effect on prices at the grocery stores.As for me, I feel like now is the time to kick my prepping into high gear.Â  My grocery order to be delivered Thursday includes bacon and chicken breast to can.Â  I have also ordered 5 lbs. of green grapes to can.Â  I saw a video on how to can grapes and thought that might be something that would give me more of a variety of fruit for my food storage.Â  The person who did the video said the grapes turn out like those included in a can of fruit cocktail, and I like those, so it is worth a try.I guess most of the elderly
