who use the same grocery delivery service as I do, order in small amounts.Â  I don't, and that sometimes befuddles those who do the actual shopping.Â  I don't always receive food in the amounts ordered.Â  I suppose that is because the shoppers don't think a gray-haired granny type would actually order 10 lbs. of cabbage, as I have this time in order to make my relish/slaw recipe to can.Â  The lady who takes my order gets it, so she has added notes to the order saying that yes, the amounts are correct.Â  We shall see...Yesterday I opened a jar of butter that I had canned 6 years ago.Â  I wanted to make sure it was still good after all that time on the shelf.Â  It tasted as fresh as the day I canned it.Â  So when I go to Sam's Club in a week or so, butter is at the top of my list.Â  I am also considering canning lard.Â  Mother made the best pie crusts using lard and she used it for other dishes as well.Â  I think in this time of dieting and calorie counting, we forget that fats are an important part of our diets.Â  Oils will go rancid after a while, but canned butter and lard will last a good long time.And now I'm off to wash canning jars and assemble the ingredients needed to can up the food I have ordered.Â  Each grocery order from now on will include items for food storage, for I just can't see that prices will go down, but likely will hit new highs.Â Whatever I buy today will cost less than if I wait until tomorrow.Keep prepping!

title: Cookies
text: I love cookies.Â  However, I am not fond of baking cookies.Â  I usually make a mess of my clean kitchen, wind up with flour on my clothes and the oven heats up my apartment while baking a regular recipe of cookies.Â  So yesterday I tested some recipes I had found for cookie mixes.I just measured the ingredients into quart sized Ziploc bags and wrote the instructions on the outside of each bag.Last evening I tried the chocolate chip cookie mix and this morning I made the oatmeal cookies.Â Chocolate Chip Cookie Mix1 Cup flour1/4 Cup white sugar1/2 Cup brown sugar1/2 teaspoon soda1/2 teaspoon salt3/4 Cup chocolate chipsMix together and store in a quart size Ziploc bag.Â  Write instructions on the bag to add:Â  1/2 Cup softened butter, 1 egg, 1/2 teaspoon vanilla.Â  Mix and bake at 350 degrees.Sugar Cookie Mix1 1/2 Cups flour3/4 Cup white sugar1/2 teaspoon baking powder1/2 teaspoon soda1/2 teaspoon saltMix together and store in a quart size Ziploc bag.Â  Write instructions on the bag to add:Â  1/2 Cup softened butter, 1 egg, 1/2 teaspoon vanilla.Â  Mix and bake at 350 degrees.Oatmeal Cookie Mix1 Cup flour1/2 Cup white sugar1/2 Cup brown sugar1 1/2 Cup rolled oats1/2 teaspoon soda1/2 teaspoon salt1 teaspoon cinnamonOptional: 1/2 Cup raisins or nutsMix together and store in a quart size Ziploc bag.Â  Write instructions on the bag to add:Â  1/2 Cup melted butter, 1 egg, 1/2 teaspoon vanilla.Â Mix and bake at 350 degrees.Gingerbread Cookie Mix1 3/4 Cup flour3/4 Cup brown sugar3/4 teaspoon soda1/2 teaspoon salt1/2 Tablespoon ginger1 1/2 teaspoon cinnamon1/4 teaspoon nutmeg1/4 teaspoon clovesMix together and store in a quart size Ziploc bag.Â  Write instructions on the bag to add:Â  1/4 cup softened butter, 1 egg, 1/8 cup molasses.Â Mix and bake at 350 degrees.I just emptied a bag into a bowl, added the butter, egg and vanilla and mixed it all together.Â  I suppose a person could use a spoon to mix, but I have always mixed up cookie dough with my hands.Â  I dropped dough by spoonfuls onto parchment paper lined cookie sheets and baked them.Â  Each recipe gave me about two dozen cookies and they taste really good.I haven't tried the sugar cookies or the gingerbread cookies yet, but I expect they will be as good as the others.I will make more of these mixes and stash them away in my pantry.Â  The amount of cookies is just right for one or two people, the kitchen stays clean and from start to finish it only took about a half hour.Success!

title: Parallels
text: Last evening I was looking for something to watch while I worked on my grandson's afghan.Â  I clicked on a video of a Holocaust survivor's story.Â  I have no idea why I chose that one as I usually look for videos or movies that are somewhat lighter in subject, but I became interested and watched several others as well.What caught my interest weren't the horrors these people suffered, but were the things that happened leading up to the deportations to concentration camps.Most had older relatives who couldn't believe that anything bad would happen to them.Â  Most had Gentile friends who turned against them and some of those friends were the cause of arrests.Â  Whether the reasons for turning against their Jewish friends were previously hidden prejudices or fear of the German soldiers, the outcome was usually the same.Â  After a while nobody trusted anybody.Another factor was food.Â  As time went on, shops closed one by one and obtaining enough food to feed a family became difficult.Â  When food rationing began, the ability to find food became close to impossible.Â  And after the JewsÂ  were forced to move into ghettos, food became nearly non-existent.Â  Many starved to death long before the deportations began.Another reoccurring theme was the lies.Â  Some Jews were told that if they presented themselves at a certain time at a certain location, they would be given extra rations.Â  When they appeared they were either loaded into boxcars or were killed outright.Other times they were told that if they volunteered to work for the German military they would earn enough to buy their food.Â  Those that volunteered were usually worked to death without pay or food.In the end, the Jews were lied to about everything.Â  It was all about promising them a better life in order to get them where the government wanted them without any fuss or bother or resistance.Food became the most important thing in the lives of many Jews.Â  The food they had managed to put away was confiscated.Â  There were no places to buy food and that didn't matter because their money and valuables had also been taken from them.Â  Starvation became a way of life.See any parallels?Â  I noticed that so many didn't believe anything bad would happen.Â  That seems to be the prevailing attitude today.Â  Even though we are watching our freedoms being eroded little by little, many don't seem to care.Â  As long as they have their big screen TVs and a couple of cars in the garage and can afford to go out on Saturday night, they pay little attention to what is happening around them.Many believe there will always be grocery stores full of food.Â  They shop once a week and believe they will do so forever.Â  The thought of stocking up on food and supplies seems like a waste of time and effort to them.Â  And they consider those of us who are into food storage to be tin foil hat wearing crazies.Most everyone is aware of the fact that politicians lie.Â  They tell us what they think we want to hear in order to promote whatever their agenda is.Â  But mostly they lie to gain or keep power.Â  They lie to keep us complacent.Â  They want us smart enough to do the work that needs to be done but dumb enough so we don't question their motives.Â  And all the while they are chipping away at your freedoms and mine.Â I don't know how all of this is going to play out, but I can guarantee it won't be to the advantage of the people.Â I am beginning to understand why so many are trying to rewrite history, for if we don't remember what happened in the past, we are doomed to see similar horrors in the future.It is way past time to wake up.

title: When you lead a quiet life...
text: sometimes you have to dig deep to find something to write about.Â  I suppose I could go on another rant, but the topics to choose from are so numerous that I really wouldn't know where to begin.~I can't seem to wrap my mind around the fact there are women who are fighting for the right to kill their babies.Â  Granted, pregnancies from rape and incest are horrible, but there are thousands of couples who desperately want to adopt children.Â  And for the rest of you women, you might not have an unwanted pregnancy if you had kept your knees firmly together.-To Representative Jerry Nadler:Â  You might want to find another hobby.Â  This 'Get Trump' thing is getting old.Â  There was no collusion.Â  There was no obstruction.Â  All the subpoenas or Contempt of Congress charges in the world are not going to change that.Â  How about concentrating on legislating for those who voted for you.Â  For a change.~Securing our borders is not racist.Â  Securing our borders is common sense.Â  I don't lock my door because of racism.Â  I lock my door so that strangers don't walk in, use my shower, raid my refrigerator or sleep in my bed.Â  I lock my door so some low-life criminal doesn't walk in to steal what little I have and likely beat me to a pulp in the process.Â  I lock my door so I have control of who enters.Â  I lock my door to stay as safe as possible in my home.Â  There is no reason for our borders to be any different.~Second Amendment:Â  "A well regulated Militia, being necessary to the security of a free State, the right of the people to keep and bear Arms, shall not be infringed."infringe (from Merriam-Webster): "to encroach upon in a way that violates law or the rights of another."So someone needs to explain to me why there are so many restrictions on gun ownership.Â  Nowhere in the second amendment does it say 'except for scary looking black rifles' or 'permits required' or 'guns must be kept securely locked up.'Â  Seems to me both State and Federal governments are infringing like crazy, and threatening to do more of the same.~Why are the criminal acts of some 'refugees' overlooked by the press.Â  Just a few nights ago, a group of Somali teens, armed with pipes and hammers, attacked citizens at a Light Rail station in Minneapolis, and yet no local news agency reported this attack.Â  According to those who monitor police scanners, the group of thugs were after affluent white train passengers with the object being to beat and rob them.Â  Several victims were taken to hospitals with serious injuries.Â  And our local news reports?Â  Crickets.Back to my quiet little life.Â  We have some weather moving our way that should show up this evening in the form of wind and rain.Â  I am off to finish washing up the dirty dishes from yesterday and to get some laundry done.Â  And check my lists to see what I need to do next for my preps.Â  If one of the crazies on the Left gets elected in 2020, I think we are going to need all the help we can get.

title: And So It Goes...
text: Mothers Day was a quiet, relaxing day.Â  Both of my daughters called.Â  One sounded awful.Â  She was nursing a nasty cold and said she was getting off the couch just long enough for her two adult kids to take her out for lunch and then she was headed right back to the couch.Â  Poor thing.The other called from the road.Â  She was headed to North Dakota to help my grandson in college move into a different dorm room.Â  He was able to get a single room and was happy to have a room to himself.Â  And she was stocking up his supply of snacks.I was happy both of my girls could spend time with their offspring on Mother's Day.Â  We have plans for shopping trips later this summer.David called in the afternoon.Â  He said the plans to come see me had to be set aside because he had to take Maddie Mae to Urgent Care.Â  Poor kid has strep throat.Â  It just wouldn't have been right to leave her home while the other kids visited Grandma, so I talked with each of them on the phone instead.Â  David stopped by this afternoon with a card signed by all of them, each writing a nice greeting, and a lovely bouquet of spring flowers.Â  He said he didn't bring me a plant because he knew I would just kill it.Â  He knows his mother well.Â  :)Â  He also had a DQ Blizzard for me, which made my day.Duane had to work Sunday, but he showed up in the afternoon with a carry-out box full of ham, turkey and mashed potatoes with gravy, and another with chocolate cake.Â  With chocolate frosting.Â  He knows how to put a smile on Mom's face.Last Friday the contractor came in to do the touch-up painting on the window trim.Â  He promised he would be back Monday to finish the job.Â  This afternoon I called my landlord and told him what was going to happen if the contractor didn't show back up by Friday.Â  I was going to pack up his paint and tools and set them out in the hall.Â  I was going to have my boys move my furniture back where it belonged and I would not, under any circumstances, allow that man back into my home.Â  This may be just a little apartment downtown, but it is my home and I will not take any more abuse.One hour later the painting was done, the tools were packed up and my furniture was back in place.Â  And I didn't have to call my boys.I did call the landlord to thank him for getting the guy over here so quickly.Â  I figured if I call to complain, I can call to say thank you.Â  My landlord told me to deduct more than half my rent for June to compensate for all the trouble and because my mother raised no fools, I accepted. I had about 8 lbs. of potatoes and 4 lbs. of carrots that needed to be taken care of, so this morning I peeled and diced and blanched an got them into the dehydrator.Â  They will go into the bags of dried vegetables I use for soups and stews.Â  I need to get my grocery order ready and am trying to decide what to get for storage this time.Â  I think I may go for some of the packaged rice and pasta mixes, as they are always good for a quick meal.Â  I'm holding off on the meat for canning until David takes me to Sam's Club where I can get it cheaper.I managed to get the dust from the construction cleaned out of my sewing machine and have been working on finishing some quilt tops.Â  With any kind of luck I will have pictures in a week or so.I know Spring is here for sure.Â  I watched three or four little boys practicing with their skateboards in the alley across the street.Â  They are fun to watch when they are working hard at mastering a trick, and when mastered, moving on to another.Takes very little to amuse me.Â  :)

title: So the day after I grumble about cooking...
text: I cooked.A couple of weeks ago, when I was digging in my freezer, I found a forgotten bag full of venison that youngest son David had given me.Â  The meat was vacuum sealed so it was all good.Â It didn't start out well.Â  I had promised Duane a venison roast dinner, but when I opened the package of meat I found I had thawed out chops instead.Â  Undeterred, I soldiered on, browning the chops and putting them into the crock pot with salt, pepper, onion, a little garlic and a sprinkling of sage.Â  They simmered all day until they were falling apart tender.Later in theÂ  day I scrubbed half a dozen potatoes and cut them into wedges.Â  Then I peeled some carrots and cut them into about 3-inch chunks.Â  I tossed the whole works in a little olive oil, spread them out on a cookie sheet, sprinkled them with salt, pepper and some parsley flakes and baked them until they were nicely browned and tender.Deciding to go all out, I dug into my pantry and came up with a yellow cake mix and a can of crushed pineapple.Â  I stirred up the cake, drained the pineapple and mixed it into the batter and baked it.Â  I used the pineapple juice to flavor the buttercream frosting.Duane says I done good.Â  He says when you make your living as a cook, it is a treat to eat someone else's cooking.Â  And I had fun fixing a meal for someone besides myself.Guess I will have to retract my previous post.Â  :)

title: I Hate to Cook
text: Well, maybe that's a little bit harsh.Â  I hate to cook for just one.I enjoyed making big meat and potato type meals or big bowls of spaghetti or pans of lasagna when there were lots of kids at the dinner table.Â  I miss that.Â  I even miss the inevitable "But, Mom...Do I really hafta eat the green beans?Â  You know I hate green beans."Â  And I miss the nearly nightly arguments about whose turn it was to wash the supper dishes. These days if I really want a full meal, my crock pot is my friend.Â  Toss the food in and let it simmer all day.Â  And there are no arguments about whose turn it is to wash dishes.Â  Sadly, it is always my turn.I read blogs where the writers are serving up fantastic meals for their families and I am jealous.Â  They spend hours slicing and dicing and sauteing and allowing the flavors to blend.Â  My idea of a gourmet meal is frying the Spam before making a sandwich.Â Perhaps I have just become lazy.Â  It's not that I dislike working with food.Â  My shelves packed full of home canned goodies and my other shelf full of home dehydrated foods are testimony to that.Â  I just can't seem to muster the ambition to cook very many real meals for just myself.Â Might beÂ  form of 'empty nest syndrome,' for I am looking forward to tomorrow when I will cook a venison roast with roasted potatoes and carrots to share with Duane.Â  There might even be a dessert involved.Â So I am wondering if anyone besides me considers crackers and cheese and a handful of grapes a sufficient lunch.Â  Sigh.

title: Mother...
text: Love her while you still have her.I miss you, Mom.

title: So I had another chat...
text: with my landlord on Monday.Â  I expressed my desire to have the window work finished.Â  Actually, what I said was that I was just plain done.Â  We talked about the pictures I had taken of the condition of my living room with furniture now taking up most of the floor space and the shelving unit moved in front of my sewing table and left there for two weeks with my sewing machine open to the dust and the fact that I couldn't get at it to clean it.Â  Or use it.Â  We discussed the notion that an attorney perhaps might consider that obstacle course a bit dangerous for an elderly lady who is tethered to an oxygen machine and who has mobility issues.Â He called me back ten minutes later, telling me the window guys would arrive this morning to finish the job.My landlord stopped by about 10:30 this morning to see how the work was progressing.Â  It wasn't.Â  They were nowhere to be seen.Â  I swear, I could see steam coming out his ears when he left.Â Half an hour later there was some serious sawing of boards and nailing of trim around the windows going on.Â  They will be back here in the morning to do some touch-up painting and to restore my living room to its original condition.Â  They know about the pictures.I don't like confrontation or yelling or unpleasantness.Â  Peace and serenity make me much happier.Â  But sometimes a person just has to stand up for themselves.Â  It has been nearly four months since this project began.Â My patience is gone.My landlord surprised me by volunteering to deduct a goodly amount of money from my next month's rent for every month I have been inconvenienced.Â  I didn't ask for that nor did I expect it.Â  But I'll take it.And now I need to order curtains to cover my lovely, new, finished windows.Â  :)

title: Prepping Lesson Learned
text: I had half a head of lettuce in my fridge that needed to be used up, so I made myself a salad to go with supper.Â  There was no Ranch Dressing in the fridge so I raided my pantry closet, knowing there were three bottles of it on the shelf.When I opened the dressing bottle, the contents smelled odd.Â  When I looked closely, I saw the color was darker than it should be.Â  The second bottle was the same as was the third.Â  They went in the trash.The expiration date on all three bottles was Feb 2017.Â  Ordinarily I don't pay much attention to expiration dates or 'Best if used by' dates.Â  Many commercially canned foods are good long after those dates.Â  Apparently Ranch Dressing isn't one of them.I don't know if the room where they were stored was too warm or if it was because so many foods like that are now packaged in plastic rather than glass.Â  I have had the same problem with ketchup in plastic bottles.Â  I also had one jar of mayo that tasted off, but I think that was because I bought the cheaper store brand.I know there are dry mixes for ranch dressing.Â  I may try that.Â  I don't use much dressing, so it makes more sense to use a mix rather than try to keep bottles of it on hand.I also found this recipe that looks good, so I may try it before buying the commercial mix.RANCH DRESSING MIX1/2 cup nonfat dry powdered milk2 tablespoons dry parsley flakes1 teaspoon dill weed1 teaspoon onion powder1 teaspoon onion flakes1 teaspoon salt1 teaspoon garlic powder1/2 teaspoon ground black pepper1/4 teaspoon celery seed1 teaspoon brown sugarMix all ingredients. Store in an airtight container. To make dressing, mix 1 heaping tablespoon into 1 cup buttermilk that's been mixed with 1 cup mayonnaise. Stir until well blended. Store covered in refrigerator until ready to use. Wait at least 30 minutes for flavors to combine.RANCH DIP1 cup mayonnaise1 cup sour cream1 heaping tablespoon Ranch Dressing MixStir all ingredients together and refrigerate for 2 or more hours before serving to allow flavors to blend.Buttermilk is not somethingÂ Â have on hand, butÂ Â found powdered buttermilk in the grocery store next to the non-fat instant powdered milk and I bought one.Â  I may get a couple more. I'll let you know how it all works out.

title: An Experiment...
text: Some time back I saw a few videos on homesteading and prepping channels about using Crisco to make candles.Â  As it happens, I have three or four large cans of Crisco that I bought at Sam's Club several years ago.Â  I find that I rarely use it for baking or frying like my mother did.Â  So the cans were taking up space that could be used for other things.I filled a pint jar with Crisco, leaving about an inch of space at the top.Â  I have some utility- type candles that are about half an inch thick and 6 inches long.Â  I shoved one of these down into the center of the jar and lit the wick.Â  I let it burn for 8 hours and found it had burned down less than half an inch.Â  Â I don't yet know how far down it will burn before it goes out. There was no noticeable odor or smoke.The Crisco burns sort of like the wax in any other container candle.Â  It melts as it burns so there is very little unmelted Crisco clinging to the inside of the jar.Â  I used a regular pint jar.Â  I'm not sure if the Crisco would have melted from the sides of a wide mouth jar as well as it does in the small mouth jar.I have 6 more of the utility candles, so I will make more of the Crisco candles to use as emergency lighting.Â  I also have a couple of cases of the very small canning jars that hold 1/2 cup each.Â  I am wondering if I could also fill them with Crisco and use thick birthday cake candles for the wicks.Â  Those would be like over sized tea lights.Sometimes ideas work and sometimes, not so much.Â  I was kind of surprised that the Crisco candle actually worked.Â  Candles don't give off a lot of light, but in a pinch, they are better than no light at all.

title: Tuesday Tidbits
text: It has been a week and still no window guys.Â  Guess they are in hiding.Â  My landlord hasn't been able to get them to come back here to finish the job.Â  I sure hope he didn't pay them in advance.I am loving the fact that Duane is back working at the restaurant where one of the perks is a meal each day he works.Â  The other evening he shared a meal of Chicken Alfredo.Â  It was delicious.Â  The man knows how to cook.Â  This from someone who, as a teenager, thought peanut butter and dill pickle sandwiches were the height of gourmet cooking.Â  (Shudder.)So what does a quilter do when she can't get to her sewing machine?Â  She cuts out more quilt pieces, of course.Â  Spent some time yesterday cutting some of the scraps left over from other projects into squares for a scrap quilt.Â  Or maybe two quilts.Â  I have lots of scraps.Â Over the weekend I dehydrated 10 lbs. of potatoes and 5 lbs. of onions.Â  I decided to make my own packaged scalloped potato mix instead of ordering those boxed scalloped potatoes from the store.Â  I just put 3 cups of dehydrated potato slices into freezer bags and added one recipe of the basic sauce mix in a sandwich bag, on top of the potato slices, and sealed the freezer bag.Â  So now when I want scalloped potatoes, all I have to do is grab a bag of mix from the pantry, dump it into a crock pot, add water and butter and ta-da...scalloped potatoes for supper.Â  I can always add a jar of my home canned ham cubes or bacon or shredded cheese about an hour before serving.Â  The recipe is here.Is anyone besides me already tired of political ads and politics 24/7 on most of the news outlets?Â  Good grief!Â  We have a year and a half to go until the next presidential election.Â  Give it a rest for a little while before we have total politics burn-out.Â  And as a side note, someone needs to tell Bernie et al, there is no such thing as free lunch.Â  Someone has to pay the bills for their 'Free Medicare For All' ideas.Â  A good sized chunk of money is taken from my Social Security every month to cover my Medicare.Â  I'm not complaining.Â  I have decent coverage.Â  But it is not free.Â  Nothing is.Â  (Soapbox kicked back into the corner now.)Not much else going on here in my little corner of the world.Â  Outside it is cool and rainy.Â  Inside it is warm and cozy.Â  I have lots to do to keep me busy.Â  Life is good.Â  :)

title: The Light in the Tunnel Was a Freight Train...
text: headed my way.The window guys did manage to install the two remaining windows in my living room on Tuesday.Â  Wednesday morning they did some work on the outside of the building.Â  I haven't seen them since.Â I wouldn't mind so much except for the fact that they moved furniture again - a couple of pieces into my bedroom and the rest taking up most of the floor space in my living room.Â  I can't get to the new windows to open them to let in the lovely spring air.Â  I can't get to my sewing table because one of my shelving units now sits in front of it.Â  They did cover my sewing table that holds several quilt tops I am working on, but they neglected to cover my sewing machine.Â  I wonder if I can get the dust out of it so it isn't ruined.Â  Sigh.I called my landlord but he had no better luck in getting them back here to put up the trim around the windows and straighten things up.Â  I thought about going all mad-as-a-hornet old lady on them, but realized that if they didn't care enough to move things so a woman with mobility issues could easily walk in her living room, I doubted they would get the point.Â  I have come to the conclusion that good manners and common sense are basically a thing of the past.So now that I have griped enough, the rest of the week has been productive.Â  I have 10 lbs. of sliced potatoes in the dehydrators.Â  Tomorrow I will dry 5 lbs. of onions.Â Earlier I had dehydrated the cranberry pulp left over from making cranberry juice, so I dug that out and turned it into powder.Â  I now have nearly two pints of cranberry powder.Â  I know it can be used for flavoring like in cranberry/banana bread, but I wonder if it could be mixed with something like lemonade and honey as a tea and used in place of the cranberry juice that I keep on hand for urinary infections.Â  I remember that years ago I bought cranberry powder at a pet store, on the advice of my vet, to treat a cat with a urinary infection.Â  I may have to experiment with it.My kids always get me something nice for Mother's Day and my birthday in June.Â  This year I have something specific in mind.Â  I can no longer drive or even go out without help.Â  So I talked with my youngest daughter Jeri, and she is going to take me to a huge thrift store nearby.Â  I love rummaging about in thrift stores and particularly want to add to my collection of reading material along with browsing among the kitchen stuff.Â  David called today and I talked with him about a trip to Sam's Club to stock up on some of the things I can't order with my grocery delivery service or are cheaper at Sam's.Â  He thought that was a great idea.Â  Jill doesn't know it yet, but she will be taking me to the fabric store.Â  I need fabric for the backs of quilts, quilt batting and a few miscellaneous sewing notions.Â  Duane can't drive yet because of the effects of his stroke, so we won't be going anywhere, but once in a while he brings me food from the restaurant where he is working, so I will let him off the hook!Â  Today he showed up with a half a pizza, so I didn't have to cook supper.Â  Last Sunday he brought me some sliced turkey, ham and roast beef along with a big bowl of mixed fresh fruit.Â  I'd say that was more than enough of a gift.Â  :)So that's what is going on in my little corner of the world.Â  Even with a couple of irritations, life is still pretty darned good!Keep smiling and keep prepping.Â  :)

title: There is light at the end of the tunnel...
text: and also in my living room.The windows guys showed up bright and early this morning.Â  They don't know how lucky they are that I had already had my first cup of coffee.They are busy tearing things apart and hopefully, they will be just as good at putting them back together again.Â  On the up side, it is not below freezing outside this time.Â  The plywood that was covering one window opening is gone before I painted flowers all over it as I had threatened to do.I will return when things get back to what passes for normal here in my little corner of the world.Â  :)

title: Just a Bit of a Ramble
text: It has been one of those weeks when nothing of any great value gets done, but lots of little chores are accomplished.First off, Bella the Rat Terrier stayed with me for three extra days, not that I'm complaining, mind you!Â  Apparently the restaurant where Duane is working was so happy to have him back at work that they scheduled him for more days than he thought they would.Â  So Vicki's Doggie Day Care Service was called upon to help out.Â  And when there is a pup to pet and belly rub and spoil, not much else gets done, especially when said dog is afraid of the thunder when a storm rolled through on Wednesday morning.Â  If I sat at my desk, she was under it with her chin on my foot.Â  If I sat in my recliner, she was on my lap, snuggling and trembling.Â  I don't think she got more than two feet away from me all morning.Â  But once the storm passed, she laid claim to my green fuzzy blanket and snoozed until Duane picked her up later in the day.Â  She went home Wednesday evening in order to be there when her owner arrived on Thursday.Â  I miss her.I have four large jars of bread and butter pickles in my pantry.Â  I can not eat an entire jar of pickles and chances are pretty good that if I put a large opened jar of pickles in the fridge, I will either lose it or forget about it.Â  So I re-can them into half pint jars.Â  This was the plan until I discovered I am low on canning lids.Â  Canning lids are not in the catalog I use for ordering groceries, but I have found a couple of places where I can order them in bulk, so that is on my 'to do' list for next month.Â I re-can several food items that I buy in bulk - usually in #10 cans - that are cheaper to buy than individual cans.Â  There was a time when I would get 25 lb. boxes of tomatoes from the Farmer's Market and make my own pasta sauce, tomato sauce and ketchup, but these days, age and arthritis have slowed down that process.Â  Re-canning makes it possible to get some foods at a good price and put them up in smaller batches that work better for a single person living alone.Â  I have done the same thing with cheese sauce and nacho cheese sauce, both of which turn out just fine.Â  Pickles turn out just a wee bit softer than the original, but that doesn't bother me at all.Â Most grocery stores have a shelf of bulk foods.Â  Mine includes instant mashed potatoes in a 3.5 lb. carton.Â  I will buy two or three cartons and divide the contents into single servings, stored in zip lock bags.Â  If I want flavored mashed potatoes, I just add a little garlic powder or onion powder or parsley flakes when I make it.There was a time when I thought it was a sin to serve anything that wasn't totally made from scratch.Â  But that was when I had a huge garden and when I milked my own cow and raised my own chickens.Â  And when I was decades younger.Â  I have since changed my mind.I know how to make chocolate or butterscotch pudding from scratch, but I prefer to add milk to a mix and whisk it for a couple of minutes instead of standing at my stove and cooking the pudding.Â  Sometimes I would rather use a Hamburger Helper mix for a quick meal rather than making a casserole from scratch.Â  Same with stuffing or the mashed potatoes.Â  Those of us with mobility issues often look for methods of doing things that don't hurt.Â  But it seems we need permission to use convenience foods because our mothers and grandmother cooked everything from scratch.Â  Sometimes I use store bought mixes and sometimes I make my own.Â  But if they will make life a little bit more bearable, it is OK.And that is enough rambling for one day.This is me...wishing all of you a blessed Easter.

title: Survive and Thrive
text: In my travels through the Internet, I found that FEMA had once recommended that citizens keep a three day supply of food and water in their homes.Â  Then their recommendation was six weeks worth of supplies.Â  The latest FEMA warning I read says that six months worth of food and water is recommended and they talk about power outages lasting that long.Â  Do they know something we don't?We have become a nation of selfish, lazy people.Â  I wish I had a dime for every time someone has remarked that they wouldn't go to all the work of preserving their own food because they can just buy what they want at the store.Â  And I might add, pay a whopping price for organic, non GMO food.People don't know how to do much of anything any more.Â  Why bother learning the old skills when you can just hire someone else to do the work.Â  Or push a button on the microwave.Â  Or Google to find out whatever you want to know.Â  This got me to thinking about how my grandparents were able to cope in their world without electricity and running water.At Grandma's farm in northern Minnesota, water was obtained by pumping it into buckets at the hand pump outside the back door and hauling it into the house.Â  A bucket of drinking water with a dipper in it was kept on a stool in the kitchen by the back door.Â  If hot water was needed, it was heated in big pots on a wood burning stove.Meals were cooked and bread was baked in that same wood burning stove in the kitchen.Â  That meant that Grandma and her daughters needed to know how much wood to use in order to cook food or bake bread but not burn it.Â  Someone also needed to know how to cut down trees, how to season the wood so it would burn properly and how to cut it up into pieces that would fit in the stove's burn compartment, as well as how to cut kindling to get the fire started.Grandma didn't have an electric refrigerator, even after the family finally got electricity in the house.Â  She had a wooden, tin lined ice box.Â  One door opened to shelves that held the food and another compartment held blocks of ice.Â  There was a tray below that held the water from the melting ice.Â In the country there were no ice delivery services as there were in the cities.Â  To get the blocks of ice, in the dead of winter, Grandpa and his sons hitched up a hay wagon to their team of horses and went to a nearby frozenÂ  lake.Â  They used hand saws to cut through the thick ice and cut the ice into blocks.Â  They loaded the blocks onto the wagon and drove the team back home.Â A large hole had been dug in the side of the hill behind the house.Â  It was like a small cave with steps leading down into it and wooden beams shoring up the ceiling and walls.Â  There was a wooden door installed at ground level that when closed acted like a trap door.Â  This was their root cellar where potatoes, cabbages, carrots and rutabagas were kept.Â  It was in this root cellar the blocks of ice were hauled and packed in thick straw, where they remained frozen all summer for use in the ice box.In the summer, Grandpa and the boys would load a small wood stove onto a wagon.Â  Grandma would get together food for a few days, canning jars and canning supplies and off the family would go to the blueberry bogs north of their home.Â  There the kids would pick blueberries and Grandma would can them up in jars using the wood stove for heat.Â  They slept on quilts under the wagon at night and worked during the day until Grandma had filled all her jars with canned blueberries, usually enough to last a year.Â  Then they would pack up and go home.I remember walking to the barn with my Uncle Kenneth when he went to milk the cows by the light of a kerosene lantern.Â  The fresh milk was run through a hand cranked cream separator, the milk running out a spout into a bucket on one side and the cream on another side.Â  Grandma would churn much of the cream into butter.The family kept a huge garden and Grandma canned most of the vegetables, but she stored some of them in the root cellar to have fresh over the winter.Â  She washed clothes in a wash tub using a washboard and handmade lye soap.Â  Her clothes dryer was a rope strung between two trees and a bag full of clothespins.Â  She and her daughters sewed their own clothes as well as shirts for the boys.Â  They saved chicken feathers to stuff pillows with.Â  They stuffed mattresses with straw.Â  They sold eggs and butter to pay for what they couldn't make themselves.Â  During the Depression, some of the girls taught in rural schools and some of the boys rode freight trains west to earn money on wheat thrashing crews or picking potatoes in Idaho, all of them sending money home to help the family.Grandma, Grandpa and their nine children not only survived, but thrived because they knew how to do things.Â  The family had greater importance in their eyes than families seem to today.Â  I have a hard time envisioning kids today working as hard as my Dad and his siblings did, without complaint, to see that the family had what they needed.Â  Given the same living conditions, and that's pretty much what we will have if the lights go out for an extended period of time, I have to wonder just how many these days would be able to cope.

title: This is Bella...
text: Bella is an 8 year old Rat Terrier.Â  Duane is taking care of her while his friend is on vacation.Â  And now I get to take care of her over the weekend while Duane is at work.Â  He will bring her home at night, but I get to play with her during the day here at Doggie Day Care.There are rules involved with watching Bella.Â  No feeding her French Fries.Â  Or spaghetti.Â  We must toss her toy every fifteen minutes so she can play 'Fetch the Toy.'Â  Bella is allowed to lay on the back of the sofa so she can watch the world go by in the street below.Â  I must share my recliner with her at nap time.Duane didn't bring any doggie treats with him, but I found that Bella dearly loves my home canned chicken cubes.Â  She is now my very bestest friend forever.Poor Bella spent the first half hour this morning staring at my kitchen door, waiting for Duane to come back.Â  She is now on my lap, helping me write this post.I think we're going to get along just fine.Â  :)

title: Ah, Spring.......
text: Duane posted these pictures on FB this morning.Â  They were taken just a few blocks from our apartments where he is house sitting and puppy sitting for a friend.And these represent the prevailing attitude here today.Sigh.

title: Getting Ready and More Mixes
text: We have a storm rolling in.Â  The clouds already look ugly and the temperature is dropping.Â  West of us are expecting blizzard conditions.Â  Here we are looking at rain, sleet and snow starting this evening and continuing until Friday.So this morning I made sure my dirty dishes were washed, dried and put away.Â  My washer and dryer are running and will continue until my clothes basket is empty.Â  Nothing worse than a sink full of dirty dishes and a basket full of dirty clothes if the power goes out.Â  Several 5 gallon buckets are ready to fill from the bathtub before the water pressure goes away.Â  Thankfully I have plenty of home canned food on the shelves that can be eaten right out of the jars if need be.So in between washer loads I have been working on making more mixes.Â  The following are ones that I use most often.Â  I expect that many of you are already familiar with them, but here they are anyway.Homemade Bisquick Mix9 Cups flour1 3/4 Cups instant dry milk1/3 /cup baking powder4 teaspoons salt1 3/4 Cups shorteningWhisk together the first four ingredients, blending well.Â  Add the shortening and cut it into the dry ingredients.Â  You don't want to see any lumps of shortening.Â  I use my hand held electric mixer for this step.Store in an air tight container.Â  Shortening is used because it doesn't need to be refrigerated.Â  I make up several recipes at a time, keeping one in the cupboard to use and freezing the rest.Â  If I am going to make a mess, I want to do it only once within several months.Â  :)To use:Â  Combine 1 Cup of mix with 1/4 cup water for biscuits and dumplings.Â  Bake at 400 degrees until lightly browned on top.Admittedly, biscuits from scratch are better, but these work well when I want biscuits quickly or when I am making them to pour stew or gravy over.Â Beef Gravy Mix1 1/3 Cups dry milk3/4 Cup flour3 Tablespoons beef bouillon powder1/8 teaspoon thyme or 1/8 teaspoon celery powder1/4 teaspoon onion powder1/8 teaspoon sage or 1/4 teaspoon garlic powder(Note:Â  When this recipe and the next one call for choices, I put it all in.)Mix well.Â  To use:Â  Whisk 1/2 cup of the mix into 1 Cup of cold water.Â  Stir constantly over medium heat until slightly thick.Â  2-3 minutes.Chicken Gravy Mix1 2/3 Cups dry milk3/4 Cup flour3 Tablespoons chicken bouillon powder1/4 teaspoon sage1/8 teaspoon pepper or 1/4 teaspoon onion powder or 1/8 teaspoon paprikaDirections are the same as for the Beef Gravy Mix.I dehydrate lots of different vegetables including potato slices.Â  I slice the potatoes thin using a mandolin slicer.Â  The slices are blanched in boiling water for 3 minutes, cooled down in very cold water, drained and then spread out in a single layer on the dehydrator trays.Â  I dry them at 135 degrees.Â  The time varies according to the kind of potato and the weather, mostly humidity.Â  I use the following recipe for using my dehydrated potatoes more than any other.Scalloped Potato Basic Sauce1/3 Cup plus 2 Tablespoons nonfat dry milk2 Tablespoons flour2 Tablespoons cornstarch1 teaspoon onion powder or 1 Tablespoon crushed dried onions1/8 teaspoon pepperMakes sauce for one recipe of scalloped potatoes.To use:Â  Place 3 Cups of the dehydrated potato slices in a medium sized casserole dish.Â  Sprinkle with sauce mix and dot with 3 Tablespoons of butter.Â  Stir in 3 Cups boiling water.Â  Bake at 400 degrees for 30-35 minutes or until potatoes are tender.Â  Cubed ham or bacon bits or cheese can be added for flavor.Note:Â  I wasn't completely satisfied with the results from baking the scalloped potatoes in the oven, but find that they turn out well when cooked in a crock pot.Stuffing in a Bag3 Cups bread crumbs or small cubes(Note:Â  I make my own by slicing bread into small cubes and drying it on cookie sheets in a 200 degree oven.).1/2 Tablespoon dried parsley1 Tablespoon onion powder2 Tablespoons dried celery slices or 1 Tablespoon celery powder(Note:Â  I found the celery pieces didn't rehydrate well.Â  I used my little coffee grinder to turn dehydrated celery into powder, so I get the taste of celery but not the hard pieces.)1 teaspoon thyme1/2 teaspoon pepper1/2 teaspoon sage (I like more so I double the amount.)1 1/2 teaspoons powdered chicken bouillonCombine all ingredients in a zip lock bag.To use:Â  Bring 1 1/2 Cups water to a boil with 1/4 Cup butter.Â  Stir in contents of the bag.Â  Remove from heat and cover for 5 minutes.Â  Fluff with a fork.I use many of my dehydrated vegetables for soup.Â  To avoid having to haul out several bags of vegetables every time I want to make soup, I put several pint jars of soup mix together at one time, and then it is just a matter of grabbing a jar, dumping into a crock pot, adding 2 quarts of water and letting it cook all day.Â  There are many recipes out there for soup.Â  I tend to follow a basic formula:2 Cups of vegetables2 Tablespoons of either beef or chicken bouillonSometimes I use dehydrated mixed vegetables.Sometimes I use just potato cubes, carrot cubes and celery pieces. (Celery rehydrates well in the crock pot.)Sometimes I put together vegetables that appeal to me at the time, including dried onions and cabbage.If I want a beefy vegetable soup, I add either dried tomatoes or a couple Tablespoons of tomato powder and a Tablespoon of beef bouillon.If I want chicken flavored soup I skip the tomatoes and use chicken bouillon.Â  A couple of bouillon cubes can be used instead of powdered bouillon.If I want meat in the soup, I just add a pint of my home canned beef or chicken or pork cubes.Â  Or maybe ham or turkey.Â  Or whatever meat is leftover from supper the night before.Â  The combinations are endless.Â  And the soup is really good.Â  Beats the heck out of soup that comes in a can.I saw it had started to snow about an hour ago.Â  That wasn't supposed to happen until tonight.Â  My green fuzzy blanket is folded over the arm of my recliner.Â  My Kindle is fully charged as is the battery in my laptop.Â  I'm ready for you, Mother Nature.Â  :)

title: Homemade Mixes
text: I am working on cutting back the amount of money I spend on groceries.Â  Over the years I have tried making my own convenience mixes and I spent the better part of today replenishing part of my stock.This first recipe isn't a mix, but it is a substitute for one.Â  I love chocolate milk and have in the past bought Nestle's Quick or Ovaltine for that purpose.Â  Prices have gone up and I just can't justify paying that much for an indulgence.Â  So I made a batch of chocolate syrup, similar to Hershey's.Chocolate Syrup1/2 Cup dry cocoa1 1/2 Cups sugar1 Cup water1/4 teaspoon salt1/4 teaspoon vanillaSift cocoa.Â  Whisk into water over medium heat.Â  Add sugar and stir to dissolve.Â  Bring to a rolling boil and stir constantly for 3 minutes.Â  Remove from heat and stir in salt and vanilla.Â  Cool.Â  Store in fridge.Â  Will keep for several months.I have stopped buying brown sugar.Â  I make my own, usually 4 cups at a time.Â  For every cup of granulated sugar I add 1 Tablespoon of molasses.Â  Using either a stand mixer or a hand held one, I stir the sugar and molasses together on a medium speed setting, scraping the sides of the bowl now and then, until they are completely combined.Â  I can't tell the difference between store bought brown sugar and my homemade.I am getting low on laundry soap, so I made another batch.Laundry Soap1 bar Fels Naptha soap (I use whatever bars of soap I have on hand - 1 bath size bar or 2 smaller bars.)1 Cup Washing Soda1 Cup Borax(Washing Soda and Borax can be found in the laundry soap section of the grocery store.)Finely grate the soap.Â   Stir in the Washing Soda and Borax and blend well.Â  Use 1 Tablespoon per washer load.I dearly love a cup of cocoa in the evenings or sometimes I will have cocoa and toast for breakfast.Â  This isn't the Swiss Miss type of cocoa, but more like what Mother made by heating milk and adding cocoa powder and sugar.Hot Cocoa Mix5 Cups dry milk3 Cups powdered sugar1 1/2 Cups cocoa powder1 Cup dry coffee creamer (like Creamora)Sift the ingredients together and mix until well blended.To use, stir 1/3 Cup of the mix into a mug of hot water.Toss in a few mini marshmallows for an extra treat.I know that the Jiffy cornbread mixes are fairly inexpensive, but I like the taste of my homemade mix better.Jiffy Cornbread Mix4 Cups flour4 cups yellow cornmeal2 Cups dry milk3/4 Cups sugar1/4 Cup baking powder1 teaspoon saltPut all the ingredients in a large bowl and blend well.To use:Â  Beat 1 egg and 1 Cup of water together with a fork.Â  Stir in 2 1/3 Cups of the mix and 1/4 Cup melted butter.Â  Bake at 425 degrees for about 20 minutes.Â  This makes an 8 x 8 pan of cornbread or 12 corn muffins.Â  Good just buttered but even better with a little honey drizzled on.That was enough for one day.Â  I have a few other mixes to make, but that will keep until next week, as I have other projects going that need to be finished.Â  I store all my mixes in canning jars, well labeled, so I don't accidentally try to wash a load of clothes with cornbread mix.Â  Don>t ask.Â  :)I like to have convenience foods like mixes on hand, but don't like paying the prices in the stores.Â  And by making my own mixes, I know what is in them.Â  Win - win!

title: You haven't heard from me because...
text: most of this week I have been a lazy bum.Thursday I had an appointment with my doctor.Â  Medicare wouldn't pay for part of my oxygen unless I saw my doctor, face to face.Â  So I did.Â  I suspected he would use this visit to do the usual blood tests that come with a visit and I was right.Â  So I found out I am healthier than I was 6 months ago.Â  I have lost 36 lbs. within the past two years.Â  I was able to drop one of the meds I take daily.Â  The swelling in my feet is reduced.Â  I still need the oxygen, but hey...you can't have everything at my age.Â  But I don't have to go back for a year.Â  That works for me.The best part of the day was having time with my youngest daughter who took me to my appointment.Â  There was enough waiting time for conversation and that was a good thing.Â When I have a day that includes stairs and walking hallways and in and out of a car, it takes a bit to recover.Â  Friday was mostly spent reading and napping.Â  I pretty much stayed away from my computer.Â  Sometimes I just need to get away from Crazyland in the political world.Â  I usually follow the news so it was lovely to ignore it all for a day.Granddaughter Boston called me.Â  She is spending her Spring Break week checking out colleges with her parents.Â  She told me all about the ones she had visited and so far really likes a smaller school not far from her home.Â  She is looking to take classes in business and finance.Â  She will be a high school Senior next fall and I'm glad she is getting a head start on making her choices.Â Son David and family stopped in on their way home from visiting another college.Â  They came bearing ice cream.Â  It was really good, but the most fun was getting caught up on what the three grands had been doing.Â  And hugs.Â  Hugs are good.When they called to see if I wanted them to pick up anything for me on their way to my apartment, I had Maddie Mae's afghan spread all over the kitchen table.Â  I had been sewing all the granny squares together and had to gather them all up and hide them so Maddie wouldn't see them.Â  The kids usually don't check this blog unless there is something their Dad tells them about, so I can post a picture soon.Â Not much else going on here in my little corner of the world.Â  I saw that nasty word 'snow' in the forecast for next week.Â  I have David's permission to stop praying for snow now because his customers are clamoring for the spring clean-up work his company does every year.Â  I hope this forecast is wrong.Â  It is time for lilacs - not snow!

title: Things Are Looking Up
text: God never closes a door but what He opens a window.Duane stopped in a little while ago to tell me he found a job.Duane spent many years cooking in restaurants.Â  He saw an add for a bar and grill that needed a cook.Â  He applied and got the job.Â  It helped that he knows the manager.Â  He knows the manager because he has worked for him before.Â  Both of my boys have worked in this establishment at one time or another over the years.Â  The manager told Duane that he was about to call Duane's brother to get Duane's number, to ask if he would like to work there again.This is a nice place.Â  I have had dinner there with my kids and grands several times.Â  It has been in business longer than I can remember and is a place where you can take your young children for a meal.Â  And it is only a block away from our building.One of the perks is that Duane gets one meal every day he works.Â  They make the best pizza in town.Â  I have been promised some of that pizza now and then.Â  :)I am really happy for him.Â  He has been working since he was in High School and not being able to work was wearing on him.Â  He is nearly finished with Occupational Therapy and is going to Cardiac Therapy two or three times a week, but that will not interfere with his work schedule.Â  He no longer needs to worry about transportation or driving on snowy, icy roads to get to a job.Â Life is again pretty darned good!!

title: Long Ago April
text: Many years ago, this mother of four youngsters was working in one end of her house when she heard an awful crashing, banging sound come from the other end.Â  It was followed by children's voices yelling, "Mom!Â  Come quick!Â  Jill fell down the basement stairs!"I rushed to the basement door, peered down to see my oldest daughter sprawled at the bottom of the stairs, covered in blood.Flying down the stairs, I reached my daughter, only to be met with a chorus of, "April Fool, Mom!!"My ketchup covered daughter was laughing, as were her siblings.Â  They had tossed a couple of kitchen kettles down the stairs for the noise and had positioned Jill at the bottom, looking like a bloody discarded rag doll.I let them live, although at the time this was debatable.Â  They all grew up to be fine adults.Â  But I always wished that each of them would someday have a child who would come up with a similar April Fool joke.Â  :)

title: Bits and Bobs...
text: I have been a bit under the weather this week.Â  Not sick...just a little head achy and low energy.Â  Sort of blah, like when you are coming down with a cold.Â  Last evening I curled up in my recliner with my Kindle and promptly fell asleep about 8:30.Â  This morning I woke to a gorgeous pink and purple sunrise, feeling great.Â  Or as great as I can feel until I have my coffee.Â  Guess sometimes getting enough sleep will cure what ails you.Although it is only 39 degrees this morning, I have a window open an inch or two and will open it more later when we are promised a 50 degree afternoon.Â  The tree outside my window is beginning to bud and the little birds are back - about a dozen of them, mostly sparrows and chickadees - perched on the branches, squabbling and gossiping and carrying on.Â  The sound is welcome after such a long, cold winter.While I was feeling out of sorts, I spent some time on YouTube.Â  It amazes me the things you can learn.Â  I ran across several videos about growing herbs in jars of water.Â  A couple of years ago I tried growing some vegetables in pots on my window sills, but it pretty much was a dismal failure.Â  When I order my groceries again in two weeks, I think I will order a few herbs to try and maybe a couple other things like lettuce and celery that they say can be grown in bowls of water.Â  It is worth a try and might be fun.The nurse who takes care of my legs three times a week is such a cute little thing.Â  When I talked to her about using flannel for the bandages on my legs, she didn't think I was crazy (or if she did, she didn't say so), and jumped right in to test the theory.Â  Anyway, she told me last week they are expecting their first child.Â  She says she doesn't want to know the gender of the baby until it is born.Â  I have been going through my stash of fabrics to see if I have enough baby neutral colors of fabric for a baby rag quilt.Â  I think I found enough yellow and green with bunnies and carrots on it to make a cute quilt.Â  If there isn't enough, I can always order some fabric online.Â  It is so much fun to make things for others.I am looking forward to my grocery delivery today.Â  I don't often indulge myself, but this time I ordered a box of Little Debbie Nutty Bars.Â  Life is always happier with a box of Little Debbie Nutty bars.Â  :)And now it is back to the sewing machine to sew zig-zag stitches around the edges of the last stack of 4x4 inch bandages.Â  That will give me around 200 of them and I go through close to 20 per week.Â  I love it that I no longer need to order more of the commercial ones, but can just wash these in hot, soapy water (to get rid of the salve on them) and they come out just like new.Love it when a plan comes together and actually works!

title: Cranberry Juice
text: So a couple of weeks ago I awoke with the symptoms of a bladder infection.Â  I opened a quart of my home canned cranberry juice and sipped on it all day.Â  The next morning the symptoms had disappeared and have not returned.I have used cranberry juice on other occasions for the same purpose, but used store bought juice, which took several days to work.Â  I suspect what the makers of cranberry juice advertise as 100% juice, isn't.A couple of years ago Duane brought me 75 lbs. of fresh cranberries from the Farmer's Market.Â  There is a vendor there who has the most beautiful cranberries I have ever seen.Â  I have never found a bad berry and each and every one is a gorgeous dark red color.Â  They make the cranberries from the store look like poor seconds.The berries come in 25 lb. boxes.Â  I had used most of one box but circumstances prevented me from preserving the rest, so I bagged them up and froze them.Â  Last year I needed the freezer space, so I thawed out the berries, filled canning jars with them, adding water to cover and canned them, thinking I could use them up at a later date.Â  The later date has arrived.After drinking one quart of cranberry juice, I saw I had only three quarts left.Â  It was time to make more, so yesterday I hauled all 29 quart jars of canned cranberries to the kitchen.Â  I dumped 5 quarts at a time into the stock pot, added an equal amount of water and brought it to a simmer.Â  I let it simmer for 10 minutes and then ran it through a colander, letting the juice drip into another pot and saving the cooked berries.Once that was done, I mashed up the cooked berries, added water to maybe an inch over the berry pulp and brought that to a simmer.Â  Then I drained all of that, extracting more juice.Â  Again I saved the pulp and will dehydrate it tomorrow.Â  Have no idea what to use powdered cranberries for, but I can't stand wasting them.This morning I dumped 7 quarts of juice at a time into a stock pot, added 2 1/2 cups of sugar and heated the juice until the sugar was dissolved and the juice was fairly hot.Â  Then it went into quart jars and was canned in a boiling water bath for 15 minutes.Â  I now have 35 quarts of lovely, ruby red cranberry juice, plus a couple of quarts in the fridge just to drink.This whole thing was an experiment.Â  I had only before made juice using fresh cranberries, but it turned out well.And now, you guessed it.Â  Time for a little nap.Â  :)

title: I Can Be Such a Dunderhead...
text: So I am at the sewing machine, happily stitching zig-zags around more 4x4 bandage pads.Â  I had just switched an empty spool of thread for a full one, when the stitches went all wonky.Â  I fiddled with the dials, trying to adjust the tension to straighten out the stitches.Â  Didn't work.So then I went in search of the instruction manual, tearing apart the book case where I thought it was.Â  Finally found it, buried under a stack of quilting books.Â  By that time there were books and magazines scattered all over the floor.Read the instructions.Â  Tried all the fixes for stitches.Â  The zig-zags were still wonky.Frustration is building.Â  I dug out my other sewing machine, only to find that the spindle that holds the thread was broken off.Â  Why do they make these things out of breakable plastic?Â  Better buy some super glue soon.Gave up and fixed a sandwich for lunch.Â  Back at the machine, I took a long hard look and discovered I had threaded it with quilting thread by mistake.Â  Quilting thread is stiffer and thicker than regular sewing thread.Â  No wonder the stitches had gone all wonky.Â Threaded the machine with regular sewing thread.Â  Worked like a charm.Â By the time I figured out what was wrong and cleaned up the mess I made looking for the manual and packed up the second machine and put it away, my morning was shot.Â Those who don't sew will likely not understand how frustrating these machines can be sometimes.Â  And those who do sew will get how something as simple as using the wrong thread can really mess things up.Â Yep.Â  Dunderhead.Â So then I took a nap, which seemed like the most reasonable thing to do at the time.Â  :)

title: Mysteries
text: Most evenings after supper dishes are done, will find me at my desk working on one handiwork project or another.Â  My computer is my source of entertainment.Â  I don't own a TV.Â  I got rid of mine when I realized I hadn't found anything I cared to watch for over 6 months.Â  Sometimes I will find a movie on YouTube.Â  Sometimes I listen to music on Pandora.Â  Then I discovered YouTube had audio books.Â  Many of the offerings were newer publications.Â  And that's when I realized how much our society has changed.Most of the books on my Kindle were gleaned from the Project Gutenberg website, where books can be downloaded in several formats, all for free.Â  They are mostly books that are out of copyright, so their publication dates range from the mid 1800's to around the 1930's or so.Â  Â My taste runs mostly to mysteries, but I have others like Dickens, Mark Twain and other authors of the era.Upon browsing the audio books on YouTube, I found some of the older books, but also found many newer mysteries.Â  Â So I decided to try them out.Â  What I found was that while the older mysteries had great stories to tell, the newer ones seem to be written more for shock value than for the stories.Â  Nearly every mystery contains a murder, and then the hero goes about finding clues to identify and ultimately capture the murderer.Â  The older mysteries follow a story line with a colorful cast of characters and various clues that lead to a conclusion in the last chapter and the mystery is solved often on the last couple of pages.The newer books seem to lean toward graphically describing every torture, often prolonged, that the victim endures before having their life viciously ended by the murderer.Â  And often the bad guy is a serial killer so we can relive these tortures through several victims before he is caught by hard hitting, hard drinking detectives who aren't much better than the bad guy.I realize that bad things happened during the times the older novels were written.Â  And sometimes those things are the subject of books.Â  But most of those authors didn't feel the need to rub our noses in every bloody, gory detail like they do now.I read for pleasure.Â  I read to escape the horrors of the day.Â  If I want nightmares, all I need do is watch the news.Me...I'll take Agatha Christie's novels any day.

title: What Will You Do When The Lights Go Out
text: I'm not talking about how to deal with domestic chores or the feeding and watering of animals.Â  Nor am I talking about how to start a fire or build a shelter or forage for food.Â  All of us will have plenty to do what with laundry and meals and dealing with sanitary conditions.Â  Those who raise animals and gardens will be even more busy.Â  I am talking about how to keep the kids from killing one another or driving you crazy during the times when, with electricity, they would be busy with their computers or cell phones or watching television.Â  Â Or those adult apartment dwellers like this chubby granny who will need to have something to occupy their time when the chores are completed.Â  Sitting in the dark waiting for the sunrise is sort of a bleak prospect.My number one suggestion is books.Â  Real paper books.Â  I love my Kindle, but unless I invest in a solar charger, when the battery runs down, I am done.Â  And I am not talking about the how-to books or medical books or survival books most preppers want on their bookshelves.Â  Those are important, but I'm talking about picture books for the little ones.Â  Story books, adventure books, girly-girl romance books for the pre-teens.Â  Mysteries, spy novels, travel books, history and biographies for the rest of us.Â  Many afternoons and evenings have been wiled away, lost in stories found in books.Â  Sleepless nights have occurred when I just had to keep reading to find out what happened next.There are other kinds of books.Â  For the kids, coloring books and sticker books.Â  There are all sorts of activity books for kids that not only keep them busy but can also teach.Â  My mother, who was in a nursing home but still had a very sharp mind, went through so many puzzle books to pass the time and keep her mind active, that my Dad had a hard time finding books for her that she hadn't already done.Â  There are how-to books.Â  Learn to knit.Â  Learn to crochet.Â  Learn how to build a birdhouse.Â  Learn just about anything you want to learn with a book.Â  Remember, without electricity, YouTube doesn't exist.Â  Nor do Google searches.You don't need to sell the farm in order to buy books.Â  My local library has a book sale every summer.Â  There are used book shops, thrift shops and garage sales.Â  I checked Craig's List and found a complete set of the 'Little House' books for $3 each and a set of 32 military history books for $30.Â  The good prices on books are out there.Â  We just have to look.Then there are craft supplies.Â  One year for Christmas I gave my then pre-teen grands small tubs full of craft supplies.Â  Construction paper, drawing paper, pencils, markers, a small paint set, sequins, buttons, scissors, glue sticks, feathers, art foam, etc.Â  Kept them busy for hours.Â  I have a stash of yarn and another of fabric.Â  And a picnic basket full of sewing supplies.Â  I make things.Â  I also have a stash of scrapbooking supplies.Â  I would bet that some of my grands would love to make small picture albums from those.Â  And a stash of beads and jewelry making supplies.Â  One granddaughter gave me a bracelet she made, so I know she would have fun creating necklaces and ear rings.Â Board games are another way to pass the time and have fun doing it.Â  Usually when my family gets together, sooner or later you will find several of them engrossed in a game of Monopoly or Yahtzee or Sorry.Â  Playing cards are used for any number of games as well as solitaire.Â  I need to pick up Uno cards and a couple of the other specialty card games to have on hand.I know that in a real grid down situation, much of our time will be spent just staying alive.Â  But we also need some down time to decompress.Â  The constant stress can wreak havoc on the human body and mind, and when that happens we are useless to our kids, our loved ones and ourselves.Â  Â  And kids don't always understand the seriousness of a situation and they need to be kept busy when plunking them down in front of a TV for cartoons or video games is no longer an option.I truly hope it never comes to this.Â  But the world has gotten so very out of control that I wouldn't bet against it happening.Â  And if it does, this is just another part of being prepared.

title: Flannel Update
text: I am pleased with most of the results.I cut out 40 bandage pads, 20 of the 4x7 family cloths and 20 of the 6x10Â  paper towel substitutesÂ  and ran a zig-zag stitch around each one.Â  I wanted to test them before going crazy cutting flannel.I am using the bandage pads now.Â  The nurse was here and applied them to the areas on my legs that needed them.Â  I use an antibiotic salve on each one.Â  Without that, they could stick to an open wound, but any kind of salve including just Vaseline would work.Â  My personal preference is Bag Balm (for cows) to use on scrapes or minor cuts.Â  My legs are wrapped from toes to knees in Ace bandages and they hold the pads in place.Â  For use in other areas I have found the first aid tape they sell in stores to be pretty much useless.Â  It doesn't stick well at all.Â  I would use duct tape before I would use the first aid tape to hold a pad in place.Â  I have used the ribbed part of a sock to hold a bandage pad on a cut on my arm, but I need to find a better way to keep them in place where I wouldn't use the Ace bandages.Â  Â I think two or three layers of flannel could be sewn together with a zig-zag stitch to provide different sizes or thicker pads, but I will make mine single layered and just use several together if I need more absorption.I got another dozen or so family cloths cut and then decided to quit being so persnickety about size.Â  My ruler that I use with my rotary cutter is 6.5 inches wide.Â  The cloths are now 6.5 x 6.5 inches square.Â  Went much faster cutting.I have been using the family cloths for a couple of days and find no problem with them.Â  They are softer than toilet paper and are very absorbent.Â  I washed them in my little apartment sized washer on the low water setting in hot water with a little bit of bleach and laundry detergent, and they came out clean with no odor.Â  In a grid down situation, they can be washed by hand.Â  Sometimes I think we have become more squeamish and less practical.Â  Grandma washed diapers for 9 children using a wash tub and washboard.I need to buy a small trash can with a lid to hold the used ones until laundry day each week.Â  I folded each cloth and stacked them in a basket that sits on top of the toilet tank.I don't like the flannel paper towels.Â  I'm not sure why.Â  Maybe they are too small and too thin, but when I made a couple larger sizes and double thickness, I still didn't like them.Â  The ones I have seen in how-to videos online and in Etsy shops are much more elaborate, often using terry cloth on one side and another fabric on top, with enclosed edges and top stitching around each one.Â  This isn't rocket science.Â  This is paper towels and I just can't justify the time and expense for making them like that.Â  So I may just buy some cheap washcloths at the dollar store or maybe use some of my older terrycloth dishtowelsÂ  instead and use the ones I already made for handkerchiefs.Â  I have a big bag that holds more sturdy rags that are from old clothes I cut up and recycled for scrub rags, mostly t-shirts and sweatshirts and pants.Â  With those and a few washcloths, I likely can get along just fine without paper towels of any sort.I will definitely be making more of the bandages and the family cloths.Â  I can dry them in my little clothes dryer, but I think I will look for one of those fold-up wooden clothes drying racks.Â  I should have one anyway in case we lose our electricity for any length of time making the dryer useless.Â  If stored in zip lock bags, they will stay neat and clean and can be tucked anywhere for storage.Â  Because they can be stored flat rather than on a roll, they take up much less space.Â  Any fabric will eventually wear out so having extras stashed seems like a good idea to me.Â  Lord knows - I surely do have enough flannel for it!!

title: Up To My Knees in Flannel
text: Daughter Jill arrived this evening with 26 yards of flannel.Â  I am going to be busy cutting and sewing.Â  I have decided to not only make the 4 x 4 inch bandages, but will also try some 6 x 10 inch pieces to use instead of paper towels and some 4 x 7 inch pieces for what is known in polite society as family cloths (washable TP).Â  The way I look at it, the more I use washables instead of use and toss, the easier it will be to store.Â  Rolls of paper towels and TP take up space I just don't have.Â  Fabric can be folded and stored in a much smaller space.Â  And as a bonus, I will save money that can go for other preps I can not make at home.So I will return in a couple of days and let you know how it all works out.Â  In the meantime, if you haven't already read Frank and Fern's latest article, you should.Â  The link is in the side bar.Â  It is definitely worth your time.

title: Back to My Normal Life
text: I have been busy getting back to my relatively drama free life.Â  Duane is home and doing well.Â  After a couple of months of physical therapy and occupational therapy to help him recover from his stroke, his remark was, "Oh, goodie. Now I get to go to heart therapy."Â  Sometimes we have to make jokes to keep depression at bay.Â  He says his diet is basically don't eat anything that tastes good.Â  But in all seriousness, he and his family are grateful that the problem of clogged arteries was found and fixed before he had a heart attack.Â  There have been many prayers of thanks as well as heartfelt thanks to all of you who have kept me and mine in your thoughts and prayers.I have been getting back into a sort of routine.Â  I found some ideas for quilts that will make use of all the leftover pieces of fabric from other projects.Â  I have been ironing bits and pieces, getting themÂ  ready to cut into little squares and rectangles.Â  Who knew a person could accumulate so many scraps of fabric, but there they are.Â  I can't make myself just toss them all.Â  Not when they can be made into something useful.I was talking with the nurse who comes in to care for my legs.Â  In the course of conversation we decided that the 4-inch gauze pads that are used to cover the open areas on my legs could just as well be made from flannel.Â  Â If I order the pads, sometimes the delivery person brings them to my door, but most times they are left at the bottom of the stairs and sometimes outside.Â  A box of 25 pads costs anywhere from $9 to $12, depending where I get them.Â  If I buy white flannel, cut it into 4-inch squares, run a zig-zag stitch around the edges to keep the fabric from fraying, I can get 90 pads out of one yard of flannel, which is on sale now for 2.99 per yard.Â  Even including the price of the thread, that's still way cheaper than buying ready-made.Â  And they can be washed and re-used.Â  So my daughter is making a run to Joann Fabrics to buy flannel for me.Â  Looks like I will be busy next week.Mother Nature is still grumpy.Â  She is sending us more snow for the weekend.Â  They say between 6 and 12 inches worth.Â  At least the temps are now above miserable cold.Â  We may even see some thawing next week.Â  I was beginning to believe a new Ice Age had arrived.Â  :)Â Not much else going on here right now.Â  I have more canning to do, but that will keep until a couple of my sewing projects are finished.Â  Nothing I can do about the snow except watch it fall and pile up - from my rocking chair - wrapped in a green fuzzy blanket - with a nice cup of coffee.Â  They only way to get through another snow storm.Â  :)

title: Update...
text: Duane's surgery went well.Â  The doctors inserted one stent in one artery and two stents in another.Â  He will remain in the hospital overnight.His sister called earlier to let me know the surgery went well.Â  Just a few minutes ago, Duane called me.Â  He was still pretty groggy, but he managed to tell me about the surgery.Â  It seems that one of his arteries was 90% blocked.Â I am so grateful that they found it and fixed it.Â  And I am so very grateful for your response to my call for prayer.Â  This little online community has a way of taking care of one another that is astounding.Â  Duane says "Thank you" for all the thoughts and prayers on his behalf.Â  And may God richly bless each and every one of you.

title: Calling on the Prayer Brigade Again
text: This morning Duane is back in the hospital.Â  This time he is having surgery to unblock two arteries.Â  Please. if you are so inclined, keep him in your prayers today.Â  I will post when I know more.Â  I thank you all in advance and thank God there are those of you I can ask for this favor.Â  Bless you all.

Dear Politicians, Both State and Federal:I see you have been busy devising more ways to deprive we honest, law abiding citizens of our Second Amendment rights.Â  For instance, in my state of Minnesota, there are two bills pending:"...One bill calls for universal background checks for any and all gun transfers in the state, including family members passing down an heirloom hunting rifle or shotgun, or a friend giving a gun to another friend. There are fears it could lead to the government compiling a list of gun owners. Another bill allows people to go to a judge with concerns about potentially dangerous people owning guns, and allows the judge to confiscate those weapons before going through due process."Â  (from the Lakeland Broadcasting Website)There is no law that will prevent the bad guys from getting their hands on guns.Â  Your laws will not stop bank robberies, convenience store robberies, gang related shootings or the actions of a man who wants to shoot as many school children or concert attendees as possible.Â  None of them.Â  Because criminals don't care about your laws.So before you get to the point where you want us all to turn in our guns, and don't think for a minute that we don't know that is the ultimate goal of politicians, I really wish even one of you would tell me all about your plans to keep guns out of the hands of criminals, because so far, none of your ideas are working, except to make it more difficult for we - the ones who you work for -Â  to defend our lives and the lives of those we love from the bad guys.I'm waiting..........

title: Sometimes things go according to plan...
text: sometimes not so much.The original plan was to combine all the ingredients for the soup and divide it between the two largest pots I own to simmer it for awhile before canning.Â  It soon became obvious that there were way more vegetables than would fit in the pots.Â  As I didn't want to spend the better part of the day cooking and not canning, I devised a Plan B.I filled each jar 2/3 full of raw vegetables and topped them off with diced tomatoes.Â  Â I made beef broth with bouillon cubes and used that for the liquid in each jar.Â  Â Because beef bouillon contains protein, I canned the soup at the same times I use for canning meat.One pint jar didn't seal, so I heated that soup for lunch.Â  It turned out really good.Â  There are still two canner loads waiting to be processed, but when all is said and done, I will have 48 pints and 25 quarts to go on my shelves.Â  It was definitely worth the time and effort.And now I think I could use a nap.Â  :)

title: Breakfast of Champions And Vegetable Soup
