text: So Wednesday I ordered some chicken and a salad to be delivered.Â  I was lazy.Â  My kitchen was clean.Â  I wanted it to stay that way.Â  Anyhow, about that time Number One Son shows up with one of my favorite foods - onion rings from the little Mom and Pop restaurant on the corner.Â  It has been years since I treated myself to a plate of their onion rings.Â  They are wonderful!Â  There were so many in the carry-out box that I could only eat about half, and half the chicken.So this morning, following directions from my son, I heated my oven to 400 degrees and put the leftovers in for about 4 minutes.Â  Perfect.Â  Breakfast of champions!!So here is what have been up to today.Â  And tomorrow.Â  And maybe Saturday.My grocery order was delivered today, including 10 lbs. of potatoes, 4 bunches of celery, 2 lbs. of onions, 8 lbs. of carrots, 1 cabbage and 4 bags each of frozen green beans, peas and corn.The fresh vegetables all need to be sliced, diced and chopped.Â  The frozen vegetables are thawing in the fridge.Â  Into my big roaster and largest stock pot they will go, along with several quarts of home canned tomatoes and maybe a pint or two of the tomatoes I canned a couple of years ago, with bell peppers and onions in them.Â  I will add beef bouillon cubes, parsley and black pepper. The whole shebang will be heated to a boil and then simmered for an hour or so.Â  Then into jars it all goes and will be run through my pressure canner.I use this mixture as vegetable soup.Â  Or I add home canned beef cubes for vegetable beef soup.Â  Or I thicken it for beef stew.Â  It is basically the same recipe, minus the tomatoes, that I use for chicken vegetable soup.Â  Both are my go-to home canned foods for a quick yet nourishing meal.Be back when I have worked my way out from under this pile of vegetables.Â  :)

title: I Thought I'd Heard It All...
text: but I was wrong.Â  Our legislature - the one in Washington - voted that it is perfectly fine to kill a baby that lived through a botched abortion.How do these people sleep at night?Â  I have nightmares at the very thought of killing a baby.Â  When did this become acceptable in the United States of America?The left fusses and stews and carries on about children of illegal aliens being separated from their parents at the border but have no problem with slaughtering a helpless, innocent infant.Â  I just don't understand.Â There was a time when I thought we as a nation could come together and solve at least some of the problems that face us.Â  Now I am not so sure.Â  A friend sent me the link to this article.Â  Â It is part of an interview with former U.S. Attorney Joe diGenova, a well respected lawyer who served as special counsel to investigate the Teamsters and as counsel to the Senate Select Intelligence Committee.Â  He made his remarks on the Feb. 21 edition of The Laura Ingraham Podcast.Â  The following is a quote from the article, as he says it better than I ever could.â€œWe are in a civil war in this country," diGenova told Ingraham.â€œThereâ€™s two standards of justice, one for Democrats one for Republicans," he said. "The press is all Democrat, all liberal, all progressive, all left. They hate Republicans, they hate Trump.""So the suggestion that thereâ€™s ever going to be civil discourse in this country for the foreseeable future is over," said the former federal prosecutor. "Itâ€™s not going to be.""Itâ€™s going to be total war," he said. "And as I say to my friends, I do two things â€“ I vote and I buy guns.â€I see every day how the left is working overtime to bring down our duly elected president.Â  They put way more time and effort trying to achieve that goal than they do in caring for those they are supposed to represent.And now they want to kill babies.I think Mr. diGenova is spot on.Â  I no longer think it is a matter of 'if.'Â  It is a matter of 'when.'

title: My Get Up and Go Got Up Went
text: Saturday was a lazy day.Â  A little reading, a little napping, some video watching on subjects that are of interest to me.Â  Sunday was more of the same.Â  I did enough work to keep from being slovenly, but that was about it.Â  I suppose I should feel a bit guilty for being such a lazy slug, but I don't.Â  I enjoyed every minute of it.Duane had a lazy streak going today, too.Â  When I suggested ordering a pizza and splitting it, he was all for it.Â  So we did.Â  To do penance, he is goingÂ  to cook a couple of nights this week and I will make fried chicken for us one night.Â  It is more fun to cook for two than it is for one.Duane posted this picture on Facebook a couple of days ago.He said that piece of equipment taped to his chest was his new best friend.Â I guess it isn't enough that he has had diabetes for years and that he recently had a stroke.Â  While in the hospital the doctors discovered that his heart isn't pumping exactly like it should.Â  So last Wednesday he had an appointment with a heart specialist.Â  They ran tests and gave him that heart monitor to wear for two weeks.Â  He hasn't got the test results yet and I expect they will know more when the two weeks is up.Â  He is taking it in stride - "one day at a time."Â  His sense of humor is still alive and well.Â  After all the snow we have had lately, he posted this meme on Facebook.I'm not sure, but it might have something to do with the fact that his Mother and sisters are all not much over 5 feet tall.Â  :)We had more snow over the weekend.Â  Here we got 3-4 inches, but the southern end of the state got closer to a foot of snow.Â  The wind has been howling.Â  It doesn't have much effect here in town, but I hear reports that roads, including some of the freeways going through rural areas, are closed.Â  The wind produced white-out conditions until they had to pull the plows off the roads.Â  Last I heard, the National Guard was out rescuing those who got caught in the storm.Â  We have had so much snow and cold this year that somebody posted a notice that all ice fishing houses needed to be pulled off the lakes this year by the 4th of July, just before the fireworks.Â  :)Me...I am ordering vast amounts of fresh and frozen vegetables to make vegetable soup to can this coming weekend.Â  Might as well keep busy.Â  I hear more snow is on the way this week.And I moved back here from a warmer climate because?Â Oh yeah.Â  I remember.Â  This is where my kids and grands are.Â  And they are the only reason the move was worth it!

title: This and That
text: It is one of thoseÂ days where there are several minor chores to accomplish before the weekend.Â  I like my weekends free to crochet or sew or indulge in other hobbies, so I try to get things done before.We had 8 - 9 inches of snow and more is on the way for Saturday.Â  Youngest Son just called me.Â  He said he has been telling the snow removal crews he manages that he already knows how to shovel snow and doesn't need the practice.Â  But he has shoveled snow this week anyway.Â  I asked him if I could stop praying for snow now, and he said absolutely not.Â  His youngest needs braces on his teeth, so David says he needs all the hours he can get!!Have you ever had something happen that set your antenna to vibrating?Â  Just a little thing.Â  My landlord hired a handyman who fixed my kitchen lights.Â  The next day he came knocking on my door, asking if I needed help with things like taking out the trash or moving heavy furniture.Â  I declined the offer.Â  When I mentioned it to David, he thought I should call my landlord about it.Â  I decided to give the guy the benefit of the doubt.Â  He might just be a kind hearted soul trying to help an old lady.Â  Or not.Â  I don't know.Â  This is where being protected is important.Â  So many politicians are working overtime to take away our Second Amendment rights.Right now it is legal for one person to sell another person a gun without having to obtain a permit to buy firearms.Â  Either a permit from the sheriff's office or a conceal-carry permit are required to purchase from a store.Â  Our state legislature is looking to change that so even sales between individuals would be unlawful without permits.Â  I have also heard rumors that they want to limit the amount of ammunition a person can buy.Â  Of course, this just makes it harder for honest citizens to protect themselves.Â  The criminals don't care.Â  If they followed the laws, they wouldn't be criminals.I had dehydrated lots of bell peppers and celery, but found the skins on the peppers and the celery both remained tough when re-hydrated.Â  So I used my little electric coffee grinder and ground them all into powder, along with some dried tomatoes.Â  I am finding I like being able to add the powder to my cooking for the flavor, without having the tough bits in the dish.Â  I may make powders from other vegetables for that reason.This afternoon I am to be pampered.Â  My home health care nurse is going to give me a pedicure.Â  I have never had a pedicure.Â  I have always trimmed my own toenails until recently when arthritis made it difficult to bend enough to reach my toes.Â  I think it will be nice to gt rid of these gnarly looking nails.Â  I swear, if God wanted me to touch my toes, he would have put them on my knees.Â  :)I am in the middle of making out my grocery order for Monday.Â  So far I have listed a bunch of vegetables, both fresh and frozen, to use in making vegetable soup to can.Â  I only have a couple of quarts left on my shelves.Â  It is good as a soup or, when canned beef cubes are added, makes a great vegetable beef soup.Â  Last night I heated up some and added beef cubes and a couple of packets of beef gravy mix.Â  That made a delicious beef stew that was easy, quick and required little attention from me other than a quick stir now and then.Â  It was wonderful with a slice of fresh, homemade bread.Â  Duane thought so, too, as he went home with a big bowl of the stew and some bread.And now I am off to the kitchen.Â  Chocolate chip cookies have been promised to kids, so I had better get busy.Â  These snow days seem to bring out the Suzy Homemaker in me.Â  They aren't much good for anything else.Â  :)

title: Yep...It's Snowing
text: This morning Duane's sister picked him up to take him to a doctor's appointment.Â  Before he left, Duane took these pictures from the corner of the block where our building is located.From my window, it looks to be maybe 6 inches of the fluffy white stuff on the ground.Â  It is still snowing at 1 pm.Â  Judging by the radar on the National Weather Website, the worst is past us but there is still more to come.Â  If this snowfall doesn't break our record for snow in February, the storm headed our way for the weekend will.Me...I am indoors in my cozy kitchen.Â  Loaves of bread, buns and cinnamon rolls are rising, getting ready to be baked.Â  There is a pot of vegetable beef soup simmering on the back burner.Â  The snow is actually kind of pretty.Â  I am just grateful I don't have to be out in it!

title: Interesting Week
text: Today started out at -2 degrees F.Â  Tomorrow will be warmer with 4 - 8 inches of snow, depending on which weather report you listen to.Â  Thursday is to be sunny, Friday cloudy and then it gets interesting.Â  Rain and snow is predicted for Saturday with more snow on Sunday.Â If things go true to form, the grocery stores will be jam-packed with panicked shoppers stocking up on bread, milk and whatever else they think they need to survive the weekend.Â  I just don't understand why folks would rather fight the crowds in stores than get ready ahead of time.For example - I will run out of milk today.Â  I usually have two gallons delivered every other week.Â  It is my own fault I ordered only one gallon this time.Â  My bad.Â  But I have lots of instant powdered milk on hand.Â  So this evening I will make up three quarts of milk and put it in the fridge to chill.Â  I am not fond of drinking powdered milk, but chilled with a few drops of vanilla added to each quart, it is palatable.Â  And I will have milk to cook with or bake with.By tomorrow evening I will be out of bread.Â  So tomorrow morning I will bake a couple of loaves, some hamburger buns and a pan of cinnamon rolls.Â  (And yes, Duane, you can fill up a plate of rolls to take home with you!) I have all the ingredients stocked.Â  I will cheat and use my bread machine, but should the ice storm headed our way knock out the electricity, I have the knowledge to bake bread the old fashioned way, stirring and kneading by hand.Â  I wonder how many of the younger generation have bothered to learn this skill.Â  Or of my generation, for that matter.Suppose for one storm related reason or another, I can not use my kitchen stove or oven.Â  I have a propane camp stove that will work to heat all sorts of food.Â  And most importantly, heat water for coffee!!Â  My shelves are filled with jars of home canned meats, potatoes, vegetables, fruits and soups.Â  And some pickles and relishes and jam for variety.Â  Even if I can't cook, the food is fully cooked from the canning process and can be eaten straight from the jar, if necessary.This is NOT a post to say that I am better than you because I prep and you don't.Â  Not at all.Â  It is merely a reminder that life can be easier and more safe if a person plans ahead.Â  I learned from my parents who learned from their parents.Â  My grandparents had no weather forecasts other than the signs of nature.Â  They couldn't just run to the corner store because the corner store was miles away and required first hitching a team of horses to a wagon and later, travelling in a Model T type of car over roads that were bumpy and rutted in the best of weather and impassable in the worst.Â  So they stored supplies.Â  They canned vegetables from their garden.Â  They butchered their meat and salted it down or cured it or canned it.Â  And they saw to it that their family of nine children was fed no matter the weather.Grandma and Grandpa weren't preppers, especially those with all the gear and bug-out bags and the like.Â  They were ordinary people who knew how to survive.Â  We could do well to learn from them.

title: Sidetracked
text: I tend to get sidetracked easily.Â  I start out to do one thing and often find myself off in another direction.Â  Sigh.Last week my kitchen lights went off and stayed off.Â  The handyman finally fixed them Tuesday.Â  So I have been busy catching up on the kitchen stuff that is difficult when the lights are out.Then I started out going through my fabric stash looking to see if I had enough of one color for the back of a quilt.Â  I found myself surrounded by fabric scraps and an idea for a nifty scrap quilt.Â  Now that I have light above my kitchen table, I can start cutting the pieces.My grocery order was delivered today.Â  I postponed ordering vegetables for the soup I plan to can, but will get them in two weeks.Â  I hope to fill in some of the open spaces on the shelves.Â  I did order 4 lbs. of butter and will order 4 more next time to can.I have been crocheting like a mad woman evenings.Â  I am determined to finish the last two afghans by spring.Â  I am getting tired of yarn and want to move on to playing with fabric.Â  When the afghans are finished, the sewing machine will get a good cleaning and oiling and then off to the races on quilts.Â  Â In between canning and dehydrating, that is.Â  The way things are going in the Swamp, I have a hunch we all had better be prepared for anything.Can you believe that 'Green New Deal?'Â  Let's see.Â  They want to eliminate gas, oil, coal - all fossil fuels.Â  We all will need electric cars.Â  Planes will go the way of the dinosaur, which begs the question... How does one get to places across the oceans.Â  Even ships need fuel.Â  And I won't even get into the discussion about farting cows.Â  What is really scary is that most of the Dems who are in the running for President are buying into it.Â The lunatics are running the asylum.Â  I'm just too old to go protest anything.Â  Phone calls, emails, letters and petitions are a waste of time.Â  Unless it involves power or more money in their bank accounts, they just don't care.Â  The only thing I can do is try to vote them out of office.Â  And gripe.Â  Here.Â  To you all.Â  Which is 'preaching to the choir!'And keep prepping.

title: Yesterday...
text: Duane went to physical therapy.Â  He has gone three times a week since he came home from the hospital after his stroke in December.Â  Each time, the therapist pokes his hand with something sharp to see if any of the feeling in it has returned.Yesterday, for the first time, he said he could detect a little bit of feeling in his hand.When you are recovering from a stroke, that is huge.He still has a long way to go, but we are so very encouraged by this.To all of you who have been sending good thoughts our way and to those who have been holding my son in prayer, a very heartfelt thank you.Â  There is power in prayer and God does hear and answer.

title: Murphy Lives at my House
text: First we had the window drama that is yet to be resolved.Â  There haven't been any days warm enough for the crew to finish the job.Â  It doesn't look real promising as the wind chill factor this morning was -25.Â  And more snow is on the way for Sunday and again on Tuesday.Â Then there have been problems with the furnace in the building.Â  The landlord has had repairmen out working on the problem.Â  This building is old - built in the late 1800's.Â  He told me the duct-work is a nightmare of a maze, my apartment being at the very end of this mess.Â  There is only so much they can do without shutting down the furnace and at the temps we have had lately, that is not a good option.Â  Duane's apartment next door to mine stays in the mid-70's range while mine is at 63 degrees when I wake up in the morning.Â  The space heater helps and I have lots of heavy sweaters and sweatshirts, so I am not exactly freezing to death, but Murphy strikes again.My kitchen is located between my living room and bedroom.Â  There is one window facing a brick wall next door, so not a whole lot of light from outside comes in.Â  There are two florescent lights in the kitchen that provide more than adequate lighting.Â  Yesterday when I flipped the switch, both lights remained dark.Â  Murphy, you devil, you!My landlord sent his handyman here to change the bulbs in both lights.Â  Nothing.Â  Turns out there is another part to the lights that needs replacing.Â  They will fix that sometime today.When the handyman was finished, he went down to his truck to get some rags to wipe up the mess of dirt and melted snow he had dragged in.Â  He had been shoveling snow before coming here.Â  He came back a short time later, asking to use some of my paper towels, as his damp rags were now frozen solid.Â  All I could do was laugh.Â  Welcome to Minnesota in February.Â  And Murphy, you are an evil genius.Here is my point with all of this foolishness.Â  None of it is within my control.Â  I have two choices.Â  I can get all mad and upset and raise my blood pressure to dizzying levels.Â  Or I can see the humor of it all and relax.Â  The windows will, at some point, get installed.Â  The furnace will get fixed.Â  So will my kitchen lights.Â  So I might as well get on with whatever I decide to do today and enjoy what I can.Â I find that my go-to meal of home canned food when either time is limited or something like a dark kitchen happens, is either vegetable beef or chicken vegetable soup canned in quart jars..Â  I have it as soup for lunch and then thicken it for beef stew or chicken ala king over biscuits for supper.Â  I have one whole chicken in the freezer.Â  So my groceryÂ  order will include two more chickens, a couple of beef roasts and vegetables to make more of each, as I am getting low on both.If nothing else, this last couple of weeks have been a lesson on how to cope when Murphy shows up and makes himself comfortable.Â  This is a far cry from the problems we would have should the grid go down, but it gets me to thinking about what I really need to do, just in case.I still believe that a working sense of humor goes a long way to make life bearable.

title: Some Days are a Delight
text: So this morning my phone rang.Â  It was Oldest Son.Â  He has a key to my apartment.Â  He uses it every couple of days to check up on Mom.Â  He thinks I don't know he checks up on Mom, but I know.Â  And I feel more secure because of it.Anyway, when Duane called, he said he had used his key earlier.Â  I was back in the bathroom, using the nebulizer which is noisy, so I didn't see or hear him.Â  He told me to check my refrigerator.Â  Seems he had been grocery shopping.Â  The store where he shops has an ongoing deal in the meat department.Â  The package a variety of meats in separate packages, selling them for $5 each - buy 4 and get 1 free.Â  He left half a dozen sausages in my fridge, bought using the store's sale.Â  I cooked three for breakfast and still have enough for another meal.Â  It was a nice surprise and the sausages are really good.When I checked the weather report this morning, I found more snow headed our way.Â  Some time back David asked me to pray for snow.Â  His job in the winter involves managing snow removal crews and earlier, we had very little snow.Â  That has changed.Â  We have had snow nearly every other day lately.Â  There is more snow forecast, along with wind and plummeting temps.Â  So I emailed David, "Can I stop praying for snow now?"Shortly after sending the email, my phone rang.Â  The first thing I heard was, "Don't you dare stop praying for snow!Â  This week alone has paid for Jacob's hockey."I wouldn't want David's job.Â  When there is snow, he gets very little sleep.Â  Customers call him all hours of the day and night.Â  They tell him there is snow on their sidewalks.Â  He says that's because it is snowing.Â  His crews go in and remove the snow when the snow stops.Â  And when the snow stops, customers call 5 minutes later, complaining that nobody is at their place of business to plow yet.Â  David is convinced that common sense has left the building.Anyway, it seems I need to continue to pray for snow for the sake of my son and his family.Â  :)On another topic, Fiona over at 'Confessions of a Crazed Cattlewoman' has a post today dealing with the insanity of late term abortion.Â  She talks about it much better than I could and I would wish that you all would read what she has to say.Me...I'm waiting for the next round of snow to begin.Â  In the meantime, I think my green fuzzy blanket may get a workout, as will my Kindle.Â  It is that kind of day.Â  Or maybe another surprise will come calling.Â  Who knows!Â  Even the life of a chubby grandma can occasionally be an adventure.Â  :)

title: What is Happiness
text: Depends on your point of view.For some it is a fancy sports car or a shiny new truck.For others it is a big house with the interior fashionably decorated.Some are happy with cruises or vacations to exotic places.Still others are completely happy with counting their money as it accumulates in the bank.Me...I have sort of a different take on happiness.This morning happiness was watching big flakes of snow fall, turning the dirty city streets into a white wonderland.This afternoon happiness was a phone call from granddaughter Maddie Mae, telling me about her 4.0 grade average and that she ranked 5th in academics out of her class of over 400.Â  I asked her what she wanted to study when she goes to college in a few years, and she said something in the field of psychology.Â  I told her then maybe she could find out what made her Grandma tick.Â  She laughed and said, "Grandma, you are so funny."This evening happiness was a nice mug of hot chocolate.Happiness is when I shared a meal of stew and biscuits with my son.Happiness is looking at my shelves full of home canned food, knowing my family will be fed should the time come when we need it.Most of all, happiness is the realization that I am content with what I have.Â  I woke up this morning and that is a bonus.Â  I have a roof over my head.Â  Many don't.Â  I have food to eat and clean water to drink.Â  So many don't know where their next meal is coming from.Â  I have family who love me.Â  That is a gift from God.I feel sorry for those who need money or power or luxury in order to be happy.Â  They really don't know what they are missing.

title: Recommended Reading
text: I just have nothing today.Spent the morning with the cleaning lady and a nurse.Â  Spent the afternoon going over what I need to get canned, finding the recipes and making out grocery lists for the next few grocery orders.Â  More bacon and hamburger and chili are at the top of the list, followed by vegetable soup, pork and beansÂ  and my favorite coleslaw/relish recipe.Â This evening finds me working on Maddie's afghan.Â  At the rate I am going, she will be married with half a dozen kids before it is finished.Â  And I haven't even started on the last one for Jacob.Â  Good thing he is only 11.Â  Might get it done before he graduates.Â  :)I did manage to read a couple of my favorite blogs today.Â  Rev. Paul over at "Way Up North" has a good article you will find interesting.Â  He has a way of getting to the heart of the matter.I will be back when I have something worthwhile to say.

title: Teamwork
text: So Duane read my post where I mentioned canning bacon.Â  We both like the results of the method that calls for lightly browning the bacon pieces before canning as opposed to filling the jars with raw bacon.Â  He said he would come over and cook up the bacon for me.Â  I could sit and fill the jars.Â  Turns out we figured that between us we have one good body.Â  :)I got 13 half pint jars of bacon bits.Â  There are so many uses for them.Â  They are good in scrambled eggs or in fried potatoes.Â  I have used them in scalloped potatoes and in casseroles.Â  Anywhere commercial bacon bits are used, these home canned bits can be used.I will be ordering a couple pounds of bacon with each grocery order until I have enough to can again.Â  I am low on canned hamburger, so will do the same for that.Â Teamwork.Â  Makes the job so much easier.Â  Thank you, Son.

title: Time To Get Busy
text: There have been a couple of wake-up calls for me lately.Â One was when my 54 year old son had a stroke.Â  He is way too young for these problems. I watch him fight to regain what he lost.Â  He can walk without tipping over now.Â  But his right hand is still completely numb.Â  He can't tell if the dishwater is hot unless he tests it with his left hand.Â  His hand still has the strength it did before, but he can't hold onto anything with it because he can't feel anything with it.Â  He worries about being able to work again.Â  I learned up close and personal that life can change in a heartbeat.The second wake-up call was learning that it is now legal to kill a full term baby as long as it has not yet been born.Â  I knew that evil had gained ground in our country, but I did not realize to what extent until now.Â  Â And to see the smiling women cheering as this horrific piece of legislation was signed into law was sickening.Â  If one state can legislate the killing of babies, what is next?I have always preached preparedness.Â  But I have become lazy.Â  I have used my medical issues as an excuse to put off doing the things I know I should be doing in order to be as prepared as possible for whatever comes next.Â  And if you think everything is just dandy, read the headlines.Â  As I write, our new governor is working to promote more gun control laws in my state.Â  We have our very own Sanctuary County that includes the City of Minneapolis.Â  Old friends tell me that the small town where I grew up is totally unrecognizable due to the influx of 'refugees' who find it entertaining to harass the locals in what was once a lovely downtown shopping area.Â  The list goes on and on.So it is time to stop making excuses and get busy.There are 18 cases of empty canning jars that need to filled.Â  This morning I dug through the freezers and found several pounds of bacon that need to be canned.Â  I have put off doing this because I have difficulty standing for more than a few minutes at a time.Â  Not good enough.Â  I am changing the way I can bacon.Â  Â I used to dice the bacon and brown it before jarring it.Â  But if I sit at my kitchen table and pack the raw bacon into jars and can it that way, all I need to do is lightly brown it when I go to use it, requiring less standing time.I found several small bags of sliced bell peppers.Â  Those are now in the dehydrator.Â  I have found that when dried, the skins are really tough when rehydrated, so I am running them through my little coffee grinder and turning them into powder that can be added to dishes for flavor.Â  Â Same with dehydrated celery that wants to stay rock hard.Â  I can use the powder for flavor.Â  I have canned celery that works well in soup or casseroles and will can some more as I am nearly out of it.I don't know what the future holds.Â  I just know I am not as ready for it as I can be.Â  Right now I am at a place where I don't need to run to the grocery store to stock up before a major storm.Â  But that's not good enough.Â  Should something really bad happen and my grandbabies come knocking at my door saying, "Grandma, we're hungry," and I couldn't take care of them, I would be hard pressed to forgive myself.Yep.Â  Time to stop fussing about my limitations and concentrate on doing what I can.

title: I Want to Know
text: I want to know why in New York it is alright to murder a baby up to one day away from its birth.Â  In many states, if a pregnant woman is murdered, the killer is charged with two counts of murder - one for the mother and one for the unborn child.Â  But yet it is now legal to end the life of the unborn for any reason or no reason at all.Â  And for the love of God, why are women in particular, cheering the right to kill their offspring.I want to know why a red cap with the words 'Make America Great Again' on it is considered in many circles to be the equivalent of a white hood.Â  Why is this cap such a threat to the left.Â  I thought every American wished for our beloved country to be great.Â  Now it seems to be a reason for the media to work itself into a frenzy over a school boy whose only sin was attending a religious school, having light skin, standing his ground and wearing a red cap.Â I want to know why my sons should apologize for being men.Â  As far as I know, neither are 'toxic.'Â  Both have a work ethic second to none.Â  They take care of themselves without the help of our nanny government.Â  They protect and defend family, whether it is their own wife and children or whether it is their mother and siblings.Â  They both have strong religious convictions and believe in the power of prayer.Â  Their sin is being male and white.Â  How having faith, showing respect for elders and peers and protecting their own equals 'toxic masculinity' is beyond me.I want to know why protecting our borders is 'immoral.'Â  I want someone to explain to me why 'our betters' feel it is quite alright for them to live behind the protection of gated communities and walls, but it is wrong for my home to have the same protection on our borders.Â  And while we are at it, why is it a good idea to protect illegal alien criminals in sanctuary cities and states.Â  Might as well hang a big sign over your front door - "Come on in.Â  Steal everything I worked hard to obtain.Â  Rape my daughter.Â  Shoot my son.Â  You will be set free to do it all again."I'm done.Â  Thoughts?

title: What Was Great-Great Grandpa Up To In 1878?
text: Having become just a bit burned out on crochet work and having become a lot tired of the window drama, I decided after reading a comment from a friend who is enthusiastically researching her family history (thanks, SJ) to do some work on my own.Â  I have tons of information, census records, birth, marriage and death records, letters, etc. on my computer that need to be organized.Â  So I am spending the next few days doing just that.I came across a bit of information that some might find interesting.Â  I know a couple of my kids will like it.My Great-great Grandfather wanted to run a ferry service from one point on the Minnesota River across to another, in the southern part of the state.Â  This required permission from the State of Minnesota in the form of a Legislative Act.Â  I stumbled across a transcript of that Act from 1878.Â  It is fascinating to me for the way it details how he is to run his business - even to how much he can charge his customers."GENERAL LAWS OF THE STATE OF MINNESOTA,PASSED DURING THE TWENTIETH SESSION OF THE STATE LEGISLATURE,COMMENCING JANUARY EIGHTH, ONE THOUSAND EIGHT HUNDRED AND SEVENTY-EIGHT,AND TERMINATING MARCH EIGHTH, ONE THOUSAND EIGHT HUNDRED AND SEVENTY-EIGHT.8,000 COPIES ORDERED PRINTED.ST. PAUL:RAMALEY & CUNNINGHAM, PRINTERS.1878.Page 411 - 412Chapter 131.AN ACT TO AUTHORIZE WILLIAM MATHENY, OF THE VILLAGE OF OTTAWA, TO ESTABLISH A FERRY ACROSS THE MINNESOTA RIVER, AT OR NEAR THE VILLAGE OF OTTAWA, LE SUEUR COUNTY, MINNESOTA.Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Minnesota:SECTION 1.Â  That William Matheny, of Ottawa, Le Sueur county, Minnesota, his heirs, executors, administrators and his assigns, shall have the exclusive right and privilege for the full period of fourteen years, to establish, keep and maintain a ferry on the Minnesota river, at a point where the section line between sections twenty-seven (27) and thirty-three (33), town one hundred and eleven (111), range twenty-six (26), in Ottawa, crosses the Minnesota river.Â  Said right of ferry to extend one and a half (1-1/2) miles on each side of said described location of said ferry.SEC. 2.Â  That said William Matheny, his heirs, executors, administrators or assigns, shall within four months of the passage of this act, place and maintain in good condition such boat or boats in said river as the requirements of public travel may demand for the safe and expeditious crossing and transport of teams, horses, carriages, cattle and other animals, and for the safe and speedy crossing of all foot passengers, goods, baggage and lumber, and all other freight that may offer or be offered at said ferry, and shall, on all occasions, give prompt and ready attendance at all hours of the day, during the season of ferrying, from the hour of seven (7) o'clock A. M., to the hour of seven (7) P. M., from the removal of the ice in the spring until such time as autumn or winter ice renders crossing dangerous.Â  Provided, always, that such ferrying shall not be demanded of the public as a right when by reason of high winds, floating ice, or other impediments of nature, crossing would be dangerous to the ferry or public safety.SEC. 3.Â  The said William Matheny, his heirs, executors, administrators or assigns, shall have the right to land their boats on the land of any person or persons in the county of Le Sueur, or in the county of Nicollet within the three mile range hereby granted in this act, provided the permission of the owner be first obtained.SEC. 4.Â  The said William Matheny, his heirs, executors, administrators or assigns shall, within three months after the passage of this act, file or cause to be filed with the auditor of said Le Sueur county a bond of satisfactory to such auditor with two or more sureties, in the penal sum of five hundred dollars (500.00) conditioned for the faithful performance of all the conditions of this act, and which said bond shall be for the benefit of any and all persons sustaining any damage by the neglect of the said William Matheny, his heirs, executors, administrators or assigns to perform duties enjoined by this act, and in case of failure so to do, the rights, benefits, and privileges granted by this act shall at once determine.SEC. 5.Â  That for each and every neglect to keep good and sufficient boats, or failure to give due and prompt attendance to all persons wishing to cross said ferry, the aforesaid parties shall be liable to a penalty not exceeding ten dollars ($10) to be recovered by and for the use of the county of Le Sueur, in a civil action before any justice of the peace, or court having competent jurisdiction, and shall further be liable for all damages that may be sustained by any person by reason of neglect of any of the parties acting under the privileges of this act.SEC. 6.Â  The rates to be collected at said ferry shall not exceed the following:Â  Each foot passenger five (5) cents;Â  each horse or mule and rider fifteen (15) cents;Â  each team of two (2) horses, whether loaded or not, twenty (20) cents;Â  each single carriage, drawn by one (1) horse or other animal, fifteen (15) cents;Â  each head of cattle, horses or mules five (5) cents;Â  each swine or sheep two (2) cents.Â  Provided, That the parties desiring to cross said ferry at unusual hours shall pay double prices.SEC. 7Â  If any person or persons, other than the said William Matheny, attempt to cross for passengers, teams, stock or freight within the three mile limit granted by this act, he or they shall forfeit and pay to him, the said William Matheny, his heirs, executors, administrators or assigns the sum of twenty dollars ($20), to be recovered in any action before a justice of the peace or court of competent jurisdiction.SEC. 8Â  All acts or parts of acts inconsistent with this act are hereby repealed.SEC. 9Â  This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.Approved March 11, 1878."I thought this was awfully wordy for permission to run a ferry, but I guess that's how the government does things - even at the state level.Â  It amazes me what information is floating around on the Internet.Note to my kids - Now you know how your Great-great-great Grandfather spent his time in 1878.

title: I'm From the Government and I'm Here To Help
text: So the crew of two brought along a third worker and they were going like a house afire.Â  Right up to 10:00 this morning.Â  When a City Official informed them they had to cease and desist.Â  It seems they were lacking a permit.They had just removed the second window and were getting ready to install the new one.Â  Mr. Official wouldn't even let them put it in.Â  The guys are now boarding up the opening and putting up as much insulation as they can.Â  They can do no more work on the windows today.They apologized like mad.Â  They will put my furniture back where it belongs.Â  They will dig my laundry basket out from behind a mountain of stuff in my bedroom so I can at least have clean knickers.Â  There is no point in moving the rest of the stuff as it will all need to be moved again when they return.Thing is...the temperature here will drop tonight into the 'way too cold to replace windows' range.Â  And the prediction is for it to stay in the single digits for at least a week and maybe two.Â  Most night time temps will be below zero. The wind is predicted to blow tonight and tomorrow up to 45 mph.I would really like to know where Mr. Official was last week when the guys were replacing the windows in the apartment next door.Â Your Government at it's finest.I don't know why I am surprised!

title: Not Done Yet
text: There is one new window installed.Â  There is one old window with all the surrounding woodwork removed.Â  There is one old window yet untouched.Â  There is plastic sheeting covering one of the two heat registers in my living room.Â  The temperature in my apartment remains a brisk 61 degrees compared to the comfortable 70 degrees where it usually is.Â  My green fuzzy blanket and I have become inseparable.Â The crew departed early afternoon today.Â  There is one more 20 degree day forecast before another cold snap hits.Â  Unless the crew moves at the speed of light, I can't see this project being finished in one day.Â  I hope I am wrong.Â I called my cleaning lady and asked her to wait until next week to clean my apartment.Â  My bedroom is piled high with stuff from my living room.Â  All my crochet material is piled on my kitchen table.Â  My living room is torn apart.Â  I didn't want her to take one look and quit on the spot.Â  Seriously, there is so very little space available to clean that it wasn't worth her time to drive here to work.Â On the positive side, my oldest daughter brought me a space heater this evening.Â  My living room is heating up nicely.Â  The new windows aren't quite what I expected, but they still look nice.Â  I thought they would be more like the tall, narrow windows you see on old buildings and they are a bit taller but just as wide as the old ones.Â  I found out that has to do with the fire codes.Â  The old windows were the crank-out type.Â  These are the kind that open top and bottom.Â  These are required so that a fireman can open them and climb through to rescue me in case of a fire.Â  Can't argue with that.Â Me...I have been mostly living at my kitchen table with my lap top, Kindle and crochet work.Â  Inconvenient - yes.Â  But not a permanent situation.Â  And I can still get to my recliner, so life is still good.Â But I am about as tired of window talk as you must be of reading about it.Â  I will post a picture when the job is finished.Â  And then it is on to other more interesting things.Â  :)

title: Oh Hold
text: So this morning the window crew of two showed up and moved furniture, hauled out the old blinds and screens and transferred some odds and ends to my bedroom.Â  Then they went out to work on the outside of the building.Â  About ten minutes later one of the guys came back in and said, "We took a company vote and if it is alright with you, we will be back on Monday when it might be warmer."I can't fault them for postponing work in hopes of warmer weather.Â  It is cold out there today.Â  Last I looked, it was 9 degrees F. with a wind chill factor of 1 degree.Â  That is almost guaranteed frostbite.They offered to put things back in place in my living room, but they didn't move stuff enough to bother.Â  The forecast for Monday and Tuesday is for temps in the 20's, not ideal for outdoor work but better than today.Â  By Tuesday they should be busy moving old windows and installing new ones.Â My cleaning lady comes in Tuesday morning.Â  I hope she doesn't cry easily.Â  :)

title: New Windows
text: This is my building.It was built in 1895.Â  Last summer my landlord had the stucco taken off the front of the building to reveal the original white brick underneath.A couple of days ago my landlord stopped in to tell me he was replacing the six windows across the front of the building.Â  Three of them are in my living room.Â It seems that the city, in trying to preserve the old look of the downtown area, wants the old buildings brought back to their original architectural designs.Â  Sometime in the life of this building, the original tall windows on the second story were shortened and modernized, probably when the apartments were partitioned off.Â Sure enough, the last couple of days the sounds of banging on the brickwork and sawing through Lord only knows what have filled my apartment.Â  They started on the side hidden by the little tree out front and are moving steadily toward me.Here's the thing.....it is winter.Â  It is cold outside.Â  It snowed some this morning and is likely to do so again tomorrow.Â  I hope they are just doing the prep work and will change out the windows come spring.Â  But if the new windows go in this week, it will be interesting to say the least!I like the look of the building now that the stucco in the picture is gone.Â  I'm pretty sure I will like the look of the tall, old fashioned windows.Â  But I think I will like them much better in the spring than at 15 degrees F.

title: A Light Bulb Moment
text: I have a new cleaning lady.Â  She is fairly young and is a city girl who didn't grow up as we rural types did, preserving our own food.Â  So I was rather surprised yesterday when she had finished her job, she came to me and said, "I don't mean to be nosy, but when I was dusting those jars of food on your shelves in the bedroom, I saw jars of cream cheese.Â  And butter.Â  And bacon.Â  Why do you do all of that?"Now usually if someone comments about my shelves full of home canned food, it is accompanied by remarks about tin foil hat wearing conspiracy theory nuts.Â  But she was genuinely interested, so I explained that should there be an emergency like a storm that knocked out the local power for any length of time, I didn't need to worry about food going bad when the freezer wasn't working or that should there be a national emergency, I had enough food canned to last a long time without having to go to a store.Â This conversation took place in my living room where another shelf of home canned food sets against a wall.Â  She wanted to know about those jars, so I explained about canning different kinds of soups and the makings for stews that fill two shelves and about the fruit on another shelf.Then she said, "So that's why you keep all those cases and bottles full of water.Â  If the electricity doesn't work, the water won't work either."It is fun to watch a person pick up on a new idea - sort of like watching a light bulb slowly become brighter.Â  She had questions about how to can different foods and questions about other ways to prepare.Â It isn't often that we who believe in being prepared have a chance to answer legitimate questions about the life style.Â  We usually get ridicule.Â  This was one of those rare 'light bulb' moments and I enjoyed every minute of it.

title: Made My Day
text: Sometimes it is the simplest of things that provide the most joy. I have been just a bit under the weather.Â  I am not really sick.Â  I think I am just fighting off an oncoming cold.Â  I am tired and very low energy.Â  Might be just a case of winter blahs or laziness.Â  Most likely laziness.Â  :)Anyway, Duane stopped in to tell me he had been to the grocery store where he bought a nice ham that he will bake for our dinner tomorrow.Â  I will provide scalloped potatoes and a vegetable.Â  He said he had dessert covered.Â  We do this now and then.Â  When you live alone it is nice to cook for more than just one person and to have company for a meal.Then from behind his back he produced a lovely tin filled with chocolates.Â  I love chocolate.Â  I have been known to call Duane of an evening and ask if he had anything chocolate he would be willing to share.Â  I have no shame when it comes to chocolate.But it wasn't the chocolates that really made my day.I asked Duane what had I done to deserve such a treat.He simply replied, "You're my Mom."

title: Finished - Finally
text: It just took forever to finish this afghan.Â  But over the weekend I put the finishing touches on it and it is done.Â  I lack good lighting and the space to spread it out, so these pictures will have to do.Â  It is large enough to cover a double bed.Â  The main color is more a teal than the pictures show.Â  Only two more to go and all the grands graduation afghans will be completed.I have pretty much been a lazy slug since.Â  Reading, napping, playing on the computer.Â  Â Once in a while, being a slug is a good thing.Â  I am now rested and ready to take on the world.Â  Well. OK.Â  Maybe just my little corner of the world.Â  Most times, that is enough.

title: Time Before Electronics
text: My Grands probably do not remember a time where nobody had a cell phone or an iPad or any other hand held device with a screen.Â  So I am here to show them what life was like for a kid way back then...We played outside, summer and winter.The year those pictures were taken, a blizzard had roared through Willmar, leaving a snowdrift about three feet deep in front of the house where my family lived.Â  My sister, the little one on the sled, stepped off the front porch and promptly disappeared from view in the snow.Â  Dad dug her out and after she realized she wasn't hurt, she wanted to do it again.The neighborhood boys would play hockey on the ice rink at the local elementary school.Â  There was a small shack at the edge of the rink that had a small potbellied stove in it and when toes and noses became numb from the cold, they would all pile into the 'warming house' to thaw out before resuming play.Every kid had a bike and we rode them all over town.Â  Parents today often consider that to be a dangerous activity.Â  Kids now wear helmets and often knee or elbow pads.Â  We just rode and bandaged up skinned knees when we got home about suppertime.Â  Parents today have to worry about their children being snatched up by bad people, but then we all knew who the crazies were and we stayed away from them.Sometimes Dad would set up an old Army tent he had and we would camp out in the back yard.Doors were never locked, so if the boogie man got too close, we could make a mad dash for the back door and safety.Little girls had dress-up boxes where their mothers would toss discarded skirts, dresses, purses, high heeled shoes and any number of other articles of clothing suitable for the world of 'pretend.'Â  One of the neighbor girls had a playhouse, which made clomping about in high heels even more fun.Â  I have to admit that occasionally I would play dress-up, but most of the time found me involved in a ball game or dashing down the sidewalk on roller skates.We knew about wildlife.We could tell the difference between a chipmunk and a squirrel and could most times tell what kind of bird was in the tree by the sound of its song.Nearly every backyard had a swing set.Â  They weren't the fashionable wooden sets we see today, but were more lightweight metal ones.Â  As we grew older, the goal became to get the swing going high enough to pull the legs of the swing set off the ground.I don't begrudge my grands their electronics.Â  After all, I realize that we live in different times, even though their Grandma is probably the only civilized human on the planet who doesn't own a cell phone.Â  I just want them to know it is possible for a kid to have fun without staring at a screen.

title: Ancestor Photos for David
text: My youngest son, David, emailed me this photo yesterday.He wanted to know if this was his Great Grandfather on his Dad's side of the family.Â  I dug through the pictures I have stored on my computer and found this one, taken in 1954 on the occasion of his Great Grandparent'sÂ  50th wedding anniversary.In the back, left to right, are their children, your Grandpa Henry, Great Aunt Caroline and Great Uncle George.Â  In front are your Great Grandparents, Louis Jewett Eddy and Hannah Berkness Eddy.Â  (I have seen Hannah listed as Hannah Berkness Moe, but have not delved far enough into the Eddy family history to know the reason of the difference in last names.)Â  There is no doubt the pictures show the same man.I found a few more pictures that might interest you, David.Â  You may have seen them before, but I thought it would be fun to add them here.This is Caroline, George and your Grandpa Henry, taken about 1917.The next one is your Grandma Inez Larson Eddy and her brother, Cliff.It was taken on Christmas of 1919.The next photo is of your Grandparents.Â  I think it may be on their wedding day, but I'm not sure.And this is your Grandpa Henry holding your Dad.Â  It must have been taken in 1942.The next two pictures I found online on a website called "Find A Grave."Â  It is a huge listing of grave sites that can be searched for location or name.Â  I use this site in genealogy research, for often there are other family connections and information listed.This is your Great-Great Grandfather, Pascal P. Eddy.Â  I also found his obituary from the Willmar, Minnesota newspaper."Willmar Tribune., September 27, 1911, Page 1Pascal P. Eddy.Another pioneer of Kandiyohi County has entered into his reward.At the farm home in the Town of Whitefield, on Wednesday, September 20th, occurred the death of P. P. Eddy, at the age of eighty-three years and ten months.Death come as a welcome relief to the worn-out body. The past year Mr. Eddy had been confined to his room most of the time and much The late P. P. Eddy of the time to his bed. The long, lonely hours were passed with his Bible, his books and papers. His interest in the news of the day was as keen as ever. But his greatest comfort was his Bible.Funeral services were conducted by Rev. D. B. Spencer at the farm on Saturday at 10:30 o'clock and at the home of Thos. Scotton at 1:30 p. m. The Presbyterian choir touchingly sang "Lead Kindly Light" and "No Sorrow There." The five sons of Mr. Eddy and Mr. Scotton bore the remains to their last resting place beside his wife who passed away four years ago.Pascal P. Eddy was born in Dudley, Massachusetts, on November 22, 1830. He was one of a family of nine children. His boyhood days were spent on a farm. In early youth he went into a woolen mill and learned the trade. On August 18,1852, he married Caroline M. Jewett.Soon after they moved to Norwich, Connecticut, and later to Ypsilanti, Michigan. In 1867 he came to Minneapolis to take charge of the woolen mill there, and they resided in Minneapolis until 1880 when they moved to the farm in Whitefield. The story of the thirty-one years spent on this farm is similar to that of many of the early pioneers tale of hardships, privations, loneliness and of toil unceasing. These labors have not been without material returns, for with his sons he has built up a splendid business. The Eddy farm is a synonym in these parts for a progressive dairy farm. Eight children were born to Mr. and Mrs. Eddy, six of whom are now living â€” W. Frank of Duluth, George H. of Minneapolis, H. B., C. T. and L. J. on the farm, and Mrs. Thomas Scotton of Willmar. There are eleven grandchildren, and one brother, William P. Eddy, of Brooklyn, New York, is still living.â€”"This last picture is of your Great-Great Grandmother, Caroline Matilda Jewett Eddy.Â  She is the source of the family tradition of using the middle name, Jewett, that was passed on to your Great-Grandfather, Grandfather, Father and brother.Here is her obituary."Willmar Tribune., November 20, 1907, Page 1MRS. EDDY DEADProminent Whitefield Woman's Useful Life Is Ended, and the Community Mourns.Death visited at the home of P.P. Eddy in the town of Whitefield on Friday, Nov. 15, and took away the wife and mother, Mrs. Caroline M. Eddy, a well known and highly respected resident of Kandiyohi county. Her death took place at five o'clock in the afternoon and was undoubtedly caused by general debility resulting from old age.MRS. CAROLINE M. EDDY.Mrs. Caroline M. (Jewett) Eddy was born at Dudley, Mass., March 27, 1833. She grew to womanhood in that place and on Aug. 18, 1852, she was married to Pascal P. Eddy.The following year they left Dudley for Norwich, Conn., where they lived for two years. In 1856 they moved to Ypsilanti, Mich., where they staid two years and in 1858moved to Minneapolis, this state.They were residents of the flour city during the pioneer days and in 1880 they came to Kandiyohi county, settling in the western part of Whitefield, which was at that timevery sparsely settled. Here they have lived ever since, honored members of the community.Mrs. Eddy leaves, besides her sorrowing husband, six children - W. Frank, the oldest, of Duluth Henry B. and Charles T.. at home George H., at Minneapolis Mrs. Thomas Scotton, of Willmar and Louis J., the youngest, at home.She also leaves nine grandchildren. Two sisters are living in Massachusetts. Mr. Eddy, the bereaved husband, is an uncle of Ex. Congressman F. M. Eddy.Deceased was a very lovable woman and of that sturdy uprightcharacter which distinguished the pioneers of our country. It is needless to say that she is mourned by a large circle of friends, in her community, in Willmar, Minneapolis and elsewhere.The funeral took place last Monday, Rev. Buell officiating. Short services were held at the home in Whitefield. The Presbyterian choir from this city rendered songs. The remains were brought to Willmar, where services again were held at the home of Thomas Scotton at 721 Sixth St., Rev. Buell making a very impressive sermon on the occasion. The floral gifts of friends were many and beautiful. Mrs. Eddy's earthly remains were laid to rest in Fairview cemetery and were carried by her five sons and her son-in-law. Long will her memory live in the hearts of those who knew her."Son, I probably could of gotten by just letting you know who was in the photo you sent me, but I got a little bit carried away.Â  You come from ancestors who were strong and brave in settling the land, who had excellent work ethics and who were good, God-fearing people.Â  You and your siblings have a rich heritage to be proud of.Â  See to it that your children know where they came from.Â  It is important.Love, Mom

title: Back Home For Janet and Jeanine
text: Two of Duane's aunts from his Dad's side of the family are coming to visit him on Sunday and will stop in here as well.Â  Duane's Dad's family lived on the same Minnesota farm since 1880, and in the middle of the 1950's, my Dad bought a small piece of it.Â  We had a big, old farmhouse on 20 acres.Â  We always referred to that place as 'The Farm,' even though it was only 9 acres of yard, garden and woods and 11 acres of field, which my Dad rented out to Duane's Grandpa every year in exchange for beef from the cattle he raised.Duane's aunts visited him in the hospital and they got to talking about the old house my family lived in.Â  I found a few pictures on my computer that reference that place, so I decided to do a quick blog post.Â  It is easier to blog the photos than it is to email them.This is the house Dad bought from a member of my kid's aunt's family.Â  It is the only picture I have of the house.The house was huge.Â  In the front were the living room and dining room.Â  To the back of the house were the kitchen and a bedroom.Â  The bathroom and four bedrooms were upstairs.Â  I loved that old house even in the winter when it was drafty.Â  I often would sleep on the big screened porch in the summer.These are my parents standing in front of the house.I don't know the name of the bushes behind them, but they are the kind that are filled with tiny white flowers in the spring, typical of those planted in front of many farmhouses of that era.Along the eastern edge of the yard was a long row of peonies.I wish I had a color photo of them, for they were beautiful in full bloom with colors ranging from white to deep red.Â  Beyond them was a narrow farm road going through the woods and dividing the property, coming out on the field to the north.Â  Janet and Jeanine, if this picture extended further to the right, you would see your Mother's garden.Â  I remember seeing her out there, planting, weeding, harvesting.Our garden was in front of the house, between the front yard and the road.Â  I think this is where I learned to love gardening, working there with my Dad.Â  There was a huge pine tree where the driveway split, going left to my house and right to your house.Â  Â This picture in front of it was the first day of school for my sister and me at the two room rural school called Sunnyside.Â  Had to be about 1955.Â  I was in the fifth grade and my sister, first grade.Â  If you look close you can see a white building in the background.Â  That was your Dad's garage.Â When my family moved into the house, the kitchen left a lot to be desired.Â  This was the kitchen sink area.Â  My uncle Ronnie and his Dad, Lawrence, came in and remodeled the kitchen.Â  This next picture is of me at age 15, feeding my baby brother, but if you look closely, you can see that same corner of the kitchen after the remodel.This last picture is of my parents in front of the big bay windows on the east side of the house.Â  I have no idea why they are so sober looking, for as I am sure you remember, they smiled more than they frowned.There was a shelf built in below the windows that you can't see because the couch sits in front of it.Â  Mother always had that shelf full of African Violets in pots.Â Janet and Jeanine - I hope you have enjoyed this little stroll down memory lane as much as I have.

title: Smile
text: Whenever I need a reason to smile, I go through some of my pictures of my Grands.Â  The smile turns into a big grin when the pictures include my Grandpuppy, Oreo.I think Oreo probably has more toys than my kids had when they were small.Â The dog even has her very own Christmas sweater.Boston emailed me these next two pictures.Â  She said that Oreo loves to sit like this with her and Maddie.Grandkids and Grandpuppies - guaranteed to take Grandma to a happy place.Â  :)

title: Merry Christmas
text: This Christmas promises to be more merry than I had anticipated.Â  Barring any unforeseen problems, it sounds like Duane will be coming home Monday.Â  He still faces a considerable amount of time with out-patient care, but he is really looking forward to getting home.My heartfelt thanks for the good thoughts and prayers for his recovery.Â  Â They have meant so very much to both of us.I want to wish all of you a happy and blessed Christmas.Â  I will be back right after the New Year.Â  God bless each and every one of you.

title: This is What a Positive Attitude Looks Like
text: This is Duane the day after he was admitted to the hospital.This is Duane today with his Aunt Jeanine, who works at the hospital where he is a patient.He looks 100% better than when he left my apartment a week ago.Duane is getting therapy every day.Â  He says they are working him.Â  I said, "Good."Â  He is out of the fashionable hospitalÂ  gowns and into his own clothes, which will raise anybodies spirits.Â  :)There was a family meeting with hospital staff to let them know how he is doing and what he will need when he goes home.Â  His siblings are looking into options.Â  He will need physical therapy.Â  He will need grocery delivery until he can drive again.Â  I'm sure there are other services he will need, but the kids are taking care of all of that for now.Â  They keep me informed and I talk to Duane daily.I just wanted to show you all what a positive attitude and prayer can do!

title: A Great Day Filled With Hope
text: My phone rang first thing this morning.Â  It was my son calling to tell me that he had just received a text from his Aunt telling him he had been accepted into the rehab program at the Sister Kenny Center at Abbott Northwestern Hospital.Â  It is not easy to get into this program.Â  Patients have to wait for an opening.Â  His Aunt is in a supervisory position at that hospital and even though she denies having anything to do with it, I have a sneaky suspicion that one or two strings were pulled to get him in.Â  Duane hasn't sounded this upbeat since this whole ordeal began.There is no denying the power of prayer.Â  My heartfelt thanks to you all who have been praying and voicing your support.Â  I wonder if you have any idea how much this means to my family.And most importantly - Thanks be to God.

title: Family Pictures For Kelly
text: When my brother was here we looked at old pictures of ancestors that I have saved on my computer.Â  He asked me to email them to him, but I decided to put them here so I could write better descriptions than I could via email.Â  Plus I seem to have a talent for screwing things up when I try to email pictures.Â  :)Kelly - To enlarge each picture just click on it.Â  You can right click - Save image as, to save to your computer.Â  Â As a reference in case you didn't know, this is how the lineage works...Our grandfather was Clifford Alton Matheny - grandmother was Rachel Alzora (Allie) Olmstead.Our great-grandfather was Hiram King Matheny - great-grandmother was Aletha Zarade Smith.Our great-great-grandfather was William Matheny - great-great-grandmother was Elizabeth Everhart.Here are the pictures in no particular order:Clifford and Allie on their wedding day - December 1879.Clifford and Allie - date unknown.Dad and Grandma in Blackduck, June, 1946.Mom and Grandma, June 1946.Grandma with 8 of her 9 children.Â  Veda was in California at the time and didn't make it home for Grandma's 80th birthday in 1950.Â  Taken in the front yard of the old home place.Left to right:Â  Grandma, Lois, Ronald, Vera, Kenneth, Keith, Clarice, Bruce and Ralph.Hiram King Matheny, taken in the mid-1930's.Hiram and Aletha family.Â  The tall boy in the back is Grandpa Clifford and the small boy on the right is Harley.Â  The girls in front are Sarah on the left and Bertha in the middle.Â  The girls in back are Maude and Esther, but I'm not sure which is which.Â  Taken about 1890.Family of Hiram and Aletha.Â  Â In the back Harley is on the left and Clifford on the right.Â  I think BerthaÂ  is in front between her parents, but I am not sure of the identity of the others.Our great-great great grandparents, William Matheny and Elizabeth Everhart.Family of William and Elizabeth.Â  They are on the far right in front.Â  I think Hiram is on the far left in front.Â  I'm not sure who is who with the rest of them.Â  Their names are (oldest to youngest):Â  Mary Jane, George Leander, Hiram King,Â  Simon Peter, Hannah Anne, Jesse Newton, William Andrew, Sarah Elizabeth and Minnie Orrilla.That's all the pictures I have for now, brother of mine.Â  Enjoy!

title: Family and Friends
text: The time we learn what family is all about is the time when life smacks us upside the head.Duane's brother and sisters have been at the hospital with him off and on, sort of taking turns and keeping track of his progress.His two aunts on his Dad's side, along with several of their family members visited him in the afternoon on Friday.Â  One of those aunts works at the Sister Kenny Rehab Center at Abbott Northwestern Hospital in Minneapolis, and has started the ball rolling to try to get him in there.Â  The Sister Kenny centers are the premier centers for stroke rehabilitation.Â  We are praying that he qualifies for admittanceÂ  and that his insurance will not quibble over that treatment.Â  We should know Sunday or Monday if he will be transferred.My brother drove the 230 miles one way from his home in northern Minnesota to here, and spent time with Duane.Â  He then came to see me and it was good to be able to spend a couple of hours with him.I have a cousin living in Texas.Â  We haven't seen each other since we were children.Â  We 'message' on Facebook.Â  She has been in touch with Duane through FB, so I let her know what had happened.Â  She asked for the phone number of his room and she called him.Â  They had a nice phone visit and I think it cheered both of them up.Â  And it gave her a reason to tease a bit about our Minnesota/Scandinavian accent compared with her Texas drawl.Â  :)When I talked with Duane this evening I asked how he was doing.Â  He said his main goal at present was to be able to stand without tipping over.Â  His sense of humor is alive and well.Â  Â When he first went to the hospital I think he thought he would maybe stay overnight, the doctors would sprinkle some fairy dust and he would be back at workÂ  Monday.Â  He now knows that it will take time and hard work to recover.Â  If anyone can do it, it is my wonderfully stubborn and determined son.My kids are keeping an eye on Mom, too.Â  They know how much of a help Duane has been to me.Â  Living next door, he has run errands, hauled out trash and brought me my mail, among many other things.Â  So they ask if I need anything.Â  David is stopping by tomorrow to do a trash run.Â  I said I wouldn't let him in unless there was ice cream involved and he allowed as to how that could happen.Â  :)Everything is on hold over the weekend and then we will see what the next step is for Duane.Â  I can not begin to express my thanks for the positive thoughts and prayers you all have sent for us.Â  Duane was blown away when he saw all the comments with prayers and good wishes for his recovery.Â  God bless you all.

title: Update
text: Duane's siblings have been with him at the hospital.Â  When the chips are down, they rally around.Â  Always have.My youngest daughter called to tell me the tests show that Duane suffered a minor stroke yesterday afternoon.Â  Being stubborn like his mother, he waited until early this evening to do anything about it.Â  He will remain in the hospital for now and have more tests and therapy tomorrow.I am humbled by the outpouring of concern and prayers from all of you.Â  There are still good people in this world and you are at the top of the list.Â  My heartfelt thanks to each and every one of you.To any of you who are of a mind to, prayers for my oldest son would be greatly appreciated.He has weakness and numbness on the right side of his body.Â  The paramedics offered no diagnosis but took him by ambulance to the hospital.Â  Duane said he would call me when he knows what is wrong and his brother will be with him in a couple of hours.I am praying and I am scared.Â  But we both believe in the power of prayer.Â  Thank you in advance and I will post when I know more.

title: Gone AWOL
text: I'm busy trying to finish Boston's afghan.Â  I finished the crochet work on the 144 granny squares.Â  There are 10 yarn ends per square that have been woven into the backs.Â  Now I am in the process of sewing the squares together.Â  After that there is a border to crochet all around.Â I will be back with pictures when I am done.Â  And will then answer comments and emails.Â  Just wanted to let you know I really didn't fall off the edge of the earth.Â  :)

title: Wednesday Ramble
text: There are workmen on the roof of my building.Â  I heard scraping sounds earlier in the week.Â  Yesterday there was a crash that rattled the dishes in the cupboard.Â  Thought for sure I would find an elephant had come through the ceiling and was sitting in the middle of my kitchen table.Â  Today more resounding crashes have occurred.Â  Â I don't know what they are doing up there.Â  I am sort of afraid to ask.Â I have decided that if God had wanted me to be able to bend down and touch my toes, He would have put them on my knees.Â Take several small pieces of venison steak.Â  Sprinkle with the contents of a package of onion soup mix.Â  Add just a splash of water.Â  Let the steak simmer in the crockpot all day.Â  Make gravy with the drippings.Â  Â Add potatoes and a veggie and you have a meal fit for a king.Â  Or a chubby grandma.Â  Your choice.Â I love it when I see the light bulb go on over the head of one of my children.Â  A while ago the power in our building was shut off most of the day.Â  A couple of days ago Duane said to me, 'I need to store more water.Â  I didn't realize just how many of those small bottles of water it takes to fill the coffeemaker.'Â  Nothing like priorities to change one's way of thinking.Â  :)Â Nothing exciting or earth-shattering going on here.Â  Crochet work, naps, reading, etc.Â  It is a simple life, but it is my simple life and I like it.Â  :)

title: Yesterday Was a Good Day
text: Late yesterday morning David, my youngest, showed up at my door bearing gifts.Â  Now I love seeing my kids even when they come to see me empty handed.Â  But these gifts were really welcome.Â  He came through the door, hauling a large tote bag full of meat.David buys a quarter beef every year and this year's order was ready.Â  He needed to make room in his freezer, so he brought two packages of steaks and a good sized roast.He had gone deer hunting this fall and had brought down a nice sized buck.Â  The rest of the bag was packed with venison summer sausage, steaks, chops and roasts.Â  He made me promise to share with his brother and I said I would.David had time to sit and visit for awhile.Â  I got caught up on what his wife and kids had been doing.Â  He told me he was leaving Sunday for a week-long seminar in Long Beach, California, for his work.Â  By the end of it, he hopes to get his irrigation certification.Â  He told me that he would have a view of the ocean from his hotel window.Â  He knows how much I loved being at the ocean, so he promised to call me from the beach so I could hear the surf again.Â  :)I left a message for Duane to stop over after work because there was venison and beef in my freezer with his name on it.Â  When he arrived, he found me sitting at my living room window, watching a parade.Every year my town has a huge Christmas tree set up in the middle of the old part of downtown, just a block away from my apartment.Â  The Friday a week after Thanksgiving, they have a tree lighting ceremony, followed by a parade.Â  I can't see the tree from my windows, but the parade goes by in the street right in front of my building.Â  Everything was decked out in Christmas lights, including the dancing elves and kids on bicycles doing stunts.Â  There were floats and a fire truck and all sorts of trucks with elves in them, tossing candy to the kids lined up watching.Â  Santa was in fine form with his own Christmas tree and a huge candy cane.Â  It was fun to watch.Duane came in while I was watching the parade and then we sat and talked for a time before he raided my freezer.Â  It isn't all that often I get to spend time with both my boys on the same day.After Duane left with his bounty, I had just settled in to do some crocheting when I heard a couple of loud 'Booms.'Â  I went to the window to see what was going on, only to discover the town had added fireworks to the celebration and I could see them perfectly.Â  It was a nice ending to a very good day.

title: Do You Remember...
text: Family picnics by the lake, complete with potato salad, ham sandwiches and Auntie Emily's famous dill pickles.Â  And a huge watermelon cooling in the water under a tree on the shore.Â  And Mother reminding us that if we didn't wait an hour after eating to go swimming, we would surely get cramps.Or playing Scrabble or Sorry or Yahtzee after the supper dishes were done.Â  And the Monopoly marathon with a cousin that lasted the whole weekend.Â  And those of us who had mothers who insisted regular playing cards were of the Devil, played Rook and Authors and Old Maid and Uno instead.There were lazy summer afternoons spent with actual paper books and we could get lost in them solving mysteries or going on wonderful adventures or, for the girls, sighing over romances or riding the range with Zane Gray, for the boys.Â  Seems to me we knew the difference between boys and girls back then.The hot Sunday afternoons spent sitting on the porch with friends or with visiting relatives, trying to catch a bit of a breeze.Â  There was a pitcher of ice cold lemonade, made from real lemons and a plate piled high with gingersnaps.There were summer days of riding our bikes as fast as we could go down 'Killer Hill,' trying to stop before hitting the railroad tracks andÂ  getting pitched off into the weeds.Â  Or in the winter, riding that same hill on Flexible Flyer sleds - the wooden ones with the steel runners - trying to stop at the bottom for the same reason.For us in the North, there were Saturdays watching our kid brother play hockey on an outdoor rink.Â  And there were Sunday afternoons at the skating rink, pretending to be a world class skater, even though I never did get the hang of doing jumps or even skating backwards.Â  But oh, it was fun to glide across the ice, stopping only when noses and toes became numb with the cold.Â  The little warming house with the attendant keeping a fire going in a small pot bellied stove was welcome.I realize that we can not live in the past, but sometimes when the headlines tell of riots and political stupidity and just plain meanness in our world, it is nice to revisit those long ago places and remember there was a time when our world was a place of kindness and respect for one another.Â  Where life was not so hectic.Â  Where the simple pleasures lived.Â  I rather like it there.

title: I Am Thankful
text: It is easy to find all sorts of things to complain about.Â  Our world has become a madhouse of biblical proportions.Â  But today, on the day we are setting aside to count our blessings, I would like to do just that.I am thankful for four adult children and six grandchildren along with various and assorted spouses and significant others who are all healthy and happy.Â  Everyone who needs to be gainfully employed has a job.Â  They all have roofs over their heads and food on their tables.Â  God has truly blessed my family.I am thankful for those adult children, for they are always there for me when I need them to be.Â  I seem to need their help more now than I did when I was still able to get out and about to do for myself, but they don't ever refuse and they don't ever complain about being inconvenienced.Â I am thankful for the wonderful nurses who come to my home three times a week to change the dressings on my legs and re-wrap the ace bandages for me.Â  They are a cheerful lot and their expertise keeps me free of infection and out of the hospital.I don't know if I have ever told you the story behind my use of oxygen, but I think now is the time to tell it.Â  One of my nurses sat me down and explained that when a person is not getting enough oxygen, the organs in the body begin to deteriorate and shut down.Â  With tears in her eyes, she told me that she didn't want me to die.Â  And when my stubbornness got in the way, she went over my head and called one of my kids, explaining the situation to them.Â  That's when two of them showed up at my door and bundled me off to the doctor's office.Â  The efforts of that nurse and my kids are the reason I can walk the length of my apartment now without having to stop to catch my breath.Â  They are the reason my health has improved and I am no longer sick half the time or too tired to do anything.Â  They are the reason I am enjoying my life much more than before. For them, I thank God every day.I am thankful for the friends I have made through this silly little blog.Â  Even though I will never meet you all in person, you have become an important part of my life.Â  I so enjoy reading and answering your comments and emails.Â  Sometimes I have lots to say and sometimes, not so much, but you stick with me anyway and that means much to me.So this is me.....wishing all of you a Happy Thanksgiving.Â  May God bless each and every one of you.

title: Right On Schedule
