text: The weather guessers told us the snow would start right about suppertime this evening and sure enough, it did.Â  There is only an inch or so on the ground now at 9 PM.Â  We may get another inch or so, but that is the extent of this round.Â  No complaints here, but I expect the ski crowd and the snowmobile people are hoping for more.My weekend looks to be a quiet one.Â  I think I am finally seeing the light at the end of the tunnel when it comes to finishing Boston's graduation afghan, so I will work on that.Â  I don't do much canning or dehydrating between Thanksgiving and Christmas.Â Everybody has places to be for Thanksgiving this year.Â  That's the way it goes sometimes when there are families of spouses to share holidays with and that's the way it should be.Â  Duane will be home, so he will roast a small turkey and make the stuffing.Â  I am in charge of mashed potatoes and vegetables.Â  There will be pumpkin pie.Â David called me the other evening.Â  He had taken Maddie Mae to her gymnastics practice and then delivered Jacob to hockey practice.Â  He was on his way to pick up Maddie Mae, after which he would collect Jacob and take both of them home.Â  Then he told me about all the stressful dealings he had with customers.Â  He is in charge of snow removal crews in the winter and some customers expect them to be at their place of business two minutes after it stops snowing.Â  Not going to happen.Â He asked what I was doing.Â  I told him I was spending a quiet evening with a book.Â  He said, rather wistfully, "Maybe I can do that someday."There is something to be said about my quiet lifestyle after all.Â  :)

title: Laughter
text: So last night the outdoor temp was 9 degrees.Â  And although my little apartment was warm, the idea of curling up in my recliner with my favorite green fuzzy blanket seemed like a good idea.Â  So I did.Â  Kindle in hand I began to read and several paragraphs later, fell sound asleep.Six hours later I opened one eye to discover morning had arrived.Â  As I levered myself into an upright position, my joints screamed bloody murder from being in one position for so long.Â I stumbled into the kitchen and started water heating for coffee, then proceeded on to the bathroom.Â  As I passed the bathroom mirror, I glanced at it.Â  The apparition that stared back at me caused me to back up for another look.A bleary eyed old woman looked at me, every wrinkle visible in the harsh light.Â  My hair has grown to be just a couple of inches above where my waist used to be.Â  I usually just tie it back in a pony tail to keep it out of my food and the dishwater.Â  It was now all askew with a huge rat's nest lodged in the pony tail over my left shoulder.Â  My shirt was rumpled like I had slept in my clothes.Â  Well. duh!And that's when I started to laugh.Â  I remembered this meme I had shamelessly stolen from Gorges over at Gorges' Grouse.Â  He posts some good memes and this one had tickled me.We live in a world of corrupt, power hungry politicians, and a government hell-bent on invading every aspect of our lives.Â  Some of our schools are now teaching kids about alternative lifestyles, as if kids aren't confused enough just being kids.Â  We have mobs of thugs harassing those who do not agree with their politics.Â  We have laws that apply to the rank and file of us but not to the elite, apparently.Â  And to top it off, we seem to be confused about which bathroom is appropriate to use.We need more laughter.Â  We need it to offset the craziness surrounding us.Â  We need the silly jokes and comedians who are actually funny and the ability to laugh at the truly ridiculous situations where we find ourselves now and then.Because when we lose our ability to laugh it quickly becomes just too much to bear.

title: Winter Wonderland and Vegetable Soup
text: Well, OK...So it is only maybe an inch of snow on the ground, but still...The lovely lady who cleans my apartment didn't show up Wednesday as scheduled.Â  She called to tell me she was a bit under the weather.Â  So this morning she called again to tell me she was still down with some sort of respiratory problem and we decided she should just skip this week and get back on schedule next week.Â  The last thing I need is to be exposed to some bug going around.Â  I'm glad she had the good sense to call me rather than just showing up.Â  The poor thing sounded just awful on the phone.Â  I hope she gets to feeling better soon.So now that my Friday is free, I am soon off to the kitchen to do some serious slicing and dicing.Â  My grocery order yesterday included the ingredients for a big stockpot full of vegetable soup.Â  Today I will prep the vegetables and tomorrow, combine them and can the soup.I don't use a recipe as such, but just toss in what I like.Â  There are 6 one pound bags of frozen, mixed vegetables, two pounds of carrots, one bunch of celery, one small cabbage, about four pounds of potatoes and two large cans of crushed tomatoes.Â  These I cover with water and toss in a few beef bouillon cubes along with onion powder, garlic powder, celery seed and dried parsley.Â This makes a good soup base that can be eaten as is or if I want a more hardy soup, I just add some of my home canned beef or pork for a meal.Â  This is good thickened served over biscuits, too.Â  It has become a staple in my pantry.So even though it is cold outside, it is a day of beautiful sunshine.Â  Even theÂ  city streets are pretty with a new covering of snow.Â  Enjoy your day as I am enjoying mine.Â  :)

title: Sigh of Relief
text: The midterms are over.Â  The mudslinging ads are done.Â  Here in Minnesota it was all about health care.Â  The left told us if we had a pre-existing condition we would die if the right was voted in.Â  And the right was all about calling the left liars.Â  The left pretty much won here, which is no great surprise.Â  And life still goes on and will probably continue regardless.I had a few days of catching up on chores that had been neglected and a few days of staying in my jammies and reading and napping and crocheting.Â  So now I am ready to get back into my normal routine.Â I have ordered enough vegetables for huge batch of soup to be canned.Â  They will arrive Thursday, so I will prep them Thursday afternoon and can the soup either Friday or Saturday.Â  When I get ready to use it, I just add a jar of canned meat and a bit of seasoning.Â  It can be eaten as soup or thickened over dumplings or biscuits.I haven't seen much of my two oldest.Â  Daughter Jill came down with pneumonia, but is recovering nicely.Â  Son Duane was feeling under the weather and then broke out in a rash on his forehead.Â  Turns out he had shingles, which caused him to stay home a week because shingles is contagious.Â  He stayed away from me, too.Â  He went back to work today.Feels like winter is just around the corner with colder temps and just enough snow in the surrounding area to cause a bunch of fender benders this morning.Â  Happens every year.Â  We forget over the summer how to drive on icy roads.Â  But we relearn fast.Â  :)So it is off to the kitchen to fix a bit of supper and then settle in for an evening of crocheting and movie watching.Â  I swear, this afghan I'm working on for Boston is taking forever to finish.Â  With 144 granny squares in it, I shouldn't be surprised it is taking so long.Â  I'll show it to you when it is done, but that may be awhile.It is good to be back.Â  :)

title: Taking Some Time Off
text: I need a break.Â  I don't watch TV but get my news from several Internet sources.Â  This doesn't insulate me from all the negative political ads and all the other political nonsense floating around these days.Â  I am sick to death of it all.Some lunatic sends bombs, real or fake, to Dems, it is Trump's fault.Trump wants to stop an invasion from the south, he is an unfeeling monster.When our President puts Americans first, the left loses its mind.I swear to God, if a Democrat gets a hangnail, Trump will be blamed.I think the proverbial straw was when I read that because I enjoy a glass of milk with my chocolate chip cookies, I most definitely am a racist.Â  See the column by Patrice Lewis on WND.I have several projects going, the most important of which is working on the afghans for my grands.Â  There is bread to bake and quilt tops to finish sewing and some canning and dehydrating to do.Â  I have found several audio books on YouTube that I will listen to while working.Â  I have set up Pandora to play selections of country and bluegrass music.The politicians can continue to chew each other up and spit each other out, but they will do it without me watching them do it.I'm done.So right now I m off to my kitchen to wash a few dishes and stir up a cherry cheesecake dessert.Â  I'll see you all right after the midterm elections.

title: First Solo Flight
text: My grandson, Zach, who is at college studying aviation, took his first solo flight yesterday.His mother says he did four takeoffs and landings.Â  She also said she was glad he didn't tell her until it was over!Congratulations, Zach.You done good!Love, Grandma

title: What Else...
text: do I store besides food and water.Â  That question was asked of me by one of my commenters.Â  I have been thinking about it over the weekend and have come up with a list.Before I get into that, I want to mention that there are countless websites full of opinions on what to store for an SHTF situation.Â  I have seen videos where people have entire rooms dedicated to preps and have everything under the sun stored 'just in case.'Â  Some store extras to use for barter.Â  Others order ready-to-eat meals or #10 cans of freeze dried food.Me...I live in a three room apartment and use all three rooms.Â  My storage space is minimal at best, so I have to pare the lists down to the absolute necessities.Â  That being said...I have a propane camp stove and a propane space heater should the gas to my building be shut off.Â  I have no place to store larger propane tanks, so I buy the small ones, pack them into boxes and keep them in the closet farthest from my exit door, which is also the coolest room.Those with a medical condition need supplies.Â  I stock 4x4 sterile pads to cover wounds, antibiotic cream and ace bandages.Â  That is the minimum to properly care for my legs.I don't buy first aid kits.Â  I have found that often when a kit is advertised as being say, 100 pieces, 80 of those are bandaids.Â  So instead I buy a variety of bandaids, a cream for burns, peroxide and alcohol wipes for cleansing an area needing treatment in addition to the above mentioned supplies..Â  I also have rolls of gauze.Â  I don't buy the tape sold with the medical supplies, for I have found it useless.Â  Masking tape or even duct tape works better.I keep Vicks, Vaseline, lip balm, hand lotion, cough drops and vitamins on hand.Â  Also a diarrhea treatment and Pepto Bismol.Â  My Dad always swore by 7-Up or Ginger Ale for upset stomach, so I use those as well.I keep extra dish soap and sponges along with Borax, washing soda and Fells Naphtha soap for making my own laundry soap.Â  Also bleach and bar soap.I have been negligent in taking care of lighting needs should the power be out for an extended time, but my list of 'need to buy' includes at least three oil lamps and fuel (kerosene is too flammable to risk storing in my apartment - thus the oil) candles, flashlights and batteries.Â  I am also wondering if those solar lights that people use in their yards might work.Â  Wooden kitchen matches are a must for lighting stoves, lamps and candles.I have a wicker picnic basket full of sewing supplies.Â  If a person has a hobby, now would be the time to collect materials.Â  I have lots of yarn and fabric.Â  And books.Â  I have a Kindle, but it would be pretty difficult to charge it without electricity unless I had a solar charger.Â  A selection of board games, playing cards, paper, colored pencils and markers are going into a box for a worst case scenario time if the grid goes down.Â  If I didn't have anything to occupy my time and mind, I would be a raving lunatic in no time at all.And a selection of hard candies.Â  I know that sounds silly, but if things get bad for a long time, a Tootsie Roll Pop or a butterscotch disc might be the very thing to make us feel better.Â  A little treat never hurt anyone and it might just keep the kids from doing damage to one another.I'm sure there are many more items one could stock up on, but that is about all I can cram into my small living space and still be able to get from one room to another without having to crawl over stuff.Â  :)What items do you consider necessary to store?

title: Good Report
text: So today I had my yearly Dr. appointment.Â  Looks like I am going to be around a while longer to pester everyone.Last year I had to argue with my Dr. about coming in every three months like he wanted me to.Â  I held out for a yearly visit unless I became ill.Â  Today, when we were finished, he said, "See you next year."Â  A years worth of prescriptions are being sent to the pharmacy like I requested.Â  All the levels he checks for are in the 'normal' range.Â  I am 20 lbs. lighter than a year ago, through no fault of my own.Â  :)When a person reaches a certain age they are required to answerÂ  questions about their mental health.Â  Judging by the questions, there must be many of my vintage who have no interests to keep them busy and who are suffering from depression.Â  I find that so sad.Â  My youngest son was there with me and while I was filling out one of those questionnaires,Â  he asked the nurse if there was a blank to fill in about being stubborn and ornery.Â  I love that kid and his sense of humor.Â  :)Even though I was in the last place I cared to be, it has been a lovely day.Â  I got to spend time with my youngest and I enjoyed every minute of it.Â  He has a new car and he was showing me all the features it has.Â  There is a screen showing what is behind him when he backs up.Â  The screen is also his cell phone that he can access with a touch of the finger while driving.Â  When he stops at a stop sign, the engineÂ  automatically shuts off and then restarts when he wants to go forward.Â  The seats heat up.Â  Good grief!Â  I asked him what he would do if suddenly all the gadgets failed.Â  Considering that his job requires extensive cell phone and computer use, he said he would probably enjoy the peace and quiet.I think what is left of my day, having taken a nice long nap, will be spent quietly recovering from climbing stairs and answering questions.Â  But tomorrow, watch out.Â  There are cookies to be baked and bread to be made.Â  Â All things considered, life is still pretty darned good.

title: Off and Running like a Herd of Turtles
text: Having spent a relaxing weekend, it is time to get busy.15 lbs. of hamburger are waiting to be jarred and processed.4 lbs. each of broccoli and cauliflower and onions await the dehydrators.10 lbs. of potatoes need to be peeled and sliced and driedMy bread machine has been dusted off and is ready to produce lovely loves of bread and some tasty rolls.Â  My gosh, but store bread has become expensive.Â  I don't like baking bread in the machine, but shape the dough into loaves and bake it in the oven, now that the heat of summer has past.Â  The only drawback is that I can make only one loaf at a time.Â  But I can live with that.Â  The machine makes it possible to have good bread for pennies and it does the stirring and kneading for me.Â So I am off, like a herd of turtles, to see what I can accomplish in the next couple of days.Â  As they say, 'Keep on prepping.'Â  Judging by what is going on in Portland with the antifa mob taking over the streets and all the craziness elsewhere, that seems to be pretty good advice.

title: Shiver

title: It Rained...
text: yesterday.Â  It rained the day before yesterday.Â  It is going to rain tomorrow.Â  And the day after tomorrow.Â  It is raining now.Â  I wonder if I can find building plans for an ark online.Youngest son called me yesterday.Â  He was picking Maddie Mae up from gymnastics, so I talked to her, too.Â  The gymnastics season hasn't started yet, but she practises and says she is learning some new moves.Â  I made her promise to pester her Dad until he took some video of her so I can see what she is doing.Â  She said she would be happy to do just that.Boston's school now and then has a themed day.Â  A week or so ago, the theme was patriotism.Â  Boston wanted to wear a Trump 'Make America Great Again' hat.Â  Â David said he couldn't find one in time.Â  Even so, I was so proud!!Â  We both agreed that the way things are these days, wearing a Trump hat might have gotten her beat up.Â  I still love the fact that the hat was her first choice for the day.Â I was going to make beef stew and biscuits last week but life just got in the way.Â  So today I put a big pot of stew on the back burner to simmer the better part of the afternoon.Â  Duane came over to eat supper with me and took a bowl full home to take in his lunch when he goes to work tomorrow.Â  Wish he had taken more - I will be eating stew the rest of the week.Â  :)There is really very little going on here at the moment.Â  I read or crochet or nap.Â  I have ordered some more food for the dehydrator - hash browns and corn - that will arrive Thursday.I have noticed that some of the bloggers I read regularly are experiencing the same sort of uneasiness that I am.Â  And maybe a sense of urgency to fill in any gaps in the preps.Â  Sort of like waiting for the other shoe to drop.Â  My retired cop friend who keeps me and several others informed of what is going on around us, has been more prolific with his emails lately.Â  I might have to give him a call and see what he knows for sure.Â  In the meantime, I just keep adding to the shelves as often as I can.Â  Seems like the smart thing to do.

title: Desserts From the 1950's
text: A frequent commenter on this blog and I have been talking about old time Jello dessert recipes.Â  My Mother was the Queen of the JelloÂ  refrigerator type dessert recipes and I have several of those recipes in my possession.Â  Thing is, I couldn't find them.Â I have Mother's old recipe box.Â  I think it is actually Dad's recipe box.Â  Mother's would have been organized and alphabetized.Â  This one is full of clippings from magazines and newspapers, recipes written on the backs of old envelopes, recipes written on pieces of notebook paper and recipes cut from the backs of boxes and labels.Â  I went through, piece by piece but no dessert recipes.I carefully looked through all of my old cookbooks.Â  No luck.Then the light bulb went on and I remembered I had moved those recipes to my own recipe box.Â  Sure enough.Â  There they were.As it turns out, only one of these recipes uses Jello.Â  But if memory serves, the rest are so good that I am including them as well.The following are written here as they appeared on the original recipe cards.Â  Notes in parenthesis are mine in the hope of making instructions more clear.Lime DessertDissolve 1 pkg. (small size) lime Jello in 1/2 cup boiling water.Â  Add 2/3 cup sugar.Â  Stir until dissolved.Beat 3 egg whites until stiff.Â  Add 1 tsp. vanilla.Fold Jello into egg whites.Â  Fold in 1 pint whipped cream (I think this means start with 1 pint of whipping cream - then whip) into mixture.Crush 25 Hydrox (or Oreo) cookies.Â  Butter pan (I don't know what size) and spread 2/3 of the crumbs on bottom.Â  Pour in lime mixture.Â  Top with remaining cookie crumbs.Â  Chill 12 hours.Cherry Dessert18 - 20 graham crackers1/2 lb. marshmallows1/2 lb. butter1 cup whipping cream1/2 cup milk1 can cherry pie fillingCrush crackers.Â  Place 1/2 in 7 x 12 inch pan.Â  Melt butter, add milk and marshmallows.Â  Cook until marshmallows are melted.Â  Cool.Add cream which has been whipped.Place 1/2 mixture over crumbs, then pie filling, then rest of marshmallow mixture.Sprinkle with remaining crumbs.Â  Refrigerate overnight.Strawberry Chiffon Dessert30 marshmallows1 - 1/4 cup milk1 pkg. frozen strawberriesÂ  (Many brands of frozen strawberries come in 10 oz. packages.Â  Back when this recipe was used by my Mother, the berries came in 16 oz. packages.Â  I would go with more berries rather than less.)1 pint cream, whipped1 loaf angel food cakeMelt in double boiler marshmallows in the milk.Â  Cool.Drain juice from berries and save.Whip cream and add berries and marshmallow mixture.Tear cake into bite sized pieces and put in loaf pan.Pour mixture over cake.Â  Chill.Topping:1/2 cup sugar3 Tbsp. corn starchreserved juice plus 1 cup waterCook until thick and chill.Â  Spoon over pieces of dessert when served.Â Lemon FreezeÂ 1 cup graham cracker crumbsÂ 1/4 cup lemon juiceÂ 1 1/2 tsp. grated lemon rindÂ 1/8 tsp saltÂ 1/2 cup sugarÂ 3 eggs, separatedÂ 1 can (6 oz.) evaporated milk, chilledÂ Line refrigerator tray (I'm not sure what a refrigerator tray is, but I would use a pie tin or a 9x9 inch pan.)Â  with 1/2 the crumbs.Â Blend lemon juice, rind, salt and sugar into well-beaten egg yolks.Â  Stir over low heat until mixture thickens.Â  Cool.Â Beat egg whites until stiff peaks form.Â Whip chilled milk.Â Fold egg whites and whipped milk into lemon mixture.Â Turn into crumb-lined pan.Â  Top with remaining crumbs and freeze.Â Fluffy 2-Step CheesecakeÂ 1 pkg. (8 oz) cream cheese, softenedÂ 1/3 cup sugarÂ 1 8-oz. tub Cool Whip, thawedÂ 1 prepared graham cracker crustÂ 1 can cherry pie fillingÂ Beat cream cheese and sugar until smooth (use wire whisk).Â Gently stir in Cool Whip.Â Spoon into crust.Â  Refrigerate 3 hours.Â Top with pie filling just before serving.Â Raspberry RevelÂ 1/2 lb. vanilla wafersÂ 2 1/2 cups powdered sugarÂ 3/4 cup butterÂ 2 eggs, well beatenÂ 1 box frozen raspberries, drainedÂ 1/2 pint whipping creamÂ Crush wafers and line a lightly buttered 9-inch pie pan with half the crumbs.Â Cream the sugar and butter well.Â  Add eggs and blend.Â Pour over the crumbs.Â  Add a layer of berries.Â  Cover with whipped cream.Â  Top with remaining crumbs.Â Refrigerate 24 hours.Â Â May garnish with additional berries.Â So there you go, SJ.Â  :)Â These are the recipes I remember from the 50's and 60's.Â  None of them are fat free or sugar free or anything free.Â  They are what we ate before we were supposed to be skinny.Â  Personally, I am not fond of all those 'free of everything good' foods, which is probably why I love these desserts.Â Â So go ahead.Â  Live dangerously.Â  And above all, enjoy.

title: The Case For Storing Water
text: It doesn't need to be a catastrophic event to find we need to have water included in our food storage plans.Duane stopped in about midnight Friday night.Â  He said the lady living in the apartment beneath his had knocked on his door to find out if he was having problems with water overflowing in his apartment.Â  It seems she was having water pouring into hers through her ceiling.Â  Finding no source of the water problem, they concluded that a pipe may have burst between the two floors.Â  Duane went down to the basement and shut off the main water valve.Â  (That's one of the advantages of living in the same building for a number of years.Â  You know where the shut-off valve is.)Â  They called our landlord and left a message about the water problem.Â  Duane then let me know what was going on.For some in my building, having the water shut off will be a major problem.Â  I asked Duane if he needed water for the morning before he went to work.Â  He said he was good.Â  He keeps cases of drinking water in his apartment.Storing water in my small apartment is a challenge.Â  I have no place to store those big water barrels that many use.Â  What I do have is space behind my sofa that contains several dozen 2 liter soda bottles and gallon juice bottles filled with water.Â  I have 6 cases (24 per case) of bottled drinking water on a shelf in one of my shelving units.Â  Used sparingly, that amount of water will last both Duane and me at least a week or more.Â  Including the absolute necessity of morning coffee.Â  :)In looking around my apartment I found that with a little bit of rearranging, I have room for 4 more cases of bottled water.Â  If I spend the money to buy several of those square, stackable water jugs I have seen advertised, I could store still more water under my bed or in an out of the way corner of my apartment.Water is more important to have on hand than is food.Â  They say we can go a couple of weeks without food but only about 3 days without water.Â  I'm sure there are others like me to whom water intake is vital.Â  I take a pill each day to help get rid of the fluid build-up in my body.Â  Which means I need to drink plenty of water to avoid becoming dehydrated.Â  Â  Which is a really silly Catch-22 situation, but there it is.We are not in an emergency situation by any means, but it has caused me to rethink my water storage and think of ways to improve it.

title: Upright, Taking Nourishment
text: Still have no idea what this creeping crud that has been plaguing me is, but it sure is a sneaky devil.Â  Thought I was about over it when it smacked me upside the head and said, "Not quite yet."Â  I'm not the only one.Â  One of my nurses and the cleaning lady were down with pretty much the same thing last week.Â  A couple of my blogging friends have been fighting it as well.Â  I feel pretty good today, so it is time to fold up the green fuzzy blanket and get some stuff done.Over the weekend I did manage to do some dehydrating.Â  I dried 4 lbs. of green beans, 1 lb. of corn and 1 lb. of carrots.Â  Found the corn and carrots when I was digging the green beans out of the freezer.Â  This morning I put 4 lbs. of broccoli and 4 lbs. of cauliflower in the dehydrator.Â  I still need to clean and chop 4 lbs. of onions to dry.Â I just mailed off a letter to my grandson Zach, who is in his first year of college.Â  His Mom thought he might like a letter from home.Â  Â I write letters the old fashioned way with pen and paper.Â  Do they still teach cursive writing in schools?Â  I wonder if he will be able to read it.Â  He is a smart kid, so I suppose he will figure it out.Â  :)It is cool and rainy here today, with the temp at 46 degrees at noon.Â  I heard a nasty rumor about the possibility of snow in the northern part of Minnesota.Â  I guess I shouldn't be surprised.Â  One of the worst blizzards here occurred on Halloween of 1991 and dumped 28 inches of snow on Minneapolis.Â  I don't mind snow as long as I can look at it through my window from the comfort of my rocking chair, but not quite yet, please.Not much else going on here in my little Home Sweet Apartment.Â  I have 4 lbs. of bacon to can, but I think I will order another 4 lbs.Â  next week before canning so I have a full canner load.Â  I had started an afghan for granddaughter Boston, but I just didn't like the way it looked, so my daughter Jill brought me different yarn to try.Â  I like the new yarn much better and will post pictures when I am further along with it.Â  I think the weather calls for beef stew with biscuits for supper.Â  That's the plan, anyway.

title: Why I Don't Believe Her
text: There was once a 9 year old girl who escaped being molested by her 21 year old cousin.Â  Some 60 years later she remembers every detail.She remembers her cousin asking her to go for a ride at night to 'shine the deer.'She remembers the pickup truck was red and white with rusty spots on it.She remembers the seat cover was red plaid with some spots worn through.She remembers the smell of stale cigarette butts in the ashtray.She remembers when they stopped at the edge of a field and he plugged the spotlight into the cigarette lighter.She remembers seeing three deer in the light from the spotlight.She remembers how dark it was when he turned off the light.She remembers feeling sick to her stomach when he started kissing on her.She remembers crying and him stopping and telling her she better not tell.She remembers spending the remainder of the evening at her aunt and uncle's house, drawing cartoon characters over and over again with a pencil on notebook paper.Â  Goofy and Pluto and Mickey Mouse, mostly.She remembers pretending to be asleep in the back seat of the car on the ride home, listening to her parents talk.She remembers her mother saying something was wrong and she thought the cousin had done something bad.She remembers her father saying he didn't think the cousin would ever hurt his daughter.She never told.Â  Her mother had often told her that she was a bad girl, for she was headstrong and tended to get into mischief.Â  Children often believe when something bad happens, it is their fault, so she remained silent.Â  When the girl was a grown woman with a family of her own and when she knew none of it had been her fault, it made no sense to hurt family by dredging up the past.Â  It did not take years of therapy to come to that conclusion.Â  It just took believing that forgiving is the right thing to do.You just can not convince me that a 15 year old girl now a grown woman has so few memories of an attack except for the name of a man who is up for Supreme Court Justice.Â  A man who has never had even a whisper of scandal associated with his name.Â  Â  It may be what the Dems want to hear as truth.Â  It may be what her lawyers have told her is truth.Â  But you just can not ever convince me that her testimony is the real truth.

title: Be Back Soon

title: Russian Food Preservation
text: A couple of posts back I mentioned that I had a new home health care nurse, Tatiana, who was born in Russia, immigrated here and became an American citizen.Â  On her first visit she noticed my shelves full of home canned food and remarked that many in Russia did home canning.Â  When she was here last Friday, I asked her more about the subject.Tatiana told me that back in the old USSR, everybody canned everything they could find.Â  It was a matter of survival.Â  She said the grocery stores had very little in the way of food, canned or otherwise.Â  She remembers standing in line for over an hour to buy one loaf of bread.Her mother used the old fashioned canning jars that had glass lids held down by stiff wire.I asked if her mother used a pressure canner to process food.Â  Tatiana wasn't sure what a pressure canner was, so I showed her one of mine.Â  She said she hadn't ever seen one in Russia and that her mother used large kettles similar to my stock pot.Â  Food was boiled and ladled into the jars and the glass lids tightened down with the wire.Â  SheÂ  said much of the vegetables were preserved in a vinegar brine and they made lots of sauerkraut because it required only cabbage and salt, both of which could be had fairly easily.I asked if her mother had ever canned meat and she said she had not heard of anyone doing that.Â  She was amazed at the variety of meats that may be canned.Tatiana says that things are much better in Russia now.Â  The stores carry a large variety of foods and people don't spend nearly so much time standing in line.Â  Like here in the USA, home canning isn't done as much as it was years ago.Â  And like here, the Russians, especially in the cities, don't bother preserving food, but just get what they want at the stores.I found it fascinating to compare how things are done in one part of the world to another.Â  If we kick the politics into a corner and just concentrate on the people, we may find we aren't so different after all.

title: Prayer Request
text: A regular commenter on this blog has become one of those friends I will never personally meet, but is considered a friend, nonetheless.Â  She just this past week buried her beloved husband of 40 years.Â  Her home is owned by the company her husband worked for and must be vacated within 60 days.Â  Her adult daughter is chronically ill.Â  The lady has a lot on her plate.Through all of these hardships she has not lost her faith in God.Â  She and I both believe in the power of prayer.Â  I know that some of you are already bringing her situation to the Throne of God.Â  I would humbly ask that any of you who are of a mind to, please include her and her daughter in your prayers.

title: And So It Begins...
text: Once in a while I will go from one room in my apartment to the next, only to forget why.Â  I wasn't too worried about this.Â  Talking with others of my vintage and even younger, I find this is fairly common.Â  But there were a couple of things lately that make me wonder if I have started on the downward slide toward total memory loss.Today, Thursday, my grandson Chris is having surgery to repair damage to one of his fingers due to an accident at his place of work.Â  (His mother, my daughter, called to tell me the surgery went well and is successful.) So yesterday, Wednesday, I called my daughter to find out how the surgery went.Â  Daughter said I must have lost a day somewhere, for the surgery was the next day.Â  I thanked her for giving me back my lost day and hung up the phone with the sound of her laughter ringing in my ear.About suppertime yesterday Duane showed up with a club sandwich and fries from the little restaurant in our neighborhood.Â  He knew I had been feeling a bit off all day so he brought my evening meal so I didn't need to cook.Â  Bless him!Anyway, while he was here I asked him if he had noticed any changes in my memory capabilities lately.Â  I told him about calling his sister a day early for surgery results.Â  And I said there was one other thing that made me wonder, but I couldn't remember what it was.Â  He just laughed and said as far as he could tell, I still had all my marbles.Later in the evening I messaged him on FB..."The other thing was yesterday I couldn't remember how to work my apple peeler.Â  Peeled all those apples by hand.Â  Remembered how it worked this morning.Â  Plink - plink - plink-Â  the sound of marbles hitting the floor."His response was a cartoon picture of some sort of little animal, rolling on the ground, laughing hysterically.Deep, exaggerated Sigh along with a grin.Â  :)

title: Silly Phone Call Day
text: So the first phone call today was from my caseworker for the county government nursing and housecleaning services I use.Â  He thought it would be a nifty idea if his office collected the fee I pay to have my groceries delivered, and they would then add that to my monthly bill.Â  It took some time and lots of patience to convince him that my grocery delivery service was a volunteer service for Seniors and has nothing to do with his government department.The second call later in the day was from the very same caseworker.Â  He was concerned that I was paying for the supplies used in the care and treatment of my legs, out of pocket.Â  He offered to call Medicare for me and find out if they covered those supplies.Â  I understand he might just be trying to be helpful, but it still took some time and lots of patience to make him understand that I had already done that when I first found out that I was responsible for the supplies and found they weren't covered.He then suggested that I get prescriptions for the supplies so that my prescription insurance would pay for them.Â  It took some time and lots of patience to convince him that I had already checked into that possibility and found it was just as cheap and less of a hassle for me to order supplies from Amazon than it was to go through a prescription.Â  Â I can order in bulk and Amazon delivers to my door.Sometimes I think that some government workers have the mistaken notion that their clients do not have more than a couple of functioning brain cells.Â  I suppose I shouldn't be too hard on them as they are likely used to folks who work harder at getting free stuff than they would at a regular job.Â  To run across someone who takes care of her own stuff is a shock to the system.The last call was from Kevin at Windows who was terribly concerned about the state of my computer.Â  Being out of time and patience, I informed Kevin that he was a fool if he thought I was going to fall for that old scam.I wonder just how many fellows named Kevin there are in India.

title: Farmer's Market Haul
text: There was a time when my son would make a Farmer's Market run and bring me bushels of produce.Â  Â Now that things have changed and I can no longer process bushels of produce at one time, the haul is smaller, but still very welcome.Â There were 2 small - a little bigger than grapefruit sized - cantaloupe.Â  I ate one last evening and the other for breakfast this morning.Â  They were delicious.Â  I saved some of the seeds.Â  One of my daughters has a small garden and I think I can maybe talk her into planting some of them in the spring.There were a dozen green and two red bell peppers.Â  What a difference between theÂ  store bought peppers and the ones from the Farmer's Market.Â  These I sliced thin, packaged in individual portions and froze them.Â  I probably wouldn't have thought to preserve them this way, but one of my readers left a comment a couple of posts ago telling me that's how he had preserved his peppers.Â  Thanks, "Red."The last item was two bags of apples - about 20 lbs. total.Â  They aren't pretty enough to sell in the grocery store, being of different sizes and not uniform in color, so they are sold at a reduced price as 'seconds.'Â  I don't know why the buying public has to have the perfect looking produce.Â  These apples are fresh picked locally, which is more than you can say for those in the stores.Â  We have been enduring another heat wave that should end by tomorrow, so then these apples will become applesauce.Â  The applesauce will be canned in half pint jars, which is just the right size for Son to take in his lunch for work and for me to consume.Today I had a new home health care nurse attending to my legs.Â  She is from Russia.Â  When she saw my shelves of home canned food, she asked if I had canned it all myself.Â  She said that here in America she hadn't seen anything like that.Â  She works in city areas and I told her that it was fairly common in the rural areas, but many living in town just go to the grocery stores instead of canning at home.Â  She told me that in Russia, everyone cans food at home.Â  She said that they can't count on the stores to have what the people need and if they didn't garden and can, they might go hungry.Â  She thought the Farmer's Market was the most wonderful thing.Â  Tatiana immigrated from Russia and became an American citizen.Â  She speaks fluent English with just a slight accent.Â  She is a lovely lady who came highly recommended and seems to be doing a good job in her chosen field of nursing.Â  She is the kind of immigrant I will welcome.

title: Full Speed Ahead
text: Which is sort of a joke as speed isn't exactly working too well for me these days.Â  However, I am in full food prep mode and moving along, even if it is at the rate of a turtle's progress.Â  :)After putting away my groceries I shredded two heads of cabbage.Â  They are in zip lock bags in the fridge and tomorrow morning they will go in the dehydrator.Â  The rest of the veggies will be shredded in the morning and will go in the other dehydrator.Â  I am drying them separately because some dry faster than others.Â  When everything is dry they will be mixed together and packaged for storage.It rarely happens, but this time there was a mix-up in my order.Â  I ordered frozen hashbrowns and got Simply Potatoes.Â  Frozen hashbrowns have already been blanched and can go directly into the dehydrator.Â  I'm not so sure about the Simply Potatoes, so I sent them back.Â  I will just re-order in two weeks.The 4 lbs. of frozen green beans are resting comfortably in the freezer until I am finished with the fresh veggies.Over the weekend, 15 lbs. of hamburger will be browned, packed into pint jars and canned.Â  I decided to can the hamburger plain.Â  As much as I like having taco meat canned and ready to use straight from the jar, upon reflection it makes more sense to me to can the burger without seasonings so it can be used in a variety of ways.Â This past week I learned a lesson that falls into the category of 'what not to do.'Â  Do not leave bags of apple slices in the freezer for 5 years and expect them to be good.Â  After slow cooking them all day I wound up with much of them being the consistency of soft leather.Â  The apples were just in the freezer way too long and this was the result of freezer burn.Â  I expect they would have been fine being frozen for a year, but 5 years was just too long.Â  There were 3 bags of peach slices that were frozen about the same time, with pretty much the same results as the apples.Â I took time to make a pan of Rice Krispy bars.Â  Makes me think of my childhood where they were considered a special treat.Â  Still are.Â  I messaged Oldest Son telling him there was a possibility that there would be Rice Krispy bars at my house.Â  He messaged back that I would see him as soon as he got home from work.Bribe them with food.Â  Works every time.Â  :)

title: Dear Celebrities...
text: I wonder how many of you remember just what your job entails.Â  Let me remind you.Â  Your job, the one you chose to make your life's work, is to entertain me.Â   It may be that you chose to be a comedian.Â  You have a library of jokes and stories that make me laugh and over the years you have succeeded in doing just that.You may be an actor.Â  Through movies, plays and television you have shown me a world beyond that of my imagination.Â  You have pulled at my heartstrings, caused me to weep, to smile, to think, to remember.Â  You have given me many hours of viewing pleasure.Perhaps you are a star of the music world.Â  Your voice has risen to incredible heights.Â  Your instrumentals have been heard with heartfelt awe and emotion.Â  Your music has accompanied both the good times and the sad times in the lives of your fans.Maybe you are one who excels at sports.Â  You are the one my grandson looks up to and the one he wants to be when he grows up.Â  You are a role model to him.Â  You represent not only talent, but also fair play, sportsmanship and the willingness to be a team player.I have to tell many of you that you have failed to do your jobs.Â  You have gone out of your way to loudly and proudly proclaim to the world that you have become unhinged when it comes to our President.Â  You have not only disrespected the office, but you have done so in the most vile and vulgar of terms.Â  Some of you have taken to disrespecting our National Anthem and our beloved American Flag that represents the country that gave you the freedom to do so.I will defend your right to say or do whatever you feel the need to say or do within the confines of the law.Â  But I will remind you that words and deeds have consequences.If you think it is funny to stand before an audience and talk about our President and those who work for him and support him, in the most vile and disgusting of terms, I will not watch your performances.If you think it is cute to spew vulgarities at an awards ceremony or during an interview, or if you really think I appreciate your wisdom in telling me how I should join you in your hatred, I will not watch your movies or television dramas.If your concerts or songs include rants against our President, I will listen to someone else's music.And I will encourage my grandson's parents to point him in the direction of sports heroes who not only have talent and ability, but who also have class.I do not believe it is required of us to love our President. There have been some over the years who, in my opinion, had less than stellar performances.Â  There hasn't been even one with whom I was in complete agreement.But the office of the leader of the free world deserves our respect, as does our Anthem and our Flag.Â  And if we fail to do so or if we, by our silence, condone this slap in the face to our President and the symbols of patriotism and love of our country by those who are citizens of the same and who enjoy more freedoms than any other nation on earth,Â  then we are as good as finished.

title: I Have Plans
text: Today was a good day.Â  I canned 29 half pint jars of peas and with what is already on the shelf, I should have enough to last at least one year.Â  I seem to use peas a lot.Â  I put them in tuna-macaroni salads and eat them as a vegetable with a meal.Â  My favorite is creamed peas on toast for aÂ  quick meal.Â  My mother would make creamed peas or asparagus on toast every once in a while and I still like it.Â  Reminds me of home.I didn't have as much butter in the freezer as I thought, so I decided to build up my supply before canning.Â  I only have 6 lbs., so will wait until I have 15 or 20.Â  Butter here is spendy, so I only order 4 lbs. at a time in my grocery order.Â  I can wait.Now that the weather has cooled down some I am back in 'fill the shelves'Â  mode.Â  I looked to see what I needed before filling out my grocery order for Monday.Â  Here's the plan:4 bags of hashbrowns to dehydrate4 lbs. of frozen green beans to dehydrate12 lbs. of hamburger - with the three lbs. in the freezer I will have 15 lbs.fresh vegetables:Â  cabbage, carrots, celery, green peppers and onions.It takes about one lb. of hamburger to fill a pint jar.Â  I also ordered taco seasoning.Â  I think I will make taco filling and can it.Â  I tried that once before and it was a success.Â  I just this past week used my last jar of taco meat and I love tacos, so that seems like a good use for the hamburger.Â  I will can at least two more cases of plain hamburger later.Â The fresh vegetables will be shredded, mixed together and dehydrated.Â  A couple handfuls of the dried vegetable mix adds flavor to soups or casseroles.My groceries aren't delivered until Thursday.Â  In the meantime there are several bags of apple slices in the freezer.Â  I am not a tall person.Â  I can not reach the bottom of my chest freezer without practically standing on my head.Â  Oldest Son has taken pity on me and said he will come over after work on Sunday and drag the apples out of the bottom of the freezer for me.Â  They will go into my big roaster to cook down for applesauce.So that's the plan.Â  Now, I realize that often when we plan, God laughs.Â  And I believe that when God finished creating this wonderful world we live in, he said, "OK, Murphy.Â  You're in charge."Â So we shall see how the plan works out.Â  :)

title: Once in a while...
text: an absolutely perfect day comes along.Â  Yesterday was one of those and today is shaping up to be more of the same.Â  The sun is shining which is welcome after a considerable amount of rain earlier in the week.Â  Temps are dropping to the mid-50's at night and staying under 75 degrees during the day.Â  It is a relief after the hot summer days.I have bags of frozen peas and several pounds of butter thawing to be canned tomorrow.Â  If all goes well, on Monday I hope to cook down several bags of frozen apple slices for applesauce to can.A few months ago I decided I needed a Mr. Coffee coffeemaker.Â  I had been using this to make coffee.My Dad gave me that old drip coffee pot years ago when I didn't have a coffee pot.Â  My parents bought it right after they married - 73 years ago.Â  That old pot makes better coffee than the new one does.Â  The new one is now on a shelf.Â  The old one is still producing really good coffee, which is important to someone like me who considers coffee the 'elixor of life.'And now I believe it is time for a short nap, after which I may sit out on the deck and crochet for awhile.Â  It is just too pretty a day to be indoors.Â  :)

title: Evil
text: I have been watching some of the confirmation hearing for Supreme Court nominee Bret Kavanaugh.Â  The pure evil spewing forth from the mouths of some of the Senators on the left is breathtaking to behold.Â  This hearing has little to do with the confirmation of a judge and everything to do with getting President Trump.Â  I am convinced that if Jesus Christ were the one being questioned, the left would find fault and blame it on Trump.Â  I knew there was hate and discontent but I didn't realize how deep that hatred went.Pray for our nation.Â  I am beginning to doubt that we can ever overcome the pure evil among us.

title: Still Here...
text: Just busy.Â  I found some new to me information about my family tree, and have been sorting that out to share with my cousin in Texas.Â  And she is doing some research on another branch of our tree.Â  It is fun to be working with another relative.Â  I enjoy the search and don't even mind so much the tediousness of organizing it all, even though it is awfully time consuming.There was a little bit of sadness in my life this morning.Â  I have two nurses who deal with the cleaning and bandaging of my lower legs.Â  Ingrid is the one I see most often and today was her last day.Â  I am sad at losing her, for she is very good at her job and I really like her personally.Â  I credit her with saving my life, or at least prolonging it.Â  She was worried about the low numbers when she took my oxygen levels and she finally had a talk with me, explaining that low oxygen over time would cause some vital organs to be damaged or to shut down.Â  And when I didn't agree to getting the oxygen setup right away but said I would think about it, she went over my head and called my daughter, who called her brother and sister, who kidnapped me for a doctor visit and the order for oxygen and a nebulizer.Â  I still hate being tethered to a machine, but it has made a world of difference.Â  Ingrid has taken a job as a school nurse and I am happy for her.Â  And the other nurse, Caroline, is just as good and is a boatload of fun to be around.Â  Could be worse.Â  Could have gotten a Nurse Ratched.Â  :)Duane likes to go to the State Fair.Â  He usually goes alone and likes to wander around, look at some exhibits and mostly eat.Â WalleyeDole Pineapple WhipThe crowd, which is why I don't go to the fair!!I asked if he was going to bring me some Fair Food on a Stick, but he said anything on a stick would go bad before he got it home.Â  This afternoon he showed up with a paper sack full of goodies.Â  He said there was no food on a stick, but there were three boxes, each containing a different flavor of fudge.Â  He took a thin slice off each and left the rest for me.Â  I may have to hide some away or I will be tempted to dive in, head first.Â  :)Youngest son, David, showed up early this afternoon.Â  He sat and visited with me for quite a while, showing me pictures he had on his iPad from his job.Â  They were mostly of things his landscape crews had missed.Â  He takes pictures to show them what needs to be done, but in most of them, the problem area was circled and he had added text to tell them exactly what to do.Â  It isn't rocket science.Â  It is pulling weeds, mowing grass, replacing shrubs, planting flowers, and cleaning up after themselves.Â  Jobs that should be self explanatory to seasoned crews, and yet, if David doesn't point out specifics, the jobs don't get done.Â  I asked if workers were becoming more stupid and he said maybe, but most times they take no pride in a job well done.Â  I am not surprised.David also had some video he took with his drone.Â  He was at his house, practicing with it.Â  There was footage of their dog, Oreo, in the back yard.Â  She would sniff at a spot on the lawn, roll in it and then run like mad around the yard.Â  And do the same thing again.Â  And again.Â  I remarked that it might be a good idea to check to see what Oreo found so fascinating.Â  Dogs love to roll in the nastiest of stuff.Â  :)And that's how my day went.Â  How was yours?

title: Puttering
text: The heat is still with us.Â  The humidity, too.Â  But the weather guy tells us that cooler temps will visit us by the end of the week.Â  They will be welcome!Â  But I suppose if we were having weather like Rev. Paul is seeing in Alaska, we would be complaining about that, too.Â  :)I did manage last week to get some ham and bean soup canned.Â  I did a cannerful of quarts, being seven of them.Â  One jar didn't seal so I had lunches of bean soup for a couple of days.Â  Two jars broke in the canner.Â  I'm not sure why.Â  Sometimes jars just break.Â  Sometimes a scratch in the glass can turn into a break under pressure.Â  And sometimes jars will break if the canner is heated too quickly.Â  I'm thinking the latter operator error might have been the cause.Â  At any rate, I put four more quarts of ready-to-eat food on the shelf, so it wasn't a total loss.Today is not a high energy day.Â  Even when I am indoors the humidity seems to bother my breathing some.Â  The nebulizer helps more than I ever thought it would.Â  My youngest son gave it to me so I didn't have to go buy one.Â  He had it for one of his kids when they were younger.Â  It is shaped like a penguin.Â  It makes me smile.Â  Takes about 20 minutes to use up the medicine that helps open my airway.Â  I keep my Kindle alongside my penguin and indulge in a bit of reading while I wait for the process to complete.Â  Right now I am in the middle of a mystery that has not one, but two murders to solve.Â  I just love a good who-done-it.Â  :)So today I am just puttering around, doing little chores that require little energy output.Â  Fall is nearly upon us, so it is time to make a batch of hot chocolate mix.Â  I dearly love a cup of cocoa in the cool of an evening.Â  Usually I use that universal recipe calling for Nestle's Quick, but this time I am using the following recipe that tastes like the cocoa Mother used to make with milk, cocoa powder and sugar, heated on the stove.Â HOT COCOA MIX5 cups nonfat dry powdered milk3 cups powdered sugar (more or less according to your taste)1 1/2 cups dry cocoa1 cup nondairy coffee creamerpinch of saltMix powdered milk, creamer, and salt into a large mixing bowl. Sift in cocoa and powdered sugar. Mix well. Store in a airtight container.When ready to use, add approximately 1/3 cup to a mug of boiling water. Stir until cool enough to drink.You might want to try some of these variations. The recipe is very flexible.* crushed peppermint sticks* cinnamon* malted milk powderI found this recipe at 'katz kradle' YouTube channel.Â  It has been several months since she posted anything, but she has a wealth of information on preparedness, recipes, etc.Looks like there may be a thunderstorm or two headed my way.Â  Â The weather reporters always make it sound like the storm of the century is headed directly for us.Â  I will be happy if we get a little rain.Â  We need it.

title: Answer to a Comment
text: Someone asked me a question in the comment section of my last post.Â  For a couple of reasons I declined giving an answer.Â  Later I found this person has commented before, very nicely, as a matter of fact.Â  So upon reflection, I decided to answer here.I was asked my opinion on the growing Muslim population in my state.First let me say that I am all for legal immigration.Â  I understandwhy people from all over the world want to come here.Â  I have ancestors who came from France, Germany, England, Scotland. Some came as far back as 1635.Â  Others before and during World War I, fleeing war torn Europe.Â  All of them followed the laws of the day and became citizens and earned their keep.I have zero tolerance or patience for those who think it is OK to jump the border and immediately collect benefits, paid for with my taxes and the taxes of my family.Â  Every one of my children and the older of my grands hold down jobs, pay their own rent, buy their own food and pay for their medical care, whether it be insurance or out of pocket.Â  It would not cross their minds to expect a handout.I am also totally against open borders.Â  The reasons should be clear after the news stories of crimes committed by illegals including the Iowa college student who has been missing for a month and whose body was found yesterday, murdered by a man who has lived in the area for several years - illegally.Â  One has to wonder just how many terrorists have entered our borders illegally.As far as the Muslim population goes, I understand that there are some who are peaceful and just want to live out their lives.Â  Sadly, we only hear of the ones who would like to eliminate all who do not believe as they do.Â  We hear of the ones who want nothing better than to turn America into a Muslim nation.Â  They make no secret of wanting the nation to be governed by Shariah Law.Â  And many have no intention of assimilating into our culture.Here in Minnesota, the Somali Muslims have been welcomed with open arms by Left leaning groups.Â  Some have been convicted for having ties to terrorist groups.Â  Others have amused themselves by chasing locals from parks and lakeside beaches and by going into affluent neighborhoods to harass residents.Â  Many have stayed in the Minneapolis area, settling in a neighborhood now known as 'Little Mogadishu.'Â  The effect on the area depends on who you talk to.Â  Those on the Left will tout the diversity of the area, waxing rapturously about the community.Â  Those on the Right will point out that non-Muslims take a great risk in entering there.Â  I find it interesting that many crimes in that area of Minneapolis that I hear about listening to the police scanner never make the local news.Other immigrants have been dispersed throughout the state, many to smaller farming towns and communities.Â  As I no longer travel, I can not speak from experience.Â  But I can relate what has been told me from friends who live in those communities.Â  Some say that places like the public swimming pools or recreational facilities are no longer safe for local kids.Â  Other female friends tell me that they cannot walk in the downtown areas of their hometown without being harassed or threatened.Considering that some of the most horrific terrorist acts here and overseas have been carried out in the name of Allah, it seems to me that political correctness needs to go into the trash bin where it belongs and truth should be told.Â  We are so afraid of offending anyone that we ignore the obvious.The thing is, those in power here in Minnesota don't give a rodent's behind if I am offended.Â  And I am offended by people who demonstrate by shouting 'Death to America.'Â  I am offended by those who wish to change the culture in my state.Â  I am offended by those who don't want to obey our laws but want their own form of law to be the law of the land.Â  And I am offended by those who insist their religious laws concerning food and prayer be adhered to, here in the land of Lutherans and Catholics, who practice their religions without fanfare and without insisting others do as they do.Â  And I am particularly offended by those who consider a woman without a head scarf to be fair game.To the person who posed the question, I am sorry I didn't recognize you.Â  I hope this post adequately answers it.

title: They Bring Me Food
text: Sunday afternoon my youngest son and his family stopped in to see me.Â  They had been at the horse racing track in the town where I live.Â  They weren't watching a horse race.Â  It was a Basset Hound race.The track will sometimes hold special races.Â  I have heard of ostrich races and camel races, but this is the first time I heard of Basset Hound races.Â  A neighbor of theirs was entering his two Basset Hounds in the race and had invited my son and his family to go watch.Â  David took a short video of the race and it was hysterical.Â  The winning dog made a beeline down the track to the owner who was urging him on.Â  The other dogs sort of did their own thing, from trotting to ambling along like a walk in the park.Â  One kept tripping over his ears.Â  A fun time was had by all.Before they came here, David called to see if I needed anything.Â  As I had just received my groceries a couple of days before, I didn't need anything, so they brought me a Blizzard from Dairy Queen.Â  I kind of think the kids picked out the flavor as it contained Pop Rocks candy.Â  It tasted good and the grands laughed at me when the little candy bits started exploding on my tongue!We had a good time getting caught up on what the kids had been doing over the summer.Â  But the best part was the hugs when they arrived and the hugs when they departed.Duane's workplace frowns upon personal phone calls during working hours.Â  So sometimes he will Facebook Message me to see if I need anything.Â  Today he messaged to ask if I would like a deli chicken dinner tonight.Â  Not being one to turn down a hot meal that somebody else cooked on a hot evening, my reply was, "Oh, Yes.Â  Please!Â  A good son you are!"And then Jeri let me know that their fish from Alaska had not yet arrived, but when it did, she would deliver some to me.Â  Â I am already drooling in anticipation.Â  Fish is one of my favorites.Looks like my family is going to make sure I don't want for good things to eat.Â  :)

title: Where Does the Time Go...
text: It seems like just yesterday I held a tiny boy child in my arms - my third grandchild, the only son of my oldest daughter and her husband.Â  He was no bigger than a minute and I fiercely loved him from the moment I laid eyes on him.Â  When he was a little older, whenever I would go to his house, he would come running to give me a hug.Â Now that he towers over me in height, he hasn't forgotten that grandmas still need hugs from grandkids.Over the weekend his parents turned him over to North Dakota State University.Â How can this be?Â  Wasn't it just last week he started Kindergarten?Zach is enrolled in the Aviation program.Â  He has been taking flying lessons since he needed to sit on a cushion to see out the windshield of a small plane.These two pictures were taken in 2009 when he was taking his first flying lesson at age 9.And this is a picture of my "Joe Cool" grandson, taken in 2014, looking like a pilot!My daughter once told me that Zach was happiest when flying.Â  His goal is to become either a commercial pilot or a corporate pilot.Â  There is no doubt that he will achieve his goal.Grandma loves you, Zach.Â  You do me proud.

title: Same Song - Second Verse
text: More heat.Â  More humidity.Â  Doesn't seem to be going away any time soon.Â I did manage to can 22 half pints of corn last week.Â  The rest is going to wait for cooler temps.Â  Just that small bit of canning heated up my apartment and it took hours for it to become comfortable again.I have to admit that I have caved when it comes to cooking.Â  Usually I cook from scratch or I use my home canned food for meals.Â  But my grocery order this week includes a variety of microwavable stuff.Â  I just can't make myself use my oven or even the burners on my stove for fear of adding more heat to my small apartment.Â  I hang my head in shame.Â  On the up side, I don't suppose that a couple of weeks of processed food will kill me off.Â  The heat might.Â  To redeem myself just a little bit, I did order lots of fresh fruit to counter the frozen sausage, egg and cheese breakfast biscuits and the frozen White Castle sliders.Â  (I love the sliders!)I have tried unsuccessfully to come up with a way to share my genealogy research with interested family members.Â  I can enter all the information into a genealogy program on my computer, but the only way someone can access it is to have the same program.Â  I have tried using online websites for that purpose, but there are limitations with them unless I pay a lot of money for a full featured setup.Â  I have started a couple of blogs for that purpose only to delete them when they didn't work as well as I hoped.Â  But over the weekend I think I have found a blog setup that will suit my purposes.Â  I spent most of the weekend working on it and will continue until I have enough data entered to see if it works.Â  It is too hot to do much of what I usually do to occupy my time so this is a good chance to work on my sadly neglected family tree.Â  Jeri called last evening.Â  They arrived home from their Alaska vacation Sunday morning, tired but happy.Â  They took time to drive the coast highway from Astoria to San Francisco.The bridge at Astoria, WashingtonRedwoods in CaliforniaAnd I get some halibut!!Â  I forgot to ask her if they caught any salmon.That's all the excitement here.Â  Hope you all are well and staying cool.Â  :)

title: Sibling Love
text: Recently I connected with a cousin of mine.Â  She has lived for many years on the other side of the country from me, and I don't think we have ever met in person.Â  That doesn't matter.Â  We are family.My father and her grandmother were brother and sister.Â  I have a story or two about them I want to share with my cousin.Â  Messaging isn't adequate - hence this post for her and for anyone else who might find it interesting.My Dad and his sister Clarice had a love for one another that one doesn't often see these days.Â  I have no doubt that each would have moved Heaven and Earth for the other.Clarice was born in 1908, the seventh child in a family of nine children.Â  Dad was born in 1911, being number nine.Â  Dad often told his siblings that their parents saved the best for last.Â  :)The earliest photo of my Dad was taken in front of the first log cabin my Grandfather built in northern Minnesota.Â  He is in the arms of his sister, Clarice.Clarice was in charge of watching over her baby brother.And yes, Dad is wearing a dress.Â  At that time it was common practice for little boys to wear dresses until they were old enough to manage the fly buttons on their long pants.I was lucky enough to be born into a loving family.Â  I knew that I would be welcomed with open arms, hugs and kisses no matter which aunt or uncle I went to visit.Â  But a visit with Aunt Clarice was just special.Â  She had a sweetness about her that was beyond compare.Â  That being said, she could give as good as she got.Â  Those two liked to tease one another.Â  It was never mean.Â  Dad might remark that Clarice was getting a bit broad in the beam and she would tell him he wouldn't be so chunky if only he wasn't so darned short.When both were in their 90's they were in the same nursing home in the small town near where they grew up.Â  The two of them would be side by side in their wheelchairs, doing their upper body exercises led by one of the staff.Â  After a while Dad's arm would reach over and lightly cuff his sister on the back of her head.Â  More exercise - 1 - 2 - 3 - 4.Â  And Clarice would double up her fist and punch Dad on his arm.Â  After a couple more swats between them, the aide would say, "Now you two Matheny kids behave yourselves."Â  Â And they would - for maybe 5 minutes.Sadly, Clarice had a form of memory loss that didn't allow her to retain the spoken word for more than a minute or so.Â  I witnessed the following conversation between them.Clarice:Â  "How is Mom doing"Dad:Â  "Mom died in 1955."Clarice:Â  "Who is living on the home place"Dad:Â  'Nobody.Â  The house burned down."That conversation was repeated again and again.Â  Dad showed no sign of impatience with her.Â  I later asked Dad if it drove him a bit crazy to answer those same questions over and over.Â  His reply was, "Why should it?Â  She is still my sister and I still love her."Dad died in 2004.Â  At his funeral I was holding it together pretty well right up to the time Clarice was wheeled up to Dad's coffin to say her last goodbye.Â  In a moment of complete clarity she said, "Oh, Ralph."Â  Â Her hand reached out and gently caressed his face.Clarice followed her brother to Heaven shortly thereafter.Â  I like to think they are together, laughing and teasing and hugging as they did all of their lives.

title: Clean Apartment Again
text: Yep.Â  New cleaning lady.Â  Started today.Â  Did a great job.Â  My apartment is old and will never sparkle, but she came close.Â  Seems like a nice lady.Funny how things turn out sometimes.Â  I am perfectly content to live alone and to see nobody except family.Â  Now I have nurses coming in three days a week and a cleaning lady once a week.Â  I thought I would hate having people come and go but I find I really don't mind.Â  Everybody is pleasant and all seem to have a working sense of humor.Â  Â It helps that they all do such a good job.The heat wave continues.Â  The humidity was over 90% early this morning, but has gotten better as the day progresses.Â  Heat and humidity aside, I have canning to do.Â  Several bags of frozen corn and peas are waiting.Â  There are several bags of ham bones ready to cook down for ham and bean soup.Â  I would like to get those canned up by Monday when my next grocery order goes out for Thursday delivery.Â  Duane set up my big electric roaster for the ham bones and I hope that it won't heat up the kitchen as much as cooking them on top of the stove would.I am having one more lazy evening, messing about with some genealogy research for a cousin of mine and then no more excuses.Â  Time to hit the preps.Â  I fear if all the hate and discontent that seems to be growing in our country keeps ramping up as it has been, it won't take much to ignite a firestorm of violence.Â  Whatever happens, we need to be as ready as possible.

title: Hot...
text: and humid.Â  Too hot to cook.Â  Too hot to do any canning.Â A thunderstorm rolled through this morning.Â  A little rain and lots of thunder booming lightning.Â  More of the same forecast for tonight.Â  And then more heat.I shall be found in my recliner with plenty of iced tea and a mystery novel.Â  Big box fan is helping the air conditioned air move about the apartment.Â  I will surface when things cool down some.

title: Tough
text: This is my youngest daughter, Jeri.Â  I always knew she was tough.Â  But I didn't know she was 45 lbs. of halibut tough!She is on vacation in Alaska with her boyfriend Jim and her daughter Nicki and Nicki's boyfriend, Chris.Â  She called me this afternoon to make sure I checked FB where she had uploaded the picture.Â  She and Jim went halibut fishing today.Â  Earlier they each caught fish, weighing 20 lbs. each but were too small to keep.Â  Then she hooked the monster in the picture.Â  Reeled it all by herself, she did.Â  Apparently, when a fish that size gets up to the boat, they harpoon it.Â  Jeri said she got lucky for when Jim harpooned it, the fish got off the hook.They are going salmon fishing tomorrow.Â  If they all catch enough to make up 50 lbs., they will ship the salmon home.And if that happens, I get some.Â  :)

title: Northern Minnesota Vacation
text: A few weeks ago my youngest son, his wife and their three progeny rented a cabin on a lake near Ely, located in northern Minnesota, just south of the Boundary Waters Canoe Area.Â  Their cabin had no cell phone service and no WiFi.Â  I wondered how the kids would do without their electronics, but as you can see in the following pictures, they managed quite well.There was swimming.There was fishing.There were pontoon rides.Oreo, my grandpuppy, loved the rides.They checked out the local scenery,Â went hiking in the forest,Â explored a waterfalland paddled canoes.And there were books.Â  Real books made of paper.Â  I wonder how many still use them.The north country in my home state has some beautiful scenery.Â  I am partial to the North Country.Â  I was born in the northern part of the state as were my parents.Â  No matter where I have traveled, it will always be home to me.Â  I often wish I was still there.Â  I am so glad that my kids and grands can enjoy all that part of the state has to offer.The end.

title: The Great Biscuit Caper
text: So I am doing this biscuit experiment - freezing already baked biscuits to be reheated and freezing biscuits that have not yet been baked.Â  Yesterday I heated and baked to see which method I liked best.I heated two previously baked biscuits in the microwave.Â  I set it on 'defrost' forÂ  a couple of minutes and then on 'high' for 30 seconds.Â  They came out tasting like they had been microwaved and wereÂ  a bit tough.Â  It was my least favorite method.The next two biscuits I popped into a 350 degree toaster oven for about three minutes.Â  They were heated through and tasted like a biscuit should.I cranked up the toaster oven to 400 degrees and pre-heated the regular oven to the same temp.Â  Two of the raw biscuits, still frozen, went into each.Â  They baked for about 15 minutes.Â  Times will vary with different ovens.Â  All four biscuits didn't raise as much as biscuits baked fresh, but they all tasted good.Â I like the idea of having ready to bake biscuits in the freezer, but I think I will go with freezing baked biscuits.Â  For me, living alone, one batch of biscuits is good for about three meals.Â  If I just freeze the leftovers whenever I make biscuits, it won't take too long until I have I nice stash of them frozen, ready to heat in my toaster oven or regular oven whenever I want biscuits but don't want to mess around stirring them up from scratch.And thus endeth the great biscuit caper.Â  :)

title: The Girl Has a Car
text: My youngest son called me earlier today.Â  I asked him how he was doing.Â  He said he was nervous.Â  When I asked why, he said he was following his oldest daughter as she drove her first car home from the dealership.Yep.Â  The girl has her first car!They were stopping at a gas station on the way home to make sure Boston knew how to run the gas pumps to put gas in her car.Â  Tomorrow her Dad will show her how to check the oil and other things under the hood.Â  He will make sure she can change a tire.Â  And I'm pretty sure there will be some rules put into play.Boston isn't just handed a car.Â  She has a job to pay for expenses.Â  My grands are being taught responsibility and about the fact that there is no free lunch.I'm thinking she could get in some driving practice by coming to visit her Grandma.Â  :)

title: Canning Bacon Success
text: Patrice over at "Rural Revolution" has a post about canning bacon that shows the process way better than I am able.Â  You can see it HERE.Â  Go take a look.Â  I will wait.There are a couple of small differences in what she did and the way I did it.Â  I had parchment paper on hand so I used that to wrap the bacon.Â  IÂ  cut the bacon slices in half and used pint jars instead of quarts.Â  I used the regular thin sliced bacon and it looks like she used thick slices.Â The thinner slices of bacon got a wee bit mushy in the pressure canner, but by using a spatula it was possible to remove the meat from the paper.Â  I like to cook bacon on a cookie sheet in a 400 degree oven, and the canned bacon browned up nicely that way.Â  Still, I will use the thicker slices next time.I will still can more in pint jars for smaller servings for one or two, but I think I would also like to have quart jars of bacon on the shelves, just because.Â  I can always freeze leftover strips of cooked bacon.My youngest son stopped by while I was canning, and he wanted to know why I didn't just freeze the bacon instead of going to the trouble of canning it.Â  I told him that I do keep a pound or two in the freezer.Â  But a couple of years ago a tornado went through a part of Minneapolis.Â  Some of those people, the ones whose homes weren't damaged, were without electricity for nearly two weeks.Â  If that kind of thing happened to us he would be cooking meat from his freezer like mad, trying to save as much as possible after it thawed.Â  Me...I don't need to worry.Â  Most of mine is in jars.Even with the thinner slices of bacon, I am really pleased with the results.Â  I know that I can buy canned bacon and many who aren't into home canning do, but the cost is way above my pay grade.Â  So I will can more myself because, after all, one can never have too much bacon.Â  :)

title: Worrisome Update and Food Experiments
text: My cleaning lady didn't show up this morning, so I had to call to report that she missed two weeks.Â  I am paying for the cleaning service and the home health care through a county program.Â  Even though the rates I pay are heavily discounted, I still don't want to pay for no service.Â  I have no idea what happened with her and I really hate to see her go.Â  She did a wonderful job.Â  Wherever she is, I wish her well.Â  Those in charge of the program will find me a new cleaning person.Â  If the new cleaner is half as thorough as the other, I will be happy.On another note, I saw some videos about canning bacon.Â  I already can bacon bits, but the videos were about canning bacon slices.Â  So in the interest of adding to my home canned goods stash, I ordered four pounds of bacon which should give me 8 pints.Â  I will give this a try over the weekend and let you know how it works.Â I have another food experiment going.Â  I made up two batches of baking powder biscuits.Â  One batch I cut and baked the normal way, put them in a freezer bag when cool and popped them into the freezer.Â  The idea was that when I want a biscuit or two I can grab a couple and heat them up for a meal.Â  The second batch I rolled out, cut the dough into biscuits, put them on a parchment paper lined cookie sheet and froze them for about an hour.Â  Then I took the frozen raw biscuits and put them in a freezer bag and back into the freezer they went.Â  The theory is that I can take out as many as I want and bake them.Â Â Â  I will test both methods to see which one I like best.Â  It is sort of fun to test new ideas to see if they really work.

title: Worrisome
text: So last week the cleaning lady didn't show up.Now I know what that sounds like.Â  I have heard those well-to-do, every hair in place, designer jeans types complain about the 'help.'Â  But for me, having someone do the heavier cleaning isn't a luxury.Â  It is a necessity.The last time she was here she didn't seem to be her usual cheery self.Â  I asked if she was ok and she replied that she hadn't taken her medication that day.Â  She told me she has anxiety attacks.Â  We sat and talked about that for a time.Â  She seemed better when she left.She missed work one other time.Â  But then she called, all apologetic, telling me she had overslept.Â  I just laughed, told her not to worry about it.Â  She just came here the following day.She hasn't called.Â  Her day to work for me is Thursday.Â  I believe in giving folks the benefit of the doubt, so I haven't called the company she works for.Â  I hope she shows up tomorrow.Â  I hope she is alright.

title: Sons
