text: So yesterday I was in the middle of having my legs treated by the home health care nurse.Â  She is a sweetheart.Â  There is some pain involved in the process and she works hard to minimize it and yet do what is necessary.Â Anyway, in the middle of all that, Youngest Son showed up.Â  He had pictures on his phone of his family on vacation last week.Â  They stayed in a cabin just south of the Minnesota Boundary Waters area.Â  No wi-fi, no cell service, just them and nature.While the nurse worked on my legs, David scrolled through the pictures on his phone, showing my grands swimming in the crystal clear lake, fishing, canoeing and enjoying the scenery from the deck of a pontoon.Â  The dog particularly loved pontoon rides.Â  I was having so much fun looking at the pictures that I didn't even notice when the nurse had finished her work.Â  :)David says he will transfer the pictures to a flash drive for me.Â  I may show you some of the beautiful scenery then.This evening, after a less than stellar day, Oldest Son showed up with a package of deli corned beef, my favorite lunch meat for sandwiches.Â  When it is so very hot outdoors, I really dislike using the stove.Â  The corned beef will get me through with cold suppers for a few days, assuring that my apartment stays cool.And Duane also brought me a bag of my favorite fruit - cherries.Â  It is amazing how something as simple as a bag of cherries can lift a person's spirits.Doesn't matter how old sons become - they still look after their Mama.Â  :)

title: Low Energy Week
text: It is hot again and promises to continue the rest of the week.Â  Therefore, I am doing things that expend the least amount of energy possible.Â  It is too hot and humid to work with yarn.Â  Can't even scrape up enough energy to sew.Â  I have been neglecting my genealogy research, so this seems like a good time to put in some serious computer time where my only exercise is fingers on keyboard.I love reading other folks blogs about their searches for ancestors.Â  Most times they give me new ideas about where to look online.Â  Sometimes their family stories are inspiring or courageous or amusing.Â  I am surprised at how many will go to great lengths to try to prove royalty or celebrity in their family lines.Me...I like the black sheep.Â  The ones that other researchers in my family have glorified, ignoringÂ  their sins.Â  Like one of my great grandfathers.Â  He served in the Civil War and was wounded in battle.Â  I will give him credit for that.Â  But nobody else mentioned the fact that he was court-martialed for being drunk on guard duty. He remained in the army as it was wartime and every man was needed to fight, but he forfeited most of his pay for three months. I once asked my Dad about him and Dad's reply was that his grandpa 'sure did love his booze.'Â  He was the reason my grandmother, his daughter, made my grandfather sign a paper stating that Grandpa would stay away from liquor.Â  Grandma wouldn't marry Grandpa until he signed on the dotted line.Another ancestor has been praised by other researchers as the hero who was the first of that family line to reach the shores of America - the New World.Â  And that much is true.Â  However, while combing through old court records I found that this ancestor was a real bugger.Â  He harassed his neighbors to the point of being involved in several lawsuits.Â  He was put into stocks in the village square for leaving his wife alone long enough for her to become pregnant with another man's child.Â  Eventually the local citizenry had had enough of him and he and his wife were banished from the town.Now here's the rub.Â  This boy child born to the wife is the ancestor from whom my family line descends.Â  If all of this is true and even though he carries the family surname, he may not be blood related.Â  So I am off to see what I can find out concerning this dilemma.I love a good mystery, especially when it is within my own family.Â  :)

title: Pickles, Pickles Everywhere
text: So by the time I finished canning dill pickles last evening it looked like the Gedney Pickle Factory had exploded in my kitchen.Â  I did wind up with 30 pints of pickles, so it was well worth it.Â  For those interested in my dill pickle recipe, I have to admit that I cheat.Â  I have a long history of making lousy tasting dill pickles from scratch.Â  So now it is Mrs. Wages Dill Pickle Mix all the way.When the last jar was cooling on my kitchen table I decided that the Clean Kitchen Police weren't likely to come knocking on my door, so I relaxed for an hour or so and called it a night.Â  So now I am off, scoop shovel in hand, to see if I can find my kitchen counters and table top.Â  Wish me luck.Â  I'm gonna need it.Â  :)

title: Just Busy
text: So Friday I peeled and cut up 8 lbs. of carrots.Â  Saturday I packed them into jars and ran them through my pressure canner.Â  They yielded 16 pints.Â  One jar broke so I have 15 to add to my shelves.Sunday Duane made a Farmer's Market run looking for strawberries.Â  We waited too long for there wasn't a strawberry to be found.Â  He did find cucumbers and brought home a small sack of tiny ones for baby dills and another larger sack full of bigger cukes for whole dill pickles, along with a nice bunch of dill.Â  In the afternoon I washed them and got them ready to pack in jars, which I will do in the morning.I have corn and peas in the freezer waiting to be canned, but I think I will wait on those.Â  The temperature is creeping back into the 90+ range and my little apartment heats up when canning.Â  But all in all, it has been a fairly productive weekend.

title: Figuring Things Out
text: Sometimes we get so involved with our day to day lives that we forget what is important.Â  Since I have been dealing with my medical problems, I find I have sorely neglected to keep up with my food storage plan.Â  There are large empty spaces on my canning shelves.Â  I haven't dehydrated anything in months.Â  There are at least half a dozen recipes for homemade mixes that are still 'in the planning stages.'If I am to keep it honest, I need to own up to the fact that I have used my medical issues as an excuse to be lazy.Â  I keep telling myself I can not do many of the things I did before becoming ill.Â  Truth is, I can probably do more than I think I can.Â  I just need to figure out how to manage it.I keep a list of products I like to can and have on the shelves.Â  I keep this list because my memory sometimes takes a vacation and leaves me here all alone and then I will forget something.Â  Last evening I went through the list and compared it to the home canned foods on my shelves.Â  There is a glaring need to restock several items.Just because I have made the decision to get off my duff and back to my food storage plan doesn't mean I need to pretend I'm Wonder Woman and go nuts with it.Â  Those of us with medical issues, depending on the problem, need to figure out alternate ways of doing things.Â  I figure that if I do not do a canning marathon like I once did and if I stick to foods that I can prep at my kitchen table as opposed to standing over a stove or sink, I should be just fine.Today my grocery order went in.Â  I ordered 4 lbs. of frozen peas, 6 lbs. of frozen corn kernels and 8 lbs. of raw carrots.Â  The frozen vegetables can stay in the freezer until I have a good day to can them.Â  The carrots can be cleaned and cut up at my kitchen table, along with the filling of the jars.Â  Very little standing time is required.I know that many are not the least bit interested in coping with chores when dealing with the pesky medical stuff, but I thought that if I could be encouraging to even one person who is struggling with similar problems, then this post is well worth it.Â  I'll let you know how it all works out.Â  :)

title: Sparklers
text: Do you remember 4th of July sparklers?When I wasÂ  kid, my family often had a 4th of July picnic at the lake with my aunt, uncle and cousins and whatever relatives were nearby.Â  After a day of ham sandwiches made with Mom's homemade rolls, potato salad and watermelon and a jar of Auntie Em's famous dill pickles, we would spend the afternoon swimming.Â When evening was near, we would climb into the cars and head to town to watch the fireworks.By the time we got home, it was pitch dark.Â  Dad would get the packages of sparklers from wherever he had hidden them to keep them out of our hands until the right moment.Â  Then he would light them one at a time for each kid and we would run around the yard, leaving a trail of sparks.Â  We made circles and wrote our names in the air.Â  We played until the sparklers were gone.I think Dad would have loved to have some fireworks that made lots of noise or shot up in the air, exploding in a blaze of glory.Â  But Mother wouldn't allow it.Â  So we had sparklers.Â  Dad did manage to sneak some firecrackers under Mother's radar so there was a grand finale of a whole package of firecrackers going off.Last evening it was cool enough to open some windows.Â  Somewhere around midnight I heard a strange sound.Â  When I looked out my front window I saw in the street below, in front of the bar next door, a group of six or seven adult men and women.Â  Â They had sparklers.Â  They were running back and forth with them, drawing shapes and writing their names with them in the air.Â  They were having such a good time, laughing and cutting up just like we did as kids.They made me smile.

title: Just Hot
text: No other words describe our weather.Â  Yesterday we had a heat index of 110 degrees.Â  At 5 am today it was 80 degrees.Â  The central air in my building is struggling, with my apartment a few degrees warmer than the thermostat setting.I am ready.Â  My fridge is stocked with bottled water and quart jars of iced tea.Â  Fans are set up in front of floor vents to help move the cool air.Â  My activities for today include reading and a little bit of computer time.Â  Number One Son stocked my freezer with popsicles.Â  As soon as I post this I will be putting into play a trick Duane learned while he worked as a restaurant cook.Â  I will get dishtowels wet, ring out the excess water and put them in the freezer.Â  One of the frozen towels applied to the back of the neck does wonders for cooling a person down.I really feel sorry for those who need to be outside today.Â  Storms are predicted for this evening.Â  I hope they cool things down a bit.Â  Stay cool and safe.

title: Everything is Racist
text: While reading online the other day, I discovered that Laura Ingalls Wilder was a racist.Â  Must be true, for the American Library Association, in it's infinite wisdom, has decided to remove her name from a prestigious award for children's literature.Â  They do not like the way Wilder wrote about African Americans and Native Americans.Â  Seems her words don't conform to the politically correct standards of today.Born in 1867, Wilder's books chronicle her life as a child in a pioneer family.Â  The words and terms she used reflected the times.Â  They are a part of our history.I bought the entire set of 'Little House' books for my children.Â  I read them all, marveling how those hardy pioneers lived and worked and loved and managed to survive under harsh circumstances. But I suppose by today's standards I should be condemned for exposing my young children to the evils of racism.Finding this attitude of burning history on the alter of political correctness, I dove a little deeper into the subject.I was not at all surprised to find the political correct among us throwing hissy fits over the Uncle Remus stories, published in 1881.Â  Â Had they done their research, they would have found that the author held in high regard those black story tellers from whom he gathered the stories.Â  The dialect he used when writing them had nothing to do with mocking that kind of speech and had everything to do with preserving the integrity of the stories.Some of my fondest childhood memories are of my Dad reading to me from the big book of Uncle Remus Stories.Â  The antics of Br'er Fox, Br'er Rabbit and Br'er Bear were a delight to a little girl and the lessons taught remain with me.Â  But all that should be erased from our history, according to those who can find racism in a jelly sandwich.Moving on to 'Little Black Sambo,' the PC people lose their minds.Â  How dare any author write about a character named Little Black Sambo.Â  Those who know best about these things, scream 'racism' at the top of their lungs.Â  So much so that some publishers have changed the setting of the story to other countries where dark skinned people are not prevalent.The PC police may have done better to leave this children's book alone, for in it, Little Black Sambo is the hero, outsmarting the bad tigers who stole the fine clothes Sambo's mother had made for him.Â  He not only got his beautiful clothes back, he got the tigers to chase each other around and around so fast they turned into butter, which his mother used to make pancakes.Â This was another children's book read to me long ago.Â  Kids love the story, and through the telling learn that bullies are bad, even if they are tigers, the boy in the story is smarter than the bad guys and there are consequences for bad behavior.Â The PC police can't stand to leave these stories alone because, as we all have been told ad nauseam, most everything today is racist, racist, racist.Sigh.

title: Bullwinkle and the News
text: Most mornings I scroll through the news websites while getting my caffeine fix.Â  The news wears me down.Â  If politicians aren't fussing about one thing, they are fussing about another.Â  None of which makes any sense to me any more.Â  They pretty much spend their time blaming one another for what is wrong and spend no time working together to fix the problems.Â  They would rather call each other names and throw tantrums.Â  I have seen better behavior on a playground full of toddlers.I have pretty much given up on the news.Â  It isn't really news, after all.Â  It is finding 'causes' to use as ammunition to fire at the opposing political party.Â  This weeks 'breaking news' will be next weeks bird cage liner.So this morning I finally had enough of the posturing, political points gathering and useless rhetoric.Â  I found an alternative to the insanity.Rocky and BullwinkleRemember that TV cartoon show from the early 60's?Â  It featured a moose and a flying squirrel and was full of silly puns and satire and was just plain funny.Â  My Dad loved it.Â  The jokes appealed to his wry sense of humor.Â  My favorite part is the 'Fractured Fairy Tales.'The news is no longer news.Â  It is propaganda.Â  At least Bullwinkle and company don't make my blood pressure rise.Â  They make me laugh.Â  We need as much laughter as we can manage these days.

title: Blogger Hiccup
text: Folks, I have no clue what happened.Â  It seems that Blogger hiccuped and my comments were deleted.Â  I value those comments and am working on it to see if I can get them back.Â Grumble, grumble...

title: I wonder...
text: if other people clean up before the cleaning lady arrives.This morning found me washing up the few dishes that were in the sink, folding the light quilt and the green fuzzy blanket I keep in the living room for recliner naps, straighting up my desktop, etc.Guess I just don't want her to know how sloppy I really am.Â  :)

title: Saturday Fun
text: Granddaughter Boston is in Green Bay, Wisconsin for dance competition Nationals.Â  Her Mom is with her and helps get her ready for each dance number.Â  This is one of the competitions that live stream each day, so I get to watch.Boston had her solo tap dance on Wednesday.Â  I don't have a picture of her in this year's costume, but here she is from last year.The girl loves what she does and Wednesday she won First Place in the tap dance division.Â  And yes, I am unabashedly bragging.Â  Grandma's get to do that.Today she has three dance routines with the group from the dance studio she attends.Â  It is easy for me to pick her out in the group, just by the way she moves.Â  I am ready.Â  Popcorn has been popped.Â  Coffee has been brewed .Â  Bring it on.I just love watching my girl dance!

title: Occasionally...
text: everyone has a bad day.Â  Mine showed up earlier this week.Â  Between shortness of breath and arthritis, I felt sort of like something you would scrape off the bottom of your shoe.Â  Normally I just work through it, but this time I found myself sloshing around in a puddle of self pity.Â  I was remembering all the things I was once able to do.Â  Gardening, taking a dog for a walk, going for a drive, being able to take care of myself without help.And then I remembered this.I stole this from Gorges over at Gorges' Grouse.Â  He posts some pretty good memes on his blog and this one I saved for an occasion like this.Â  Remembering the past is good when it comes to learning from our mistakes.Â  And it is good for remembering good times.Â  But when remembering serves no useful purpose, then looking forward is the way to go.Thanks, Gorges.

title: Up to My Elbows in Yarn
text: So the other evening my daughter Jill - the one with the excellent taste in yarn colors for afghans - stopped by, toting three huge bags stuffed full of yarn.Â  Here is what she brought.Â  (My photography skills leave a lot to be desired, but I think you will get the idea.)When I went to pay Jill for the yarn, she wouldn't let me.Â  She told me it was my birthday present!Â  Wow!She sat and visited with me for a time.Â  We came up with a few ideas on how to use those colors in the next two afghans.Â  Of course I couldn't stand it until I made some sample granny squares.This one is for Maddie Mae.Â  There is some gray yarn intended to go with these two, but it didn't quite work, so I am just using the two colors of yarn instead.Â  The multicolored yarn is so beautiful that I don't think it needs anything else except the purple.These are the squares for Jacob's afghan.Â  Jill suggested I find a way to make an afghan with stripes, so I will sew the squares together in alternating rows of black and red.I think they are going to be such fun to make.Â  I guess there is no real rush.Â  Jacob, the youngest, is only 10.Â  I just want to be sure all six grands get their graduation afghans.Â  And it gives me something to do that gives me pleasure.Â  Win - win!

title: So this morning...
text: I was awakened by the sounds of dump trucks and heavy equipment banging about in the street outside my windows.Â  This was followed by jackhammer and cement saw noises.Shortly thereafter there was a knock on my door.Â  It was Chris, my long, tall oldest grandson.Â  My gosh, but that boy is tall!Â  He is working with the excavation crew outside my building today.Â  They are tearing up the street in order to run new water and sewer lines into the building next door.Â  Which explains why my landlord let us know our water will be shut off all afternoon.Anyway, Chris wanted to pop in to give his Grandma a hug and to wish her a happy birthday.Â  (Yep - 72 years have come and gone already).Â  He couldn't stay very long.Â  He was on the clock, after all.Â  But when it comes to the grands, I will take every minute that I can!I just can't think of a better way to start the day.

title: Reading Other Blogs
text: Folks are working in their gardens.Â  They are posting vacation pictures or they are planning vacations.Â  They have funny stories about their chickens and their dogs and their cats.Â  They have outdoor building projects or indoor remodeling projects.Â  They are cooking fantastic meals or baking wonderful sweets.Me...I crocheted today.Â  Sigh.

title: Finally a Cool Down
text: Monday the temperature reached 100 degrees.Â  We who are old and have breathing problems hunkered down in air conditioned comfort rather than going out in air that seemed thick enough to cut with a knife.Â  My apartment with its outer walls nearly 12 inches thick, stays relatively cool.Â  Cooking has been kept to a minimum.Â  The apartment is small and heats up quickly.Â  Cold cereal for breakfast, sandwiches for lunch and a jar of something home canned and microwaved for supper.(And wasn't it just a few weeks ago we were complaining about snow and cold?Â  Never satisfied, we in Minnesota!)Today is another story altogether.Â  The heat brought on small storms in my area that cooled things down considerably.Â  68 degrees as I type this morning.Â  Windows wide open.Â  Birds chirping in the tree outside.Â  Light breeze carrying away the stuffiness of too many days of closed windows.Â I had a lovely visit with my brother and his beautiful wife on Sunday.Â  We drank coffee and devoured donuts, took strolls down memory lane and looked at old family photos.Â  Some time back I had sorted through all the family pictures I had received from my Dad a number years ago.Â  When I got them, they were all loose in a cardboard box.Â  The photos of each person went into a large manila envelope.Â  I gave Kelly his photos to take home with him.Â  The physical distance between us and the conditions of his job that keep him away from home much of the time, prevent us from seeing each other very often.Â  But it is what it is.Â  Knowing that we love one another is enough.Grandkid number 3 has graduated from High School.Â  He is planning a career in aviation and will attend school in the fall to further that goal.Â  I have no doubt that he will succeed.Â  This kid was taking flying lessons when was so small that he had to sit on a cushion to see out the windshield of a small plane.Â  I believe he is happiest when he is soaring up among the clouds.Â  We are partly sad because he is leaving home for school, but mostly very proud of his accomplishments so far.Â  Oh, and he loved the afghan his grandma made for him.Â  :)Â Me...I'm thawing out a pork chop for supper - my first hot meal in about a week.Â  Life is still pretty darned good.

title: Middle of the Night Thoughts
text: It has been very quiet here lately.Â  The weather still hasn't decided if it wants to be spring or summer.Â  One day the temps are in the 90's, the next, dropping down to the 40's at night and a couple of days later, back to the 90's.Â  Anyone with arthritis is likely getting their butt kicked.I have postponed a few things until Mother Nature settles.Â  The ingredients for ham and bean soup and the applesauce to can will keep for a while longer in the freezer.Â  I am just doing the necessary stuff for now.Â  Clothes are washed, folded and put away.Â  The dirty dishes are done.Â  Sometimes I sleep well at night - sometimes not so much.Â  This past week has been not so much.Â  You know how you sometimes just doze rather than sleep?Â  Sleep brings dreams, but dozing brings random thoughts.Â  Some of the thoughts are of bad memories and those I chase away.Â  Over.Â  Done.Â  I have learned from my mistakes, I would hope.Â  And even if I wanted to, I can not change the past.Â  No point dwelling on it.Â  Just makes me sad.Instead I think of happy things.Â  I think of each of my children in turn.Â  I think of how I am truly blessed to have given birth four times.Â  I remember what they were like as babies.Â  And how they grew up into good people.Â  I think about family picnics at the lake with Uncle Ronnie and Aunt Em.Â  I think about Mother patiently teaching me how to sew and of Dad, trusting me to use his tools and to drive his cars.Â  And I think about living in the north woods where in winter it is so quiet you can hear the snow fall and in summer, listening to the haunting song of the loons, calling to one another across the lakes.And lately, I think about Heaven.Â  Contrary to previous opinions held by the young, I know I shall not live forever.Â  I am much closer to the going away date than I am to the coming into being date.Â  I do not fear death.Â  I look at it as just going home.Â  But I wonder sometimes.Â  The Bible talks of mansions and crowns and golden streets.Â  And there are many who look forward to that.Me...I have no use for mansions or crowns or golden streets.Â  I believe I would be happy with a cabin on a lake just large enough to accommodate my kids and grands, when they arrive.Â  And enough garden space to grow my food in a climate warm enough to grow watermelons and peanuts.That is my idea of heaven.Â  And I do believe God listens.

title: Phooey
text: So yesterday I tried another one of my freezer meals.Â  It was supposed to be a chicken and rice casserole.Â  Even though I added extra seasonings for flavor and followed the instructions to the letter, it turned out to be a bland mess that looked like someone had thrown up in my crockpot.Â  Even without the visual, I just could not eat it.Â  I am truly glad the pizza shop delivers.Â  :)I have one more experimental freezer meal to test and I will likely do that sometime next week.Â  I am beginning to think I will just go back to my normal way of cooking.Â  Freezer meals are basically a time saver.Â  I am retired and pretty much housebound.Â  I really don't need to save time.Â  I have plenty of it.All I have to do is remember to remove my oxygen tube before turning on the gas burner on my stove in order to prevent those annoying 'poofs.'

title: The First Freezer Meal...
text: was a dismal failure.Â I had baked a pork chop in the oven, made Stove Top dressing and put them together in a freezer bag.Â  I put a serving of frozen carrots in a small Zip Lock bag and added them to the chop and dressing.Â  Into the freezer it went.Today I thawed the pork chop meal, put it on a plate and microwaved it until it was heated through.It was awful.Â  The pork chop was tough, the dressing was dry and the carrots were only about half cooked.Â  I had cooked a chop from the same package earlier and it was tender, so I don't think there was anything wrong with the chops.Â  Â I buy these same chops all the time and have never before had a tough one.I doubt I will make any more freezer meals for the microwave.Â  Tomorrow I will cook a different meal made for the crockpot and see how that turns out.Live and learn.

title: Freezer Meals Experiment and a Surprise
text: Sometimes we need to find new ways of doing day to day chores.Â  Cooking is one of those things that has become a challenge.Â  You have heard me whine about not being able to stand for more than a few minutes at a time, and you have also heard me whine about being tethered to an oxygen machine (hereafter referred to as R2D2 of Star Wars fame).Â  So I need to find a way to prepare my meals that doesn't involve standing by the stove while constantly stirring and doesn't involve oxygen near an open flame.One of the ideas I have decided to try is putting together simple meals that can be frozen and later thawed and cooked in a crock pot.Â  Most of the prep work can be done while sitting at my kitchen table and cooking the meals should be easy with the crock pot.I ordered some of the ingredients that came with my grocery delivery today and much of the rest I already have in my pantry.Â  By the first part of next week I will do a post to let you know what I did and how it worked.On another note, I had a really nice surprise today.Â  I have been thinking about buying one of these.Lo and behold, that very one arrived at my door.Â  Duane said he hoped it would arrive closer to the day, but Happy early Mother's Day!I have several large stainless steel stock pots.Â  They work really well for some things, but many times if the contents aren't stirred constantly or at least often, they will burn on the bottom of the pot.Â  Food in the roaster still needs stirring, but that can be done while sitting if the roaster is on my kitchen table and I won't need to worry about the oxygen going 'poof'.Â  I'm going to give it a test run later next week, making a pot of ham and beans.Â  I think I can get lots of ham and beans in a 22 quart roaster.Â  Thank you, son.I'm off to get my recipes together and my spices out for the freezer meal experiment starting in the morning.Â  See you all next week.

title: Bait
text: I have an apple pie in the oven.Â  I'm guessing that sometime later today I will see Duane walk through the door carrying a plate and a fork.Â  If he wants it ala mode, he will have to stop at the store on his way home.The best bait to use to get kids to come round are baked goodies.Â  Â Pie and cookies work the best.Â  :)

title: She's Back
text: After spending way too much time wallowing about in a puddle of self pity, it is time to get back to the land of the living.Â  True, this round of medical stuff kind of reached out and slapped me upside the head.Â  And I still am struggling to get it all together, but that is no reason to just check out.Â  It is what it is.Â  It isn't going away.Â  I still don't like it, but I need to learn to live with it.Â  So onward and upward.There have been changes.Â  Some time back Duane and I had talked about moving one of my shelving units and my freezer to his apartment, replacing the freezer space with another shelving unit to hold the canning overflow and most of my smaller kitchen appliances.Â  After thinking about it we decided to leave things the way they were and he ordered shelving from Amazon, to be delivered, since the box the unit came in would not fit in his car.Â  Since my chest freezer is still in my kitchen, I decided to make up some freezer meals that can either be microwaved or cooked in my crock pot.Â  Last evening I went through my recipes, writing those I wish to use in a notebook.Â  This way I can cook for a day or two and have suppers for a month.Â  Between the freezer meals and my home canned food, meal preparation should be easier for me.Yesterday wasÂ  a beautiful spring day.Â  The sun was shining and the air was at about 70 degrees.Â  Barb, my cleaning lady, showed up yesterday at her usual mid-afternoon time.Â  Within a few minutes she came to me to tell me we didn't have any running water.Â  Sure enough.Â  Â Just air coming from the taps.Â  Now I have water stored in bottles, but I didn't think it was right to expect her to heat water for cleaning.Â  So I told her to go enjoy the day.Â  Like most janitorial services, she is paid for x number of hours per job.Â  If she finishes after the time limit, the extra time is on her dime.Â  But if she finishes before, she is paid for the number of hours.Â  She must have thanked me half a dozen times before going back out into the sunshine.Â  Made me smile.Last week, knowing that I was less than happy, Duane showed up one evening with surprises.Â  Included were two bags of deli pastrami, which I love, two large boxes of popsicles and two bags of Hershey's Kisses - one with (be still my heart) a caramel filling.Â  I have been known to call him and ask if he has anything chocolate in his apartment.Â  He said now I won't have to call because I have my very own chocolate.Â  :)Youngest son, David, showed up last week.Â  He had an app on his iPad he wanted to show me.Â  It isn't like a video, but more like an overview line drawing of a baseball field.Â  It shows, by name, where each player is on the field.Â  It shows every move each player makes.Â  It shows whether each pitch is a ball or strike or hit.Â  And it shows the actions of each player.Â  David is scorekeeper for his son Jacob's baseball games so this app is easier for him to use as opposed to keeping track watching the actual field.Â  And I can use it to see how my grandson does at each game.Â  He is a pitcher.Â  How cool is that.So that's what has been going on in my little corner of the world.Â  I just finished washing up a couple days worth of dirty dishes and am ready to start a load of laundry.Â  After that it will be recliner time with my Kindle.Â  Hope you are all well and enjoying a wonderful spring day.

title: Off Kilter
text: Have been a bit off kilter lately.Â  Think it likely is due to getting used to the oxygen, the nebulizer three times a day and a new prescription - all at once.I will be back when I get these ducks all in a row.

title: Spring Has Sprung
text: The outside temp is 48 degrees this morning, with the promise of near 70 by this afternoon.Â  I am so looking forward to opening windows to the warm spring breezes.Â  The 18 inches of snow that fell last week is gone with the exception of a couple of small piles left from the snow plows.Â Life is truly good.

title: Adult Children Can be Sneaky
text: Another fun thing about aging has reared its ugly head.Â  I have increasingly become short of breath.Â  My nurses check my oxygen levels at each visit, and the numbers have been less than spectacular.Â  One of the nurses explained to me that I should be on oxygen and in order to do that, a visit to my doctor was required.Â  I declined, using the excuse that we are up to our collective bums in snow and I would wait for warmer weather to venture out.Â  I can not wear shoes due to swelling, and sock feet and snow drifts are not compatible.Â  She smiled, nodded and put in a call to my daughter, who is listed as next of kin on the paperwork.Jill called her sister and younger brother, who made an appointment for me with my doctor.Â  The person they didn't call was me.Â  I guess they knew I would have some serious objections.Â  They did call, however, when they were enroute to my house to take me to said appointment.I blew a gasket.Â  Said I wasn't going anywhere.Â  Said I didn't appreciate them going behind my back to make an appointment for me that I had no intention of keeping.Â  Said a bunch more stuff I probably shouldn't have said.Here's the thing.Â  We of a certain age come to the realization that we have reached a time in life where we know we will not live forever.Â  And we don't like it.Â  Our bodies betray us.Â  Sometimes our minds betray us as well.Â  Some of us just give up andÂ  meekly allow others to run our lives while we wait to die.Â  Others of us fight tooth and nail to maintain some sort of independence even when things become increasingly difficult.Â  And we resent the hell out of anyone trying to tell us what to do.By the time my son and daughter reached my apartment, I had somewhat calmed down.Â  I yelled at them a little bit more, grabbed my coat and went with them to keep the dreaded appointment with the doctor.Blood was drawn, tests were taken as was a chest X-ray.Â  Everything came out OK except for the oxygen levels.Â  The oxygen equipment will be delivered sometime today.As angry as I was with my kids, I am still eternally grateful that they love me enough to risk Mom's wrath.Â  I acknowledge the fact that I can be a royal pain in the patoot.Â  And even with that being said, my kids go to great lengths to try to keep me above ground and in their lives.God love them.Â  I know I sure do.

title: Spring in Minnesota - 2
text: This is the same corner as the picture Duane took this morning.Â  By 5 pm visibility was down to near zero.Â  The ditches along the freeway are full of vehicles.Â  DuaneÂ  was listening to the scanner and heard about a car stuck in the snow in the middle of the street just a few blocks away.I believe hot chocolate and a warm green fuzzy blanket are in my future for this evening.Â  And a prayer for the police and first responders who have to be out in this mess.

title: Spring in Minnesota
text: Duane posted this picture on Facebook this morning.Â  That is my neighborhood.Â  The middle of April.Â  More snow predicted for all day today.Â  And maybe part of tomorrow.Happy Spring.Â  Sigh.

title: Nothing
text: I have nothing to write about lately.Â  Just passing the days doing a little sewing, a little crocheting and a lot of reading.Â  I have settled into the routine of my cleaning lady, home health care nurses and grocery delivery.Â  There is so much crap going on in the world that it is hard to pick just one thing to rant about.Â  Sometimes it is overwhelming.Â  And I can do nothing to stop the train wreck that seems to be overtaking my beloved America.Â  So instead I am enjoying the simplicity that is my life.Go read those in my side bar.Â  Lots of good stuff there.Â  I will be back next week, hopefully with some inspiration.Â  :)

title: Tidbits
text: It is 14 degrees outside tonite.Â  Mother Nature really needs an attitude adjustment.Even with the cold temps, I am finding out that popsicles are a good thing.Â  Popsicles are also addicting.Â  Just ask my kids who are feeding my addiction.A cleaning lady who will swamp out the inside of my refrigerator without being asked is worth her weight in gold.I think I may beÂ  little bit burned out in the crochet department.Â  Time to do something else for a while.Â  Maybe work on the stacks of quilt pieces waiting to be sewn together.A train had five cars jump the tracks.Â  I live half a block from the railroad tracks.Â  I am glad the derailment occurred on the other end of town away from any houses.Â  Small blessings are good.Granddaughter Boston was in a dance competition this week.Â  Her Dad called to tell me that of the three highest awards in the tap dancing category, one of them went to Boston.Â  Way to go, girl!!Â  Grandma is proud of you.The three youngest grands, Boston, Maddie and Jacob, called me a few days ago.Â  There was no special reason.Â  Just wanted to know how I was doing and to tell me what they had been up to.Â  I love those calls.More snow is on the way Sunday.Â  I now understand why the 'global warming' people changed their tune and now talk about 'climate change.'Â  Not much warming going on here.I have all the sympathy in the world for those kids who lived through the school shooting in Florida.Â  But I truly hope the 15 minutes of fame is nearly at an end for those few who think they know best when it comes to gun control.Â  I wonder if they know how badly they are being used by the gun hating politicians.I believe it is time to do some baking.Â  I'm thinking chocolate chip cookies and maybe a batch of cupcakes.Â  Chocolate with chocolate buttercream frosting.Â  One can never, ever have too much chocolate.And that's pretty much the extent of the excitement here in my little home sweet apartment.Â  Next week may be even more exciting.Â  I hear we might have a warming trend.Â  Might hit 40 degrees.Â  Happy dance time!

title: The day after Easter means...
text: Pie for breakfast.Ham sandwiches for lunch.Ham dinner from leftovers.A big pot of ham and beans.Â  That will have to wait a couple of weeks.Â  A few months ago I had an infestation of little black bugs here in my apartment.Â  They were concentrated in my bedroom around my pantry closet.Â  That was the first time in the 21 years I have lived here that there has been an insect problem.Â  Well, except for a few fruit flies during canning season.Â  Anyway, I finally discovered the bugs were coming from my dry beans.Â  Tossed out the beans - problem solved.Â  I will order beans next week and make enough ham and beans for a couple of meals for me and for Duane, and then can the rest.When I go to replenishing my stock of dry beans, I believe I will freeze them for a week and then vacuum seal them.Â  That should take care of any future creepy crawly problems.My landlord knocked on my door a short time ago to let me know the water would be shut off while they fixed a pipe in the basement that had sprung a leak.Â  Not a problem.Â  I store cases of bottled spring water for drinking and lots of 2 liter soda bottles and large juice bottles of water for washing up, etc.Â  The lack of water gave me a really good excuse to postpone laundry and to spend the time playing with green and purple yarn.Â  Not that I needed an excuse .Â  :)I have been glancing out my windows now and then, waiting for the snow to start falling.Â  Between now and Tuesday evening we are supposed to get 6 - 8 inches of the stuff.Â Â Happy Spring!!

title: Saturday Bits and Bobs
text: Fridays are good days, especially if you have hermit tendencies.Â  Friday means that once the home health care nurse leaves I have three whole days plus the rest of Friday to myself.Â  When you have lived alone for ten years, it takes some doing to get used to having people in and out of your home.Â  I have come to terms with that but still enjoy my alone time.Â  Now that alone time can be interrupted by kids and grands and you will hear nary a complaint from me.It helps that the two nurses who come to work on my legs are both cheerful souls.Â  I kid them about drawing straws to see who loses the draw and has to come here and deal with this grumpy old lady.Â  They just laugh at me. Both are very good at their jobs.I get a kick out of the cleaning lady.Â  She is a chatterbox, but doesn't seem to care if anyone is listening.Â  Just a nod of my head or an "Um Hum" from me is enough.Â  She does an excellent job.Â  And Wednesday she left me a lovely Easter card - so thoughtful.Mother Nature seems to be taking a page from Hillary Clinton's playbook, refusing to just go away.Â  Overnight we got maybe two inches of snow and there is the threat of more come Monday.Â  Guess it will be a while before the scent of lilacs is in the air.Â  Sigh.I am hanging up my crochet hook for a couple of days to give my cramping fingers a bit of a rest.Â  And then it will be 'forward, march' with Boston's afghan.Â  The green and purple yarns make it fun to work on.When you have several children who have spouses and inlaws, you don't always spend holidays with them.Â  Â We have to learn to share.Â  So this year it will be just Duane and me for Easter dinner.Â  He is roasting a ham and I am in charge of the potatoes and vegetables.Â  If I am feeling really ambitious, there might just be a cherry pie with ice cream involved.This is me...wishing all of you a very blessed Easter.

title: Finished...
text: Spent the better part of the weekend finishing up the borders on the two afghans and called it good last evening.Here is Zach's graduation afghan.And here is mine, made from the yarn Jill and her family gave me for Christmas.Sorry about the poor picture quality.Â  The battery in my camera died before I could get some better shots.I have started the next one for Boston.Â  I have over a year to complete this one before she graduates.Â  After that there are two more to make and all six grands will have afghans from Grandma.And now I had better get busy getting caught up on those things that were put on hold while I was playing with yarn.Â  Like the mountain of laundry waiting for me.Â  Sigh.

title: Still here...
text: finishing up afghans.Â  Takes time to crochet several rows around them, one being 81 inches square and the other 60 inches square, but hope to have pictures within a day or two.Depending on which weather forecast we listen to, we could get anywhere from an inch of snow up to a foot of the white stuff overnight.Â  I love the way they hedge their bets.Â Not much else going on here.Â  Just a quick post to let you all know I am still upright and taking nourishment.Â  Be back soon.

title: How to Spoil Mom
text: It has been a lovely day here in my little Home Sweet Apartment.Â  It started out just grand with Oldest Son sharing some delicious caramel rolls for breakfast.Â  The rolls combined with several cups of mighty fine coffee were the perfect way to begin.I find I am a bit burned out when it comes to crocheting.Â  I managed to get all the granny squares sewn together.Â  All I have left on both afghans is to crochet three rows around each for borders, but I just couldn't make myself work on them today.Â  Instead it was a day of reading and napping and movie watching.Â  There was nothing constructive happening here and I enjoyed every minute of being a sloth.Duane said he would be going to the grocery store and did I want anything.Â  I had seen that they had bacon on sale so I asked him to bring me several packages as the price was nearly half of what I would normally have to pay.Later this afternoon Duane showed up with a couple of grocery bags and and big grin.Â  He set three packages of bacon on the table.And a box of Little Debbie Nutty Bars, my go to treat.And a bag of jelly beans.And a great big package of smoked whitefish.Â  I dearly love smoked whitefish from Morey's Fish Company, located in northern Minnesota.Â  Years ago we had a cabin on a lake north of here and we would usually stop at Morey's on the way to the cabin to pick up some smoked fish.Â  Once in a while when Duane went fishing in the northern part of the state, he would bring me some smoked fish, but it had been several years since I had any.Â  I didn't know that Morey's fish could be found locally, so this was a surprise.Â  I ate half for lunch and the rest for supper.Â And that's how this Mom is being spoiled.Â  :)

title: My phone rang...
text: yesterday evening.Â  It was Youngest Son.Â  He was calling to report on his daughters.Boston and Maddie are 15 and 13 years old respectively.Â  Their school participated in the student "Walk Out" demonstration the other day, regarding the school shooting in Florida.Â  Some schools made it mandatory that students participate.Â  The school the girls attend made participation optional.Boston and Maddie stayed in school.Boston and Maddie were of the opinion the demonstration was, to quote them, "dumb."The girls had talked with their parents about what happened in Florida.Â  They understand the tragedy of the situation.Â  They also picked up on the talk floating around about gun control as a way to prevent school shootings.Â  I asked their Dad what the girls thought about that aspect of the situation.Â  He told me they thought that was dumb, too.Â  Boston said that if someone is killed in a car accident, nobody blames the car.Â  It is the driver who is at fault.Â  Same with guns.I don't think I have ever been more proud of those girls.Â  They followed their beliefs instead of following the crowd.Â  And I am equally proud of their parents for raising children who can think for themselves and who have what is lacking in many adults - common sense.To quote Boston, "I'm not going to school to demonstrate.Â  I'm going to learn."Boston and Maddie, your Grandma says, "Well done."

title: Still At It
text: The crochet hook is still flying.Â  Or maybe at this point I should say the yarn needle is working overtime.Â  I am in the process of sewing all the granny squares together and when that task is finished there are a couple rows of crochet around each afghan to finish them off with a border.In the meantime, I just couldn't resist testing out the new yarn for Boston's graduation afghan.I will put this one together in a checkerboard pattern.Â  I like it.Â  I hope Boston likes it too.And now I'm off to catch up on the homemaker stuff that has been neglected while I have been playing with yarn.Â  I haveÂ  a friend who teased me that I did my laundry only when I ran out of clean knickers.Â  That was before I bought my apartment size washer and dryer and had to trudge up and down two flights of stairs to wash my clothes.Â  I am a bit embarrassed to say that this time she isn't all that far from the truth, and me with no excuse other than I have been having fun instead of doing chores.Can't say I feel sorry for that.Â  :)

title: It is quiet...
text: here in my corner of the world, now that the snowstorm has come and gone, leaving several inches of heavy, wet snow on the ground.Â  Oldest Son said it was a white knuckle flight all the way home that evening.Â  Most of the snow has been hauled away from the streets and we are just waiting to see what Mother Nature will throw our way next.Â  I am so ready for daffodils and lilacs.I have been working almost exclusively on finishing the two afghans in progress.Â  There is an occasional nap thrown in for good measure.Â  Not exactly a party animal here.Â  :)I have been hearing about storms to the east.Â  I hope they slide on past you who are in their path.Take a look at some of the folks in my sidebar.Â  Their lives are more exciting than mine.Â  I will be back with pictures - soon, I hope.

title: The Yarn Has Arrived
text: So this morning Jill stopped by, hauling in two large bags full of yarn.There was enough to finish Zach'sÂ  afghan.Â  With any kind of luck I should be able to complete that one in a few days.And then there was this deliciousness.Again, I would never have thought of these colors.Â  That's why I beg Jill to do the shopping for the yarn.Â  I'm not sure yet just how I will mix these colors, but I have a couple of ideas.Â  When I get a few granny squares done, I will show them to you.Boston is going to love this one.This is going to be such fun!

title: Time Marches On
text: So I ran out of a couple colors of yarn for Zach's graduation afghan.Â  His mother, my daughter Jill, came to my rescue and picked up the needed yarn for me.Â  I should have messaged her the proper names of the colors, for one of them, while being very close to the color used, was just far enough off in hue that it would be noticeable.Â  She will bring me the proper yarn this week.Â  In the meantime, I have finished another 10 granny squares with the yarn she brought and only have another dozen or so waiting for the proper colors.Â  Then it will be ready to sew the squares together and add a border.Â  Jill assures me that Zach will like it.Â  I hope so.I have plenty of yarn for my own afghan and only need to crochet the last two rows on about 15 squares.Â  Then it will be ready to be sewn together and the border added to it.Â  It is so pretty.Â  I will post pictures of both afghans when they are finished.While Jill was here I talked with her about yarn for the graduation afghans for my three youngest grands.Â  She said she would be happy to pick out the colors and bring me the needed yarn.Â  She said that my granddaughters seem to like her taste in colors so I am just leaving that selection up to her.Â  As long as I am on a roll here with crochet hook and yarn, I think I would like to get the rest finished.Â  After all, I am not getting any younger and I want to be sure that all the grands get their granny made afghans.I don't keep regular hours like I did when in the working world.Â  I sleep when I am tired and am up doing things when I am not.Â  I slept for about three hours after supper last evening and as a result was awake all night.Â  Probably a good thing it worked out that way, for the City crews were removing snow from the last snowfall a couple of days ago and the noise from the equipment they use likely would have kept me awake.Â  The streets had been plowed, but there were rows of snow piled up along the curbs and in the alleys.I watched the activity in the street in front of my building for a while.Â  It was sort of like watching a precision drill team.Â  The huge front end loader with a plow blade on it scraped the snow from the sidewalk and curb out into the street.Â  A smaller loader cleaned the snow from the alley.Â  A small bobcat came behind the other two and cleaned up what they had missed.Â  All of the snow was piled in a row in the middle of the street.Â  After that came the dump trucks which were loaded with snow and off they went to dump it wherever they dump snow - usually on a vacant lot.Â  Other places I have lived in warmer climates have had the theory that God put the snow there, let Him worry about it.Â  But here in Minnesota, we have precision drill teams of loaders and trucks to take care of the vast amount of snow we usually get in the winter.Â  It was kind of fun to watch.Duane brought me breakfast of some orange rolls the other morning.Â  That was a treat.Â  He was here yesterday, helping me put some jars of baking soda on a top shelf in my kitchen, when he found a container of raisins I had forgotten I had.Â  So perhaps a batch of oatmeal raisin cookies is in my near future.Â  That was Duane's suggestion anyway.Â  He knows I share.Â  :)Not much else going on here in my little corner of the world.Â  Hope all is well in yours.

title: Work Ethic
text: Dad had a work ethic second to none.Â  He learned this from his parents who were both hard workers whose priority was the family.He grew up on a farm in northern Minnesota.Â  It is not easy to make a living on a farm in northern Minnesota.Â  He was the youngest of nine children.Â  Everyone worked.Â  Some worked on the farm and some got outside jobs to help the family.Â  Dad told me about plowing the fields behind a team of horses and about pitchforking hay into the loft of the barn to feed the few cows they kept for milk and cream and butter.In the winter his Dad and brothers would take a wagon hitched to the horse team out on a nearby lake.Â  There they would cut large blocks of ice, load them on the wagon and take them home where they were put into the root cellar, packed in straw.Â  If done right, the ice would last until the next winter.Â  They didn't have a refrigerator, but used an ice box to keep food cool in their kitchen.Â  The blocks of ice were put in the lower compartment of the ice box for this purpose.During the Depression, Dad went to work for the CCC (Civilian Conservation Corps), a government work program for young men.Â  Most of their wages were sent to their families.Â  Dad liked to show us a park on a local lake that had been one of the jobs he worked on then.After Dad married and when I was about 4 years old, Dad lost his job at a local gas station.Â  He and Mother decided to go to St. Paul and stay with her mother for a time, thinking that job opportunities might be better.Â  He found a job working at a manufacturing plant that made refrigerators.Â  Shortly after, he saw an ad in the newspaper for an opening for a 'grain sampler' in Willmar, Minnesota.Â  He had no clue what a grain sampler did, but he applied for and got the job.Â  He spent the rest of his working life climbing in and out of boxcars at the railroad yard at Willmar, carrying a six foot brass probe, taking samples of the corn, wheat and oats in the boxcars.As Mother's disease progressed, the Dr. and hospital bills increased.Â  His solution was to find more jobs.Â  Welfare was never an option with Dad.Â  I remember times when he cleaned the church where we went for services.Â  He cleaned office buildings at night after working all day.Â  He found a weekend job feeding turkeys in huge turkey barns.Â  He likely had other jobs I didn't know about.Â  He never talked about the extra work, nor did he ever complain.When Dad retired at age 65, he moved with Mother and my brother back to his hometown of Blackduck, Minnesota, finding a small house nearby.Â  Not content to just sit and do nothing, and I am sure needing money for medical bills, he landed a job with the local bank.Â  This was before computers, and the bank needed someone to take paperwork and/or cash to Bemidji, 25 miles away, and bring back whatever the Bemidji bank had for the Blackduck bank.Â  He made two runs every weekday - one in the morning and another in the afternoon.Â  He also took a disabled boy to school in Bemidji each morning and brought him home in the afternoon.Â  He spent most of his free time with Mother at the nursing home.Â Dad instilled in me the importance of working hard.Â  There was a time when I lived on a farm.Â  Dad came to see me and found me whining about being dirty and sweaty from mucking out a small shed.Â  He told me there was no shame in being dirty from working.Â  The shame came when a person was dirty from laziness.Â  He just couldn't abide lazy.He also told me once that if you were going to do a job, do the best job you could do.Â  If that job was digging a ditch, then make it the best ditch you could dig.Â  And do it not for your employer, but for the satisfaction of knowing you did your best.Seems to me we could use more with that kind of work ethic and fewer with their hand out expecting it to be filled with free stuff.

title: The Seamstress
text: Mother was a seamstress of exceptional talent.Â  There was nothing she couldn't sew.She sewed my clothes until my last year of high school.Â  I'm pretty sure that after I left home, she made most of my sister's clothes as well.I'm not sure where she learned this art, for I don't remember her Mother doing any sewing.Â  Grandmother may have sewn in earlier years, for most housewives did at that time.Â  Sewing was just part of what homemakers did then.Â  But when I first knew Grandma, her husband had died and she was working at a publishing house in St. Paul to support herself and those of her children still living at home.Â  She may not have had time to sew.I would have been happy to spend my life dressed pretty much like this.My little sister and me.But Mother would have none of it.Â  She wanted pretty, dainty, feminine looking and acting girls.Â  I am afraid I was something of a disappointment to her, with my preference for blue jeans and flannel shirts.Mother saw to it that my sister and I usually had new dresses to wear to Easter church services and to the annual Sunday School Christmas program.Â  I liked dressing up at Easter, but would have cheerfully skipped the Christmas program, for I had a fear of speaking in front of a crowd.Â  Still do.Â  The only thing that made me go through with it was knowing when it was all over, each child received a small brown paper bag full of my favorite Christmas candies.Easter dresses.Christmas dresses.Mother sewed our school dresses.Â  At that time there was a dress code in Junior High and High School whereby girls had to wear skirts/dresses.Â  Jeans and slacks were not allowed.Â  These were the dresses Mother made for my sister and me when I started 4th grade.When Mother's youngest sister married, Mother sewed her wedding dress.Â  Emily was married in the front room of her Mother's home.Â  I remember how Mother fussed over making that dress, getting it just right.Â  Emily was a beautiful bride the day she married my favorite uncle.Â Mother had way more patience than I ever had.Â  She exhibited that patience when teaching me to sew.Â  My 4-H project was sewing and it required us to make a dress or a skirt and blouse all by ourselves, with no help from parents.Â  Mother had me practice by making several blouses and skirts that were play clothes before beginning the 4-H project, which was a light brown blouse and a full, flowered skirt to match.Â  Each year there was a county wide 'Dress Review" that was a judging of the quality of work and a modeling of the clothes we had made.Â  Mine won me a trip to the State Fair and I have to give the credit to my Mother, who had the patience to keep at it.Â  It could not have been an easy job for her.Money was sometimes tight and Mother had to get creative when the price of fabric exceeded the cash on hand.Â  When I was very young, Mother took apart an old coat of hers to make a winter coat and bonnet for me.Â  Another year she found that one of the stores was selling flour in the old timey printed flour sacks.Â  She made sure that when Dad bought flour he got enough of the same printed sacks to make my matching skirts and blouses.Â  They were so pretty that nobody knew where the fabric had come from.I think that home sewing is another one of those skills that are going the way of the dinosaur.Â  I no longer sew clothing, mostly because the cost of patterns and fabric has become prohibitive.Â  I can buy ready made for less.Â  But at least I have the skills to be able to make my own clothing should the need arise.Â  And that is a good thing.

title: I was going to stay out of this.
text: I really was.Â  I was going to let the gun control people - the ones who begin their rhetoric before the bodies have cooled - and the defenders of our right to bear arms, duke it out.Â But then I had a conversation with a lady who, in all other respects, is a nice, sensible, caring lady, but who is in favor of getting rid of all firearms.Â  She really believes that if we all turned in our guns the problem of mass shootings would be solved.I suppose I could have given her the standard arguments.Â  Could have cited statistics favoring firearm ownership.Â  Could have pointed out that the gun is nothing more than a tool and is not responsible for killing people.Â  The person holding the gun is the one at fault.Â  Could have said that gun confiscation leaves the honest citizen vulnerable to attack, while the criminal to whom the law has no meaning, will still obtain his firearms.Â  Could have mentioned that while I believe that the mentally disturbed should not possess guns, there are way too many who fall through the cracks.Â  They do not visit mental health facilities.Â  They may avoid the people who might 'see something, say something.'Â  Same goes for the millions of illegal aliens living here who stay under the radar - particularly the criminals and gang members.Â  None of those will appear on a database.Â  Could have said all that.But I didn't.Â  This lovely lady is not politically minded.Â  As long as she can continue her life in relative peace, she is happy.Â  All of the above would not mean very much to her.Â  So here is what I said...She is a single Mom, living in an apartment, working hard to make a living and raise a teen-aged son and daughter.Â  We talked about as parents, how our first responsibility is to keep our children as safe as possible.Â  We talked about how things have changed what with the influx of 'refugees' who hate light skinned people and consider it their duty to rid of our civilization of its laws and traditions to be replaced by theirs.I asked her what she would do if some of those people kicked down the door to her apartment and entered with mayhem on their minds.Â  How would she protect her beautiful daughter from being beaten to a pulp and gang rapped.Â  What would she do if they decided it would be fun to rape her son before slitting his throat.Â  She is smart enough to know that these things happen - here - everywhere - more often than any of us would care to admit.She came to the conclusion that the only way she could prevent those things happening to her children was to shoot the bastards as they came in the door.I have the utmost respect for law enforcement, but they have no way of getting there in time to help in a situation like that.Â  We are pretty much on our own.Â  It would take maybe three good, heavy kicks to my door to break in.Â  And once in, how am I going to stop them from hurting me or killing me.Â  Throw a jar of tomatoes at them?Â  Spray them with my choice of defense sprays?Â  That would maybe slow them down a little and is sure to mostly piss them off, which gets me beaten or killed.Which is why, should our betters - the ones who live in gated communities - the ones who are protected by men with guns - those betters - decide to try to rid us of our protection, I will never, ever comply.We will get back to our regularly scheduled program in a day or so.Â  But right now I am way too angry with those who think they know best how to keep me and my family safe.

title: Putting Up the Harvest
text: When I was about 10 or 11 years old, my family moved from town to a 20 acre plot of land with a big, old farmhouse on it.Â  The selling point was not so much the house, which needed some work, but that it had a large yard and more importantly, a huge garden space.Â  As my Mother's arthritis continued to wreck her body, the medical bills continued to grow accordingly, and it became more important to garden as a way to feed our family without the outlay of so much cash.Â  In Minnesota, getting through the cold winters is a priority.As Mother became more ill, she could no longer do the canning as she had in the past, so as the oldest child it fell to me to help her.Â  About the time we moved to what we called 'the farm,' I learned how to can vegetables and fruit and how to properly freeze some of the garden's bounty.Â  At the time I complained bitterly about having to spend so much time working when I would rather have been playing, but in later years I was grateful to have learned those skills for they were used to keep my own family fed.We canned the standard vegetables along with dill and sweet pickles and several kinds of relish.Â  We froze the garden fruits of strawberries, raspberries and rhubarb.Â  In addition, Dad brought home cases of peaches, pears, apricots and cherries.Â  Some of these we canned in a sugar syrup to be used as a dessert sauce.Â  Some we froze to use in various recipes like peach cobbler, or to use over ice cream as a treat.Â  And some of the fruit from the store as well as from the garden went to make jams.The cellar had a large bin for potatoes, and another where we kept squash.Â  We canned half the carrots and stored the rest in a third bin, to be eaten raw.There was a small apple orchard just southwest of the house.Â  It was an old orchard and some of the trees no longer produced fruit, but there were enough apples in the fall to make lots of jars of applesauce.Â  And there was one crab apple tree that had the best tasting crab apples I have ever tasted.Â  We ate many of those fresh from the tree and we used many of the smaller ones to make crab apple pickles.When we had as many jars of canned fruit on the basement shelves as we needed, we started making pies, using peaches and apples.Â  We kept a stack of those foil pie tins and used them for the freezer pies.Â  We made the pies the same as we would if we were going to bake them, wrapped them in tin foil and stacked them in the freezer.Â  I don't know how many pies we made each fall, but I do know there were at least two stacks of each kind in the freezer when we were finished, just waiting to be baked for a dessert treat or for when company came for supper.We didn't can meat back then.Â  I don't know why, but I never heard of anyone doing so.Â  We bought chickens from a farm neighbor.Â  Dad had a small field on the property and the neighbor rented it to plant corn or soybeans and paid with beef he raised on his farm.Â  I think we got the better of that deal.Food preservation wasn't just a trendy thing to do as it seems to be now.Â  It was a way of life.Â  It was the means by which you fed your family.Â  I fear that these skills will be lost.Â  I do hope that enough people will learn them for a time when we may need them to survive.

title: Mother
text: My Mother was born in 1924 and died in 1996.Â  She was one of six sisters and one brother, who were raised in a small town in northern Minnesota.Â  Her father was a railroad depot agent and lay minister and her mother was a homemaker.Mother at age 16.Mother believed in honoring her parent's wishes, so when her Dad told her he did not wish her to marry until she was 21 years of age, she obliged and married my Dad one week following her 21st birthday.Mother at age 21Shortly after my birth in 1946, Mother was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis.Â  The next 50 years were defined by pain.Â  Mother, Dad and me.Although arthritis was a huge part of her life, she was much more than the disease.Â Mother about age 21 in Blackduck, MN.Mother was musically talented.Â  She played piano, guitar, ukulele, violin and cello, lettering in high school for her orchestra performances.Â  She also had a beautiful alto singing voice and could harmonize with nearly any song.Â  My sister and I have decided that our singing abilities came from our Dad, who couldn't carry a tune in a bucket.Most of Mother's siblings had musical abilities and often accompanied their father to his church services, providing the music.My brother, being 15 years younger than me, tells me he never heard Mother play any of her instruments, for by the time he was born, her hands were becoming deformed and she could no longer make music.Â  My sister remembers hearing Mother play all, but I only remember hearing her on the piano, violin and cello.Â  The last time I heard her play the violin was at a 4-H meeting, where the parents took over the meeting and provided the entertainment.Â  Dad found a very small child's toy violin.Â  He stood in front of the room, telling jokes and clowning, playing the toy, while Mother stood out of sight, playing her violin.Â  I think the tune was "Red Wing," one of Dad's cowboy favorites.Â  I consider myself lucky to have heard her play.Mother was an accomplished seamstress.Â  She sewed her own dresses as well as those for my sister and me.Â  We nearly always had new Easter and Christmas dresses and she sewed our school clothes until I was well into high school.Mother enjoyed needlework and often would embroider on those white flour sack dishtowels that were popular then.Â  She taught me to embroider on the dishtowels as well.Â  She also crocheted beautiful lace doilies using a very small crochet hook and thin crochet thread.Â  I never could get the hang of that, but enjoy using regular yarn instead.Mother loved decorating for the holidays.Â  I can remember when she took a branch from a bush and painted it white.Â  She had us blow the insides out of eggs, leaving just the hollow shells, which we painted in bright colors and Easter designs.Â  She then hung the eggs by threads from the branches, making an Easter Tree centerpiece for the dining room table.Â  She did the same for Valentines Day, using red and pink paper hearts.Mother was in her element at Christmas time.Â  She had evergreen boughs, Christmas ornaments and silver bells everywhere.Â  The Christmas tree, always a real tree, was a sight to behold.Â  And when she could no longer walk, she could be found sitting in her wheelchair in the middle of the living room, directing Dad as to where each decoration went.Mother and Dad at our house in the country about 1957.As her body deteriorated, I never heard her complain.Â  I saw her cry only once, when I had to leave her in the nursing home section of the local hospital.Â  The insurance required transfer from the hospital to the home in order to pay.Â  Dad didn't have the heart to do the deed, so as the oldest child, it fell to me.Â  She begged me to take her home, knowing full well that Dad could no longer care for her.Â Once Mother settled into a routine at the nursing home, she became calm and seemed to thrive.Â  The home is small and in her hometown, so she knew nearly everyone and the staff took very good care of her.Â  Dad spent much of his day with her and evenings would usually find them in a rousing game of Scrabble, which Mom usually won, with Dad saying she won because she cheated.Â  That became something of a family joke.Dad and Mother outside the nursing home in Blackduck where she lived out her remaining years.Through the years of pain and surgeries and hospital stays and nursing home living, Mother never once lost her faith.Â  One of the last things she did was to request her pastor to read the 23rd Psalm to her.Â  She died peacefully on a spring day at age 72.There are those who tend to refer to Mother as a Saint, and that seems to irritate me somehow.Â  She was a good woman, but not a Saint.Â  She had her faults just like the rest of us.Â  She just was able to handle what life threw at her better than most.Â  Whenever I find myself slipping into a pool of self-pity, I think of her and realize that my difficulties are minor compared with what she lived with most of her life.I still miss her.

title: Dad's Garden
text: My Dad loved a garden.Â  He once told me that he acquired his love of all things growing, from his Mother.Â  When his older siblings were busy with the daily chores of running a farm, the youngest children spent time in the garden with his Mother, where he learned about planting and growing and harvesting.Â  I think part of it was that he just enjoyed spending time with his Mother.When I was growing up, my family lived in a series of small, rental houses.Â  If a landlord permitted, Dad would dig up a small corner of the back lawn and plant tomatoes and potatoes, along with a few other vegetables.Â  In the mid 1950's when he was finally able to purchase a 20 acre hobby farm that had space for a large garden, Dad was in gardeners heaven.Dad, my little sister and me in Dad's garden.Dad poured over the seed catalogs, making lists of the vegetables he wanted to plant.Â  He planted all the standard vegetables - sweet corn, green and yellow beans, peas, carrots, beets, etc.Â  But then the fun began.Â  He would try something new every year.Â  Once he planted peanuts that were a dismal failure.Â  The plants came up, but the Minnesota growing season just wasn't long enough to produce the peanuts.Â  Another time he ordered blue seed potatoes.Â  These grew well and yielded a good crop of potatoes that really were blue in color.Â  Sadly, when cooked, they turned a disgusting gray color that nobody was interested in eating.The 'giant pumpkins' gave us some large jack-o-lanterns, but none grew as big as advertised.Â  His rousing success was popcorn.Â  The ears were small, and when the plants turned brown in the fall, Dad picked all the ears, spread them out on old window screens, held up by two sawhorses, on the front porch, and left them there to dry.Â  We shelled the cobs and excitedly tested the popcorn by popping a batch.Â  We were not disappointed.Dad added a small strawberry bed and a long row of raspberries.Â  Both did well, although we rarely had enough to use for jam or to freeze.Â  He didn't seem to mind, however, when he would catch us picking and eating the berries as fast as they would ripen.One of my fondest memories is of grabbing a salt shaker and heading to the tomato patch with Dad.Â  We would sit on the ground, surrounded by tomatoes and eat until we couldn't any more.During that time I joined the local 4-H club.Â  Each member had 'projects' for the year, usually ending with county fair exhibits.Â  Many of the kids raised cows or pigs or sheep to show at the fair, but because we weren't a regular farm and had not the means to care for animals, my main projects were sewing and gardening.Â  Those with a gardening project exhibited their best vegetables at the fair, and there was also a 'garden tour' held by the club to look at the various gardens in the neighborhood.Â  That meant that the garden had to be really spiffy with no weeds in sight.Â  After a year or two, I finally caught on and asked Dad if he encouraged me to garden for the love of raising food or if he just wanted free labor to keep the garden free of weeds.He just smiled!

title: Sunday Memories
text: I have found that since retiring, it is easy to lose track of which day of the week it is.Â  There are no alarm clocks to set, no time cards to be punched.Â  The days just flow, one after another.Â  Early on I decided to designate Sundays as a day of rest, leaving the normal chores for the weekdays.I think I get this idea from Mother, who was rigidly religious.Â  She would have been happy if our family attended Sunday School, morning and evening church services.Â  She would have been even happier if we had spent the rest of the day reading our Bibles.Â  While these were good pursuits all, things just didn't work out for Mother.Dad was a good, Christian man.Â  His beliefs aligned themselves with Mothers, but with a healthy dose of fun thrown in for good measure.Â  We were spared the forced Bible study.Â  Often he planned a family activity for Sunday afternoons.Â  In the winter he would take us ice skating or sledding.Â  If the weather was too cold and blustery for outdoor activities, we might spend an afternoon reading one ofÂ  the many books he kept for us, or we might play board games like Monopoly.Â  Playing cards were forbidden - Mother thought them to be of the devil - so we played Old Maid or Authors or Uno.Â Summertime Sunday afternoons were for picnics, swimming at the lake or maybe a lazy afternoon of fishing.Â  We had a badminton set and a croquet set and sometimes he would set up one or the other of those games and we would have tournaments on the front lawn.Â  Sometimes we just piled into the family car and went for a drive.Â  We admired the crops in the fields, went for walks along the river or stopped to explore an abandoned rural schoolhouse.Â  Often these excursions ended with a treat of an ice cream cone.Mother's beliefs did not allow us to go to the movies.Â  I never did get her to explain why she felt this way.Â  I don't know how Dad managed it, but he took me to see 'Bambi' and 'Snow White' when I was very young.Â  Even though it was well over 65 years ago, I still remember watching Snow White running through the forest and finding the cottage of the Seven Dwarfs.Â  And I still can't watch 'Bambi' without crying when his mother is killed.Â I suppose Mother's beliefs may have come from her father, whom my Dad once described as "stern but fair in his dealings."Â  I wish she had been able to enjoy life a bit more as did those on Dad's side of the family.Â  I'm sure that the fact that she spent many years in pain from rheumatoid arthritis did not help any.Â  I think Dad's sense of humor matched with Mother's rigid religious beliefs probably tempered both and made for a successful marriage.Â  I once asked my Dad how he could take care of Mother, day in and day out, in those later days when she could do nearly nothing for herself.Â  His answer was simple.Â  "I love your Mother."And that's what it really is all about, isn't it.

title: Bits and Pieces
text: Never before have I seen a variation of the flu bug so insidious.Â  You think you are done with it and then it comes back just enough to sap you of your energy and keep you tired all the time.Â  On the up side, I am getting lots of sleep which is probably a good thing.One result of too many daytime naps is being awake at odd hours.Â  The other evening, being awake at 3 AM, I looked out my living room window and noticed it had started to snow.Â  My street looks kind of old fashioned, with street lights made to look like the gas lights of long ago.Â  Combined with the big snowflakes falling, the scene was quiet and peaceful.Â  I watched for a time, thinking how nice it was to have an ordinary city street turned postcard pretty.Â  Only about two inches of snow fell, but it was lovely.My cleaning lady is worth her weight in gold.Â  I have a tall, narrow shelving unit in my kitchen that holds large bottles of seasonings, canning jars full of things like mashed potato flakes, dehydrated hash browns, canning salt, pancake mix, etc.Â  Today she cleared out the unit, washed down all the shelves, the top and the two small cupboards it contains.Â  She even wiped the accumulated kitchen grunge from the bottles and jars.Â  In the past few weeks, she has washed down my bedroom and kitchen walls, all without being asked.Â  I don't think my apartment has ever looked this good!I still plan to do some canning, but am putting it off until my energy returns.Â  In the meantime I am ordering what I need using my grocery delivery service and just freezing items like corn and peas and beef roast and hamburger when it is on sale.Â  That way I can do small batches on good days and avoid those canning marathons I used to do.Duane brought me a bucket of ice cream and a box of ice cream cones.Â  Yes, I know.Â  It is Minnesota and it is sub-zero temps.Â  But here in the tundra, it is never too cold to indulge ones self with ice cream.Â  Which I have done.Â  More times than I care to admit to.All things considered, life is still pretty darn good!

title: Back to Normal
text: That flu bug is sneaky.Â  You think you are over it, for the nasty symptoms have disappeared.Â  But then there is a week or so of feeling weak and tired.Â  That's where I have been.Â  Spent way too much time in my recliner, under my green fuzzy blanket.Â  Finally this morning I woke up feeling close to normal.Â  Well, normal for a chubby grannie with various and assorted old age things going
