on.Â  Guess I need to call that the 'new normal.'Â  :)So as long as I was feeling pretty chipper, I took look at my canning shelves.Â  Seems I have used food from them a bit more often than I realized.Â  I'm going to have to stop being a lazy slug and get busy, replacing what I have used.I need to can corn and peas.Â  For those of us who can't garden any more, I find that buying frozen vegetables on sale works well for me.Â  I just pour them into a pot, cover with water and heat them until they are thawed and warm.Â  Then it is to can them the same as if they were fresh.Â  They turn out just fine.I am waiting for chicken legs to go on sale.Â  Four legs will fit nicely into a quart jar.Â  I add water or broth and run them through my pressure canner for 75 minutes.Â  They are good for a variety of meals, but I particularly like them for chicken and dumplings.Although I have lots of soups canned, I need to make more vegetable soup.Â  I have chicken vegetable but want to have some vegetable beef soup on hand.Â  It is super easy to make.Â  It takes bags of frozen mixed vegetables, cubed potatoes and carrots, onions, tomatoes and cubes of beef roast.Â  I usually brown the beef cubes first for flavor and then just mix it all together with broth for the liquid.Â  If I don't have broth on hand, I just use water with some beef bouillon mixed in, and can pints for 75 minutes.Guess I had better stop talking about it and get busy.Â  I will be ordering some of the ingredients in two weeks when I do my next grocery order.Â  Sometimes I get a bit complacent, thinking that I have well stocked shelves.Â  Can't let that happen.Â  Preparing isn't just a one time thing.Â  It is a lifestyle.Â  About the time I let thing slide is the time when a life changing event will come along and I might wish I had been a bit more diligent.

title: Storm of the Century...
text: is how the weather forecasters describe every new snowfall we get here.Â  As it was, my neighborhood wound up with about a foot of snow.Â  There was some wind along with it, but that didn't make much of a difference here in town.Â  Out in open country the snow drifted and the freeway was shut down further south.Â  Folks around here forgot how to drive on icy roads and many spent a fun filled evening trying to get their vehicles out of the ditches.Â  The tow truck drivers were ecstatic.Â  Their finances are now looking pretty good.Â  There were a few fender benders and a couple of jackknifed semis, all of which are par for the course when a storm rolls through here.Oldest Son told me that the business where he works turned him loose about an hour early the night of the storm.Â  Said it took him nearly twice as long to get home, but the worst part of the trip was when he got into town ahead of the snow plows.Â  Said it took him a couple of tries to get into the parking lot here.Â  Yesterday morning the lot still had not been plowed, so he then couldn't get out.Â  Don't think he was too sad about having to take a 'snow day.'Talked to my three youngest Grands on the phone last evening.Â  Got caught up on all of their activities.Â  My, but they are busy!!Â  I surely do love hearing about what they have been doing.Â  Afterwards I talked to their Daddy, my youngest.Â  He works for a landscaping company that does snow plowing in the winter.Â  It is his job to get the contracts and then to manage the crews who go out to remove the snow from driveways, parking lots, sidewalks, etc.Â  He is also the person the clients call when they think their driveway should be plowed half a minute after the snow stops.Â  He said that sleep would only be fond memory for the next couple of days.Me...I watched the snow fall from the comfort of my rocking chair, which is the very best way to observe the latest Storm of the Century.

title: Toddlers and Grown-ups
text: After coming out of my flu induced stupor, I decided to take a look at the news headlines to see what I had missed.Â  I found that our government had again shut down.Â  Which begs the question, 'I wonder what life could be like if Congress were populated with grown-ups instead of toddlers?'I have seen children who were much better behaved than those who make our laws.Â  The back biting, name calling, blame assigning, complete with posters and charts, is astounding.Â  I can't help but equate their behavior with a three year old who is on the floor, kicking and screaming because they can't have their own way.I think we should limit Congress to sessions lasting only three months out of the year.Â  This would give them ample time to deal with the problems our country is facing without giving them the time to waste on posturing, rhetoric and outright lies.Â  They would be forced to work together rather than spending so much time arguing and tantrum throwing for their pet causes.Â It is way past time for politicians to remember who voted for them and why.Fruit juice and tea have been sipped.Chicken soup, that cure for what ails you, has been consumed.Audio books have been listened to.Naps under the green fuzzy blanket have been taken.Â  Lots of them.Yep.Â  Looks like I am going to live after all.Â  :)

title: Pride...
text: goeth before a fall.Here I was.Â  All self satisfied, patting myself on the back for avoiding the flu bug that is running rampant across the land.I had two bouts of the stuff earlier, but both only lasted a couple of days each and were comparatively mild.Then BAM!!Â  Right between the eyes.Â  Tired.Â  Yucky.Â  Cranky.Â Like my friend SJ who often comments here and who has been dealing with the flu for a couple of weeks now, I am reduced to a diet of Jello for that is the only food I seem to be able to handle at the moment.I am off to curl up in a corner, dragging my green fuzzy blanket behind me, and take yet another nap.Â  I am here to tell you, this flu bug is one nasty little creature.Â  I will return just as soon as I can kick it on down the road.

title: Playing With Yarn
text: I am about halfway finished with my grandson's graduation afghan.Â  I'm afraid I will have to send my daughter Jill back to the yarn store as I am running out of one color and will likely need more of a couple of colors to complete the border.Â  Jill is very good at picking out colors of yarn for me to turn into beautiful afghans.Â  I warned her that when I am ready to make the three graduation afghans I have left to make, I will just send her to the store and let her choose the yarn.Jill proved her taste in choosing yarn at Christmas.Â  She gave me two very large gift bags full of these beauties.She said that after making afghans for the grands, I might enjoy making one just for me.Â  She was right!I couldn't stand having that yarn just sitting in the bags without applying a crochet hook.Â  After a bit of experimenting I came up with this design for the granny squares.I found that the variegated yarn showed up better sandwiched between the solid gray than next to the teal.Â  True colors don't always show in photos.Â  The blue is a lovely teal color.Â  The yarn is soft to the touch and will make up into a cuddly afghan just right for afternoon naps.So thanks again, Jill.Â  This one is going to be fun.Â  :)

title: Messing with my computer...
text: gave me the opportunity to learn some brand new swear words.Â  They didn't help much except to vent some of the frustration of losing the battle between computer and human.Â  I was able to fix enough to make my laptop usable again but there are still strange noises coming from within.Â  So I tossed some money at Duane and he went to the local computer store and came back with a very reasonably priced laptop.It sounds a bit crass to say I tossed some money at Duane.Â  That is sort of a running gag between us.Â  He often buys the things I need but can not get out to shop for myself.Â  When asking him to do those errands for me, I usually tell him to stop over and I will toss some money at him to cover the cost.Â The reality is that I have made it a practice to stash cash for emergencies, a little at a time.Â  I try to keep a couple of months rent on hand - just in case.Â  And because I can no longer go shopping, it has been fairly easy to save enough so that I can replace a wonky computer without breaking the bank.So now I am in the process of transferring information from the old computer to the new.Â  Several years back, the lady I worked for gave me an external hard drive.Â  I'm pretty sure it is now considered obsolete, what with the popularity of flash drives and other sources of data transfer.Â  It still works like a charm and has really come in handy for this use.Now I just need to learn the ins and outs of the new operating system.Â  They seem pretty straight forward, but I am no computer genius, so it may take a little time to become comfortable.Â  At least, nothing growls at me when I use this new one!!

title: I'm Still Here
text: Just dealing with some computer issues.Â  Hope to have them straightened out shortly.On other fronts, we happily have moved out of the sub-zero deep freeze with a high today of 34 degrees.Â  But this is January and this is Minnesota, so we are looking at single digit temps on the weekend.Â  Guess I won't be working on my tan any time soon.I will return as soon as I finish swearing at my wonky computer!!

title: Thursday Ramble
text: It is cold.Â  It is January and it is Minnesota, so this is not a surprise.Â  Looks like we have a heat wave of plus 30 degrees coming over the weekend.Â  I don't care.Â  I don't plan on going out until the tulips are in full bloom.I am giving up on watching the news for a while.Â  Today I spent some time looking at several news websites.Â  Most of the news programs consisted of a moderator who announced a bit of a news story.Â  Then they went to a panel of so-called experts who voiced their opinions.Â  Before long all of them were talking or shouting over one another so I couldn't tell what anyone was saying.Â  I wonder what happened to the nightly news where the newsman just read the news of the day.Â  Seems to me we used to be able to form our own opinions without 'personalities' telling us what to think.Â  Phooey.Â  Done with them.I am feeling a bit spoiled.Â  The lady who comes in to clean once a week does a terrific job, leaving me more time to indulge myself in the things I like to do.Â  I have been working on Zach's graduation afghan.Â  It is coming right along, but will take at least the rest of this month to complete.Â  His mother, my daughter, Jill, gave me two large gift bags of yarn for Christmas.Â  There are skeins of a light teal, gray and some variegated with those two colors.Â  I haven't quite decided just how to put the colors together, but I will show you how pretty the yarn is when I get a few squares made.Â  She said that after making so many afghans for the grands that I might like to make one just for me.Â  She was right.The last time my sister came to see me, she and her husband brought me a box full of pork from their farm.Â  There were pork chops and sausages and I can't remember what all else.Â  There was one package left in my freezer that contained a large pork roast.Â  Yesterday I thawed it out and slow baked it all afternoon.Â  Duane came over when he got off work and shared supper with me.Â  It is always more fun to cook when the meal can be shared.Â  The roast was delicious.Â  Tasted better than anything you can buy at the store.Â And now I am off to do some serious damage to the leftovers.Â  I think a hot pork sandwich with mashed potatoes and gravy is just the ticket for a cold, below zero Minnesota night.Â  :)

title: New Years Eve Reflections
text: They say the older you get, the faster time seems to pass.Â  They are right.Â  2017 slid on by at warp speed.The New Years celebrations of my youth were pretty tame affairs.Â  Mother, being a very religious woman and a teetotaler to boot, made sure our celebrations included nothing more exciting to drink than Hawaiian Punch.Â  She made oyster stew as a treat for Dad and a big pot of chili for the rest of us who considered oyster stew something not to be consumed but should be buried in the back yard.After supper the board games were brought out and rousing games of Sorry or Yahtzee or Scrabble were played.Â  A big bowl of popcorn accompanied the games.Â  Sometimes Dad would cook up a batch of molasses taffy or maybe a pan of fudge.Â  The leftover Christmas cookies were brought out, insuring that sugar highs would keep us awake until midnight.My family didn't have a television until I was in high school, so we listened to the radio track the new year until it reached our old farmhouse in Minnesota.Â  Sometimes we stayed awake to welcome the new year and sometimes, not.Â  Depended on how much candy and cookies were available.Â  If we were lucky, we would hear 'Auld Lang Syne' played half a dozen times.I don't make New Years Resolutions.Â  I learned at an early age that resolutions had a life span of maybe a week.Â  Now I just remember the good times past and look forward to the new year.Tonight will be a quiet night for me.Â  I am a bit lazy today so meals consist of opening jars.Â  Ham and bean soup for lunch and chili for supper.Â  There will be crocheting on my grandson's afghan, possibly a bowl of popcorn, watching the ball drop in Times Square and some listening to the police scanner, which can get exciting on this holiday.I wish for all of you a very Happy New Year, no matter how you celebrate.Â  May it bring you peace and joy.

title: Christmas Memories
text: This time of year my mind tends to wander back through the years to visit Christmas Past.There was the time in about 1950 when my Dad lost his job in northern Minnesota.Â  The decision was made to stay with my maternal grandmother in St. Paul, where Dad would likely have a better chance for employment.Â  Money was tight, but Dad found a way to make Christmas special.We walked a couple of blocks to Snelling Avenue where we caught a streetcar.Â  You young ones don't even know what a streetcar is, do you.Â  It is like a passenger car on a train only smaller.Â  It ran on tracks built into the city streets.We rode the streetcar to downtown St. Paul where all the big department stores were located.Â  This was before shopping malls.Â  Each store had big display windows and each store tried to have a better display than their competitors.Â  There were Santas and elves and reindeer and toys and most everything was animated so it moved.Â  There were Christmas lights everywhere and to a little girl it was a magical fairyland.Grandma's Christmas tree was a marvel, filled with lights and old glass ornaments she had collected over the years.Â  She even had some bubble lights.Â  Remember them?The best part were the little mesh bags that hung from the branches, filled with chocolate coins wrapped in gold foil.I take that back.Â  The best part was Grandma, who laughed and wouldn't let Mother scold me when I got caught playing in her flour bin.Â  Grandma, who had an ample lap just right for snuggling a small granddaughter.Â  Grandma, who lived until my 30th year and who I still miss, especially this time of year.As a young girl, my family always had a real tree for Christmas.Â  Except for the one year when Dad came home with what was the newest modern tree.Â  It was made of silver foil.Â  Looked like several rolls of tin foil had exploded.Â  Mother decorated it with pink glass ornaments.Â  We were hip.That tree gave a whole new meaning to the word 'ugly.'Â  I believe it went on the garage sale in the spring.When my own children were young, I had a real tree, cut down from the woods surrounding our home.Â  There were few real ornaments, but we made up for that with tinsel.I set out big bowls of popcorn and a bowl of cranberries, gave the kids darning needles and strong thread and set them to making garlands that we wound around the tree.Â  After Christmas we hung the garlands on the bushes outside for the birds.We filled in the tree decorations with candy canes and homemade gingerbread men.Â  I used those small, round, red cinnamon candies for the features and buttons down the fronts of the cookies.Â  I don't think my kids ever found out where I hid the candies until it was time to bake.Â  By the time Christmas Eve rolled around, the lower branches of the tree were naked, having been stripped of candy canes and gingerbread men.It is good to remember those times.Â  But it isn't about trees or decorations or presents.Â  It is about the birth of our Lord and about time spent with those we love.Â  I will be with my children and grands on Saturday evening.Â  Christmas Day Duane and I will share a ham dinner while the others celebrate with their own families or in-laws.Â  I am glad that my children have so many in their extended families with whom to share the joy of the season.I am taking a bit of a vacation from blogging until after the New Year.Â  I wish for all of you, my friends, that you are blessed not only now but throughout the year.Merry Christmas!!

title: This Cleaning Lady Thing
text: So my cleaning lady called to ask if she could come in Monday rather than our agreed upon Thursday.Â  I had cancelled last Thursday because the city chose that day to shut off the water to this building.Â  I keep a supply of water in old 2-liter soda bottles and juice bottles, but thought that to be too awkward for her first time here, especially since there were floors to be mopped.I have to say I think I will like this cleaning lady thing.Â  Never in all of my 71 years have I had someone in to help with household chores.Â  My kids all had chores to do when they were young - wash and dry the dishes, haul out the trash, clean their rooms.Â  But to have someone deal with everything else is pure bliss.The lady did a wonderful job.Â  My nasty old kitchen floor shines and my bathroom sparkles.Â  The dust is gone from my bookshelves.Â I think I am being spoiled.Â  And I like it.Â  :)

title: Here Today - Gone Tomorrow
text: The city workers in the town where I live have been busy for the past week at the Town Hall, located across the street from my apartment.Â  The two story building takes up about a third of the city block along the street where I live.Â  Barriers were erected, people wearing hard hats were scurrying about and the water was turned off for part of the day last Thursday.Â  I didn't pay a whole lot of attention.Â  Until this morning.I was enjoying my first cup of coffee of the day while scanning the news headlines and perusing some of the blogs I read daily, when I heard the sound of a crash, coming from the street below.Â  This was no ordinary crash, but was loud and long and sounded like someone was dumping great quantities of cans and bottles into the middle of the street.Â  Nosy person that I am, I went to the window to see what was going on.To my amazement I saw a giant backhoe that was taking huge bites out of the building.Â  The crash I heard had been the collapse of one of the outer brick walls.Â  I watched the progress off and on throughout the day.Â  The machine kept taking down chunks of the building.Â  The work had begun about 8 AM and by 4 PM there was nothing left but a mountain of rubble.I guess I lied when I said nothing ever happens in my corner of the world.Â  I can't hardly wait to see what happens next.Â  :)

title: What Makes Us Happy
text: I don't watch TV.Â  I do watch news programs, movies and read stories, blogs, etc. on my computer.Â  Nearly everything I see has ads telling me how much happier my life would be if only I bought their product.That got me to thinking about what, exactly, does it take to make me happy, and I found it has little to do with the purchase of goods.Â  Oh, I do like my kitchen gadgets as much as anyone else and I could do some serious damage to my budget in a fabric store or a yarn shop, but for the most part my happiness has nothing to do with spending money.Some of the things that make me happy are:The words "I love you, Mom."The phone call from a grand that starts out with, "Guess what, Grandma!"The first cup of coffee each morning.A cup of hot chocolate on a cold winter evening, especially if it is made using my homemade mix with malt powder in it.Cornbread fresh from the oven.Watching the snow fall from the window in my cozy apartment.Reading a good murder mystery book that keeps me up all night so I can find out 'who done it.'Working on an afghan I know my long, tall grandson will like.Sewing quilts that one day will keep my family warm.Looking at the hundreds of jars full of food that insures my family will not go hungry in a crisis.Going through the old family photos that sometimes make me smile and sometimes make me cry, missing those who are no longer here, but always make me remember the good times.Reading and answering the comments from friends who stop by here now and then.I don't need that new car or that ocean cruise or that expensive whatever to make me happy.Â  My heart is full with what I already have.

title: A New Project
text: Whenever a grandchild of mine graduates from High School, they receive a crocheted afghan from their Grandma.Â  My third grand, Zach, graduates in the spring.Â  I asked his Mom, my daughter Jill, to pick out the yarn for me.Â  She knows better the colors he would like.Â  This is what she brought me yesterday.Â  (The pictures aren't very good, but at least they will give you an idea of colors and patterns.)I wasn't quite sure just what to do with them.Â  I only do the Granny Square pattern.Â  It is easy to do and if I try to crochet a pattern that involves counting stitches or rows, I tend to get lost or mess it up.Â  I experimented with several variations and decided I liked this one the best.Each square is 7.5 inches across, so it will take at least 81 squares plus a good sized border to make the afghan big enough to cover my 6 ft. tall grandson.I suppose I could just buy a graduation gift or give my grands cash.Â  And I don't expect them, at that age, to appreciate a handmade gift.Â  But when they are older, they might like to have something their Grandma made just for them.Â  I know I would.

title: Excitement!
text: I usually moan and groan that nothing exciting ever happens here.Â  I stand corrected.Last evening I had just finished with supper when I heard a commotion in the street in front of my building.Â  Curiosity got the best of me and I went to the window to find out what was going on.When I looked out I saw a pickup truck decorated with Christmas lights pulling a float with even more lights.Â  This was followed by another truck and float.Â  I was watching a Christmas parade!There were at least 15 floats, all lit up and carrying people who were tossing candy to the kids lining the street with their parents.Â  There was a dance studio group full of kids in costumes that had the Christmas lights on them.Â  They danced on down the street to the sounds of Christmas music.Â  The local fire department was having a good time walking along giving out candy and they were followed by one of the fire trucks, completely covered in lights.Â  There was a group of kids on bikes who had strings of lights woven in and around the spokes of the wheels.Â  There was a decorated snowmobile on wheels (no snow here as yet) pulling a decorated cart holding a small Christmas tree.Â  I'll bet I saw at least four Santas.About a half hour after the parade had passed by I heard horse's hooves clip clopping on the pavement.Â  There was a team of horses pulling what looked like a long hay wagon full of kids and their parents.Â  And standing in the street outside my window was Santa himself, talking to the kids and posing for pictures.Did I mention the fireworks?Â  There were fireworks as good as the ones on the 4th of July.Each year my town puts up a huge Christmas tree in the center of the downtown area.Â  On the first Friday in December, they have a tree lighting ceremony followed by rides in the horse drawn wagons.Â  But this is the first year they have held a Christmas Parade.Â  Or had a fireworks display.It was fun to watch the families enjoying the razzle dazzle of the parade.Â  And I think I had just as much fun as the kids, watching the parade pass by under my window.Â  I hope it becomes an annual tradition.

title: Dealing With Change
text: I am old.Â  I do not like change.Â When I was young, changes in routine were welcome.Â  The excitement of new places, new adventures, new people were all welcome.Â  Today.....not so much.A few short weeks ago I saw my kids now and then, saw the grocery delivery guy twice a month and that was pretty much it.Â  And I liked it that way.Â  There are folks who feel the need to be surrounded by friends and family continually.Â  I am not one of them.Â  Â There are those who retire and then find themselves bored to death.Â  I am not one of those, either.Â  I have many interests - quilt making, crocheting, scrapbooking, reading, genealogy research, food preservation, etc.Â  Finding ways to occupy my time has never been a problem.Â Living alone and being alone have never bothered me.Â  I have often thought that in another life I might have made a pretty decent hermit.Â  Â  As long as my kids and grands check in from time to time, I am happy.Â Then came the time when I had to reach out for help.Â  Now I still have the grocery delivery guy here every other Thursday afternoon.Â  Tuesdays and Fridays are reserved for the nurses who come in to deal with the care of my legs.Â  And yesterday I met with the lady who will be cleaning my apartment every Thursday morning.It is like Grand Central Station, I tell ya!I am grateful for the help.Â  And so far the people who flow in and out of my home seem like nice folks.Â  But I find that keeping my sense of humor in good working order seems to help.Â  My youngest son always teased me about checking my busy calendar to see if I was free on a specific day, knowing full well that I was free as a bird any day of the week.It now appears the joke is on him.Â  :)

title: Turkeyed Out
text: There were enough Thanksgiving Dinner leftovers so that I had two more turkey dinners and a couple of sandwiches.Â  A 14 lb. turkey goes a long way for two people.Â  Duane kept what he wanted and brought me the bones and some leftover meat.Monday I cooked the bones for a couple of hours, strained off the broth, picked the remaining meat from the bones, and added more leftover meat to the broth.Â  Â Later I added diced potatoes, carrots, onions and corn, all from my stash of dehydrated vegetables.Â  Tossed in a few chicken bouillon cubes for flavor along with dried thyme and parsley and let that simmer the rest of the afternoon.Duane took home a bucket of soup, added some seasonings of his own and declared it to be pretty darned good soup.Â  He was right.Â  I have been eating off of my half the past couple of days.Â  Tonite I will add dumplings for supper.And then I believe I have gotten as much mileage from that turkey as I can.Â  I will be officially turkeyed out.Â  :)

title: Not Much...
text: going on right now here in my little Home Sweet Apartment.Â  Just doing the small daily chores and puttering about with this, that and the other.Â  Thanksgiving is easy this year since it is just Duane and me, and he is cooking the turkey.Â  Nearly everything else comes from my deep pantry, so there is no last minute shopping to be done.I am taking the rest of the week off from blogging.Â  So this is me...wishing all of you...a very Happy Thanksgiving.Â  Even with the world's insanity surrounding us, there is so very much to give thanks for.Â  My wish for you all is a day filled with love, laughter and time spent with those you love.

title: Finishing Up...
text: my canning marathon gave me, in addition to the soups I had canned the day before, 12 quarts and 24 pints of soup base.Â  Each jar contains potatoes, carrots, celery, onions, peas and cabbage.Â  I tossed some chicken bouillon in for flavor.Â  This soup base can be heated as is for vegetable soup.Â  I can add a jar of home canned meat for a heartier meal or thicken it for stewÂ  with dumplings or biscuits.Â  It can also be used as a base for a casserole.Â  I like having jars of food on my shelves that have multiple uses.All that canning wore me down a bit, so I took a couple of days for rest and relaxation.Â  Books were read and naps were taken.Â  And now it is time to get caught up again.Â  The washer and drier are humming away.Â  I have been doing some rearranging on the shelves to find room for the latest bit of canning.Â  And in between when I need to rest, I have been adding information to my genealogy program.Â  My genealogy research has been sorely neglected lately.Â  If I want to leave a record of who we are and where we come from for my kids and grands, I need to take the time to work on it.I have settled into a routine with the home health care people who are here twice a week.Â  They come in, wash my lower legs, apply the antibiotic ointment and bandages and wrap my legs from knees to toes in ace bandages.Â  I thought perhaps they would do things differently, but the routine is exactly the same as Duane has been helping me with for the past two years.Â  I will continue with the home health care if for no other reason than to give Duane a break.Â  He has helped me with this for two years without complaint, so I figure he has more than earnedÂ  a rest from that responsibility.I still don't have a cleaning person lined up, so if I don't hear anything positive about this, I will call and whine a bit to see if we can't get going on it.And that is the extent of the excitement here in my little Home Sweet Apartment.Â  I still check the news headlines from time to time, and then thank God for my quiet, stress free life.

title: Canning Again
text: So this past week I ordered two boneless half hams and a bunch of fresh vegetables.Â  The plan was to can up several kinds of soup.Â  I love having soups in my pantry for a quick lunch or with a sandwich or cornbread for supper.This morning I canned 16 pints of ham, potato and cabbage soup and this afternoon it was 16 pints of ham and potato soup.At which point I ran out of ham.I had prepped all the vegetables earlier - potatoes, carrots, onions, celery, peas and cabbage - so tomorrow morning I will mix them all together, stir in some granulated garlic and powdered chicken bouillon and can that up to use as a soup or casserole base.I don't care what anybody says - you can never have too much food put by.

title: Oh No!
text: You know when you go for an appointment with your doctor and they weigh and measure you first?We will not discuss the reading on the scale.Â  That is way too depressing.But I found that I have shrunk from my original statuesque 5 feet 3 inches to a mere 5 feet 1 and 1/2 inches tall.So now I m not just a chubby granny, I am a SHORT, chubby granny.Life just is not fair.Â  :)

title: I Have Been AWOL
text: There has been considerable activity in my little apartment lately.Â I spent the weekend happily sewing on quilt tops and hope to do the same this coming weekend.Â  I will post some pictures when they are finished .Monday was taken up with the normal household chores and giving my grocery order to the nice lady who calls for it.Tuesday the home health nurse was here and we got the schedule figured out.Â  They will begin working on my legs as soon as they receive orders from my doctor.This afternoon I have an appointment with my doctor.Â  It irritates me to have to see the doctor when I am not sick, but there it is.Thursday is grocery delivery day.Â  I have ordered the ingredients to make several kinds of soup to can.Â  I seem to have used quite a bit of soup from my shelves and need to replenish before winter.Â  I can do most of the prep work while sitting at my kitchen table which helps.Friday the home health nurse will start treatment of my legs.Â  I found that I can order the supplies through the nursing service which will save my kids the trouble of having to shop for them.The cleaning service hasn't shown up as yet, but my case worker tells me that should happen within a week.Some time back my youngest son wanted to know if I was available on a certain date.Â  I told him I would have to check my calendar, knowing full well I didn't have a calendar nor did I need one for my quiet lifestyle.Â  His response was asking me to pencil him in for that date and he and his siblings have teased me about my busy calendar ever since.The way things are shaping up around here, I may just need one.Â  :)

title: Woke Up This Morning...
text: looked out the window.Â  There is no smoke from burning cities.Â  There are no masked antifa gangs marching in the streets.Â  As far as I can tell, nobody is rioting.Â  Guess the Moms of these deluded wanna be gangsters wouldn't let their progeny leave their basement bedrooms long enough to carry on their revolution.Â  Sigh.On another sad note...evil has again reared its ugly head in the form of the massacre of the congregation in a small church in Texas.Â  Right on cue, the anti-gun politicians are touting their beliefs before the bodies have even cooled.Â  The pundits are busy speculating about motive before we even know who is responsible.Â  I will wait for the facts before holding forth on the who and why.Â  Until then, the only thing we can do is pray for the families of the dead and for the recovery of those wounded.Â  And for our country, where this kind of thing seems to be happening way too often.

title: So today...
text: the antifa fools have announced they will be holding protests across the country and they will continue to protest until our President and Vice President resign.Suppose the thugs stood around in the park in their black clothes and their face masks with their banners and their clubs, just waiting for someone to show up so they could thump them, and nobody did.Â  I'm thinking they would look pretty silly, especially if the newscasters ignored them too.Â  Kind of tough to protest when nobody else is interested.Â  Just saying.

title: Update on Services
text: Last week the fellow who is my case worker came here to talk about my specific needs and to tell me about my options.Â  He is knowledgeable and courteous.Â  I have found that I become irritated with those who treat me like a child just because I am old.Â  There was none of that.Â The result of our conversation is that the home health care people will come in twice a week to deal with my legs.Â  The nurse called me today to set up an appointment for Thursday this week.Â  Duane has that day off from his job so he asked to be here.Â  That way he can learn how the health care workers deal with my legs and he can be a backup if needed.Â  This is Minnesota.Â  We have ice storms.Â  We have snow storms.Â  A backup is a good thing should the worker be unable to get here.My case worker is setting up a cleaning service that will come in for three hours a week.Â  They will do the basics - clean the bathroom, mop the floors, dust, vacuum, etc.Â  Should there be time after that, they will do specific jobs like cleaning out a cupboard or washing windows, etc.These services are not free.Â  I did not expect them to be.Â  The cost to me is based on my income and which services I require.Â  Bottom line - I pay $59 per month.Â  I was surprised.Â  I thought it would cost me more than that.Â  The fee is well within my budget and as far as I am concerned, worth every penny.This will take some getting used to.Â  Having people who are not family in my home three days a week is not something I normally do.Â  But I will just have to adapt, for I think this will be a good thing.Â  As my youngest son said when I called him to tell him what was happening, "Good, Mom.Â  Now maybe life will be easier for you."He may be right.

title: I stole this...
text: from "Spinster Stitcher".Â  I found her in the sidebar of "The Polka Dot Chicken," a blog that I adore.Â  I have been known to spend a considerable amount of time browsing through the 'Chicken' posts, drooling over her beautiful pictures of all things quiltyÂ  and stitchy.Â  Her sidebar is loaded with more of the same.Anyway, when I saw this picture...made me laugh and it so reminded me of the crowd that would gather whenever I was stirring up goodies to bake.Â  When you have four children who were born within six years and they are all waiting for the beaters, it seems like a crowd.Â  Two got one beater each.Â  Two got spoons and the bowl.Â  Everybody was happy.I think the world might be a happier place if we all had beaters to lick.Â  :)

title: Crud
text: Slight headache.Â  Chills.Â  Snotty nose.I can be found in my recliner, snuggled under the green fuzzy blanket, listening to Agatha Christie mysteries in audio book form.I shall return when this crud goes away.Â  In the meantime, the folks listed on the sidebar have some good posts.Â  Hope you all have a fun weekend.

title: Our local weatherman...
text: tells us there could be some snowflakes in the air in the next couple of days.Â  My first reaction was "Noooo!!"And then I remembered that those protesters who like to gather in the town square or on the freeway to bring traffic to a grinding halt don't like to march while spewing their hate filled slogans or stand on the highway waving their 'No Justice - No Peace' signs when the wind is howling and the snow is falling.Maybe winter is not a bad thing after all.

title: Friday Ramble
text: We have had a couple of lovely warm fall days and today looks like more of the same.Â  I have a couple of windows open and the fresh air is welcome.Â  Some years ago the city planted some small trees downtown.Â  I noticed that some in my block have already dropped their leaves, but the one outside my window is a brilliant yellow.Â  I expect that tree will be bare before long.Â  Winter isn't all that far off.I have been busy clearing off one of the shelving units in my living room, getting it emptied so Duane can drag it home.Â  He helped yesterday by movingÂ  cases of bottled water and 25 lb. sacks of sugar and flour.Â  To make space on the other unit for the water, sugar and flour, I moved a tub and a couple of laundry baskets full of fabric, yarn and quilting supplies.Â  I am about halfway finished sorting through, organizing as I go so I can actually find what I need when I need it.Â  So far I haven't tossed anything.Â  I am a quilter.Â  We keep even the smallest of scraps of fabric because they might come in handy for another quilt.Â  That's just the way it is.Â  Sigh.When I planted my windowsill garden some time back, all the plants died off.Â  Except for the green bell peppers.Â  They are still flourishing in my kitchen windowsill.Â  They have been blooming like crazy and I actually have one pepper that is about as big around as a quarter.Â  There may be more, but so far they are too small to be sure.Â  Anyway, the pot of pepper plants is pretty, so even if I don't get more peppers, it is alright.My granddaughter, Boston, emailed me this.Â  Boston is on the left and I believe her dance instructor is on the right.Then she called me to tell me about it.Â  It is an honor for her to participate in this show.Â  Years past in dance competitions she nearly always had a tap solo.Â  She loves what she does and is really good at it.Â  I hear that she did a good job dancing in the show.Â  She also told me it had been a busy week.Â  She found out she was to be inducted into the National Honor Society.Â  I am so proud of this girl.Â  But the best part for me was that she made the effort to call her Grandma to let me know what was going on in her life.Â  I just love that kid to pieces.That's pretty much all of the excitement here in my little 'Home SweetApartment.'Â  The days go by, stuff gets done and now and then one of my grands makes me smile.Â  It really doesn't get much better than that.

title: Sense of Humor
text: When I told my youngest daughter that my goal in life was to live long enough to be a problem to my children, she replied that my work here on earth was done.Â  I love her sense of humor.Â  And this has become a family joke.While being interviewed for the county services, I was asked about my goals.Â  At my age, waking up tomorrow is a pretty good goal, but I didn't say so.Â  And I didn't mention my goal of having at least one year's worth of food put back, for most folks think you are a hoarder or you are crazy.Â I did make the mistake of quoting the above mentioned family joke because my youngest son was sitting there and I thought he would find it funny.Â  I then went on to talk about more serious goals like keeping the cellulitis under control in order to stay out of the hospital.I suppose I should have explained the family joke to the interviewer.Â  Not everyone has a sense of humor or the ability to recognize humor.I received a printed copy of the interview in the mail.Â  Sure enough, under the heading of Goals were these words.Â  "Vicki has the goal of living long enough to be a problem to her children."Sheesh.Â  Now I suppose I will need to explain to a case worker the difference between real goals and family jokes.Â  :)

title: I Have Been Evaluated...
text: and it appears I qualify for the services I need.Â A cheerful little woman sat at my kitchen table, went over my paperwork, asked me some questions, put my information into her computer and announced that I could get the home health care for my legs and I could get someone in to do the heavy cleaning chores.Â  Works for me.This service is through my County.Â  They required one family member to be present.Â  I suppose they dealÂ  with elderly folks whose memories are shaky at best or some who are sadly living with some form of dementia.Â  My youngest son, David, acted as the designated relative.Â  Basically he just listened.Â  Except when the questions concerned my memory.Â  I allowed that it was still functioning, but occasionally I will go from the living room to the kitchen and forget why.Â  He piped up and said that he could ask me about an event fifty years ago and I could remember the details.Â  I guess that means I passed the memory test.Â  :)Anyway, it takes about three weeks to get everything set up.Â  I will be assigned a case worker who will schedule a nurse to check out my legs and who will train nurse's aids to take care of my legs.Â  The case worker will also arrange for the house cleaner.Â The lady who interviewed me said what I already knew, that Medicare does not pay for home health care unless it is needed following a hospital stay.Â  So there will be a fee for the two services that is figured according to income.Â  She told me the amount per month and it is a small amount that will not in any way wreck my budget.Â  That was a relief, as I feared I would not be able to afford this.Â  I can.I am of two minds about this whole new situation.Â  I hate that I need to ask for help.Â  And I am not thrilled about having strangers come into my home for any reason.Â  I am a private person who likes her solitude.Â  You, my readers, probably know more about me by now than do some of my family unless they read this blog.But on the other hand, I know that I absolutely have to keep my lower legs from becoming infected.Â  Cellulitis includes in some like me, open, draining wounds that may heal and may not.Â  There is no cure and if infection sets in, it means time in the hospital, which I want to avoid.Â  It also, if it gets too bad, can be life threatening.Â  My oldest son, Duane, has done a phenomenal job of helping me stay as healthy as possible by doing the application of gauze pads where needed and the Ace bandage wrapping of my legs two and sometimes three times a week for nearly two years.Â  He says he would continue, but I think he has already gone above and beyond.Â  All of my kids are helpful, but if I can get done what needs to be done without having to call on them, then I will not feel like I am a burden.Â  That is important to me.I am not overjoyed about becoming involved in a government program, even if it is at the County level.Â  But so far nobody has asked any questions that I would refuse to answer.Â  And I found out that there are many other services available to me should I want to use them.Â  Meals on Wheels was mentioned, but I thought it would be rather silly to request that one considering my deep prepper pantry!So I will give this program a go.Â  I will admit to being relieved at having some help with those things I can't seem to manage any more.Â  I am grateful to my kids for all their help and for setting up this solution to a problem.Â  Sometimes a person just has to swallow a little bit of pride and do the sensible thing.Â  Not something I am very good at doing.Â  :)

title: Still Alive and Kicking
text: I have been busy.Â  I am getting closer to finding the floor of my freezer.Â  Cases of my home canned food are being transported to Oldest Son's apartment, giving him easier access to them and freeing up storage space for me.Â  The people in charge of such things will be here in the morning to go over the paperwork and evaluate my living space to see if I qualify for home health care and for basic apartment cleaning services to help with those chores that have become difficult for me.Â With any kind of luck I will be able to get caught up with those blogs I enjoy sometime next week and may even find the time to post more of my usual drivel.Â  Just wanted to let my blog friends know that I did not fall off the edge of the earth but am up to my elbows in dealing with the stuff I want to get done before the snow flies.Â  Check out those folks listed in my sidebar.Â  Good stuff there.Â  :)

title: Why?
text: I find it troubling that I was not surprised early this morning when I saw the headlines about the Las Vegas shooting.Â  I was even less surprised when Hillary Clinton's Tweet about the event was a condemnation of the NRA.Â  And the newscaster's reports consisting of speculation before the facts are in was expected.It was reassuring to see how many police, firemen and first responders heroically ran in toward danger to protect and save those in the line of fire.Â  And the civilians who put themselves in harm's way to save others and the ones who used their personal vehicles to get some of the wounded to hospitals when the ambulances were full are to be commended for their humanity and unselfishness.What I want to know is why we have gotten to the point where mass killing has become the norm.Â  Why are we seeing more violence in one years time than I saw in the first 50 years of my life.Â  Thugs protesting at college campuses, riots in the streets, banning anything that can possibly offend someone and crazies shooting up schools, churches, nightclubs, offices and concerts have become a way of life.Perhaps we need to take a long, hard look at what has changed.Â  Perhaps laws should apply to everyone.Â  Perhaps schools should go back to teaching the basics and not worry about diversity or white privilege or free speech zones.Â  Perhaps a good work ethic should again be an important trait to have.Â  Perhaps plain good manners and respect should be the norm again.Â  And perhaps it was a mistake to remove God from so many areas in our lives.Â  Perhaps.

title: The Singer
text: In the past couple of months I have heard someone singing outside my window.Â  She never sang more than a few lines of a song.Â  By the time I got to the window she had stopped singing, so I had never seen her.Minnesota doesn't allow smoking in public buildings, including bars.Â  So of an evening there are often groups of people out on the sidewalk.Â  The bicycle shop beneath my apartment set out a wrought iron table and four chairs, and often those are filled with people, talking and laughing.Such was the scene when I heard the singer again.Â  This time she sang a song all the way through.Â  I don't know what the song was, but it sounded like one of those lilting Celtic songs.I was able to see her standing near the table and chairs out front.Â  She reminded me of the hippies from the 60's.Â  She wore a long full skirt, a blouse that we used to call a peasant blouse and a short embroidered vest.Â  Her hair reached her waist.Â  She had the voice of an angel.The bar crowd, while not rowdy, can be loud.Â  By the second or third line of her song, the only thing I could hear was the sound of her voice.Â  When she finished singing the last verse, there was silence.Â  And then applause.She smiled, turned and walked away.I hope she sings again and I hope I am here to listen.

title: The Argument
text: So I am sitting in my recliner a couple of nights ago, happily sewing fabric hexagons together, listening to an audio book when I hear a ruckus outside.Â  Nosy old bat that I am, I went to the window to see what all the fuss was about.Â  My line of vision includes the sidewalk in front of the bar next door.I see a big hulk of a man standing there, arms flailing about while trying to make his point and he is bent over some at the waist, which brings him nose to nose with a little bitty woman who is cute as a bug's ear.Â  The argument was along the lines of, 'Yes, you did,' 'No, I didn't.'Finally the little lady takes two steps back, puts her hands on her hips and says, 'Homer, you are drunk.'His arms fall to his sides, he straightens up, hangs his head and says, 'Yes, I am.Â  Will you take me home, please?'The last I saw of them, they were quietly walking down the street, hand in hand.Wouldn't it be nice if all disputes could be reconciled so easily?

title: Today...
text: the temperature had dropped 30 degrees. Â The air conditioning is shut off. Â The windows are open. Â There is a light rain falling.Tomorrow I will drum up some ambition to clean a closet and sort through boxes and tubs of fabric and yarn.But today is a good day to stay in my jammies, sew little fabric hexagons together on my Grandmother's Flower Garden quilt and watch old movies.I love retirement. Â :)

title: The Last Hurrah of Summer
text: It is hot. Â The temperature is headed toward the 90's with a heat index of at least 100. Â The humidity is in the 80's. Â I know this is nothing compared with what our friends in the South live through, but we Yankees just wilt in anything over 80 degrees. The combination of heat and high humidity has an adverse effect on those of us who have achieved geezer status. Â We can become a bit short of breath and arthritic joints complain loudly.So I shall be spending the weekend as quietly a possible. Â I'll be back Monday when a cool front is due to chase away the hot and damp and usher in some fall weather. Fall - my most favorite time of year. Â :)

title: Stuff
text: I am not one of those people to whom shopping is a recreational activity. Â When I still could get out and about, I would make a list, go to the store and buy what was on that list, get out and go home. Â And I am not an impulse buyer. Â I generally would look online and compare products and prices before buying anything major. Now either my kids shop for me or I can order what I want online. Â And the same applies. Â I check it out before I order it.Even with careful comparison shopping, somehow I find myself knee deep in stuff. Â There are tubs of stuff on the floor of my closet. Â There are boxes of stuff on the deep shelf above. Â There are clothes on hangars that I haven't worn for maybe 10 years or more. Â I have two night stands with drawers and shelves full of stuff. Â I have a bookcase full of stuff. Â And I have no earthly idea how I managed to accumulate so dratted much stuff.I have begun the task of sorting and tossing. Â Some stuff is in good shape and will go to Goodwill. Â Some I will keep - but not that much. Â The rest is destined for the dumpster. It is amazing what I have found so far. Â I have no idea why I have a shoebox full of floppy discs. Â It has been years since I had a computer that would read them. Â I know there is nothing important on them. Â Out they go.I have the dress I wore to my oldest daughter's wedding over 20 years ago. Â I couldn't get into that dress even using a shoehorn. Â Goodwill can make use of it.I will keep the photos and the box of picture frames. Â The old letters and printed genealogy material will stay, too. Â And the tools. Â But I think the dumpster might just be overflowing by the time I am finished.There is just way too much stuff!

title: Mother Nature...
text: is a bit cranky. Â Last week it was warm enough to turn on the air conditioning. Â By Friday this week it looks like I will need it again.But today at 12:19 pm, the temperature is 56 degrees and it is raining. Â I have the heat cranked.So my green fuzzy blanket and I are spending quality time in my recliner. Â There is some hand sewing and some crocheting and some reading to keep me occupied. Â And naps. Â Don't forget naps.Mother Nature, please make up your mind. Â Is it still summer or has fall arrived. Â Inquiring minds want to know.

title: It has been a quiet day...
text: here in my little corner of the world. Â The biggest excitement here was my grocery order delivery. Â And that was pretty dull as I just ordered necessaries and no fun stuff. Â I don't know what I was thinking. Â I usually order one treat like Little Debbie Nutty Bars or maybe a small bag of butterscotch candies. Â Guess I can suffer through with the cookies I made a couple of days ago. Â :)Our cool weather went away and has been replaced with heat. Â It is nearly 6 pm and the temp is 91 degrees. Â The humidity is up there as well and we have an air quality alert from smoke blowing in from wildfires. Â But it looks like a cool down is coming by Sunday.I'm pretty much having to confine myself to reading just the headlines. Â My blood pressure can't handle the details. Â For a time it seemed like common sense and goodwill had returned, what with the efforts of citizens helping citizens. Â It did my heart good to see all those folks showing up with their boats to rescue those stranded in the flood waters. Â Race, diversity and white privilege be damned. Â People just helped people. Â But now that the storms have passed, it seems we are right back where we were before.I saw where a bunch of bottom feeders were busy helping themselves to high dollar shoes in the wake of the Florida hurricane. Â I was glad to see that a couple dozen of them had been arrested. Â Oddly enough, no work boots were stolen.Black Lives Matter found it necessary to cover the statue of Thomas Jefferson at the University of Virginia in a black shroud. Berkeley is ramping up to deal with the violence when a (gasp) conservative speaker shows up. Â In typical response, the administration is offering counseling to those who can't handle opposing opinions.And just this afternoon there are reports that the lunatic in North Korea has launched another missile.I know I need to keep track of what is going on around us. Â But for this evening, I believe a glass of lemonade, a cookie or two and a good mystery book are in order. Â Perhaps my sanity can be saved after all.

title: A Chocolate Chip Cookie Kind of Day
text: The first two cookie sheets full are in the oven. Â I haven't done much baking lately and was craving cookies. Â I may have to make some gingersnaps, too. Â The gingersnaps bring to mind evenings on the porch with family and friends. Â Mother always served gingersnaps in the summer with ice cold glasses of homemade lemonade.I thawed out eight quarts of sliced apples, with another eight or so still in the freezer for another day. Â I filled quart jars and used plain water to cover them. Â They were in the boiling water bath for 20 minutes. Â They will be good to use for desserts like apple crisp.I found two whole chickens underneath the apple slices. Â They look OK - no freezer burn. Â I think later this week I will boil them up and can the meat in half-pint jars for use as sandwich meat. Â I am low on chicken broth, so I will be able to can that as well.I also found ten quart bags full of pumpkin and another dozen bags of butternut squash. Â I haven't decided what to do with them, but am leaning toward dehydrating. Â I have seen where others have dried both pumpkin and squash and then ground them into a powder. Â It seems they rehydrate well and can be used anywhere one would use canned squash or pumpkin.And way underneath the squash and pumpkin are maybe four quarts of shredded zucchini. Â One day in a week or so, those will go into a few loaves of zucchini bread.I think I actually caught a glimpse of the floor of the freezer. Â When it is all cleaned out, I will ask Duane to come over and wipe it out. Â I am way too short on one end to do it. Â Chances are if I tried to clean the bottom of the freezer, I would wind up with my head inside and my legs sticking out the top. Â  Not a good position for a chubby granny. Â :)

title: Prayer Request
text: For those of you who are so inclined, I have a prayer request. Â My daughter has a friend. Â She is widowed. Â She is in a wheelchair. Â She is on the east coast of Florida. Â For several reasons she can not leave, so she is riding out the storm at her house. Â Prayers for her safety would be much appreciated. Â Thank you.

title: Friday Ramble
text: It was a peaceful day here in my little corner of the world. Â There was laundry to do and dishes to be washed. Â Dust bunnies vanished from a few surfaces.Yesterday Duane brought me a big bowl of venison chili for supper and I finished it off for lunch. Â It was really good. Â I am still amazed at what a good cook he turned out to be. Â I still remember that his specialty as a child was peanut butter and dill pickle sandwiches!I have been watching Hurricane Irma's advance toward Florida. Â That is not going to be pretty. Â My heart goes out to those in the path of that storm. Â I found out that a cousin in Texas lost her home to the storm that went through there. Â Everything was ruined by the flood waters as were the stables for her horses. Â She and her husband managed to get their motor home to high ground and they were able to move the horses. Â But everything else is either covered in muck or under water. Â I feel so bad for them.In between household chores, I have been entering information into my genealogy program. Â I am amazed at the amount of data I have accumulated over the years. Â I have been fortunate enough to acquire pictures from other relatives to add to the information. Â  It is nice to see what those ancestors looked like and many times I can see a family resemblance.The moving project seems to have come up against several brick walls. Â One wall is the price of rent compared to what I pay now. Â After I pay my rent which includes all utilities except phone and Internet and after I buy my groceries each month, I still have enough leftover to be able to enjoy life a little bit. Â It might be a bit selfish, but I don't want to give that up. Â I want to be able to do some of the things that make me happy without having to decide if I want to pay rent or buy groceries. Â There was a time in another life where I was hungry. Â I won't go back there.And then there is the problem of home health care. Â Medicare will only cover that after a hospitalization. Â And there are no home health services that are at all affordable. Â My daughter is coming over tomorrow with some paperwork to fill out for County services. Â I am not overjoyed about getting involved with any government programs, but I will take a look to see just what is involved. Â If they have too many rules and regulations or if they want my soul in payment, it won't happen.I mention the above just for anyone in my situation to know what we have found here. Â It looks like I might just stay put and hire someone to do basic cleaning once a week. I would rather deal with the stairs than become so poor I look longingly at a can of dog food. Â :)Otherwise, all is well. Â It has been cool for this time of year. Â I turned the heat on a couple of nights ago when I saw it was 51 degrees outside and 62 degrees inside. Â I like cool weather, but that was a bit much for this granny. Â I am not ready to dig out the long johns just yet!!

title: Minnesota Students Get It
text: The following was posted on Facebook and on the Internet news page for the local television station."MINNEAPOLIS (WCCO) â€” Some students at ROCORI High School are taking issue with the schoolâ€™s policy that would prevent them from displaying flags in the parking lot.The policy was revealed to students this week as they returned to class for the new school year.According to the text of the parking permit application, â€œstudents are not allowed to display flags or banners from their vehicles while parked in the ROCORI school parking lot.â€Furthermore, the school says that â€œany violations of these procedures can and may be given a ticket or towed away at the expense of the owner.â€On Wednesday, a number of pickup trucks at the school arrived with American flags prominently displayed.Community organizers have also set up a 2:30 p.m. â€œSupport Our Students And Our Countryâ€ rally at ROCORI in support of the students displaying those flags. As of noon, about 30 people had responded to the Facebook event page."We have allowed any mention of God to be taken out of schools. Â School administrators have been known to send kids home for wearing a t-shirt with the American Flag on it, saying the picture of our flag might offend immigrant students. Â A couple of years ago a kid here in Minnesota had been hunting the day before and forgot to take his shotgun out of his vehicle when he parked it in the school parking lot, which was against the rules. Â He did the right thing by telling those in charge what had happened and asked permission to drive back home to remove the weapon. Â School administrators called the police instead.Political correctness is at an all time level of stupidity. Â Under no circumstances should our flag be banned Â From anywhere. Â Period.What really got to me were the comments on FB from adults condemning the kids for breaking the rules. Â I suppose I should have expected it since I live in the middle of dimmocrat land.But I will say this. Â If my kid chose to break such an idiotic rule and fly the American Flag on his truck, I would stand behind him 100%. Â Those students have more courage than the rest of the population who just follow along like lambs to the slaughter.Good on you, Ricori students. Â You make me proud.

title: Of Sharing Memories
text: Since my sister was here and since we talked of family memories, I have shifted gears and am spending more time on organizing the mountain of family history I have accumulated over the years. Â I had let it go by the wayside while working on my food storage and on my sewing endeavors. Â But I need to get back to preparing our family history to share with others in my family. Â None of my offspring or their offspring are showing signs of taking up where I leave off, but I need to remember that I was well into my 60's before 'genealogy bug' bit me.When I got to the point where I needed a genealogy computer program to keep track of my findings, I tried out several. Â Some were too complicated. Â Others seemed like there was more interest in cool graphics than in entering information. Â Still others required the family information be sent on to their websites to be used for whatever purposes they wished. Â And still others stole information that I later found listed elsewhere.I finally found a program that is free and easy to use and has no restrictions. Â It is 'Personal Ancestral File' from the Mormon website, 'FamilySearch.org.' Â In checking the Mormon website before writing this post I found, sadly, that they have discontinued that program and now offer online solutions. Â Lucky for me, I have saved my original download and when I have entered all I wish to enter, I can put the program and the information on a DVD and send it to any relatives who wish to view what I have entered.When I first started this journey into researching my family, I found many websites where folks had uploaded their family tree information. Â I thought I had hit the motherlode of genealogical information until I discovered errors in the family relationships. Â Not only that, but specific errors were found in many different family trees. Â People were just copying someone else's work and claiming it as their own. Â I knew the work was wrong because I had personally known some of the people who were listed in error as to parental relationship or spousal relationships. Â Birth and death dates were often wrong. Â As were the names of places where the families had lived.So I started doing my own research. Â Many state historical societies have websites that can be searched for birth, marriage and death information. Â Other websites have searchable Social Security information of the deceased. Â Another called 'Find A Grave' is searchable to find the burial locations of ancestors. Â I have found it reliable and useful. Now I just enter into my program those that I know or knew personally and those for whom I have found to have proof of their existence. Â This way I know that the information I leave behind is true and accurate.This research thing may seem as dry as dust to those who have no interest in family history, but I find it fascinating. Â I found details of one ancestor who, upon his arrival to North America spent a couple of years living in a cave. Â When he finally obtained a small farm, he was such a disagreeable neighbor that he was literally run out of town. Â Another has documented statements of his bravery during the Revolutionary War. Â And another was fined 6 months pay for being drunk on guard duty during the Civil War. Â It would seem that I have more rogues than heroes.Not everyone needs to go to the lengths I have in finding my roots, but I think my grands need to know something of their history. Â They need to know that their great-grandfather on one side of the family carried on his family tradition of farming the land that had been in the family for generations, both milking cows and raising beef cattle. Â And another great-grandfather (my Dad) spent most of his adult life caring for his invalid wife, sometimes working three jobs in order to do it. Â Both of those men had a work ethic second to none. Â This is part my grand's heritage. Â They need to know.

title: Family Stories and Pictures
text: I have decided that the easiest way to share family stories and pictures was to set up another blog. Â This is not a genealogy blog. Â I tried that, but with such a large family and with the mountain of information I have collected over the years, that one soon became cumbersome. Â This new blog is simply to share family stories and writings as well as photos. Â I am starting with the Paul family for I have lots of writings by my grandfather and his brother, Walter. Â Later on I plan to get into the other branches of my family.The name of the new blog is "Remember When." Â When setting up this blog I found that every genealogy or family related name had been taken. Â So I finally gave up and used an address that I knew would be available. Â It is:vickimatheny.blogspot.comI have hard copies of all the stories I am posting for this branch of my family and will do the same for the other branches, for we can not count on the Internet to always be here for us. Â But until then, it is my hope that my children and grands will take this opportunity to acquaint themselves with those who went before, for they had a hand in making us who we are today.Â It is important to remember.

title: Sisters
text: Yesterday I spent a lovely afternoon with my sister.She and her husband came to see me. Â We don't often get to spend time with each other, so this was particularly fun for me.My sister and her family have lived for years on the family farm, which is a hog raising operation, in the southern part of the state. Â My brother-in-law took over the farm from his father and has now passed it on to his son. Â I like that the farm has stayed in the family all these years, rather than being sold to a corporation as so many here have.They brought presents. Â There was a box filled with pork from their farm - ham and sausage and bacon and a roast and chops. Â I thawed a package of sausage links and shared them with Duane for breakfast this morning. Â He said that was the best tasting sausage he had ever eaten. Â He was right.And there were tomatoes fresh from my sister's garden. Â I sliced one for breakfast and have been nibbling on the cherry tomatoes all day. Â Delicious.We got each other caught up on what our kids and grands had been doing and we talked of the past. Â Some memories were shared by both of us and others were new to one or the other of us. Â We talked of our parents and aunts and uncles, all gone now. Â They and their stories live only in our memories, which, we decided, weren't all that great any more. Â We need to write the stories down, but it is doubtful they would be of any interest to the younger generation.I knew they needed to get back home, but I was sorry to see them leave. Â It was a truly nice afternoon.I am adding some pictures here. Â My sister says she reads this blog, so she should see these and hopefully remember. Â She is five years younger than me and is the cute blondie in the photos.I think this is my favorite picture of me and my sister.There were few hills where we lived, so Sister got her snow sled rides by big sister power.Mother sewed our clothes. Â These were Easter dresses. Â Mother would have preferred we look like this all the time, but to her chagrin, there were bicycles to ride and mud puddles to splash in and trees to climb.At Grandma Paul's house with Aunt Margaret's Cocker Spaniel puppies.This is my favorite photo of my sister.It is a good thing - spending time with one's sister.

title: A Heartfelt Thank You
text: This moving business is not easy for me. Â I don't do change very well any more. Â It is hard to think about leaving my home of well over 20 years. Â The home where I lived with my husband until his death several years ago. Â The home that is jam-packed with memories.I am slowly getting used to the idea. Â The notion of living where I might be a bit more mobile is a definite plus. Â A place where I can go outside without having to use the dreaded stairs. Â A place, perhaps, where I can see green grass and trees rather than concrete and asphalt. The wheels are turning. Â Oldest daughter is checking out home care options to deal with my physical limitations. Â And looking into light housekeeping services. Â Youngest son is in charge of finding a suitable place for me to live. Â He has suggested that perhaps I might enjoy living close to his family (45 miles away from my present location) so that I could spent time with my three youngest grands. Â That would be delightful.I am doing my part. Â The canning and dehydrating, aside from the food still in my freezer, has been put on hold. Â I am beginning to sort and toss - some for charity shop donations, some that my kids might find useful and some for the dumpster. All of this will take time, but there is no great rush.I write about many things here on this silly little blog. Â Sometimes I debate with myself whether or not I should post about my difficulties or less than upbeat topics. Â But what it boils down to is that this is life. Â And life is not always unicorns and sunshine. Â There are storm clouds now and then. Â So I write about them, too.What really amazes me is that there are folks out there who stop by and visit and leave comments who are caring enough to offer suggestions when I find myself in a place that is less than ideal. Â Many times those suggestions have helped me deal with one thing or another. Â I want you all to know just how much I value the friendship of each and every one of you, for even though we have never met, I still consider you as friends. Â Thank you for continuing to stop by, even when the unicorns are not here. Â I am truly humbled.

title: There comes a time...
text: when a person has to stop pretending that all is well and face the harsh realities of life. Â That time has arrived for me.I finally had to admit that I need help. Â Simple day to day housekeeping chores have become overwhelming. Â What should take an hour of my time now takes the better part of a day. Â I can still cook my meals and wash my dishes and do my laundry. Â I can take care of my personal hygiene and can dress myself without help. Â It is the rest of it that has become a bugger.So yesterday I talked to all four of my kids about the problems I am facing. Â They mostly agree that I need to move into an apartment that is more suited to my needs. Â My apartment is too small to be able to use the walker. Â There just isn't room. Â I need additional help in dealing with the cellulitis in my legs. Â I need additional help in maintaining the cleanliness of my living space that the arthritis has made difficult. Â And I need to live somewhere that doesn't have stairs as the only means of getting to and from my apartment.So my kids are researching the possibilities. Â There are several options. Â The only option I refuse to consider is a nursing home. Â I need my personal space. Â I am somewhat ornery. Â I do not play well with others. Â Should some fresh faced little nurse's aide tell me it is time to eat, time to sleep or time to go to the community room for a sing-long or for arts and crafts, I am apt to throw something at her, even though she would just be doing her job. Â Aside from my family and those blogging friends I have made, I mostly want to be left alone. Â Living somewhere that has a schedule that must be kept and that expects participation in activities that hold no interest for me is my idea of what Hell would look like.I kind of feel sorry for my kids. Â They have their work cut out for them in finding ways to do what needs to be done and still stay within my budget. Â But they are smart. Â They are good at finding solutions to problems. Â And even though I have made good on my promise to live long enough to be a problem to them, they still love me and are more than willing to help me through a time that is not much fun.I am not telling you about this life changing time because I desire sympathy. Â I do not. Â I still enjoy life as much and sometimes more than most. Â But I know there are some who might read this that are facing a similar change. Â I put it off longer than I should have. Â I am a stubborn person. Â And because my stubbornness got in the way of common sense, this isn't as easy as it could be. Â There is no shame in admitting you need help, especially in the later years. Â I still do as much as possible for myself, but it has gotten to the point where it just isn't enough. Â And if this helps even one person, then it has accomplished what I hope it would.And even with complications, life is still grand. Â :)

title: Hurricane Harvey...
text: has made landfall in Texas with high winds and rain being measured by the foot rather than by the inch. Â All reports indicate it will continue to wreak havoc for several days. Â If you are of a mind to do so, please join me in prayer for the safety of those folks in the path of this monster storm.

title: Weird Weather
text: I suppose there have been times when the month of August has been cool, but I don't remember any. Â In a normal year August is hot and sunny. Â Today at noon, even with the sunshine, the temperature was only 68 degrees with promise of the 50's for tonight.Those who delight in days spent lakeside basking in the heat are not happy. Â Gardeners are bemoaning the fact that their tomatoes are very slow to ripen this summer as are other vegetables. Â  There is talk of an early fall and a long, cold winter.But I don't care. Â It is now cool enough for me to drag out my green fuzzy blanket at nap time.It takes very little to make me happy. Â :)

title: Frozen Treasure Hunt
text: Cleaning out my chest freezer is proving to be interesting. Â I have found all sorts of things I had forgotten were there.I knew about the gallon bags of cranberries. Â I have been putting off dealing with them, I suppose, because I knew the work involved. Â But I finally dragged them all out and thawed them. Â I intended to make juice to can, but the recipe I use calls for much lifting of heavy pots and straining of berries and time standing on my feet stirring. Â My physical limitations put the brakes on that idea. Â So I just filled jars with the thawed berries. Â I used plain water instead of the usual sugar syrup. Â By canning them in water I can use the cranberries multiple ways - for cranberry sauce, in muffins or cranberry bread, or I can make juice, a couple of jars at a time. Â I wound up with 20 pints and 20 quarts of whole cranberries.I found seven one-pound packages of yeast. Â Those I stacked in my closet pantry.I also found a bunch of those small snack sized Ziploc bags full of chopped onions. Â I thawed them out, cooked them until they were translucent, packed them in half pint jars and pressure canned them for 45 minutes. Â I got 7 jars of onions. Â I usually use my dehydrated onions for cooking, but these canned ones are handy for when I need onions for dishes like hamburgers or meatloaf. The next projects are a stack of quart freezer bags full of pumpkin puree to be dehydrated and a layer of quart bags full of sliced apples to be turned into applesauce. Â Those are going to wait a few days until the latest arthritis flareup subsides. Â Until then, it is quiet time for this chubby granny.I can hardly wait to see what treasures lay underneath the apples. Â :)

title: Just Because I Can
text: My youngest son, David, stopped using Facebook a while back. Â He said he was tired of posts from a few friends and relatives that were dedicated to Trump bashing. Â I understand why he just eliminated that hassle from his life. Â But David was really good to post pictures of his family. Â I missed that. Â So when he and his family stopped in the other day, I whined. Â I asked him if he wouldn't reconsider just enough to post some pictures for me. Â He did.This is Boston on her way to dance auditions to see which team she will be on this year at the dance studio where she is in competition dancing.This is Maddie Mae just being Maddie Mae.This is Jacob at the end of the summer baseball season, with his other grandparents. Â I'm so glad they can go to his games to cheer him on.And this is Oreo with her favorite squeaky toy. Â She is just so stinkin' cute!David's sister Jill posted this photo of my grandson Zach at Aviation Camp in July.I love it when my kids post pictures. Â It helps me stay connected to family and that's important. Â So thank you David, for indulging your mother and going back on FB long enough to give me more pictures. Â And thank you Jill, for all the pictures of Zach.Love, Mom

title: Flying South
text: It is a lovely day here in southeastern Minnesota. Â Temps are in the high 70's. Â The sun is shining. Â I have windows open to let in the soft, summer breeze.We have a large number of Canadian geese here. Â They fly south usually in late September and October and return in the spring. Â But today I have heard the unmistakable honking of several fairly large flocks of them, all heading south. I wonder if they know something we don't!

title: It has been quiet here...
text: in my little corner of the world. I guess the nut jobs were congregated in Charlottesville, busy with beating each other to a pulp and doing their best to run over as many as possible with a car.
