Â Didn't seem to slow Chicago down much, what with 5 dead and 22 injured in shootings over the weekend. But in my world, laundry was caught up, floors were mopped and scalloped potatoes and ham were consumed.The politicians are trying every way possible to blame each other for the grievance of the day. Â I don't pay attention to them any more. Â World leaders are rattling sabers and making not so veiled threats to one another. But in my world, brownies were baked and grandchildren were properly hugged and the words, "I love you, Grandma" were heard.The headlines still scream gloom and doom. Â Nearly every crime and perversion is touted in bold type. Â And nothing changes.But in my world, raspberry pancakes from a mix given me by my grands (along with a jug of real maple syrup) made a memorable breakfast this morning. Often I find myself wishing I had exciting things to write about like so many other bloggers do. Â And then I take a look at the world around me and quickly decide that I am perfectly content with my life here at my little apartment. Â Nobody tries to shoot me. Â Nobody tries to run over me. Â I get to see my youngest son and his family when they stop in after a day at the local arboretum. Â I get to spend time with my oldest son at least twice a week. Â My daughters are close by as are the rest of my grands.I get to do what I want when I want, which usually includes a damn good cup of coffee and a mystery book. Â Or time spent doing things that make me happy like sewing or crocheting. Â Or canning and dehydrating.I will take this less than exciting life any day of the week. Â :)

title: Fabric Fondling and Other Pursuits
text: 'Hello. Â My name is Vicki and I am addicted to fondling fabrics.'I wonder if there is a 12 step program for that. Â :)I have spent the last few days pinning and sewing and marking and cutting fabric. Â One quilt top is nearly finished and two more are in the works. Â Photos will be posted when I have finished them. Â I hope to spend time working on them over the upcoming weekend.But until then, it is time to get on with the food storage thing. Â I don't think I should put it off any longer, considering that the North Korean lunatic is threatening to nuke us either at our military bases in Guam or here at home. Â Might never happen, but with a loose cannon like that, you just don't know.At any rate, there are 24 lbs. of butter melting on the stove in preparation for canning. Â There are about a gallon and a half of Great Northern beans (the ones the bugs didn't find) to can and two gallons of cranberries thawing to can whole.So I am off to spend some quality time in my kitchen. Â If you don't hear from me in a couple of days, send in the Rescue Squad. Â I will be the chubby granny buried under a stack of canning jars. Â :)

title: The Other Day...
text: my phone rang. Â It was my brother. Â He was about two minutes away from my apartment. Â I urged him to hurry.We had had a phone conversation a week or so earlier. Â He wanted to know about my physical condition. Â I assured him that I was doing alright, considering. Â That wasn't good enough. Â He had to come and see for himself that his big sister was OK.We have a long history of little brother looking out for his sister. Â Kelly is 15 years younger than me. Â When he was about four years old, he spent quite a bit of time with me and my young son. Â At that time we lived in a rented house. Â The landlord was an grumpy old man who liked to yell at people. Â That landlord had yelled at me for something long since forgotten, but he did it Â when Kelly was with me. Â The next day my mother discovered Kelly with pockets full of rocks. Â When questioned about the rocks, he said they were to throw at the mean old man who yelled at his sister.Once Kelly had seen for himself that I was getting along just fine, we sat at the kitchen table, drank coffee and strolled down Memory Lane. Â And we talked of his kids, my kids and all the grands. Â It was a lovely way to spend an afternoon.Kelly Â wanted to know if there was anything that several thousand dollars would fix as far as my physical condition is concerned. Â I told him no. Â I told him that the best I can hope for is maintaining. Â He remarked that I seemed so happy. Â I am. Â I have made peace with the facts of my situation. Â Mostly I am just content.We don't get to do this very often. Â Kelly lives at least a 4 hour drive north of me and his job takes him further afield for months at a time. Â When he was getting ready to leave, he expressed regret that we couldn't do this more often. Â I told him that he knows how much I love him and I know how much he loves me. Â And that is enough.

title: Apparently...
text: plants growing in pots on windowsills have a shelf life. Â All were doing well. Â They were starting to put out blossoms. Â And then.....they keeled over and died.I noticed all was not well when I saw that the blossoms would start to open and then they just withered and fell to the floor. Â And the leaves began to curl up and fall off. Â And those plants standing tall sort of leaned over and gave up.But I had fun trying to grow veggies in my window sills so it wasn't a total loss.Oh...and my harvest? Â One bean. Â It was delicious.So now I am cleaning out the pots and putting them away until spring. Â It gets too cold in the window sills in winter for plants to survive. Â Come April or May I will plant things that do not need blossoms to produce food, like lettuce and spinach and beets and maybe celery.I have one pot of bell peppers that is still healthy. Â I will continue to care for that one just for the fun of it. Â Like I have said before, it takes very little to keep me entertained.

title: Cowboy
text: Sometimes of an evening when the work day is done and when the foot traffic between the several bars in my neighborhood is at its peak, filled with Happy Hour revelers, I will pour a mug of coffee, pull up a chair and watch the comings and goings on my street. Â It is a great time for people watching.This particular evening found me watching the groups of ladies, having been released from their office cubicles, strolling down the street in a cloud of perfume and giggles.Along came the office girl's counterparts, having ditched the suit coats but retaining white shirts and ties, trying to impress each other with the deals they had put together at work that day.The construction workers, retail sales people and fast food workers came in, all in good moods, happy to be released from whatever jobs they held. Â Many had husbands / wives / boyfriends / girlfriends in tow, all determined to create a memorable 'partay.'Half a dozen Harleys lined up at the curb across the street. Â Their riders were all decked out in leather and dew rags. Â They looked tough. Â They looked mean. Â And because I recognized a couple of them, I knew they would go back to their jobs at the local grocery or accounting firm in the morning.And then I saw him. Â Strolling down the alley across the street, headed for the bar next door. Â He wore starched Levis, a plaid western style shirt and what looked like brand spanking new cowboy boots. Â I'm not sure he was quite used to walking in boots with heels, for he sort of listed a bit to the left every now and then.But the hat. Â That magnificent white cowboy hat. Â The hat that had been worked and manipulated to create just the right effect. Â The hat that sat at a rakish angle on his head. Â The hat that was bigger than the one worn by Hoss Cartwright in 'Bonanza.'Keep in mind that there are no working ranches within several hundred miles in any direction. Â This is farm country with Holstein milk cows and fields of corn and soybeans. Â We have horses, but they are either used as kiddie rides at the apple orchards locally or they are the subject of bets placed at the track on the other side of town. And yet, there he was Â Doing his best impression of a cowboy. Â And all I could think of was...All hat - no cattle.

title: Vacation
text: Just because I am retired doesn't mean that I don't need a vacation now and then. Â I seem to have hit a brick wall when it comes to writing. Â So I am taking time away from the computer to relax and refresh. Â I am not going anywhere, but daydreams put me on a sunny beach with a fruity, paper umbrella enhanced drink in one hand and a good mystery novel in the other. Â I truly appreciate those of you who stop by this silly little blog. Â I will be back in a week or two.

title: Dog Days of Summer
text: "The dog days or dog days of summer are the hot, sultry days of summer. They were historically the period following the heliacal rising of the star Sirius, which Greek and Roman astrology connected with heat, drought, sudden thunderstorms, lethargy, fever, mad dogs, and bad luck. They are now taken to be the hottest, most uncomfortable part of summer in the Northern Hemisphere." - WikipediaThat seems to describe the mood here in my little Home Sweet Apartment. Â Except that our weather hasn't been all that hot, with temps in the 80's during daylight hours and the humidity at mid-range. Â Of all the descriptive words used above, I think that 'lethargy' best describes it. Â My 'get-up-and-go' seems to have 'got-up-and-went.'I have been doing just enough of the housekeeping chores to keep my apartment from reaching pig-sty status. Â Otherwise it has been naps and reading and naps and entering data into my genealogy program and naps. Â I think this might just continue over the weekend and with any kind of luck I may acquire some energy by Monday. Â I have several projects waiting for me to wake up enough to do them. Â Until that happens, those folks listed in the sidebar are leading lives much more exciting than mine at the moment. Â Go visit them and enjoy.

title: Some mornings...
text: are better than others. Â This morning is one of those.Beautiful sunrise.Cool enough yet to have my windows open.Birds singing their little hearts out in the tree outside my window.Slight breeze bringing fresh air into my apartment.Rain shower helping to keep the heat at bay, at least for now.Good cup or two of coffee.Bacon and eggs for breakfast.The rest of the day is a crap shoot what with storms and heat predicted, but for now it is a good morning just to be alive.

title: Responsibility
text: There are several YouTube channels I like to watch on a regular basis. Â Some are about artsy craftsy stuff. Â Others are about quilting. Â And some fall into the category of homesteading. Â They include everything from gardening to raising small livestock to food preservation to frugal living and a self-sustaining lifestyle.One of my favorites is called 'Deep South Homestead' Â and is done by a couple living in southern Mississippi. Â I have learned much from watching their videos. Â At present they are doing a series about financial freedom. Â Unlike many videos with similar topics, they do not give tips on money management, but rather show how experiences from childhood and beyond can influence the way an adult manages their finances to be debt free.As I watched their video this morning, it got me to thinking about how the way I was raised was similar in many ways to the things they spoke of and how different things were then from the way they are today.As a child, the rule was that nobody played until the work was done. Â That meant that at suppertime, the table was properly set and the family sat down together for the meal. Â After supper the dishes were cleared, washed, dried and put away. Â Only then were we free to relax and pursue whatever was of interest to us.I was 15 yearsÂ old before our family had a television. Â Before that, we listened to the serial programs on the radio like Dragnet or Abbot and Costello or Amos 'n Andy. Â Sometimes we could get musical shows, mostly country or western, my Dad's favorites. Â Whether it was radio or television, mother believed it was a sin to just sit and watch or listen, so I always was doing something at those times. Â Maybe it was knitting a scarf or hemming a skirt or embroidering a dish towel, but my hands were never idle. Â I have continued along those lines to this day.If a person kept animals of any kind, their needs came first. Â No matter if it was raining or if there was a blizzard raging, the animals had to be fed, watered and their living areas had to be kept clean. Â Only when these tasks were accomplished could a person even think about their own needs.Gardens were more than just a hobby. Â The produce grown was essential to keeping the family fed over the winter months and until the garden of the following year began producing. Â Early mornings would find us weeding. Â That was also the time of day when vegetables were picked, cleaned and made ready for either freezing or canning. Â When the vegetables were in the freezer or in jars cooling on the counter, then and only then were we free to do what we wanted to do.Saturday mornings were not for watching cartoons, but were for cleaning the houseÂ 'just in case we get company.' Â Wooden and tile floors were scrubbed, rugs were vacuumed, bed linens were changed, furniture was dusted and bathrooms were made to sparkle. Â After that there were cakes or cookies to bake to make sure there were treats to go with coffee should any neighbor or relative drop by.Another thing we were taught that I find sadly lacking today were manners. Â It didn't matter whether or not we liked an adult, they were treated with respect. Â 'Yes, Ma'am' and 'No, Sir' was the correct way to respond. Â We never, ever called an adult by their first names. Â It was always Miss, Mrs. or Mr. Â I suppose it might have been easier then because we were clear about gender rolls. Â The only time first names were acceptable were when addressing Aunt Emily or Uncle Oscar.I think the whole thing boils down to being taught responsibility. Â Making sure the garden was well kept insured that we would eat over the winter. Â Working before playing instilled in us a work ethic that would last a lifetime. Â And good manners combined with respect for others is what separated us from the savages. Â All of these things, even those learned as children, went a long way to attaining responsibility in all areas, including financial.

title: I Am Tired...
text: I am tired of hearing about the Russians.I am tired of listening to celebrities telling me how they think I should live while they are paid millions to pretend to be somebody else.I am tired of all the reports of people being beaten to a bloody pulp for the crime of wearing a Trump cap.I am tired of Congress spending so much time trying to get rid of Trump and so little time on doing what we elected them to do.I am just plain tired of Black Lives Matter for dozens of reasons.I am particularly tired of California Representative Maxine Waters and her ilk screaming impeachment at every turn.And I am tired of news articles like the one that set me off on this rant today. Â It seems that two black ministers are suing Coca Cola because they believe too many persons of color drink too many sodas that cause them to become obese. Â It's because Coca Cola advertises their products, don't you see.Let that sink in.Seems to me that if you drink sodas and you are fat, one thing you could do is, oh I don't know, maybe stop drinking sodas? Â Of course, that would require some personal responsibility. Â Can't have that. Â Being personally responsible means that you have to work on the problem yourself and stop blaming others for your actions. I can't do anything about any of the above. Â People are going to be mean and hateful no matter what I say. Â And so far, I have found no way to fix Stupid. Â I can't just stop checking the news reports because I think it is important to keep an eye on what is going on in the world. Â That is part of the preparedness thing.But I can spend far less time on the headlines and much more time doing what makes me and mine happy. Â Sounds like a plan to me.Kicking that well used soapbox back into the corner now.

title: Beat the Heat
text: I know that our temperatures here in Minnesota can't come close to those in the states west of us, but nonetheless, it is hot. Â And muggy. Â Staying indoors in my air conditioned apartment is the best possible option. Â I don't do well with hot and muggy.I have 10 lbs. of potatoes waiting to be dehydrated and beans ready to be canned up into pork and beans, but I believe they can just wait a while longer. Â  The central air in my building works fine as long as I keep the windows closed and don't run the dehydrators or the stove too much. Â I am glad that I canned several varieties of soup earlier. Â Lunches this week will be soup from a jar that I can microwave and maybe a sandwich. Â The crockpot will be getting a workout this week as it throws off very little heat. Â I thawed out some chicken legs and will add some broth, a jar of diced potatoes and carrots, some dehydrated onion and let it cook all day. Â Dumplings added Â about a half hour before suppertime will make a good meal.My scrawny bean plants have a few more blossoms on them and so does the cantaloupe. Â Looks like I should have blossoms opening up on the zucchini in a week or two. Â So far I haven't killed off any of the plants in my little windowsill garden. Â I thought for sure I would have murdered at least some of them by now.Aside from a few minor housekeeping chores, I think it will be quiet here in my little corner of the world. Â I have sewing projects and books to read and I need to make some entries in my genealogy program. Â Lots to do without having to deal with the heat and humidity.Life is good.

title: Never Too Old To Learn
text: So two or three months ago I bought half a dozen one pound bags of Great Northern beans. Â Thought about taking them out of the original packaging, but got busy and just tossed them into an empty box in my pantry closet. Â Well, that's not quite true. Â There may have been some laziness involved. My grocery order this week included five bags of the dry beans. Â I brought the box of beans from my pantry out to the kitchen table with the intent of repackaging part of them and using some of the older ones to can up as pork and beans.To my horror I found the original six bags crawling with little black bugs. Â And so was the box they were in. Â I double wrapped the whole shebang in trash bags, sealing the tops with tape. Â Now they can live in the dumpster and not in my pantry.So I learned that dry beans should be removed from the original plastic bags to be repackaged, the same as I do with anything I want to store that comes in cardboard packaging. Â I know that bugs like to hide in cardboard. Â I didn't know they also like plastic bags full of dry beans.I opened the five bags I just bought, sorted them to remove any bad beans, put them into freezer bags and stacked them in the freezer where they will stay for a few days, just to make sure nothing is crawling around in them.We are never too old to learn. Â I am glad all that lesson cost me was a few bags of beans.

title: An Artist in the Family
text: Artistic talent has shown up from time to time in my Mother's side of the family. Â My Aunt Margaret painted beautiful portraits. Â I have no examples of her paintings, but I do have this pencil sketch she did of me when I was young.Uncle Duane painted landscapes. Â Here is an example of his work.Sadly, the artistic gene bypassed me. Â My attempts at drawing or painting looked like something done by a toddler. Â Sigh.So I was delighted when I learned of my granddaughter Maddie's interest in painting. Â She sent me a card thanking me for the birthday money I had sent her and telling me she would use the gift to purchase art supplies. Â I asked her Dad to take some pictures of her paintings for me.I would like them even if I weren't her Grandma. Â Her Dad tells me that she loves to paint. Â I hope she continues.Oh, and Maddie May - I'm pretty sure I could find a frame and a blank wall. Â Just sayin'.

title: I Have Four...
text: count them - four actual, for real snap beans growing on my three leggy, raggedy looking snap bean plants in the window sill. Â And I'm not for sure certain, but it looks like the cucumber and zucchini plants might be thinking about setting some blossoms. Â  What I think may be blossoms are tiny, so it will be a while before I know for sure. Â Hope springs eternal. Â :)That's about all the excitement this old heart can stand. title: Independence Day

title: Look!  Green Growing Plants!

title: What Do You Do...
text: when life smacks you upside the head to get your attention and then proceeds to add some difficulties to your life. Â When you get to be my age, those difficulties are mostly medical.Those who are regular readers know of my physical limitations because I whine about them periodically. Â Those new visitors, take heart. Â I promise to keep the whining about fun stuff like arthritis and cellulitis to a minimum.To my way of thinking, there are two things a person can do.The first is to crawl into bed, pull the covers up to your ears and just wait to die.The second, and my personal choice, is to just to get on with it. Â Make peace with the fact that life has changed and there is bloody little a person can do about that. Â So after you get through the initial anger and frustration and periods of weepy self pity, find ways to adapt to the situation.Everyone has different situations to deal with. Â Many are much worse than mine. Â I still have a mind that works - well, sort of. Â I can still walk - sort of. Â I can still take care of myself as far as personal hygiene, cooking, keeping my apartment clean enough to stay the health department, etc. Â But each task needed to be thought out as to how to do it in my present condition.The hardest part for me was knowing that I was not the Wonder Woman of the past who could work hard from dawn to dark and beyond. Â That fact pretty much shredded my ego. Â I have never been one to cry for help unless it was obvious that the task at hand could not be accomplished alone. Â So having to call on my kids to do for me was not high on my list of things I enjoyed. Â But, after swallowing some of my pride, I did it. Â Thankfully I have grown children who are more than willing to help out when needed. Adapting to current limitations has been a challenge. Â I know that I can not stand or walk for more than 10 minutes at a time before the arthritic pain becomes overwhelming. Â So I have learned to do the chores either in ten minute increments or do what I can while seated at my kitchen table. Â Youngest Son and his family gave me a walker for Mother's Day so I can now leave my apartment and enjoy the outdoors. Â Admitting to myself that I needed a walker was tough. Â I have learned that if I do too much one day, I will spend the next day quietly recovering. Â Sometimes it is worth it - sometimes not.I believe the most important thing about dealing with limitations is attitude. Â I suppose I could sit around in a puddle of self pity, but I won't. Â I haven't the time nor do I have the patience for it. Â I think that concentrating on what I can do rather than what I can't makes all the difference. The point of this post is not to dwell on my physical problems, but to encourage anyone out there who is facing life-changing obstacles. Â If just one person who reads this is able to realize that life, even with limitations, can be good, then this was worth posting. Â Just do the best you can with what you have to work with.Oh yeah...keep your sense of humor. Â Laughter is the very best medicine. Â Really - it is.

title: More Canning and Dehydrating
text: It is one of those busy days. Â I dehydrated three good sized heads of cabbage, filling the dehydrators last evening. Â I got about three quarts of dried cabbage, all bagged up and ready to use in soups, etc.This morning I am browning 12 lbs. of hamburger to jar up and can. Â I had seen a video about packing raw hamburger into the jars without browning it first, so last time I canned hamburger, I tried that method. Â It turned out just fine, but I find I like the texture of the precooked meat better. Â It is just a personal preference.There are 6 bananas sitting in the fruit bowl on my kitchen table that need to be turned into a couple of loaves of banana bread, so as soon as the pressure canner full of meat is going, banana bread making will commence. Â I will share a loaf with Oldest Son. Â He loves banana bread as much as I do. Â He reads my blog, so I am guessing he will show up tonight after work to collect his loaf without my having to call him.And that's the extent of the excitement here in my little Home Sweet Apartment. Â When the chores are done, some sewing will happen. Â And quite possibly, a nap.There was a time when I would tease my Dad about his afternoon naps, but the older I get the more I realize, the man was on to something. Â :)

title: Stretching a Meal
text: When I was a kid, it was not unusual for friends or relatives to show up at our house on a Saturday or Sunday afternoon. Â TV was a rare commodity then. Â My family didn't have one until I was 15 years old. Â Personal computers and cell phones were somewhere in the future. Â People went visiting. Â They sat on front porches and talked about the weather and the condition of the crops and wasn't that daughter of Aunt Ruby's acting just disgraceful with that boyfriend of hers. Â And when the sun was getting low in the western sky and the visitors showed no signs of leaving, they were invited to stay for supper. Â And most times, they accepted.My mother was one of those women who planned. Â She knew that on Monday she would wash clothes and on Tuesday I would iron them. Â She planned nothing for Saturday morning except setting her daughters to cleaning the house. Â If you have ever experienced scrubbing out the corners of a set of stairs with a toothbrush, then you know the extent of my mother's planning. Â And she knew exactly what each meal would be for a week.Mother didn't take it well when her plans were disrupted. Â So it was always a wonder to me how she coped with guests for the supper she had planned for four people. Â She took it in stride and never batted an eye. Â Thinking back, I realized how she did it.If she had a roast beef or a chicken in the oven, she sent one of us kids down to the basement, which doubled as our cold storage area, to bring up more potatoes to be boiled and a handful of fresh carrots to be cleaned and cut into carrot sticks. Â She had us get a quart jar of dill pickles and a pint jar of relish. Â And added to that were a couple of jars of home canned peaches for dessert. Â A plate of homemade baking powder biscuits rounded out the meal, now with enough food for company.I remember once having supper guests when Mother had made a pot of chili that was enough to feed just our family. Â Mother calmly cooked up a pot of rice and made a double batch of cornbread. Â She added a plate of sliced cheese and another of raw carrots, radishes and sliced cucumbers from the garden. Â She filled bowls half full of rice and topped that off with chili. Â Dessert was sliced strawberries from the garden, with cream and sugar .The point is.....Mother was prepared. Â She was a girl growing up during the Great Depression. Â After that came the WWII food rationing. Â Her mother taught her how to stretch a meal. Â Although my Grandfather was one of the fortunate ones to be employed during the Depression, he still had seven children to feed. Â That was not always an easy task. Â My grandparents grew a garden. Â They canned as much food as they could. Â My father grew up in a similar environment with the added benefit of living on a farm where they could have meat and milk animals to feed his family of nine children. Â Both my parents carried on the tradition of preserving as much food as they could in the summer and fall. Â They passed on that lifestyle to me. Â One of the best things they taught me was how to stretch a meal.I don't always have fresh food on hand. Â I can't raise a garden. Â But I can go to my shelves and pantry and get the fixings for any number of meals. Â And like Mother, I keep on hand ingredients to be able to stretch a meal when needed. Â Just makes sense.

title: The Plants in My Windowsills
text: They are growing. Â By some miracle I have managed to keep them alive - so far.The cantaloupe, zucchini and cucumbers are flourishing. Â They have beautiful green leaves and are beginning to spread out.I have two pots of cherry tomatoes grown from saved seeds. Â They are slow to grow, but are beginning to leaf out. Â I thinned them down to about six plants per pot.The bell peppers finally popped through the soil and have grown a couple of inches.The green peas are maybe 6 - 8 inches tall and have fallen over, but they are still alive and growing.And last but not least, the yellow snap beans are setting on blossoms. Â Amazing! Â If they form actual beans, there may be enough for a meal. If the plants are still alive in a week or so, I will take some pictures to post. Â I was kind of busy today, what with my grocery delivery and getting 12 lbs. of hamburger ready to can tomorrow. The plants in my little windowsill garden must be tough. Â They have to be to still live in spite of my abysmal track record with indoor plants. Â Even if I get nothing off them, it is still fun watching them grow. Â :)

title: It is turning into...
text: a really nice week. Â Temperatures here are in the mid to high 70's and the humidity isn't too bad. Â It is nice to be able to turn off the air conditioning and open the windows. Â We had some rain and some sunshine and a lovely breeze.I canned up the rest of the chicken thighs and got five pints. Â There was enough broth to fill five quart jars. Â I have ordered 12 lbs. of hamburger to can. Â That will be delivered tomorrow. Â Hamburger is the only meat I am low on, although I probably could use some more bacon bits. Â The price of bacon has gone through the Â roof here, so I will have to see if Duane can find some bacon ends and pieces at a reasonable price. Â I was thinking about canning some bacon slices but not at the current price of $6.99 Â a pound.My daughter Jill and grandson Zach stopped over yesterday evening. Â Zach was all excited. Â He will be spending a week at Airplane Camp. Â I asked if the camp was just for instruction or if there would be actual flying involved. Â He said, with a grin, that they would be flying. Â Zach has taken flying lessons since he was maybe 12 years old. Â He needed to sit on a pillow to be able to see out the window of the plane. Â That's no longer a problem for that over 6 ft. tall 17 year old grandson of mine. Â I told him that when he gets his pilot's license, he needed to remember that his Grandma loves to fly. Â I'm not overjoyed with commercial flights, but I dearly love a ride in a small plane. Â He said he would keep it in mind.David stopped in a couple of days ago. Â Both of his daughters have birthdays in June and he said he would pick up the cards I had for them so I wouldn't need to mail them. Â I think he was actually checking up on me. Â He knew I hadn't been feeling well and he knows I hate going to the Â doctor, so he sometimes checks to make sure I don't need make an appointment. Â I just can't get away with anything! Â He left yesterday for a conference in Canada, having to do with his job at a landscaping company. Â He said he was torn...he was looking forward to the conference but he knew he would miss his family while he had to be gone.Nothing earth shattering or exciting going on here in my little corner of the world. Â I'm just puttering about with the necessary Susie Homemaker stuff. Â And in between times the sewing machine is being put to good use. Â That's pretty much the story of my life and I like it that way. Â :)

title: Quilts and Chicken
text: I watched Boston dance at the National competition via live stream. Â She did very well as did her whole studio group. Â Even though the picture quality on the live stream isn't the best, I can still pick her out of a crowd and follow her dance steps. Â Loved every second of it.I did some sewing in between Boston' dances. Â I finished sewing the pieces together to make these blocks.Now I just need to sew the blocks together and then add the batting and backing before quilting. Â So many now use quilting machines or even use their sewing machines to do the final quilting, but I am old fashioned, I guess. Â I like the look of hand quilting, even though it takes longer to finish.I don't do fancy art quilts like so many who enter their quilts in quilt shows. Â Mine are strictly utility quilts that are made for warmth on beds - not to be hung on a wall and admired. Â I love to look at all those fancy quilts, but I make mine from leftover fabric or from fabric that is on sale at my local fabric store.This is the quilt I will finish only if I live another 10 years. Â It is called "Grandmother's Flower Garden." Â Each hexagon is sewn by hand - no sewing machine work here.Please excuse the untidy look of it. Â It gets wrinkled while working on it. Â All of the flower blocks are done and I am in the process of sewing them together. Â I work on it sometimes in the evening while watching something I like on my computer. Â Maybe a movie or some other program like Antiques Roadshow. Â It takes lots of tiny stitches to sew the pieces together and is time consuming. Â But I really like this old fashioned pattern, so I keep plugging away at it.Lori was going shopping on Saturday and asked if I needed anything. Â Our local big box grocery had chicken legs and thighs in the family-sized packs on sale at a good price, so I asked her to get me three packages of each. Â In between Boston's dance numbers I filled 13 quart jars with whole legs and thighs. Â I use the wide mouth jars Â for ease in removing the meat when I go to use it. Â That took care of all the wide mouth quart jars I had. Â That left me with two package of thighs. Â Those are simmering on the stove and when they are done I will take the meat from the bones and can it in pint jars. Â There should be some nice chicken broth to can as well. I hadn't planned to do any canning over the weekend, but when the opportunity presents itself, it seems like a person should take advantage of it. Â After all, that gives me another couple of weeks worth of suppers and the way things are going in the world around us, I think I will be glad to have it. Â Things are just getting way too crazy to ignore. Â We need to be prepared for anything.

title: Plans...
text: don't always work out. Â That irritating flu-like bug that visited me has moved on to greener pastures. Â But it did put a bit of a crimp in my plans for a couple of sewing days.However, optimist that I am, a new plan is in the works. Â My granddaughter, Boston, is dancing with her studio at Nationals in Wisconsin Dells. Â She has four routines with her group today. Â I'm not sure yet about tomorrow. Â But the competition is being live streamed. Â  So Grandma will be setting up the laptop where I can see it while sewing. Â Regular scheduled programing will commence on Monday. Â The coffee is brewed. Â The snacks are at hand. Â Supper is in the crockpot. Â I am all set for some serious sewing machine time and more importantly, some time well spent watching the girl do what she does so well. Â Hope you all have a weekend as happy as mine. Â :)

title: I am beginning to believe...
text: there is something nasty in the air or in the water. Â This is the third or fourth time this year that I have come down with flu-like symptoms. Â Never had that happen before.Back to bed for me. Â I will return when this round of icky has run its course.

title: Spending time...
text: sewing for a couple of days. Â Just because I can. Â I have neglected the piles of quilt pieces on my sewing table for far too long. Â Sometimes we have to let the world do what it will without us, let the day to day stuff pass by and just do what makes us happy.I will be back in a day or two - possibly with some show and tell.

title: Even Grownups Need a Play Day
text: So I had me one.I think the only things I did all day that even came close to being work were to wash up a few dishes and sweep the kitchen floor.There was a novel that needed reading and a movie that needed watching and a few quilt pieces that needed sewing. Â And there was a long and luxurious afternoon nap. Â Can't forget the nap.My phone rang several times during the day. Â Various and assorted kids and grands called to wish me a happy birthday. Â I don't do birthday celebrations any more, but leave that for the kiddos. Â And I don't need gifts - I have all I need. Â It is enough that they remember and call.I talked to my youngest grandson, Jacob, who is 9 (I think. Â I can never remember for sure.). Â  He wanted to know about the important stuff like did I have cake and ice cream. Â He thought it was just wrong that I didn't. Â I had to promise I would have cake later this week. Â And I might just do that. Â I have been hungry for an apple spice cake with caramel frosting.I got to thinking about how much things have changed in my 71 years on this earth. Â Change can be good or sometimes, not so much. Â I have many more conveniences than my parents had - microwave, air conditioning, telephone that isn't on a 9 family party line. Â If I want to look up some information on any subject I don't need to go to the library because there is Google. Â If I want to watch a movie I can find one on my computer or just insert a DVD. Â I can communicate with people all around the world with just a keystroke or two. Â I know what is going on around me almost as soon as it happens.But I think there is a trade-off. Â We don't sit on the front porch of an evening and just talk any more. Â Unless Dad has a really good job, Mom can't be home raising the kids because it takes both paychecks to afford all those conveniences. Â We live in a high stress, fast paced world rather than the slower one of years gone by. Â Lately, common sense and common decency seem to have vanished, at least in some circles. Â Vulgarity has become commonplace. Â We are expected to accept as normal behavior things that were once considered shameful and wrong. I hope the trend toward rude and crude and violent behavior is just a passing thing. Â I know there are still good people out there. Â I know many of them. Â I just have to wonder what kind of a world my grands will find when they, like me, have lived 71 years.I pray that by that time good manners and common sense will have made a comeback.

title: So Far - So Good
text: My windowsill garden is growing by leaps and bounds. Â The snap beans are about 6 inches tall, though kind of leggy. Â But they are leafing out so I guess they are OK. Â I may have to stake them up before they fall over.There are 7 green pea plants, all healthy and leafy. Â I have two pots of cherry tomatoes and I thinned them out this morning. Â When they get bigger I will thin again and save the best looking plants.The cucumbers, zucchini and cantaloupe are all about 4 inches tall and looking good.So far the bell peppers haven't sprouted. Â I will give them another week and if they don't poke through the soil by then, I will plant something else in that pot.I water my little garden every other evening and have notes posted here and there to remind me to do so. Â That schedule seems to be working well so far.Now if I can just rein in my homicidal tendencies toward houseplants, this might actually work out.I'm stoked!

title: Sunday Night Ramble
text: Had me a nice, relaxing weekend. Â Our weather has been warm, with temps hitting the 90 degree mark. Â I was happy to discover the central air conditioning for my building has been turned on. Â We Minnesotans tend to melt at anything over 85 degrees, wimps that we are. Â I have been turning off the air and opening windows at night when the temp goes down around the 60 degree mark. Â Lovely sleeping weather.Went into slug mode on Saturday. Â Just pottered about with this and that. Â Got my grocery order ready for tomorrow when the nice lady calls for it. Â She has a sense of humor and likes to chat for a bit, which makes for a pleasant break in the day. Â I really don't need to order much as my pantry is nearly full, so I'm filling in with staples like more salt, oatmeal, canned salmon, tuna, etc.Now that my shelves are sorted out and I can see at a glance what I have for home canned food, I can better tell what I need to can this summer and fall. Â Duane stopped in (I needed a tall person to get a box of dehydrated tomatoes off the top shelf.) and we went over the list for the Farmer's Market again, keeping in mind that shelf space is now at a premium. Â  His apartment is smaller than mine, but he said that he would do some rearranging to try to fit in a shelf for more canned food. Â That would help.A while back I connected on Facebook with a guy I went to school with. Â He is a Vietnam Vet and a retired cop. Â He knows more about what is going on around us than I do, so he messages me articles he finds that keep me up to speed, as much as I can be, anyway. Â He calls me now and then and we brag on our various kids and grands and talk prepping and the state of insanity we now live in. Â We talked a bit today of the latest terrorist attack in London. Â It is just a matter of time until we are in the same boat as England. Â I wish our government would care as much about keeping us safe as it does about scoring political points. Â By the time the politicians figure that out, it may be too late.In my quest for more storage space, I came up with a brilliant idea. Â Well, OK. Â Someone else thought of it and I am copying it. Â I have been dehydrating lots of vegetables for long term storage because when dried, they take up much less space than canned. Â I saw where some were grinding dehydrated vegetables into powder which reduces them even more. Â So I experimented first with dried tomatoes by running them through my blender and then through a wire mesh strainer to take out the bits that wouldn't grind down any further. Â Worked like a charm. Â I tested the powder by adding a bit of water until I had a passable tomato paste. Â More water gave me tomato sauce. Â The leftover bits I stored in a jar separate from the powder to toss into soup, stew, etc. Â I reduced the dried bell peppers I had to a powder and can add that to any number of dishes for flavor. Â I think it would be good sprinkled on a salad or in scrambled eggs, omelets, etc. Â Tomorrow I will powder some more tomatoes and some onions as well. So that was the extent of my excitement here in my little corner of the world. Â Quiet. Â Peaceful. Â No stress. Â Just the way I like it.

title: There are green things...
text: growing in pots on my windowsills. Â Amazing!I have yellow snap beans, green peas, cucumbers and cantaloupe that have poked up through the soil. Â Oh, and two lonely little cherry tomato plants.I am surprised to see the cantaloupe growing. Â Maybe three years ago I saved some seeds from a store bought melon that was exceptionally tasty. Â I haven't done anything special with the seeds - just put them in an envelope and stored them in a box on a shelf with the rest of my seeds. Â Same with the cherry tomato seeds. Â They came from the little garden David had in his back yard. Â My grands had picked a bucket of cherry tomatoes for me and I saved a few seeds. Â And they are actually growing. Â Well, two of them anyway.What possessed me to buy some garden seeds to begin with, I don't know. Â I live in an apartment. Â The communal deck on the building isn't large enough for any serious container gardening, although Duane and Lori have three tomato plants growing there. Â I guess acquiring seeds is just part of the preparedness thing.I know I am easily amused, but the fact that these plants are actually trying to grow tickles me.I wonder if I can keep from murdering them like I do with most house plants. Â I hope so.

title: Ready
text: Home canned food sorted and properly shelved - check.List of needed Farmer's Market produce completed and Oldest Son approved (He is the one who has to go get it all and huff it up the stairs.) - checkList of the amounts and sizes of canning jars needed for processing produce completed and Oldest Son approved for the same reason (He says he feels like a pack mule sometimes. Â I don't know why. Â :) - check.Dehydrator trays and liners all scrubbed and ready to use - check.Shelves in living room rearranged to make space for more food in jars - check.OK Summer. Â Bring it on.I am ready.

title: Sidetracked
text: I am afraid I am one of those who is easily sidetracked. Â I have in mind a chore I want to accomplish and before I know it, I am off doing something else. Â I call it my "Oh, look. Â Squirrel!" syndrome.I know I have been talking about canning cranberries from my freezer. Â I had really good intentions. Â But they are still in the freezer and I am busy with other things. Â Squirrel.Last summer I tried growing some herbs in pots on my windowsills. Â I don't know what happened, but I managed to kill them all. Â In frustration, I took the pots, dirt, dead plants and all, stuffed the whole shebang into a trash bag and tossed the bag into the back of my closet. Â Well yesterday I found them.I cleaned the dead foliage from the pots, stirred up the soil, watered it down and planted some seeds. Â I now have pots with peas, yellow snap beans, cucumbers, sweet green peppers, cherry tomatoes, cantaloupe and zucchini. Â I have no idea if the seeds will even grow, but I thought it would be fun to try. Â I have no expectations of harvesting anything, but at least I may end up with some greenery growing on my windowsills.So this morning I thought I would can cranberries, but squirrel. Now that the weather is warmer, I want to get out to the fabric store. Â I need fabric for the backs of several quilts and batting. Â So I was digging through the tubs that hold the quilt tops - both finished and partially finished - to see what I needed to finish them all. Â And in the process I found two bags containing partially crocheted afghans. Â I had started them to use up yarn left over from other projects, knowing I would need more yarn to finish them. Â So I took some pictures to remind myself of the colors I need. Â The fabric store carries yarn as well, so I will get some when I go to buy fabric.I love crocheted afghans. Â My grandmother had a couple of them in this same 'granny square' pattern that I remember from my childhood as being soft and warm and comfy. Â The pattern is easy to do and is something I can work on in the evenings while watching a movie.So as long as there is no canning going on today, I think I will finish my afternoon doing those piddly household chores that never seem to go away - mop the kitchen floor, vacuum, straighten up my pantry, etc. Â And I may have to find a cage for that pesky squirrel that keeps diverting my attention. Â :)

title: This and That
text: It is a lovely day here in the north country. Â Temperatures have risen enough so I could shut off the heat in my apartment and crack open a couple of windows. Â  Spent the morning getting caught up on the household stuff that the latest arthritis flare up prevented me from doing. Â Dishes are washed, laundry is folded and put away and a pan of cornbread muffins are in the oven. Duane and Lori were here this morning. Â Duane wanted to borrow my large roaster pan for a beef roast he is cooking for supper. Â He raided my shelves for a couple pints of baby carrots to go with the beef. Â I am glad when my kids raid the shelves. Â That's what all those jars of food are for. Â And he will bring me a plate of food for my supper. Â Pretty good trade, I'd say. Â :)I was reading the website for one of our local news sources when I saw this headline:'An Undocumented Future: Â Fear in The Immigrant Community.'Basically the article tells of those illegals who are worried about deportation now that we have a president who seems to believe that laws should be enforced. Â I can't really blame many of these people, especially those who have families here. Â They were told for eight years that there would be no consequences for breaking our immigration laws. Â I suspect they counted on the coronation of Hillary to continue that practice. Â Well, surprise, surprise. Â Now many are heading for CanadaÂ to avoid deportation here. Â What a mess Obama created by refusing to enforce those laws. Â And how terribly wrong he was to mess with the lives of those who believed him.So I have goofed off long enough. Â I am off to the kitchen to rid the freezer of a few more gallon bags of cranberries that, with any kind of luck, will be cranberry sauce and cranberry juice. Â I am almost afraid to see what is lurking underneath all those berries. Â :)

title: A Green Fuzzy Blanket Kind of Day
text: It is cold. Â It is breezy. Â It is wet. Â It will stay like this for the next three or four days. Â Arthritis in my joints is protesting. Â It is easy to let depression settle over us under these conditions.But I won't let it.There is a recliner and a Kindle and some music on the radio and a green fuzzy blanket, all calling my name.Right after I have a slice of chocolate cake and another cup of coffee. Take that, arthritis and depression. Â You can't begin to compete with chocolate cake and coffee. Â Nor can you compete with the jar of home canned ham and beans I'm having for supper tonight, along with a pan of cornbread. Comfort food and a murder mystery. Â And a green fuzzy blanket. Â Chases the blues away every time. Â :)
