title: More Canning
text: I need to empty my chest freezer. Â There are Farmer's Market vendors that sell beef and pork by the half or quarter. Â Duane and I have decided to order a little later this year and split the meat and the cost. Â Having done the math, I find it is cheaper to buy in bulk than it is to buy from the grocery. Â And by buying directly from the farmer, we know what we are getting. Â So far, in addition to the asparagus, I have canned peas and sweet corn. Â Today I am canning ground beef. Â Tomorrow it is cranberry sauce, whole cranberries and cranberry juice. Â I will be back when I am a little bit closer to seeing the bottom of my freezer. Â :)

title: A Lovely Weekend
text: As any Mom will tell you, any Mother's Day where you hear from all of your kids is a good day.My youngest daughter phoned to wish me a Happy Mother's Day. Â She is home recovering from knee replacement surgery. Â My stairs are not on her list of doable things at present, but I am glad that she is healing and the surgery seems to have been successful. Â Her adult kids will spend time with her, as it should be.Oldest daughter Jill stopped in with a gift. Â A little background information here. Â I have cellulitis which causes my lower legs and feet to swell. Â As a result, it is necessary for me to wear Ace bandages from knees to toes on both legs, 24 - 7 to try to keep the swelling down. Â I can not wear regular shoes because of this. Â I have a pair of those less than fashionable, Velcro adjustable boot-like things with hard soles to wear outside. Â Inside I have been wearing those socks with the gripper soles over the bandages to keep them clean. Â So when Jill showed up with a cute pair of house shoes that are made of a knitted, stretchy fabric with a gripper sole and will fit over the bandages, I was thrilled. Â When you have probably the ugliest legs and feet in the State of Minnesota, being able to wear something on your feet that looks normal is a great boost to your morale.The ever practical Duane made a Farmer's Market run and brought me four bundles of asparagus. Â I love asparagus. Â I cut it into one inch lengths and this morning filled 16 half pint jars that are happily cooking away in my pressure canner. Â There is enough left over for at least two meals. Â Fresh asparagus is spendy, which is why I don't include it in my grocery order. Â Now I will have enough canned so I can treat myself now and then. Â I woke from an afternoon nap to find a Mother's Day card next to me from Duane and Lori. Â Lori had called me earlier from Colorado where she is visiting relatives. Â Made me feel good that she did that.David, Staci and my three youngest grands came over here on Saturday. Â They brought lunch. Â And they brought the dog, who puked three times on the way here due to the motion sickness she still has. Â I asked David why they didn't wait until she could ride without getting sick and he said that they all wanted me to meet my new Grandpuppy. Â Oreo is adorable and so well behaved for a pup. Â She obviously adores the kids and they, her. Â So I got to pet and love on a puppy again. Â It was great! Â If she ever grows into those long legs of hers, she will be a good-sized dog.David's family had another surprise for me. Â Knowing I would have to buy a walker soon, I had been researching them to find which one would work best for me. Â I don't need to research any longer, for they brought me a walker that fits all of my needs. Â It has wheels and brakes. Â It has a seat so I can rest when I need to. Â It folds up making it easy to carry up and down stairs. Â David said he was sorry there was no cup holder. Â I had been joking that when I got my walker it had to have a cup holder, an Ooga horn (remember those?), and those handlebar streamers that kids used to attach to their bikes. Â Sometimes when faced with the fact that your life has changed and you need help with something as simple as walking, making jokes helps to deal with it. Â We Â have stormy weather moving in today, but maybe by the end of the week I can be outdoors, terrorizing the neighborhood. Â :)It was a lovely weekend. Â It wasn't all about the gifts, though I am pleased by and appreciative of each one. Â It was about my kids and grands who are my heart. Â I do so love each and every one. Â Thank you, God, for blessing me so richly.

title: News Blackout
text: I think I need to take a break from the news.Every morning I pour a cup of coffee, sit down at my computer and check out the various news websites. Â This morning I came to the realization that the news headlines are the same old crap - just a different day.Politically, the left mocks whatever the right is doing and vice versa. Â The Democrats will never, ever get over the fact that Hillary lost. Â Donald will continue to Tweet stupid things. Â And the pundits will continue to pontificate whether they have any actual knowledge or not. Â Congress continues to fight among themselves like spoiled children. Â And pass laws that are not helpful but mostly harmful to all but the elite. Â The Constitution has become an afterthought. Â The laws of our land seem to be optional.Around the world sabers continue to be rattled. Â Threats continue to be made. Â If we lived in a peaceful world, where would the attention getting soundbites come from. Â If world leaders didn't have constant turmoil and strife to keep their populations riled up about, someone might actually figure out that these leaders are mostly ego maniacal blowhards who care little about the general population and a lot about money and power.Here in the States we have gone from the ridiculous to the sublime. Â Special snowflakes need their safe spaces so they need not hear anything that might upset them. Â Social Justice Warriors have decided that I need to apologize for being born white. Â If I were a white male I would be expected to apologize and then fall upon my sword. Â I am expected to accept every perversion known to man as 'the new normal.' Â And if I object or openly declare my faith in God, I am racist. Â Or guilty of 'hate speech.'College students dictate to school administrators what should be taught in classrooms, none of which prepares students for the real world. Â And the administrators let them get away with it. Â Tension between the races is at an all time high. Â Peaceful demonstrations turn into window breaking, car burning, rock throwing riots. Â Police are told to stand down and let it happen. Â Those who are speaking against the thuggery are shouted down or are silenced with just the threat of riots should the speakers exercise their right of free speech. We have become a lawless nation. Â People are welcomed into our country who have broken the law just by coming in through the back door. Â We may be accepting some on humanitarian grounds, but the majority of the illegal aliens are here to do more harm than good. Â Our taxes pay for their food, housing and medical care and our Vets go without proper care. Â Some of those crossing our borders have vowed to kill all who do not convert to Islam. Â Many expect US citizens to accommodate their way of life and their beliefs, but have no intention of Â accepting ours. Â And yet many in Congress fight against securing our borders.Gangs of thugs block our freeways shouting slogans about killing cops, but few arrests are made. Â A friend who is a retired cop tells me the police have their hands tied by the politicians. Â I can pretty much guarantee that if I were standing in the middle of a road blocking traffic, I would find myself explaining to a judge why I would do something that stupid. Â People are being harassed and even assaulted simply because of who they voted for in the last election. Â Some are being abused just to see how many 'likes' the perpetrators can get on their social media live stream. Â And some are being hurt just because the thugs think it is funny.I wish I could change it. Â I wish I could just wave a magic wand and turn the world, or at least my country, into Mayberry. Â I know there are still good people here. Â I know many of them. Â I read their blogs and their comments. Â I am proud to be related to some of them. Â Problem is that the politically correct crowd is larger and stronger and louder and more vicious. Â It is like Pandora's box has been opened and has released it's demons among us.I have no earthly idea where it will all end. Â I am not well versed enough in the scriptures to quote any of God's promises or solutions. Â And I am not arrogant enough to think I know the mind of God. Â What I do know is that we as a nation desperately need to get back to the principals of our founding fathers. Â We need to hold true to our core beliefs without worrying about offending those who have differing opinions. Â And we need to stand firm against those who seek to destroy us.That is a pretty tall order. Â I have no doubt that my parents and grandparents were equal to the task. Â I wonder if we are.

title: The Days Roll On
text: There is nothing special going on here in my little Home Sweet Apartment. Â Just the day to day routine of living. Â And when I look at the news and see the chaos in our country, I find myself very grateful that I live such a quiet life.Lori left yesterday for Colorado to spend time with her family and to see her daughter graduate from college. Â We miss her but are really happy for her as this is something she has been looking forward to. Â This means Duane is batching it this week. Â He came over last evening as he does twice a week to help me with my leg bandages. Â I fed him pork chops covered with dressing and baked in the oven. Â I will be seeing him often as the landlord has sent workmen to fix the bathroom in Duane's apartment. Â The contractor who remodeled the apartments several years ago did a lousy job there. Â The shower had developed a large crack in the wall, the toilet had been leaking underneath the floor so the plywood flooring had rotted out and there were other issues. Â By the time the work is finished, Duane and Lori will have Â brand new bathroom. Â Meantime, he is using mine. Â Good thing we live so close.Youngest son David called me yesterday to let me know that he would likely bring his family to see me on Saturday. Â It is always fun to see the grands. Â They might bring the new puppy. Â Puppy still doesn't do car rides very well. Â Motion sickness. Â And given that puking puppies are not much fun to travel with, they may just wait on the pup's visit. I am enjoying the spring breeze through my open windows in the afternoons when the outside temperature is warm enough. Â I admit to having a slight case of Spring Fever which accounts for the need to tidy things up a bit after the long winter. Â The few dust bunnies that have been found are now gone. Â Cupboards have been straightened and shelves have been reorganized. Â I'm waiting for my grocery order to be delivered today, after which I think I had better bake a couple batches of cookies. Â To have a grandchild find an empty cookie jar is just, well, wrong. Â :)My days are peaceful for the most part. Â I still am working on being prepared for whatever comes - canning and dehydrating as much as possible - adding to the other supplies - spending some time in the evenings learning skills that may be useful. Â YouTube is a great resource for tutorials on most any subject. Â So many of the skills that were second nature to our grandparents seem to have been all but lost. Â Sometimes I long for the days before electronic gadgets took over our lives. Â The days when we read real books and wrote letters in cursive using pen and paper and actually held conversations rather than texting. Â I do admit to loving my computer, for it gives me the opportunity to connect to the outside world at a time when it is difficult for me to leave my apartment. Â But I think I would give it up to be able to sit on the porch and listen to Grandpa tell stories about his childhood. Â I treasure the memories of those conversations with my Dad in his later years. Â Reading from a screen or watching a video just isn't the same. Â I guess the older I become, the more I wish the world hadn't changed so much. Â Sigh.

title: Spring Has Sprung...
text: the grass has riz,I wonder wherethe flowers is.A direct quote from my Dad, who was known to recite that little ditty every spring, for the amusement of his progeny, while taking on the stance of a great orator. Â Dad was funny.I much prefer spring in the country to spring in the city, but even here the wonder of the change in seasons makes itself known.My building has a communal deck attached to the back. Â There is a table and a few chairs there and even though it overlooks the parking lot, it is still a nice place to sit on a sunny spring day, coffee cup and book in hand, for an afternoon of sunshine and mystery novel.There is a bar located next door to my building, just across the alley, and another behind my building. Â It is possible to near snippets of conversation as patrons walk from one to the other."Come on. Â I'll buy you a drink.""No, no, no. Â But I will take the money.""I'm going to have one for the road.""OK. Â And I will have one for the gutter.""There's a reason you can't start that car.""What's the reason.""Because it's not your car,""Oh."The downtown area where I live has old fashioned looking street lights. Â Every spring the city hangs baskets of brightly colored petunias from hooks on the lamp poles. Â There are also large flower boxes on every corner that are filled with more colorful petunias. Â I expect to look out my window and see the flowers within a week or so, for Mother's Day is usually when they arrive, turning a drab city street cheerful and pretty.Whenever my windows are open I can hear the chitter chatter of sparrows and chickadees coming from the tree in front of my building. Â Last spring a pair of sparrows built a nest in the small tree outside my living room window. Â While the Mama bird sat on her eggs, the male was busy chasing away any and all threats to the nest. Â I watched him go after birds several times his size. Â The pair hatched out at least four babies and between two and three weeks later, the young birds were out on their own and the parents began a second family. Â  The nest was partially hidden from view, but I caught glimpses of the babies now and then. Â I am easily amused.Every spring the sky is filled with honking Canadian geese. Â Minnesota is the "Land of 10,000 Lakes," but I bet there are more if you include all the smaller ponds. Â The geese have been nesting here for generations. Â It is not unusual to have to stop your car and wait for mama goose to lead her gaggle of young across the road. Â Every summer there is at least one golf course that tries to remove the geese from their pristine fairways. Â And each attempt results in failure. Â The geese were there first and they will remain, no matter what.I like fall best of all because of the color, but spring runs a close second. Â It means that the long winter is over and there is hope for summer breezes and sunshine. Â In February we in the north wonder if we will ever see green grass and leaves again. Â We do...thanks to spring.

title: Beautiful Day
text: The temperature is 61 degrees and rising. Â There is sunshine and blue skies. Â A soft breeze finds its way through my open windows. Â After lunch I may go sit out on the deck and soak it all in. Â Even the scenic view of the parking lot for the bar next door can't put a damper on such a lovely day.Ah Spring. Â You were worth the wait.

title: Wednesday Ramble
text: It is a quiet day in the neighborhood today. Â I am occupied with the usual chores that keep my apartment livable - washing dishes - putting away yesterday's canned soup - vacuuming - etc. It is finally looking like Spring. Â The temperature reached 65 degrees this afternoon and the forecast is for more of the same. Â Brown is no longer the predominate color. Â Everywhere I look there is green grass and green leaves coming out on the trees. Â We didn't have a bad winter. Â But it just seemed to last so long. Â Spring is very welcome. Â Soon I will be able to open my windows and let that lovely spring breeze in.I read an article the other day that made me laugh. Â It seems that Harvard Law School has stopped the practice of charging a late fee for overdue library books. Â The reason for this is that it is way too stressful for the precious snowflakes to have to worry about overdue library fees. Â Really? Â Overdue book fees are too stressful? Â Good grief. Â How in the name of all that is good and holy are those people going to handle the stress of everyday living. Â Not to mention the stress that goes along with their chosen profession of Attorney at Law. Â  If I should ever need a good attorney, I'm pretty sure I would want one who wasn't stressed by overdue library fees.So I am off to the kitchen to fix me a bit of supper. Â I'm thinking some homemade chicken nuggets and a bowl of coleslaw. Â With a dish of banana pudding for dessert. Â Works for me!

title: A Good Day For Soup
text: I don't think the temperature got much over 36 degrees today. Â And it has been raining off and on for a couple of days. Â I won't complain. Â The worst of the weather went around us and that included snow. Â Any time the snow gives us a miss, I am happy. Â But the chilly, wet weather is most definitely good soup making weather.Friday before my dance watching marathon, I dug four ham bones out of the freezer, tossed them into my biggest stock pot, covered them with water and simmered them most of the day. Â I picked the meat from the bones and strained the resulting broth. Â There was enough good, rich ham broth to cook up three bags of split peas, which I did today. Â I added some diced carrots from the freezer, a couple of handfuls of my dehydrated onions, some garlic powder and the ham pieces. Â I let the soup simmer all afternoon and then ladled it into pint jars. Â I got 16 pints of split pea and ham soup, with enough left over for supper.I have about 20 lbs. of hamburger in the freezer, so tonight I will take that out to thaw and can it up tomorrow. Â Seems like whenever I take something out of the freezer to can, I find more food underneath it that needs to be processed. Â I still have cranberries that were under the hamburger, so dealing with them is my next project. Â Maybe if I keep at it, I might actually find the bottom of my freezer. Â Maybe.

title: Dance Like Nobody's Watching
text: This afternoon I received an email from Youngest Son. Â His oldest, my granddaughter Boston, has a dance competition this weekend. Â It will be live streamed so I can watch it. Â He sent me the link and the scheduled times for Boston's dances.Later my phone rang. Â It was Boston. Â "I am so excited that you are going to watch me dance, Grandma." Â I'm excited, too. Â This is the first time this year that one of her competitions has been live streamed. Â I haven't as yet seen her solo tap dance and I'm really looking forward to watching her perform it.I told Boston that I already had my popcorn popper out and ready to go, so I could watch her dance and munch popcorn, just like in the theaters. Â She said, "Grandma, you're so funny."I will be back on Monday after my marathon dance competition watching.Go get 'em, Miss B. Â Dance like nobody's watching!!Love, Grandma

title: Dad and the Seven Foot Tall Tomato Plant
text: My Dad loved to grow things. Â He lovingly tended his gardens for many years. Â And when he could no longer garden, he planted tomatoes in pots on the balcony of his apartment.One fall he found that a tomato plant had not yet died off as had the others, so when the nights became colder, he brought it indoors. Â He continued to water it and it continued to grow.Dad lived in a town of about 600 people, not ten miles from where he was born. Â Everyone knew everyone else. Â Knowing Dad, I suspect that he did just a little bit of bragging on his tall tomato plant. Â Probably showed it off to some of his friends and relatives who lived in the same Senior apartment building.Word got around and one afternoon a reporter from the local weekly newspaper came knocking on his door. Â An interview was given and pictures were taken. Â And Dad and his tomato plant had their 15 minutes of fame the following week when the paper was published.Some years later I inherited a box full of family pictures. Â While sorting them out, I found this one.That's Dad. Â That's the famous tomato plant. Â Dad was 5' 5" tall so the plant might look taller than it was. Â I looked at the distance between the top of the plant and his living room ceiling. Â Looks to be about a foot. Â After this photo was taken, the silly plant continued to grow until it touched the ceiling.We always teased him that it must have been a slow news week when the article appeared in the newspaper. Â He just smiled and remarked that he knew of nobody else who had grown a 7 foot tall tomato plant.I sure miss that old man.

title: Just Not Working
text: I have been trying all morning to write a new post and it just isn't working. Â The words aren't there. Â It isn't that the subject is difficult, for it was just about another day in the life of this chubby granny. Â Rather than fight with it any longer, I shall give my brain a time-out and head to the kitchen to re-can some pickles and bake some bread. Â Perhaps tomorrow my brain cells will line up and let me write something that makes sense. Â :)

title: If I report the bad...
text: then I had better report the good.A little while ago there was a knock on my door. Â It was my neighbor. Â The one of the barking dog and smoke alarm fame. Â That one.He said he was truly sorry for the trouble he had caused. Â He hoped I would accept his apology and his assurance that there would not be a repeat performance.I accepted his apology. Â All I want is for him to take responsibility for his actions and to stop doing dumb stuff that threatens me and mine. Â And aside from the smoke alarm incidents, he is a quiet neighbor who doesn't bother anyone.I do not know what brought about this change in attitude. Â And it really doesn't matter. Â I will give him the benefit of the doubt. Â After all, he isn't the only one living here who has slipped into stupid at one time or another.And I would hate to see Cooper have to move. Â I love that dog. Â :)

title: A Couple of Days R&R and a Bit of Apartment House Excitement
text: So I thought I was Wonder Woman.I'm not.After all the canning I need a couple of days of rest and recuperation. Â Dratted arthritis! Â All I had left to can was hamburger and peas. Â Those are now in the freezer waiting until my aching joints get with the program. Â I had some onions, cabbage and bell peppers leftover, so those will go into the dehydrators this evening.There was a bit of excitement here in my building Saturday night. Â My neighbor across the hall seems to have overindulged at the bar, Â came home and put some food in his oven and neglected to take it out. Â I heard his dog barking about 1 AM. Â The dog never barks unless something is wrong in his world. Â Then the neighbor's smoke alarm started blaring at 1:30 AM. Â I had been dozing in my recliner and when I noticed it was still going off 20 minutes later and I started to get up to call 911 when it stopped.Duane asked me the next day if I had heard all the excitement. Â I had not, for I must have gone to sleep right after the alarm stopped. Â He said that he and Lori opened their apartment door to find out where the alarm was, and they found the hallway was filled with a smoky haze. Â Lori called 911. Â Police and firemen showed up in short order and found the source of the smoke. Â  Â They set up fans to clear the smoke from the building. Â Duane came here to check on me and found me peacefully snoozing. Â Duane and Lori said that later the neighbor, thinking the caretakers had made the call, had taken his drunken self down the hall and was pounding on the caretaker's door, shouting obscenities and calling them some very unflattering names.This is the third time this fool has done this. Â We are hoping our landlord will invite him to take his sorry self elsewhere to live. Aside from that, all is quiet and peaceful in my little corner of the world. Â :)

title: Canning Corn Relish
text: I like to have a variety of relishes on hand. Â They give just a little bit of zing to a meal. Â One of my favorites is corn relish. Â Here is the recipe.Corn Relish6 cups cooked fresh or frozen whole kernel corn3 cups chopped cabbage1 cup chopped onion1 medium green bell pepper, chopped1 medium red bell pepper, chopped4 cups cider vinegar2 cups granulated sugar1 cup water1 Tbsp pickling salt1 Tbsp celery seed1 Tbsp mustard seed1 Tbsp turmericCombine all ingredients. Â Bring to a boil over medium-high heat, stirring occasionally. Â Reduce heat to medium and cook for 15 minutes, stirring occasionally.Immediately fill hot pint or half-pint jars with mixture, leaving 1/2-inch head space. Process pints or half-pints in boiling water canner for 15 minutes.I doubled the recipe. Â That gave me 12 pints of relish plus about a half pint to eat with supper tonite.I am taking tomorrow off. Â Duane is baking a huge ham. Â He is working his magic with a sauce that has pineapple in it. Â He and Lori are doing most of the cooking. Â All I have to do is make some candied carrots and set the table. Â Spoil me, they do. Â :)This is me, wishing all of my blog friends a happy and blessed Easter.So I decided to try another experiment. Â I am canning grapes.Now, why on earth would anybody want to can grapes, you might ask. Â First, I love grapes. Â Nearly every grocery order includes grapes. Second, lets pretend that the reason we prepare has happened and the only food we have to eat is the food we have stored. Â If I had canned no other meat than chicken, or if I only had canned peaches for fruit, it wouldn't take very long before I could not stand the sight of chicken or peaches. Â That's why I can a variety of meats and fruits. Â And grapes are just another variety to add to my shelves.I have not canned grapes before, but according to those who have, they can up well. Â If you only like fresh grapes, this method is probably not for you. Â But if you like the grapes that come in a can of fruit cocktail, you might like these.Canning grapes is easy, peasy. Â Remove the grapes from their stems and wash them well. Â Fill jars with grapes (I used pints) to within 1 inch from the top of the jar. Â Make a simple syrup of sugar and water. Â As grapes are naturally sweet, I used a very light syrup of 6 1/2 cups of water and 3/4 cup sugar, brought to a boil to dissolve the sugar. Â This is enough for 8 - 9 pints. Â Pour the syrup over the grapes and water bath can them for 15 minutes. I had ordered 2 lbs. of green grapes and 2 lbs. of red. Â That gave me 6 pints of grapes, total (minus a handful or two or three that I ate). Â When the jars had cooled, I opened one to see how I would like them, and I did. Â I would think you could use them like fruit cocktail, just for snacking or maybe as a dessert. Â I will probably can more of these.You gotta try new things. Â :)

title: Canning Ham and Bean and Vegetable Soup
text: When I can soups I keep the recipe as simple as possible. Â If I keep the ingredients basic, I can add others when it is served, giving me more options.Last evening I did the prep work on the ingredients for this soup. Â This recipe calls for the following per pint jar, layered in no particular order:1/3 cup of dry white beans that have been sorted and washed1/4 cup diced onion1/4 cup diced carrots1/4 cup diced celery1/4 cup diced ham2 teaspoon beef bouillon powderwater to fill jarThe jars are processed in a pressure canner for 75 minutes at 10 lbs. pressure for my altitude. Â The beans will cook through and expand while processing. Â The recipe can be doubled for quarts that are processed for 90 minutes. Â I ran through a canner load of 16 pints.Some instructions for similar soups call for more beans. Â I am reluctant to use more because the beans fully expand in the canner. Â Too many beans in the jar will push the lids off when they expand, leaving a nasty mess in the canner and the loss of your jars of soup. Some serve the soup as is with just the addition of salt and pepper. Â Others add a variety of spices and seasonings to taste. Â Some like the addition of tomatoes or tomato powder for a different flavor. Â There are all sorts of possibilities.This soup along with a chicken vegetable variety are my "go to" soups. Â I make sure I have lots of both canned and on the shelves so that I can use both in a variety of ways. Â They are nice to have when you want a quick lunch or supper. Â Add a salad or cornbread or maybe a slice of homemade bread and you have a really quick and easy meal. Â And as you know, I am all about quick, easy meals now that I am cooking for just one.More SoupI still had vegetables and ham left after canning the ham, bean and vegetable soup. Â I also had some potatoes that needed to be used up. Â So I peeled and diced the potatoes. Â Each pint jar got 2/3 cup of potatoes and 1/3 cup each ham, carrots and celery. Â I added 1 teaspoon of chicken bouillon powder for flavor and water to cover. Â I ran this through the pressure canner at 10 lbs. pressure for 75 minutes. Â I got 16 pints of ham, potato and vegetable soup.I sort of made this soup up as I went along so I'm not exactly sure what to do with it. Â I expect it can be eaten as is or maybe thickened for a chowder type soup. Â No matter how it is consumed, it is still 16 more meals on the shelf. Â And that's the goal - fill the shelves.

title: Canning Kielbasa
text: As it turned out this week, the only food items I needed to order were eggs and milk. Â So I thought it might be a good opportunity to fill out my grocery order with things to can. Â My groceries were delivered this afternoon. Â In order to get a head start on the canning, I started with the easiest which is kielbasa. Â This is sort of an experiment for me as I have not canned kielbasa before.I started out with 6 rings of kielbasa. Â I cut them into about 1 inch thick pieces. Â I didn't want the pieces any smaller than that because of the time they are in the pressure canner. Â I was afraid they would become a bit crunchy if the slices were too thin. Â I am not fond of most meats that are canned in liquid so I added none to the jars. Â I just packed pint jars with the kielbasa chunks and pressure canned them for 75 minutes at 10 lbs. pressure for my area. Â I got 7 pints from the 6 kielbasa rings.I am pleased with the results. Â The kielbasa did not shrink hardly at all in the canning process, and the taste and texture are really good. Â I will can more of this.Tomorrow I am canning ham, bean and vegetable soup and will post the recipe when the soup comes out of the canner.

title: Taking a Few Days Off
text: I have a major canning session coming up after my grocery delivery on Thursday. Â Duane and Lori picked up 6 cases of pint jars and 3 cases of half pints for me. Â I hope that will be enough. Â At any rate, I am taking a few days off to deal with those pesky domestic chores that need my attention before I am knee-deep in home canned stuff. Â Instructions and a recipe or two to follow. Â Meanwhile, those folks listed over there in the sidebar have all sorts of interesting things to say. Â Enjoy.

title: Canning Ham
text: So yesterday I saw that ham was on sale at my local grocery. Â Ham is one of my favorite meats to can and my supply was getting low. Â Lori said she would be happy to do a grocery run for me (Bless her heart.). Â She came back with a lovely spiral cut ham for our Easter dinner and 4 regular hams for me to can. Â The hams to can weighed in at about 40 pounds, total. I spent the afternoon cutting the meat from the bones. Â Roughly a third of the meat was cut into 2 to 3 inch chunks to be used for regular ham dinners. Â The rest was cut into smaller cubes. Â These will be used in scalloped potatoes and ham or casseroles or for sandwiches.Early this morning I packed the ham into pint and half pint jars. Â I don't add any liquid. Â The ham generates its own juices. Â Both are processed in the pressure canner for 75 minutes. Â The four hams gave me 13 pints of the larger chunks and 45 half pints of the smaller cubes.There is a generous amount of meat left on the bones, so maybe tomorrow I will boil up the bones and can the resulting ham broth. Â The meat will be packaged and frozen for use in ham and beans or in soup. It is good to have a variety of meats on the shelf and canning ham is one way to accomplish that. Â It is a bonus that the home canned ham tastes really good.

title: Nooooooo...
text: You know what our local weatherman said?He said it might snow tomorrow.That is just wrong, even for Minnesota.Mother Nature, I don't like you very much any more.

title: Jelly Experiment
text: I bought 6 jars of grape jelly a while back. Â The good thing was, they were on sale. Â The bad thing was, the jelly came in 32 ounce jars. Â There is no way I can eat a quart of grape jelly before it starts growing mold. Â Jelly isn't supposed to be hairy.So I decided this morning to try something with it. Â I opened one jar, dumped the contents into a sauce pan and heated the jelly over a low flame until it became liquid. Â Then I poured it into half pint jars and hot water bath canned them for 15 minutes.I wasn't at all sure the jelly would jell up after being melted, but it was worth a try.It worked. Â Now I have my sale jelly in small enough jars so that it will be used up before it goes bad.Think outside the box.

title: When Do You Have Enough Home Canned Food
text: That is a question I have been pondering this week. Â Because I enjoy the process and results of canning food in jars and because I seem to be constantly rearranging to make room on the shelves for more, I began to wonder when I would have enough.If I were canning for just myself I would probably concede that I have enough now to last me a couple of years, even with using it regularly as I do. Â But there is more to consider. Â For a number of years I have taken into consideration that because my oldest son is the one who does grocery and Farmer's Market runs for me and because he has hauled countless cases of jars up the stairs to my apartment, often refusing to let me pay, that my canning efforts would feed him as well as myself. Â And now that his girlfriend has joined our family and they live in my building, the food in jars is, of course, split three ways. Â That gives me maybe a years worth of canned food.None of us knows what the future holds. Â The only thing I know for sure is that I now live in a more volatile world than I have ever before in my lifetime seen. Â There are riots in the streets over any number of causes, political and racial being the two most prominent. Â  We have those who are supposed to be representing we the people, fighting amongst themselves worse than the Hatfields and McCoys. Â We have the occasional terrorist who tries to kill as many of us as possible for the glory of Allah. Â We have countries in the Middle East whose theme song seems to be "Death to America." Â  And lest we forget, there is that crazy North Korean dictator who threatens on almost a weekly basis to nuke us to smithereens or at the very least, nuke our electric grid out of existence. Â And we haven't even talked about the natural disasters that could occur.So all of that being said, when do I have enough food in jars to stop canning. Â Do I stop when there is enough to feed three people for a year? Â Or do I think ahead to the possibility of other family members knocking on my door when their food supply is gone. Â I am not saying this will happen, but what if it did. Someone once looked at my well stocked shelves and asked me, in all seriousness, what in the world I was going to do with all that food, should nothing bad ever happen. Â I said I didn't know. Â Maybe I would just..........eat it.To answer my own question about when do you have enough food stored, I think that "never" is likely correct. Â Especially for those of us who live where we can not raise our own fruit and vegetables and livestock. Â Eventually, no matter what our best efforts are, the food will run out. Â But having a couple of years of food stocked, we have given ourselves time to plan and carry out the next move should it be necessary. Â It is good to have options.

title: Quiet Weekend
text: It was a very quiet weekend here in my little Home Sweet Apartment. Â I did a whole lot of nuthin'. Oh, there were the usual domestic chores that keep one's living space from turning into pig sty. Â There were dishes to be washed and Â floors to be swept and dust to be removed from furniture surfaces. Â But between bouts of domesticity there were mystery novels to be read and movies to be watched and most importantly, naps to be taken. Youngest Son called and wanted to know what I was doing. Â I replied that I was pretty much just being a turnip. Â He said he wished he could just be a turnip for a day. Â He was busy doing those chores that most folks with jobs do on weekends. Â And he was driving his offspring to dance competitions and hockey games. Â Makes me appreciate retirement even more.So I am off to do a couple loads of laundry. Â And maybe bake a pan of brownies. Â In a world that has gone completely mad, sometimes a pan of brownies is all that stands between us and total insanity.

title: If I Brag About Successes...
text: then I also need to report my fails.Out of the 14 quarts of chili I canned, one jar didn't seal right out of the canner. Â That is not unusual. Â While I was washing the jars prior to shelving them, another six jars popped their seals. Â That is unusual.I am not sure why this happened. Â There are a number of reason why lids don't seal, but this is the first time I can remember having jars that seal, only to come loose the next day. I put the offending jars in the fridge. Â Tomorrow I will transfer the chili from the jars to freezer bags and freeze them. Â I am debating whether or not I should just open the rest of the jars and freeze the contents of them as well. Â With a failure rate of 50%, it seems likely that others could lose their seals and I could have chili on my shelf, slowly rotting away if I don't catch the popped seals right away. Â Better to err on the side of caution.On the bright side, I didn't lose any chili due to spoilage. Â Good thing I cleaned out the freezer. Â :)

title: Lots of Chili
text: So yesterday I cleaned out the freezer compartment of the refrigerator. Â I did that mostly because in my typical unorganized fashion, stuff was just crammed in there willy nilly. Â And when a rock solid package of food slid out when the door was opened, I was in danger of winding up with a busted toe. Â I can't jump out of the way of falling objects quite as fast as I used to. Â Anyway, in the process of cleaning and sorting, I found about 15 lbs. of hamburger. Â Decided it was time to can some chili. Â I had been out of my home canned chili for a while and I really like having it on hand for a quick meal.This morning I browned the meat, drained it and tossed it into my big stock pot. Â I added 9 pints of tomatoes with green peppers and onions that I had canned a couple of years ago. Â That wasn't enough, so I added 5 quarts of diced tomatoes. Â Threw in a big handful of dehydrated onions just because. Â I had a couple of cases of kidney beans in the pantry, so I added 6 cans of them to the mix. Â I seasoned the chili with salt and pepper and chili powder to taste.When I can chili, I don't need to cook it first. Â I just heat it up enough to warm it before filling the jars. Â Because the chili contains meat, the quart jars are processed in the pressure canner for 90 minutes which is plenty of time to fully cook it. Â I wound up with 14 quarts of chili.When I was growing up, my Mom always served chili over rice. Â I always thought she did that because she liked it that way. Â It wasn't until I was grown and feeding my own family that I realized she used the rice to stretch the chili to feed our family. Â By that time I liked the combination of chili and rice, so while the chili was in the canner I cooked up a big pot of rice, let it cool down and portioned it out into small freezer bags and froze it. Â So now when I want chili for supper, I just need to microwave the rice enough to thaw it out and heat it up while the chili heats on the stove. Â Add a pan of cornbread and I have a quick, easy supper. Â And goodness knows, I am all about quick and easy meals. Â :)

title: Shakopee Wind Symphony Tour

title: Roast Beast and Caramel Sauce
text: So Oldest Son wants to know if he can borrow my large roasting pan. Â I say he sure can if he comes over and retrieves it from on top of my kitchen cupboard where it lives. Â I don't do step stools any more. Â When he gets here, he wants to know if I would like a plate of roast beast with potatoes and carrots for supper. Â Of course I would. Â And it was hand delivered right to my kitchen table. Â And it was delicious. Â And I didn't have to lift a finger. Â And there is enough left over for my supper tomorrow. Â Life is good. Â :)I imagine most have heard of making caramel sauce by boiling an unopened can of sweetened condensed milk. Â The other day I saw a video where the milk was poured into half-pint jars and water bath canned for three hours. Â I decided to try it. Â Son brought me some cans of the cheaper store brand sweetened condensed milk and some cans of the more expensive name brand. Â He figured I could can both to see if there was any difference in the finished product. Â So today I gave it a try.After supper we did a taste test on the caramel sauce. Â Turns out the cheap stuff from Walmart has a more creamy consistency and tastes better than the more expensive name brand. Â I had some on ice cream for dessert and it is really good. Â I think it might make a good caramel dipping sauce for apple slices, too.I have to add a disclaimer here. Â This is not an "approved" product to home can. Â Which means that the government agency in charge of the home canning rules has not tested this and therefore has not given it's approval. Â That being said, I am not telling you to can sweetened condensed milk as caramel sauce. Â I am just reporting on what I did.And that it is really, really good. Â :)

title: How did we survive!!!
text: I was doodling about the internet this morning while waiting for the coffee to perk and I stumbled upon this little article. Â There is no author listed, but here is the link. Â As I have no real post today, I offer this for your amusement. Â Enjoy.If you lived as a child in the 40's, 50's, 60's or 70'sLooking back, it's hard to believe that we have lived as long as we have...As children, we would ride in cars with no seat belts or air bags. Riding in the back of a pickup truck on a warm day was always a special treat.Our baby cribs were covered with bright colored lead-based paint. We had no childproof lids on medicine bottles, doors, or cabinets.When we rode our bikes, we had no helmets. (Not to mention hitchhiking to town as a young kid!)We drank water from the garden hose and not from a bottle. Horrors.We would spend hours building our go-carts out of scraps and then rode down the hill, only to find out we forgot the brakes. After running into the bushes a few times we learned to solve the problem.We would leave home in the morning and play all day, as long as we were back when the streetlights came on. No one was able to reach us all day. Our parents knew that all the neighbors would watch out for all the kids. No cell phones. Unthinkable.We played dodge ball and sometimes the ball would really hurt.We got cut and broke bones and broke teeth, and there were no lawsuits from these accidents. They were accidents. No one was to blame, but us. Remember accidents?We had fights and punched each other and got black and blue and learned to get over it.We ate cupcakes, bread and butter, and drank sugar soda, but we were never overweight... we were always outside playing. We shared one grape soda with four friends, from one bottle and no one died from this.We did not have Playstations, Nintendo 64, X-Boxes, video games at all, 99 channels on cable, video tape movies, surround sound, personal cell phones, Personal Computers, Internet chat rooms ... we had friends. We went outside and found them.We rode bikes or walked to a friend's home and knocked on the door, or rung the bell or just walked in and talked to them. Imagine such a thing. Without asking a parent! By ourselves! Out there in the cold cruel world! Without a guardian.How did we do it?We made up games with sticks and tennis balls and ate worms and although we were told it would happen, we did not put out very many eyes, nor did the worms live inside us forever.Little League had tryouts and not everyone made the team. Those who didn't, had to learn to deal with disappointment.... The teams actually kept score and the winning team was allowed to be excited and the losing team learned to be good sports about it and learned that, in life - sometimes you win and sometimes you lose.Some students weren't as smart as others so they failed a grade and were held back to repeat the same grade..... Horrors. Tests were not adjusted for any reason.Almost no one went to "pre-school" and when we graduated high school we all knew how to read, use proper grammar and do basic math. We all learned how to count out change without a calculator to tell us the amount.The worst problems in school were tardiness and chewing gum in class. Our actions were our own. Consequences were expected. No one to hide behind. The idea of a parent bailing us out if we broke a law was unheard of. They actually sided with the law ... imagine that!If you misbehaved - your parents spanked you and no one arrested them for doing that! We also learned that when a parent said "No" - they actually meant that and our lives would not be ruined forever by being denied every little thing we wanted at any given moment.New toys were received on birthdays and holidays..... not on every trip to the store. Parents gave us gifts out of love.... not out of guilt.This generation has produced some of the best risk-takers and problem solvers and inventors, ever. The past 50 years has been an explosion of innovation and new ideas. We had freedom, failure, success and responsibility, and we learned how to deal with it all.And you're one of them.Congratulations!

title: More Canning and Dehydrating
text: Lately I have been concentrating on using my grocery delivery service to bring me items to add to my food storage. Â This week, in addition to the normal groceries I use like fresh fruits and vegetables, I ordered 6 lbs. of butter. Â Those, along with the 6 lbs. I had in my freezer, are waiting to be canned in half pint jars. Â The half pints are just right for everyday use for one person or maybe two, but I need to can some more in pint jars for when I need butter for baking. Â Thing is, I am low on pint jars. Â I may have to buy a few more cases of jars or wait until I empty more from my shelves. Â If you are a canner, you know that one can never have too many jars. Â :)I had 2 bags of hash browns in my freezer, so I ordered 4 more. Â Those went on the dehydrator trays that were lined with the plastic mesh inserts to keep the little bits from falling through the trays. Â I like having the dehydrated hash browns on hand. Â They just need to be soaked in water for maybe 15 minutes, then drained and they are ready to fry or to use in casseroles.Next were the frozen vegetables. Â This time I got 6 bags of broccoli and 6 bags of whole kernel corn. Â Dehydrating frozen vegetables is a snap. Â Just spread them out on the mesh lined trays and set the dehydrator temperature at 135 degrees. Â I did chop the broccoli into smaller pieces to use in soups or casseroles and so they would dry a little more quickly.I ordered 10 lbs of russet potatoes. Â These I will be slicing thin using a mandolin, blanching the slices for 3 minutes and spreading them in a single layer on the trays. Â They are dried at the same temperature as the other vegetables. Â I use these mostly for scalloped potatoes. Â I find that cooking them in a crock pot works better for me than using the oven. Â My instructions for crockpot scalloped potatoes using dehydrated potatoes are here.Sometimes I will re-can food, when it is less expensive to do so than it is to make it from scratch. Â This is true of sweet pickles. Â Because I can not raise my own cucumbers and have to buy them at the Farmer's Market, canning sweet pickles become somewhat pricey to make. Â I had 3 jars of sweet bread and butter pickles on the shelf from when I bought them on sale. Â The jars each contain 24 ounces of pickles, which is way more than I consume within several months. Â I ordered 3 more jars. Â I will be dumping the pickles and juice into a stock pot and heating them to near boiling. Â Then I will be packing the pickle slices and juice into half-pint jars and water bath canning them for 10 minutes. Â If you have to have a really crisp pickle this probably won't work for you as they soften up just a little bit in the process. Â I don't mind, so it works just fine for me and gives me jars of sweet pickles that get eaten soon after opening and don't live in my fridge for months on end.We like the baby dill pickles too, and those cukes aren't so expensive, so we get them at the Farmer's Market. Â I use Mrs. Wage's dill pickle mix when canning those and they turn out absolutely delicious.I need to spread the work over several day's time. Â If I don't, I am finding it takes this old body a couple of days to recover. Â I am not happy about that turn of events at this stage of my life, but there it is. Â So today I will deal with the butter and pickles and Monday will find me up to my elbows in potato slices. Mama Pea over at " A Home Grown Journal" had a giveaway - and I was one of the winners!! Â She gave away two sets of potholders she made.â®I appropriated the photo from her blog. Â I hope she doesn't mind. Â My camera battery gave out and I really wanted to show how pretty these potholders are. Â Mine are the top set. Â I admire anyone who does handmade. Â She makes some of the prettiest quilts and she knits socks and I don't know what all else. Â And there are posts about her homesteading experiences. Â I just love her blog.And now I am off to work on the canning of butter and pickles. Â Hope your weekend is snow free and shows signs of spring. Â :)
