title: Days and Nights Switched
text: I was blessed to become the mother of four babies. Â At one time or another, at least two of them got their days and nights switched around. Â They wanted to sleep during daylight hours and were wide awake, happy, smiling and wanting to play at 2 AM.It seems I have reverted to the behavior of those babies. Â I suppose I can blame some of it on being retired and living alone. Â I no longer need to keep "office hours." Â Nobody tells me it is time to get up or time to go to bed. Â I can nap whenever I feel tired. Â I can stay up all night if I am not tired. Â And I do.It is not all bad. Â There are no revving of engines or honking of horns in the street outside my windows in the middle of the night. Â There are no delivery trucks in the alley alongside my building. Â The bar patrons have gone home. Â Aside from the occasional train going past on the tracks a half a block away, the city is peaceful at 3 AM. Â I like that.It is 2:30 AM. Â My second load of laundry is swooshing away in the washer and the dryer is humming along. Â I am slowly but surely moving my home canned fruit and soups from the bedroom shelves to the ones in the living room, and arranging the meat and vegetables on the bedroom shelves.I take frequent breaks. Â I can not be on my feet for more than 15 minutes at a time without feeling pain in my back and legs. Â So I use this down time to write blog posts or watch videos or read. Â The sit-down time is also used to make out my grocery order and decide what I need to can or dehydrate next week. Â I do online research to find the items I need to get to round out my preps and make a list to send with Duane or Lori the next time they are going shopping. Â They are so good to pick up what I need.My sewing mojo seems to have left me, but I have been pinning together quilt pieces, getting them ready for the sewing machine. Â Perhaps by the weekend I will be inspired to sew them together. Â Lori has said she will take me to the fabric store for quilt batting and fabric for the backs of my quilts. Â We will do that when the weather is warmer and when I have my walker. Â  I don't think the fabric store has those handicap motorized carts, so it is necessary to wait until my walker arrives. Â It will be nice to be able to get out and about again.Maybe by then my days and nights will be back where they should be. Â This weekend we start Daylight Savings Time, so that might help. Â Maybe. Â At any rate, I guess it really doesn't matter when a person sleeps or when they are up and about. Â This should come as no great surprise to me as I have never been one to do things strictly by the book anyway. Â :)

title: Strange Weather Day
text: This is the time of year when most Minnesotans are tired of the snow and cold. Â I would be complaining, too, except that there isn't any snow and today's temperature topped out at nearly 65 degrees. Â Late this afternoon a storm rolled through complete with thunder and lightning. Â And a tornado touched down north of Minneapolis. Â Another one was spotted near our southern border. Â A tornado in February has never happened here since the Weather Bureau began keeping records.And snow is predicted for the weekend.I think Mother Nature must be off her meds.Lori is in the northern part of the state for a few days. Â Her Dad is suffering the effects of aging, so she goes to see him as often as she can. Â Duane was alone, so I asked him if he would like to come over for supper when he got off work. Â I had a couple of butternut squash that needed Â to be eaten and we both love squash. Â A couple of thick pork chops added to it made a pretty good meal. Â It is nice to have someone to cook for now and then.I keep busy. Â At least as busy as arthritic joints will allow. Â This goofy weather with it's changes in temperatures and conditions every other day seems to bring on flare-ups, but it does help to keep moving as much as possible. Â In addition to the usual household chores, I sorted out my dehydrated foods. Â I keep them in freezer bags stored in Banker's boxes on a set of shelve behind my bedroom door. Â I had gotten lazy and hadn't put someÂ many of the bags into the proper boxes. Â Now that I have, I can tell how much I need to dehydrate and what I have enough of.While Duane was here I asked him to get down a bottle of maple syrup from the top of one of my shelves. Â It is nice having a tall person living close by, especially when you aren't much over 5 feet tall and don't climb well any more. Â I need the syrup for a recipe of caramel corn that you make using the microwave. Â It is really good stuff.Microwave Caramel CornPop 1/3 Cup of popcorn kernels. Â I use my air-popper.Mix together 5 Tbsp. butter, 1/2 Cup brown sugar and 2 - 1/2 Tbsp. real maple syrup.Microwave for 2 minutes.Stir in 1 tsp. vanilla and 1 - 1/2 tsp. salt.Stir in 1/2 tsp. baking soda. Â This will cause the sugar mixture to foam up.Pour over the popcorn and mix well.Microwave the caramel corn for 1 minute. Â Stir. Â Repeat at 30 second intervals until the popcorn is a rich, caramel color. Â (Three or four times.)Duane said he would trade me some caramel corn for a milkshake made using crushed Girl Scout Thin Mints. Â Sounds like a pretty good trade to me. Â :)

title: Canning Sweet & Sour Chicken
text: I like to keep some heat and serve meals on hand for days I am busy and don't want to spend time cooking. Â I have had this recipe in my files for a long time - so long I don't recall where I found it. Â I had all the ingredients on hand so I decided to give it a try. This is the original recipe.Sweet and Sour Chicken5 lbs boneless, skinless chicken breasts cut in bite sized pieces3 large green peppers chopped2 large onions chopped3 (20 oz) cans pineapple chunks drained, reserve juice3/4 cup brown sugar1 1/4 cups white vinegar6 tablespoons soy sauce4 tablespoons ketchup1 tsp gingerLayer the chicken, onions, peppers and pineapple in quart jars.Heat the brown sugar, vinegar, soy sauce, ketchup, ginger, and 3 cups of pineapple juice (add water if there is not enough) and bring to a light boil until the sugar is dissolved.Pour liquid over the solids in the jar to the fill line.Pressure can for 90 minutes at 10 lbs pressure or according to your elevation.I did a couple of things differently. Â I used frozen chicken breast, so I thawed it, cut it up and stir-fried the pieces in a little bit of oil until they were just cooked through. Â You can use raw chicken, but when I have canned raw chicken before, the juices sort of become glued to the inside of the jar during the canning process. Â I didn't want that to happen.I used pint jars rather than quarts. Â I had to double the sauce in order to have enough. Â I had ordered a few cans of pineapple juice in case I needed more sauce and that worked out well. Â By using the canned juice, I didn't need to open more cans of pineapple just for the juice. Because I used pint jars instead of quarts, the processing time was 75 minutes at 10 lbs. pressure.If you expect this recipe to look like the take-out sweet & sour chicken from the Chinese deli, you will be disappointed. Â The chicken and pineapple chunks take on a brownish color during canning. Â The onions and peppers are softer than regular stir-fry. Â I used a little cornstarch in water to thicken the sauce while heating it up and served it over rice. Â If you can get past the color changes, the taste is excellent.It is good to have jars of quick and easy meals on hand. Â This is a Â nice change from the usual soups I can. Â I got 15 pints from this recipe, doubling the amount of sauce. Â If by chance there is sauce left over, it can be water bath canned for 15 minutes. Â I will be canning at least one more batch.

title: Rollerskates and Hayrides
text: When I was between the ages of 5 and 9, my family lived in town. Â One of the things that kept kids in my neighborhood busy in the summer was roller skating. Â Now, we aren't talking fancy rollerblades. Â This is what we had.That key at the bottom of the picture was used to tighten the toe clamps on the skates. Â Every kid I knew had a skate key on a string around their neck whether they were skating that day or not. Â It was sort of a 1950's fashion statement among the kiddie crowd. You put your feet on the skates, buckled the leather straps around your ankles and tightened the clamps. Â You learned quickly to wear hard soled leather shoes for skating. Â Skates clamped to sneakers soon raised some impressive blisters.It took a while to get the hang of sidewalk rollerskating. Â I think my knees had scabs on them all that first summer I skated. Â When four or five kids got together to skate, you could hear us coming a block away. Â The metal wheels were noisy on the sidewalk and each time you skated over a crack, a clickety clackity sound was heard.There were two ways to negotiate the curb at the end of a block. Â There were no wheelchair ramps then, so you either jumped off the curb or fell off. Â You knew which method was used by the size of the scabs on the knees.When I was about 10 years of age, my parents bought a big, old farmhouse on 20 acres of land. Â One of the first things I did upon moving to the country was to join the local 4-H club. Â To my delight I discovered that once in a while the club had a "Fun Night" and sometimes the fun included a 20 mile drive to the nearest roller rink.None of the kids could afford shoe skates of their own, so skates like these were rented at the rink.The roller rink where we skated had a floor about the size of a basketball court. Â There were colored lights in the ceiling and one of those mirrored disco balls in the center. Â Round and round and round we skated, trying not to run over the smaller kids and staying away from the better skaters. Â I always wished I could skate backwards or do the dance steps, but I did pretty well as long as I kept moving forward. Â To try to do anything fancy usually ended in disaster.The 4-H club held a hayride on Halloween night. Â We didn't go trick or treating. Â The houses were just too far apart. Â Everyone gathered at the two-room schoolhouse where the club meetings were held. Â One of the local farmers arrived on his tractor, pulling a hayrack behind. Â Hay had been spread over the bed of the hayrack and we all piled on. Â A couple of the dads, armed with flashlights, came along to keep the older boys from becoming too rowdy, to keep the younger kids from falling off and to keep the older boys and girls from becoming too amorous in the dark. We rode for about an hour - up and down gravel roads and across fields and pastures. Â Arriving back at the schoolhouse, there were games like bobbing for apples and pin the tail on the donkey. Â The moms provided treats - hot apple cider - sandwiches - pumpkin cookies - brownies with orange colored frosting. Â Each child took home a small bag of Halloween candy.I suppose all that was pretty tame compared to the elaborate Halloween doings for kids today, but for a kid in the late 1950's and early 1960's, it was absolutely wonderful!

title: Quiet Time
text: Even though that nasty flu bug seems to have finally departed, it has left me somewhat worn down. Â So there hasn't been anything in the way of sewing or food processing going on here lately. Â I am mostly catching up on the chores that fell by the wayside while I was down. Â Laundry took priority today as well as getting rid of those science experiments gone bad in my fridge.I have spent some time on my computer the last couple of days. Â It was nice to catch up on reading many of the blogs I enjoy. Â It was not so nice to catch up on the news. Â It seems the left still have their panties in a twist over the election results and they don't seem inclined to stop acting like tantrum throwing toddlers any time soon. Â I read today about some who screamed like demented banshees in order to disrupt the opening prayer at a town hall meeting Â and then continued during the Pledge of Allegiance. Â Those on the right are not entirely blameless, either. Â I understand that the favorite sport of politicians has always been to take pot shots at one another, but it seems like the mood in our country has gone way beyond mere insults. Â I'm not so sure that the divide can be mended.Some believe that the new administration will cure what ails us. Â Others believe it will ruin us. Â Most folks don't seem to care as long as they can watch sports on their big screen TVs, buy whatever they want at their local grocery whose shelves are always full or can get the newest electronic gadget. Â They think life will continue as it always has. Â Maybe it will.But then again, maybe it won't.Me...I have no faith in governments. Â I have no illusions that they are on my side. Â So I have been spending time assessing my preps and making a list of those things where I am not as well prepared as I should be. Â The list includes where I can find these things and the most economical place to buy them. Â I don't think anyone can be completely ready for whatever comes our way, but it just makes sense to me to give it my best shot.God tells us that He will provide. Â I know this is true, for He has blessed me with family who care and with the means to do what I need to do. Â I'm not talking about providing me with a truckload of money, for that is not the case. Â And I don't think for a minute that God will send someone to my door with a sandwich and a Coca Cola when I am hungry. Â I am talking about providing me with the opportunities to learn the skills that will help me and my family should our world go sideways. Â I am talking about giving me the clear vision to see that all is not well. Â I am noticing that many are slowing down on their preparations. Â Even though I feel more hopeful than I have for a long time, now is not the time to back off. Â About the time we become complacent is the time when we usually are smacked between the eyes with a 2x4. Â I have always thought that after 6 days of creation and a day of rest, God said, "OK, Murphy. Â You are in charge now."I suspect I am preaching to the choir here.

title: Sunday Memories
text: Growing up, Sundays were always a day of worship and a day of rest. Â Sunday school and church services were mandatory. Â There were Bible verses to be memorized during the week and then recited in class and sermons to be listened to afterward. Â The preachers then didn't give a hoot about your "feeeelings." Â They weren't even close to being politically correct. Â They preached Hellfire and Brimstone. Â They didn't worry about offending anyone. If you didn't repent and give up your wicked ways, you were going directly to Hell. Â There were no gray areas. Â I think I liked that. Â At least you left the church service knowing exactly where you stood.Arriving home from church, we were greeted by wonderful aromas coming from the kitchen. Â Before church, Mother would put a pot roast or a chicken or a pork roast in a pan, surround it with potatoes, carrots and onions and let it slow bake in the oven while we were gone. Â I noticed that if the preacher was particularly long-winded and his sermon went past the noon hour, Mother would get fidgety, worried that her Sunday dinner would dry out in the oven before she got home. Â I don't ever remember that happening. Â Sunday dinners were always the highlight of the week as far as meals went.Sunday afternoons were a time for family. Â We didn't always do things together, but we were still together as a family. Â On rainy Sundays I could be found in my bedroom, reading Bobsey Twins books or the latest Nancy Drew mystery. Â Or sometimes I would just sit listening to the radio and knitting or crocheting. Â  Or maybe embroidering a pretty picture on one of those flour sack dishtowels. Â My little sister was more interested in dolls so she would be in the playhouse my Dad built for her, having a tea party with the neighbor girls. Â Or we might spend the afternoon putting together a jigsaw puzzle. Â There was always a card table set up with a half finished puzzle on it.I never understood Mother's reasoning, but she believed that regular playing cards were evil. Â So in the evenings we might play some Mother approved card games like Rook or Uno or Old Maid. Â Sometimes Dad would get out one of the board games and we would play Scrabble or Yahtzee or Sorry or Clue (The professor in the library with a candlestick.) Â :)Sunny summer Sunday afternoons were a good time to go for a ride. Â We didn't usually have a destination in mind. Â We might stop at one of the one room schoolhouses in the area and play on the swings and teeter-totters. Â Or we might go for a swim at the lake. Â Sometimes Dad would just drive a meandering path until we came to one of the small towns in the area where he would find a place that sold ice cream cones.Sometimes on a Sunday afternoon we would have company come. Â Could be friends from town or my aunt and uncle and cousins. Â Dad might set up the badminton net for the kids or maybe get out the croquet set. Â Most often he would fill the ice cream maker with the ingredients and ice, and set the kids out on the back steps to work the crank until we had real, homemade ice cream. Â The best was when he added sliced peaches or strawberries to the mixture. Â We would enjoy the ice cream with a pitcher of ice cold lemonade and either gingersnaps or sugar cookies out on the front porch.Now you might say that I grew up in a Mayberry kind of world, and you might be close to right. Â It was a time, 60 years ago, when we enjoyed the more simple things in life. Â It wasn't perfect by any means, but we were raised by parents who taught us right from wrong and who took the time to be with us, whether it was going for a Sunday ride or to church or playing a game of Scrabble. Â I look at my grands and see that even though their world is much different than mine was, they are still being raised with some of the Mayberry values. Â Gives me hope for their futures.

title: Sat in my rocker this morning...
text: watching out the windows, waiting for the blizzard the weather people have been forecasting for the past few days. Â You know how they are, at least how they are in snow country. Â They get all wound up at the thought of a snow storm and act like it is the storm of the century.Giving credit where credit is due, folks living 70 - 90 miles south of here have 10 to 12 inches of snow on the ground so far, so the forecasters got that part right. Â But my little suburb was lucky to see maybe half a dozen snowflakes. Â Not exactly the makings of the horrible Friday morning commute they have been warning us about. There are many who are disappointed the storm missed us. Â I'm sure those who ski or ride snowmobiles would like to see some snow. Â The little we had is gone after a week of 50-plus temps. Â Me...no complaints here. Â I have kids and their spouses and a couple of grands who have to drive to and from work no matter what the weather and I am happier knowing they are driving on dry roads.In a normal year, we are up to our backsides in snow by now. Â That being said, here is what my oldest Â daughter was doing last week."Golfing in February. Â Awesome."She has a great sense of humor and makes me laugh. Â Laughter is the very best medicine. Â :)

title: Round 2
text: Symptoms started last evening. Â When I woke up this morning there was no doubt that the flu had returned. Â I am not alone. Â Chickenmom has also had a relapse, as have several others. Â I will return when I feel less like something you would scrape off the bottom of your shoe and more like my old self. Â Be careful out there. Â This stuff will sneak up on you and kick your behind, given half a chance.

title: Sometimes Dumb Stuff Happens When You Are Sick
text: My regular readers know that due to physical limitations, I use a grocery delivery service. Â They call every other Monday to take my order and deliver my groceries on Thursday that week. Â I make out my grocery list well in advance of the call. Â And this time, well in advance of the flu bug slapping me upside the head.Monday, while in a flu induced fog, I read off my list to the order taker, hung up the phone and went back to bed. Â It did not register with me until my groceries were delivered that I had failed to remove from the list 12 lbs. of hamburger to use in canning a big batch of chili, several large green peppers to use in canning sweet and sour chicken and 6 lbs. of butter to add to the 4 lbs. in the fridge, also to be canned. Â I suppose I could have put all of that into the freezer - except that the freezer is already full to the top. So I spent today prepping the food. Â Chicken breasts have been cut into bite sized pieces. Â Peppers have been cleaned and cut into pieces along with onions. Â Hamburger has been browned. Â All are in plastic bags in the fridge. Â Quart jars of home canned tomatoes and cans of kidney beans along with a jar of chili powder are waiting on the end of my kitchen table, as well as cans of pineapple chunks for the sweet and sour chicken. Â Tomorrow morning the canning will begin.And guess what. Â I feel better now than I have since the flu bug showed up. Â I think I must be one of those people who feels better when doing something than when just laying about. Â Granted, I had to take several rest breaks, but even with that, it sure is nice to be back in the land of the living.

title: The Jury is Still Out...
text: but the general opinion is that I will likely live after all. Â Still feel somewhat crappy and I have learned the art of hibernation, but slowly I'm beginning to feel somewhat human again. Â The biggest thing I have done since Monday is to open and heat jars of home canned soup. Â My appetite is slowly returning and I added a sandwich to the menu this evening. Â Thank you for the comments and concern. Â With any kind of luck I shall be back to annoying the general public in another couple of days.

title: Flu Bug
text: Oldest Son had the flu this past week. Â Missed a couple days of work. Â He shared. Â My own fault. Â I asked him to come over to help me. Â He is better. Â I am not. Â Headed back to bed. Â This flu bug isn't lethal - just has given me that "run over by a bus" feeling. Â I will be back as soon as possible to dazzle you with my brilliant posts. Â But not today. Â Probably not tomorrow either. Â I can be found under my green fuzzy blanket, Kleenex and cough syrup and fruit juice at hand. Â I really hate this.

title: Check List
text: Rugs vacuumed - check.Meals prepared ahead for the weekend - check.Laundry in progress - check.Dishes washed and floor swept - check.Sewing machine uncovered, threaded and a fresh needle inserted - check.Remaining weekend of sewing little pieces of fabric to other little pieces of fabric well under way. Â Other folks look at a weekend as a time to party. Â This little old lady looks at the weekend as a time to create. Â See you all next week - with pictures.Have a great weekend doing what makes you happy.

title: Thursday Ramble...
text: I think my get up and go has got up and left. Â Can't seem to get motivated to do much of anything today. Â Spent part of the morning wrapped in my green fuzzy blanket, Kindle in hand. Â The rest of the morning was devoted to reading my favorite blogs and roaming about on the web. Â There were several cups of coffee involved, so it wasn't completely wasted time.Here in my little corner of Suburbia, Mother Nature seems to have developed a case of attention deficit disorder. Â Earlier this week the temps were just at the freezing point which made streets and sidewalks interesting when the misty rain froze to their surfaces. Â Early this morning the temperature hovered at +3 degrees, rising to +13 by noon. Â Tomorrow temps in the +40 degree range are predicted. Â And after that, the weatherman's guess is as good as mine. Â When I look out my window I see a few patches of ice and no snow which is unusual for this time of year, even in my downtown location where streets are plowed and sidewalks shoveled. Â I am not complaining. Â Could be like "Joisey" where Chickenmom lives. Â She says they are expecting at least a foot of the white stuff today.I have been just scanning the headlines of the day to keep myself somewhat informed about what is going on in the world around me. Â I find myself becoming irritated at the childish antics of our lawmakers. Â Years back, when children squabbled and hurled insults at one another, their parents applied the palm of the hand to the seat of the pants and sent the miscreants to bed without supper. Â I get an urge to do the same to those in Congress, considering they are more often than not acting like tantrum throwing toddlers.Guess I have goofed off long enough. Â Time to open a jar of ham and bean soup for lunch. Â After that I think I can rouse myself enough to bake some cookies. Â Chocolate chip and maybe peanut butter. Â Chocolate chip cookies and a cold glass of milk makes the world look a bit brighter. Â :)

title: Finishing Up
text: Saturday sort of wore me out, so I took Sunday off. Â Turned into a Â slug, I did. Â Watched a couple of movies. Â Did a bit of sewing on my quilt top. Â Read several chapters of my latest murder mystery. Â Drank coffee. Â Took naps. Â It was a lovely day.Had a bit of a scare Saturday evening. Â Oldest Son was cooking supper when he fainted dead away. Â Scraped up his back some and hit his head on a chair on the way down. Â Lori took him to the Emergency Room where they ran an EKG, a CT scan to make sure his brains weren't too badly scrambled and took X-Rays to make sure he hadn't done damage to his back. Â The tests were all negative. Â The doctors decided he was dehydrated and gave him some intravenous fluids. Â A few hours later he was back home with a giant headache and very stiff back, but thankfully, all in one piece. Â Lori promised me she would make him mind and not overdo, a difficult task considering he is at least as stubborn as his mother. Â I don't care how old our children are, they are still our babies and we worry. Â I am just thankful Lori was there to help.This morning I pressure canned the ham cubes, winding up with 20 half pint jars. Â The half pints are just the right size for one person to use for ham sandwiches or ham and scrambled eggs or in omelets. Â The next time I can ham I will use pint jars. Â That is a good amount of meat for scalloped potatoes and ham or in soup or casseroles. I washed the jars of potatoes and carrots, wrote the contents and date on the lids and stocked them on the shelf. Â I had filled 34 pint jars with half potato dices and half carrot dices. Â My reasoning was that this would work well for smaller batches of soup or stew at times when I want a quick meal - just add broth, meat and seasonings. Â There were more potatoes than carrots, so I canned 10 pints of potato dices to be used mostly for fried breakfast potatoes. Â They are fully cooked after processing, so all I need to do is brown them in a frying pan and maybe toss in some onion or garlic.The onions and cabbage went into the dehydrators late this afternoon. Â They should be fully dried by morning. Â I seem to go through a lot of onions, so that is something I order in quantity at least once every couple of months to dehydrate. Â I keep a few fresh onions but drying them seems to be the best way for me to keep them on hand.And that, I think, is enough for one day. Â Time to fix a bit of supper, fire up the Kindle and read awhile. Â It has been a good day.

title: Canning Season
text: Most folks who have a garden find themselves up to their hips in vegetables to can in the fall when it is time to harvest. Â Because I don't have a garden, my canning season is whenever I find a good sale at the grocery store.This week I ordered two of those boneless half hams. Â They were 2 1/2 lbs. each. Â I also got 20 lbs. of russet potatoes and 8 lbs. of carrots. Â And I have about 15 lbs. of onions and one head of cabbage.I spent the better part of Friday prepping the ham and potatoes and carrots. Â The ham was cut into 1 inch cubes. Â The potatoes and carrots were run through my food chopper and turned into 1/2 inch cubes. Â Saturday morning I will run them through my pressure canner.While the canner is doing its thing, I will chop the onions and shred the cabbage for the dehydrator.I know that I have already put back enough canned and dried food for at least a year. Â Oldest Son has been working with me on this prepping thing for the last few years, so I figure the amounts I need for his household and mine.I had planned on sewing Friday and Saturday, but it is a matter of priorities. Â Some say I am foolish to can and dehydrate so much, but the meat I canned two years ago that I ate for supper cost considerably less when I bought it than it does now. Â And the ham I bought this week will likely cost more next year. Â And even though things seem to be looking a bit brighter now, we still live in an uncertain world with more unrest here in the States than I can remember. Â So, I keep on adding to the pantry whenever I can. Â Just in case...

title: It Is a Combination of Things
text: It seems that my muse opened the door to my apartment, took a hard right, galloped down the stairs and flung itself out into the street. Â There must be a reason for that. Â I have decided that there are several reasons why I can't seem to find anything to write about.The most obvious is that it is February in Minnesota. Â The sun has stayed hidden for days at a time. Â It is cold. Â Today the temp is holding at 13 degrees, falling close to zero at night. Â Last week we enjoyed a heat wave in the mid-forty degree range. Â St. Paul holds their Winter Carnival the last week of January and the first week of February. Â They build a huge ice palace and have ice and snow sculpture contests. Â Last week the sculptures were melting. Â This week folks are dressed in snowmobile suits and felt lined boots.I am just plain tired. Â Not so much sleepy tired but more worn down. Â I was tired of politics long before the election. Â And now that the inauguration has come and gone, I am even more tired of the childish behavior of those on the left who are acting like spoiled toddlers throwing the mother of all temper tantrums. Â You lost. Â Deal with it.And to top it all off, there was the March of the Pink Pussy Hats. Â Really? Â You think those stupid hats are going to make me take your causes seriously? Â Especially when you add to the mix a gaggle of foul mouthed celebrities? Â I don't think so.Well, now that I have turned this post into a bit of a rant, I believe I shall go take a nap. Â After which I will likely be back to my normal posts.Sometimes it helps to just blow off some steam.

title: Just one of those days...
text: that I have nothing. Â Talk among yourselves or read those folks in the sidebar. Â I'll be back in a couple of days when, with any kind of luck, I will have something worthwhile to write about. Â :)

title: Slightly Sidetracked
text: Sometimes I am easily sidetracked. Â I start out with a goal in mind and before I know it, I am off in another direction.My intention was to get out the fabric pieces that are ready to sew together for a quilt. Â While rummaging around in the tub where they have been living since I cut them out last fall, I found two bags of partially crocheted afghans. Â They are partially done because I was using yarn left over from another project, and I ran out. Â And I haven't been to the store to get enough yarn to finish them. Â So I sat down and figured out what colors and how many skeins of each color I need.Back to the tub. Â A little further down I found a length of fabric that will work well for sashing strips between the blocks of another quilt top waiting to be finished. Â Ironed the fabric and cut out the pieces I will need.Back to the tub. Â Next I found another quilt top that was finished. Â I think I remember that when I sewed this one together I made a mistake that has to be fixed. Â I looked it over but couldn't find the error, so I set it aside and will press it later, when I get ready to add the batting and backing.Back to the tub. Â I finally I found the quilt pieces I was looking for to begin with. Â I sat down and started sewing. Â This quilt is an old pattern that has just two colors. Â I'll take a picture when it is finished. There are quilters who make fancy quilts that are the kind seen in quilt shows. Â I am not one of those quilters. Â Mine are of simple patterns and are made to be used as opposed to being hung on a wall and admired. Â Guess that comes from my frugal ancestors. Â Those other quilters have studio sewing rooms and shelf after shelf of designer fabrics that cost a lot of money. Â I wait until my local Joann Fabrics store runs a sale on quilt cottons and then I stock up on enough fabric for several quilts. Â My "studio" consists of my kitchen table for cutting fabric and a table in my living room for sewing. Â I love the looks of all those beautiful quilts at quilt shows, but the thing is, I really love what I do and more importantly, I love making something that is useful. Â And for that I don't need a studio. Â My setup works just fine.And with that, it is back to my sewing machine. Â There are lots more little pieces that need to be attached to other little pieces. Â Funny...I have very little patience for some things, but all the patience in the world for making useful stuff.

title: Prayer Request
text: I don't often ask for prayers from my readers, but I am asking now.A dear, long time friend took a hard fall, hitting his head. Â After spending a few days in the hospital, in the wee hours of this morning, he died from his injuries.My request is not for him, for I know he has met his Maker. Â My request is for prayers for his wife. Â She not only lost her husband of many years, but she has also lost her very best friend. Â Their grown children and grandchildren have lost a wonderful father and grandfather. Â My family has lost one who can only be described as a true friend.Of those of you who are of a mind to pray, I would ask that you pray for the strength and courage his family will need to get through the next few days, and for God's blessings on them as they face life without him.He was one of the good ones.

title: It's a Good Day...
text: to make a big pot of chicken soup Â or...to bake chocolate chip cookies Â or...to curl up in a recliner with a good book, a mug of hot chocolate (with marshmallows) and a green fuzzy blanket Â or...to spend the afternoon sewing little pieces of fabric together for a quilt top.It began snowing late last evening, dropping a couple of inches of heavy, wet snow. Â South and west of us got enough to warrant either delaying school opening times or Â closing schools altogether for the day. Â There are still some flakes floating down, but that should end by this evening.The soup is already simmering in the crockpot. Â I don't follow a recipe. Â This time I tossed in a quart of chicken broth, a pint of canned chicken and some dehydrated vegetables - potato cubes, carrots, cabbage and onions. Â I usually add a little chicken bouillon for flavor. Â I'm thinking some cornbread would taste good with the soup for supper.â¯I don't know how much of my list will get done today. Â That is one of the nice things about being retired and living alone. Â I can do what I want when I want. Â Right now I think my sewing machine is calling my name. Â When I get enough quilt blocks together to give an idea of what the finished quilt will look like, I will post a picture.I wonder what it is about falling snow that makes a person want to bake cookies and sew a quilt. Â Whatever it is, it makes for a pleasant day in my neighborhood.

title: Busy Week
text: Last week was a busy one. Â Lori picked up my new shelving unit and Duane set it up for me. Â I spent a couple of days getting boxes and tubs of fabric and quilting supplies and yarn off the floor and onto the shelves, along with several cases of home canned food. Â Didn't take long to fill up the shelves.Friday morning the cleaners came in and scrubbed out my apartment. Â Thanks to my kids for such a good Christmas gift. The cleaners did a great job. Â It is so nice to have the dust bunnies gone and the corners that have been tough for me to get into, shiny clean again. Â It will make it easier to maintain when I'm not trying to get caught up but am starting out fresh.I had about 20 lbs. each of potatoes, carrots and onions to dehydrate, so after taking Saturday off to just rest, I got the vegetables cleaned, sliced and diced. Â The potatoes are in the dehydrators. Â The carrots and onions are in the fridge waiting their turn.I watched parts of Inauguration Day and I have to admit to feeling a real sense of relief when Mr. Trump was finally sworn in as our President. Â There has been so much protesting, negative rhetoric and outright threats connected to this event that I wondered if someone would actually do something to try to stop the Inauguration from happening. Â Aside from the expected sign carrying, foul mouthed protesters and the few window breaking, car burning thugs, the whole thing went off without a hitch. â¬I have to admit that the best part was watching that helicopter carrying Obama flying away and knowing that finally there is a President now who actually wants to work for the people rather than work to destroy my beloved America.I do fear that we who prep may become complacent just because of the changes in Washington. Â Our government is far from being fixed. Â And although the major threat to our well being is gone, there remain those who will do everything in their power to try to keep we the people in what they consider to be our place. Â I am guessing that President Trump will have to fight hard to keep his campaign promises. Â That being said, I still have much more hope today than I have had in the last several years.So I will continue as I have been doing - preserving whatever foods I can - adding to my supplies - learning as much as I can that will help me and mine weather whatever storms come our way. Â Seems like the sensible thing to do.

title: Yesterday's Message
text: I have a Facebook account. Â I don't use it to post my opinions, nor do I get involved in the political arguments I have seen springing up lately. Â I mainly use it to swipe grandkid photos that have been posted by their parents.So I was pleasantly surprised yesterday when I found a message from my former sister-in-law. Â We grew up close neighbors - she on her Dad's dairy and beef cattle farm and me right next door on my Dad's 20 acres that had once been part of the same farm. Â She had been looking through some of her mother's things and had run across an old card that reminded her of our childhood. Â She shared those memories with me.I answered her message by telling her some of the memories I had of that time. Â Like when her older sister and I decided to try smoking corn silk. Â I was about 13 years old then, and all we succeeded in doing was singeing our eyebrows nearly off. Â There were memories of a playhouse where she and my sister played with their baby dolls and a tire swing behind it that was used by all the kids. I told her about the time my Dad came into our house, chuckling. Â He said he had just seen the oldest boy in the family next door, running as fast as his 16 year old legs would carry him, across the barnyard, with his Dad hot on his heels. Â Dad said he didn't know what the boy had done, but he kind of hoped he didn't get caught. Â That Dad doing the chasing would later be the best Father-in-law anyone could hope for. Â The boy doing the running grew up to be my husband and the father of my four children. After that little meander down Memory Lane, I got to thinking about other things from that time period of the late 1950's and early 1960's. Â I wonder if anyone remembers the telephone party line. Â In rural America it was common for several families to share a telephone line. Â I think there were nine families on ours. Â There were no long chats with friends. Â You said what you had to say and then hung up, because someone else might be waiting to use the phone line. Â That sort of put a crimp in the teenage social life. Â And you didn't dare plan any shenanigans with friends over the phone, for there was always the one busybody on the line who loved to tell your mother when you were up to no good. Â Don't ask how I know this. Â :)I was thinking about TV programs back then. Â Most farmers in my neighborhood didn't have a TV. Â They were too busy to watch TV and they were content to get the weather forecasts and farm reports from the radio. Â I was 15 years old when my family first owned a TV. Â  Kids living in town had more choices of programming, but the rural areas were lucky if two or three channels came in clear using the rooftop antenna. Â The one kids program I remember most was "Axel and His Dog." Â Axel was a goofball with sort of a Scandinavian accent who lived in a treehouse. Â Axel is sort of hard to explain to those who never saw this local program, so here is a clip.My Dad loved the ending of each show - the "Birdie with a yellow bill" part, because sometimes in the last line of that little poem, Axel would sneak in something that the kids might not understand, but the grownups would surely get the double meaning.Dad would chuckle. Â Mother, on the other hand, was not amused.

title: The Sniffle and Snort Are Gone...
text: but the cough remains. Â Thought I was getting better right up to the time my cold circled around and kicked me a good one in the keister. Â The cough is much better now and I am finally feeling good enough to be up and about again. Â Just don't bounce back as quickly as I used to.Duane brought me a bag of those lovely, sweet little Clementines and a bucket of ice cream. Â Have been doing a pretty good job of eating my way through the Clementines. Â And yes, I know it is winter. Â And it is miserably cold outside. Â But I still love ice cream and a treat always seems to make things better.Later this week Duane will set up my new shelving unit and I can move cases of home canned food from the floor of my bedroom to the shelves. Â I'm using the two bottom shelves for my fabric, quilting supplies and yarn. Â I wanted to get that done before the cleaners come on the 20th of this month. Â Other than some frozen hash browns and 20 lbs. of regular potatoes to dehydrate, I have nothing planned as far as canning or dehydrating goes. Â I really want to get some serious sewing on quilt tops done.I hear about major snow storms across the country, but so far they have missed us. Â One day the temperatures are in the 20's and the next day, below zero. Â We have had only an inch or two of snow now and then - just enough to keep the roads a bit slippery. Â Duane has a good sized hill to climb going to work and he has to navigate the curves on that road downhill coming home at night. Â He tells me that hill is probably the most clear of any road in the state. Â The county keeps it well sanded and salted. Â If they didn't, there would be a pile-up of cars at the bottom every night.That's about all I know. Â I have pretty much let the world continue to turn without any help from me the past few days. Â Hope to get caught up on reading my favorite blogs in the next day or so. Â It is nice to be back in the land of the living once again. Â :)

title: The Common Cold
text: Sniffle - cough - snort. Â Yep, I caught one. Â Nothing serious - just enough to be annoying. Â On the bright side, I am doing my bit for the economy by keeping the cough drop people in business this week. Â Same goes for the Kleenex factory. Â Things should improve on Wednesday when my grocery order arrives. Â I ordered a box of Little Debbie Nutty Bars. Â Everything is better if one has Little Debbie Nutty Bars. Â :)Lori is out of town visiting her Dad, so I messaged Duane telling him I had this dead chicken I was going to roast, if he wanted to come over for supper. Â A big bowl of potato salad and some corn rounded out the meal. Â Later he showed up with a bowl of ice cream for me. Â I opened a jar of home canned strawberry rhubarb sauce, poured half of it over my ice cream and sent the rest home with him. Â The cold doesn't seem to have affected my appetite much.Don't think there will be much going on here for a few days. Â I've been sucking down cranberry juice and water, although I admit to running some of the water over ground coffee first. Â In my world, coffee is the elixir of life. Â If you want me, you will find me curled up in my recliner, covered with my green fuzzy blanket, reading a good murder mystery. Â I will return when the sniffle - snort slows down.

title: Happy Dance Time
text: I have been going to weekly appointments at the physical therapy clinic due to the problems with my feet and legs. Â Wednesday the therapist told me my legs have healed to the point where I needn't go back - I can just continue treatment at home. Â Yep. Â Happy Dance time!!I still have to keep my legs and feet bandaged and wrapped in Ace bandages and those have to be changed every other day, but the fact that this can be done at home with the help of a kid or two is reason to celebrate. Â And when completely healed, I will have a compression device for each leg, kept closed with Velcro, that I think I can handle by myself. Â That makes me even happier. Â My kids have been great - hauling me to appointments and helping me with the bandaging in between times. Â But I will be pleased when I don't need to ask for help. Funny, isn't it. Â When family has asked me for help in the past, I have always been glad to help if I could and have never, ever considered it a burden. Â But it makes me a wee bit (alright - a lot) crazy when I have to ask any of them to help me with anything. Â My kids tell me that I am just stubborn, and I suppose they may be right. Â Well, OK. Â They are spot on, but don't tell them I said so! Â But I think it is more that the older I get, the more I fear losing my independence. I have a few things I want to get done before the cleaners come in sometime in January, so I am taking off until after the first of the year. Â There are a couple pieces of furniture to be moved and another shelving unit to be set up. Â I am out of space on the shelves that hold my home canned food. Â As a result, I have several cases of food in jars sitting on the floor of my bedroom. Â They need to be shelved so the carpet can be properly vacuumed and after that I can shampoo the carpets.And when all is said and done, I plan to spend the rest of the winter sewing and quilting and crocheting. Â Not very exciting, I know, but those are the things I enjoy. Â Give me a nice, quiet winter, preferably indoors where it is toasty warm, Â and I am one happy granny.

title: Santa, Disguised as My Family...
text: was good to me this year.I have been wanting one of those jackets that look like a flannel shirt only they have a warm, quilted lining. Â  I have heavy winter coats, but wanted a jacket more lightweight. Â Oldest Son has one and I had talked to him about shopping for a similar one for me after Christmas. Â  Lo and behold, the jacket I wanted turned up under the tree. Â I love it and I'm sure it will get lots of use when I can be out and about again. Â And my daughter assured me that plaids are "in" this year!My kids are good at finding useful and unusual gifts for me. Â As anyone who visits here regularly knows from my occasional whining, I have been dealing with arthritis and leg problems this year. Â This means that although I am still capable of doing the basics for myself like cooking, laundry and basic housekeeping chores, the details often are neglected. Â Dust bunnies are multiplying at an alarming rate. Â Cupboards do not get scrubbed. Â Anything requiring climbing up on a step stool or excessive bending to reach rarely get done. So my family gave me cleaners. Â They hired a company to come in to do a one-time deep cleaning of my apartment. Â This will happen some time in January. Â They won't let me stay home while the cleaners are at work. Â They think I will try to help. Â Don't know where they got that idea, but they are taking me out somewhere while my apartment gets a top to bottom scrubbing.Anyone who has physical limitations will understand that once we fall behind on those chores, it seems like an impossible task to get caught up again. Â I have good days and not so good days. Â On good days I can accomplish quite a lot. Â On not so good days it is all I can do to cook meals and wash the dishes. Â So I think it will be easier for me to maintain a clean apartment once the dust bunnies have been eradicated and the surfaces and corners I have trouble reaching have been dealt with.God has blessed me with a better family than I deserve. Â And I Â am forever grateful.

title: Merry Christmas
text: Like so many others, I am a bit busy before the holidays. Â Computer time takes a back seat. Â My family will gather as we have for several years now, at my daughter's home for Christmas Eve brunch. Â I think this is my favorite time of year when everyone is together. I will likely not be posting until after the holiday, so I am using this opportunity to wish one and all a very blessed Christmas. Â I value each and every one of you who take the time to stop by this silly little blog. Â Your comments make me think, make me smile. Â It is like a get-together of friends with the click of a mouse.May God bless you all in this season when we celebrate the birth of His Son. Â And may the flicker of hope for a better year to come continue to grow.Love to you all,Vicki

title: A Bit Nippy
text: It looks like we got about 7 inches of snow in this recent go-around. Â And then it turned cold. Â Rob over at "At The Lake In The Woods" reports temperatures at his place fell to minus 31 degrees early this morning. Â He and his family live 50 miles away from me - a shorter distance as the crow flies. Â I am a craven coward. Â I didn't want to know how cold it was then. Â I checked my thermostat that registers both indoor and outdoor temperatures and found that at 10:30 am it was still 12 degrees below zero. I checked my Facebook page this morning as I usually do. Â I rarely comment there, but look to see if any of my children have posted pictures of their families. Â I chuckled when I saw my oldest son had posted two words before braving the elements to go to work this morning. Â I quote: "bursy toad." Â Years past, when I would take my little ones to see their grandparents in the middle of a Minnesota winter, at least one of them would ask Grandpa how cold it was, knowing his answer would be, "Brrrrrrzy Cold," said with the proper voice that was guaranteed to make the kids laugh. Â The younger ones, having the usual pronunciation by toddlers, parroted the phrase as "bursy toad," which has been our description of mind freezing weather ever since.I am happy to report that the healing of the legs is progressing nicely. Â I have been going to therapy appointments twice weekly to have the progress assessed. Â My legs are bandaged knee to toes, partly to deal with the seepage of fluid that goes along with the Cellulitis and mostly to provide the compression necessary to keep the fluid from building up and to help reduce the swelling of legs and feet. Â I have been able to reduce the appointments to one a week and go from daily changing of bandages to every other day. Â May not seem like much, but to me, it is a huge difference. I wonder when the insanity within the pharmaceutical industry will end. Â Or if it ever will. Â I realize there are folks who need medications that are much more spendy than those I need to take, but here is what I learned this week. Â My doctor sent a prescription to my pharmacy for medication that should greatly increase my chances of having near normal feet and legs. Â The usual dosage requires two refills each month. Â One refill costs $365. Â Two come to $730 per month. Â I just signed up for prescription drug insurance which kicks in Jan. 1, so I won't know until then if this medication is covered.But what happens to those who can not afford insurance. Â Those like me who are on a fixed income. Â I did the math, just to see how I would fare should my meds not be covered. Â Figuring in rent, monthly bills, groceries and the meds I already take plus the new one, I would wind up in the hole each month by over $400. Â One of my kids is facing a similar situation. Â His insurance does not cover his latest prescription, which is necessary in a life sustaining way, that costs nearly $900. a month. Â He doesn't qualify for his clinic's program of financial aid to those who need assistance because he has insurance. Â But if he were uninsured, other medical bills would eat him alive and our government would fine him for being uninsured. Â I don't know what the answer is. Â I do know that if either of us is required to pay these outrageous prices, the only way we could afford to live is if we pitched a tent in the park and lived there.One the bright side, my apartment stays warm and cozy even on the coldest of days. Â And I need not go outdoors unless I want to. Â I don't. Â There has been one casualty due to the cold. Â My herbs that have been growing nicely on my windowsills have given up the ghost. Â I didn't think there would be enough of a variance in temperature next to the windows to affect them. Â I was wrong. Â I seem to have, once again, murdered my plants. Â I was, however, able to make use of them while they still lived. Â Parsley, sage, thyme and basil lived long enough to let me experiment with cooking using the fresh herbs. Â I will give them a decent burial and try again in the spring. Â But next time I will move them to a warmer place when the snow starts to fly.There is a pot of vegetable beef soup simmering on the back burner. Â I think a pan of cornbread will go well with it for supper. Â Until then, there is a half read murder mystery book that needs my attention. Â And a mug of hot chocolate - with mini marshmallows - is calling my name. Â  Not a bad way to spend a cold afternoon here in the "Land of 10,000 Lakes," which is now the Land of 10,000 ice skating/hockey rinks.

title: Railroading
text: A gentleman by the name of Steve Boyko visited this blog the other day and left a nice comment. Â I checked out his Google + site and was delighted to find that many of his posts had to do with trains. Â I have ancestors who wrote about their days "railroading." Â My Dad dearly loved trains, especially what he called the "long, lonesome sound" of the whistles. Â He passed the love of that sound down to me.My mother's father, Andrew Paul, was the Depot Agent in Blackduck, Minnesota for many years. Â I am not sure when he started the job, but I do know he was working there at the time of his first wife's death in 1912. Â I believe he retired in the early 1940's.Grandpa Paul at work in the Blackduck Depot.Blackduck Depot. Â This photo was among pictures from my parents.I found this photo of the Blackduck Depot online.Andrew's younger brother, Walter, worked for many years as dispatcher for the M&I railroad in northern Minnesota. Â Walter was also a prolific writer of Paul family history. Â He wrote the following two stories about events that occurred while Andrew worked at the Blackduck Depot."One day my brother Andrew who was agent at Blackduck went out on the platform to hand up orders to a passing log train. As the train went clattering by swaying like a boat in rough water, he noticed the protruding end of a small log on top of one of the approaching loads. Knowing the dangerous spot he was in he jumped back to safety just as the log rolled off, landed on the far end of the depot platform, skidded straight through the bay window and came to rest with one end protruding into the ladiesâ€™ waiting room.""One day a woman showed up at the Blackduck depot where my brother Andrew was agent. She announced that she was going to Bemidji right now and would ride in the caboose of the freight train then about to leave. It being against company rules to permit a woman to ride a freight train she was told she would have to wait for the evening passenger train. No, she would not wait, she was going on this freight and there was nothing anybody could do about it. Suiting action to words she picked up her bundles and climbed onto the caboose. The conductor argued with her all to no avail. She was in the caboose and in the caboose she would stay until it got her to Bemidji. Andrew and the conductor withdrew for a consultation and finally came up with a solution. They went back to the caboose and told the lady that if she Â would not get off it would be necessary to set the caboose out at Blackduck and take the train on to Bemidji and leave her just sitting there. Even that did not budge her, so the conductor in her presence told his brakemen, â€œWell boys, set the caboose in on the house track out of the way, cut it off and we will have to ride the engine and on top.â€ So they set the caboose in on the house track, uncoupled it and away they went with the rest of the train, down around the curve and out of sight. Just as the train was disappearing around the curve one of the brakemen dropped off where he could keep an eye on the depot. A little further on the train stopped. Soon the woman in the caboose seeing no more hopes of getting to Bemidji on the freight came out, clambered down the steps and went back up town. Andrew, watching proceedings, then went out on the platform and gave the distant brakeman a back up sign, he in turn relayed it to the engineer. The train backed up to the depot, coupled onto the caboose and away they went."Grandpa had a pretty good sense of humor, I'm thinking!My cousin Gene's wife wrote this piece about the Blackduck depot some years ago. Â I don't know when the depot closed or even if it is still standing. Â But her article talks some about my Grandpa and gives an idea of his duties as Depot Agent."Living History by Leona MathenyÂ  Â  Several weeks ago, in May, the railway depot in Blackduck was closed. Â Just a little building standing deserted near the railroad. Â It wasn't always like that, just a little building.Â  Â  In the early 1900's a man by the name of Andrew Paul came to Blackduck as the depot agent. Â There were many jobs to keep him busy. Â He was the telegrapher, the freight agent, the baggage handler.Â  Â  There were four or five freight trains through town each day, and two passenger trains each direction. Â Many days a train known as an extra would also come into town.Â  Â  The first passenger train arrived in Blackduck from Minneapolis about 6:00 A.M. Â It was known as #11. Â The destination of this train was International Falls. Â It turned around there and returned late in the afternoon. Â Then it was known as #12. Â The other passenger train was a local. Â It started in Kelliher and went to Bemidji. Â It got into Blackduck about 1:00 P.M. and went on to Bemidji, returning about 6:00 P.M. and on to Kelliher.Â  Â  At the depot which was much larger then,--to the West there was a large waiting room, for ladies only. Â Just off the office to the East was a general waiting room. Â To get to the restrooms, you had to go outside and across the tracks to the little building there. Â It was a single building with two doors, LADIES and GENTLEMEN, and it had a center partition.Â  Â  On the days when the "extra" train would be on the track it could not interfere with the schedule of the regular trains so the extra would have to go onto a siding. Â Some times these trains were so long they would hardly fit on the siding. Â At times the depot agent would stand out between the two tracks to make sure the large trains had sufficient clearance, and sometimes this was only inches.Â  Â  Messages were relayed by telegraph from station to station. Â The depot agent would take these messages off the key, which was an apparatus which tapped out the message in Morse Code. Â Some of these messages were of special freight shipments coming in, or a message to be relayed to the engineer of a train which was passing through without stopping. Â At these times the message was written out and clipped to a wire hoop. Â This hoop was placed on the end of a pole which the depot agent held up at the end of the platform. Â The engineer would reach out the window and slip his arm through the hoop and after removing his message, would drop the hoop at the other end of the platform. Â Telegrams of a personal nature were also transmitted on these keys. Â Messages were taken by the agent, written up and after his day was done the agent would go out into the country to deliver a telegram. Â After Mr. Paul had been here a few years a man was hired especially for telegraphy work. Â This was Paul Whitney, who is well known in the area.Â  Â  Depot is defined as a place of storage. Â There were many things stored to be shipped out. Â Great quantities of wool were shipped at times. Â It was stored in huge long gunny sack bales until shipping time. Â Years ago the fishermen who were visiting the area would bring in their catch of fish which were packed in crates of ice and shipped home, mostly to Iowa. Â Pulpwood was a leading industry in the are in those days. Â All of it was shipped out by rails on flat cars. Â One of the timber buyers would come in and request the cars, it was always, "Andrew, you got any flatracks?" Â The depot agent and several employees were responsible for loading much of the freight into the cars.Â  Â  There were many types of cars, each with a special use. Â There were the slatted cars known as stock cars. Â They carried livestock to market, or they have been known to carry a load of watermelon. Â Refrigerator cars were cooled by ice which was stored in a compartment at the front and back of the car. Â A fan in the top of the car drew the cool air through the car to keep the fruit, vegetables, or meat from spoiling. Â Each car had a number which indicated to the agent it's contents.Â  Â  It is sad to see an era end. Â It is sad to realize that many will never have the enjoyment of riding on a train, dining in the elegance of a dining car with the tables so beautiful with the snowy white linens, the shining silverware, and the sparkling glassware. Â Those who have not had this opportunity have missed a memorable experience.Â  Â  And now there it stands. Â A small white deserted building. Â Just a reminder of a part of history we lived with."I have seen old train depots turned into useful businesses. Â Just two blocks from my apartment is a beautiful old brick depot that had been vacant for years. Â Some enterprising local ladies renovated it and turned it into a beautiful quilt shop, while retaining the look and feel of the depot. Â It is good to see those old buildings put to good use instead of being left to fall apart.

title: Canning Marathon
text: This week found a couple of pretty good sales at my grocery. Â My order included four family-size packs of chicken thighs and three boneless chuck roasts, weighing about 4 lbs. each. Â I also ordered potatoes, carrots, onions and two 1 lb. bags each of corn and peas.The chicken went into a couple of stock pots and were boiled until they were falling-off-the-bone tender. Â Once they cooled, I stripped the meat from the bones and chopped it into 1/2 - 1 inch pieces. Â  While the chicken cooked, I chopped the potatoes, carrots and onions into 1/2 inch pieces. Â All the vegetables were put into a large bowl and mixed.I put 1/2 cup of chicken in the bottom of pint jars and added 1 cup of mixed vegetables to each. Â I covered that with broth from cooking the chicken. Â There wasn't enough broth, so I got three quarts from my shelves that I had canned last year, to finish filling the jars. Â I pressure canned this at 10 lbs. pressure (for my altitude) for 75 minutes. Â I wound up with 31 pints of chicken vegetable soup, having one jar that broke during the canning process. I had leftover vegetables, so I packed them into pint jars, added water to 1 inch below the rim and processed these for 55 minutes at 10 lbs. pressure. Â When canning mixed vegetables, the vegetable that requires the longest processing time dictates how long to process. Â In this case, the corn required the longest time. Â I got 16 pints of mixed vegetables.The beef was cut into about 1 inch cubes and packed into jars. Â When canning raw meat I don't add any liquid. Â That is a personal preference. Â Liquid, either water or broth, can be added. Â I just like the taste and texture better when I can raw meat without. Â If the meat is cooked before canning, then it is necessary to add liquid. Â I got 10 pints of beef cubes from the three roasts.There was some chicken left over, so I packed it into 3 half pint jars and added broth. Â The chicken was processed right along with the beef at 10 lbs. pressure for 75 minutes. Â The smaller jars of chicken, when drained, make good sandwiches.I also got a dozen bell peppers that were on sale. Â Those I cleaned and cut into about 1 inch pieces. Â They went into the dehydrator. Â I have found that the skin on bell peppers doesn't rehydrate well - it stays sort of tough. Â So when dry, I will run the peppers through the food processor, turning them into powder. Â I can add the powder to various dishes to have the flavor of the peppers without the bothersome tough skins.We have snow in the forecast for this evening and tomorrow. Â I wanted to get this canning done before, even though the forecast is for only 4 to 6 inches of the white stuff. Â But here in Minnesota, you never know. Â This same forecast has brought only a few flakes or it has been known to bring a surprise blizzard. Â Whatever happens, my canning this week is done and I can sit in my rocking chair by the window, coffee cup within reach, a good book in hand, and green fuzzy blanket snuggled up to my neck. Â Do whatever you want, Mother Nature. Â I'm ready. Â :)

title: I Was Happily Reading Blogs When...
text: my modem went belly-up. Â Just flat quit working. Â My internet service provider is my phone company, and I rent the modem, so I called them and told them their modem had died. Â We played "jump through the hoops" for a while before they decided I was right. Â The new modem arrived today.I spent some time today on the phone with their tech support - a nice lady with a sense of humor from Nebraska - and got it sort of working. Â She seems to think part of the problem is within my phone line. Â A repairman will be here Friday, and because she thinks the problem is in the lines entering the building and not within my apartment, I will pay nothing for that service. title: Pride Goeth Before a Walker
text: It is official. Â I have attained geezer status. Â The therapist I saw yesterday has ordered one of those handy, dandy walkers with four wheels that have a seat attached so I can sit if needed when I am out and about. Â Well, crap!I have had a misplaced sense of pride in the fact that I could continue to function without the aid of a cane or crutches or a walker. Â Well, stick that pride on the back shelf and leave it there. Â My therapy session yesterday was good in that I learned more about dealing with the problem of swollen legs and feet and cellulitis outbreaks than I had learned in two years with my family doctor. Â I have another session scheduled for next week to learn the exercises and other methods for reducing the swelling.But the blow to my pride came when, after extensive questioning, it became apparent that most of my mobility issues were due to osteoarthritis rather than the lower leg thing. Â I have gotten to the point where standing for more than 10 minutes at a time has become painful. Â This is not a problem within my apartment, but it is limiting when I go out. Â Hence, the walker.This turn of events is really a blow to my pride and my desire for continued independence. Â After thinking about it overnight, I have come to the conclusion that I have two choices.I can rant and rave and throw a hissy fit and blame the gods for visiting this misfortune on me.Or...I can suck it up and learn to use the damn walker and learn the other things necessary to keep me here at home. I have decided on the latter. Â And with that in mind, I have spent the morning going through my apartment and making a list of those things that are now difficult for me and figuring out alternative ways to do them.Having a shower has been challenging. Â By the time I finish washing my hair, my hip joints and lower back are screaming at me for relief. Â I already have one of those hand held shower heads installed. Â And I am ordering a stool designed for the bath so I can sit when necessary.I have always scrubbed my kitchen and bathroom floors on my hands and knees. Â That is no longer happening. Â So I am getting one of those janitorial type mops and buckets with the wringer attached. Â Having spent several years cleaning office buildings, I am familiar with them and am confident they will work better for me than any other type of mop. Â And I can attach one of those green scrubbies to that kind of mop for getting the stubborn dried on spills off the floors.I have already dealt with the problem of lugging laundry up and down two flights of stairs by investing in a portable apartment sized washer and dryer. Â Both work like a charm. Â But the dryer sits on the floor. Â The controls are beneath the dryer door. Â That means there is a lot of bending over to put clothes in and take clothes out and to push the buttons for the proper settings. Â I found that several of the big box stores carry those storage cubes that when two of them are set side by side, the combined size is perfect to hold the dryer up off the floor, making its use much easier for me. Â Plus it will give me a handy place to store laundry supplies.A simple thing like putting on socks can be difficult when a person doesn't bend so well any more. Â Yesterday I was shown a device that I can slip a sock onto, slide my foot in, and using the handles on either side, pull the sock up. Â I will be ordering one of those devices as well as some over-sized tongs for picking up things from the floor that are hard to reach. Â In addition, any shoes I buy once I can wear shoes again, will be the slip-on variety.The purpose of this post is not to encourage sympathy. Â I don't feel sorry for myself, so nobody else should even entertain the notion of feeling sorry for me. Â I just won't have it.The purpose of this post is to encourage those who may be dealing with similar life-changing circumstances. Â I really hate having to admit that I need a walker to be able to enjoy being outdoors again. Â And I hate having to change the way I do things due to limitations. Â But there it is. Â Old age ain't no picnic. Â Some sail through without having to deal with aches and pains and others don't. Â For those that don't, we need to remember that even though there are adjustments to be made, life is still grand. Â And well worth living.My youngest son, David, took me to my appointment yesterday. Â On the way home I remarked to him that I had always said I wanted to live long enough to be a problem to my children and that I may have reached that goal. Â (That has been a standing family joke for years.) Â His response was that he didn't think we had reached that time just yet. Â He said he didn't care how big a pain in the whatever I was, they still wanted me here with them.God bless those kids.

title: Kitchen Table Folks
text: Sometimes my mind starts to wander. Â Often times these days it goes skipping on down Memory Lane. Â This evening the memories were about kitchen tables.When I was a kid my Uncle Ronnie and Aunt Em were our only relatives who lived close by. Â This was a time long before cell phones, when people went visiting instead of texting. Â The kids would play games outdoors and the grown-ups would visit. Â My aunt and uncle had a nice living room in their house. Â My parents had a nice living room in their house. Â But the place they all sat to talk to one another was at the kitchen table.My Grandma in northern Minnesota had a kitchen table next to the only window in her kitchen. Â When we went to visit her, we sat around the kitchen table while she cooked on her big wood burning kitchen stove. Â Often we would sit there peeling carrots or shelling peas for her. Â She could always find a glass of milk, fresh from the cow, and a cookie or two for a granddaughter to consume at that table.Mother's friends would stop in now and then. Â It wasn't unusual to find two or three neighbor ladies sitting at our kitchen table, drinking coffee and catching up on the neighborhood gossip. Â And when Mother and her sisters gathered around the kitchen table, there was always a lot of laughter and a lot more "Remember when..."When I had a home of my own, life seemed to revolve around the kitchen table. Â Friends would sit there for a game of cards. Â Others might bring their kids over to play with mine, and there were always coffee and cookies or cake or donuts to go with good conversation at the kitchen table. Â Homework was done at the kitchen table. Â Letters to relatives were written there. Â Pictures were drawn by children, books were read while drinking countless cups of coffee and checkbooks were balanced - all at the kitchen table.I am not a fancy person. Â I am much more comfortable with a mug of coffee at the kitchen table than I am sitting in a living room chair trying to balance a cup and saucer on my knee. Â I suppose that comes from having a long line of kitchen table folks in my family history. Â So should you ever drop in for a visit, don't expect tea in china cups. Â With saucers. Â You will, however, usually find cookies in the cookie jar and will always find a steaming mug of coffee. Â In my world, it doesn't get much better than that.

title: Quiet here...
text: in my little corner of the world. Â We had a good Thanksgiving dinner with enough leftovers so I didn't have to cook for a couple of days. Â I have been spending time reading and listening to my audio books while sewing or crocheting. Â The biggest thing I did was to run six pounds of frozen corn through my dehydrator. Â I may become more productive this coming week, but until then, enjoying the peace and quiet of my Home Sweet Apartment is enough.

title: Yesterday...
text: started out with rain that turned into sleet. Â The temperature hovered a degree or two above the freezing mark, so according to those who had to be out in it, the roads were sort of sloppy but not overly icy. Â This morning brought maybe an inch of snow on the ground. I am still dealing with some problems with my legs. Â I am not in pain and I can still get around ok. Â But I seem to be unable to reduce the swelling in my legs and feet. Â As a result, I will miss the big family Thanksgiving dinner at David's house. Â A few days ago oldest son Duane asked what my plans for Thanksgiving were. Â I told him I would be home as I didn't think it wise to go out in the ice and snow. Â The swelling is such that I can't fit these fat feet into shoes. Â He and Lori talked it over and decided to stay home, too, so I would not be alone for the holiday. Â Duane is roasting the turkey and making a bowl of scalloped corn, a long time family tradition. I have several physical therapy sessions scheduled in the upcoming weeks. Â The goal is to reduce the swelling so I can wear shoes again. Â Minnesota is not a really good place to be in the winter if all you can get on your feet is socks. Â :) So today I will be busy. Â There are pumpkin pies to make and stuffing to assemble and dinner rolls to bake. Â I think I enjoy the holiday preparations nearly as much as the holiday itself. This year has been one full of blessings. Â I have so very much to be thankful for. Â I have reached the ripe, old age of 70, still pretty much intact. Â Unlike many, I have a warm place to live, plenty of food to eat and I am surrounded by family who go out of their way to see that my needs are taken care of. Â Although my body gives out on me from time to time, my mind still works reasonably well and I am able to spend my days doing the things I love to do. And I am blessed with blogging friends who visit here. Â Your comments bring me happiness and I am grateful for each of you. Â I wish for all of my blog friends a truly wonderful Thanksgiving. Â May God bless each and every one of you.

title: Smoothies
text: No, I am not talking about those green ones that are supposed to be full of healthy stuff. Â I'm talking about the fun ones.I love ice cream. Â When I was a kid, the best day of the month was the one where the Schwan's man showed up with a freezer truck full of ice cream. Â We didn't get a lot of treats, but Dad always bought one of those big tins of ice cream. Â We took turns ordering our favorite flavors. Â I nearly always ordered Butter Brickle or Mint Chocolate Chip. Â If we were feeling flush, there might be a box of fudgesicles, too.I can order ice cream when I order my groceries to be delivered. Â But the folks who do the actual shopping work between 6 am and 8 am. Â My groceries don't arrive at my apartment until between 1 pm and 3 pm. Â I don't care how good the packaging is for frozen foods, ice cream partially melts before I get it.I thought about getting an ice cream maker, but my kitchen space is very limited. Â And most ice cream recipes call for ingredients I don't keep on hand, like whipping cream. Then I found this recipe:Fruit Smoothies3 cups frozen fruit1 to 1/2 cups milk(add sugar to taste if desired)Blend in a blender until smooth.So last month I ordered a variety of fruits - strawberries, raspberries, blueberries and bananas. Â I did sort of a mix-and-match thing and filled freezer bags with 3 cups of fruit in each. Â Last week I gave it a try and made a batch of strawberry, blueberry and raspberry. Â Last evening I whipped up some strawberry and banana. Â Both were delicious.The mixture turned out kind of like a cross between a fruity soft serve ice cream and a sherbet. Â The recipe makes enough for two big bowls, so I just put the second half in a freezer container and froze it for later. Â It isn't rich and creamy like real ice cream, but it is close enough to satisfy that ice cream craving.I love it when an experiment actually works. Â :)

title: This Girl...
text: called me a couple of days ago. Â She was excited. Â She had been participating in tryouts for the gymnastics team at her school."Grandma," Â she said. Â "I made the team!"Maddie Mae has been a dancer since she was quite small. Â Many of the Â dance routines, especially those in her competitions, included some gymnastics moves. Â She took some gymnastics classes, decided that she liked gymnastics so much that she dropped the dancing in favor of gymnastics.Maddie has worked hard to make the team. Â She has practice sessions during the week. Â Her Dad tells me she works at home to perfect her moves. Â Most of the girls on the team have been involved in gymnastics for a number of years. Â Maddie became involved about a year ago. Â She is the youngest girl on the team.Am I bragging? Â You bet I am! Â Grandmas get to do that. Â It says so, right there in the contract.Maddie Mae...I am so very proud of you. Â I know how hard you worked to be an excellent competition dancer.
