Â And I know that it has taken more hard work to achieve your goal of being a member of your school gymnastics team. Â I am looking forward to hearing all about how you are doing and about the success of your team.You Go, Girl!!Love, Grandma

title: A Surprise Present
text: So Saturday afternoon there was a knock on my door. Â It was my son's friend, Lori. Â She was carrying Â a cardboard box. Â She set the box on my table, grinned from ear to ear and said, "I have a present for you." Â When I opened the box I was astonished to find this.Lori comes over to my apartment from time to time. Â She is interested in what I am doing and we chat about all sorts of things. Â I suppose that during one of those chats I must have mentioned that after the holidays I would be looking to add a food processor to my collection of kitchen gadgets. Â Bless her heart, she ordered one for me.Yesterday morning Lori made a quick run to the grocery store and brought back two 5 lb. bags of carrots. Â They were the baby carrots, so all I had to do was wash them and shred them. Â Now understand that I have never before owned a food processor. Â If I wanted shredded carrots, they were shredded one by one on a box type shredder - by hand. Â The whole 5 lbs. of carrots ran through the processor in mere minutes! Â They are in the dehydrators as I type.Lori also brought me four heads of cabbage - two green and two purple. Â I shredded the rest of the carrots and the cabbage, packed them into Ziploc bags and stored them in the fridge. Â As one batch of vegetables dries, I have another ready to go on the dehydrator trays. Â This is so cool. Â :)When a person has a physical condition like arthritis that causes pain, the tendency is to find alternative ways of doing even the most simple of chores that hurt the least. Â This gadget is a godsend for me, for much of the canning and dehydrating I do requires vegetables to be shredded or sliced.Thank you, Lori. Â You have made my life easier and I am most appreciative.

title: A Lovely Fall Day
text: The gray light of dawn is visible through my front window. Â The sun will be up soon and the weather guessers tell me it will be Â beautiful fall day. Â The golden leaves on the trees are gone now, all at once. Â Even though the days have been warm for this time of year, I think winter will be upon us before we know it.The fall foliage was gorgeous, but something was missing. Â I couldn't figure out just what that was until I remembered that in younger days we raked the leaves from our yard and piled them on the gravel driveway, where we lit them on fire. Â The smoke from burning leaves is different from other smoke. Â Even during the years I lived in town, the air carried the smell of burning leaves for at least a week. Â It was as much a part of fall as red maple leaves and orange pumpkins and caramel apples. Â I miss the scent of burning leaves.Sometimes a person needs to just let the world go ahead and do what the world has to do. Â The earth will continue to turn and people will continue to do stupid things whether I pay attention or not. So today there is a crock pot full of apple butter cooking down and a stock pot on the back burner doing the same thing. Â The other back burner holds a simmering pot of vegetable beef soup made with my canned beef and dried vegetables. Â There are little granny squares of yarn to be crocheted for an afghan and quilt pieces to be sewn together. Â There is music to be heard and appreciated. Â There is probably a nap or two to be taken in my recliner, covered by my warm, green, fuzzy blanket.So world, you go right ahead and stomp your feet and throw your tantrum. Â Today I don't care. Â Today is for me.

title: What if...
text: I have been watching news reports about the protests and riots that have been happening in major cities across our land. Â Those on the political left blame those on the right and vice versa. Â Each ethnic group blames the other. Â It seems like no matter what a person's beliefs are, we feel the need to attach blame to those who differ. Â I don't think our country has been this divided since the Civil War.I wonder what would happen if we as a nation could act like grown-ups and take responsibility for our own actions. Â What if we expended as much energy on fixing the problems that divide us as we do in tearing us apart. Â I know this is probably just a pipe dream.But what if...

title: Veteran's Day
text: Chickenmom over at Chicken Feathers has a good post concerning Veteran's Day. Â She gives a history of the day much better than I can, and it deserves a read. Â It is my opinion that those who have served and those who are currently serving have more than earned our respect. Â I am grateful for each and every one of the men and women who have sacrificed so much for the country I hold dear. Â May God bless them all.

title: Well...
text: he did it Â He won. Â  I am ashamed to admit that I didn't think it would happen. Â I didn't think anyone could beat the Clinton Machine, what with their underhanded ways, their dirty tricks, their out and out lawlessness. Â But Mr. Trump whomped them. Â It was close, but he whomped them good.I did not listen to her concession speech. Â I thought it was a bit tacky to send one of her minions to tell the faithful to go home after they had waited most of the night. Â And I just couldn't stand the thought of hearing that voice again.I will refrain from rubbing the noses of those who supported Hillary in the dirt. Â I won't do it. Â We all have a right to our own opinions. Â And it isn't nice to gloat. Â But I have to own up to the fact that I probably have spent more time at my computer today than I should have. Â There is a certain amount of satisfaction in watching some of the media and some of the politicians express their utter disbelief that there will be no coronation. Â They shot themselves in the foot and I don't mind seeing them bleed a little.Then there are the high school and college kids who are protesting the outcome of the election, complete with safe spaces and counselors to validate their feeeelings. Â This was an election. Â An election usually has a winner and a loser. Â There are no trophies for the loser. Â That's what happens in the real world. Â Get. Over. It.My favorites are the celebrities who vowed to move elsewhere if Mr. Trump won. Â Even the husband of Justice Ginsburg was quoted as saying that it might be a good time to move to New Zealand. Â How about we take up a collection, rent a bus, round them up and give them all a free ride to the border of their choice. Â If they don't care enough to stay the country that gave them the opportunity to become rich and famous and try to make it better, then they really should be somewhere else.I don't know what is going to happen once things settle down. Â I truly hope and pray that Mr. Trump is as good as his word and he tries to fix some of the damage done to my homeland over the last eight years. Â I do know that this morning I awoke with a feeling of hope. Â That maybe.....just maybe......my grandchildren have a fighting chance to live in the America I remember so well.

title: Family Ties
text: A number of years ago I became interested in tracing the roots of my family tree. Â It is a process that I enjoy - the digging through old records to find mention of one of my ancestors. Â Some find this activity dry as dust, but I find it fascinating.Growing up, I had heard stories from family members about the possible links to a couple of famous people in history. Â My Mother's side of the family claimed to be related to the famous sea captain, John Paul Jones. Â Try as I might, I have yet to find any relationship between him and my family. Â The only remote tie I found is that both John Paul Jones and my 8X Great Grandfather were born in Scotland.My Dad's side of the family claimed to be related to our 15th President, James Buchanan. Â I have found this to be true. Â Although President Buchanan never married and never had children, he can be traced by a round about path to my ancestors. Â My Dad took considerable pride in having a president in his family history.James Buchanan has been known to be the worst president in American history. Â His refusal or inability to deal with the question of secession prior to the Civil War and his alienation of both the North and South at that time were the major reasons for his title of Worst President. Â His love of alcohol and the epic parties he hosted at the White House in a time of crisis in our nation's history did little to endear him.You might know that my only claim to fame within my family tree would be to a disgraced president. Â Perhaps that is one reason why I love finding the black sheep and scoundrels among my ancestors. Â They are much more fun than the rich and famous.I am glad my Dad never found out the history of his source of family pride. Â He needn't have worried, however. Â I do believe the title of Worst President Ever has been passed on to the current holder of that office. Â Compared to Obama, Buchanan was a rank amateur.

title: No, I haven't really fallen off the edge of the earth.
text: I've just been busy.Had another appointment about my swollen feet and legs earlier this week. Â They tell me now that I have Lymphedema which causes the Cellulitis outbreaks. Â Swell. Â Lymphedema is incurable, so there is another appointment coming up with a therapy person to figure out how to lower the swelling and learn how to keep on an even keel. Â I think at some point I must have done something really bad, for Karma is nailing me with the one thing I really hate - medical appointments. Â Sigh.On a happier note, my bread machine stirs up the best cinnamon rolls ever. Â I shared a pan of them with Duane and Lori. Â About 15 minutes after Duane took his rolls home, my phone rang. Â Duane said the cinnamon roll were really, really good. Â I could hear Lori in the background, heartily agreeing with his assessment. Â Might have had something to do with the cream cheese frosting.I have been sorting through tubs of quilt fabric and organizing the half finished quilt and crochet projects that seem to accumulate. Â Lists of needed supplies to finish each have been made. Â I think I will beg a kid to make a fabric store run for me. Â There is a Joann Fabrics close by where everything I need can be purchased. Â I would like to do that before the snow flies, for winter is when I do most of my sewing and crocheting. Â I love winter, viewed from the window of my toasty, warm apartment!Grandson Jacob, the 8 year old, has a toy that shoots foam darts. Â There are two foam darts now residing on the ceiling fan of their living room. Â The ceiling in the living room is two stories high. Â The darts are too close to the light bulbs for comfort. Â David, his dad, says the step ladder he owns is not tall enough to retrieve the darts. Â He doesn't want to buy a new ladder. Â They are expensive. Â So he will rent one. Â When informed that he would be donating a share of his allowance each week to pay the rental fee for the ladder needed to fetch his darts, Jacob thought maybe his dad could climb to the top of the existing ladder and he (Jacob) could stand on his dad's shoulders and maybe he could then reach the darts so the ladder rental would be unnecessary. Â Dad said no, he did not think that would work very well. Â Jacob has learned about consequences for actions and sometimes those actions cause you to lose your allowance.It is 60 degrees here today with clear skies. Â Most of the leaves have fallen from the trees down along the river, but the small trees along the sidewalk outside my building are a glorious yellow. Â They are usually the last to hit the ground each autumn. Â I enjoy that splash of color outside my window and am glad it lasts as long as it does, for soon the snowflakes will cover the ground. Â But I'm ready. Â I have plenty of coffee, lots of hot chocolate mix and the makings for many pots of homemade soup. Â Life is still good, even with the approaching cold and snow.

title: Homemade Sandwich Meat
text: I like sandwiches. Â Especially when I am busy and don't want to stop what I am doing long enough to cook a meal. Â But lately I have stopped buying sandwich meat. Â I am not fond of the packaged stuff at the store. Â It just doesn't taste all that good and the ingredients are questionable. Â I could get the sliced deli meat, but the prices have gone through the roof.So the other day I was going through my old recipe box, looking for inspiration, when I found two recipes for sandwich meat. Â I had made these years ago and they were good tasting. Â Both use hamburger as a base and the other ingredients are those most have on hand or are easy to find in the grocery store.Summer Sausage2 lbs. hamburger1 cup water2 tsp. liquid smoke1/2 tsp. pepper1/2 tsp. onion powder1/4 tsp. garlic powder1 tsp mustard seed3 Tbsp. Morton's Tender Quick Cure SaltMix all the ingredients together. Â Roll into firm rolls. Â Wrap in foil with the shiny side out. Â Refrigerate for 24 hours. Â Punch holes in the bottoms of the rolls with a fork. Â Place the rolls on a rack in a baking pan. Â Bake at 325 degrees for 1 hour and 35 minutes.Salami2 lbs. hamburger3 Tbsp. Morton's Tender Quick Cure Salt1 tsp. pepper1/4 tsp. mustard seed1/8 tsp. garlic salt1/4 tsp. peppercorns1 cup waterMix all ingredients thoroughly and form rolls. Â Wrap the rolls in aluminum foil. Â Refrigerate for 24 hours. Â Place rolls in a Dutch oven, cover with water and bring to a boil. Â Gently boil for 1 hour. Â Drain and rewrap.If memory serves, I made 3 rolls out of one batch of either meat. These sandwich meats are not going to taste exactly like store bought summer sausage or salami. Â But they will make some seriously good sandwiches. Â And both freeze well. Â I'm going to order some hamburger on my grocery order in two weeks, and get some Tender Quick. Â I think I have everything else on hand. Â Sure beats that packaged stuff at the store.

title: A Little Cheese With That Whine
text: So a couple of weeks ago it was a bit of stomach flu that kept me close to my bathroom for two days. Â Then it was a head cold that made my nose drip in a most unladylike fashion. Â Now that the cold has run its course, a flare-up of arthritis has made it impossible to keep an appointment this morning. Â I think I might be able to get down the stairs in an emergency situation, but I wouldn't bet on being able to get back up them.Sometimes it feels good just to be able to moan and groan and whine a little bit. Â Doesn't take the pain away, but it gets rid of the stress from nodding and smiling and telling everyone that "I'm just fine."So now that I have gotten that out of my system, I think I will spend most of my day sewing on a Grandmother's Flower Garden quilt top that I am determined to finish by spring. Â It is made up of hundreds of inch and three quarter sized hexagons, all sewn together by hand. I'm adding another row of sage green hexagons around each of these blocks. Â The quilt has sort of an old fashioned look to it and I like that. Â If I remember right, the quilt is done in rows of seven blocks each, making it seven rows wide and seven rows long, equaling about a 75 inch square quilt. Â I'll post a picture of the finished quilt, if I ever get done with it.Sewing on my quilt - listening to some audio murder mystery books I downloaded - might turn out to be a good day after all.

title: For the Record
text: The mini marathon of dehydrating is about finished. Â Here are the results.4 medium sized heads of chopped cabbage = 2 quarts dried10 lbs diced carrots = 1 quart and 1 cup dried10 lbs. diced onions = 1 1/2 quarts dried20 lbs. diced potatoes = 5 quarts driedI also dehydrated 12 cans of diced tomatoes, but I am not overjoyed at how they turned out. Â Instead of getting small pieces of tomato, they kind of dried in a sheet like a fruit roll-up. Â The idea was to be able to toss a handful of tomato pieces into soup or stew. Â I broke the sheets into pieces and they fit in a 1 quart bag. Â I think I will probably run them through my little electric grinder and turn them into tomato powder to use as flavoring.Finally got my kitchen cleaned up including the nasty science experiments from my fridge. Â I really don't know how I wind up with leftovers that I forget about until they growl at me. Â I need to be more careful about finishing up those odds and ends. Â I hate waste and I get irritated with myself when I have to toss what once was perfectly good food.So I am off to do more fun stuff like a bit of rearranging in my living room in order to fit in one more shelving unit. Â This one will hold my Â quilting fabric and supplies with room to spare for the odd cases of home canned food that I can't fit on the other shelves. Â After which I plan to spend a few days sewing and reading and napping. Â Not necessarily in that order. Â :)

title: When They Come Knocking on Your Door
text: Just a quick note here about something that happened this past Sunday. There was a very loud knock on my door. Â When I answered, I found a well dressed woman standing there with a brochure in one hand and a clip board in the other. Â She wanted me to look at her brochure and fill out a form.I just glanced at the brochure and remember it had something to do with drugs - perhaps drug usage in my town - I'm not really sure, for at that point I told her I was not the least bit interested. Â She tried to get me to take the brochure and I refused.Then she wanted me to fill out her form, which I refused to do as well. Â She was persistent, telling me I only had to fill in my name and address and phone number. Â I made it perfectly clear that I would not give out any personal information, especially to people I did not know who came knocking on my door on a Sunday afternoon. Â She didn't want to take "No" for an answer, so I finally just shut the door and locked it.Maybe I am just paranoid. Â Maybe there was a legitimate reason for her calling on me. Â But it just seemed strange that she knocked on my door on a Sunday afternoon rather than on a regular work day. Â And the fact that she was so determined to get my personal information sent up a red flag. Â The whole incident smelled like a scam to me.Anyone can go get brochures printed that look like legitimate worthy causes. Â And the main goal seemed to be to procure my signature. Â We are close to election day. Â I have read about scams that involve getting signatures to be used in voter frauds. Â Whether that was the reason for this visit, I can not say. Â But I still will never give out information to strangers. Â Just sayin'.

title: Away From the Computer
text: I will be AWOL until probably the end of the week.The cabbage has been dried. Â The tomatoes have been dried. Â The carrots are in the dehydrators. Â I still have 10 lbs. of onions and 20 lbs. of potatoes to deal with. Â I need to bake bread and do laundry. Â And my kitchen looks like someone's vegetable garden blew up in the middle of it.Add to that a follow-up appointment on Wednesday with the guy who takes care of my legs. Â He is a really nice guy, but after this appointment I am hoping not to see his face for a long time. Â :)So taking into consideration just how slowly I move these days, it will likely take me the rest of the week to finish doing what needs to be done. Â  Longer if I spend time messing around with my computer like I have been known to do.My Kingdom for a really good cleaning lady!!

title: Confusion Reigns
text: So today I woke up about 4:30 AM, with no hope of falling back asleep. Â Made my coffee. Â Cooked a couple of eggs and toast for breakfast. Â Puttered about until it was time to get ready for an appointment with a tech at the clinic. The tech did an ultrasound on my feet to check on blood circulation. Â She also did a blood pressure check on both ankles and my arm. Â Apparently even though I am slowly coming apart at the seams, my blood is doing a fantastic job of moving around inside me. Got home about 12:30 PM. Â Fixed some lunch and did a couple more Suzy Homemaker things before deciding about 2:30 that a nap was a really good idea.Woke up about 7:00. Â Made coffee and fixed breakfast. Â Dinged about on the computer for a little while and then got started on my day.Only it wasn't.I had glanced out my window, observing that it was awfully dark for 8:30 in the morning. Â Looked at the clock on my computer only to discover it was 8:30 Saturday night - not 8:30 Sunday morning.Oh, good grief. Â I wonder if other people nap for a few hours and wake up thinking it is morning of the following day.Don't tell my kids. Â They think I am a little bit off center anyway. Â If they hear about this they will be looking up the early symptoms of Alzheimer's and Googling local nursing homes. Â :)

title: About to Get Busy Again
text: Yesterday my grocery delivery service called to take my order. Â This time in addition to the normal stuff I ordered 4 heads of cabbage, 10 lbs. of carrots, 10 lbs. of onions and 10 lbs. of potatoes. Â I have another 10 lbs. of potatoes here from the previous order. Â All of this is going into the dehydrators. Â I have another 12 cans of diced tomatoes I found when I was moving some store bought canned goods from the closet pantry to the new shelves. Â Those I will drain this evening, saving the juice to drink, and dehydrate them overnight. Â The dried food takes up much less space than canned and even with the new shelves, I think I will be doing a juggling act trying to store it all.Oldest Son Duane and his friend Lori (I don't know why I haven't used their names. Â My sons names are already on several comments, so I'm not fooling anybody.) made another Sam's Club run. Â This time they brought me one 25 lb. bag of sugar and the same of flour, 2 boxes of instant mashed potatoes (each weighing 3.25 lbs.) and 2 10-packs each of cream of mushroom and cream of chicken soup.I am also ordering cases of bottled water (24 packs). Â And yes, I know it is silly to buy water. Â But my apartment is on city water. Â City water doesn't taste very good. Â I do fill from the tap the 2 ltr. soda bottles and the empty large juice bottles from when the store has had apple juice on sale. Â I moved my sofa out about 12 inches from the wall so I can get two rows of water bottles hidden away there. Â I have water stashed all over. Â I think I can fit 5 cases of bottled water on the bottom shelf of the new shelving unit. Â Water is important. Â Three days is considered the amount of time person can survive without water, although there have been cases where some have lived 8 - 10 days or longer. Â From what I have read, much of that depends on climate, conditions, etc. Â Water is the chink in my prepping armour. Â I have no place to store the big blue barrels of water, so I do the best I can with what I have to work with.I don't think I am the only one who feels like time is running out. Â I have felt that way for a while now. Â I have worked hard to put away some cash each month so I can take advantage of Sam's prices and sale prices to fill in my preps where I am low on some things. Â I don't know what will happen. Â I don't know if anything will happen. Â But no matter what, my family will not go hungry.

title: I'm Done
text: So I'm scanning the headlines this evening and I find that Wikileaks has released emails concerning speeches made by Hillary to big money groups. Â And then I see where an audio tape from eleven years ago in which Trump engages in locker room talk has also been released. Â I'm pretty sure both of these will provide more mud to be slung about.I am tired of both candidates wasting my time and discounting my intelligence in order to bash one another. Â If they insist on participating in a mud wrestling match, fine. Â But I don't want to hear any more about who did what to whom. Â I want to know what they will do to help the American people get out of this mess we find ourselves in. Â I want to know what they will do to make America as good a place for my grandchildren to grow up as it was for me. Â I do not wish to watch a couple of clowns thumbing their noses at one another crying, "Neener, Neener, Neener."Really, America. Â This is the best we can do? Â Unless an honest to God Constitution loving statesman emerges out of this train wreck of a presidential campaign, I'm done. Â Just let me know when it is over.

title: A Meandering Sort of Week
text: This week has been a little of this and a little of that. Â Oldest Son came over for supper this evening. Â His friend is out of town visiting her Dad and Son had to work so he didn't go with her. Â I had a big butternut squash from the Farmer's Market to bake and I had some chicken to go with it and Son said he would be happy to share. Â It was nice to cook for more than just me.Youngest Son took me to a medical appointment this morning. Â It was with the "wound care" guy who had taken care of me nearly two years ago when I was in the hospital with that bad outbreak of cellulitis. Â Apparently I have been doing everything right this time for my legs are both nearly healed. Â The best part was when he told me to lose those awful compression socks. Â I hated them because I couldn't get them on by myself. Â And the tops wouldn't stay in place, but would roll down a bit and would cut into my legs just below my knees and that was painful. Â He said they were acting like a tourniquet and that is not a good thing. Â I still have to wear some elasticized coverings, but they are soft and comfortable. Â I can live with that.Oldest Son and his friend are making frequent trips to our local Sam's Club. Â Each time I give them a short list, throw some cash at them and they bring home what I need. Â I am slowly but surely filling in the gaps in my food storage with the items I can't make myself - flour, sugar, baking powder, cases of cream of mushroom and cream of chicken soup, etc. Â Trouble is, I had no room to store it all. Â So Son got me another shelving unit. Â The two I have are both full of home canned food. Â The new one is the same size as the others - 72 inches high and 48 inches wide. Â He is coming over tomorrow to help me set it up. Â Which is a good thing because the stuff from the last Sam's haul is still on my kitchen table for want of a place to store it!It rained here most of the night last night but today was sunny and pleasantly warm. Â The fall leaves are turning colors faster now, especially the maples that are now nearly all a brilliant orange. Â We haven't had a frost as yet, but I'm sure that's not too far off. Â I opened windows in my apartment today to let in some of that beautifully clean fall air. Â This is the kind of day that will be remembered in February when the ground is covered with a white blanket and the wind is howling down the street and around the corner.My days are not very exciting. Â There is no drama. Â There is no stress. Â They just move along peacefully. Â I am aware of the fact that the world is in a turmoil and we as Americans are in trouble. Â I check the alternate news sources and see how much mud the presidential candidates have thrown at one another each day or how many ginned up protest marches have taken place. Â I read about the latest politically correct fad to hit the college campuses and about the spreading disrespect for our flag and anthem among some of the athletes, both in the professional ranks as well as in some schools. Â And I know there is precious little I can do about any of it, aside from an occasional rant.Even with all the garbage going on, there are still good people around us. Â I read their blogs. Â I watch their videos. Â I converse with them through the comments here or by email. Â And I talk to them on the rare occasion I am out and about. Â I have family who fall into that category of good people, and for that I am truly thankful. Â It is those good people who give me a glimmer of hope for our future. Â I just can't give up. Â I am old enough to remember what life used to be like and I need to hope that by some miracle it will be that way again.

title: The Babushkas
text: A couple of blocks away next to the river is a large apartment building, several stories high, that has been there for as long as I can remember. Â There is a street that runs between the building and the steep river bank. Â There is a sidewalk on the river side of the street with some narrow areas of grass between the sidewalk and the trees that grow at the top of the river bank. There are several Russian families living there, most of them elderly. Â Five of the ladies can be seen walking together when the weather is nice for walking. Â They walk slowly so the one who uses a walker can keep up. Â They all wear dark colored dresses and sensible shoes. Â And each of them wears a brightly colored head scarf that is tied under the chin. Â Which is why I fondly refer to them as "The Babushkas."These sweet little ladies try really hard to converse in English. Â But when they are talking to one another, it is always in Russian. Â I think it probably is not easy to learn another language at their age. Â They are so friendly that it is easy to take the time to listen and attempt to understand their broken English. Â Their smiles will light up a dreary day.The Babushkas are an industrious group. Â I have seen them working the soil in those narrow strips of grass, turning them into little gardens. Â With spades and rakes, the four who are mobile get the soil ready in the spring. Â The one with the walker supervises. Â They plant all sorts of flowers next to the sidewalk - daisies, marigolds, zinnias.Behind the flowers they plant tomatoes, peppers, beets, green beans and cabbage. Â I have often seen them out there tending their little gardens. Â They are happy to show anyone who is interested what they are growing. Â They once tried to teach me the Russian names for the plants, but I didn't do too well remembering them. Â My efforts at wrapping my tongue round the Russian words made them laugh, so it was fun, just the trying to say them.I read an article not too long ago about another group of immigrants living not very far from here. Â That group had several among them convicted of terrorist activities. Â The families of the convicted were loudly protesting. Â They were shouting about how unfair they felt American justice was. Â Threats and demands abounded.I think we could use more Babushkas.

title: It has been one of those weeks...
text: when little or nothing has been accomplished. Â I have been a little bit under the weather. Â Not sick, really. Â Just kind of tired. Â I have been napping more than usual but I finally am feeling more awake. Â I managed to cook and wash dishes and do some laundry, but that has been the extent of my ambition the last few days. Â On the Up Side, my legs are healing nicely. Â I didn't have to bandage the right leg this week and the left one is nearly healed as well. Â I would do a happy dance, but chances are pretty good that I would do myself a mischief if I tried.It is fun having one of my kids living next door. Â Oldest Son popped in to see how I was doing. Â And to plunder my shelves of home canned food. Â He said he was making beef stew for their supper this evening and wanted to know if I would like some. Â Answering like a true Minnesotan I said, "Yeah, sure. Â You betcha!" Â Said I would trade a bowl of stew for a mess of baking powder biscuits. Â I think I am getting the better of that deal. Â I finally had to turn the heat on here in my little apartment, just to take the chill off. Â The forecast this week is for temps in the 60's during the days and in the 40's at night. Â Won't be long before the trees down by the river will be a blaze of color. Â The Farmer's Almanac is predicting an average fall through October, but after that we can expect a colder than normal winter with lots of snow. Â I think I will ask Son to get me another 100 lbs. of flour and maybe 50 lbs. of sugar from Sam's. Â Now that I am back to baking bread, I don't want to be running out of flour. Â There are only a couple more items I need to stock and I will be ready for winter. Â When the temps are below zero and the snow is blowing, nobody needs to be going out to the store. Â That's what deep pantries are for.So I am off to catch up on everything I let slide this past week. Â Ah, well. Â At least I will be too busy to find any mischief. Â I may be old, but I'm not dead - yet. Â Mischief is still occasionally a distinct possibility. Â :)

title: A True Minnesotan...
text: will heat up the leftover Tater Tot Hotdish at 8 AM and call it breakfast. Â Don't ask me how I know this.Elsewhere people will bake a casserole for supper. Â Here in Minnesota a casserole is the dish used for baking and hotdish is what goes into the casserole. HotdishÂ appears in church basements after a funeral or at church suppers and family reunions. Â Every farm wife worth her salt has a favorite hotdish recipe. Â They usually consist of a meat, a vegetable, a starch and a can or two of cream of whatever soup.Here's mine.Tater Tot Hotdish1 pint jar (or 1 lb. browned) hamburger1 pint jar (or 1 can) mixed vegetables2 cans cream soup (chicken or mushroom or celery or a combination)Tater Tots to cover the topLayer the above ingredients in a casserole dish. Â Like onions? Â Toss some in with the vegetables. Â Same with mushrooms. Â Bake uncovered at 350 degrees for 1 hour. Leftovers can be heated up for breakfast the next day. Â :)

title: Oh, Say Can You See...
text: I thought about doing a rant about the football players who are dishonoring our country by refusing to show any respect for the playing of our National Anthem before the games.I thought about pointing out the disrespect being shown to those who fought, were wounded and died defending this land we love.I thought about remarking on how I found it difficult to rationalize a protest for justice from those making millions to play a game.I thought about reminding these over paid athletes that they are in the position of being role models to the high school and college kids who are now staging similar protests.I thought about pointing out that at one time the music and words of that song and the sight of our flag were enough to make hearts swell with pride, knowing that they represented our great nation.But then I thought about the freedoms those two symbols of America represent. Â They represent our right of free speech. Â They represent our right to peaceful protest. Â They represent all of our God given rights that we still enjoy today.Including the right of a multi-millionaire football player to make a complete ass of himself.

title: Shortcuts
text: I remember going on short trips with my Dad. Â He liked to take shortcuts. Â He usually got lost.Same thing sort of applies to canning tomato juice.The method I have used in the past is to dunk the tomatoes in boiling water until the skins crack. Â Then transfer them to a sink full of cold water to cool them down. Â Next I would peel, core and run them through a food mill to get rid of the seeds. Â What was left was thick tomato juice that I would simmer for 15 minutes, ladle into jars and water bath can for 35 - 40 minutes.But today I decided to take a shortcut. Â I cored the tomatoes, cut them into large chunks and ran them through my blender. Â Now, it might have helped if I had the good sense to taste some of the resulting pureed tomatoes, but I didn't. Â Not until I had blended the whole 50 lbs worth, minus those we ate.Turns out it is not as bad as it sounds. Â The result of my efforts was that I have 25 pints and 12 quarts of a cross between crushed tomatoes and tomato sauce. Â I can use this in any number of recipes calling for tomatoes. Â And if I am not fussy about having tiny lumps in my tomato juice, I can drink it as well.But I should have remembered Dad and his shortcuts. Â They rarely turn out as planned.

title: Fifty pounds of tomatoes...
text: have found their way into my kitchen. Â Oldest Son and his friend made a Farmer's Market run earlier today. Â The tomatoes are gorgeous - not a bad one in the bunch and at just the right ripeness. Â I sent some home with Son and I'm saving out half a dozen to eat. Â I thought $15 per 25 lb. box was a pretty good price. Tomatoes are being turned into juice as we speak. Â I'll be back tomorrow when I have them all canned up.I just love these locally grown tomatoes.

title: For My Records...
text: Three slightly heaping cups of chopped onions will fill one dehydrator tray. Â 10 lbs. of onions will fill 10 trays. Â The trays have the plastic mesh liners to keep the onions from falling through as they dry and shrink. Â The onions are not blanched and are dried at 135 degrees. Â Drying time depends on several things - the kind of onion - the outdoor temperature and humidity - whether I am running the air conditioning or the heat in the apartment. Â And if I use one dehydrator or divide the trays between two. Â I keep a window open in the room where the dehydrators are in order to try to let the odors escape and that makes a difference as well. Â The onions in this batch were huge - 11 onions made up the 10 lbs., so the dices are a bit thicker than if the onions had been smaller. Â I use my Vidalia Food Chopper to dice the onions. Â One of the best investments in kitchen gadgets ever.My grocery order was phoned in today. Â The store had frozen vegetables on sale. Â I am pretty well set with most, but am needing broccoli, so I ordered a dozen 1 lb. bags. Â I will keep one or two bags in the freezer for eating and dehydrate the rest.Oldest Son's friend got a membership for Sam's Club. Â They went there yesterday to look around and picked up a couple of items for me in the process. Â When they got home, they brought over my items and we sat and talked for a while. Â We had talked earlier about ordering half a beef this fall. Â Son was telling me about what was available at Sam's. Â As much as I like the idea of ordering beef, I am not enamoured with writing a large check. Â Were I independently wealthy it would not bother me. Â I'm not. Â Plus the fact that included in an order would be several cuts of beef that I normally do not buy. Â I can most of the meat I buy, saving out a little to eat fresh. Â I checked out Sam's website and found Sam's carries everything I would normally buy. Â And the prices are reasonable. Â The more we discussed the pros and cons, the more it made sense to buy the beef we want , a little at a time, at Sam's. Â That way I can get just what I want in the amounts I want. Â And I can stay on budget.So I spent part of today going through Sam's website and making out a list of what I need to get my food storage where I want it to be. Â The list includes items other than meat, like sugar and flour and oatmeal and rice as well as things like aluminum foil and freezer bags and toilet paper. Â And possibly a box or two of Little Debbie Nutty Bars. Â  Or maybe a big bag of M & M's.Life is always better if there is chocolate involved.

title: Nearly everyone remembers...
text: where they were when the first plane hit the tower. Â We remember watching our TV's as the horror unfolded. Â We felt the gut wrenching pain of realizing there were so many who didn't make it out before the buildings collapsed. Â And it became worse when it dawned on us that the police and firefighters and emergency medical people who had rushed in to save lives had now lost theirs. Â And on top of the tragedy of the towers came the news of another plane plowing into the Pentagon. Â And still another crash in Pennsylvania. America was battered. Â America was bruised. Â But America was by no means defeated. Â Three firemen raised our flag at Ground Zero. Â And we as a people came together. Â Race didn't matter. Â Religion didn't matter. Â Social standing didn't matter. Â We were Americans, one and all.Today we remember. Â We remember the mind numbing pictures of destruction. Â We remember those whose lives were taken. Â We remember the heroes of that day. Â And we remember who caused this tragedy.But most of all, we need to remember that we can come together as a nation. Â As a people who love our country and who love our flag and all it stands for. Â And we need to do so again.

title: I was sure...
text: that I would be writing this post from the hospital. Â But the gods smiled down on me and I am writing from the comfort of my cozy little apartment.Cellulitis is an insidious disease. Â I think everything is fine and then Blam--- I discover the signs of it just above my ankles. Â Within a couple of days I have large, open, weeping sores on both legs. Â The trick is to keep these patches from becoming badly infected. Â I can not manage that alone, so Oldest Son shows up twice a week to help me change the bandages. Â This is in addition to helping me with the compression socks I have to wear all the time. Â They are difficult to pull on in the best of circumstances and I don't bend all that well any more. Â Lucky for me, he lives next door and is willing to help. Â It is not a pleasant task.I had an appointment to see my family Dr. yesterday morning. Â Youngest Son took me there. Â Because my feet are very swollen and shoes don't fit just now, a wheelchair was needed to keep my socks from shredding on the concrete and to navigate hallways and office rooms. Â I rode. Â Son drove. Â He only whacked a doorway once. Â I fully expected him to try a wheelie, but he refrained. Â :)The Dr. looked at my legs, told me to continue what I had been doing as far as treating them, gave me instructions on how to reduce the swelling, added yet another pill to my already full prescription list and sent me home. Â I am not happy about adding more medication, but I will go along with it for now. Â I am thrilled to be home and not in the hospital where I was the last time I had an outbreak. Â Thing is, I really do not play well with others. Â I love being with family but other than that, I am not one who needs to be surrounded by people all the time. Â And a hospital setting is a particular kind of hell for me.So...I am off to the kitchen. Â I have a large stock pot in the fridge full of crab apple pulp waiting to be turned into jam. Â And 10 lbs. of onions need to go into the dehydrators. By the way, my bread machine works like a charm. Â I have made three loaves so far...one for me and one for each of my boys. Â The bread is delicious. Â Oldest Son says it makes really, really good French toast. Â Sometime today I will make another loaf for myself and maybe a couple of batches of cinnamon rolls. Â I haven't used the baking feature, but am using the dough feature, putting the dough into pans and baking it in my oven. Â Bread making has never been easier. Â I just layer the ingredients, liquids first and then the dry ingredients with the flour on top and the yeast last. Â Wish I had thought to invest in one of these machines years ago. Â I didn't, but I am thoroughly enjoying it now!Note to Chickenmom who wanted recipes: Â I just used the basic white bread recipe that came with the machine, but I am sure any yeast bread or roll recipe will work just fine. Â The instructions call for bread flour and bread yeast, but I just use all-purpose flour and regular dry yeast because that is what I have on hand. Â Didn't seem to make any difference because the loaves raised nicely, baked just fine and were tasty.

title: Another Grand Heard From
text: Phone rings yesterday. Â Granddaughter Maddie Mae is calling. Â There is no particular reason for the call. Â She tells me about her gymnastic classes and about her first day in the 7th grade. Â She asks what I have been doing so I tell her about making bread and crab apple jam. Â She thinks that's cool. Â She laughs at me when I tell her I stole the first day of school pictures her Dad posted on Facebook.Boston - 9th GradeMaddie - 7th GradeJacob - 3rd GradeI love it when one of my Grands calls to share some exciting news. Â But I also love it when they call just to chat a bit with Grandma. Â They live on the other side of the city and are so busy with school, sports and all the things that keep families busy these days that I don't see them all that often. Â But being able to talk with them now and then via phone calls keeps me connected and that is a good thing.After chatting with Maddie I talked with her Dad for a little while. Â He asked how I was liking my new kitchen toy and I told him that so far I liked it fine. Â He is taking me to an appointment tomorrow. Â He mentioned how much his kids liked the homemade buns I occasionally supplied for family get-togethers. Â He was of the opinion that perhaps his family should test the bread I made using the machine. Â Wanted to make sure it was as good as I said it was! Â So this evening I will make another loaf and send it home with him tomorrow.My life is not jam packed with excitement or drama. Â But it is full of these little snippets in time that make it well worth living. Â I will take a call from a Grand over excitement or drama any day of the week.

title: Woke this morning...
text: to the sounds of rolling thunder and raindrops. Â A look at the radar tells me there will be more of the same today. Â There doesn't seem to be any wind involved so there is no real threat of storms. Â Just a nice, soaking fall rain.Oldest Son and his friend brought my bread machine over yesterday. Â I was busy with other things so I haven't tried it out yet. Â But if it works as well as advertised, I can see lots of loaves of homemade bread in my future.They brought me an added bonus of two very full plastic grocery bags of crab apples they had picked for me while they were up north. Â We took a vote and the results were that crab apple jelly would be the best way to use the apples. So after one more cup of coffee, just to get my heart kick started, I am off to the kitchen to do a test run with the bread machine and to get going on turning crab apples into juice for jelly. Â Looks like a busy day ahead of me. Â :)

title: Hi Grandma...
text: the voice on the other end of the line said. Â "It's Boston."I love it when the Grands call me."I'm so excited," she said. Â "I got chosen to do a tap dance solo!"Boston recently changed dance studios. Â The one where she is now is smaller, but has an excellent instructor. Â She is learning all sorts of new things. Â Boston is a really good dancer, having been in competitions for six of her 14 years, usually performing tap dance numbers. Boston's first competition in 2010.April 2016 competition.That she is so excited about her dancing and the new things she is learning tells me that the right choice was made when she and her parents made the decision to switch studios.Boston went on to tell me that her sister Maddie was busy with her gymnastics classes and her brother Jacob had finished flag football for the summer and was starting practice for "real" tackle football."I was just so excited about my solo that I had to call and tell you about it, Grandma."I'm so glad you did, Boston. Â You made my day!Love, GrandmaThis is a quiet time of year for me. Â The fall produce at the Farmer's Market - cabbage, apples, and squash - aren't quite ready, so my canning and dehydrating has slowed down until probably mid-September. Â I did order 10 lbs of onions that are on sale, so Thursday I will get them to drying. Â I seem to go through more onions than anything else.This summer has been a stinker for arthritis flare-ups. Â One would think that our bitter winters would be a worse time, but the opposite is true. Â Maybe it is the humidity. Â I don't know. Â At any rate, Â we are having a bit of a cool down, with temps in the mid to high 70's, and that has helped. Â I have an appointment with my Dr. next week. Â They won't write refill prescriptions unless you show up and donate some blood to test so they can tell you nothing has changed. Â I wish it was like it used to be. Â We went to the Dr. when we got sick. Â Instead we are being held hostage to our need for refills. Â Sigh.Has anyone but me noticed that Doctors seem to want to just throw another prescription drug at you instead of discussing alternatives for a problem? Â I am up to four different pills every day, most of which I think are unnecessary. Â I have been reading about an herb called Moringa that is good for everything I am taking meds for at the moment. Â Including arthritis. Â It is readily available like over-the-counter vitamins. Â Has anyone ever tried this herb? Â I am thinking of giving it a try. Â I would much rather go with an herbal remedy than prescription drugs. Â Especially when there are no known side effects. Â Ever read those reports that come with each prescription drug? Â There are more side effect warnings than information on the benefits of them. Â That alone seems to be a good reason to go with an alternative.I'm excited. Â I have been thinking about getting a bread machine. Â I already have a Kitchen Aid mixer, but my counter space is so small that it isn't practical to leave it out. Â It is too heavy to live on top of my freezer, which is the only space available. Â But a bread machine could sit there, no problem. Â And with my limitations, kneading bread is becoming difficult. Â Seemed like a good solution for someone who prefers homemade bread to store bought.Anyway, I mentioned this to my son's friend the other day when she dropped by for a visit. Â She told me that her Dad was in the process of downsizing and she was sure he had one he was going to put on his upcoming garage sale. Â A phone call confirmed this. Â The machine is like new, having been used only a couple of times. Â Son and his friend are going to see him this coming weekend where he lives in the northern part of the state. Â They will check out the machine to make sure all the parts are there and that it works. Â So with any kind of luck, I will be baking bread Monday. Â Woo Hoo!!Takes very little to make me a happy camper. Â :)

title: Most Times...
text: I am perfectly content with my life.But today I am not content. Â It might have something to do with our local news reporting about the abduction, rape and murder of a sweet little five year old girl at the hands of a "family friend." Â Or maybe it was the story of a father beating his two year old child to a bloody pulp. Â Or perhaps it was just the reports of the latest "protest" in Minneapolis turning violent and ugly. Â Could have been the alternative news sources jam-packed with tales of lies and corruption associated with our government. Â Whatever the reason, I would like to check out just for today..I would like to be here...or here...or here.Perhaps tomorrow will be better. Â At least, I have hope that it will.

title: Walking the Walk
text: I have a confession to make. Â I am not nearly as prepared as I would like to think I am. Â I realized this when I discovered I didn't even have a nine volt battery in the house for the smoke alarm, and when I had to wait a day or two before I could do some canning because I had allowed my stash of canning lids to nearly run out. Â I know these are only two small things, but if I don't have on hand this small, necessary Â stuff, then it stands to reason that I am probably lacking in some of the bigger, more important supplies.Minnesota can be beautiful in the winter with a blanket of snow on the ground and the tree branches covered in frost.But Mother Nature can turn mean and throw a blizzard at us almost in the blink of an eye. Â The Halloween blizzard in 1991 featured wind gusts up to 60 mph. Â My area received over 28 inches of snow and other areas got over 36 inches of the white stuff before the storm blew itself out, leaving 10 foot snow drifts in many places. Â I have seen temperatures drop into the minus 30 degree range during the first week of November. Â Mother Nature can give us some glorious days, but she can also sneak up on us and smack us upside the head, just to remind us who is really in charge.It is the memory of those winter conditions that should have made me pay better attention to my preps. Â I am well stocked in some areas like home canned and dehydrated foods. Â I have water stored, but not nearly enough. Â And I have yet to buy a decent water filter system. Â I have medical supplies stashed away, but recently realized I didn't have enough of the supplies I needed to treat cellulitis, which if left untreated, can become life threatening. Â And I don't have nearly enough of common medical needs like aspirin or vitamins.Seems I am better at talking the talk than I am at walking the walk.It doesn't matter much what a person is preparing for. Â  Each of us have a scenario in mind. Â Could be our economy winds up in the dumpster. Â  Might be we get a bat-guano crazy elected president this time around. Â Or that jokester Mother Nature may just toss us curve ball. Â Maybe nothing will happen, in which case we will have what we need on hand without having to run to the store every couple of days.Sometimes I have been known to use the excuse of my age or my medical conditions to put off what I need to do. Â That is really stupid. Â Should my grands show up here in a crisis, (And they will. Â Grandma is the one with all the extra food.) how on earth will I look them in the eye if I don't have the basics of what they need. Â After all, it is for them and my children that I prepare. Â Oh, I prepare for myself, too, but Moms tend to do for family first. Â That's how we are wired.So if you will excuse me, I need to get busy. Â It seems I have some work to do.

title: So About 3:30 AM...
text: I am settling in to sleep. Â Yes, I know it is late, but sometimes I sleep and sometimes, not so much. Â I had just gotten comfy when I heard...CHIRP. Â Loud like that. Â Half a minute later...CHIRP. Â And it continued at 30 second intervals. Â Stupid smoke alarm. Â If it is going to decide the battery needs changing, it could at least have the decency to make that decision during daylight hours. Â Not at 3 bloody 30 in the AM!!So now I have two problems. Â The first is that due to leg issues I can no longer climb up on my little step stool/ladder thing to reach the stupid smoke alarm. Â The second is that I don't have a battery to fit the alarm even if I could reach it. Â Drat.What I do have, thank goodness, is a tall son who lives next door. Â But I will not call him at 3:30 AM to come over and help me. Â My kids say they are more than willing to help when needed, but I'm not going to wake him up just for something like this. Â So I try to sleep, but the chirping won't let me. Â I try to read for a while, but that doesn't work either. Â Finally I fire up my computer and find a movie to watch in the hope that the sound will somewhat drown out the chirping. Â No such luck.About 7 AM I make the call. Â Son says he will be right there. Â That's a good thing, because another 15 minutes of CHIRP, CHIRP, CHIRP and I am in serious danger of being driven over the edge. Â I am entertaining thoughts about getting out the shotgun to stop the constant chirping. Â (No, I really wouldn't shoot the smoke alarm although the temptation is great.)Son took the alarm down until I can get a replacement battery. Â There is another alarm in the apartment, so I don't worry about one of them being out of commission. Â Except this smoke alarm, when unplugged from the ceiling, still chirps. Â And it starts yelling "FIRE, Â FIRE" at regular intervals. Â I wrap it in a couple of towels and shove it under two pillows. Â At least I can no longer hear it when I am in the other end of the apartment.I figure the rest of the day will be pretty good, having gotten this silliness out of the way. Â But I think I may take a nap before starting anything this morning. Â :)

title: Beef Roast, Strawberries and Soup
text: 15 - 1/2 pounds of boneless chuck roast, cut into large pieces equaled 18 pints of canned beef roast.12 pounds of strawberries equaled 11 quarts of Â whole frozen berries, minus the pound I kept out to eat fresh.I'm working on cleaning out the freezer in my fridge. Â I found 4 bags of ham bones with quite a bit of meat still on them, four quart sized bags of frozen, diced carrots and several small bags of frozen diced onions. Â Tomorrow morning the bones will be simmered and the ham removed and diced. Â This will be added back to the broth along with the carrots, onions, four bags of dry split peas and some chicken bouillon for flavor. Â When this has all cooked, it will go into pint jars and then into the pressure canner. Â Split pea soup cans up really well and is good to have on hand for a quick meal.Â I also found three pork chops hiding in the back of the freezer. Â They are thawing in the fridge and I think I will use them up over the weekend. Â Maybe one with sauerkraut, one with sage dressing and another with a couple of fried eggs. Â Found two chicken breasts back in a corner, too. Â They will make supper for me tonight and one or two chicken sandwich lunches.All together, I have unearthed enough frozen meat to keep me fed for at least a week. Â Maybe more. Â Guess I should clean out the freezer a little more often. Â Ya think?

title: Just Life
text: There has been nothing earth shattering going on here in my little Home Sweet Apartment lately. Â Just the usual Suzy Homemaker stuff. Â I seriously doubt anyone cares to hear about my dish washing, floor scrubbing, toilet cleaning efforts. Â I don't even care to hear about them.The lady who takes my grocery order called yesterday. Â Boneless chuck roast is on sale so I ordered 15 lbs. Â I will cut this into pieces to fit into pint jars and can them. Â Then whenever I want a roast beef dinner, I just dump the beef into a pan, add a jar of canned potato and carrot chunks, some onion and seasonings and bake it until it is heated through.Strawberries at the Farmer's Market are done, but the store has them on sale so I ordered 12 lbs. Â I haven't decided whether to freeze or can them, but am leaning more toward freezing. Â I am down to maybe 3 packages of frozen strawberries in the freezer now, so that's probably where these will wind up. Â I really like having frozen berries on hand, especially over the winter. Â They seem to taste better somehow when summer is a long way off.Granddaughter Boston called me last evening. Â She knows that I worked at a dog grooming shop and that I have had a love of animals my whole life, so she wanted to ask me about a particular breed of dog. Â Their family dog, Charlie the Beagle, died of old age earlier this year and the family is ready for a new dog in their lives. Â Boston wanted to know about Golden Doodles, which are a cross breed of Golden Retriever and Standard Poodle. Â The ones I worked with at the grooming shop were nice dogs with good personalities, especially the large ones. Â There are some that have been bred down for a smaller size, and I can't say I was much impressed by those. Â I found that downsizing the breed also seemed to downsize their intelligence. Â That may have been just the individual dogs I saw, but the large Doodles seemed to be a much more well rounded dog and were more mellow. Â I kind of hope they get one for I liked those I worked with.Thinking about Boston's questions reminded me of another dog that was in my neighborhood. Â Henry was a Labradoodle (Lab and Standard Poodle). Â He was huge and looked like an Irish Wolfhound. Â Henry was one of the best behaved dogs I have seen. Â His owner walked Henry every day past my building. Â Henry wore a leash because of the city ordinance requiring dogs to be leashed, but Henry carried the end of the leash in his mouth. Â He walked himself. Â Henry stayed next to his owner and always stopped and looked both ways before crossing a street. Â But if he saw me a half a block away, he would look up at his owner who would give him permission, and then he would run toward me, full tilt. Â To his credit, he always stopped short of knocking me down. Â Henry loved to have his ears scratched and his head petted. Â He would sit on the sidewalk next to me, reveling in the attention, until his owner caught up with him. Â I think Henry must have moved away for I haven't seen him in a while. Â I think I will call Boston and tell her about Labradoodles.Yesterday afternoon I napped in my recliner. Â Earlier I had checked the weather radar and there was no rain in sight. Â I woke an hour or so later to the sounds of wind and rain and hail. Â Looking out the window I found the rain coming down so hard that I could barely see across the street. Â Sounded like someone was throwing pebbles against the front of my building. Â Aparently a small storm cell developed right overhead. Â I didn't know something that small could produce so much fury. Â It was over as quikly as it appeared and left without doing any obvious damage.And that is quite enough rambling for one morning. Â After another cup of coffee, I believe today will be one of those dedicated to just puttering about. Â Maybe a little sewing. Â Maybe a little reading. Â I have a recipe for soft ginger cookies I have been wanting to try and today seems like a good day for it. Â The temperature is somewhat cooler than it has been so I don't mind having the oven on. Â I like puttering days. Â :)

title: Raindrops
text: It is going on midnight. Â I have opened a couple of windows to let the fresh air in. Â I can listen to the raindrops hit on the ledge outside my living room windows. Â The temperature has dropped 20 degrees since suppertime.The rainfall in my town has been a bit odd this summer. Â I watch the weather radar online when I know there is a chance of a storm headed my way. Â This year the rain has fizzled out before it got here or it divided, part going north of us and part going to the south.But tonight it has been raining for at least an hour and it looks like it will continue for a while. Â Then behind that there is another line of stormy weather headed our way. Â If it doesn't break up, that should get here by early morning.There is thunder, too. Â Not the sharp cracks of lightning strikes, but the kind that sort of rolls around in the clouds overhead. Â When my kids were young they said that kind of thunder sounded like the angels were bowling up in the clouds.If I had a garden I would be delighted with this rain. Â As it is, it's a welcome sound. Â The slight breeze coming in combined with the sound of rain makes for good sleeping - something I seem to do less and less these days. Â I wonder if others experience the same thing - the older I get the less I am inclined to sleep.

title: Today Has Been a Good Day
text: Some days are better than others. Â Some days can be a trial with simultaneous arthritis and cellulitis outbreaks going on. Â Other days can be quite lovely, in spite of the physical limitations. Â Today was one of those.Right off the bat, two loads of laundry were washed, dried, folded and put away. Â I had questioned whether I should dip into my savings to buy the appliances, but they are worth their weight in gold to me. While clothes were washing I fried some bacon that needed to be used up. Â Added toast and a couple of eggs and it was a breakfast fit for a king.The worst of the muck has been washed from my kitchen floor and it shines as much as a cheap linoleum floor can shine.I made up a batch of brown sugar today. Â I don't buy brown sugar any more. Â When my brown sugar canister gets low, I just mix in a tablespoon of molasses for each cup of white sugar and make up enough to fill the canister again. Â It is way cheaper to make my own than buy it.I mixed up a huge batch of chocolate chip cookies. Â The smell of them baking is making me hungry. Â There are enough for Oldest Son to take some to work to share with his co-workers for his birthday tomorrow, plus enough for him and his friend as well as me to enjoy. Â You just can't go wrong with chocolate chip cookies.It will be a "Lazy Granny" supper tonight. Â Homemade ham and bean soup that I canned a while back and maybe some cornbread to go with it. Â I use half store-bought cornmeal and half ground up sweet corn that I dehydrated. Â Makes for the best cornbread ever.And then I will find a movie to watch while I do a little sewing. Â Or maybe read for a while. Â There is nothing exciting or dramatic about my life, but it suits me. Â Especially when I have a really good day.

title: Remember When...
text: that seven year old school kid chewed his Pop Tart into the shape of a gun (I thought it looked more like the state of Massachusetts.) and was suspended from school? Â We were irate. Â We wrote blog posts condemning the school officials who were being politically correct stupid. Â But then we forgot about it.There were some high school kids in Virginia who were suspended for wearing clothing that depicted the Confederate flag. Â We were mad about that, too. Â And then we forgot about it.How about the little girl who was standing, spread-eagled, crying while a TSA agent touched her where her Momma had told her nobody was supposed to touch her. Â Or the Granny in a wheelchair being humiliated by another agent digging around in her Depends, looking for a bomb. Â Those incidents upset us and then we forgot about it.We were irate when we realized that every word we say during a phone call or every email we send or every word we type is all saved to be used against us if somebody with power decides to do so. Â And it got worse when we found out about the huge facility being built in Utah to store all that data. Â Guess what. Â It is still happening - in spades.Then there is the Black Lives Matter gang. Â You know - the ones whose organization is based totally on untruth. Â The same ones who like to march and scream, "What do we want? Â Dead cops. Â When do we want it? Â Now." Â Or..."Pigs in a blanket. Â Fry 'em like bacon." Â Yeah. Â Them. Â Same ones whose leaders were invited to the White House not too long ago.And then there is the presidential candidate who wouldn't know the truth if it bit her in the butt. Â The one whose arrogance and quest for power has gotten people killed. Â The same one who does whatever she pleases and continues along without any consequences whatsoever. Â That one.What I want to know is this: Â How much more are we as citizens expected to take.And when will it be enough.

title: Bottom Line
text: There are less than 100 days until the election.If she wins, it's all over but the crying.If your ducks are not all in a row, now would be the time to round them up and get them in line.And pray.

title: Note on Mixed Vegetables and a Mini Rant
text: I decided to can the rest of the frozen mixed vegetables. Â When all was said and done, the 24 lbs. yielded 23 half pints and 32 pints. Â With what I had left on the shelf, that will do for now.This evening I was looking through the grocery delivery catalog. Â Each page in the catalog has two columns. Â There is one column devoted to just cookies and another for candy. Â Nearly an entire page listed the frozen meals and entrees. Â And about a column and a half for canned soups. Â Same for boxed foods like mac and cheese or scalloped potato mixes. Â And nearly an entire page for soda pop and bottled energy drinks. Â But there was less than a column for fresh vegetables, the same for fresh fruit and only 10 items listed for fish, and most of them were the frozen kind where there is more batter than meat.This service is for Seniors. Â I was told that the catalog was put together going by what people had ordered in the past. Â I am surprised that more of my vintage don't cook from scratch. Â We are retired. Â We have the time. Â And most of us were raised by mothers who made nearly everything from scratch. Â Many of us gardened or had parents who raised vegetables. Â When I was growing up, small family farms dotted the countryside. Â Folks raised chickens and hogs and had a milk cow or two and raised one or two steers for butchering. Â Unless your Mama was a really bad cook, the food we ate was good tasting and healthy.I wonder what happened. Â I know that there are some who just don't like to cook. Â I have days like that myself, especially if I am busy. Â But truth be known, I would much rather eat my homemade baking powder biscuits than those that come in a cardboard tube from the store, even if it does take a little time and effort to make them. Â Same with homemade bread. Â And homemade soup that simmers all day on the back burner rather than just opening a can and heating that up.I don't know. Â Maybe I should have been born into my grandparents generation. Â Sometimes I don't think I fit too well in this one.I think I told you a while back about the changes in my grocery delivery service. Â  They have put out a catalog and I can only order what is included in it. Â While it is substantial, that means if a specific item is on sale but not in the catalog, I can not order the sale item. Â Much of what I normally order is included, but there are items I can no longer have delivered.This week, for instance, two pound bags of frozen vegetables are on sale. Â Unfortunately, the catalog lists only one pound bags. Â And that is where an angel of mercy came to my rescue. Â Oldest Son's friend who lives with him now, said she would not mind a bit going to the store to get the sale items I can no longer order. Â So this morning I tossed some cash and a list in her direction and off she went.She brought me 24 lbs. of mixed vegetables and 12 lbs. of green beans, along with a couple other small items. Â When she brought them to me, it was then I realized I had not taken the weight of the vegetables into consideration. Â There she was, poor girl, outside my door, all knackered out from lugging them up the stairs. Â And she was still cheerful, bless her heart.The green beans are in the dehydrators. Â 12 lbs. of mixed vegetables are in my big stock pot on the stove, thawing out and heating up. Â As soon as I see how many pints I get out of that, I'll decide whether to can the other 12 lbs. or dehydrate them.I know that for gardeners, it must seem like a sacrilege to be canning frozen vegetables. Â I would prefer canning fresh from the garden as well. Â But if I want my shelves of home canned foods to be full, I will do whatever is necessary to achieve that goal. Â And should the time come when store shelves are empty, I doubt anyone will care about whether the vegetables started out as garden fresh or frozen. Â I would think they would be happy to have food to eat when others do not, no matter what the source.

title: The Herbs Are Still Alive
text: A while back I had started some herbs from seed in little grow pots. Â When the plants were big enough I transplanted them into seven large pots and set them on my windowsills. Â At which point they all keeled over and died.Because I have a stubborn streak and do not give up easily, I replanted the herbs directly into the large pots. Â I watered the seeds in and set the pots back on the windowsills. Â And lo and behold, I have seven pots, each with green, growing plants. Â Two pots of parsley. Â One each of thyme, basil, sage, cilantro and oregano. Â The oregano is slow to sprout, but this morning I found half a dozen tiny plants poking through the soil. Â That counts, doesn't it?Every third day I give each pot a drink of a pint of water. Â They seem to be thriving on that. Â And I stuck up a sign where I will see it every day that says, "Don't murder them. Â Water them."Now if I can just keep them alive.....

title: About the time I'm feeling grumpy...
text: my kids make me smile.Youngest Son called this afternoon. Â  Their family Beagle had passed on earlier this year and they all are ready for another dog. Â He had found a rescue group that had puppies so he had filled out the paperwork and sent in the processing fee. Â He said he liked this particular group because they put their rescues into foster homes rather than keeping them penned up. Â There was a little Corgi cross puppy there and Son wanted to know if I knew anything about the breed. Â  Sadly, I know nothing. Â He wanted me to go online and take a look at the picture of the pup, so I did. Â Cuter than a bug's ear, he is. Â I don't know if this is the one they will get, but puppies always make me smile.Then this afternoon Oldest Son stopped by to bring me my mail. Â And a slice of rhubarb pie. Â It took every ounce of willpower I had to wait until after supper to eat it. Â I don't think I have had rhubarb pie since I was a kid. Â Sure brought back memories of the pies Mother made. Â It was worth the wait.I guess it doesn't take much to un-grump me.....a puppy picture and a piece of pie. Â It's more than that, though. Â  Youngest Son was telling me about an incident with one of the landscaping crews he manages. Â They noticed something wrong at one of the townhouse complexes where they were working on the shrubs around the home. Â I won't go into detail here, but it was unusual enough so that one of the crew called the police. Â Turns out the old man who lived in that townhouse had died maybe a month earlier. Â Nobody knew and apparently nobody missed him. I don't see or talk to my kids every day. Â They all are working and they all are busy with their own lives. Â But it is reassuring to know that not more than a day or so would go by before one of them would check to see why I didn't answer my phone. Â And that knowledge tends to make a case of the grumpies disappear probably quicker than puppies or rhubarb pie do. Â :)

title: Mushy Pears
text: The summer of 2012 I canned what seemed like a truck load of pears. Â I ate canned pears. Â My kids ate canned pears. Â I made cakes and muffins and cobblers using pears. Â They were delicious.Then sometime within the past year the pears turned soft in the jars. Â They were still good. Â The seals on the lids were intact. Â But the fruit had softened enough so I wasn't overjoyed with the texture. Â I like a bit more firmness in canned pears.So what do you do with 16 pints of soft pears. Â I am too frugal (read cheap) to just toss them out. Â I thought about making pear butter, but my supply of canning jars is dwindling and I still have several foods left to can before winter sets in, so I kept looking for ideas. Â Then I found a couple of videos showing how to make fruit rollups from canned fruit. I have 5 fruit rollup inserts for my dehydrator trays and even though I had never made rollups before, I decided to give it a go.I opened all the jars and drained off the liquid. Â I had 4 pints of canned peaches left that had been canned about the same time as the pears, so I drained them as well, rinsing the fruit with water to wash off most of the sugar/water syrup they had been canned in, making them less sticky. Â I ran the fruit through my blender to make a puree and filled 5 trays. Â Each tray holds two cups of fruit puree. Â I still have two quarts of puree in the fridge to dehydrate tomorrow.The fruit is drying nicely, but it is taking longer to dehydrate than expected. Â I suppose that may be due to the high humidity in the air right now. Â I will just turn the temperature down from 130 degrees to 100 degrees and let the fruit dry overnight. Â  The plan is to wrap the dried fruit rollups in waxed paper. Â I will save out a few pieces for snacking and freeze the rest. Â I think the pear rollups will make a nice evening snack for me or a tasty, healthy treat for the Grands.I read somewhere that about 40 % of the food in the US is wasted. Â I grew up in a frugal family. Â We wasted very little. Â We couldn't afford to just toss out leftovers. Â I will admit that once in a while a container of food will get shoved to the back of my fridge where it winds up looking like a science experiment run amok, but I try really hard to use up everything I cook. Â I'm glad I was able to find a good use for those pears. Â And there is the added bonus of having another 20 empty pint jars now to fill with something else. Â  I'm thinking a big pot of chili might be good.

title: Hot...
text: Those living in the south have been putting up with the heat this summer. Â Here in the middle of the north country we have been lucky...until today. Â The temperature is predicted to be sneaking up to nearly 100 degrees with a heat index of 105 - 115. Â Today will be a quiet day for me. Â Heat is not my friend.I have to feel sorry for the guy who delivers my groceries today. Â Knowing that the temps would be in the "OMG it is hot!" range, I refrained from ordering heavy stuff like cases of bottled water or lots of canned goods. Those people are volunteers and without them it would be tough for me to grocery shop these days. Â I order what I need, but I also try to keep in mind the fact that hauling boxes of groceries up the stairs, especially when it is hot and humid, is no picnic.I don't know why this happens, but it seems when the outside temps and humidity are high, it affects my arthritic joints even though my apartment is air conditioned. Â So early this morning I finished the few household chores that needed my attention. Â My crockpot is getting a workout this week. Â It is the best way to cook without heating up the kitchen. Â Last night was chicken breast. Â Today there is a pot of vegetable beef soup simmering all day. Â I may toss in some dumplings close to supper time. Â Anything else requiring using my stove or oven will just have to wait until it cools down some.So I think I will find a couple of movies to watch on YouTube. Â I saw a pattern for a crocheted afghan that is made of 2 1/2 inch Granny Squares in all sorts of colors, kind of like a scrap quilt, and I started working on that a couple of weeks ago, using the leftover yarn from other projects. Â If I sit and make some more squares I can fool myself into thinking I didn't waste an entire day. Â :)

title: Sometimes...
text: you get more than you bargained for.My cleaning and decluttering frenzy had some unexpected results. Â When I get busy canning I sometimes just stick the jars of food on my shelves willy nilly just to get them out of the way. Â The shelves are now nicely organized. Â I found that I have one entire shelf ( 48 inches long by 18 inches deep) of just chicken. Â Either I am the poster child for buying chicken on sale or my memory has deteriorated to the point where I don't remember just how much chicken I have canned. Â Anyway, I have left open spaces to fill in the foods I am getting low on. Â But basically both shelving units (same size shelves, six per unit) are full.And the jams and jellies are in another cupboard.And I haven't canned pickles yet. Â Or cheese sauce. Â Or soup. Â Or chili.I gotta buy another shelving unit. Â I found one that is the same brand as the two I already have. Â It is 36 inches long with the shelves at 18 inches deep. Â I think it will fit in a corner of my living room. Â I can hang a quilt on it for camouflage. Â  Â Oldest Son said he would pick it up for me and help me put it together. Â We are supposed to get hot and humid weather starting tomorrow, so I think I will wait until it cools down some. Â I don't like to can when it is so hot. Â It doesn't take much to make this little apartment steamy. Â And Son is no spring chicken any more. Â Huffing 75 lbs. of shelving in a box up the stairs will be a bit easier if the stairway isn't over 90 degrees warm.I am not complaining, mind you. Â I am delighted to have my shelves overflowing with canned food. Â I use it on a regular basis.
