Â When the weather is hot like this, it is nice to be able to open a jar of soup, heat it up in the microwave and keep the apartment cool. Â Other times I always have the makings of a meal just by opening a jar or two. Â That's what my parents and grandparents did. Â I think they were on to something. Â :)

title: They Took the Kids to Yellowstone
text: I still have another day or two before I am back to regular posting, so I thought I would give you something pretty to look at in the meantime. Â Youngest Son and his lovely wife took my Grands on vacation to Yellowstone. Â He called me a couple of times to let me know what they were doing and they posted pictures on FB of each days activities. Â I enjoyed the pictures and thought you might like them Â too.Everyone is excited to be heading out.Bison in the background.They got to see these bison up close.They took a zip line ride. Â Jacob insisted on going upside down.Boston couldn't let her brother get one up on her.Dad had to show off, too.Mom and Maddie were a bit more sensible.Judging by the grin, I'd say Maddie was having fun.They went on nature hikes.They hiked to Ousel Falls.Couldn't go to Yellowstone without seeing Old Faithful.Waiting...The kids were thrilled with the white water rafting. Â They took a ferry across Lake Jenny and then hiked up to Inspiration Point. Â Son said that hike about did him in!They took time to just relax and enjoy the view.They stopped to marvel at the beauty of the Grand Tetons.They visited Mount Rushmore.It was fun to see the sights, but it was nice to be home again too.It does a Grandma's heart good to see her grandchildren getting out to see the wonders of nature. Â Viewing the world on a screen just can not compare to the sights and sounds and smells of the great outdoors. Â Boston, Maddie and Jacob...I'm so glad you had such a great vacation. Â David and Staci...thank you for giving my Grands such wonderful memories.Love, Mom (Grandma)

title: Taking a Break
text: It is time to get my house in order. Â My kitchen required a bit of rearrangement to accommodate the new appliances, so that needs straightening. Â I killed the herbs so they need to be replanted. Â There are various and assorted items that have not been used for years that need to go live in the dumpster. Â There are quilt tops that need batting and backing, so those need to be ordered and other quilts in various stages of completion that need my attention. Â Carpets need cleaning and windows need washing. Â I have let things slide longer than I should have.I move much slower than I once did. Â So I know it will take more time than I would like to get my house back to where I am comfortable with its condition. Â With any kind of luck, I'll be back in a week or so. Â If you don't hear from me then, send in the rescue squad. Â That will be me, buried under a pile of canning jars and quilt pieces. Â :)

title: I have always known...
text: that the elite play by a different set of rules. Â That the laws that apply to me do not apply to them. But never before today have I had my face rubbed in it quite to this degree.Perhaps it is past time to get our ducks all in a row.

title: Washer - Dryer - Success
text: Both the new appliances work well. Â Clothes are clean. Â The dryer takes about as long as you would expect a small dryer to take. Â I've been staying close to make sure there are no washer leaks. Â So far I am well pleased. Â Four loads of clothes done and I didn't need to climb any stairs. Â Life has just gotten better.The only problem I had was in hooking up the dryer vent hose. Â Two clamps came with the machine for that purpose. Â They are pretty much useless. Â Grabbed a roll of duct tape. Â Problem solved.Red Green would be proud. Â :)

title: Know what I'm doing today?
text: Nuthin.Perhaps by tomorrow I will find some energy somewhere. Â But just for today, I am living in the world of the lazy. It's Great!

title: Done...For Now
text: Finished up with the strawberries this afternoon. Â Once they were cleaned and put into zip lock bags, there were 5 gallons of berries. Â Son had taken some home with him and I ate a couple of bowls full before bagging them to store in the fridge. Â Out of that 5 gallons I got 20 half pint jars of strawberry jam, 22 half pints of strawberry rhubarb sauce and 11 pints of canned strawberries. Â I'm thinking they will taste awfully good when the snow is falling and the wind is blowing about February.So I am done canning and dehydrating for now...unless I find a good sale on something to can or dry. Â Peak season on cucumbers, bell peppers and tomatoes at the Farmers Market is in August. Â I think there are some dill pickles in my future as well as a good stash of my favorite bread and butters. Â Many times we think only about storing the basics - sugar, flour, beans, etc. Â But I believe it is also necessary to have on hand those things like jam or pickles or even candy to keep from getting totally burned out on food should the time come when our only option is what we have in our food storage. Â A little treat goes long way to help make life tolerable sometimes.

title: Tis the Season...
text: for canning. Â I finished canning the meat from my last grocery order. Â Wound up with 19 pints of hamburger, 12 pints of chicken and 6 pints of pork. Â I was disappointed in the Â quality of the boneless country ribs. Â There was way too much fat on them, unlike others I had ordered in the past. Â That's the down side of ordering groceries. Â Sometimes the quality is less than you would like. Â Anyway, I decided to bake the pork and shred it when done. Â The fat was easier to remove this way. Â Then I stirred in some barbecue sauce and canned it as barbecued pork for sandwiches. Â I would rather have worked on the canning when our temperatures weren't in the 90's, but I just don't think, considering our uncertain world, that waiting is an option.A dozen bell peppers and 20 lbs. of carrots made their way through the dehydrators and are packaged up and on the shelves.Oldest Son did a Farmer's Market run this morning and showed up with two and a half flats of strawberries and some rhubarb that will turn into strawberry jam, strawberry rhubarb sauce and strawberries in syrup. There are several Farmer's Markets in our area, but the one we like is in St. Paul. Â They have a website that includes a list of the produce and dates when it is available, so we are checking that weekly to make sure we are able to get what we need. Â By the end of the season I hope to have everything I need canned, dried and on the shelves. I haven't had a chance to try out my washer and dryer as yet. Â That will just have to wait until preserving the food I have here right now is completed. Â It just seems to me that things are sliding downhill a bit faster now. Â I am not in panic mode, but I do think it would be foolish let an opportunity go by to add to my food storage. So I am off to the kitchen to hull some strawberries in preparation for another canning session tomorrow morning. Â I think I will take my laptop with me and listen to an audio book while working. Â Cleaning berries and a good murder mystery. Â What a combination!

title: Doing The Happy Dance
text: Anyone who reads here regularly knows that my mobility is not what it once was. Â Stairs can be difficult at times. Â Two flights of stairs to the laundry room in my building can be particularly challenging. Â And because I prefer clean clothes rather than dirty ones, I decided some months back to do something about my laundry situation.I did some online research and found there are apartment sized washers and dryers that do not require special plumbing or special electrical hook-ups. Â I compared prices and found a decent price from a place that would also deliver. Â It isn't easy to find a store that will deliver to a second floor apartment in a building without an elevator. Â But I found one locally.Then I started saving. Â Every dollar I could squeeze out of the budget went in the washer-dryer fund. Â It took some time, but I reached my goal.Today these little beauties were delivered.They are small, but once my laundry is caught up, I won't have much to wash each week. Â The washer is on casters so I can roll it up to the kitchen sink to use it and roll it back out of the way when not in use. Â The dryer has an additional kit that makes it possible to use it without having to vent it outside.Oldest Son says he will help me get them all set up. Â That won't be for a couple of days, however. Â I have bell peppers in the dehydrator now and have 20 lbs. of carrots to get to drying tomorrow morning. Â There is also chicken, pork and hamburger to can. Â My freezer is full, so the canning needs to be done right away.Nonetheless, I am giddy with excitement. Â These new appliances not only will make life easier for me, but they represent just one more thing that will enable me to hang on to my independence a bit longer. Â I know that if I asked, my kids would do my laundry for me. Â But I am so much happier when I can do things for myself.I'm kind of stubborn that way. Â Or so I have been told. Â :)

title: So last evening...
text: the fellow who calls me for my grocery order was telling me about some changes in the way their organization does things. Â Instead of the order takers having to sift through the entire inventory of the big box store to find one item, they are issuing a catalog listing the products available for ordering. Â While that may limit some of my selections, it will make it easier and faster to place an order. Â I am not concerned. Â Oldest Son calls me maybe once a week while on his way home from work to see if I need anything, so if I can't order something I want, I'm pretty certain he will pick up anything I need.Normally I place a grocery order every two weeks, but what with getting the order taker's computers changed over to the new catalog program and getting a new delivery schedule set up, it will be one month before I order groceries again. Â  Chuck (my order taker) wanted to know if the delay would be a problem for me, and then he started to laugh. Â When I asked him what was so funny, he replied that he had been taking my grocery orders for quite some time now and he knew my grocery buying habits. Â He said he was pretty sure that my pantry was well stocked enough to see me through longer than just a month. Â He told me that he had changed the way he and his wife shop largely because of our conversations about the way I shop for groceries. Â It is gratifying to know that there are still folks out there who can see the benefits of a deep pantry.The new schedule will give me a new order taker. Â I am going to miss talking with Chuck every other Monday evening. Â I know the sound of his wife's voice from hearing her in the background. Â I know that his little dog waits until he is on the phone before barking at squirrels outside their window. Â He has asked me how to can hamburger and I now have his recipe for sour dough starter. Â He left messages of concern when I didn't answer my phone while I was in the hospital. Â I worried about him when I found out he had a broken hip after a fall on the ice.It is reassuring to know there are still good people out there in the midst of all the hate and discontent and insanity surrounding us. Â It is possible to develop friendships with folks you haven't met in person.Kind of like those I have met right here on this silly little blog.I had planted herb seeds in starter pots. Â They all came up. Â Looked so pretty and green. Â When they were big enough I transplanted them into larger pots and set them on my window sills. Â At which point most of them just laid down and died.I can grow just about anything in a garden. Â But I'll be darned if I can keep a plant alive indoors. Â I baby them. Â I am careful not to over water them or under water them. Â I even talk to them. Â Tell them how pretty they are. Â Doesn't matter. Â They just won't grow for me.There are a few stragglers left and they look pretty sad. Â So I'm going to give it one more try and plant the rest of my seeds directly in the larger pots. Â And if that doesn't work I will just pack up the whole kit and kaboodle until next spring when I will buy starter plants.Sigh.

title: He Was My Dad
text: He taught me how to change a tire and jump start a battery. Â He showed me the proper way to paint a house. Â He shared with me his love of gardening and of all growing things. Â He made sure I knew how to safely handle firearms. Â When using tools like a hammer or saw, he would hand the tool to me and say, "Here, you try it." By example he showed me what honesty and integrity was all about. Â His work ethic was second to none. Â His handshake was as good as any written contract.He wasn't perfect. Â None of us are. Â He told the dumbest jokes on the planet, the kind that make you groan. Â He held opinions that were not even close to being politically correct. Â But he loved me unconditionally no matter what stupid thing I did. Â  And I knew I could always go home.Happy Father's Day, Dad. Â I love and miss you so very much.

title: All is well...
text: here in my little Home Sweet Apartment. Â The weather has been a bit unsettled with days of sunshine and rain now and then. Â There have been pockets of stormy weather, but so far they have fizzled out before getting to my town, or they have veered off and gone around us. Â It is kind of sunny - hazy today with the temp hovering around the 90 degree mark. Â Tomorrow should be interesting with temps predicted in the 95 to 100 degree range, followed by storms. Â Even though I have good air conditioning in my building, I won't be doing anything too strenuous. I am finished with the dehydrating of vegetables from my last grocery delivery. Â Everything turned out just fine, but I wasn't thrilled with the dried grapes. Â They were kind of a sticky mess. Â Others have had good results with drying grapes, but I don't think I will mess with it again. Â While sorting out my closet pantry I found 10 of the large cans of diced tomatoes (not the # 10 cans, but the ones that are bigger than a regular can). Â Because storage space is at a premium I drained the tomatoes and dehydrated them. Â They dried down to fit in a quart sized freezer bag. Â Draining them gave me three quarts of tomato juice. Â I am drinking one of them and froze the other two to use in soup.I was thinking about using the four large drawers in the base of my new bed for fabric and yarn storage. Â But while going through my pantry I realized that boxed mixes I have bought on sale were taking up room that could be better used for other things. Â And yes, I buy mixes from time to time when the prices are really good. Â I have cake and brownie mixes, scalloped potato mixes and (God forgive me) hamburger helper mixes. Â There are also flavored rice sides and muffin mixes. Â I know all the reasons for avoiding boxed mixes and for cooking from scratch. Â And most times I do. Â But sometimes, especially when the aging process has thrown me a curve and made it difficult to stand for long periods of time while cooking and baking, a mix that I can just stir together and pop into the oven just makes life a little easier.So I opened all of the boxed mixes, stapled the sauce mix bag, included with some like the scalloped potatoes, to the main ingredient bag, cut the instructions from each box and stapled that on as well, and packed them into gallon zip lock bags. Â I wound up with two of the drawers full, freeing up pantry space and leaving me two more drawers to fill. Â I was surprised at how much space those original cardboard boxes took up when stacked in the pantry.I spent some time making out my grocery order that will be delivered Wednesday. Â My store has carrots on sale for 99 cents per 2 lb. bag, so I am ordering 20 lbs. to dehydrate. Â They have boneless country style ribs on sale in the family pack size, so I have 4 of those coming, which I think I will can in large pieces using quart jars. Â They can be used like a pork roast or maybe with barbecue sauce along with a vegetable and cornbread for a meal for two or three people. Â Hamburger is on sale and while it isn't much of a sale, it is still a savings of a dollar a pound over the regular price, so I will can the 18 pounds ordered. Â Whole chickens are going for 99 cents a pound so I am getting four. Â I have one whole chicken left in the freezer and I think I will toss it into the crock pot tomorrow. Â I really won't want to run my oven when it is so hot out.I have been trying to get caught up with the odds and ends here. Â Oldest Son is making noises about a Farmer's Market run soon. Â I checked out their website and they have strawberries now. Â I need to make some jam and I would like to can some in syrup to use as ice cream topping or for things like strawberry shortcake in the winter months when fresh strawberries are really spendy. I'm thinking that retirement for me has nothing to do with sandy beaches and drinks with little umbrellas in them. Â I guess I would rather spend my time making sure my family is fed. Â And considering the insanity of the world around me, that seems to be a pretty good choice.

title: I don't  have words...
text: to adequately convey the horror of Orlando. Â Or my total disgust of the politicians who are climbing over the bodies of the dead and wounded to push their agendas. Â These folks express those thoughts much better than me.http://harryflashmansblog.blogspot.com/2016/06/another-gun-free-zone-shot-to-pieces.htmlhttp://bayourenaissanceman.blogspot.com/2016/06/the-usual-idiots-are-trying-to-use.htmlPlease pray for the families of the dead and for the families waiting for word on their loved ones in hospitals. Â And for us. Â We need all the help we can get, not only in dealing with terrorists, but in dealing with a government hell bent on making it more Â difficult to defend our homes, our families, our lives.Years ago I had a cabin on a lake in northern Minnesota.  About two-thirds of the way was the small town of Motley.  Motley was the home of Morey's Fish Company.  Morey's specialty is smoked fish.  Usually when we would head for the cabin with the kids, we would stop at Morey's for some smoked whitefish, which is a particular favorite treat for me.  I can buy Morey's smoked fish in my local grocery, but it just isn't the same as a smoked whitefish direct from Morey's, wrapped in white butcher paper.  Morey's has grown from its humble beginnings in 1934 to a major seafood plant today.  The quality of their products remain the best ever and the fish tastes just as good as it did back in the early 1970's when we would buy some on our way to the lake.Photos from Morey's website.This morning I woke to find that someone had sneaked a smoked whitefish, wrapped in white butcher paper, into my refrigerator.  Half of it is already gone.  It was really good for breakfast.  I'm saving the rest for a treat this evening.Oldest Son and his friend Lori had taken a road trip to Bemidji and stopped at Morey's on the way home.  Knowing how much I dearly love smoked fish, they brought me one.  Thanks so much.  It was a really fun surprise and treat.  :)

title: It has been...
text: a busy day. Â Groceries were delivered early this afternoon. Â After putting away everything except the food I had ordered to be dehydrated, I filled 13 trays with cole slaw mix (shredded cabbage and carrots) and got those to drying. Â I still have maybe a half gallon of mix left to dry. I had ordered red seedless grapes that were on sale to experiment with dehydrating them. Â Some folks dry grapes to make their own raisins, but this doesn't appeal to me. Â Maybe if I grew my own grapes it might be cost effective, but using grapes bought by the pound at the grocery makes for some expensive raisins. Â I had seen a video about dehydrating grapes as a kind of snack food like other dried fruit, so I filled half of a tray with grapes, cut in half to speed up the drying process, as a test. Â I'll let you know how they turn out.The rest of the afternoon I washed and chopped and diced until the tomatoes and celery were ready to be dried as soon as the slaw mix is done. Â Chopped onions can smell up the fridge even if stored in freezer bags, so they will wait until I am ready to dehydrate them. Â Both dehydrators will be running until all of it is dried. Â I was really lucky this week in that there were so many vegetables on sale that can be dehydrated.Yesterday was a fun day for me. Â It was my birthday. Â I don't do birthday parties or celebrations for myself any more. Â I figure that after 70 of them, I have done enough celebrating over the years. Â So I spent the day just puttering about with a little reading and a little sewing and a little napping. Â All my kids checked in with birthday wishes. Â Late in the morning Oldest Son and his lovely friend had run a couple of errands for me and they stopped by afterward with a pretty card and a cake, which we shared. Â Later Oldest Daughter and my Grandson surprised me with a couple of house plants in a cute tin container. Â She knows that I tend to kill flowering house plants, so she chose plants that have a fighting chance of survival. Â I will do my level best not to murder them.Youngest Daughter had sent me birthday greetings earlier in the day, and early evening I answered the phone to hear a rousing rendition of "Happy Birthday to You" sung by Youngest Son and his offspring. Â They were on their way home from Jacob's baseball game. Â His team of 2nd grade aged kids had just won their third game in a row. Â Woo Hoo - Go Jacob! Â They said they had a Dairy Queen treat after the game, in my honor. Â (That's an inside joke. Â In this family most events, large or small or even made up, are celebrated with a treat at the local Dairy Queen.)I had a nice surprise later in the evening when my sister called. Â She sang "Happy Birthday" to me as well and afterward we both decided we had inherited our singing abilities from our Dad, who couldn't carry a tune in a bucket! Â We got caught up on all the family doings and it was fun talking with her.While talking to my Grands, one of them asked me how I liked being 70. Â After thinking about it for a few seconds, I told her that I liked it. Â Even though my body seems to be coming apart at the seams sometimes, for the most part I don't feel any different than I did 30 years ago. Â Any day I wake up in the morning is a bonus. Â Although there might be those who disagree, my mind still seems to be working fairly well. Â I am not able to physically do some things I might like to do, but I can still do many things that make me happy and keep me busy. Â I have family close by and that makes me happiest of all. Â So all things considered, 70 is a pretty good thing to be. Â :)

title: Spent the Day...
text: sorting out my dehydrated foods shelf and getting the stray bags into the proper boxes. Â I have more than I thought of some foods and less than I thought of others. Â And I need more boxes. Â I am concentrating on dehydrating right now and leaving the canning for later when the Farmers Market is in full swing or if there is a really good sale on meat to use for soup to can. Â I am pretty near capacity on home canned foods right now.This is my week for grocery delivery, so I made out my order this afternoon. Â The packaged cole slaw mix of green and red cabbage and shredded carrots is on sale at 10/$10, so I am ordering 10 bags. Â Red seedless grapes are on sale and I am ordering enough to snack on as well as enough to experiment with dehydrating a tray or two of them. Â I'm not drying them for raisins but more as a dried fruit snack. Â I'm trying to get away from the Oreos and chocolate chip cookies (Not entirely, but cutting down on them.) and going more towards healthy snacks.Roma tomatoes and onions are on sale too, so 10 lbs. of each are on the list, as well as 12 bunches of celery, all headed for the dehydrators. Â Looks like I will have enough to keep both running for a few days. Â Delivery day on Wednesday will be a busy one, I think.Yesterday Youngest Son delivered my new bed. Â His sister came with to help haul it in and he set it up for me. Â He also had an early birthday surprise for me, which was a new comforter/sheet set for the bed, and a new pillow. Â I had no bedding the right size for a single bed and thought I would have to order some, but bless his heart, now I don't need to. Â So thank you, Son and family. Â That was a really nice gift that is appreciated. Â I tried out the bed last night and slept like a baby. Â It is comfy and I like it. Â Now I need to sort through my fabric stash and quilting supplies to fill the storage drawers in the base of the bed. Â I think there will be room there for extra yarn, too. Â I'm loving all this new storage space and it will make getting to my crafty materials a lot easier than digging through a closet for them, which is what I have been doing up until now.Oldest Son came over earlier to help me change the bandages on my legs. Â I was pleased to see that there is no sign of infection. Â The weeks worth of antibiotics I took seem to have done the job. Â I added more antibiotic salve and bandaged them one more time just to be sure. Â I have all the patience in the world when a loved one is sick, but none when it is me who is ill. Â Odd, that.So I think I have done enough for one day. Â Time for a little background music and another couple of chapters of my murder mystery book. Â It has been a good day.

title: Down Time
text: The past few days have been spent napping and reading and grumbling to myself. Â I have had the flu. Â Not the influenza kind of flu, which is more a respiratory kind of thing, but the flu, which is what we call anything else that causes us to feel like crud. Â The rumbly tummy, can't get warm even when wrapped in a large, green fuzzy blanket, no appetite - that kind of flu.When forced to be still, my mind wanders. Â Well, it wanders anyway, but more than usual in times like this. Â At one point I was thinking about my childhood and comparing it to that of my youngest grands. Â They are active children, but their activities seem to be more structured. Â I wondered if they had ever played Anti-I-Over with the neighborhood kids, or Fox and Geese or Duck, Duck, Gray Duck or Simon Says or Hopscotch. Â Or if they had even heard of those games that were so common to my generation.I'm pretty sure that, after their chores were done, they haven't been turned loose on a summer morning to play with friends with instructions from Mother to be home in time for supper. Â If we didn't show up for lunch, it was OK because sometimes another mother would provide a stack of peanut butter and jelly sandwiches and a jug of Kool Aid, and sometimes my mother would provide lunch for the neighbor kids and me.When we were old enough for bikes, our horizons expanded. Â We could ride to the local elementary school and play on the swings and slide and teeter-totters. Â Or we could have bike races in the alley behind our houses. Â Or we could ride about a mile or so to the woods where forts were built, cowboys fought the Indians and where Hide and Seek was much more fun than played indoors.Lest you think we were just a bunch of rowdy kids, I am here to tell you that there were rules. Â "Stay away from the railroad tracks. Â That's where the bums hang out," or "Mrs. Jones says no more crab apple fights in her orchard. Â She needs the rest of the apples for jelly," or "If you run through Mrs. Brown's garden again and trample her green beans, she will make you work all day, replanting and pulling weeds." Â And she would. Â With the blessings of our parents. One evening while reading one of my favorite murder mysteries, I heard voices from the street below. Â The bicycle shop beneath my apartment has set out a nice metal table with four chairs for the use of its patrons. Â At night, in the warmer months of the year, the bar patrons from next door make use of them. Â Most times I just tune out the voices unless the conversations are amusing to me. Â But the conversation that evening caught my attention. Â Every other sentence contained words that would have brought out a bar of Ivory Soap to be used by parents for washing out the mouth of the offending child. Â I realized that the ongoing conversation below was not unusual, but was the norm. Â Nobody was angry - nobody was fighting. Â Nobody was slurring words as if too many beers had been consumed. Â It was just a regular conversation between friends. Â I am not so naive as to believe that my own children and grands never say these words, but they have enough class not to utter them within my hearing. Â When did language like that become acceptable in public places. Â I think it boils down to respect - for ones self and for others. Â Respect seems to be in short supply these days.I wonder how many of my vintage collected a weekly allowance. Â Not I, she said. Â If there was a toy or an article of clothing we just couldn't live without, we either pestered our parents until they gave in, or we saved for it, which was the usual procedure. Â Pestering usually gained us time weeding the garden while pondering the error of our ways. Â Sometimes grandparents or favorite aunt would put a dollar or two in a birthday card. Â Once in a while a grandparent would sneak us a half dollar just for the fun of it. Â Money could be earned by babysitting or mowing lawns or shoveling snow from sidewalks. Â All of this hard earned cash was put into the Piggy Bank until enough had been saved to buy the object of our desires. Â But an allowance for doing household chores? Â Didn't happen. Â We were told that we had a roof over our heads, food for our stomachs and clothes for our backs. Â And as members of our family we were expected to pitch in and do our share. Â But get paid for washing the supper dishes - nope.Well, today I am feeling much better. Â Dirty dishes that were neglected for a couple of days have been washed. Â A couple of soft boiled eggs and toast have been consumed for breakfast. Â The better part of a pot of coffee has been drunk. Â There are just a couple of small chores that require my attention, but not enough to cause a relapse. Â Kids have been checking up on Mom - some who live farther away, by phone. Â Oldest Son, who lives next door, brought me my mail and hauled out the trash. Â He thinks I don't know he shows up every other day or so to do these things so he can check up on me, but I have figured that out. It is odd where a wandering mind can travel when the body is forced to spend time quietly. Â I can only wonder what paths it will take the next time.

title: Memorial Day...
text: It is not about burgers and beer. Â It is about those who fought and died so you could enjoy a picnic on this day, or any other day.They didn't have safe spaces. Â Microaggressions and trigger warnings? Â Nope. Â Did they fight their battles with hash tags? Â Never. Â  And I'm pretty sure they knew which bathroom to use without some fool in Washington telling them.When the country they loved was threatened or attacked, they lined up around the block to sign up. Â  They did not burn our flag in protest, but carried it high and carried it proud with all the devotion and respect it deserves. Â They carried that symbol of our freedom into places that resembled Hell. Â And they fought, sometimes for an inch of ground at a time, because they believed America was worth fighting for. Some came home to their families. Â Some came home in boxes. Â Some never came home at all. They all have more than earned our respect and gratitude. Â And they all deserve to be remembered not only on this day, but every day.

title: Another Interesting Phone Call...
text: came here today. Â This time it was someone with an accent I didn't recognize, but who assured me that he was, indeed, employed by Microsoft. Â He was very concerned that there was something wrong with my computer. Â Said it was sending out ERROR messages. Â Told me we (he and I) needed to fix this right away before my computer was damaged beyond repair. Â  Said I needed to turn on my computer RIGHT NOW.So using my very best sweet little old lady voice, all a-flutter and concerned, I Â told him that my computer was brand new and that I wasn't really sure just how to work everything on it, but that I had been able to see a little bit of that Internet thing. Â And I surely didn't want my new computer ruined (small sob). Â He allowed as to how he would be pleased to walk me through the process to make everything alright.So as I pretended to be on my computer and pretended to follow his instructions to the letter, we went through a series of steps. Â At one point he asked me to read back what was on the screen, but I told him he would have to read it to me because I had set my bifocals down but couldn't remember just where, so he did.Eventually we got to the point where I was instructed to download an exe file. Â He kindly told me how to do this. Â Then he told me to type in my password and my credit card number. Â I said I was confused, but I could give him that information over the phone. Â He happily agreed. Â Here are the words I gave him:police - fraud - scam - don't mess with little old ladiesAt which point he abruptly disconnected. Â I don't know why. Â :)

title: So Far - So Good
text: After a weekend spent doing my best impression of a vegetable, my legs are feeling better. Â I will ask Oldest Son to help me change the bandages tomorrow. Â I am using the same method used by the home care people last year. Â They came here once a week after I got out of the hospital, changed the bandages and re-bandaged with non-stick pads smeared with an antibiotic salve. Â But instead of wrapping my legs in gauze and Ace bandages like they did, I use the compression socks to keep the pads in place. Â  It just takes more than my two hands to accomplish this and Son has been really good to help, bless him.Youngest Son called me a few days ago. Â He tends to call when he is either taking a kid to an activity or when he is on his way to pick them up. Â He has a speaker phone thingy in his truck, so sometimes I talk with him and sometimes I talk with the grands. Â I love the way they stay in touch.Anyway, I asked him to do me a favor. Â He is my only kid with a truck, so I wanted to know if he could pick up a new single sized bed for me. Â  He said he could, but he had a better idea. Â He said that he and his wife were going to be getting a new bed for my grandson. Â He said I could have the old bed if I wanted it. Â The mattress is nearly new and it is the size I wanted. Â There is a bonus of four drawers and a cubby in the base of the bed, which will give me more storage space. Â I offered to buy the bed from him, but he wouldn't hear of it. Â Bless him, too!Oldest Son brought me some herb seeds. Â I have basil, cilantro, thyme, parsley, oregano and sage. Â That's a pretty good start on my little window sill herb garden. Â After lunch I will get them planted in the starter pots and see if I can actually get them to grow. I'm also working on sorting out my dehydrated foods. Â I package them in freezer bags and store them in banker's boxes on shelves. Â That keeps them out of the light. Â I have used vegetables stored that way that were 5 or 6 years old and they were just fine. Â But I got lazy and haven't put the latest dried food in their proper boxes, so that is my project for the rest of the day. Â Once that's done, I will know for sure what I have and what I need to dehydrate.And that is the extent of the excitement here in my little corner of the world. Â :)

title: Grumpy
text: The last few days I have been dealing with a cellulitis outbreak. Â This is nothing new and if caught and treated in time, it will soon be just fine. Â It is healing nicely. Â But it means that I have had to spend time sitting with my feet elevated to relieve the swelling in my lower legs. Â This makes me grumpy.I check my Facebook page daily to see if any of my children have posted pictures that I can steal. Â Today I found this one."C'mon Dad, let's take a selfie."Made me smile. Â Made me laugh. Â Chased the grump away.I love those kids!

title: Up To My Elbows in Chicken and Corn
text: I was getting a little bit low on jars of sweet corn and frozen corn was on sale this week. Â There was a bit of a glitch in my order and I got only 6 lbs. of corn rather than the 10 I ordered. Â No big thing. Â It happens once in a great while. Â I won't complain. Â My groceries are delivered. Â I no longer need to spend an hour on the bus to go grocery shopping or to haul the food up the stairs. Â I'm happy. As soon as my order arrived on Wednesday afternoon, I put the corn into a stock pot, added enough hot water to cover and set it on the stove. Â I didn't want to cook it - just thaw it out and heat it up. Â That done, I filled jars and fired up the pressure canner. Â I wound up with 10 pints. Â When the corn goes on sale again I will order enough to fill a couple cases of half pint jars.While the corn was processing, I tackled the 40 lbs. of chicken leg quarters. Â I separated the drumsticks from the thighs and bagged up the drumsticks for the freezer. Â I got 8 quart bags of drumsticks.The thighs went into stock pots along with water and couple of carrots and some onion for flavor. Â When the meat was falling-off-the-bone done, I removed it from the bones and bagged it up for the fridge. Â It was getting too late in the day to start canning the chicken. Â I strained the resulting broth, poured it into a clean pot and put that in the fridge as well.This morning I filled half pint jars with chicken and processed them for 75 minutes. Â I have lots of chicken and turkey in pint jars on the shelves, but few half pints. Â A half pint jar is just right for a couple of sandwiches or to add in a chicken salad or chicken and rice for one or two. Â I got 22 Â half pints from the thighs. Â There was still about a quart of diced chicken left after the canner was full, so I bagged that up and stuck it in the fridge to use for my meals the rest of the week.I skimmed most of the fat from the broth, added a little chicken bouillon to enhance the chicken flavor, heated it up and filled 12 quart jars. Â Those I processed for 25 minutes.Some have wondered why I would bother canning chicken when I already have lots on my shelves. Â Two reasons. Â The first is that prices don't go down - only up. Â A year ago this same sale on chicken legs packaged in 10 lb. bags was 39 cents a pound. Â I paid 49 cents a pound yesterday. Â Who knows what the price will be next year or if the store will even run the same sale.The second reason is that for under $20, I got 16 meals of chicken drumsticks (I can get two meals out of each bag.), 22 meals of canned chicken and 12 quarts of chicken broth. Â That much broth alone, at Sam's Club, would run $19.92 at their price of $1.66 per quartYes, there is some work involved, but I'd say that I got some pretty good mileage out of my $20 investment!I also got a good price on bell peppers. Â The lady who does my shopping is really good at picking out the freshest produce and always gets me the biggest peppers. Â This time there was a combination of red, orange and green peppers. Â While the chicken was cooking I cleaned and diced the peppers and got them in the dehydrator. Â On peppers I have dehydrated before, the skins tended to stay a bit tough when rehydrated, so now I grind the dried peppers into tiny pieces and use them as flavoring.That being done, I believe a nap is in my near future.

title: Butter Burgers and Fridge Magnets
text: Mother's Day here in my little corner of the world was really fun.Oldest daughter had stopped by the day before. Â We talked for a time and she gave me an Amazon gift card (I love gift cards!), telling me she thought I might like some new books. Â She was right. Â I have been wanting a copy of the "Ball Complete Book of Home Preserving." Â And while wandering around the Amazon website, I found another book on dehydrating that was on my wish list. Â I believe I will order both of them this afternoon.Youngest daughter called to wish me a Happy Mother's Day. Â We chatted for a time and she brought me up to speed on what she and her kids had been doing. Â Her kids were taking her out for dinner to celebrate the day.Youngest Son called me on his way to my house, wanting to know what I would like for lunch. Â Knowing that most restaurants would have waiting lines on Mother's Day, we decided on fast food. Â Yes, I admit it. Â Once in a while I like me a burger and fries that comes in a paper bag. Â They went to Culver's and got me a Butter Burger. Â I had never tried one and it was really good. Â The kids were happy. Â Grandma was happy. Â Win, win!After lunch the kids had a surprise for me. Â I opened the gift bag to find these.The picture doesn't do them justice. Â Son had bought tiles at the home improvement store. Â The kids attached the photos to the tiles and used Mod Podge to give them a nice finish. Â The brush strokes made them look almost like paintings. Â Although Charlie the Beagle had passed on to his reward earlier this year, they include a picture of him because I always said that family included three grandchildren and a grandpuppy! Â They attached magnets to the back of the tiles and now I have these smiling faces on my refrigerator to look at whenever I am in my kitchen.We sat and talked for quite a while. Â The kids filled me in on what they had been doing. Â One is continuing in Dance and the other has decided to leave the dancing and go for gymnastics. Â The youngest is happy to be playing whatever sport is in season. Â We talked for a time about the naughty things my kids had done when they were young. Â Now I know who shot the BB gun, putting a neat, round hole in my sliding glass door!Often I have seen families who are so busy with their cell phones that they don't really talk to one another. Â Here, there wasn't a cell phone in sight. Â I know they use them, particularly my son who uses his for work and to keep track of which kid needs to be taken to and picked up from which activity, but they also know when to put them away and as a result, they are able to carry on a conversation. Â It was so much fun to just sit and talk.Early evening when Oldest Son got home from work, he stopped in to pick up my list of herbs I want to plant for my window garden. Â He said he would go today and get the plants or seeds so I can get started with that project. Â If I can keep them alive I should have a mini jungle on my window sills in another couple of months. Â I like the notion of having fresh herbs to use. Â Having green, growing plants in my apartment is just a bonus.I thank God every single day for my family. Â I have truly been blessed.

title: Quiet Time of Year
text: When you are an apartment dweller and have no garden to plant, spring can be a quiet time of year. Â I do have 10 flower pots that I will fill with soil this coming week. Â I think I can probably talk Oldest Son into picking up either herb starter plants or seeds and I will see if I can grow them on my windowsills. Â I tend to kill off house plants, but hope I can keep herbs alive.Youngest Son called to let me know that he, my lovely daughter-in-law and their three sprouts will be stopping by on Sunday. Â He said something about bringing lunch with them and that is a real treat for me. Â Any time I can spend time with my kids and grands is time well spent.I finished getting my grocery order ready this morning. Â My grocery store has chicken leg quarters on sale for 49 cents a pound. Â They come in 10 lb. bags with a limit of 4, so I ordered 40 lbs. Â The plan is to separate the drumsticks from the thighs and freeze them for fried chicken meals. Â The thighs will be boiled, the meat removed from the bone, chopped and canned. Â I should have at least a canner full of chicken stock to can from cooking the thighs. Â Can't beat the price!I see that I am getting low on canned sweet corn and frozen corn is on sale for a dollar a bag, so I ordered 10 bags. Â I will can some of it in pints and most of it in half pint jars, which is just right for one person.Getting out and about has become somewhat difficult of late. Â Things like swollen feet that won't fit into shoes and arthritic hips that require frequent rest periods have slowed me down considerably. Â I manage quite well at home though, where I can sit when I need to. Â With that in mind, I made a list of items I need to buy over the summer and have been researching places that will ship to my door. Â I haven't bought anything online before, but the time has come when it makes sense to do so. Â I am so very lucky to have grown kids who don't seem to mind running the occasional errand for me, but my goal to stay as independent as possible won't allow me to take advantage of their willingness to help. Â Amazon may become my best friend. Â :)And now I have sat here long enough and it is time to get moving again. Â There are floors to mop and vacuums to be pushed about and I do believe a pan of brownies with chocolate frosting should be ready to be devoured by grandchildren tomorrow. Â I am looking forward to Mothers Day and I sincerely hope that all you Moms have a lovely day.

title: Pictures For My Cousins
text: Today on the Book of Face, my cousin Linda posted this photo.Left to right: Â Elaine, Marjorie (my mother), Adella, Margaret and Duane.This musical group are my mother and some of her siblings. Â I had never seen this picture, and it came as a surprise to me to see Mother holding a ukulele. Â I knew she had played violin, cello, guitar and piano, but I didn't know about the uke. Â Would have been nice if she had passed those musical genes on to me, but no such luck.Anyway, because I am easily distracted, I stopped what I was doing and went through my old family photos file. Â I found a couple of pictures I thought my cousins might enjoy. This is the official family portrait. Â Grandpa and Grandma are in front with Emily. Â Marjorie, Elaine, Duane, Margaret and Adella are in back. Â Judging by Emily's age and the fact that Grandpa is in the picture (He died in 1947.) I would guess this was taken about 1945. Â My cousins have likely seen this one, as I believe each of the siblings had a copy.I don't know where this was taken, or when. Â Elaine, Adella and Duane are in front, with Marjorie and Margaret in back. Â I think Mother looks about 15 years old, which would make the date about 1940.Left to right: Â Grandpa, Duane, Margaret, Grandma, Marjorie, Mildred (Duane's wife) and Elaine.Mother told me this picture was taken in front of the building in Nebish where Grandpa held Sunday church services for the Indians. Â As far as I know, Grandpa was not an ordained minister, but felt called to preach. Â His family accompanied him to these services and provided the music. Â The photo was probably taken in the early 1940's.One of my cousins remarked on the FB post that my Uncle Duane had been the favored one because he was the only boy in the family that included six girls. Â And this was probably true. Â He is quoted as saying that his sisters got him into trouble with their parents by telling them whenever something bad happened, it was Duane's fault because he made them do whatever the mischief was. Uncle Duane had a delicious sense of humor. Â Combine that with a quick mind and shenanigans resulted. Â One of my favorite Uncle Duane stories had to do with stealing melons. Â Duane convinced some of his visiting cousins that it would be fun to go steal some melons from a neighboring garden. Â He led the cousins, sneaking up and down the streets, through back alleys and back yards until, thoroughly confused, they arrived at the melon patch. Â It was only when they took a good look around that they realized they'd been had. Â They were stealing melons from Duane's family garden in his own back yard.I think Uncle Duane may have found a way to extract just a little bit of revenge on his sisters for their tattling. Â He waited until his parents were away from home of an evening. Â He would then rattle a doorknob like someone was trying to break in, or he would crash together pots and pans to create as much racket as possible, or he would make all sorts of ghostly sounds. Â Any one of these would send his sisters, screaming in fear, upstairs to lock themselves in their bedrooms. Â I am told it worked every time.Many thanks to my cousin Linda, Duane's daughter, for posting the picture on FB that sent me on this pleasant stroll down memory lane. Â We really should do this more often.

title: Do You Remember May Baskets?
text: When I was a small girl, at least 60 years ago, there was a spring tradition that has since gone by the wayside. Â That was the tradition of giving friends and neighbors May Baskets.About the middle of April Mother would set out paper and scissors and glue and help my sister and me make May Baskets. Â These weren't traditional baskets but looked like these.Â If we had colorful construction paper, we would use that. Â Or often we would use wallpaper left over from wallpapering a room in our house. Â Mother was frugal.Some followed the old tradition of filling the baskets with spring flowers. Â In our neighborhood, candies were put into the baskets. Â Sometimes there were jelly beans saved from Easter and other times Mother would make a batch of caramels, wrap the pieces in waxed paper and fill the baskets. Â Still other times, Dad would make a batch of molasses taffy. Â That was the most fun, for we got to pull the taffy until it was just right. Â Waxed paper wrapped taffy pieces then went into the baskets. The morning of the first day in May would find us hurrying through breakfast. Â As soon as Mother was satisfied that we wouldn't starve between breakfast and lunch, our May Baskets were carefully stacked in a cardboard box and off we would go. Â The way to deliver our baskets was to sneak up on a neighbor's front porch, hang a basket from the doorknob, ring the bell and scurry off around the corner of the house to peek and watch the reciepient claim their prize.Mother made sure that there were enough baskets for each house on the block - both sides of the street. Â There was even one for the grouchy old lady on the corner. Â I remember being astonished at seeing a smile on her face when she found her basket.When the last basket had been delivered, we hurried home to find several May Baskets waiting for us, filled with all sorts of sweet treats.That was a more gentle time. Â It was nice to have been given baskets of treats, but the fun was in the giving. Â Too bad we don't do that any more.

title: Back At It
text: It is way too early for Farmers Market goodies, but this week my local grocery yielded some decent sales. Â  My grocery order was delivered this afternoon, so I have been busy putting groceries away and working on preserving the bounty.Those plastic bags of fresh cole slaw mix, containing shredded green and red cabbage and carrots, were on sale for 10/$10. Â Seven bags were enough to fill 14 dehydrator trays, with another 3 bags full left over for tomorrow. Â A handful of the dried mix tossed into simmering soup adds such good flavor. Â  Or sometimes I will soak to rehydrate enough to add to casseroles.Onions were on sale. Â I just love the guy who calls me to take my order. Â Sometimes a sale is not much of a sale. Â He found onions for me that were less expensive than the sale price. Â I ordered 10 lbs. of onions and they will be peeled, chopped and in the dehydrators when the cabbage mix is finished.Hamburger was on sale, but there was a limit of 6 lbs. per order. Â I hate when they do that. Â But I ordered 6 lbs. anyway. Â They will be made into meatballs, browned in the oven, packed into pint jars, covered with broth and canned. Â I use them for spaghetti and meatballs, heated with potatoes and gravy or I have even made meatball sub sandwiches with them. Â It's all good.The last thing I ordered for preservation was cream cheese. Â I had seen a video about canning cream cheese so I thought I would give it a try. Â I don't use a lot of cream cheese, but I do like having some on hand. Â Seems to me that canning, if it turns out good, would be a better option for me than freezing it. Â This is another experiment, so I will wait and see how it turns out before recommending the process. Â The same video discussed canning cheddar cheese, but I have to say I wasn't enamoured with the results. Â The finished product looked sort of rubbery and although they said the taste was just fine, I think the texture would make it something I would not really want to use.Spring hasn't decided if it is ready to stay. Â Temps have been in the mid to high 40s during the day and dipping down toward freezing at night. Â I had to turn the heat back on and close the windows, as a stiff breeze and rain have accompanied the low temps. Â My way of contending with the cooler weather is to bake something. Â An apple crisp and a double batch of chocolate chip cookies are penciled in for tomorrow. Â You just can't go wrong with something chocolate.

title: Beef in Jars
text: Oldest Son brought me between 13 and 14 pounds of boneless chuck roast. Â I lost maybe half a pound in fat trimmings. Â I cut the meat into pieces large enough to fill pint jars and wound up with 13 pints of beef roast for the shelves. Â I would like to have canned more, but there are other places my money needs to go, so I will wait until the beef goes on sale again.The last dance competition of the season for my granddaughters is held this weekend. Â Youngest Son called me to let me know the website I can use to watch the girls in real time. Â There I found a list of all the dance numbers for the weekend, and I get to watch them dance 9 times! Â Each granddaughter has a solo and I watched Boston do her tap solo Thursday evening. Â She did a really good job. Â I don't know how she does it. Â If my feet were flying that fast I would be tripping over them. Â Maddie May has a duet late this afternoon and the rest are spread out over Saturday and Sunday. Â I have gotten so I can pick them out of a group so it is even more fun for me. The bananas I bought are finally ripe enough for banana bread, so I will make a couple of loaves later today. Â I am guessing that after Oldest Son reads this, he will be knocking on my door, looking for some banana bread to take in his lunch. Â Fine with me. Â Half the fun of baking it is the sharing of it.And that is pretty much as exciting as my life gets this week. Â In between watching the girls dance, I think I will do some sewing. Â I have another quilt top all cut out and ready to put together. Â And maybe a nap. Â Yep, definitely a nap. Â :)

title: Dear Target Store...
text: I have shopped at your store for close to 20 years. Â The store is convenient to my home and your personnel have always been courteous and helpful. Â On the few occasions when there was a problem with merchandise, you always took care of it to my satisfaction. Â Your prescription department has answered my questions and has had my medications ready for me in a timely manner. Â So it is with some sadness that I tell you I will be spending my money elsewhere. Â Here's why...(From the website for CBS News, WCCO, Minneapolis, Minnesota.)http://minnesota.cbslocal.com/2016/04/19/target-bathroom-gender/"MINNEAPOLIS (WCCO) â€” Target Corporation says it is â€œcontinuing to stand for inclusivityâ€ and will welcome workers and guests to use bathrooms that match their gender identity.The company made the announcement on its website Tuesday, saying Target supports the federal Equality Act that provides protections to LGBT individuals.â€œIn our stores, we demonstrate our commitment to an inclusive experience in many ways. Most relevant for the conversations currently underway, we welcome transgender team members and guests to use the restroom or fitting room facility that corresponds with their gender identity,â€ the company wrote."I have nothing against people who believe differently than me. Â If a person wants to spend their days in a bunny suit or a matador suit of lights, have at it. Â If they want to take on the persona of Mother Goose or Batman, I don't care. Â But when you tell me that it is alright for a grown man to share a bathroom with my eleven year old granddaughter or share a fitting room area with my teen-aged granddaughter, I must disagree.I realize that the disease of political correctness has spread far and wide. Â I understand that companies will trade common sense for compliance with demands of groups who stomp their feet, scream and shout and file lawsuits when their demands are not met. Â  I get the part where protection of LGBT individuals or any group of law abiding folks is a good thing.But please, please tell me why the protection of my grandchildren isn't just as important. Â Tell me that you can guarantee their safety from the predators and pedophiles who will most assuredly take advantage of your policy decision in order to satisfy their lust for children.I don't suppose that it will do any good to remind you that if a six foot tall man wears a wig, lipstick and a skirt, that does not make him a woman. Â That is not any different than if a person stands in a garage and proclaims himself to be a car.I am not foolish enough to believe that the loss of my dollars will have any effect on your financial status. But unlike companies who pander to special interest groups, I have a conscience. Â And that conscience will not allow me to fund in any way a company that has so little regard for the safety of my grandchildren.So, Target, unless you find your lost common sense, we are through.Sincerely,Vicki Miller

title: Spring has finally sprung...
text: here in the land of lakes and loons. Â The temperature got up to nearly 80 degrees today and now, in the middle of the night, is still at 68. Â I turned off the heat for my apartment a couple of days ago. Â It is so nice to be able to have the windows open again. Â Early this morning about the time the dark of night gave way to the first gray of morning, I could hear the chorus of sparrows and chickadees that live in the trees outside my windows. Â They are so incredibly cheerful sounding in the morning. Â Takes me at least a half pot of coffee to even become civil.It has been a quiet week here. Â Aside from a few bags of cranberries waiting in the freezer to be turned into juice, I am pretty well caught up in the food storage department. Â I have been using about half of my every-other-week grocery order to get fresh fruit, vegetables, etc. and the other half to stock up on whatever is on sale. Â The canning shelves are full. Â The closet pantry is full. Â The shelf holding the dehydrated food is full. Â I think I could go for at least year without having to go to the store, if necessary. Â  It is real easy to become complacent when the shelves are full and I don't want to do that. Â This week my local grocery has boneless chuck roast on sale for $2.99 a pound, which is a good price here. Â I may have to ask Oldest Son to do a grocery run for me on his next day off, and get me at least 40 lbs of beef roast. Â I have lots of jars of beef cubes canned, but it would be nice to have some bigger pieces for roast beef dinners.A couple of weeks ago my granddaughter, Maddie Mae, called to tell me that she had been named "Student of the Month" at her school. Â The honor has to do with good grades and good citizenship and I'm not sure what all else. Â It makes me glad when one of the grands calls to let me know what is going on in their lives. Â Good going, Maddie. Â You make me proud.A week ago on the weekend I was sort of glued to my computer. Â The two youngest granddaughters had a dance competition and I could watch it being live streamed. Â Each of them had a couple of dances with the whole age group, plus each had a solo dance and Maddie had a duet. Â It was so much fun to watch. Â The live stream was a bit dicey during the awards ceremony so I missed learning how they did. Â But when I talked to Boston later, she said both of them had high marks including some first place trophies. It is always a bit jarring to see them in full costume and stage makeup. Â When I think of them, this is what I see.Other than that, it has been just the usual hum drum life of a contented retiree. Â A little quality time with a good murder mystery, an apple pie shared with Oldest Son (He is really good to help me eat baked goodies!), and naps. Â Naps are a good thing. Â I have about six bananas that are nearly over ripe so I expect there are a couple of loaves of banana bread in my future, probably tomorrow. I know there are all sorts of crazy things going on in the world around me. Â Thing is, there is precious little I can do about any of it. Â So I keep one eye on the news and the other on Home Sweet Apartment. Â I'm going to be 70 years old in a couple of months. Â So I have decided to enjoy the time I have left as much as possible. Â That includes doing the things I like to do, such as sewing and quilting and scrapbooking and reading. Â And spending time with my family. Â And keeping on with the preps, for even if I never use all of it, there are those who will. Â Some find joy in world travel and others in the whirl of social activity. Â Me... Â I'm perfectly content right here. Â Can't ask for much more than that.

title: Firemen Who Aren't
text: This past week I got a phone call. Â The gentleman on the other end of the line told me he represented our local fire fighters. Â Said he was raising funds for the benefit of the fire department.I asked him if he thought $5000 would be of some help.He allowed as how it would be very much appreciated.I inquired as to how the money would be used. Â He sort of fumbled Â around a bit and then told me it was for new hoses on the firetrucks "and stuff."So I asked him for his name, mailing address and phone number, seeing how the number was blocked from my Caller ID.He inquired as to the reason I needed that information.I told him that my local fire station was just three blocks away from my house. Â I said that when I went to the station to give my friends there my personal check, they would want to know who should get credit for getting that donation.The gentleman then told me that the fire department preferred credit card funds over personal checks.To which I replied that I was sure my friend, the fire chief, wouldn't mind getting my check. Â I would go to the station right away as long as the department needed new hoses and stuff. Â And as long as I was at it, I would call the police station to see if they needed new tires for their patrol cars. Â Maybe I could help them, too.At this point the nice gentleman hung up on me. Â I don't know why.I have been receiving these phone calls several times a year for the past ten years. Â The first time it happened I asked a couple of the firemen I knew if this was one of the ways funds were raised. Â They replied that the fire department never, ever solicited funds via the phone.One would think that after ten years of having an old lady mess with them, these scammers would have removed my name from their call list by now. Â And they should really stop trying to scam us old folks. Â We aren't happy about being old in the first place. Â And we are retired with lots of time on our hands to think up ways to ruin their day. That part makes me smile. Â :)

title: School Days
text: Things are quiet here in my little corner of the world, so I thought I might give you one more offering from Great Uncle Walter. That's Walter on the right, his wife Maud on the left and two of their children in between. Â I believe this picture was taken in the early 1950's, about the time he was putting his memories on paper.Yesterday I was wandering through some of the news sites, reading about all of the foolishness going on. Â Much of it had to do with school kids. Â Things like out of control kids and teachers afraid to discipline them. Â Things like college kids needing safe spaces, and trigger warnings and requiring counseling because someone chalked a presidential candidates name on the sidewalk. Â And best of all, the demands that children of either sex should be able to use the bathroom and locker room of their choice, depending on whether they identify as male or female. Â Really? Â I always thought God figured that all out right in the beginning, seeing to it that boys were born with outdoor plumbing and girls had indoor plumbing. Â Problem solved.Anyway, all of this stupidity reminded me of the following piece Uncle Walter wrote about his own education. Â It would likely give those today a case of the vapors. Â But Uncle Walter went on to work for a railroad as a telegrapher along with other supervisory duties as well as becoming a first rate photographer. Â He raised his family, took care of business and lived a good life. Â There are a couple of passages that contain words that would make the social justice warriors break out in a cold sweat, but I won't change a word of what he wrote, for that's just the way it was then. Â Enjoy.School Daysby Walter E. PaulMy schooling, such as it was, commenced in 1894 when my folks were renters on the Andrew Anderson farm two and a half miles south of Barnum, Minn. Â Â  Â  My sisters Grace and Clara and brother Andrew had attended school back in New York State but here in our new Minnesota home there was no school within walking distance of short childish legs. Something had to be done to take its place. After a family discussion of the matter Father and Mother appointed Grace to be our teacher, she being the eldest of us children.Â  Â  Upstairs in a spare room of this Anderson house we had found a hodge podge of cast off school books no two of them alike, readers, spellers, arithmetics Â including a â€œmental arithmetic,â€ and a ragged geography, These with the few old school books our parents had brought west were the only ones we had. The room was furnished with an old slope top desk, a few discarded chairs and a makeshift blackboard.Â  Â  I started with a little red covered Swintonâ€™s First reader. Each day Grace coached me on its simple words and how they were grouped together to form little sentences. A much battered arithmetic and a torn speller were later added to my curriculum.Â  Â  On the first day I thought our little school was somewhat of a joke and began to act up accordingly until Grace set me right by jerking me out of my seat by my shirt collar and promising to report my misconduct to Father and Mother if I didnâ€™t stop my monkey shines and concentrate on my book. Her timely action I afterward realized was one of the best lessons I learned. Owing to my tender years I was required to attend our little school in the forenoons only, leaving the afternoons to spend as I saw fit.Â  Â  In the early winter of 1895 we moved to an abandoned lumber camp cabin five miles east of Barnum where we lived the remainder of the winter. This was wild country and game was often seen. The cabin stood on the edge of a tamarack swamp where snow-shoe rabbits wore cris-crossing trails through the deep snow. On the other side of the cabin heavy spruce, balsam and birch timber sheltered partridges and an occasional deer. When we needed meat and no venison was on hand brother Arthur on a sunny day would take the .44 Winchester and walk slowly along a tote road through the tamarack swamp. Catching unwary rabbits off guard as they dozed on snow hummocks in the bright sunshine he would surprise them by shooting their heads off. Returning with all the rabbits he cared to lug he would dress them, give Mother one to cook for our next meal and pack the others in a box full of snow to put away in a corner of the log barn for future use.Â  Â  Â With the first warm days of Spring we moved our few belongings into a new but very rough log cabin Father and Arthur had built two miles further east on wild land recently purchased from the St Paul and Duluth Railway for five dollars per acre.Â  Â  In the new cabin our tutelage continued under Mother and Grace until a year later when Grace left home to teach in a district near Barnum. This left Mother to continue teaching us as best she could along with the burden of keeping house and caring for her family in somewhat primitive conditions. I donâ€™t remember that father took any hand in our schooling other than an occasional encouraging remark or inquiry about our progress. Anyway I sensed some of its importance and in spite of much squirming, biting my pencil, and lamenting over the difficulties encountered I really did work at it and felt a degree of satisfaction as I passed from addition to subtraction, the multiplication table, division and so on. Numbers were difficult for me. Spelling was easier Â and in Â time I became a fair speller. Geography I loved as it gave me opportunity to study maps and to day dream about parts of the world I would visit when I became a man with plenty of money and unlimited time.Â  Â  Cost of writing paper being all of five cents for one large rough tablet we often used sheets of wrapping paper cut to suitable size. Slates were useful too. You could write on them with a slate pencil, then with a wet sponge, or, lacking that a little spit rubbed on with fingers or elbow would erase everything and prepare a clear space for more writing or ciphering. Â Sometimes the slate pencil would develop a little grain of grit on the point which caused spine chilling schreeches as it slid over the slate surface. We would grind out the offending grain on some rough hard surface which restored the pencil to more quiet operation, save for its tapping on the slate as we wrote or did our numbers. Most every Christmas we could expect some relative to give us a few slate pencils and some of the cheapest lead pencils. These lasted us through the year.Â  Â  Early in September 1897 Grace went to teach school in the Polish community of Split Rock eleven miles west of Moose Lake. A Polish family by the name of Kwapack had built a small frame addition onto one end of their log cabin. In this the teacher lived and boarded herself.Â  Â  When Grace took the position she arranged for Andrew to go with her and attend her school. He stayed with her through the winter until school closed in the spring. The following year I went with Grace and attended school until Christmas then Clara went from New Years until spring.Â  Â  When Grace and I went out to Split Rock just before school commenced, George Watson who later became her husband, drove us out from Moose Lake in a two horse livery rig. The horses were good steppers and the buggy was large enough to carry our personal belongings with us. We three sat in the front seat with the baggage piled behind. The horses were trotting along the dusty gravel road when we came to a log bridge spanning a small stream about a mile from the Kwapack house. As the horses trotted onto the bridge we heard a loud crash as the supporting logs broke in the middle and the bridge collapsed under us. Mr. Watson hollered â€œWhoa!â€ as he was pitched out headlong over the dash board landing in a heap against the horses hooves. Instantly the horses stopped, their front feet up high, their hind feet low and the buggy with its front wheelslow and hind wheels high. The break in the bridge was directly under the whiffletrees. Mr. Watson fearing the horses would kick his brains out in the position in which he lay had presence of mind enough to talk to them quietly while he painfully extricated himself, untangled the reins and stepped out onto firm ground groaning in misery because of a bruised knee. Taking the horses by their bits he slowly led them up the incline of the collapsed bridge the buggy with Grace and I still in it following onto firm road ahead.Â  Â  Â I missed Father and Mother and the home surroundings sorely. This was my first experience away from home. How I wished I could have my dog Carlo near me to pet or to go hunting partridges and rabbits with. I still have one of Motherâ€™s letters to me in which she told how the first few days after I left Carlo wandered about the place, looking here and there, watching the road, and occasionally whining disconsolately. However my time and attention was soon taken up with the new surroundings and experiences, and evidently in time Carlo also became reconciled.Â  Â  Mrs. Kwapack had three or four small children whom she frequently whipped severely for small childish sins. Aside from her severity with her children she was a good neighbor, occasionally rapping on our door when she wished to come in, sit awhile and talk to â€œMiss Paul.â€From our place a road ran across an open field into a maple and birch forest, down across the Split Rock River and up the opposite slope to the school house set back among the trees a little way from the main road. Heat for the school was furnished by a large cast iron heater burning big chunks of birch and maple wood a good supply of which the School Board kept piled close behind the building.Â  Â  Most of the school children spoke broken English. On the playground their conversation was mostly in Polish which of course left me in the dark as to what they were talking about. I did soon learn some Polish words for â€œteacherâ€™s brotherâ€ so knew when they were talking about me. Grace was careful not to show me any partiality on account of our relationship. She would correct me as sharply as any of the other children and on cold winter days she saw to it that I did not shirk my part when the kids had to bring in the days supply of wood from the pile behind the building.Â  Â  There was no social and very little other kind of entertainment outside of school hours. Sometimes I amused myself by wandering off into the woods, sliding on the river ice or helping Grace with household duties. Sometimes I went to spend a little time with Joe Burlik or with Ignace Skruilock, schoolmates of mine, but most of the Polish children had farm work to do at home with little time left for play. Part of the long winter evenings were spent with my lessons for the next day. On Sundays, there being no Protestant church closer than Moose Lake, Grace and I would read the International Sunday School Lesson together and discuss it a little in sort of a Sunday School formality. For special Sunday treats we had a supply of Brazil nuts, or nigger toes as we called them. These were carefully counted, divided by the number of Sundays until Christmas and that number we cracked and ate each Sunday.Â  Â  After Christmas Clara went to the Split Rock School to take her turn until spring. The following summer Grace and Mr. Watson were married so for a time that ended our formal schooling.Â  Â  Two miles east of us in our community which had come to be known as Deer Park, lived the Dye family. Â Mr. and Mrs. their boy William about my age and his half brother Clyde a few years younger. Mrs. Dyeâ€™s maiden sister lived with them as did also her mother Mrs. Munger, an elderly retired school teacher and a graduate of the Winona Normal School.Â  Â  In the summer of 1900 Mrs. Munger sent out word to the parents of Deer Park that she would undertake teaching their children that fall and winter in her home providing each child would bring his or her own books, some kind of a seat, and of course any paper or pencils they might need. I hope we children appreciated what Mrs. Munger proposed doing for us as we did in later years when with more maturity we looked back to that time. I donâ€™t think she ever suggested payment of any kind for teaching us, at least I never heard our parents mention it. Of course in our circumstances any payment would have to be very meager. The same thing was true with the other families. Â  Â  Â  On the morning of the opening day five or six children gathered at the Dye home besides William and Clyde. There was Clara and I, the three Lind girls and possibly one or two more whom I have since forgotten. Â Mrs. Munger proved to be a very capable and likeable teacher. First, she examined each of our books no two of which were alike, and inquired how far we had studied in them. She assigned lessons for each pupil, admonished us to study the pictures accompanying the lessons and to think about them. She would then leave us in the bed room school room for a time while she busied herself with household duties. After awhile she would quietly return and ask one of us to stand up and tell her what we had learned, or do some of the arithmetic problems on our slate or rough writing paper. She would prompt us with questions as we went along, or, when applicable relate some little event out of her past to illustrate what she was trying to teach us. About 1030AM and again at 230PM she would send us out of doors for fifteen minutes of exercise and fresh air which we sorely needed after being cooped up in that small room. At noon we had an hour to eat our lunch either inside or, if weather permitted, outside under the nearby balsams. This makeshift school lasted through the winter and spring.Â  Â  The spring and summer of 1901 a one room school building was erected a mile east of us on the main road running north from Woodburyâ€™s place to Cainâ€™s Corner. With the opening of this school that fall we of course had a regularly employed teacher, standard modern books, a large case of roll up charts and maps hanging from the wall, a globe, blackboards and a huge dictionary perched on a tall wobbly metal stand. Heat was furnished by a large wood burning heater in the back of the school room surrounded by a sheet of galvanized iron supported a foot from the floor the function of which was to help circulate heat on a cold day. Between the stove and this sheet of galvanized iron there was just room for a person to squeeze in and get the first heat of a slow starting fire before the rest of the room was warmed up.Â  Â  There was unlimited play room around the building, room for baseball, tag, anty over, and fox and geese. The nearby forest afforded opportunity for Indian fighting, bear hunting and other Daniel Boone exploits. There was no well so we had to carry drinking water from Woodburyâ€™s well a half mile away. On cold winter. days we ate our lunches in the hallway or huddled around the heater. Severe cold or deep and drifted snow did not deter us from plenty of outdoor exercise during the noon hour or at recess time. When the bell rang there would be a great scurrying into the hall to take off our snow laden overshoes, mitts and caps. Our wet garments were draped over the sheet iron encircling the stove, our overshoes placed under, then with much puffing and giggling we would slide into our seats keeping a wary eye on the teacher who was watching the commotion and patiently waiting for it to subside.Â  Â  With the first warm days of spring what zest we ever had for education slowly oozed out of us as we often sat idling away a few minutes, gazing out the windows at screaming bluejays and whispering chickadees flitting about in the nearby balsams and spruces. Chattering red squirrels running up and down the tree trunks and leaping across from one tree top to another were noted with languid interest.
