Â Sometimes I need to just back away before my head explodes.So this weekend I did some work entering data into my genealogy program. Â Part of that time was spent sorting through pictures, deciding which ones I wanted to add. Â While doing that I found some that reminded me of the fun that happened when my parents and their siblings got together.This is my Dad and his sister, Clarice. Â There was a special bond between them that lasted over 90 years. Â It began when they were children.Close to the ends of their lives they both lived in the same nursing home in the small town not 10 miles from the farm where they grew up. Â Clarice's memory went away and Dad's body wore out. Â But their senses of humor remained intact.My cousin told me this story about the brother and sister. Â Both used wheelchairs. Â Some days they, along with other residents, sat in their chairs and did exercises to help maintain upper body mobility. Â Seated side by side they dutifully did the required exercises. Â Until Dad would reach over and tap Clarice on the back of the head. Â They would continue on until Clarice's arm would shoot out sideways, smacking Dad lightly on the shoulder. Â This went on, both of them looking straight ahead, doing their level best to maintain a straight face. Â Until the physical therapist said, "You two Matheny kids behave yourselves," and they would dissolve into laughter.About 15 years ago Dad gave me a cardboard box of old family photos. Â They weren't in albums but were just loose in the box. Â I spent hours going through them, sorting and remembering. Â While trying to bring the pictures to some sort of order, I found this.Curiosity got the best of me and I called Dad. Â I explained that I had found a picture of somebodys backside. Â I said I recognized the stairs in the photo as being the ones attached to my Grandma's house in St. Paul. Â But I wanted to know about the picture. Â Dad chuckled and then told me about it.Dad and Mom grew up within 10 miles of each other. Â Dad knew Mom's family all of his life. Â He was always on good terms with Mom's brother and her five sisters. Â On the day that photo was taken, Mom's sister Margaret was teasing Dad about something long since forgotten. Â Dad, being Dad, could not let the teasing go unchallenged, so he countered with a smart remark of his own. Â At this point Margaret proceeded to express her disdain of his remark. Â And Dad snapped the picture.After I was able to bring my own laughter under control, I asked Dad why on earth he had kept that photo for well over 50 years. Â He said it reminded him of the fun that happened when they were all together. Â Dad and Mother's family remained close for the rest of their lives.This is a much better picture of Margaret!You might say that those of my parent's generation lived at a time when America was still America and their freedoms were still intact, so it must have been easier for them to laugh and have fun. Â Really?Those people lived through two world wars and at the end of the second one, they had all their illusions about humanity shattered with the news of the concentration camps in Europe. Â There was hardly a family that escaped losing a loved one in the wars. Â They lived through the Great Depression where people couldn't find work and where folks were lined up on city streets to get their only meal of the day at soup kitchens. Â Their lives were no walk in the park.One evening maybe 20 years ago I sat with my Dad on the balcony of his apartment, watching the sunset and enjoying the cool of the evening. Â We had talked of many things, including the shenanigans of the children in his large family. Â I asked him how it was that they could keep a sense of humor during such hard times. Â He said humor was what kept them going. Â If they could find something worth laughing about, it didn't change anything, but the cares of the world didn't seem quite so bad.Dad was a pretty smart cookie.

title: Staying in Touch with Family
text: You know how sometimes you just lose touch with people? Â Not their fault. Â Not your fault. Â Just happens.My Mother's side of the family is spread out. Â I grew up knowing cousins who were descendants of her Father. Â But many of my cousins who were descended from my Grandfather's siblings and who lived at the time of my youth in Minnesota, I did not know and never met. Â I have no idea why my branch of the family was separate from the other branches. Â I suspect there is some back story there, but I have never found it.Anyway, one of these long lost cousins and I found each other when I was actively tracing my family tree. Â We emailed each other regularly. Â Then when I became interested in other things, the genealogy got set on the back burner and the emails slowed down and finally stopped. Â No particular reason. Â We were on good terms with each other. Â We just sort of drifted on.Well, this morning when I checked my email, I found one from her. Â What a lovely surprise. Â There was no particular reason for it - just to say hello and tell me what she had been doing and ask how I was. Â I emailed her back right away, bringing her up to speed on my family and letting her know that in spite of this thing called aging, I was still as mean and ornery as always. Â :)My cousin lives on the East Coast. Â She mentioned that the blizzard a couple of weeks ago had dumped about three feet of snow on them. Â She works at Â local grocery store and she said that a day or so before the storm hit, the grocery shelves were pretty much emptied. Â Can't say that surprised me much. Â Same thing happens here before a bad storm is due to roar through.That email served to remind me how important it is to stay in touch with family. Â Granted, all of us have the Crazy Uncle Louie or the Weird Cousin Jane that we kind of wish were related to someone other than us, but that's not the case here. Â I don't remember ever meeting her in person and we have communicated mostly through emails, but even so, I really like my cousin Jackie. Â And I am glad she took the time to write.I need to do a better job of staying in touch with my family.

title: How to Waste a Couple of Perfectly Good Days
text: I have lately been on a quest to make my own convenience foods. Â Or to at least find quicker methods of making some of the foods I use often. Â Here is what I learned.First I tried a couple of recipes I found for making your own rice side dishes. Â I like those Knorr Rice Sides and Rice-A-Roni. Â I like them once in a while with a meal instead of potatoes or sometimes I will add my canned chicken or beef to them for a skillet type meal. Â So I followed the recipes and made both a chicken flavor and a beef flavor rice mix. Â I added meat to half a batch and left the other half plain. Â And I have to report that I didn't much care for any of it. Â Both the homemade mixes were bland and sort of tasteless. Â Even doctoring them up didn't help much. Â Given a choice between the homemade mixes and the store bought, I would choose the store bought for flavor every time.I had seen posts on a couple of food and preparedness blogs about making baking powder biscuit dough and freezing the biscuits to be baked later. Â Thinking that might work well for me, I followed the instructions, using a recipe included in the blog post for one batch, using the Bisquick recipe for another batch and finally using my tried and true biscuit recipe for the third. Â I mixed the dough, rolled it out and cut the biscuits. Â I put the raw biscuits on parchment lined cookie sheets and popped them into the freezer. Â When frozen, I bagged and labeled each batch and back into the freezer they went. Â The instructions said to bake them, just place the frozen biscuits on a baking sheet and bake as usual. Â So I took two biscuits from each bag and put them on a parchment paper lined sheet, writing on the paper with a Sharpie so I wouldn't mix them up, and baked them. Â When they came out of the oven, the first two would have made great substitutions for hockey pucks. Â The biscuits made using my recipe were a little better, but not much. Â They weren't nearly as light and fluffy as I like them but were more dense and heavy.So far, I'm not doing real well with these experiments. Â But I had one more to try.I had found a YouTube series about making no-knead bread. Â Thought it was worth trying. Â I watched the videos and wrote down the recipes and instructions for a loaf of white bread and for rolls. Â I followed the instructions to the letter. Â The guy in the videos made it look so easy, and it was fairly quick and easy to mix the dough. Â But when the loaf of bread came out of the oven, I found I had a really nice smelling door stop. Â It was heavy and had a really tough crust, even after I brushed butter on the outside to soften it up a bit. Â It didn't taste nearly as good as a loaf made the conventional way using my favorite recipe. Â The rolls weren't any better.So that is how I managed to waste a couple of perfectly good days. Â I suppose they weren't a total loss. Â I learned that quick and easy isn't always a good thing. Â I learned that sometimes substitutes for a dish like the rice sides can't be duplicated to taste like what I am used to. Â And I learned that even though kneading bread takes time and energy, the results are well worth it. Â I'm not trying to discourage anyone from trying any of these methods. Â Could be Operator Error. Â But personally, I found that for me, it just wasn't working. Â I will continue to stock the store bought rice mixes and make bread and biscuits from scratch, the old fashioned way.So mostly I learned that if it ain't broke - don't fix it!

title: Dad's Generation
text: My mind has been on my Dad lately. Â Even though I was privileged to have him until he reached the age of 93 and even though he has been gone from us for eleven years, I still miss him every day.What set him on my mind today was some articles I read about the current entitlement generation. Â Those who think someone else should pay for their food, their housing, their medical expenses, ad nauseam. Â Add to that the myth of white privilege. Â I'll tell you just how entitled and privileged my Dad and his generation were.Dad told me stories about when his family needed cash money. Â Not just the Depression years, but all the time, for a farmer like my Grandfather on a sandy soil farm in northern Minnesota would never get rich. Â Matter of fact, they would rarely get out of poverty.When Dad was old enough to do the work of a man, in the summer and fall, he and one or two of his brothers would go to the nearest town and catch a freight train going west. Â No comfortable passenger cars for them. Â A person had to have cash to ride the passenger cars. Â They found an empty boxcar and rode it to the wheat fields of the Dakotas or Montana - wherever they could find work on threshing crews. Â It was hard, hot, dirty work. Â This website tells a little bit about it. Â Once they managed to get places on a crew, they stayed as that threshing crew moved from farm to farm, threshing the wheat crop. Â They kept out just enough of their wages for their basic needs and sent the rest to their parents. When threshing season was over, they looked for other jobs. Â Most times they found jobs picking potatoes. Â That was back breaking work, following behind the horse drawn machine that lifted the potatoes out of the ground, the men going after, picking up the potatoes, tossing them into buckets or baskets and filling gunnysacks. Â This is a photo of a potato picker and although it is not my Dad, it could have been.My grandmother kept this postcard in her Bible. Â It was written by my Dad in October of 1934.It reads: Â "Dear Mother, Â Got here at Helena today and are going out on a potato picking job in the morning. Â Ken (Dad's brother) went out on another potato job to nite. Â Don't write cause I don't know how long we'll be here. Â As always, Ralph (my Dad).Here's my point. Â Dad's family needed money. Â There was a little money to be made working in the woods in the winter, but no work in northern Minnesota in the summer and fall of the year. Â The family raised chickens and hogs and milked a few cows. Â They raised a big garden and foraged for berries and such in the summer. Â But a large family still needed cash for what they couldn't produce themselves.They didn't expect anyone else to give them anything. Â Dad and one or two of his brothers went where there was work to be had. Â Another brother stayed home to help their Dad on the farm and after their Dad's Â death in 1936, they saw to it that their Mother could stay in her home and saw to it she was cared for in her old age. Â The girls helped their Mother garden and preserve food and bake bread. Â When some of the girls were old enough, they earned teaching certificates and taught school to bring in money for the family.This life wasn't unique to my family. Â Many, many other families across the country were working hard to keep a roof over their heads and food in their stomachs. Â And they did it on their own, without standing in line for welfare benefits. Â They would have been ashamed to ask for a handout.Take a look at this picture.That is my Dad at the top of the ladder. Â That is his brother below him. Â The picture was taken around 1920. Â  They are just oozing "white privilege," aren't they. Â And yet, I never once heard Dad complain about being poor. Â And I never knew him to turn down a job because it involved hard work or getting dirty or didn't pay a king's ransom. Â He was just happy to have work.I'm thinking that those who think they should have everything given to them should be introduced to the reality my Father's generation lived through. Â His generation was comprised mostly of hard working, God fearing folks who did whatever it took to keep their families going. Â They had pride in a job well done. Â They considered a handshake as good a contract as any signed document. Â They were the people who made America what it used to be.We sorely need more like them.

title: How Long...
text: until the November election? Â Not soon enough.I read a variety of news reports daily. Â I read both main stream and alternative sources. Â This morning I read about the name calling and the one liner zingers and the poll numbers. Â And then I read about the tiresome excuses.I didn't read about how any one candidate is going to make my life any better.Seems to me it is about time to move the race for President of the United States off the elementary school playground. Â We are about to elect the leader of the free world and not hall monitor.No wonder the world doesn't take us seriously any more.

title: Let It Snow
text: The weather guessers got it right this time. Â Snow was predicted for around lunchtime and it started right on cue. Â Big flakes. Â Lots of them. Â Supposed to continue off and on until early tomorrow morning.I have been listening to the scanner this afternoon. Â Normally on a weekday it is pretty quiet. Â Today the chatter is constant. Â Crashes everywhere. Â Vehicles sliding off the roads. Â Not long ago one of the police officers requested a plow to make a couple of swipes at their parking lot so they could get the police cars in and out. Oldest son stopped in a few minutes ago. Â His workplace had sent their employees home early. Â Son said that not much was being accomplished anyway. Â He said whenever he stopped his forklift, the tires would just spin when trying to move again. His drive between home and work normally takes a half hour. Â This afternoon it took him an hour and 15 minutes. Â There was maybe 5 inches of snow on the ground then, but it is heavy and wet, and where vehicle tires have packed it down it is just like ice. Â He said there were very few places where there were no cars in the ditch and one point there was a car in the median and another across the road laying on its top. Â At another point on the freeway the entire road was blocked by cars stuck in the snow.Son said he roared through the next town over at a whopping 15 mph. Â Said he just slid through a couple of intersections here in town. Â Said he was glad to be home.Methinks it is about time for a nice cup of cocoa.

title: Back to Basics
text: I admit it. Â I got lazy. Â I still bake the occasional loaf of bread, but mostly I have been ordering bread from the store in my every other week grocery delivery order.Until now.It has been nearly two weeks since my last grocery delivery. Â At that time I stashed an extra loaf of store bought bread in the refrigerator. Â Don't ask me why I didn't put it in the freezer. Â I don't know. Â I just didn't. Â And it sort of got pushed to the back where it has languished for nearly two weeks. Â Until this morning when I ran out of bread and remembered the stashed loaf.I fully expected that loaf to be hard, stale and likely growing all sorts of moldy stuff. Â It wasn't. Â It was still soft, had no stale smell or taste and there was nothing green growing anywhere on it. Â That scared me. Â I began to wonder just what the commercial bakers put in the dough to preserve it that long. Â So I looked up the ingredients in commercially baked bread. Â That scared me even more. Â Look it up. Â You will see what I mean.The way I look at it, those of my advancing years have enough health issues to contend with without filling up on food that contains stuff I can't begin to pronounce. Â Anything that will keep a loaf of bread from turning stale and moldy after sitting out for two weeks can't possibly be good. So I crossed bread off my grocery order. Â And tomorrow morning I will get back into my old routine of baking bread once a week. Â It takes time and effort to do that, but I think it is well worth it.Incidentally, I went over the rest of my grocery order list and to my chagrin realized that bread wasn't the only thing I was ordering just for the sake of convenience. Â So I reworked my order to include mostly fresh fruit and vegetables and the ingredients to make my own convenience foods. Â I have a whole box of recipes for various mixes - from baking mixes to flavored rice mixes to seasoning mixes. Â I have two large shelving units packed with jars of home canned meats, fruits and vegetables and more. Â I have boxes full of dehydrated foods. Â I have the ingredients stored to cook and bake nearly anything I want over at least one years time. Â So I have no excuse for buying anything I can make myself.I have had a less than stellar January. Â I find I am tired much of the time and haven't felt as good as I should. Â It isn't just this cold I have been fighting lately. Â It has been going on longer than that. Â I can chalk part of it to the "winter doldrums." Â But I am willing to bet that if I get away from using store bought convenience foods and other commercially made foods like bread, I will start feeling better. It is way past time to get back to the basics.

title: Be Back Soon
text: This cold of mine seems to have settled in and made itself at home. Â As a result, I am taking a few days to be a layabout. Â Lots of liquids, mostly of the tea and juice variety, chicken soup and rest. Â There is nothing life threatening going on here - just a bugger of a bad cold. Â Which leaves my body tired and my brain foggy. Â If it doesn't start to clear up in a few days I will drag myself to my local pill-pusher's office. Â I have never understood why a person who is too sick to function normally should have to sit in a waiting room full of people who are too sick to function normally. Â If doctors still made house calls, I would likely be more apt to see one when ill.I'll be back when the aches subside and the fog lifts. Â Until then, visit those folks on the side bar. Â They have lots of good things to say.

title: Charlie Was a Good Old Dog
text: Last evening I received a phone call that I knew was coming but did not want to hear. Â My youngest son called to tell me that the time had come when the quality of life of their family dog, Charlie, had deteriorated to the point where the only option left was for their vet to help Charlie pass peacefully on to his reward.Charlie came into their lives over 15 years ago. Â He was the cutest little bit of fur who endeared himself right off the bat by chewing up some of the woodwork in their rented house while they were at work. Â Thankfully he outgrew that habit.Charlie was there to welcome each of the three children born to my son and his wife. Â He was so good with the kids and they loved him dearly.I often thought his name should have been "Hoover" for he was like a mini vacuum cleaner, cruising the kitchen whenever there was a remote possibility that some stray piece of food would hit the floor. Â This earned him jail time when meals were served. Â I always felt sorry for him, so I would sneak him a treat whenever I could. Â I don't think I was the only one. Â Those eyes would get me every time.I babysat Charlie more than once when my son and his family were going out of town for a few days. Â On one occasion, my son brought the large wire kennel for Charlie to use while I was at work. Â Well, that didn't go over too big with Charlie. Â I could hear him barking and howling all my way down the stairs and out to the street. Â I was working at a dog grooming shop next door at the time, so I caved and brought him to work with me. Â He was in his glory, meeting and greeting all those people and dogs who came to the shop that day.After a while my son wouldn't let me babysit Charlie any more. Â He claimed that whenever Charlie stayed with me he gained 5 pounds. Â I said it wasn't my fault that Charlie loved french fries.It doesn't seem fair that a dog's life span should be so short. Â They give us so much more happiness than we can possibly give them. Â They love us no matter what. Â That's something we can't say about most people.Charlie, you were a good old dog. Â You will be missed.

title: Another Fading Memory Surprise
text: I have a cold. Â Nothing serious. Â Just mildly irritating. Â Caused me to sleep most of the day away. Â Which causes me to be bright-eyed at 2 AM. Â Good thing I am retired and don't have to explain my odd sleep patterns to a boss. Â Or to anyone else, for that matter. Â I have found that 2 AM is a good time for writing another blog post.I am maybe one of the few who actually likes being my advanced age. Â Take for example this fading memory. Â The other day I had finally dug my way to the back of my Fibber McGee's closet. Â I had dragged out a tub full of fabric. Â If you are one who sews, or more particularly, one who quilts, you have a stash of fabric. Â And you never, ever throw any of it away, not even the scraps. Â Because you might need it.....someday. Â And if the fabric shop has a really good sale on cotton quilt fabric, you buy more. Â Because you might need it.....someday.Anyway, about halfway through sorting and folding, I found these.Yep...my fading memory handed me 30 quilt blocks that I had completely forgotten about. Â Once I saw them, it came back to me how I had cut the squares from a set of fat quarters that I bought a long time ago for a project long forgotten. Â I had sewn the squares into simple blocks and then got busy with something else and had put them away. Â So as soon as my nose unstuffs and I stop sneezing, I will sew the blocks together into a quilt top. Â I'm sure I have fabric for the back, but I will need to make a run to the fabric store for quilt batting. Â These blocks will make a nice sized quilt - just right for snuggling under on a cold winter evening.I just love this kind of surprise!

title: Canning Apple Juice
text: I like fruit juice. Â So when a good brand of apple juice went on sale I bought 10 of the larger frozen cans. Â I stored them in the fridge for a couple of days to thaw. Â Then I made up all ten cans at once in my stock pot, heated the juice to the simmering point, ladled it into hot pint jars and processed them in a boiling water bath for 5 minutes, according to the instructions on the National Center for Home Food Preservation website. Â (That website has lots of good information for canning, freezing and dehydrating foods.) Â I got 36 Â pints of canned apple juice.Now some would wonder why I don't just put the juice cans in the freezer and mix the juice up one can at a time like normal people do. Â  Here's why.Each frozen can makes 48 ounces of juice. Â That's just too much for me to use up. Â A pint jar of juice is just right for one person.Should I lose electricity for any length of time in the warmer months, I would have to do something with the frozen juice when it thaws or lose it. If the electricity is out, that means the pumps that bring water to my apartment are not working either. Â I need water not only to make up the juice, but to fill the water bath canner as well. Â As an apartment dweller, I have limited space for water storage. Â I store enough to keep me in drinking water for a long time, but not if I have to use some of it to can juice.And fruit juice is a liquid, which means that if I have several kinds of juice canned and on my shelves, they will serve to keep me hydrated in an emergency and save some on my water storage while giving me a flavorful change from drinking plain water.As frozen juice goes on sale, I will buy other flavors and can them as well. Â Even if I never need to use them in an emergency situation, they are still a good addition to my food storage. Â I keep a couple of jars of juice in the fridge all the time and sometimes it is nice to open one for breakfast or for a bit of a treat.

title: The Minnesota Shuffle
text: One morning before this latest cold snap, I went out for a walk. Â The sun was shining and the temperature was only a little bit below the freezing mark. Â Tolerable for a Minnesota winter day. Â When I got back to my building, I sat on the front steps, enjoying the sunshine.Here we often see the "Minnesota Shuffle." Â It is a way of walking in the wintertime that is sort of a cross between a shuffle and an upright duck walk. Â It is practiced mostly by us old folks, who are convinced if we slip and fall on the ice, we will break a hip. Â And we know that if we break a hip, the kids will be checking out the dreaded nursing homes within 24 hours. Â So we walk very, very carefully on the icy sidewalks.As I sat basking in the sunshine, I noticed an old lady headed my way, doing the Minnesota Shuffle. Â As she got closer, I saw she was talking to herself. Â I thought maybe she was just a garden variety crazy, but changed my mind when she got close enough for me to hear what she was saying."Florida," she said. Â "Why didn't I move to Florida. Â Arizona is warm. Â Should have gone there. Â Or maybe Texas..." Â And on she shuffled, eyes downcast, watching the sidewalk, skirting around the patches of ice.I can relate.

title: Waste Not, Want Not
text: I guess I will never get the hang of cooking for one person. Â When you spend several years cooking meals to feed four hungry kids it is not easy to scale back, even when the kids have been out of the house and on their own for a goodly number of years.I have had three meals of the turkey vegetable soup I made on Sunday. Â That's pretty much my limit of how many meals of leftovers I can handle. Â So I dumped the remaining soup into the crock pot this morning and added another quart of turkey broth. Â I thought maybe some peas and corn would taste good in the soup, so I tossed in a pint of each, too. Â Let it heat on the Low setting the better part of the day.This afternoon after I had put my grocery order away and had the salad fixings in the dehydrators, I heated some pint jars and filled them with soup. Â They went into the pressure canner and were processed at 10 lbs. pressure for 75 minutes. Â I got 7 pints of soup to add to my canning shelves. Â That might not seem like much, but I just hate to waste perfectly good food. Â Those 7 pints equal a weeks worth of lunches. Â I may be a bit tired of it now, but it will look pretty good to me after a while. Remember when TV dinners first appeared in the stores? Â I think every family on the block owned a set of TV trays and we would take our TV dinners and put them in front of us on the TV trays in the living room and eat supper watching the Ed Sullivan Show. Mothers everywhere loved TV dinners because they could serve their family a meat and potato meal just by popping the frozen dinner in the oven. Â My parents, being frugal, bought just enough TV dinners to collect maybe a dozen or so of the aluminum trays. Â They washed them well and then filled them with leftovers, covered them with aluminum foil and stacked them in the freezer. Â I have to say that the TV dinners made with home cooked food tasted way better than the store bought variety.I sometimes think my parents were the King and Queen of Waste Not, Want Not!

title: Outside the Box
text: So today was my grocery order day. Â  I had gone through the weekly store ad and my list was ready. Â  Before the guy who takes my order called, I looked the ad over again to see if I missed anything. Â I Â had.The store had those 1 lb. bags of shredded salad fixings on sale for cheaper than buying the ingredients and making them myself. Â I usually don't get pre-packaged food, but I thought I could make good use of these.I ordered 4 lbs. of what they call salad greens. Â This is just shredded leaf lettuce. Â I will dehydrate all of it and store it in a canning jar. Â  A small amount added to ham salad, egg salad or chicken salad for sandwiches will be good, or sprinkled on top of a pasta salad or a potato salad for flavor.I also ordered 6 lbs. of shredded coleslaw mix, which is a combination of green cabbage, red cabbage and carrots. Â When dried, a handful in any homemade meat and vegetable soup adds extra flavor. Â And that combination is good in any number of casseroles. The experts tell us to store beans and rice, and I do have those items in my food storage. Â But mostly I store ingredients to make the meals I like. Â Beans and rice are good to have for they provide nutrition necessary for survival. Â But a steady diet of them would get old in a hurry. Â I like to have as much variety as possible. Â Sometimes it is good to think outside the box a bit, like dehydrating salad and coleslaw mix, especially when it is on sale for cheap.Even a small thing like dried salad mixes to flavor a meal, or a variety of herbs and spices to use for the same reason, can make life during hard times just a little bit easier to take.

title: Mind Numbing Cold
text: Minus 15 degrees this morning. Â Even though I am indoors where it is warm, the drop in temperature seems to kick this old, arthritic backside. Â  I'm not going to complain. Â Our local news reports that two people so far have died due to exposure to the cold. Â Sure am glad I bought a back-up propane space heater, just in case.Hot cup of coffee.Green fuzzy blanket.Favorite recliner.Good book.Turkey vegetable soup in the crock pot.Sounds like a plan to me.

title: It Was With Dismay...
text: that I read the last post from Frank and Fern.I have been reading their blog, Thoughts From Frank and Fern, for quite some time now. Â They have been a source of valuable information for homesteaders and for those of us who understand that the future in America is tenuous at best. Â  They have been an inspiration to me as well as to many, many others. Â I will never be able to thank them enough for all they have done to encourage those of us who are on a similar path. Â Even though many wish to pretend that all is well, we have only to read the headlines to know their warnings are true.I completely understand their decision to spend their time in preparation rather than in blogging. Â Very few have earned the kind of respect I have for them, even though we have met only through blog comments. Â I wish only the best for them.But oh, how I will miss them.

title: Frugal Cooking
text: After my last post about pancakes and sausage, I got to thinking about meals when I was growing up. Â They were plain meals but even so, we never went hungry. Â I think the way we ate had to do with two things.First, we didn't have a lot of money. Â If we were poor, I didn't know it, but now I do know that much of my Dad's income went for medical bills. Â My mother suffered with rheumatoid arthritis nearly all of her life, and that disease took its toll, both in the horrible crippling of her body and in the cost of hospital stays, medicines, doctor visits, etc.The second factor was that both my parents grew up during the Great Depression. Â Even though both my grandfathers were among the more fortunate who had jobs at that time - one as a railroad depot agent in a small town and the other as a farmer and logger, it was still tough to feed their families of seven and nine children, respectively. Â My parents quickly learned that waste was not to be tolerated. Â They lived by the saying, "Use it up, wear it out, make it do or do without." Â Both brought their frugal upbringing to their marriage and to raising their family of three children.As a child, I remember that Sunday was my favorite day of the week as far as dinner went. Â Sunday was the day my mother would put a roast or a chicken in the oven before we went to church. Â When we came home, she would make potatoes and gravy, a vegetable and maybe a dessert, usually consisting of fruit we had canned in the summer or if we were really lucky, a cake or a pie.The rest of the week, suppers consisted of dishes that weren't expensive to make, like macaroni and cheese, chili with rice, chicken ala king made with the leftover Sunday chicken and served over biscuits, or beef stew made with the leftover beef roast. Â We ate pasta dishes like spaghetti or goulash as well as a variety of pasta or rice based casseroles. Â Here in Minnesota, they are called "Hot Dish."Mother was the Queen of Creamed Anything over Toast. Â She would make a standard white sauce using flour, margarine (butter was a special treat as it was expensive, even then) and milk. Â To the white sauce she would add salt and pepper and whatever vegetables were ready for picking in the garden. Â This was usually peas or a combination of peas and carrots. Â My favorite was when the asparagus bed started producing in the spring and she would make creamed asparagus on toast. Â Once in a while Dad would splurge and bring home a jar of dried beef and we had creamed chipped beef on toast, better known as s**t on a shingle.I think we had so many of the creamed vegetables over toast because bread was the one food that was plentiful. Â Mother baked loaves of bread, buns and cinnamon rolls. Â She taught me the art of bread baking when I was about 10 years old, knowing that it wouldn't be long before the pain from the arthritis would make it impossible for her to do this task. Â Dad would buy flour in 50 lb. bags and yeast in bulk. Â Bread baking was a weekly happening, usually on Saturdays when I was home from school. Â I still like homemade bread better than store bought.We often ate breakfast for supper. Â My parents bought eggs and milk from a local farmer so eggs were plentiful and cheap. Â My Dad would make a stack of pancakes and fry up eggs to go with them. Â Most times he would heat a jar of homemade jelly until it became a liquid and that was used as syrup. Â Sometimes on Monday evenings supper would consist of hash made from Sunday's leftover potatoes and roast beef, heated and topped with an egg for each person. Â  Other times it might be scrambled eggs with a little grated cheese on top along with thick slices of toast and homemade jam.When I got to thinking about these meals I ate as a child, I wondered if the Depression Era my parents lived through had anything to do with the way they cooked. Â So when I Googled "depression era coooking" I found that many of the meals my parents made were either similar or the same as those they ate when they were children. Â I believe they ate better than most during that period of time, for their fathers were able to provide the basics for their families, when many were standing in lines in the cities, waiting for a meal at the soup kitchens that were common then. Â My grandparents had large gardens as did my Dad, which was a major factor in feeding their families. Â And my Dad's parents on the farm were able to raise animals for meat as well as for eggs, milk, cream and butter.My Dad found a solution to satisfying his sweet tooth. Â He would tear a slice of bread into small pieces and put them in a large water glass. Â He would pour hot coffee over the bread and then sprinkle on a bit of sugar. Â I asked him once where he learned to make what he called "poor man's pie." Â He told me that during both the Depression and during the years of WWII, sugar was either very expensive or it was rationed. Â His mother was careful with the amount of sugar she used, so cakes, cookies and pies were a rare treat. Â But she would sometimes let her kids make poor man's pie because it took only a small amount of sugar and she knew that sometimes the hard life of farm work could be made a bit easier with a small, sweet treat.The time is not all that far off when we may experience changes in the way we live. Â Grocery stores may not be able to keep their shelves stocked as they do now. Â It might do us well to study how the people during that depressed time were able to feed their families, especially those who lived in towns where growing their own meat and vegetables would be a problem. We could stand to learn the more frugal ways of our parents and grandparents. Â We may have to.

title: Pancakes and Sausage
text: One of my old stand-by meals has been pancakes and sausage. Â In times when I was really broke, it was just the pancakes. Â There was a time when I ate more pancakes than anything else. Â After a while I could hardly stand the sight of them. Â Thank God, that has changed and now I can fix a pancake meal and enjoy it.A while back my local grocery had pancake mix on sale for a ridiculously low price - the kind of mix that requires the addition of just water. Â I bought several boxes. Â Because I sometimes have a lazy streak when it comes to cooking for myself, I decided to spend an afternoon making pancake and sausage meals ahead for those lazy times - or for times when I needed to eat but was busy with other things. Â Sort of my own version of convenience food meals.I mixed up a large amount of pancake batter and fried up the pancakes. Â As each was done, I put them on parchment paper lined cookie sheets to cool.While cleaning out the freezer of my refrigerator, I came across several 1 lb. rolls of breakfast sausage. Â I had bought them on sale, stuck them in the freezer and promptly forgot about them. Â One of the things about getting old and having your memory fade at times is that your life is just chock full of little surprises like finding rolls of sausage in the back of your freezer! Â I defrosted a couple of the sausage rolls, sliced them up into patties, spread them in a single layer in cake pans and baked them until they were cooked through and nicely browned. Â I set the pans on my kitchen table to cool the meat to room temperature.When it came time to assemble the meals, I tore off squares of aluminum foil and smaller squares of waxed paper. Â A waxed paper square went in the center of an aluminum foil square, topped with one pancake, topped with another waxed paper square, topped with a second pancake and another waxed paper square. Â Then I added two sausage patties and folded up the aluminum foil, sealing it tightly and into the freezer the packets went.So now if I want a quick breakfast or supper, all I have to do is remove the waxed paper and heat the pancakes and sausage in the oven or toaster oven. Â I suppose I could lay the food on a plate and microwave it, but I haven't tried that as yet. Â I like the idea of having a quick and easy meal on my lazy or busy days. Â I'm thinking about trying this with a slice or two of ham or maybe some pre-fried bacon slices. Â And if I'm really hungry I can always fry up an egg or two to go with it. Â The frugal side of me likes that I got 12 meals for not much more than two similar meals from a fast food place. Â Convenience food homemade. Â I like it.

title: The Old Wood Stove
text: My youngest son left a couple of comments on my last post. Â One was teasing me about going for a snowmobile ride or sledding, knowing how I detest the winter cold. Â The other reminded me of an old pot-bellied type stove that was the main source of heat in an old house where we lived in northern Minnesota, many years ago. There is a gas furnace that provides heat for my building. Â It does a good job of keeping my apartment warm, even though my landlord regulates the temperature settings. Â The windows keep out drafts and the floors stay warm. Â But it just isn't the same as using a wood burning stove.The air in northern Minnesota seems to get very dry in the winter. Â Most folks run a humidifier to keep the dryness at bay, but at that time I couldn't afford to buy one, so I kept a pot of water on top of the stove to add moisture inside the house. Â This worked pretty well.My kitchen stove was electric, and to keep the bills down in winter, I would often use the stove as a crock pot. Â We ate a lot of venison then, for the price of beef was mostly outside my budget and deer were plentiful. Â A venison roast in a dutch oven, surrounded by potatoes, carrots and onions, slow cooking all day, makes a meal fit for a king. Â Having raised chickens, I would cook one for a meal the same way. Â I don't know what the difference is, but those meals tasted better than anything I roast in my oven.I would make soup the same way, putting a pot of meat, broth and vegetables on top of that wood stove early in the morning, right after my kids got on the school bus. Â By the time they got home, the soup was done and all I needed to do was slice a loaf of homemade bread for supper.During the time we lived there, I was gifted a knitting machine. Â The closest larger town had a woolen mill with a store of sorts attached to it. Â There I could buy wool fabric remnants and bulk yarn. Â The yarn came in hanks that had to be wound into a ball or a cone, using a small hand cranked yarn winder. Â I didn't mind doing this, for the prices of the yarn was so much less than the skeins sold in the stores. Â I took a class to learn how to use the knitting machine, bought some yarn and got busy.My kitchen table was in the same room as the wood stove. Â  Many hours were spent with my knitting machine on my kitchen table, making knit caps, scarves and mittens for my family, the stove keeping me toasty warm as the winter winds howled outside. Â At that time, a style of ski cap was popular with the school kids. Â It had the name of the town on one side and the name of the kid on the other, the letters embroidered on when the hat was completed. Â  My kids were really good walking advertisements, wearing their caps, and I soon had more orders than I knew what to do with. Â I set a comfortable rocking chair next to the wood stove and there, in the middle of all that warmth, I sewed the knitted garments together and embroidered names like mad.I wouldn't mind getting another knitting machine. Â The ones they sell now are computerized and can do all sorts of fancy stitches and patterns, but I really liked the no frills machine I had then. Â If I wanted a pattern on a garment, I just embroidered it on. Â I'm wondering if it might not be worth having something like that machine, for it didn't need electricity to work. Â And I could make sweaters and afghans with it as well as the caps and mittens. Â I might have to check into finding another machine like it.It is funny how a simple comment can bring back memories like those of my old wood burning stove.

title: Snow and Cold
text: About 4 AM I looked out my front window to discover that snow had fallen. Â It wasn't much - maybe an inch or two. Â A fresh snowfall can make even a city street beautiful, especially when the street lights look like those old fashioned lights that required a lamplighter. Â  Â The street was quiet. Â No tracks yet in the snow. Â  Made me wonder if this was how my town looked in the late 1800's when this building was built.I have seen pictures of a couple buildings in this block, taken back in the late 1800's. Â They don't look much different than they do today. Â My landlord has plans to take the stucco off the outside of this building and get it back to the original brick. Â He wants it to look like it did when it was new. Â I like that idea.Later in the day the snow started falling again. Â Huge flakes. Â Took a break in my rocking chair with a cup of coffee and watched the snow fall for a while. Â The town is quiet today. Â It was so peaceful just sitting there. Â Why can't our world be like this all the time.The snow won't last long. Â The outside temperature is 35 degrees today. Â Change is coming over the weekend, though. Â Last night Son was teasing me that if I went out over the weekend, I would likely freeze my knickers. Â The temps will be Â dropping down to single digits with overnight temps in the below zero range. Â I told him that my knickers weren't in any danger, for I plan to sit them down in front of my sewing machine. Â Indoors. Â Where it is warm and cozy.Winter can be beautiful. Â But it is also cold. Â When I was young the cold didn't bother me. Â I went sledding and ice skating and built snow forts and had snowball fights with friends. Â Later when I was a bit older, I rode snowmobiles on trails through the woods and across frozen lakes. Â But these days I will view the beauty of winter from my rocker. Â I have become a coward when it comes to cold. Â And I'm all right with that.

title: Blog Post Slacker
text: Yep.....that's me. Â I've been busy and have spent little time at my computer lately. Â That's my excuse and I'm going with it.My TV stand got emptied and moved to Son's apartment. Â He is making good use of it. Â It took a day to find a home for everything I had stored in it and another day to recover from the lifting and moving and sorting. Â I don't bounce back as well as I once did. Â There is still a stack of stuff to go into a closet as soon as I finish cleaning the closet out. Â A couple of trash bags full went out to the dumpster and that helped. Â If anyone is old enough to remember "Fibber Mcgee's Closet," they will understand why mine is taking time to sort through. Â I didn't have anything falling on my head when I opened the door, but it was close.Son helped me move my desk and I put two of the leaves in to give me a large work area for sewing. Â I like it. Â I especially like the part where I can keep my sewing machine set up as opposed to having to move it from my kitchen table so often. Â This arrangement will work well.The cleaning of the chest freezer is proceeding at a slow rate. Â So far I have unearthed a stray pork chop, hidden beneath bags of cranberries, that made a good supper. Â And a couple bags of frozen vegetables I had forgotten about. Â Hope springs eternal that there are at least a couple of chickens under there somewhere. Â  Turning cranberries into juice to can is time consuming, so I expect to be at it for a while.This week onions were on sale, so I ordered 12 lbs. Â Tomorrow I will peel and chop them and get them to drying in the dehydrators. Drying them seems to be the best way for me to keep onions. Â I will hold out a couple to use fresh, but I like having the dried onions on hand and I mostly use them in that form.I have noticed something about the grocery store lately. Â The sale ads run from Sunday to Saturday. Â Used to be that whatever the store had on sale, there was plenty to last the length of the sale. Â More often than not these days I get a phone call from the person who does my shopping, telling me the store is out of at least one sale item from my order. Â This week they were out of fresh chicken breast. Â No substitutions or rain checks. Â And this was only Wednesday. Â I have to wonder if this is a sign of things to come.Time to get busy again. Â Son called earlier wanting to know if I needed anything from the store. Â I said I didn't, but would he like a BLT and homemade french fries for supper. Â He allowed as to thinking he probably could choke them down! Â :) Â Â Sometimes a person just has to go for the taste good thing. Â I love fries.

title: Getting Busy Again
text: Today I finished cleaning stuff off the TV stand I gave to Oldest Son. Â With a small shelf unit stacked on top, it had become kind of a catch-all for odds and ends of sewing supplies, quilt books and crafty supplies. Â Son's workplace is generous with holiday time off - paid, which is nice for him - so maybe tomorrow or the next day while he is home we can drag the stand down the hall to his apartment.There are a couple of bags containing ham bones defrosting in the fridge. Â Son picked up two of those bags of mixed beans for ham and bean soup and the beans are soaking in water until morning. Â Tomorrow I'll boil the bones, remove the ham and simmer the soup all day. Â After we have had a couple of meals of it, I will can up the rest.There are four gallons of cranberries thawing in the fridge. Â Once the soup is simmering I can start cooking the berries up to make cranberry juice to can. Â Son brought me 50 lbs. of berries this past fall and I need to get them out of the freezer. Â It is full right up to the lid, mostly with cranberries. Â There are probably all sorts of good things down in the bottom of the freezer, underneath all those berries. Â The only advantage I can think of about having a less than perfect memory is that you get surprises now and then. Â Like when you find out what is at the bottom of the freezer that you forgot was there.There is a reason for this burst of energy. Â I really want to spend some guilt-free time with my sewing machine, and that is a bit hard for me to do when I know I should be doing things like making cranberry juice, especially since I have put it off for so long. I have always enjoyed sewing since my mother taught me more years ago than I care to think about. Â  I was listening to my granddaughters talking about the latest fashion trends - the ones with the hefty price tags, and I had to smile thinking that they would be horrified if they were clothed the way I was at their ages. Â I don't think I had a store bought dress until I was at least a Junior in High School. Â My mother and I sewed nearly all of my clothes and when I think back, I had some really nice things to wear. Â We didn't shop for clothes, but for patterns and fabric. Â I don't sew clothes so much any more, for the prices of patterns and fabric have gotten so high that it no longer pays. Â But I do love making quilts and that is what I am looking forward to working on.Just as soon as the last gallon of cranberries is in jars and on my shelves in the form of juice.

title: Monday Ramble
text: I have a tendency to postpone projects in December until after Christmas. Â I don't know why, for I have not one legitimate excuse. Â My place is too small for family gatherings, so there is nothing extra for me to do for Christmas except make a few goodies to take to our family day. Â I stopped putting up a Christmas tree when I had cats, for they would begin to undecorate it just as soon as I hung the last bit of tinsel. Â The final straw was cutting my foot on the remains of a glass ornament the cats had been using for a rousing soccer game. Â And yet, even without any extra holiday preparations, I still put things off until December 26. Â Makes no sense. I am busy cleaning out a fairly large TV stand that sits in my living room. Â It has deep shelves on the bottom and smaller shelves on the sides. Â It serves no purpose for me since I gave away my TV, and when I asked Oldest Son if he could make use of it, he said it would work well in his apartment to hold a microwave on the top and maybe pots, pans and kitchen stuff on the shelves. Â The only bad thing about our apartments is the lack of kitchen storage pace. Â  I'm glad he can use it.Once the TV stand is gone I can move my desk and set up my sewing machine. Â The desk is an old one I bought at a garage sale many years ago. Â It opens up with leaves like a dining room table, and with the TV stand gone, I will have room to add maybe three leaves and have a nice sewing area. Â I have fabric for several quilt tops that I want to cut out and sew together over the winter. Â  I have been using my kitchen table for a sewing table, but it is irritating to get part way through sewing a project and then have to move it all in order to use the table for meals and other things. Â It will be nice to have a permanent place to sew.I have been glancing out my windows from time to time today, looking to see if the predicted snow has started to fall. Â The weather guessers are telling us we could get nearly a foot of the white stuff. Â We have had plenty of moisture here, but mostly in the form of rain and sleet. Â Today the temperature sits at 23 degrees, so I am hoping for the sake of those who have to be out and about that we get the snow and not ice. Â  The radar shows we are on the edge of the storm with states to the east and south of us getting the brunt of it.Seems like a good day for comfort food. Â I thawed out a bag of leftover turkey and set it to simmering in homemade turkey broth along with some seasonings. Â Later I'll make dumplings in the broth and open a jar of green beans to go with it. Â Chicken or turkey and dumplings is one of my favorite comfort foods. Â My Dad used to make the best chicken and dumplings. Â More than once I showed up at his house, chicken in hand, and begged him to fix that dish for me. Â Sharing that meal with my Dad is one of my best memories.I am all done rambling now. Â I have some apples that need to be used, so I think an apple crisp would taste good for dessert. Â I'm having a nice day. Â Hope you are, too.

title: Merry, Merry and Happy, Happy
text: It's almost here again. Â So the next few days will be busy ones.The last time the three youngest Grands were here, they gave me those big, sad kitten eyes while telling me how much they love caramel popcorn. Â And since the first batch I made has long since disappeared between Oldest Son and me, I'm making a couple of batches to take with when we all get together.It has been an unusual winter here in southern Minnesota so far. Â Although there have been a couple of light snowfalls, the white stuff has melted shortly after it hit the ground. Â Most of the moisture has been in the form of rain. Â But the weather guessers are predicting one to three inches of snow for later today, so we may have a white Christmas after all. Â I'm glad I only have to travel across town.We will be together as a family early in the day on Christmas Eve. Â I always look forward to that time for I love it when all my kids and grands are in one place at the same time. Â  Granddaughter Nicki made it home from the Army base in Texas. Â I treasure this time for she will be stationed in South Korea when she finishes her training in March. Â It may be some time before she can come home again.Neither Oldest Son nor I have any other plans for Christmas Day, so we will spend time together. Â Today is grocery delivery day and I have a ham on order. Â Even though there are just two of us, it is still fun to fix a nice Christmas dinner. I am grateful for those who visit this silly little blog. Â I so enjoy reading and responding to your comments. Â It is like having a whole passel of friends even though we have never met in person. Â I wish you all a peaceful, joyous and blessed Christmas and a New Year much better than the one that is nearly finished.God bless,Vicki

title: Times Remembered
text: This morning I read a post over at Gorges' Grouse. Â Gorges is good at writing interesting articles about times past. Â This one was about a barn in his neighborhood that recently burned, and his memories of many years associated with that building. Â It brought to mind a building in my memory that suffered a similar fate.When my grandfather homesteaded his land in northern Minnesota, there were no schools in his neighborhood. Â The closest school was in the small town several miles from their farm, and in the early 1900's, there were no school buses that would transport his growing family of children to school. Â I suppose my grandmother could have taught them at home, but I am fairly sure that raising her nine children in addition to all the other chores on the farm that needed her attention took up nearly all of her time. Â She prepared the meals, baked bread in the oven of a wood burning stove, planted a garden, preserved every bit of food she could, cared for the chickens, washed clothes in a washtub with water from the pump outside the house, heated on her stove. Â And in her spare time, she mended their clothes and sewed shirts and dresses for her children. Â Not much time to spend on lesson plans.So my grandfather got together with some of his neighbors and they built a one room schoolhouse about a quarter mile from his farm. Â By the time my Dad, the youngest of the children, was ready for school in about 1917, his oldest sister had her teaching certificate and was his teacher. Â Dad once told me that having his sister as his teacher sort of put a crimp in the shenanigans he could get away with. Â Dad was big on shenanigans. Â His sister was big on threatening to tell their father.That school stood for many years, even after the rural kids started going to school in town. Â It was used as a town hall and for neighborhood get-togethers. Â Many times over the years I visited that school. Â And every time I looked at my Dad's initials carved in one of the boards that served as siding. This was done when he was about 10 years old.And then one night just a few years ago, some boneheaded fool decided to burn down the schoolhouse, just for fun. Â That idiot took away part of my family history. Â I guess I shouldn't have been surprised, for anyone who would burn a schoolhouse just because they have nothing better to do wouldn't care about hurting the people to whom that building had meaning and memories attached to it.Like Gorges, I never took a photo of the building that held memories for me. Â The building is gone but the memories linger. Â Listening to Dad tell stories about his school days. Â Running my fingers over the initials carved so long ago on the side of the school. Â Nobody can take that away from me.I do have one picture from that period of time.The three boys in the back are Dad's brothers, Keith, Kenneth and Bruce. Â The dark haired smallest girl in front is Dad's sister, Clarice. Â Dad is on the end, the one studiously studying his hands.The children are standing by the schoolhouse. Â  That is the closest thing to a picture of the school I have. Â And when it comes right down to it, that picture of my Dad and his siblings is far more precious to me than any building.

title: Minnesota School Includes Muslim Prayer Song in Holiday Concert
text: Be forewarned. Â This is a rant.First, I object to the term "holiday concert." Â On December 25th of every year, we celebrate Christmas. Â We may have become a materialistic society, all wrapped up in finding the perfect gift, spending more than we can afford and glorifying Santa Claus, but the reason we have a holiday at this time of year is because on that day we celebrate the birth of Jesus Christ. Â Were it not for that event, there would be no holiday at all. Generations of Americans have attended school Christmas concerts, Christmas plays and Christmas programs. Â But now, with the trend toward political correctness, these Christmas celebrations in our schools are no longer allowed. Â And that is to our everlasting shame.Second, there is a time and a place for exploring other religions and the traditions of other countries. Â A school in a suburb of Minneapolis has chosen to include a muslim song in its "holiday" program. Â To be fair, there are songs from other countries and faiths included within the concert. Â Local news reports state that, for instance, a Jewish song will be sung. Â So why do I object to a muslim song and not a Jewish song? Â Because to the best of my knowledge, the Jews are not beheading anyone, nor are they burning people alive in cages, nor are they engaged in mass shootings in theaters. Â As far as I know, no Jew has ever waged jihad on America, nor has even one stood in the streets screaming, "Death to America." Â That's why.I have no problem with school children learning about other countries and the religions of those countries, nor do I have a problem with them learning songs from other countries to get a feel for any nationality or religion. Â It is good to know what other countries and religions are all about. Â We can never learn too much. Â But these teachings and songs belong in a classroom setting and not in a "holiday" concert.I have ancestors who came here from England, France, Germany and Scotland. Â My children have ancestors who came here from Norway and Denmark as well. Â They brought with them the religions and traditions of the "old country." Â But each and every one of those ancestors learned the language. Â They entered this country legally. Â They jumped through all the hoops to become citizens. Â They became Americans. Â And they were proud to be Americans.The excuse the school district gave for including the muslim song in their concert was this:"In a statement, the district said that they have students from many different backgrounds and cultures, and they promote equal opportunities for all students."That is all well and good. Â I'm all for equal opportunity. Â But this all inclusive politically correct BS needs to stop. Â A Christmas concert is no place to celebrate a religion that wants nothing more than to kill me.As far as I know, the concert has been given. Â I have been unable to find any news source that reported on it after the fact. Â Whether or not the school kept to the original program is unknown. Â  Â But if they did, shame on them.Sources:http://pamelageller.com/2015/12/minn-students-to-sing-muslim-prayer-allahu-akbar-at-high-school-christmas-concert.html/http://minnesota.cbslocal.com/2015/12/17/parents-question-choice-to-sing-allahu-akbar-at-holiday-concert/

title: Saturdays Can Be Fun
text: So yesterday I'm enjoying a mug of tea and the part of a murder mystery where everyone is a suspect and nobody knows yet who-done-it. Â My phone rings. Â It is Youngest Son, wanting to know what I am doing. Â I reply that I am just piddling about, not doing much of anything. Â He wants to know if I would like a visit from three of my Grands. Â Of course I would. Â He says they will be at my door in five minutes.I am sitting at my kitchen table when they arrive. Â As they come through the door they line up, youngest to oldest, to give Grandma a hug. Â They sit down and proceed to tell me about their day. There was a birthday party for a family friend. Â Youngest Grandson's hair is still damp from working up a sweat jumping about in one of those blow-up things where the kids crawl inside and bounce around to their hearts content. Â A good time was had by all.Oldest Granddaughter told me that when they were coming back through town, she noticed that they were only a block away from Grandma's house and she told her Dad they needed to stop in to see Grandma. Â Which they did.Middle Child said they were on their way to a mall nearby where they were going shopping for their Mother's Christmas present. Â Each of them had a certain amount of money to spend, and they were trying to decide if they would buy three smaller gifts or if they would pool their resources for one really nice present. Â All three were excited to be going Christmas shopping for Mom.We talked a bit longer, including their Dad in the conversation. Â The Grands saw the jar of popcorn, a big bowl and my roaster pan sitting on the cupboard. Â I explained that I was going to make a batch of caramel corn later. Â Caramel corn is one of the treats I always made at Christmas time when my children were young. Â The Grands extracted a promise from me that I would bring some when we get together for our Christmas. And then all three lined up again to give Grandma a hug goodbye. Â Dad even got into the act. Â We are a huggy group. Â I like that in a family.They weren't here very long. Â They didn't have to be. Â The fact that they wanted to stop in to see Grandma was enough.Later in the afternoon Oldest Son showed up at my door with a good-sized spiral cut ham in hand. Â His workplace had given each of their employees a ham for Christmas. Â Son used my WiFi while the ham baked in my oven. Â I added mashed potatoes and candied carrots to the menu and we enjoyed a really good meal. Â After supper Son cut most of the meat from the ham bone to use for sandwiches to take to work in his lunch, leaving me the bone to make a pot of ham and beans with, and a freezer bag full of ham slices so I could enjoy a few ham sandwiches this week.I'm thinking Saturdays really don't get much better than that!

title: Wadena, Minnesota Says "Take That, Atheists"
text: Wadena, Minnesota (population about 5,000) has for years erected a Nativity display in the center of town to celebrate the birth of Jesus. Â This year the Freedom from Religion Foundation complained about it and threatened to sue the town, so the city council reluctantly removed the display. Wadena residents did not take kindly to having their beloved and traditional Nativity display removed, so they did something about it.It may be just a small thing, but each and every time we stand up to be counted for what we know to be right, we become stronger. Â Good on you, Wadena. Â And Merry Christmas!!

title: Seeds
text: One thing I forgot to mention in my previous post is that I save seeds. Â I know that sounds silly for an apartment dweller to save seeds when there is no place to plant a garden. Â But I save them for two reasons.The first is that when things get bad, I have children who have lawns that can be converted into garden plots, should said children finally see the error of their ways and discover that raising food is a good thing. Â To be fair, one of them has done this with a couple of raised beds. Â Should seeds become hard to get, they need look no further than Mom's shelves.The second reason is that my building has a communal deck large enough to raise several different kinds of plants in buckets or tubs. Â Someone in a newer building than mine (this building was built in the late 1800's) probably has a balcony for each apartment that can be used as well. Â Over the winter I plan to research the best way to garden in containers. Â In the meantime, I have purchased seeds and I save seeds from produce, mostly from the Farmer's Market. Â I am aware that hybrid seeds will not always produce fruit just like the fruit the seeds came from. Â I don't care, as long as they produce something edible. Â And sometimes seeds from purchased produce will not grow at all. Â So to test those I have saved, I sprinkle a few seeds on damp paper towels, wrap that in a damp kitchen towel and wait to see if the seeds sprout. Â If they do, I package the remaining seeds and mark them, storing them away from heat and light.Another idea I saw was to sprout seeds in a quart jar. Â Google "sprouting seeds" for instructions. Â There are lots of websites and videos on how to do this. Â I have not tried sprouting my seeds as yet, but will be giving it a go over winter. Â There are seed sprouting kits in stores and online. Â I see no reason not to buy seeds in bulk and use only those according to your own tastes (some might like radish sprouts while others may not, etc.). Â Seems to me this might be a good way to add fresh green things to a person's diet. We apartment dwellers may be challenged as to storage and gardening space, but with a positive attitude and a bit of research, there is no reason we can't find ways to accomplish what we set out to do.

title: What Do I Store
text: I have been asked to do a post about the items I store other than food. Â I have been struggling a bit with this one. Â There are many websites, blogs and videos out there telling about what folks should have in their preps. Â A good place to start is researching those for information and ideas. Â Many of those sources include things like water storage, tactical gear, options for cooking and heating with wood, etc. Â While excellent advice, much of it is not applicable to my living situation.I have to make decisions based on an arthritic granny living in a three room apartment. Â I have no place to store the large barrels of water, so I save soda and juice bottles, wash them out, fill them and store them wherever I have a bit of space - behind my couch and other furniture, behind a door, in the corner of a cupboard. Â I keep some empty five gallon buckets that can be filled from my bathtub in a power outage, before my building loses water pressure. Â My "Need to Buy" list includes a water filter system to utilize the water from the river located a block away.This past fall I purchased a good camping stove and a space heater, both fueled with propane. Â I buy the small propane canisters as I have no place to keep larger ones. Â These fit into boxes with lids that can be stacked, saving space.I have several flashlights and batteries. Â I buy candles whenever I find them on sale and keep a large supply of wooden kitchen matches. Â My "Need to Buy" list includes several oil lamps. Â I would prefer the old kerosene type lamps, but storing kerosene in an apartment is probably not a good idea. Â Another lighting source I am looking into is the solar lights used in outdoor yard or patio decor. Â Seems to me these could be used indoors at night and be recharged during the daytime hours. Â Same goes for a solar charger for recharging computers, Kindles, cellphones, etc.I have a basic first-aid kit and add to that items like non-stick bandages, gauze, tape, bandaids, etc. Â I also buy antibacterial creams, burn ointments, hand lotions, lip balms, etc. Â A couple of my favorites that I have used for years are A & D Ointment and Bag Balm. Â Aspirin helps me with arthritis pain so I stock several bottles of that along with multi-vitamins. Â I find that prescription drugs are a problem. Â Most doctors, including mine, tend to write prescriptions rather than recommending alternatives, and they don't seem to want to write these prescriptions for more than 6 months at a time. Â So the next time I have to make an appointment to get my several prescriptions refilled, we are going to have a chat about alternatives, and in the meantime, I am doing my own internet research on herbal medicines.I have a large picnic basket with a lid that I have filled with sewing supplies - needles, threads, pins, velcro, various kinds of scissors, rotary cutters, etc. Â  Remember Grandma's button jar? Â Got one of those, too. Â The time may come where buying a new shirt just because a button fell off the old one will not be an option. Â We need to know how to sew and mend and patch. Â I also keep darning thread for mending socks. Â These old skills could be more valuable than cash at some point. Â I buy fabric on sale - all different kinds. Â Some are good for clothing, some for quilting, etc. Â Fabric is stored in tubs in the back of my closet. Â Yarn for making caps, scarves and mittens is stored the same way.I have a Kindle. Â I love my Kindle. Â I have several hundred books stored on it. Â But I also buy paperback books at garage sales and charity stores. Â And when I find information online that will be useful, I print it out and save it in a binder. Â I do the same with recipes and instructions for canning and dehydrating.I often buy a few boxes of canning lids at a time, trying to build up a good supply. Â I have found that if I am careful not to damage a lid when removing it from a jar, it can be used once or twice more, so I save all my used lids. Â I suppose it would be wise to invest in Tattler reusable canning lids, but right now their price is not within my budget. Â I do have four boxes of them in each size and have used them with few problems so I may get more when I have the rest of my "Needs" list filled.I have a tub of bar soap stored but lately have been looking into stocking the ingredients to make my own. Â Same for laundry soap. Â I store Borax, Washing Soda and Fels Naptha bars. Â Small amounts of these ingredients will make gallons of laundry soap at a fraction of the cost of commercial laundry detergent. This list could go on forever, but I think this is enough for now. Â Each person needs to decide for themselves what is important to store and what is not. Â Parents with small children would have items on their lists that I have no need for. Â Those who are into bushcraft would have the need for tactical gear, where those of us that find the need for it is not practical for our lifestyles, do not. Â However, I can not stress strongly enough the need to be able to defend ourselves, our families and our property. Â Even in the best of times, there is a very real possibility that someone with evil intent could break into my apartment. Â I refuse to live in fear, cowering behind locked doors, so I have made sure I have the means to stop the criminal before I am hurt or killed. The surface has just been scratched here, but I hope it will be of some little help.

title: Note:  Turkey Broth and Soup
text: This is just a note to myself so I will remember what I did concerning the turkey scraps. Â After Thanksgiving, I had the bones and scraps from three large turkeys. Â That yielded 21 quarts of rich turkey broth. Â There was also enough broth for a stock pot full of turkey, vegetable and rice soup. Â I had a couple of meals from that and canned the rest. Â That gave me 12 pints of soup. Â One pint is enough for a meal with homemade bread or cornbread. Â Rice doesn't can well as it tends to turn a bit mushy, but I canned the soup anyway. Â Waste not - want not, as my mother used to say. Â Along with the meat Son took home from his turkey and the meat from mine that I froze, I'd say we got a lot of mileage out of those turkeys.I have made turkey or chicken broth before and stored it in the freezer. Â But right now my chest freezer is full to the top - mostly with that 50 lbs. of cranberries I bought at the Farmer's Market to make into juice. Â I ran across a recipe the other day for cranberry jelly or jam that I think I will try to see how I like it. Â But I really need to quit being lazy and get busy processing those berries. Â I could use the freezer space!

title: What a Difference a Day Makes
text: Winter came sliding in on Monday. Â There wasn't much snow here. Â Just enough on top of freezing rain to make the roads treacherous. Â The local news reported nearly 150 vehicle crashes and several injuries. Â  After a harrowing drive home from work Monday evening, Son braved the elements and started out early Tuesday morning. Â After his car slid through the first two intersections he came to, he turned around and came home, called his workplace and took a vacation day. Â There is a mentality of bravado here in Minnesota when it comes to driving on icy roads. Â Many risk life and limb just to be able to brag that they didn't let a little ice or snow slow them down. Â Those of us with functioning brain cells realize that if our cars are wrecked or if we are wrecked, we won't be going to work for a while. Â No work, no paying the rent. Â Better to miss one day than a lot of days. Â It is called common sense.Yesterday was a strange day. Â I spent the better part of it snuggled under my warm, fuzzy blanket. Â I just couldn't seem to stay warm. Â The only thing that tempted my appetite was a bowl of the turkey soup I had made. Â And fruit juice. Â Son came over to use my WiFi and I slept in my recliner through most of his time here. Â I knew things weren't right when the coffee he brought with him didn't appeal to me. Â My poor landlord came by early in the evening to do something or other in my apartment. Â I'm not sure just what that was, for he took one look at me and said he would be back in a couple of days. Â Guess I looked pretty rough. Â Thankfully this morning I woke up feeling fine. So now that I have had several cups of coffee, it is time to catch up on the household chores I let slide yesterday. Â  I have two large stock pots of turkey broth in the fridge to can up as well as the rest of the turkey soup. Â The soup turned out really good, but I find that I am pretty much turkeyed out. Â I have given up on trying to make small batches of soup. Â Just can't do it. Â I still have leftovers even when I palm some off on Son. Â I still have a large pot of the soup left, so I will can that up as well. Â I think it will taste pretty good to me in a month or so. Â In the meantime, supper of scalloped potatoes with ham sounds good. Â What a difference one day can make!

title: Sunday - Rest.  Monday - Work.
text: I am trying to adhere to the Biblical "Day of Rest." Â So yesterday I did just that. Â There was some reading and some napping and some messing about on the computer and some crocheting and movie watching in the evening. Â The biggest thing I did was heat up leftovers for hot turkey sandwiches with mashed potatoes, dressing and gravy, shared with Oldest Son for supper. Â It was a nice day.Just because some of us are retired doesn't mean that every day is a day of rest. Â I had the meat from my 21 lb. turkey, minus a couple of meals, in the fridge so I saved out enough for a few days worth of sandwiches and packaged up the rest. Â I was able to wedge it into the freezer by doing a bit of restacking.There were the bones and scraps from three turkeys waiting for me, so those have been cooking all morning. Â When the pots cool down, I'll strain out the bones and bits of skin, pour the broth into my large stock pot and refrigerate it over night. Â By morning the fat will have solidified on top of the broth and I can skim it off. Â This I will save for frying as it adds some really good flavor to potatoes and other fried foods. Â Using the fat this way means there is less cooking oil to buy. Â I do the same with bacon grease. Â The broth will be heated, ladled into jars and canned.I have some broth and carrots, potatoes and onions simmering on the back burner. Â Soon I will add pieces of leftover turkey gleaned from the bones and maybe a handful or two of rice to the mix. Â It is turkey soup and cornbread for supper. Â Snow is predicted here today and Oldest Son said soup would likely taste pretty good to him after a day of working outside in this weather. Â Most times Son does his own cooking when he gets home from work, but now and then it is nice to have him come over to my apartment and share a meal.Those who guess what the weather will be like on a daily basis are telling us we may get up to 6 inches of snow, starting this afternoon and continuing into tomorrow. Â It isn't all that cold, the outdoor temperature sitting at 33 degrees this morning, which means the snow will more than likely be heavy and wet. Â Power outages can be caused by that kind of snowfall. Â My Kindle is charging just in case.
