His lack of education meant that he worked at menial jobs, many times back-breaking jobs. He was a janitor at the First Baptist Church in Willmar, where we attended church. He also cleaned other buildings at night in Willmar, and then went to work at 6:30 every morning to his main job, climbing into boxcars loaded with grain and taking samples to be tested. He took a job feeding turkeys and cleaning the turkey barns on a farm near Willmar. He took on other part-time jobs over the years.Taking care of a spouse who is chronically ill is not an easy task. It requires an inner toughness. It means putting that person first and your own wants and needs second. Dad had that kind of toughness. He spent many hours at Mom's hospital bedside over the years when she had to be hospitalized for one problem or another related to her arthritis. He got up an hour earlier each morning to see that her needs were taken care of before leaving for work. He brushed her hair, he bathed her, he helped her use the bathroom. When she couldn't get her hands to work, he fed her. He did many things for her that most of us never dream we could do or would have to do. And he did them without ever complaining. When it finally became too much for any one person to handle and when she required constant medical attention, she went to live in the nursing home. Many people would have been grateful not to have to spend so much time on their ailing spouse, but not Dad. He spent every hour that he could at the home with Mom. They talked. They listed to music. They played Scrabble. When I would call, knowing that Dad was always with Mom in the evenings, I would ask what they were doing. He nearly always answered that they were playing Scrabble, that Mom was winning. And then he would add, "But she cheats!" He always maintained his sense of humor, and I think that was one of the things that helped him keep going as long as he did. I asked him once how he did it...how he could devote his entire married life to taking care of her. His answer was simple logic to him. "I love your Mother."Yeah.....Dad was tough.

title: Truth
text: This posted by my son:"I just heard the President on the radio saying how great the affordable care act is. He said that the average American family has seen their healthcare costs go down $1800 per year.I would like to know why my family's health care costs just increased over $2200 for the next year.Really, Mr. President, really! title: I've Been Playing
text: When my grandchildren graduate from High School, one of their gifts from Grandma is a photo album.Â  I enjoy scrapbooking so that is the style I use.Â  But buying all of the physical supplies has become a bit too expensive for my budget, so I decided to do the scrapbooking on my computer.Over the years I have collected a vast amount of graphics for this hobby.Â  So it was just a matter of putting them together with the photos I have of Nicki.Â  When the pages were complete I printed them out in an 8 in. x 8 in. size, put them into page protectors and then into a nice album.Â  There is still the expense of photo paper and ink, but that cost me less than the regular scrapbooking supplies. Although this particular album cost me a bit more than I was planning for.Â  Earlier this week I started printing pages.Â  After seven or eight pages, my old printer decided it really didn't like the photo paper.Â  And although it still works with regular computer paper, it refused to run any more of the thicker photo paper through.Â  I fiddled with it and couldn't find the problem.Â  So finally I gave up and called the closest store that carries printers.Â  Got lucky and talked with a nice young man who sold me a printer that I didn't need a bank loan for.Â  He also got together the ink I needed as well as more paper and had it all ready for Son to pick up the next evening on his way home from work.Here are a few of the pages.I had so much fun working on this.Â  I wound up with 58 pages.Â  And Nicki loved the finished album.Â  And that is what is important.I think I will keep on scrapbooking my pictures this way.Â  I have lots of pictures on my computer and on a backup drive, but I like having a regular album to sit and look through now and then.

title: What If You Can't Garden - Part 3
text: There are circumstances where canning and dehydrating don't work for some.Â  There may be physical limitations or financial ones.Â  The initial costs of canning equipment and a dehydrator can be prohibitive.Â  And not everyone has access to Farmers Markets.Â  And there are some who just plain dislike this sort of activity.Â  I know if I didn't like to do the physical work involved in the processes, it would be hard for me to be as enthusiastic about it as I am.That being said, I don't think I can stress strongly enough the necessity of having some sort of backup plan for feeding our families.Â  We have all read the articles that talk about grocery stores having only three days worth of food in their storerooms.Â  They count on regular deliveries.Â  How long do you suppose it would take to clean out a grocery store if those deliveries were interrupted?Â  I know that if a winter blizzard is forecast for my area, it doesn't take any time at all to wipe out the bread and milk isles.There are tons of websites and videos out there telling us what we should store and how much of each item.Â  They have lots of good advice.Â  However, I have found that I need to pick what works for me and toss the rest.Â  For instance, many say that a person should store wheat.Â  And for many, that is good advice.Â  But if I store wheat, I need a way to grind it into flour.Â  And common sense tells me that if it is necessary for me to grind wheat to make a loaf of bread, chances are pretty good that the electricity is gone.Â  Which leaves me having to grind wheat with a hand crank grinder.Â  That is just not going to be possible for me.Â  So I store flour.Â  I tend to store the basics - flour, yeast, sugar, salt, cornmeal, baking powder, baking soda, etc.Â  I know what my family likes to eat, so I store the ingredients.Â  Just because people like me enjoy the process of preserving foods, doesn't mean that you need to do things that way.Â  There is absolutely nothing wrong building up your food storage with commercially canned and dried foods.Â  The "prepper police" aren't going to show up in your kitchen and slap your hands for not doing home canning.Â  There is no right way or wrong way to build up food storage.Â  It is all about the personal preferences of your family.Â  If nobody likes beans, then storing a couple of buckets of pinto beans is just silly and a waste of space and money.There are those who say they can't afford food storage.Â  Where is it written that you have to buy all of it at once?Â  Even tossing one extra can of tuna or one extra small bag of flour into your shopping cart each time you do your grocery shopping, will help.Â  It will add up.Â Â  It has taken me several years to reach a point where I am comfortable that my family will survive on what I have stored. And who says that you have to have tons of freeze dried food or buckets of whatever.Â  You don't.Â  If your family likes pork and beans, then buy a few extra cans when they are on sale.Â  If spaghetti is a favorite, just put back cans of spaghetti sauce and boxes of noodles.Â  You just need to keep adding to your storage so that when the time comes where you can't get food, you will have some put back for emergencies.There are those who go all crazy over foods that are not organically grown or are genetically modified.Â  I understand this.Â  I agree with much of what they say.Â  But the simple truth of the matter is that this granny who lives on a fixed income can not afford to buy all organic or non-GMO.Â  And at the end of the day, I think what really matters is that there is food to fill a growling stomach.Â  I seriously doubt that those people world-wide who have suffered famine would question whether the morsel of food they had to eat was organic.Â  If you look back into history, I think you will find that starving people ate things much worse than genetically modified corn.I guess what it boils down to is that there is no right or wrong way to build up food storage.Â  What is important is that we have food put back for emergency times.Â  There are lots of other things to consider like water and medicines, but those discussions are for another time.I was talking with someone in my neighborhood a while back.Â  The conversation came around to the question of what would we do if the grid went down and we no longer had electricity.Â  Her statement was that the government would bring food to feed her and water to drink.Â  I asked if she actually believed that an agent of the government would come knocking on her door with food and water for her.Â  She said, in all seriousness, that she believed that would happen because the government has to take care of us.Â  I just quietly walked away.I understand that my food storage methods are not sustainable.Â  There will come a time when I will run out of food.Â  There is nothing, given my particular circumstances, that I can do about that.Â  But the bright side is that we won't starve right away.Â  We will have a cushion of perhaps a year to see how things shake out.Â  That gives us time to work out the next step, while others will be busy just trying to stay alive.Â  Although far from ideal, that's worth something.For me, the bottom line is this.Â  I do not ever want to hear my grandchildren cry because they are hungry and I have nothing to give them ease their pain.Â  I don't know what the future holds.Â  But more and more I hear rumblings about bad times coming in the fall.Â  Maybe so...maybe not.Â  But whatever happens, I sure don't want to be standing in my kitchen amongst empty cupboards, waiting for someone from the government to knock on my door with food and water that I should have had enough sense to store myself.I have two dehydrators.Â  Neither are top of the line.Â  Both came from Fleet Farm where prices seem to be reasonable.Â  I bought the first one to replace my first dehydrator that did not have a temperature control.Â  The old one also had the fan in the bottom.Â  That didn't work out very well as some peas I was drying fell into the hole in the bottom for the fan, effectively stopping the fan blades and basically burning up the unit.Â  The new dehydrator has the heating and fan in the top.Â  Much better design.The second dehydrator came to me via Oldest Son.Â  He heard me complaining loud and long about my frustration in trying to dry a large number of tomatoes before they turned bad.Â  Dehydrating takes time.Â  So he hot-footed it over to Fleet Farm and presented me with a second unit.Â  I showed my appreciation, as mothers are want to do, by mildly cussing him out for spending his money on something for me.Â  He promptly told me that this second dehydrator wasn't mine - it was his.Â  He just chose to store it at my house.Â  Sneaky kid!I don't dehydrate meat, other than jerky.Â  I have seen articles and videos showing others drying hamburger and chicken.Â  But I am not brave enough to try it.Â  I know that fats in meat will cause the dried product to go rancid.Â  I guess I am too cheap frugal to risk spending money on meat only to take the chance of having to toss it.I do dry a large variety of vegetables.Â  Because I have no garden, some of these come from the Farmers Market.Â  They include sliced potatoes, diced potatoes, green peppers and cabbage.Â  Others come from the frozen food section of the grocery.Â  When on sale, I stock up and dry sweet corn, peas, peas and carrots, cauliflower, broccoli, green beans and mixed vegetables.Â  All dry easily, with no blanching beforehand, as they are already blanched before freezing.Sams Club has a 50 lb. sack of onions for a little over $25.Â  That's far less than I would pay in a regular grocery.Â  I either slice them on my mandolin slicer or run them through my Vidalia Chop Wizard, for diced onions.Â  And yes, drying onions will smell up the living space.Â  The only room that I can shut off from the rest of the apartment is the bedroom, so I set the onion-filled dehydrators next to the two open windows and shut the door.Â  It sort of works.Â  At least nobody in the building has complained, yet.Â  My local grocery often runs sales on fresh carrots, making them less expensive than at the Farmers Market.Â  I dry those either sliced or diced.I have experimented with dehydrating a variety of fruit, and have had success with canned pineapple, apples and chopped cranberries.Â  I need to try a few more kinds of fruit as that is one hole in my food storage that should be filled. I like to dry frozen hash browned potatoes.Â  They rehydrate in a matter of a few minutes and the taste and texture is identical to the frozen when taken from the freezer and cooked.Â  So why mess with dehydrating?Â  Two reasons.Â  The first is that dehydrated foods will last for years.Â  And second, because when most food dries, the volume is significantly reduced, making it possible to store more food in less space.Some talk about storing dehydrated vegetables in sealed Food Saver bags and then in mylar bags.Â  I can't afford to do all of that.Â  So I store my dehydrated foods in heavy duty plastic freezer bags, using double thickness on those vegetables that have sharp edges that can puncture plastic.Â  Then they go into cardboard banker boxes with lids.Â  Those fit onto the shelves of a standing shelf unit.Â  Moisture and light are the enemy of dehydrated foods.Â  I don't have a basement for storage, so the shelves for both home canned and dehydrated foods are kept in my bedroom, which seems to stay cooler than the rest of my apartment.Â  So far, after several years, this seems to be working well.Â  My bedroom will never, ever be featured in a fancy home decorating publication.Â  I don't care.Â  I'm not trying to impress anyone.Â  I'm trying to insure that my family and I stay alive for a while should the time come when this is all we have to eat.So now you have all this dried food.Â  What are you going to do with it?There is a website called "Dehydrate 2 Store."Â  There you will find videos of how to dehydrate various foods and how to use many of them.Â Â  There are also a ton of videos on YouTube about dehydrating and using what you dry.I have found that some vegetables rehydrate better than others.Â  Corn will come back to its original form.Â  So will carrots.Â  Green beans - not so much.Â  So my canned vegetables are used for meals and my dehydrated vegetables are used mostly in soups.Â  I make a lot of soup using my crock pot.Â  I can eat off a pot of soup for a couple of days and then thicken the rest and have it over biscuits or dumplings.Â  If I make too much, I just freeze the leftovers for another day.I have one of those little grinders that looks like a mini food processor.Â  I use it to grind dried corn into coarse cornmeal.Â  Mixed half and half with store bought cornmeal, it makes the best cornbread or corn muffins.I use a lot of onions in cooking.Â  As I have no cold storage place, dried onions are the best solution for me.Â  Sometimes I will soak them in water to soften them up a bit and other times I will just toss a handful into whatever I'm cooking.Â  If I want just the onion flavor, I will run some dried onion through my little grinder until it becomes a coarse powder.Â  I do the same with dried sweet green peppers.Â  Dehydrated potato slices work well for scalloped potatoes.Â  When I dry them, I slice them uniformly using my mandolin slicer.Â  I suppose you could use a food processor for this step.Â  As they are sliced, I toss them into a bucket of cold water to which I have added a little lemon juice.Â  This keeps them from turning brown.Â  Then the slices are blanched for 3 minutes and spread in a single layer on the dehydrator trays.Â  I usually let them run overnight and most times they are crispy dry by morning.The big food storage companies sell #10 cans of freeze dried fruits and vegetables.Â  These are not the same as home dehydrated.Â  Freeze drying is a whole different process.Â  I have never tried the freeze dried food.Â  I understand that in some respects, it is superior to home dried.Â  But I just can't justify the cost.Â  So unless I find that pot of gold at the end of that rainbow, I guess I will continue on with drying my own foods.There will be one more post in this series within the next day or two.

title: What If You Can't Garden - Part 1
text: There is a blog called "Thoughts From Frank and Fern" that I regularly read.Â  If you don't, you should.Â  They are a wealth of information on homestead related subjects as well as communications.Â  Fern just posted a question to her readers concerning sustainable gardening.Â  She wanted to know what folks would do with their gardens if they knew that a catastrophic event was just around the corner.Â  You can read the article here.Â  I'll wait.Now Fern's article got me to thinking.Â  There are many of us who, for a myriad of reasons, can not garden.Â  In my case, health issues prevent that activity.Â  And I live in a small apartment in the burbs, surrounded by concrete and asphalt.Â  The very best I can do to grow food are buckets of tomatoes on the communal deck of my building and herbs in pots on my windowsills.Â  That's not going to go very far to keep me alive for a year.Â  So I have come up with a few solutions to the problem that might give others in the same circumstances an idea or two.If you can afford to invest in a pressure canner, jars and lids, do so.Â  I realize that the initial cost can stretch a fixed income budget, but it is well worth it in the long run.Â  Also look into the price of a dehydrator.Â  It should have the ability to set the temperature for various foods.Â  There are blogs and videos out there that tout the wonders of the top of the line canners and dehydrators.Â  They would be nice to own, but not necessary.Â  I have a pressure canner that cost around $60 at Walmart and another that cost a bit more that was a gift from one of my sons.Â  Together they cost less than the top of the line canner, and both work just fine.Â  My two dehydrators are from Fleet Farm and together cost less than half of the top of the line dehydrator, even with the addition of extra trays and plastic mesh liners.Â Â  So if you don't have a garden, what do you can, you ask.Â  I'll tell you.I can meat - hamburger, meatballs, beef roast, beef cubes, pork roast, pork cubes, ham cubes, chicken breast chunks, chicken breast cubes, whole chicken thighs, turkey shreds (cooked, removed from the bones and cut into about one-inch pieces), broth from cooking the turkey, bacon, sausage, pepperoni.Â  And if I am lucky enough to have a hunter in the family who gets a deer, I can venison.Â  All but the venison are purchased on sale at the grocery.Â  I freeze enough sale meat for about two weeks of meals and can the rest.Â  Should I lose electricity for a length of time, I still am able to can up the meat in the freezer before it goes bad.Â  Home canned meat will keep for years if stored in a relatively cool, dark place.Â  And it tastes good.Â  And doesn't get freezer burn.I can vegetables.Â  The Farmer's Market is my favorite place to find these.Â  I have canned tomatoes, tomato sauce, tomato sauce with green peppers and onions, pasta sauce, pizza sauce, cabbage, sauerkraut, Amish slaw, potato cubes, potato chunks with carrots, potato cubes with peas and carrots, and butternut squash, all from the Farmer's Market.Â  Except the peas.My local grocery runs an occasional sale on frozen vegetables - usually 10 for $10.Â  When this sale occurs, I stock up as much as possible.Â  Then I can the frozen vegetables.Â  And why would anybody in their right mind can frozen vegetables, you ask?Â  Because they keep longer in jars than in a freezer.Â  Because I can most of them in half-pint jars that are just right for one or two people, and some in pint jars for meals and other uses.Â  And because I can't grow them myself, but I still want jars of canned vegetables on my shelves.Â  And because most of the time it is cheaper to can the frozen vegetables than it is to buy individual cans at the store.Â  At present I have on my shelves from frozen:Sweet corn, peas, peas and carrots, mixed vegetables and green beans.Â  All taste just like the canned vegetables sold in stores with the exception of the green beans.Â  Those are just a bit softer, but that doesn't bother me although some might not like them.I can fruit in various forms.Â  The city stores don't seem to carry lugs of fruit for canning, but the outlying farming community stores sometimes do.Â  I have canned both peaches and pears from those stores.Â  We have a number of apple orchards in my area.Â  Most are tourist trap places where there are pony rides and camel rides and those inflated bouncy things for the kids and restaurants and gift shops that sell everything apple related and oh, yeah, you can pick your own apples at highly inflated prices.Â  I no longer go to those places.Â  There are a few smaller orchards that sell bushels of apples for cheap, if you don't care that each apple isn't the perfect size or the perfect color or it has a blemish on the skin.Â  I don't care.Â  I'm going to peel them and cut them up and make something from them.Â  As long as the quality of the apples are good inside the skin, I don't worry about appearances.Â  I'm kind of that way with people, too.Â  Anyway I make and can applesauce and apple pie filling, mostly.Â  If have made apple jam and may try some apple butter this fall.Â  I also make jam and jelly out of whatever fruit I can find.Â  And I get cases of cranberries from the Farmers Market that are used for cranberry juice and cranberry sauce.I think we all like homemade soup.Â  This can be successfully canned as well.Â  I make turkey vegetable, ham and bean, split pea and ham, vegetable soup and chili.Â  All are great when you just want a quick meal.Â  Just open a jar, add a pint of meat if you want, heat it up and dinner is served.Â  I also keep canned Great Northern beans on my shelves.Â  That is sort of like a convenience food because I don't need to soak the beans overnight or wait a length of time for them to cook.Â  They are cooked and ready to use right from the jar.Â  I may can a few other varieties of beans just to have on hand for quick meals.This post is already too long, so I will talk about dehydrating tomorrow.Â  There are many other foods that people home can, according to their own families' likes and dislikes.Â  What I have listed are the basics that are on my shelves.Â  I tend to can ingredients except for the soups and then put dishes together at the cooking stage of things.Â  Works better for me that way.Â  And this post is not intended to be a brag fest about my canning abilities.Â  It is all about putting an idea or two out there with the hope that someone else in my position - retired, living on a fixed income and being an apartment dweller - may find this helpful.

title: Time Flies
text: It seems like just yesterday she was a baby, all sweet and cuddly.And the next day she was a little girl, charming whoever she met. Â Especially her Grandma.And time seemed to move even faster...and faster.Until last evening when my firstborn granddaughter graduated from High School. Â Here she is with her mother and brother right after the ceremony.Congratulations, Nicki. Â I love you with all of my heart.

title: Chicken Drumsticks
text: So my grocery order was delivered today. Â The store had family packs of either chicken drumsticks or thighs on sale for 99 cents per pound. Â I had ordered four packages of drumsticks. Â Neither Son nor I are particularly fond of chicken thighs. Â The idea was to repackage the drumsticks in meal sized portions and freeze.When I took the packages out of the grocery bags I found that whoever did the shopping had given me four packages of chicken thighs. Â Aarrgh!The delivery guy was long gone. Â I suppose I could have called the office and complained. Â But when I thought about it, I decided that I'm pretty lucky to be able to have groceries delivered at all. Â And the people who do the shopping are volunteers. Â They don't get paid. Â And people make mistakes. Â And it's not like we are going to starve if we don't have those drumsticks. Â So I let it go.Now I have to decide what to do with about 20 lbs. of chicken thighs that I didn't want in the first place. I dug through my empty canning jars and set out some wide mouth quarts, washed them and stuffed them full of chicken thighs. Â Some of the pieces were so big that it only took three to fill a jar. Â I added water to about an inch below the rim, wiped the rim with a paper towel soaked in vinegar to get rid of any meat bits and fat, put on the lids and rings and ran them through my pressure canner for an hour and a half.And now I have eleven quarts of chicken cooling on my kitchen table. Â This meat will be really good in chicken and dumplings or chicken salad or chicken pot pie or chicken and rice. Â The canning process cooks it so it is falling off the bone tender.And now I am on my way to the kitchen for a bowl of ice cream. Â With chocolate sauce. Â And sprinkles. Â Which is my reward for spending a good share of the day canning when it wasn't in the plan. Â It almost always seems to work out anyway, though. Â :)

title: Minneapolis Declared Safe
text: There are very few news headlines that cause me to nearly spew a mouthful of coffee all over my keyboard. Â But this one came close: Â "Minneapolis Police Declare Downtown 'Safe'"So about 8:30 this evening I tuned in the police scanner for Minneapolis. Â Within about 45 minutes I heard the following calls:Gun shots reported.Individual on the street threatening people with a baseball bat.Individuals harassing passengers on a city bus.Several people fighting in the street.Another fight in a gas station parking lot.Victim robbed on the street.Two people causing disturbance on train.Large group of juveniles harassing and intimidating people.An attempted robbery with officer chasing suspect on foot.Yep. Â I Â sure feel safer now.

title: Tuesday Ramble
text: It is fairly quiet here in my little corner of the world. Â We had some rain over the weekend and it has rained all day today. Â Our local weatherman is predicting storms for the end of the week, but unless I see nasty clouds headed my way, I don't get too excited. Â The weathermen here get all wild about winter storms, talking like the storm of the century is coming, and usually there isn't enough snowfall to notice.The food preservation has slowed down. Â We are kind of waiting for the Farmers Markets produce, which may be later this year due to the cool spring. Â Generally that produce is well worth the wait. Â In the meantime there are a couple of meats that I want to get into jars and on the shelves. Â I have canned meatballs successfully and am all out, so that's on the list. Â And if ham ever goes on sale I would like to can some more of that as well. Â Until then I am just ordering sale items that I regularly use, buying enough to put a couple of cans in the cupboard and stash the rest. Â Mandarin oranges were on sale, so I ordered 10 larger cans with my grocery order to be delivered tomorrow. Â I think a batch of orange muffins is now on the "to do" list.I've been looking at alternative cooking methods. Â My kitchen stove is gas and even when there is no power, I can still light the burners. Â But if for any reason the gas were shut off, I need a back-up. Â Because of my location, I'm not crazy about grills or camp stoves out on the deck of my building. Â I'm thinking they would attract unwanted attention. Â And storing propane or camp stove gas in my apartment probably wouldn't be the smartest thing I have ever done. Â But I saw several videos and articles about the little one-burner alcohol stoves and wondered if anyone has ever used one. Â I know that the Heet used in vehicles and other kinds of alcohol can be used in these burners, and that might not be quite as bad to store as other fuels.So until I am back to canning, I am working on projects that have sat far too long. Â I have enough of these made for a quilt.This is all hand sewing, but it is relaxing for me. Â I'm in the process of sewing all the hexagon flowers together using a sage green fabric for the connecting hexagons. Â I may finish this quilt this year and I may not. Â But it keeps me busy and I enjoy it. Â I really need a trip to the fabric store. Â If you are a quilter, you know that we often have several quilts in various stages of completion and that we can never have too much fabric!I'm feeling a bit sorry for Oldest Son who worked in the rain all day. Â For supper I'm heating up the delicious chicken and rice soup he made a couple of days ago, because I don't want it to go to waste, and am having grilled cheese sandwiches with it. Â But thinking that just wasn't enough, I made a Peach Crisp that just came out of the oven. Â I hope it tastes as good as it smells!

title: Results of Experiment
text: The canned celery that I dehydrated worked pretty well. Â I still don't care much for it when it is rehydrated, although it rehydrates better than the celery I have dried when raw. Â Five pints of canned celery dehydrated down to a half pint in volume. Â I may just run that through my little grinder for celery powder and use it up that way, for flavor.The pineapple tidbits rehydrated almost perfectly to their original state and will work in any recipe calling for that size pineapple pieces. Â Three 20-oz. cans dried down to one pint. Â I will dry more of this.The pineapple chunks were in Â the dehydrator over 24 hours and still weren't completely dry. Â I decided that as long as both my son and I like dried pineapple snacks, I would just jar up the pieces, which have sort of a leathery feel to them and use them that way. Â The taste is wonderful, but I won't try to dehydrate any more for long term storage. Â Six cans of pineapple chunks fit into two pint jars when dried.Sometimes an idea works and sometimes not. Â I guess a person just doesn't know unless you try.

title: Dehydrating Pineapple and Celery
text: A while back 20 ounce cans of pineapple were on sale. Â I bought eight cans of tidbits and eight cans of chunks. Â I had used a few cans of the tidbits, but that still left me with a number of cans taking up valuable real estate on my shelves. Â So last evening I asked the tall person in the household (My, but it's nice to have a tall person in residence, especially when you have to climb to reach the top shelf!) to leave two cans of each in the cupboard and set the rest on the table. Â He did.This morning I dumped the pineapple into colanders and let them drain, saving the juice. Â When they stopped dripping, I spread the pieces onto my dehydrator trays, keeping the sizes separate. Â I had read somewhere that if fruit is dried at too high a temperature, the outside tends to dry while the inside stays moist, so I lowered the temp from the normal 135 degrees to 115 degrees. Â It will take longer to dry, but I would rather that than have pineapple that spoils because it isn't completely dry. Â The bonus was two and a half quarts of lovely pineapple juice to drink.Last year Youngest Son gave me lots of celery from his garden. Â I wasn't completely happy with the celery I had previously dehydrated. Â It dried just fine, but was not the best when rehydrated. Â I knew it wouldn't be like fresh celery, but it just didn't want to completely rehydrate unless used in soup that simmered all day. Â So I cut up my gifted celery and canned it. Â I wanted to be able to use the celery in casseroles and other dishes where the dehydrated wouldn't work well, and canning solved that problem.Except that now I have lots and lots of half pint jars of canned celery - more than I will use in the next several years - taking up space. Â And I am really low on empty half pint jars that I use to can bacon bits and I don't want to buy any more. Â So I decided to experiment a little. Â I had canned some of the celery in five pint jars that I had used when I ran out of the smaller ones while canning. Â So I opened them, drained the celery and spread the pieces onto my dehydrator trays. Â They went into the second dehydrator at the same temp as the pineapple.This is an experiment on both fronts. Â I have read about and seen videos on dehydrating pineapple, all with good results, but I had never before tried it myself. Â Most people cut celery into quarter to half inch pieces, blanch it and dry it. Â I've never heard of anyone drying canned celery. Â I'm thinking it all may be dry tomorrow sometime. Â I hope the experiments are successful, for dehydrated foods take up so much less space than the canned. Â I'll let you know what happens.my phone rang. Â It was Youngest Son. Â He often calls me while he is sitting and waiting. Â He waits for his daughters to finish dance lessons. Â He waits for clients to show up for meetings. Â Yesterday he was waiting in traffic.He was fussing because he wanted to be sure to get home on the other side of the city in time for his oldest daughter's induction into the National Honor Society. Â I told him to be sure to take a picture.He made it in time. Â Here is the picture of proud Daddy and daughter.Congratulations, Boston. Â Our family is so proud of you.Especially your Grandma.

title: You Have Got to Be Kidding
text: Political correctness has crossed the line from ridiculous to "You have got to be kidding."I'm pretty sure by now most of you have read about the Boy Scouts ban on squirt gun battles. Â I really don't know why I was surprised. Â This anti gun thing has totally run amok, from kids being sent home from school for wearing a t-shirt depicting any sort of weapon, to elementary age children being reprimanded for pointing a finger at a classmate and saying "pow, pow, pow," to the now famous nibbling of a Pop Tart into what was perceived as a "gun shape." Â And now Boy Scouts are not allowed to have squirt gun fights.And yes, I am going to go down that "When I was a kid" road.Dad bought a series of squirt guns for my sister and me. Â As the youngest of nine children, I'm pretty sure he remembered the fun of water connecting with a sister. Â We were kept busy for hours, chasing one another, each trying to stay dry while soaking the other. Â Or hiding around a corner or behind a tree, waiting for the opportunity of a sneak attack. Â Or getting off a really good shot at a neighbor kid. Â Who then proceeded to soak us. Â And when the cheap plastic squirt guns would wear out or break, he would bring home more. Â The only ban on squirt guns came from Mother who didn't allow us to use them in the house. Â Oddly enough, neither of us grew up with homicidal tendencies. Â Imagine that.My kids played with squirt guns. Â Pretty much the same way as my sister and me. Â Kept them occupied and out of my hair for hours. Â And guess what. Â There isn't a mass murderer in the bunch.I sometimes think that there is a plan to sissify our boys. Â My boys learned to shoot at a young age. Â For that matter, so did my girls. Â They all took gun safety courses. Â Both my boys hunt and both have provided their families with venison. Â In my Dad's time, learning to hunt was a necessary skill. Â It kept food on the table. Â There were times when the only meat my family had was the result of hunting. Â But now it seems that our children are supposed to run and hide when firearms are mentioned, seen pictured on a shirt or even pretended in little boy play. Â There may very well come a time when shooting skills are the only means of obtaining meat. Â These kids are going to grow up clueless.Little boys are no longer allowed to be little boys. Â Little boys are loud and obnoxious and like to do battle. Â It is their training ground for their responsibilities as adults to take care of and defend the family. Â But now if a boy acts like a boy, he is usually drugged. Â He learns that any sort of weapon is bad. Â He is taught to fear rather than respect firearms.So let's say that the little boy grows up. Â He has a wife, a couple of children. Â And some mean and crazy person breaks into his home. Â Won't happen? Â Read the papers. Â Watch the news. Â Happens somewhere every single day. Â So what's he going to do. Â He has no weapon for defense. Â It has been drummed into him that guns are bad. Â Mean and crazy isn't about to wait while he calls 911, or wait until the police arrive. Â Mean and crazy is going to, at best, hurt him and his family. Â Mean and crazy doesn't care if his victims are women and children. Â At worst, this husband and father won't live to regret his choices concerning the wisdom of owning a gun.So lets just keep on banning anything that smacks of defense. Â Lets keep on making our younger generation vulnerable to the mean and crazies of this world. Â Lets just keep on telling them that they should be tolerant and that gun free zones really work and nobody should have guns and nothing bad will ever happen to them. Â Because we all know that if guns are banned, surely the criminals Â won't have them either. Â Worked for England, didn't it? And for God's sake, lets not allow little boys to be what they are - little boys. Â Who grow up to be men. Â Who believe in the responsibility of caring for home and family and country. Â Who willingly defend them against all evil. That just would never do, would it?

title: Wake Up Call
text: A couple of days ago I read this post on Frank and Fern's blog. Then this morning Mary posted this.Sometimes it takes being hit with a 2x4 on top of the head to get someone's attention. Â Apparently I am one of those people.My smug self has been working hard to build up my food storage. Â I have been canning all the meat I could lay my hands on and dehydrating vegetables to fill in the gaps on my dried foods shelf. Â And in the process, forgetting about other things that are really important.I have never given much thought to a bug out bag. Â My reasoning was that I'm not going anywhere. Â Even if I could physically walk a distance from my home, which is doubtful at this stage of my life and state of my health, there is little chance I could do it carrying a bag full of supplies. After reading those two posts this morning, I remembered the fire that occurred in my building. Â I had found myself sitting on a bench across the street, watching the firemen working to put out the fire that gutted one of the ground floor apartments. Â The biggest thing I remembered was the awful feeling I had when I realized that all I had with me were the clothes on my back and my keys in my hand. Â I didn't even have on a proper pair of shoes, for I had slid my feet into a raggedy old pair of tennis shoes I used for excursions with the trash out to the dumpster. Â That's about all they were good for.Afterwards I had all sorts of good intentions. Â I would put the important stuff in a bag and keep it where I could just grab it and go if anything like the fire ever happened again. Â That was Â Almost. Â Two. Â Years. Â Ago. Â And I have yet to do it. Â Shame on me.So I started on this project this morning. Â Dug around in my closet and found a small duffel bag. Â I will replace this with a backpack as soon as possible, for a backpack is easier for me to carry. Â I also decided that, even though I rarely carry a purse, I have one with a shoulder strap. Â I will use that for some things and keep it handy to grab as well, on my way out the door. Â And I made a list. Â With my memory that is fading, a list is necessary.Everybody has different needs, so each person has their own list of what needs to be included. Â My purse needs to include a months supply of medication plus a bottle of aspirin to help with arthritis symptoms. Â Paperwork, including my Social Security card and information, my photo ID and a list of phone numbers for my children. Â I don't have a cell phone. Â Perhaps I need to rethink the need for one. Â And cash. Â Sitting on that bench two years ago and realizing that I didn't have two nickles to rub together was horrifying. Â Also a book of blank checks and my banking information. Â There are other items, but those are basic.The bag needs to include at least one change of clothes, from the knickers on out. Â And a decent pair of shoes. Â For health reasons I need to wear compression socks all the time, so a pair of those need to be added. Â A hooded sweatshirt for cool weather and lightweight shirts for warm days. Â Wintertime necessitates the addition of a knit hat, scarf and mittens. Â I remember how hungry I was after several hours of waiting to get back into my apartment after the fire was put out. Â So emergency rations of things like hard candies should my blood sugar levels drop, a couple of bags of dried fruit and things like granola-type bars and snacky things that will keep for a time are needed. Â Also the travel size shampoo, soap and lotion, along with a small towel and washcloth. Â And some bottled water. Â And something small that easily fits in a purse or backpack for my personal protection, which is on my "need to buy now" list.I'm not packing for an extended stay in the woods. Â Heading for the hills is not practical for me, so packing like I might for a couple of nights at a motel is more what I need. Â I'm sure there are other additions to my list, but for now I am going with the basics, which is more than I had done.My thanks to Frank, Fern and Mary for getting my attention. Â Being prepared isn't just filling the shelves with food. Â There is so much more to preparing than that, and I aim to make those corrections now.

title: Microaggression
text: While browsing through the WND website as I do most days, I ran across this headline:" 'WALK-ONLY ZONES' CALLED MICROAGGRESSION AGAINST DISABLED"The article can be accessed here. Â It says in part:"(Campus Reform) Arizona State University students are petitioning the university to change the name of its pedestrian walkways as its current nameâ€”Walk-Only Zonesâ€”might be a â€œmicroaggressionâ€ and â€œoffensiveâ€ to people who cannot walk."I've been seeing this word "microaggression" fairly often lately. Â Unsure of it's exact meaning, I looked it up. Â Wikipedia says, "Microaggression is a form of unintended discrimination. It is depicted by the use of known social norms of behavior and/or expression that, while without conscious choice of the user, has the same effect as conscious, intended discrimination. Psychiatrist and Harvard University professor Chester M. Pierce coined the word microaggression in 1970 to describe insults and dismissals he said he had regularly witnessed non-black Americans inflict on African Americans. In 1973, MIT economist Mary Rowe extended the term to include similar aggressions directed at women; eventually, the term came to encompass the casual degradation of any socially marginalized group, such as poor people, disabled people and sexual minorities."It seems that I can't open my mouth to say anything these days without offending someone. Â Do I care? Â Not particularly.I live with fun being made at my expense all the time. Â How many Senior Citizen jokes have you heard lately? Â How about Fat jokes? Â I hear them or read them often. Â And do I get my panties in a wad over them? Â Not likely. Â Some I actually find funny. Â Like when I told one of my daughters that my goal in life was to live long enough to be a problem to my children. Â Her reply was that my work here was done. Â Now, that's funny!As far as I can tell, there is not one single word in our Constitution about the right not to be offended. Â We will be offended by something or someone, often on a daily basis. Â I am offended when I hear the language used by the drunks in the street below my window. Â But the same freedom of speech that allows me to write this blog gives them the right to talk as they wish.There is a time and place for everything. Â If, for example, I am in a family restaurant with small children and someone is loudly holding forth using the same profanity as the drunks outside the bar, I might have a chat with the manager of that restaurant, requesting that he/she speak to the offending party, asking that because of the children present, they tone it down just a bit. Â If this doesn't happen, I will simply take my family and leave, making it crystal clear that not only will I cease to do business with this establishment, I will tell everyone I know about the circumstances. Many years ago I was in the market for a pickup truck. Â I Â went to a local dealership to see what they had to offer. Â The salesman asked me if I thought I could handle driving a pickup. Â Did I get mad? Nope. Â Did I scream at him for offending my female feelings. Â Nope. Â I merely told him that his commission would not come from me that day. Â I added that he might do well to refrain from making assumptions, considering at that time my job was driving an 18-wheeler pulling a flatbed trailer, carrying steel and lumber to points in the lower 48 states and Canada. Â And I wished him a good day on my way out the door.I had two choices. Â I could let his remarks offend me and hurt my feelings or I could let them roll off me like water off a duck and get on with my life. Â The first would keep me angry and annoyed and eventually give me ulcers. Â The second would make me a happier person. Â The look on the salesman's face when he realized his mistake was absolutely priceless and still causes me to smile when I think about it.When it comes to being offended over a "Walk Only" sign, I know whereof I speak. Â My Mother was wheelchair bound for many years. Â There was a time when I would take her shopping or to visit a friend or just for a drive in the country, if that's what she wanted to do. Â Never - not even once - did I hear her complain that she was offended because others could walk and she couldn't. Â Matter of fact, I can't ever remember her complaining at all, even though the pain in her joints must have been horrific due to the rheumatoid arthritis that ravaged her body. Â But offended? Â Never.We can't control what others say or do. Â We can only control how we let it affect us. Finding things to be offended about is a choice. Â So is being happy. Â I choose to be as happy as possible.The weather radar screen shows solid rain for today, slowly moving north from Iowa. Â No storms, but just a steady drip, drip, drip. Â It is expected to last all day. Â Most are glad to see it. Â My sons are not.Oldest son works mostly outside, driving a forklift, loading and unloading trucks. Â Last evening he came home and told me that until further notice he would be working from 6 AM toÂ 6 PM Monday through Friday and 7 AM to 3:30 PM on Saturday, starting today. Â He was really happy about the chance to get in some serious overtime. Â The rain...not so much. Â But last week he bought some rain gear, so he is prepared.Youngest son spent yesterday loading a large rental truck with boxes, bins and tubs full of his family's belongings. Â Today the movers come to get the heavy furniture. Â And tonight David's family will sleep in their new home. Â Luckily the new house is only a few miles from their old house, so it isn't like they have to travel far. Â But unloading the trucks in the rain will not be a joy. Â The kids are excited. Â I think by now Mom and Dad are too tired out and just want to get the moving part over with. Me...even though I have been told several times before that because I am not made of sugar, I won't melt in the rain, I don't think I will test the theory. Â It is a good day to sew or crochet or work on Granddaughter's photo album. Â Last night I took a 12 lb. turkey breast out of the freezer to thaw and will roast it later for supper. Â The best part is turkey sandwiches made with the leftovers. Â And I think a nap is probably in my future as well.Unless you are in a drought area, I hope your day is dry and sunny.

title: Weekend Totals
text: So after Son made another couple of grocery runs, here is what I have:A total of 45 lbs. of chicken breast that yielded 54 pints. Â I had one jar break in the canner and another that didn't seal, using all metal lids. Â The one that didn't seal will be supper tonight, in gravy over biscuits.12 lbs. of bacon ends and pieces, cut into pieces no larger than 1 inch, yielded 19 half pints of bacon bits. Â The yield is less than other meats due to shrinkage when I fry it up before canning. Â There might have been a little more, but it's bacon and the temptation to sample as I worked was just too great.They jury is still out on the 28 lbs. of carrots. Â They are all diced and waiting to be blanched before being dehydrated. Â All I know for sure is that I will have 28 lbs. of carrots that, when dry, will likely fit into a one gallon freezer bag.And now I'm going to take a nap.

title: This One Is For You, Boston
text: Boston is nearly 13 years old.Â  Boston isn't usually wearing makeup, but this picture was taken while she was in stage makeup for one of her dance competitions last month.Â  It is the latest picture I have of her.Boston had a goal.Â  She wanted to make the National Honor Society.Â  So she worked to make it happen.Â  Yesterday it did.The letter was waiting for her when she got home from school.Â  She called her Dad.Â  He told me she was so excited that he couldn't understand a word she said.Â  He had to wait for her to calm down and speak a little more slowly, without the squeals of delight.Â  Girls who are almost teenagers squeal with delight.Â  A lot.Â  I think it is in their DNA.I called her last evening.Â  I wanted to congratulate her and tell her how proud her Grandma is of her and her accomplishment.Because I am.to see just how much I can accomplish in a weekend.Â  It is probably a good thing that much of it can be done while sitting at my kitchen table.Â  :)Last evening Son came home with 15 lbs. of frozen chicken breast.Â  The price hasn't gone up as yet, so he is going back to the store today for more.Â  Every day we hear of the bird flu spreading to another farm.Â  I have lost track of how many millions of chickens and turkeys have been destroyed.Â  One of the largest chicken/turkey processing plants in our state just laid off 233 workers because of it.Â  It is a sad state of affairs, especially for those who were working and now are not.Â  Common sense tells me that before too long the prices in the stores will reflect the damages.Â  The local news reports have even suggested that folks would do well to think about serving something other than the traditional Thanksgiving turkey dinner this year.Â  So I am buying as much chicken as I can now while it is still affordable.Â  When canned and stored under the right conditions,Â  it will keep for years.Our local store got rid of that awful bacon I canned and then had to toss, and replaced it with the good stuff.Â  Another 3 lb. package came home with Son as well.Â  Both of us really like the bacon bits I can and even though he won't be living with me forever, he will still benefit.Â  All of my kids know they can shop in Mom's pantry whenever they want, and they can leave their cash and credit cards at home.Â  That's what makes Moms happy - feeding their kids, even when they are all grown up.Fresh carrots are also on sale this week for 50 cents a pound, so Son grabbed 10 lbs.Â  Last evening I peeled them and cut them into pieces that will fit in my Vidalia Chop Wizard.Â  I love that little gadget.Â  I already wore one out and replaced it.Â  Lucky for me our local Target store carries them.Â  Tomorrow I will dice, blanch and get the carrots to drying in the dehydrators.Â  I really like having the dehydrated vegetables on hand.Â  They take up so much less space than the canned.Â  I prefer the canned or frozen for meals, but for soups that I simmer all day on the stove or in the crock pot, the dried can't be beat.Â  And kept away from light and moisture, they will keep indefinitely.Â  Son is getting more carrots, too, as long as they are so cheap.I finally feel like I am getting caught up from this past winter.Â  Before I started with the grocery delivery service, I pretty much just ate from my food storage.Â  And I ate well.Â  There are those who can't figure out why I spend so much of my time on food preservation and storage.Â  I am blessed to have children close by who have been happy to bring me the food I needed at other times when I couldn't get out myself.Â  And I have no doubt that any of my four would do whatever I asked of them.Â  But it is very important to me to be able to take care of myself, even with the physical limitations that seem to show up fairly regularly as I age.Â  And should everything come crashing down around our ears, the knowledge that my family will not go hungry is a huge comfort.Â  I pray we never have to test the theory, but if we do, I would rather be ready than wonder where the next meal was going to come from.Â  Been there.Â  Done that.Â  Don't ever want to do it again.

title: Today I'm Canning Pork
text: The other day I sat at my kitchen table enjoying a cup of coffee and browsing through my local grocery store sale ad for this week.Â  I noticed they had boneless country style pork ribs on sale for $1.99 a pound.Â  I don't know how it is in other parts of the country, but you can't hardly ever find any kind of meat for that price here any more.Â  I told Oldest Son about the sale and he said he would stop on his way home from work yesterday and get some.So late yesterday afternoon Son came in the door with just a bit under 28 lbs. of pork.Â  He said he cleaned out their display.Â  I know from past experience that when the store runs a sale on this kind of meat, it isn't the neat, evenly cut pieces that one usually gets.Â  Some of the pieces are large and thick while others are smaller.Â  It isn't as free of fat as pork loin, but the fatty bits are small and easily trimmed.Â  There is very little waste.After supper I browned the pieces of pork in my cast iron frying pan.Â  IÂ  could have skipped this part, but I think it helps keep the meat moist and adds to the flavor.Â  It was too late in the evening to start canning, so the meat went into the fridge overnight. This morning I put the meat pieces into 9x13 cake pans and into the oven for 15 minutes just to warm them before packing into the jars.Â  I wound up with 18 quarts of pork.Â  I will use them like I might a pork roast.Â  One quart jar will yield one nice pork roast meal for one or two people with leftovers for sandwiches or soup.Â  I think that's well worth the time and money.

title: Quiet Sunday
text: Beautiful day with temperatures hovering around 80 degrees.Working on Granddaughter's photo album for her graduation.Â  Sometimes the mojo is working - sometimes not.Â  Today everything seems to be coming together without a lot of aggravation.Still smiling after a phone call last evening from a friend.Â  Amazing how the sound of a voice you care about can make a person feel so good.Conversation with Son is always a good thing.Â  I wondered if it would bother me having another person here after living alone for so long.Â  It doesn't.Afternoon naps are necessary.Â  Especially when one tends to stay up late at night.Ordering pizza for supper, which is something we rarely do so it is a treat.Listening to the sound of raindrops and thunder boomers as a mini storm rolls overhead.Â  The radar website tells me it will be over in a few minutes.Â  Maybe a little more rain headed this way overnight.Â  We need it.Windows open and a slight breeze entering the apartment.Â  I will enjoy that now, for before long they will be closed and the air conditioning will be on.Â  I love the smell of fresh air, even if it is town air. All in all, a very good day.

title: Once Upon a Time...
text: there was a relatively peaceful building with apartments above a bicycle shop.Â  This peace and quiet was shattered about 11:00 last evening by the sound of a smoke alarm.Â  There was no smoke smell and my alarms were quiet.Â  I headed out into the hallway to see if I could tell where the noise was coming from.Â  It was coming from the apartment directly across the hall, which is occupied by a single guy and hisÂ  dog.I gave the guy a little bit of time to get the alarm shut off.Â  I know all about our smoke alarms that will sound for the most slim of reasons.Â  But he doesn't shut it off.Â  By this time 10 minutes have past.Â  I knocked on his door, thinking that maybe something was wrong with him.Â  No answer.Â  His dog started barking when I switched from knocking to pounding.Â  Still no answer.Down the hall and around the corner I went, fashionably dressed in nightgown and robe, to see if I can rouse the caretaker couple.Â  No such luck.Â  Back to my apartment, meeting another neighbor on the way who was just as fashionably dressed as I was and who was not pleased about being awakened.Â  If we had chickens, she would be going to bed when they did and getting up with them.Â  Unlike the night owl that I am.I called the landlord, apologizing for the lateness of the hour and explained the situation.Â  I didn't want to call 911 if there is no reason.Â  He says he will call me back.Took the landlord two calls to wake up the caretakers.Â  The guy in the apartment where the smoke alarm was still beeping like mad, never did answer.Â  The dog was not happy.Â  Neither was the sleepy chicken lady neighbor.Â  20 minutes had now passed since I first heard the alarm.Turns out the guy across the hall had been doing his level best to see that the whiskey industry remained solvent.Â  When the caretakers finally went into his apartment, they found him passed out on his couch and his pizza that was in the oven, burned to a crisp.Â  The dog was glad to see the caretakers.Â  He is such a nice dog.Â  They shut off the alarm, deposited the round piece of charcoal in the kitchen sink and ran water over it to stop it from smoking, shut off the oven and fed the dog.Â  And we all lived happily ever after.Â  Except for the guy across the hall who is probably nursing a monumental hangover today.The End.read the instructions.When canning any food, I take the jars from the pressure canner and set them on a towel on my kitchen table. Â There they stay overnight, giving jars and food plenty of time to cool. Â In the morning I remove the metal bands and wash the jars in hot soapy water to remove any residue, label them with the contents and date, and stack them on my shelves.This morning while removing the bands from the pints of hamburger I discovered to my absolute horror that over half of the lids had not sealed. Â I had used the Tattler lids on these jars. Â And that's where the reading the instructions part comes in.When using Tattler lids, the metal bands that hold the lids in place need to be tightened and then backed off about a quarter inch before canning. Â I did that.Often times while processing, the metal bands will loosen. Â So when the jars are removed from the canner, the bands need to be tightened down immediately. Â I did not do that.I forgot.Read. Â The. Â Instructions. Â Especially if you have a memory like a sieve as mine is.I wiped down the rim of each jar that hadn't sealed with vinegar on a paper towel to remove any grease or food particles that would keep the jars from sealing. Â Back into the canner they went for another go-around. I used all metal lids on the jars of bacon, and they all sealed just fine. Â But then, they don't require any special handling. Â Used to be that metal lids needed to be simmered in hot water to soften the rubber part that adheres itself to the rim of the jar, but that isn't even required any more.Sometimes I think my mind is just slowly turning into Jello.

title: I Lied...
text: Well, not on purpose. Â I just wasn't paying attention yesterday when the packages of bacon arrived in my kitchen. Â They were 3 lb. packages - not 5 lb. Â They yielded 13 half-pint jars of diced bacon. Â The 18 lbs. of hamburger gave me another 21 pints for the shelves. Â The last of it is in the pressure canner as I write. Â And I wonder why it is that I can't get my fingers to type a single sentence on this laptop without creating errors. Â Sigh.Tomorrow morning I will get going with the Great Northern beans. Â I didn't write down how many quarts of canned beans I can get from one pound of dry beans last year, so your guess is as good as mine. And now I'm off to clean up my messy kitchen. Â I really wish I were one of those tidy people who can wash a dish as soon as it is dirtied, dry it and put it back into the cupboard. Â Alas, I am not. Â I have two dishwashers, but both are located on the ends of my arms, so there is no hiding away the dirty dishes. Â Pray for me. Â And if I don't resurface in a day or two, send in a rescue party.

title: Canning Experiment Results
text: So my 12 lbs. of hamburger yielded 10 pints of taco meat and 4 pints of Sloppy Joe meat.Â  That's about right.Â  I always figure about one pint per pound of meat.Â  Yesterday we tried the Sloppy Joe meat.Â  I will not be canning any more.Â  It isn't bad, but it isn't very good either, at least not for it's original intended use.Â  It won't go to waste.Â  I can use it in spaghetti sauce or something else that will hide the flavor.I know that sometimes when ingredients are added to meat for canning, the flavor doesn't always turn out as one would like.Â  So I was kind of afraid to try the taco meat.Â  But we put on our brave faces and had tacos for supper.Â  They were really good.Â  And even though I liked the results, I probably will stick with my original plan to can plain meat as ingredients rather than risking a failure.Â  Groceries are just too expensive these days to mess with what I know works.The grocery delivery guy brought me 18 more pounds of hamburger.Â  I had 6 pounds left from the previous batch and I froze that for burgers, meatloaf, etc.Â  This afternoon I browned the 18 pounds and tomorrow morning I will pack it into pint jars and run it through the pressure canner.Son started his new job today.Â  He came home smiling.Â  He says the people there seem like they will be good to work with and he gets to drive a big, ol' diesel forklift, moving pallets of potting soil and mulch.Â  And he gets weekends off, although he can get overtime if he wants it.Â  His previous Minnesota job worked him two weeks at a time with only two days off.Â  He worked holidays as well and because he worked nights, a good share of his days off were spent sleeping.Â  Looks like this new job is a good fit for him.Â  And he says that he is always happier when working a opposed to being unemployed.Anyway, on his way home from work today, Son stopped at the grocery store.Â  He brought me home 10 lbs. of the good bacon ends and pieces as well as 10 lbs. of Great Northern beans.Â  I will dice, brown and can the bacon as soon as I'm done with the hamburger and then can up at least half the beans.Â  I like having beans in jars on the shelf.Â  There are so many uses for them and it is nice because I can use them without having to soak them overnight or spend a long time cooking them.Â  Kind of a prepper's convenience food.Looks like I will be spending lots of time in my kitchen the next couple of days.Â  Not complaining, mind you.Â  I am so glad to be able to add to my food storage.Â  A person doesn't have to prepare for anything in particular.Â  I'm really not expectingÂ  street full of zombies outside my building.Â  Although there are some days when I think maybe they have already arrived.Â  Lots of strangeness running around loose these days.Â  But if I am ready for just the normal stuff that happens, then it is good.

title: Buying Meat.....
text: before the prices go completely through the roof.I couldn't find any chicken in the sale ads that came out over the weekend. Â But hamburger was on sale. Â If you call the already outrageous prices a sale. Â But still, I'm saving around $1.25 per 3# chub of meat, so I guess that's better than full price.Son went to the store and brought me back 18 pounds of hamburger, along with some taco seasoning. Â I'm doing an experiment. Â I like to have a variety of home canned food on my shelves, so I browned up 9 lbs. of burger, drained it and seasoned it with the taco seasoning. Â  It will stay in the fridge overnight and in the morning I'll can it in pint jars. Then I took another 3# of meat, browned it, drained it and added the ingredients for Sloppy Joes. Â We will give both a taste test in the next week or so and decide than if I want to do more.Wednesday this week is grocery delivery day. Â I have another 18 pounds of hamburger ordered, giving me a total of 24 more pounds of hamburger to can just plain. Â I hate paying the high prices for meat at the store, but I know that prices are not coming down any time soon. Â Even if I have to pay full price for chicken breast to can next week, should there be none on sale, I think it will still be worth it. Â Minnesota, as well as some of the surrounding states, is dealing with the bird flu outbreak. Â Our governor has called out a National Guard unit to help in hauling truckloads of water to the poultry farms where the birds were killed, to mix with the chemicals used to get rid of the disease. Â I fully expect that the lower prices we have enjoyed for chicken and turkey will soon be a thing of the past. Â Anything that I can have on my shelves at today's prices is a good thing.

title: Adventures in Groceries With Dad
text: In my last post I made as silly remark about fixing myself a fried Spam sandwich which garnered me a couple of comments about that kind of food. Â That got me to thinking about some of the foods I grew up with. Â Mother was very conventional in her notions of what food should consist of, but Dad was another story altogether.Dad dearly loved pickled pig's feet. Â Every once in a while he would buy a jar as a treat for himself. Â Mom turned up her nose. Â She didn't like how they looked or smelled, so Dad and I would go out on the back steps and eat pickled pig's feet straight from the jar, tossing the bones to the dog, who then wasn't allowed in the house until the effects of the pickled bones had passed through his digestive system.Dad loved the pies and cakes that Mom made. Â And he could bake an apple pie to rival all others himself. Â But often times when no dessert was on the table, he would tear up a slice or two of bread into his coffee cup, pour a little hot coffee over the bread and top it off with a spoonful of sugar. Â He called this Poor Man's Pie. Â He told me once that desserts were rare when he was growing up. Â His family was rather poor, eking out a living on a small farm in northern Minnesota. Â With nine children in the family, basic meals were more important than dessert. Â He said his mother came up with this concoction as a means to satisfy a sweet tooth.Mother didn't go into town alone very often. Â Riddled with arthritis, she was physically incapable of grocery shopping and carrying heavy bags of food from the car into the house. Â Dad worked in town, so he mostly bought the family groceries on his way home after work. Â Which is why an odd assortment of food in cans or jars wound up in our cupboards. Â Dad liked to try new things.One of the first of these experiments that I remember was Potted Meat. Â Comes in a little can - smaller than a can of tuna. Â Looks kind of like bologna that has been whirled in a blender for a while. Â It tastes sort of spicy. Â Whether it is really meat is open for debate. Â Dad loved the stuff. Â He made sandwiches with it. Â What he liked best was that it was cheap. Â As a kid I had to try most everything he brought home that was new and different. Â I found that I actually like the stuff. Â It is on my food storage list as something to have on the shelf for a quick, easy sandwich. Â Along with Spam. I wish I knew what brand of canned ham Dad used to buy. Â It was delicious. Â We went on a lot of picnics at the lake in the summertime. Â Mostly with my aunt, uncle and cousins. Â Our family nearly always furnished a canned ham that we sliced up to go on homemade buns, and potato salad. Â Sometimes the ham was sliced and fried for breakfast and sometimes it was roasted in the oven until nicely browned, usually with a raisin sauce on top. Â It was all good. Â But the last canned ham I bought that I could afford was so bad the dog wouldn't even touch it. Â We're talking about a dog who, given a 10 second window of opportunity, would be buried up to her tail in a sack of evil, foul smelling garbage that was sitting by the door, waiting to go out to the dumpster. Â  Â That's bad.About the only thing that Dad brought home to try that I couldn't eat was sardines. Â I think sardines are one of those foods that a person either loves or hates. Â Dad loved them. Â I hated them. Â Just couldn't stomach those oily little fish crammed into that can. Â Dad said that was alright. Â He would eat my share for me.Gee, but I miss Dad.

title: Change Isn't Always Good
text: I love my old computer. Â I have had it for nearly 7 years. Â It has had a workout, for I use it for many tasks as well as entertainment. Â It is a desktop model with a large monitor screen, so often in the evenings I would find something interesting to watch, get comfy in my recliner and sew or crochet and watch a video. Â Or listen to music. Â Or listen to an audio book. Â Or listen to the police scanner.But more often than not, my trusty old computer has been showing me the blue screen of death. Â Lucky for me, while recovering from health problems this past winter, Â Youngest Son agreed to go buy me a new laptop. Â It's not his fault. Â He bought exactly what I told him to buy. The latest version of Windows is, in my opinion, the worst operating system ever. Â In the vernacular of my Father, "You have to go all the way around the barn to get to where you want to be." Â I've sort of got it figured out now, after much trial and error and the use of many new swear words muttered under my breath. But it's not just the inconvenience of the operating system. Â I had Google Chrome installed on the old computer. Â I didn't have it installed on the new one. I was using Explorer. Â This version of Explorer doesn't like Google's Blogger or YouTube. Â While working on a post for my new genealogy blog, I needed to upload photos. Â Sometimes I could, and other times not. Â I get all sorts of error messages popping up when trying to post. Â And worst of all, while trying to watch a YouTube video, I get sound but no picture.So I installed Chrome, which fixed some of the problems. Â But I still can't watch videos, which irritated me no end as I wanted to watch my granddaughters dance via streaming video over this weekend.Guess I'll have to swallow my pride and get a computer savvy grandkid over here to sort it all out for me. On the up side, I hope to be knee deep in poultry next week. Â According to the news reports, the price of chicken and turkey will be going up due to the outbreak of bird flu here in Minnesota and some of the surrounding states. Â The sale ads for the local grocery stores come out over the weekend, and #1 Son says he will do a grocery run to buy up any chicken that is on sale. Â And even if I have to buy it at regular price, and even if the bird flu weren't a factor, the meat will still cost more by next year. Â Whatever I am able to can or freeze now will save money in the long run.I have been sorely lacking in blog posts lately. Â My only excuse is that I have been spending time working on my granddaughter's scrapbook for her graduation in June. Â I don't know why it is, but when working on anything that takes just a bit of artistic creativity, the mojo is either there, or it isn't. Â Sometimes the digital scrapbook pages go together like a dream and other times I fight to get the look I want. Â It has been a good time for indoor activity, for the last few days have been cool and wet. Â No storms but just lots of drizzle. Â This morning the temperature has warmed to 48 degrees and the sun is shining. Â Sunshine is good. Â Makes for a whole new outlook on life. And now I am off to make a fried Spam sandwich for lunch. Â My Dad dearly loved a fried Spam sandwich and he passed that love along to me. Â It is one of my comfort foods. Â I'm sorry. Â :)

title: April in Minnesota
text: This morning Son had a job interview in a suburb north of here.Â  He said that it was snowing when he got there.Â  I looked out the window about a half hour ago at 6:30 PM and saw a few flakes in the air.Â  Enough, already.Â  In a normal year folks around here are wearing shorts and flip flops by now.Â  I'm seeing heavy jackets and hoodies in abundance. But I have faith that within a month or two I will probably be complaining just as loud and long about the heat and humidity.Â Â  We are never satisfied unless the temperature is in the mid-70's and the sun is shining.Â  I wonder which day that will happen.Oh, by the way...Son's job interview went really well.Â  As soon as the drug test results come back and the company checks out his references, it looks good for him to be employed at just the kind of job he has been looking for.Â  He is happy about it and greatly relieved.Â  His instincts were correct when he decided to come back home.Â  Always believe in your gut feeling, I think.So what with cold temperatures, snow flakes in the air and being a generally gloomy day, it seemed a good idea to bake some bread.Â  The fact that I had about half a loaf left in the house influenced that decision.Â  Three loaves, two dozen buns and a pan of cinnamon rolls are cooling on the kitchen table.Â  Of course some of it had to be taste tested right away.Â  If it isn't the law, it is at the very least the rule of this household that at least some bread must be consumed right out of the oven.Â  So we did.Â  :)

title: Just Playing
text: I went through the scrapbooking supplies I have on hand and discovered that I am sorely lacking what I need to make a conventional decorative scrapbook album for my granddaughter's graduation. Â Supplies are spendy. Â I'm not so sure I care to put out a bunch of cash right now for a hobby, even if it is a gift.I got to thinking that I had, at one time, a blog that consisted of family pictures featured in scrapbook pages that I made using graphics and my computer - digital scrapbooking. Â I found that I still had those graphics saved on my external hard drive. Â I wondered why I couldn't make the decorative pages using the graphics program I have and then either print them out myself or take them somewhere for printing. Â Easy enough to do using an 8 x 8 background and printing to fit into a nice 8 x 8 album, sliding each page into protective sleeves I can get at the craft store. Â And there is the advantage of being able to put the album pages on a DVD and make copies for anyone else who might like to have it. Â Her mother, for instance.So I spent last evening downloading some new graphics to add to my collection. Â There are some digital scrapbook designers that offer a selection of freebies for the digital scrapbook enthusiast. Â They are free to use as long as they are not used commercially. Â I am doing this just for family, so no problem with copyright issues.If you would care to see what these scrapbook pages look like, here is a link to my old blog. Â I am amazed that it can still be accessed, as it hasn't been added to for several years. Â I used it just for family pictures.momsscrapbookpages.blogspot.comMy methods and choices in graphics have, I hope, improved since then. Â At any rate, today I am messing about with it all to see what I can come up with for the album. Â It is a good day for it - cool and damp outside. Â A good day to stay indoors and just play.

title: Lots of Chicken
text: Grocery delivery guy arrived yesterday. Â Usually he doesn't get to my apartment until the middle of the afternoon, but yesterday he was here before noon. Â My order this week included 18 lbs. of chicken breast that was on sale. Â The early delivery gave me time to can it up the same day.Sometimes I pack cut up chicken breast into the jars raw. Â When I can turkey I cook it first to make it easy to get off the bones. Â I decided to cook the chicken mostly to thaw it all quickly so I would have time to can it before evening.Son helped. Â He put the chicken on cookie sheets and baked them in the oven until they were done through. Â He passed the pieces on to me and I cut them up into bite-sized pieces and filled the jars. Â Most of the time when cooked meat is canned, a liquid is needed, so I filled the jars with hot water, wiped off the rims, added the lids and ran them through my pressure canner for 75 minutes. Â 21 pint jars of canned chicken are waiting to be wiped off, labeled and put on the shelf.I wondered if there was any difference in price between canning on-sale chicken breast at home or buying the cans of chicken breast at Sam's Club. Â I did the math this morning, Â It would have cost me nearly $20 more to buy the cans than to buy the 18 lbs. of frozen chicken breast and can it myself. Â I didn't figure in the cost of jars or the Tattler lids as I already had them and they had all been used at least once before this. Â And they can be used again as opposed to opening a can and tossing it when empty. Â I think it was worth the cost.Cub Foods also had smoked sausage on sale - the kind that is like ring bologna. Â I bought 5 of the rings, cut one of them into about 1-inch pieces, packed the pieces into jars and canned them with the chicken. Â They look good in the jars and I will taste test later this week to see if I like the result. Â I hope so, for that could be another variety to add to my meat shelf.So until I have more to add to my food storage, it is on to another project. Â My oldest granddaughter graduates from high school in June. Â Each graduating grandchild gets an afghan crocheted by her grandma and a photo album full of pictures of her taken over the past 18 years. Â The afghan was completed over the winter, but I haven't started on the album. Â The photos will be placed on decorative scrapbook pages and put into a nice album for that purpose. Â Son is off running errands and will bring me the supplies that I have run out of and need to do this.I love scrapbooking. Â This is gonna be fun!

title: It is Lovely...
text: when the son who is staying with you for a while was a restaurant cook in a former life.Menu for supper: Â crispy chicken fried to a golden brown, hash brown potatoes and the vegetable of the day. Â Followed by pineapple upside-down cake for dessert.I think I may have died and gone to heaven. Â Or at the very least, I am being spoiled completely rotten.

title: New Blog
text: For my children, grandchildren and cousins who are interested: Â Cousin Linda asked me about our Morehouse ancestors. Â I have accumulated too much information to make it practical to print out or email, so instead I started a new blog for the purpose of sharing genealogy information and photos. Â So far there are only three posts, but there are more to come. Â The title of the blog is "Matheny - Olmstead - Paul - Morehouse Family Tree," and the url is mathenyfamilytree.blogspot.com.
