Â Feel free to comment or email with questions, corrections or information. Â My email can be found in the profile section of both blogs. Â I'd love to hear from you.

title: Beef Stew and Biscuits
text: So yesterday morning Son says to me, "I'll make you a deal. Â I'll make beef stew for supper if you will make the biscuits." Â Being a reasonably intelligent person as well as a lover of stew and biscuits, I jumped all over that deal.Middle of the afternoon he raided my canning shelves. Â A couple jars of beef chunks, a jar of potatoes, carrots and peas, another of green beans and a small jar of corn and a quart of tomatoes went into the pot. Â He mixed in seasonings and let it simmer. Â While the biscuits baked, he thickened it for gravy. Â It was wonderful! Â And the leftovers will be good tomorrow, too.The kid can cook.In the interest of honesty and not wanting anyone else to experience the same failure, I have a bacon update.My method for canning bacon bits is to cut up the meat into about half inch pieces. Â Then I lightly brown the meat in a pan, drain off the grease, pack the meat into jars and pressure can for 75 minutes. Â And the result has been lovely bacon bits, fully cooked. Â Even the fatty pieces are crispy. Â Just like when you fry up bacon in a pan for breakfast.It didn't work out that way this time. Â Last evening I opened the jar that hadn't sealed. Â Wanted to see how it tasted. Â The first piece I pulled from the jar was one of the fatty bits. Â It is bacon. Â There will be fatty bits, but this one was slimy. Â Even with the frying before packing into the jars and even with an hour and 15 minutes in the pressure canner, the fatty bits did not crisp up. Â I have 23 jars of slimy fatty bacon bits that are browned on the outside and disgustingly greasy in the middle. Â It is something I would have a hard time eating without gagging.It is my own fault. Â The boxes the bacon was packed in said that the product was smoked but not cured. Â This was different from all the other bacon I have previously canned successfully. Â I should have paid better attention and canned up a couple of test jars to see how it turned out before canning the whole works at once. Who knew. Â I thought bacon was bacon, either smoked or cured.Live and learn.

title: Bacon...
text: is one of life's little pleasures.Son made a run to our local grocery store today and came home with two 5 lb. boxes of bacon ends and pieces. Â The store must have changed suppliers, for this bacon was different from what I had always bought there before. Â This was smoked but not cured. Â A taste test showed it to be tasty - sort of smoky with a touch of maple flavor. This bacon had been chopped before packaging so there wasn't the variety of sized pieces I was used to. Â The pieces were a bit large for the jars, so I cut them a little smaller, browned them slightly and packed them into half pint jars. Â Wound up with 23 jars. Â And a quart jar full of lovely bacon grease for frying and baking.It looks like one jar didn't seal, so we will use that in scrambled eggs for breakfast one day this week. Â If we like it, I will buy more. Â The price is less than the previous brand, so that is a plus.I'm confident that this bacon will taste good after canning. Â I mean, it's bacon. Â I have yet to find bacon that didn't taste good!

title: Mother Nature Hates Us
text: So I'm sitting at my kitchen table this morning, happily filling cookie sheets with peanut butter cookie dough, when I happen to glance out my kitchen window...And see SNOW!Not just a few flakes, but big, huge, fluffy flakes. Â Lots of them.The only saving grace is that it is too warm for the snow to stick to the ground.Give it up, Mother Nature! Â We are so done with you!

title: Rain and Refrigerators
text: Sometime during the night I heard the sound of raindrops bouncing off the ledge outside my windows. Â We are in a mild drought area - nothing like the west and southwest, but the lack of snowfall and spring rains have contributed to the general dryness. Â There is no significant wind or lightning - just a gentle, soaking rain and it is welcome. Â Although it is still a chilly 38 degrees this morning, the warm sunshine is promised for the weekend and into next week. Early yesterday afternoon my new stove and refrigerator were delivered. Â I have to admire the cheerfulness of the two delivery guys, who, in spite of huffing appliances up and down the steep stairs to my apartment, were smiling and pleasant. Â I remarked to one, a tall, muscular young black man, that I marveled at how he and his partner could spend their days carrying heavy refrigerators, especially on stairs like mine. Â He laughed and replied that it was a job and he was glad to have it. Â He said that many who don't have jobs wind up behind bars and he would much rather be working. Â Besides, with all the lifting and carrying, he didn't have to go to the gym to get a work-out.The new refrigerator is larger than the old one. Â The guys took my apartment door off the hinges. Â They removed the doors from the refrigerator. Â They took a part that was protruding off the back. Â And even with all of that, they only cleared the doorway by maybe a quarter of an inch. Â But the old, troublesome appliances are gone and the pretty new ones are in place. Â Landlord came by about suppertime and hooked up the gas to the new stove. Â I think it is a good day to test the oven with a batch of homemade bread.Son went to the store this morning and brought me back two packages of bacon ends and pieces, for a total of 6 lbs. Â This afternoon I will chop the bacon into about half-inch pieces, lightly brown them and can them in half-pint jars. Â The homemade bacon bits are so good on salads or in scrambled eggs or omelets. So now I'd better get busy. Â After weeks of relative inactivity, it really feels good to have stuff to do!

title: So This Afternoon...
text: I called Number One Son to find out where he was. Â He had spent the night in Grand Island, Nebraska, on his way home. Â When he answered his phone, the reception was terrible, so I just told him to call me later and hung up.Right about supper time my phone rang. Â The reception was perfect. Â He said, "It is 1855 miles from the door of my apartment in Las Vegas to the door to your apartment."I'm so glad he is home.

title: Off On A Ramble
text: My family is not getting together for Easter this year. Â As sometimes happens, especially with larger families, some had commitments elsewhere. Â That is fine with me, for I kind of wanted to be home in case Oldest Son calls. Â And I am probably the only human being on the planet (or at least in the USA) who still has a house phone and doesn't have a cell phone.Oldest Son left Las Vegas yesterday morning. Â Around lunch time he called from St. George, Utah. Â He wanted me to look up St. George on my computer so I could see how beautiful the country was there. Â I did. Â It is. Â Last evening he called from Grand Junction, Colorado. Â He said that he had driven about 500 miles, was tired and thought he would sleep and set out again in the morning. Â I thought that was a good plan. Â If I remember right, the road between Grand Junction and Denver has a lot of up and a lot of down and a lot of curvy, which means that daylight driving is a good thing. Â It will be a couple more days before he is home.The oven in my kitchen stove died. Â It was a slow death. Â First it would light (it is a gas stove) but would not heat. Â A few days later it would not light at all. Â Yesterday my landlord found the problem. Â The burner for the oven was fried - as in a hole burned into it. Â When he left my apartment, I thought he was going to order the parts and fix the oven. Â A couple of hours later he called, wanting to know if I had to have white appliances or would a stove and refrigerator with a stainless finish be OK. Â He said that he decided to just replace both, as I had been having problems with them and the way things are made now, they likely wouldn't last much longer anyway. Â So my new stove and refrigerator will be delivered Wednesday. Â And I can bake bread again. Â I have been missing baking bread.Â I don't ever again want to hear anybody complain about not having enough storage space. Â Within my three rooms I have been moving things around to make room for Duane and his stuff. Â There isn't any furniture to deal with, but there is all of his household goods, clothes, etc. Â I have two closets in my bedroom. Â The largest of the two I had converted into a pantry, using some cheap stand alone shelves (6 of them), stacked and holding assorted extra food like baking supplies, commercially canned soups, other canned goods I had bought on sale and lots of pasta. Â The shelves are about a foot wide and deep and about table-top high. Â One went into my bathroom for extra towels and Duane's toiletries. Â The rest were distributed into nooks and crannies and corners of my living room. Â Next week I will pick up some fabric to make tablecloth-type pieces to drape over them to hide the contents. Â Worked out just fine. Â Where there is a will, there seems to always be a way.Today will be a day of just puttering. Â I hear the beautiful sound of church bells coming from the Catholic Church a couple of blocks away. Â I believe that a person doesn't have to go to church in order to worship. Â But we do need to find our faith and stay strong within that faith.My wish for you is to have a blessed Easter Day.

title: My Children...
text: lost their Grandmother today. Â She was 98 years old.I met her nearly 60 years ago when my Dad purchased a 20 acre parcel of land with an old farmhouse, from a family member. Â It was located literally next door to the family farm. Â In 1964 I married her oldest son. Â And when we could no longer make the marriage work, she said she loved me anyway.She worked harder than most women. Â She kept a big, old farm home spotless. Â She raised a family of five children. Â She kept a huge garden to help feed that family. Â And when her husband and sons were out working in the fields, she hauled countless lunches to them so they didn't have to take the time to come to the house to eat. Â She was involved with the local 4-H club and never missed a Sunday of church services.After a time she and her husband, along with those children remaining at home, moved into town. Â She lived in the same house for many years after her husband's death. Â And when she began taking Senior bus tours all over the country, I was glad that she was doing something for herself.She cared for her own home well into her 90's. Â My youngest son once called me. Â He had stopped by her home to see her, only to find she was out someplace having coffee with her friends. Â "She's gone all the time," he complained. Â "She is 90 years old," he said. Â "Good for her," I replied.She lived about 100 miles from me. Â I saw her occasionally at family get-togethers with my children and grandchildren. Â She was always interested in what I was doing and always had a hug for me. Â She always told me she loved me.I will always be grateful to have had such a wonderful mother-in-law. Â She was a remarkable woman, dearly loved by family and friends alike. Â I will miss her.The first thunder storm of the season rolled through here last evening. Â I had been listening to the police scanner when the storm reached my county. Â When the Weather Bureau issued a severe storm warning, the weather spotters were called out.If you are at all interested in following storm tracks, the spotters make it kind of interesting. Â Here in my county there is one central dispatcher for the weather spotters. Â Each spotter has an area of the county that they cover. Â They radio in to the dispatcher, sort of like a roll call, to report conditions in their area. Â They tell if the lightning is in the clouds or hitting the ground. Â They report on wind, rain, hail and anything else they see. Â It is one thing to follow a storm on radar, but by listening to the weather spotters, it is easy to tell if anything bad is headed this way.It wasn't much of a storm this time. Â Just a little wind and rain and spotty small hail. Â Some, but not much, lightning hit the ground. Â I didn't even have to close my windows.I have always liked to watch a storm. Â As a kid, my Dad and I would stand in our front porch and watch the storm clouds roll in. Â Unless the weather turned really nasty, we would stay there and watch as long as we could. Â Sometimes the lightning displays were spectacular. Â And the cloud formations were fascinating. Â And it was even more fun to be brave and stand with Dad on the porch, as opposed to cowering in the basement with Mom and sister!I still like to watch a storm, and if one is headed my way from the west, I can probably be found out on the deck, watching the clouds.

title: Popcorn and the Smoke Alarm
text: For quite some time now I have had issues with the smoke alarms in my apartment. Â The locations of the two smoke alarms make sense only to someone who actually understands the fire codes for this city. Â One alarm is located on the kitchen ceiling about a foot away from my bedroom door. Â The other is located on the bedroom ceiling about a foot away from that same door. Â Which puts the alarms about two feet apart.My kitchen stove is across the room from the kitchen smoke alarm. Â That alarm works fine. Â The identical alarm in my bedroom will go off if I leave the door between kitchen and bedroom open and use any burner on my stove or open the door on the hot oven. Â That alarm not only beeps loudly, but screams "Fire, Fire!" Â Doesn't matter what the landlord does to fix this problem. Â This is just the way it is. Â And it is not easy to shut off. Â Takes a little time to get it to stop beeping and screaming.I like popcorn. Â I like popcorn for an evening snack. Â I particularly like popcorn dribbled with a little bit of butter, sprinkled with Lawry's coarse ground garlic salt with parsley and then with Parmesan cheese.I haven't owned a popcorn popper for a while. Â The last one I had was one of those hard plastic bowls used in the microwave. Â Cat knocked it onto the floor and it broke right in the middle.Then I made my own microwave popcorn by putting about a half a cup of popcorn kernels into a brown paper lunch bag, taping the bag closed with Scotch tape and microwaving it. Â Worked like a charm. Â Until I ran out of lunch bags. Â Do you suppose I can remember to buy more bags? Â Not likely.So I have been making my popcorn in my cast iron frying pan. Â Works well. Â Except when I get careless about watching it and I burn the heck out of the popcorn. Â Which sets off the smoke alarm because I also forgot to shut the door between kitchen and bedroom. Â At 11:00 at night. Â I don't think my neighbors were very happy with me.I'm thinking there will be no more popcorn in my future until I get to the store and buy a popcorn popper that is smoke alarm friendly.Sigh.

title: On My Way Out the Door
text: Happy Dance first.  No more bandages.  My shoes will now fit on my feet again.  I am free to go where I want, when I want.  I'm going to celebrate with a walk down by the river - something I haven't been able to do for at least five months.Â  So you will excuse me, won't you, while I go enjoy the great outdoors.Â Life really is good!

title: Coming Home
text: Last fall my oldest son headed out for Arizona. Â He spent several weeks looking for work with no results. Â So he moved on to Las Vegas to try his luck there. Â The temp. job he found ends this week. Â There are no other jobs for him on the horizon. Â My son has always been a hard worker and has not been picky about jobs. Â This tells me that the job market is really lousy or it is flooded with those willing to work for starvation wages. Â I'm not sure which.At any rate, he is headed home in a little over a week. Â As a Mom, I'm really happy to again have all of my chicks close by. Â In this time of such uncertainty I am glad that my family will be close. Â There is strength in numbers and I would rather have those numbers be family.Duane has kept his sense of humor. Â This morning he posted a link on Facebook to the Ozzy Osbourne song, "Mama I'm Coming Home." Â :)

title: One of Those Days
text: I don't have them real often. Â One of those days where I just don't feel like doing anything worthwhile. Â But today seems to be in that category.Snow is in the forecast. Â As I look out the window, I see that it has just begun to fall. Â I am told that when all is said and done, there should be anywhere from 3 to 8 inches of the stuff on the ground. Â That really doesn't affect me much as I won't be going outside just yet. Â But my sympathy lies with those who have to drive to work tomorrow morning.In anticipation of a lazy day, my Kindle is fully charged. Â A freshly made pot of coffee awaits. Â Supper is in the crock pot - two beautiful pork chops that I will later smother with sage dressing. Â In an hour or so I will combine breakfast and lunch with a fried egg sandwich. Â Sprinkled with garlic salt. Â Maybe a bit of shredded cheese.I thank God on a regular basis that after so many years of working, I am now able to take a lazy day if I wish to. Â For me, that is the absolute height of luxury. Â So I'm going to grab my Kindle, put my feet up, settle back and finish the story I'm reading about a couple of amateur detectives in the 1920's. I just love those old books. Â Especially the murder mystery ones. Â It is fun to sift through the clues to try to guess "who done it." Â I am often wrong, but it is fun just the same. Â Yes, I know. Â I am easily amused!

title: Ball and Kerr Lids vs Tattler Lids
text: Lately I have been experiencing lid failure in my canning - that is, jars that don't properly seal. Â I seem to have more failures with the meat I can than with fruit or vegetables. Â Some of this may be due to operator error. Â Maybe I didn't wipe down the rim of the jar well enough or maybe I should have simmered the metal lids in hot water, even though the directions now say not to do so. Â I don't know.I'm not losing any product, for I just put the unsealed jars into the freezer and use them before using the ones on my shelves. Â But that's not the point. Â If I wanted frozen hamburger, I would have wrapped it and froze it to begin with. Â I want canned hamburger in jars on the shelf. Â And this last batch left me with five jars destined for the freezer, out of 13 jars, total. Â That's way too many failures.A while back I bought three boxes of the wide mouth Tattler lids and three boxes of the regular size. Â Tattler lids are plastic with a rubber gasket that goes between the lid and the rim of the jar and forms the seal. Â I tested these lids with fruit, vegetables and meat, all with good results. Â They worked just fine.There are two reasons I didn't buy any more Tattler brand lids. Â The first is the price is more than double that of the standard metal lids. Â But Tattler lids can be used again and again until the rubber gasket wears out and then new gaskets can be purchased, so the price is probably justified. Â The second is a perfectly silly reason. Â Tattler lids don't have that satisfying popping sound when they seal like metal lids do. Â You don't know if they have sealed until you test them the next day to see if the lids are firmly attached. Â I didn't like that. Â Silly me.I'm seriously considering investing in a large number of the Tattler lids. Â I don't need to add shipping, for my local grocery store now carries them. Â So I'm wondering if anyone else who cans has had similar problems with metal lids recently (since Ball and Kerr have made changes to the sealing component on their lids) or have used the Tattler lids and if so, with what results.Inquiring minds want to know. Â :)

title: Just For the Record...
text: Who keeps these records? Â And why? Â And is there really a permanent record anywhere? Â And did all of those transgressions of my youth really go on my permanent record? Â There were threats to that effect!Oops. Â I got off the track for a bit there.The record I'm talking about is the one I keep to let me know how much produce or meat equals how many pint jars full when canned. Â I found that 25 lbs. of carrots, some sliced and some diced, equals 32 pints and 24 half-pints. Â Or 44 pints. Â I can a number of vegetables and meats in half-pint jars simply because that is a good amount for one person - which I am.So the last canner load of carrots is heating up. Â Then it is on to the 15 lbs. of hamburger. Â The excitement builds. Â (Insert snarky grin here, because canning 25 lbs. of carrots and 15 lbs. of hamburger really is the most exciting thing going on in my life at the moment.) Â Sigh.

title: Time to Do...
text: a Spring Happy Dance. Â Temperature is in the mid 50's with a forecast of up to 65 this week and into next week. Â My landlord put a nice little bench by the back door of my building. Â I think I will go out, sit on the bench and soak up some of that warmth and sunshine.This may not last. Â For us here in Minnesota, March can be a cruel month. Â Blizzards in March are not unheard of. Â But for now, my apartment windows are open a little, letting in a warm breeze.The sun is shining. Â There is no ice. Â There is no snow. Â I'm just going to enjoy this while I can!

title: Making Do
text: I've been craving green salads lately. Â My last grocery order included a head of lettuce and a couple of tomatoes. Â I forgot about the salad dressing.I have in my recipe collection, several recipes for a dry mix to make and keep on hand to make a Ranch Salad Dressing. Â But in looking over those recipes I found that I was missing several of the ingredients. Â So I dug through my old recipe box that contains recipes I have had for many years. Â Sure enough, I found a recipe for Ranch Dressing that I could make with just a few minor adjustments.Ranch House Dressing2 C. buttermilk Â (I found buttermilk powder at the grocery store, so I keep a couple of cans on hand and make up just the amount I need.)2 C. Mayo Â (I use Miracle Whip)1/4 C. chopped fresh parsley Â (I use the same amount of dried.)1/2 of a large onion, chopped (I used a handful of dehydrated onion.)1-2 cloves garlic, finely chopped (I used 2 tsp. garlic powder.)Dump everything into a bowl, whisk it together and refrigerate. Â This dressing doesn't taste exactly like the store-bought ranch salad dressing, but if you like ranch, you probably will like this substitute. Â It will fit into a quart canning jar.As long as I'm on the subject of salad dressings, here is a recipe that I've been using for over 40 years. Â The name of the recipe is FrenchDressing, but it is more like a darker, richer Russian dressing. Â It is really good on a green salad.French Dressing1/2 C. vinegar1-1/2 C. ketchup2 Tbsp. lemon juice1/4 tsp. paprika1 large onion, grated2 C. vegetable oil1 C. sugar1/2 tsp. salt1 heaping tsp. celery seedWhisk to blend. Â Pour into jars and refrigerate. Â This dressing will separate in the fridge, so just shake it up before pouring on a salad. I've taken pork chops, covered them with slices of raw onion and poured this dressing over the chops like you would a barbeque sauce. Â That's when I tried this - when I was out of barbeque sauce! Â Baked in the oven until well done, they are delicious.I think one of the most important things my parents taught me was how to "make do." Â Growing up, we lived 10 miles from town. Â If we were out of something, we couldn't just jump in the car and go to the store. Â We "made do" with what we had. Â I have found that making do with what I have often saves me money in the long run. Â And as grocery prices continue to rise, I think I will be making more of the things like salad dressings rather than buying them pre-made. Â Both of these dressings cost me much less to make than to buy. Â Same goes for making things like cakes or brownies or cornbread or pancakes from scratch rather than buying ready-made mixes.I know there are times when buying new is necessary. Â But when it comes to cooking and baking, I think the lessons I had on how to make do were a good thing.

title: Canning Update
text: Just a short post to give the results of the canning marathon that has been going on here.Applesauce - 12 pintsMixed vegetables - 20 pintsGreen beans - 23 pintsFruit juice - 45 pintsI lost one pint of mixed vegetables when the bottom broke out of the jar in the canner. Â I don't know why that happens. Â It just does. Â Thankfully, jars rarely break.Until I am able to be out and about myself, I will shop the store sales every two weeks for grocery delivery. Â What I add to my food storage will depend on what is on sale. Â I have found that the people who take my grocery order over the phone have a computerized grocery list to go by. Â That list doesn't always include what I might buy, like the 5 lb. boxes of bacon ends and pieces or some of the foods that come in #10 cans that I re-can in smaller jars. Â Those things will wait until I can go get them myself. Â I still have the handy dandy little old lady shopping cart and I haven't forgotten how to use it! Â (grin)On a personal note, I am celebrating the fact that I no longer need bandages on my right leg. Â I have graduated to a compression sock only, to help control fluid build-up in my lower leg. Â The left leg is more problematic, but nevertheless is healing. Â The home care nurses tell me that hopefully, within a month, that leg will no longer need the protective bandages. Â And when that happens, look out world, for here I come!

title: Back At It
text: Not much blog worthy going on here lately. Â Just the normal cleaning, laundry, etc. Â You know - exciting stuff! Â However, yesterday was grocery delivery day and I am back to working on my food storage.I know that the way I do things is a bit unconventional. Â Most of the folks whose blogs I read regularly have gardens, or raise their own meat chickens or goats or other meat animals. Â But as an apartment dweller, I don't have those options. Â I have the best landlord in the universe, but I'm pretty sure he would be unhappy if he found a goat or two living with me. Â And there are no community gardens in my neighborhood, so I have to rely on other resources for some of my food storage.I prefer home canned foods to commercially canned. Â Mostly because I was raised on home canned food and because I have, over the years, continued preserving food this way, first for my family and now for myself. Â I buy frozen vegetables when they are on sale. Â This week it was 32 oz. packages of green beans and mixed vegetables. Â I bought 6 bags of each. Â Yesterday afternoon I canned up the green beans and got 24 pints. Â Later today I'll run the mixed vegetables through my pressure canner.There wasn't much for meat on sale this week, but there were apples for 99 cents a pound, which is good for my area. Â I bought 12 pounds. Â This morning I peeled and sliced the apples and they are cooking down for applesauce. Â I prefer chunks of apple in my applesauce and by making it myself I can have it just the way I like it. Â I can also control the amount of sugar by adding just enough brown sugar to taste good. Â I'll water bath can the applesauce as soon as it has cooked down enough.I like to have fruit juice on hand. Â But if I buy the frozen concentrate, chances are good that I won't drink a whole can before it goes bad. Â Same with the half gallon jugs. Â Juice is sugary so those of us with blood sugar issues need to drink it sparingly. Â I get around the problem this way. Â Half gallon jugs of cranberry juice and cranberry-apple juice were on sale for $1 each. Â I bought 6 bottles of each flavor. Â When I finish with the applesauce and vegetables, I will pour the juice into a large pot, heat it to near boiling, fill hot pint jars with the juice and water bath can it for 15 minutes. Â By canning it in pint jars I can still have a glass of juice from time to time without messing up my blood sugar, as I can drink half a pint one day and the rest another. Â And it is a good thing to have on hand should my blood sugar get low. Â And I won't have to throw any away because it has sat in the fridge too long, as has happened before I started canning it in smaller containers.I guess I write about the way I do things so that maybe somebody else in my position will be encouraged to at least give it a try. Â I hear excuses from some of my vintage for not having any food storage at all. Â They say that they can't have a garden. Â They tell me that they have no room to store anything. Â They say they just want to buy what they need each week. Â This last excuse I just don't understand. Â People get sick - particularly within my age group. Â I am the perfect example of that. Â If I didn't have food put back and if I lived in an area that didn't have a grocery delivery service, I would have been screwed. Â I am lucky to have adult children living close by, but many of my peers don't. Â The point is not that a person has to do things the way I do. Â The point is that no matter if you like to can your own food or whether you buy it already canned or packaged at the grocery store, there are ways to have enough food on hand for emergencies. It is all about taking care of yourself. Â In the end, nobody is going to come knocking at your door to deliver food and water during a crisis. Â Think Katrina and Sandy. Â And then get busy.

title: In the Military
text: This afternoon my oldest granddaughter became Private Nicole.She will finish High School this coming spring and toward the end of summer will leave for Basic Training.I want to cry because my grandbaby is all grown up. Â But I can't because I am way too proud of her to shed tears. Â She did not come to this decision easily. Â She gave it serious thought, did her research and decided that the Army was the best fit for her.Nicki, I have always been proud of the person you are, but I have never been more proud of you than I am right now.Love, GrandmaHad a small setback this morning. Â Nothing serious, but I find I will not be let loose on the general population quite as soon as I would like. Â New skin that has grown over wounds is fragile and can split. Â And it did, so more time to heal is required. Â Drat!Anyway, I was trying to keep my mind occupied with some genealogy research after my leg was bandaged up again. Â Wasn't working very well. Â I was on Â the brink of feeling sorry for myself when the phone rang.The word "friend" doesn't always refer to someone we have known since school days. Â Friend can mean someone we have never met in person, but have gotten to know through our blogs. Â She reads mine. Â I read hers. Â We have exchanged comments and emails. Â She worried about me enough when I was in the hospital to call and leave a message for me. Â I worry about her living in a drafty house when the snow falls and the wind blows. Â We both have senses of humor that mesh.She called me today. Â We chatted about everything and nothing. Â We laughed at the crazy drivers on icy roads in her part of the country and mine. Â We talked about what each of us had been doing. Â We talked about upcoming events. Â We marveled at what a small world we live in where a friend of hers lives about 10 miles from the town in northern Minnesota where my brother lives and within 25 miles from where my family is from.And I forgot all about feeling sorry for myself.Thank you, Mary. Â I wonder if you have any idea what that call meant to me and how much it cheered me up when I really needed it.

title: On Being Prepared
text: My canning session today turned into a longer one than expected.I had opened the freezer in my refrigerator to take something out, and found that everything was thawed. Â Checked the refrigerator and it was warm as well. Â Called my landlord, who said he would be here by suppertime, and if he couldn't fix it, he would get me a new refrigerator. Â He was able to fix it, but has plans to replace all of the appliances in the building within the year. Â He is right when he says that things just aren't made to last any more.In the meantime, I had 6 lbs of thawed hamburger. three pounds of thawed chicken breast and a thawed whole chicken.Some laugh at me or just shake their heads when they see that I have extras of most everything. Â Including canning jars. Â Including canning lids.Cut the chicken breast into about one inch pieces and packed them into pint jars. Â Ran those jars through the pressure canner with the second canner load of ham and bean soup.Browned the hamburger and packed it into pint jars. Â Processed it after the soup and chicken were done. Â Got 8 pints of hamburger.I was reluctant to refreeze the whole chicken, so I plopped it into a stock pot, covered it with water and added seasonings. Â Cooked it over a low flame the better part of the afternoon and had part of it for supper. Â The rest I packaged up and put into my chest freezer.If I hadn't had what I needed on hand to can the thawed meat, I might have lost it. Â I can't afford to toss out meat. Â And I don't like to freeze meat that has been frozen and thawed. Â So for me, canning is the best option.Let them laugh. Â I don't care. Â I would rather be laughed at and be prepared than to not have what I need when I need it.Two days ago, youngest son called me. Â He had a couple of meaty ham bones for me. Â Bless his heart - whenever he bakes a ham for his family, he saves the bones for me. Â He knows I dearly love homemade ham and bean soup.So that evening I set to soaking a quart and a half of great northern beans. Â And yesterday morning I dumped the beans, 3 quarts of homemade chicken stock and a couple of handfuls each of dehydrated chopped onions and dehydrated grated carrots into a large stock pot. Â Added enough water and chicken bouillon to make enough soup broth and slow cooked it all morning. Â After lunch David showed up with the ham bones and into the pot they went to cook the rest of the day.I love it when my kids show up at my door. Â They don't even have to bring anything except themselves. Â Well, maybe a grandkid or two would be nice!So this morning I re-heated the soup and filled pint jars. Â I suppose if I were canning for a family I would use quarts, but a pint jar is just right for me, provided it is accompanied by cornbread. Â Gotta have the cornbread with ham and bean soup. Â I think it might be the law.Anyway, out of that quart and a half of beans and two meaty ham bones, I got 14 pints of soup. Â Plus enough for supper last night and supper tonight. Â Love it when a plan comes together. Â Especially when it involves ham and beans!

title: Brrrr...
text: The temperature is still in the minus column and it looks like it will probably stay there today. Â My apartment stays warm with the thermostat set at 70 degrees, and it only occasionally drops down to 67 or 68. Â I am grateful to be living in an old building with outer walls that are nearly a foot thick, and living on second floor where the rising heat from the bicycle shop downstairs keeps my floors warm as well.Today is a good day to piddle about with sewing projects. Â I got to digging through my closet and found a couple of half-finished quilt tops, so I'm working on those today. Â Country music on the radio and once in a while some classical for a change of pace. Â Hot coffee within reach. Â The promise of my favorite cold weather comfort food - chicken and dumplings - for supper.I have some running around to do, but that will keep until it warms up later this week or the first part of next week. Â Need to get fitted for compression socks and maybe take a trip to the fabric store, just for fun. Â Been a while since I was out and about just for fun. Â I'm thinking I will do more of that when warmer weather arrives.Sometimes I tend to get caught up in the seriousness of my latest illness or in the horror of the news lately, and forget that life needs to be lived, too. Â I used to go places and do things just for the fun of it, and maybe it is high time to get back into that habit.

title: It's Grocery Delivery Day
text: By the middle of this afternoon, I will have a variety of meats, fresh fruits and fresh vegetables delivered to my kitchen. And most important of all, a new jar of Orville Redenbacher popcorn, which is my evening treat a couple of times a week. Â The longer I use this service, the more I like it. Â Especially on days like today. Â It is -9 degrees outside, with a wind chill factor of -31 degrees. Â You can bet your bottom dollar that I'm not going out.I do feel a bit sorry for those volunteers who do the deliveries. Â Especially since they are not allowed to accept tips for this service. Â There are ways to get around that rule, however.The last time I had groceries delivered, there were peanut butter cookies waiting, fresh from the oven. Â Another time it was cinnamon rolls. Â And today there will be blueberry muffins waiting.There are ways to express appreciation without dollars changing hands. Â My delivery guy seems to like this arrangement, for he tries to guess what the delicious aromas are that greet him when he enters the building. Â I make sure to send along enough for him to share with his wife. Those who volunteer to help make the lives of others a bit easier, deserve heartfelt thanks and recognition for what they do. Â And a few cookies now and then when we aren't allowed to tip in cash.

title: What is Wrong With This Picture
text: A young thug is shot by a police officer. Â The violent protests of this action, fueled by the usual suspects of race baiters, spread across our nation. Â There was righteous indignation aplenty. Â TV sound bites abounded. Â Our president even weighed in on the subject.There were 21 Christian men who were lined up on a beach in Libya to have their heads chopped off by Muslim terrorists. Â Where is the righteous indignation of the Christian community? Â Where are the protests to this horrific deed? Â Why aren't people marching in the streets to decry the acts of these savages?These things aren't happening because we are too busy being politically correct. Â God forbid that we should offend anyone, even a bunch of bloodthirsty savages.God help us, although I can't say as I would blame Him if He doesn't. Â We aren't doing such a good job of defending Him, are we.

title: Last Health Update
text: Just finished having the bandages on my legs changed. Â All the wounds are healed over. Â Looks like in another week or so I will be able to go out and about again. Â And life can get back to something close to normal. Â Doing a Happy Dance, right here, in my living room. Â Good thing I live alone. Â A Happy Dance performed by a chubby grandma is best not seen by any other living human being. Â But this news was just too good not to celebrate just a little bit.

title: Life is Good
text: Doctor visit yesterday. Â Told me that judging by my older records, I am now healthier than before I became ill. Â Said according to tests given me in the hospital, my heart is strong. Â Although I am not a fan of vaccines, I agreed to a pneumonia shot. Â And although I am also not a fan of the medical profession, I kind of like this guy, who is new to me as a physician. Â Seems like a straight shooter and I think I can work with him.So this morning...Bluegrass on my radio.Browning 18 lbs. of hamburger prior to filling pint jars for canning.While the hamburger is being processed, I will be making out my grocery order, which is interesting as I need to find sugar-free foods. Â Not happy about that, but I can live with it. Â I miss chocolate chip cookies, though! Â :)It is so very good to be home.

title: Nellie Dreschler, WWII Survivor
text: While fiddling about on the Internet a while back, I stumbled across this video. Â Nellie Dreschler is a charming lady who, as a child, survived WWII in Holland. Â Later she immigrated to the United States and became a citizen.She decided to record her experiences for her children and grandchildren, to give them an understanding of what life was like for her family during that period of history. Â I found her testimony fascinating. Â There are many parallels between what life was like then and what we are living through now. This video was filmed Oct. 17, 2013. Â I think it is well worth watching. Â Draw your own conclusions.Nellie Dreschler, WWII Survivor

title: Darn It!
text: Anybody know what these are?They are called darning eggs. Â A sock with a hole in the heel or toe is pulled over the darning egg which gives a stable foundation for darning the hole.I wonder how many sewing kits today include darning needles and thread. Â My mother always had a good supply for fixing holes in socks. Â We didn't just toss socks when a hole appeared. Â We fixed the hole and wore the sock until it couldn't be fixed any more.We didn't have a darning egg. Â That was a luxury. Â We had burned out light bulbs that served the purpose just fine.And I wonder how many of today's young even know what darning is. Â I have my doubts that there are any. Â We wear a hole in a sock and toss it. Â I find it sad that we live in a throwaway society. Â So much waste. Me...I'm glad that I know how to fix socks, replace zippers, sew up seams and patch pants knees. Â I might not have the newest or most fancy clothes on the block, but they are without holes and rips and tears.Oh yeah. Â I forgot. Â That's the style now, isn't it. Â Silly me.

title: Coffee
text: My doctor said that I can have only two cups of coffee each day.I can live with that.

title: Rethinking Food Storage
text: While waiting to go home from the rehab facility, I spent some time looking online at the floor plans of apartments in the building where I put in my application. Â I hope to be able to get the least expensive one, which isn't much more than I am paying right now and is within my budget while being comfortable for one or two people. Â After some quick calculations, I found that my heavy duty shelves that hold my canned goods just won't fit anywhere. Â Drat.After thinking about alternatives for a while, I have come up with a plan.I did some extensive reading online about dehydrating. Â I already dehydrate a variety of vegetables, but other foods can be dehydrated as well. Â And when dry, they are light in weight and smaller in volume, making them easier to store than food in jars. Â Food in jars is more convenient, but I have to work with the living space available.So I have started dehydrating some of my canned goods. Â I had 10 large cans of diced tomatoes. Â I drained them, saving the juice to drink, and filled the dehydrator trays. Â Those ten cans will dry down to about a quart of tomato bits.I had five trays with mesh liners left over from the tomatoes, so I opened jars of canned sweet corn and dried them. Â Corn rehydrates back to its original form - you can't tell the difference between canned or dehydrated. Â And ground up in a blender, it makes cornmeal that results in the best cornbread ever.I read a couple of articles about making your own instant mashed potatoes, so I have an experiment going for that. Â I opened two quarts of canned potatoes and dumped them into the blender, liquid and all. Â Whizzed them around for a while until the lumps were gone, and then spread them thinly on fruit roll-up sheets. Â Three trays are in a dehydrator now, and when finished I will test the theory to see if it works. Â I hope so, because I have at least 16 cases of canned potatoes on the shelves.I've decided that I will continue to can meat. Â It is so much cheaper to buy chicken breast and can it than it is to buy the little cans of chicken. Â And canned meat doesn't get freezer burn. Â Here is a list of the meats I normally can:chicken breastturkeyhamburgermeatballs, plainmeatballs in mushroom gravyham cubespork roastpork cubesbeef roastbeef cubesbacon bitssausage crumblesI even tried some pepperoni slices for pizza, and it worked just fine.Anyway, that's the plan. Â We'll see how it goes.

title: Short Update
text: I am healing. Â Previously the changing of the bandages on my legs every other day would cause a session of pain that would last several hours before subsiding. Â Today the bandages were changed not 15 minutes ago and there is no pain. Â Thank you, God.I go home tomorrow morning. Â Home health care nurses will come in to do the changes twice a week. Â My right leg is almost completely healed. Â The Wound Care nurse who has been dealing with my legs tells me that the left leg should be healed Â within a couple of weeks. Â Earlier they were talking perhaps two months to heal.I will be back as soon as I am settled in at home. Â I want you all to know how much your thoughts and prayers and encouraging comments have meant to me. Â Thank you.Home. Â Such a lovely word.....

title: Home Again, Home Again, Jiggity Jig!
text: I sorta doubt that there will be many dancing jigs involved, but it looks like Thursday this week is going home time. Â I'm thinking it will probably will be more like crawling up the stairs and then a nap. Â But at least the nap will be in my own bed. Â That to me is pure gold.I'm still not off the hook. Â I will have home health care nurses coming in two or three times a week to change the bandages on my legs. Â The wounds are healing nicely, but there are still some places that rate an "ugly" description. Â I am told that total healing may take up to two months. Â That being said, I am in much better shape than I was two weeks ago. To my chagrin, it seems that part of the deal is to also have physical therapy people showing up as well. Â That does not thrill me, but I will do it until I run out of patience. Â As we all know, patience is not my long suit.The only part about going home that is difficult for me is that I am going home to an empty apartment. Â After I had to have my Lily put down a couple of weeks ago, I was down to just one cat, namely Kizzie. Â (There was a time when two Yorkies and three cats shared space with me.) Â Because it is difficult to deal with cat hair and because I know that I will be moving, I made the decision to let her go. Â  Fortunately, one of my daughters is seeing to it that Kizzie goes to a good home. Â At this point, others are more likely better able to care for her and give her the attention she needs. There are a lot of changes in my life just now. Â Some good. Â Some lousy. Â But all things considered, life is still very, very good!!

title: Sometimes You're The Dog...
text: other times you're the hydrant.Well, life tends to have its little ups and downs, doesn't it. Â  The past days have been more on the down side, but things are getting better each day.I spent nearly a week in the hospital. Â The final diagnosis was Cellulitus (sp.?), which amounts to fluid build-up followed by a bacterial staph-like infection Â taking over, which left me with two ugly open wounds on each lower leg. Â Surgery was done to clean these up and begin treatment.It was also found that I have diabetes, but it looks like that can be controlled without the use of insulin.I am now residing in a rehab facility where treatment continues and my strength is slowly being restored. Â I'm guessing it will probably be another week before I am released back among the general population.The hardest thing for me is not the treatments or the physical rehab. Â It is being in constant contact with people. Â As most of you know, I live alone and like it that way. Â I don't do Bingo. Â I don't do group activities. Â I don' enjoy all of those Senior Citizen type frolics. Â I love my solitary life and most times don't care if I see anybody except my family. Â But I have put myself in a grin and bear it mode. Â I will do whatever I need to do to get to go home again.My children have been wonderful. Â They have seen to my every need. Â They have been at my apartment taking care of the things I haven't been able to do for myself before entering the hospital. Â They are helping me find another apartment with elevators and easier laundry facilities and no stairs. Â I am on a waiting list.Last evening my brother walked through the door of my room, totally surprising me. Â He had driven many, many miles just to see for himself that I was doing OK. Â I love my brother.So that's what I have been up to. Â How are things with all of you?

title: Off The Radar
text: I will be off the radar for hopefully, a short period of time. Â I have fluid build-up in my lower legs. Â This has caused ulcerated areas to appear above my ankles where the fluid is draining. Â These areas have become painful and no home remedy is helping. Â There seems to be no sleep for me tonight due to the pain.My children have ganged up on me and bawled me out for not going to the hospital Emergency Room before this. Â So this is to my children: Â You win. Â And you are right. Â I am as stubborn as you say I am. Â If any of you read this before I call you in the morning, I am ready to go to the Emergency Room. Â I ask that one of you take me. Â The ambulance service charged me over $1400 for a ride across town for your Step-dad seven years ago. Â Don't want to think of the cost now. Â Don't want to have to pay that much for a five minute ride.I need to get this fixed. Â I need to get my life back. Â And I need to let go of stubborn so my kids will quit yelling at me. Â :)

title: Good-bye Miss Lily
text: Today is not the best of days. Â My little Yorkie, Lily, had deteriorated in health to the point where she was merely existing and not living. Â My daughter took Lily to her vet today and she was put out of her misery.Lily was a hoot. Â She loved to chase a ball and would bring it back, only to veer off course at the last second and hide the ball in her kennel. Â She dearly loved her stuffed animal toys and sometimes would gather them all into her kennel as well, other times hauling them around, play growling at anyone who came close.Some years back my landlord installed an intercom system for security. Â When the correct numbers are punched into a keypad by the outer door, my phone rings. Â After finding out who is at the door, a button on my phone opens the door. Â It didn't take Lily long to equate the ringing of my phone with the knock on my apartment door. Â So whenever my phone rang, she positioned herself at my door, ready to challenge anyone who wished to enter. Â She never did anything about it, just barked like mad. Â My landlord called her my early warning system.Unlike most dogs and their owners, Lily and I did not go for walks. Â When we went outside, I walked. Â She would not. Â She was perfectly content to sit at the end of her leash and watch the world go by. Â But walking on the end of that leash was something Lily absolutely would not do. Â So Lily went for a carry!I was so proud. Â Here was this little 9 pound bundle of fluff, defending her master. Â Right up to the point I realized that protecting me had nothing to do with her behavior. Â But God help anyone who had designs on her food dish.She was sweet and cuddly and obnoxious, all in the same package. Â She was smart and funny. Â She took to spending nearly all of her time in her kennel, only coming out to relieve herself and eat a little bit, and then refusing all food except the bits of chicken I finally started fixing for her to tempt her appetite. Â Her toys stayed in their basket. Â The small tennis balls she loved to chase stayed with the toys. Â My phone rang, ignored by Lily. Â A neighbor knocked on my door without rousing her interest. Â She wasn't really sick, but not well either. Â I think she was just old and ready to be done.I do not take this decision lightly. Â I don't call a vet for this last service if there is hope for good quality of life. Â But Lily was 15 years old. Â She lived a happy life, at least in the 7 years she lived with me. Â And my life was happier, living with her.Rest in peace, Miss Lily.

title: Then...Now
text: Seven years ago I was introduced to this young man.And here he is now.Happy Birthday, Jacob.Love, Grandma

title: Count Your Blessings
text: I am still housebound. Â I have some issues with my legs that are keeping me in. Â But it is slowly but surely getting better. Â Nobody needs to feel sorry for me, though. Â I can do a pretty good job of that when left to my own devices!I was grumping about this morning, working myself up into a "poor pitiful me" state, when this little Sunday School tune popped into my brain:"Count your blessings.Name them one by one.Count your many blessings,See what God has done."So I did. Â Came up with a list as long as your arm. Â Here are a couple of highlights.I am blessed with grown children I can count on. Â Even though Oldest Son now lives halfway across the country, I know he would be here if I needed him. Â My daughters are only a phone call away for me, and will do whatever I ask of them, willingly. Â Youngest Son is always available when I need him.I am blessed with grown children who have good senses of humor. Â Whether it is something they post on Facebook that makes me laugh or something they tell me when I talk with them, they can always bring a smile to my face. Â That is important.Even though I am sometimes grumpy about it, I really don't mind so much being housebound. Â Were I able to leave right now, you would probably find me right here doing what I am doing. Â Being alone doesn't bother me. Â Some have to be around people much of the time, but I'm not one of those people.I have lots of interests. Â I bake and preserve food and sew and quilt and crochet and do genealogy research and read and scrapbook and blog and... Â  Â  I never lack for something to do and I am never bored.I have a deep and abiding faith that sustains me. Â Even when things look dark, I know that when I pray, God hears me. Â I know He answers prayer. Â Took me a lot of years to figure out, though, that sometimes the answer is "No."When I finished my list, the grumpy had given way to content. Â My legs still hurt. Â There are still things I need to do every day to get back my health. Â But the good things in my life so far outweigh the bad that grumpy just can't exist for very long.Well, that and when a son pops in bearing gifts of chocolate, fresh strawberries and a six pack of Coca-Cola in real glass bottles. Â That helps, too!

title: Keeping My Town Safe
text: Even though it is winter, every now and then when the temperature gets up in the double digits, I'll crack open a window or two. Â The apartment gets stuffy after a while and a breath of fresh air is welcome.So I opened one of my living room windows late this afternoon. Â The sun was nearing time to set so it was still light enough to see outside. Â And as I crank the window open I hear a commotion in the street below.I look down and there is a middle aged man named Billy whose claim to fame is that he can be found nearly any evening at one of the bars in my neighborhood and by suppertime he is usually happily sailing along on an alcohol induced trip. Â He generally is harmless, but once in a while he gets feisty. Â That would be OK except for the fact that Billy stands about 5' 4" on a good day. Â And he usually picks fights with someone twice his size.This evening Billy got lucky. Â The fellow he chose to fight with stands maybe 6' 4" and is still reasonably sober and really doesn't want to pound Billy into the ground. Â You've seen those cartoon fights where the little guy is swinging his fists for all he is worth and his huge opponent is holding him off with an outstretched arm and his hand firmly resting on the little guy's forehead. Â That was the scene below my window.About that time a cop car pulls up. Â Two officers get out and survey the scene. Â One of them says, "Now, Billy, I thought you promised me you wouldn't fight any more."Billy answers, "Well, you know you can't believe anything I say when I'm drunk."The officer answers that it was his mistake. Â He forgot about that part.And that's when I laughed out loud.The evening was one of those that was quiet and sound carries easily. Â The cop heard me and looked up at my window. "That you, Mrs. Miller?"I said that it was."You doing OK? Â Haven't seen you out and about for a while."I told him that I was doing just fine and remarked that he seemed to have his hands full. Â By that time Billy had a new set of bracelets and was having a bit of a problem remaining upright."Well," Â he said, "Billy and I are going to go check out a nice jail cell where he can get some sleep. Â Shakopee will be safe for another night."Sometimes this place reminds me more of Mayberry than of a Minneapolis suburb. Â I know it's not, but now and then it is good for a chuckle.

title: Ice, Ice and More Ice
text: The temperature in my area warmed up a little bit. Â And some snow fell earlier today. Â And the snow turned to ice as it came into contact with the highways.I've had the scanner on this afternoon, listening to the police calls for my town and the surrounding area. Â I have heard the highways described as skating rinks. Â Several sections of freeway have had to be shut down due to crashes. Â During the first fifteen minutes of listening to the scanner there were reports of 6 crashes - either rear end collisions or vehicles sliding into the ditches. Two big trucks slid off the road into the ditch. Â Another collided with a car.As the afternoon progresses, it has gotten to the point where they can't keep up with all of the accidents, and are reporting them two and three at a time. Â There aren't enough tow trucks.I called both my daughters who were at their jobs, just to tell them about the roads, in case they didn't know.OK. Â I'm done with winter now. Â Spring can come most any time.

title: Police Brutality - Minnesota Style
text: This morning I'm taking it easy - sitting and doing a little bit of hand sewing on a quilt. Â I've got the Internet scanner on. Â I don't bother with listening to police calls for my little suburb as usually on a weekday the most exciting thing going on are the writing of speeding tickets. Â The scanner is set for Minneapolis, which is usually pretty action packed.When there is bad weather, particularly cold and wind, a dispatcher will periodically relay that information to those officers out in their squad cars. Â About an hour ago the temperature was -9 with a wind chill of -30.About 20 minutes ago one of the dispatchers called Â a squad car that was close to the police station downtown. Â She said that there was a homeless man wrapped up in a sleeping bag huddled in the doorway of the building across the street. Â She said that it was probably the same man that usually slept in that spot, but he hadn't moved all morning and she was worried about his condition. Â Would the officers please check on him.About 10 minutes later the officers called the dispatcher back to report that the homeless man was OK. Â They had tried to get him inside out of the cold, but he had refused help. Â Apparently they had tried to help him on other occasions and the man wouldn't let them. Â The dispatcher said she would watch to make sure he was OK until the end of her shift.Now I don't know what the police are like in New York or Los Angeles or Ferguson, Missouri. Â I just know what they are like here. Â Here they check on homeless people and try to get them out of the freezing weather. Â Sometimes they can help. Â Sometimes the homeless don't want to be helped, but just want to be left alone. Â But the police try.So Al Sharpton and Jesse Jackson and all of those people who feel the need to protest police brutality, you might want to look elsewhere for a place to do your race baiting and your police badmouthing. Â The kind of thing that happened today is not an isolated incident in my neck of the woods. Â It is the norm.All we ever hear about is the bad. Â Maybe some of the good that most of these officers do should be publicized as much as the bad that the few do. Â Seems only fair.

title: Time for Comfort Food
text: Woke up this morning to a temperature of -1 and a wind chill index of -19. Â The temperature is still falling and the wind is still blowing.It seems that when the temperatures drop, the craving for comfort food increases. Â In my house that means biscuits and sausage gravy for breakfast and a big pot of homemade chicken vegetable soup for supper. Â With cornbread and lots of butter.I live in an apartment. Â I don't have outside chores to contend with. Â At this stage of my life, I consider that a blessing. Â The local weather forecasters are making noises about wind chill temperatures of -35 degrees. Â  Funny, when I was young there were farm animals to be fed and snow to shovel and all sorts of things that needed my attention no matter how cold or snowy it was. Â That didn't bother me much. Â Just added another layer of clothes and went out and did what needed doing.But these days now that I have a considerable amount of age on me, I am content to stay indoors until it warms up. Â No problem. Â I have a rocking chair. Â I have a heavy, warm crocheted afghan. Â I have my books. Â All I need is a fresh pot of coffee and I'm good. Â Let the younger ones go romp in the cold and snow. Â Me...now where did I put that murder mystery I've been wanting to read.

title: It's Winter...
text: It's Minnesota. Â It's 6 degrees below zero this morning. Â Am I surprised? Â Nope. Â Am I grateful that I don't need to get out in the cold? Â You betcha!After Christmas is when I settle in for a few months of sewing, quilting, crocheting or scrapbooking. Â I don't go out to celebrate the New Year. Â It seems as though folks around here feel obligated to over indulge in adult beverages on that occasion. Â I don't drink any more. Â So I find that I'm happier just being home. Â The cat will celebrate with some tuna - the dog with a taste of whatever I fix myself for supper that night - and we are all happy.Some of my kids know that I want to make two or three new quilts this winter. Â So a couple of gift cards for Joann Fabrics appeared in my Christmas stocking. Â Or taped to my box of chocolate covered cherries! Â I dislike shopping. Â I have never understood women who consider shopping as entertainment. Â I'm more of a get in, find what is on my list and get out kind of shopper. Â Except when it comes to fabric stores. Â Then you might as well go find a place to sit and be comfortable, because it will take me some time. Â Along with the cards was the promise of transportation to and from Joann's. Â This is gonna be fun!And my kids know that I am working on restocking my supply of home canned meat, so a gift card for my local grocery was also taped to the candy box. Â That will go a long way toward filling my shelves. Â I know there are some who think that gift cards are impersonal. Â Not me. Â When a couple of my kids asked me what I wanted for Christmas, I replied that I wanted their time. Â I explained that I have a small apartment. Â I don't have room for extra "stuff." Â What I really would like was if they could take the time to ferry me to the fabric store or to the grocery to buy the things I wanted to get at those two stores. Â At present a bus ride to shop is out of the question as my legs are giving me problems. Â But I can manage a short car ride. Â So I wanted their time. Â The gift cards were a bonus, bless their hearts.Youngest daughter asked me the same question, and for her, the answer was different. Â I wanted framed graduation photos of both of her children. Â And they delivered!Chris' graduation was a couple of years ago and Nicki graduates this spring. Â I love grandkid pictures. Â And I find it hard to believe that they are both grown up. Â Both were just babies when I moved back to Minnesota and now both are taller than I am. Â I am so proud of the people they have become.So I'm off to go through my quilt books and the patterns I have stored on my computer and to make a list of fabrics I need for the patterns I choose. Â And decide on any other crafty supplies I need for other projects.Because once my little shopping trips are done, I don't plan to stick my nose out the door until spring!

title: Time for Elves to Go Home
text: The elves are nearly ready to go back to the North Pole until next year. Â I hear from reliable sources that my Grands have been pretty good so there will be no coal in their Christmas stockings.Personally, I think the elves are headed home because they have run out of places to hide!Chippy and Daisy found the Blessings Jar.I wonder just what is in Santa's Ho Ho Ho drink that kept Chippy and Daisy warm while hiding out in the fridge?!I know it is silly, but I look forward to their appearance every Christmas Season. Their antics make me smile.

title: The Elf
text: This morning I read a report from Drudge that stated the "Elf on the Shelf" conditions children to believe that spying is OK. Â Really? Â How incredibly paranoid we have become.I don't recall anyone ever accusing Santa Claus of spying all those years ago when parents told their children that Santa knew if they were naughty or nice. Â Even had a Christmas song that proved it with the words, "He knows if you've been bad or good, so be good for goodness sake."Me...I made up all sorts of silly facts to get my children to behave when they were young. Â I told them that raw cookie dough causes worms. Â I told them that if they didn't straighten out, I was going to line them up along the highway with "Give Away" signs around their necks. Â And I told them if they weren't good, Santa was going to leave a lump of coal in their Christmas stockings.They didn't believe a word of it.The same way that kids don't equate the Elf with spying.Only adults do that. Â The kind of adults who want to suck the fun and joy out of everything.And with that in mind, here is what the Elves who live with my grandchildren were up to last week.They were watching from the ledge above the kitchen cupboards.They got themselves stuck in the VCR. Â (David said he was surprised that they still owned a VCR!)And they made snow angels.Sometimes an elf is just an elf. Â And kids having fun are just kids having fun with no sinister hidden meanings.Some adults really need to find a life. Â Preferably one with a little bit of fun in it.

title: Made My Day
text: So the middle of this afternoon my phone rings. Â Youngest Son wants to know if I would like some company. Â Of course I would. He has one stop to make and then he will go to the Dairy Queen. Â He wants to know what flavor Blizzard I would like. Â I tell him. Â He says he will see me in about 15 minutes.We sit at my kitchen table and eat ice cream and talk. Â He tells me what his family has been doing. Â We talk of other things. Â It is good to be able to sit and talk with my son.I would have let him in, even if he didn't bring ice cream. Â :)

title: A Quiet Week
text: It's been a quiet week here in the frozen north. Â I've been puttering. Â That's what my Dad called it when he was just fiddling about with this and that. Â His puttering was along the lines of fixing a hole in the porch screen or weeding a bit in his garden.My puttering has been along the lines of organizing photos on my computer. Â Or going through my quilt patterns and deciding which quilts I will sew over the winter. Â Or adding photos of my ancestors to my genealogy program.It appears Chippy the Elf and his new girlfriend Daisy have been busier than I have.On Monday Chippy and Daisy were sitting in a tree.On Tuesday they went on a double date with Ken and Barbie.Wednesday found them involved in a serious game of Uno with their friends.And on Thursday they were looking cozy inside a lantern.This morning they were hanging out in the bathroom. Â Maddie Mae said they were probably watching to make sure she didn't spend too much time doing her hair!Guess I'm going to have to get busy if I'm going to have a social life that equals those two elves.

title: Chippy - Elf on the Shelf - 2014 Edition
text: Yes, Chippy the Elf is back at my grandchildren's home. Â I have as much fun as the kids, checking my son's Facebook posts to see where Chippy turns up each day. Â This year there is an addition. Â It seems that Chippy has acquired a girlfriend. Â Go, Chippy!It will be fun to see where they hide this year!I know. Â I'm as bad as the kids.

title: Oh Christmas Tree
text: Every year, the weekend after Thanksgiving, my son and his family go to a tree farm to cut down their Christmas tree. Â And they always post a picture of their adventure.They make my heart glad.

title: Canning Marathon
text: Wednesday morning, the guy who grocery shops for me called. Â Wanted to know if I really wanted a dozen bunches of celery. Â I did. Â And how big a turkey did I need. Â I replied I wanted the biggest one he could find. Â He laughed and said OK. Â See you soon.Celery has been on sale at that grocery store at other times for 98 cents a bunch. Â And those times the bunches have been skinny - about half the size of a normal bunch of celery. Â Not this time. Â They were huge. Â I already have all the dehydrated celery I want, so I went ahead and canned up this batch, even though there was more than I bargained for. Â Wound up with 8 pints and 56 half pints of chopped celery. The turkey I got weighed in at a little over 23 pounds. Â A 23 pound turkey yields 12 pints of meat and 11 quarts of turkey broth. Â I need to get at least another four turkeys that size - maybe six. Â I use the canned turkey more than any other canned meat, and I was completely out of it.I've still got 10 lbs of frozen peas and 10 lbs. of frozen green beans to can. Â But I think that will wait until tomorrow. Â I'm slowly and reluctantly learning what my limitations are and after the last of the turkey comes out of the pressure canner, I do believe a short nap might be just the thing. Â Although if this winter continues as it has been so far (yesterday morning the temperature was at six degrees below zero), naps may give way to hibernation. Â I think the bears are smarter than we are. Â They sleep the whole winter long.

title: Consequences
text: I have never liked swearing. Â I'm not a prude. Â I just don't like it. Â Probably comes from my Baptist upbringing and the fact that my Mother was extremely religious. Â I'm sure that my children use four letter words from time to time. Â But they have enough respect not to use them within earshot of their Mother.Anyway, Youngest Son was telling me about his daughters. Â One of them wasn't pleased with something her sister did. Â And she let her know about it by dropping an F-bomb to express her displeasure. Â What she didn't take into consideration was the fact that her Daddy was within hearing distance. Â And he heard.The girl has spent a considerable amount of time with a pencil and paper, writing "I will not swear at my sister." Â 500 times. Â And when she has finished all 500 sentences, she can have her cell phone back.Does my heart good to know that in some families, actions still have consequences.

title: A Monday Ramble
text: Today is grocery ordering day. Â Yesterday I went through the weekly store ad that came in the mail and made out my list. Celery is on sale for 99 cents a bunch. Â I ordered a dozen. Â I have quite a bit of celery dehydrated. Â It takes a long time to rehydrate so I use it in soups that simmer all day. Â The plan is to cut the celery into about half inch pieces and can them in half pint jars. Â I had done that a couple of years ago and liked the convenience of adding canned celery to casseroles, stew, etc.The store brand frozen vegetables are on sale in the two pound bags. Â I ordered 10 lbs. of peas and 10 lbs. of cut green beans. Â I'll can those in pint jars and that will bring those two vegetables back up to the amounts I like to have on hand on my pantry shelves.Now and then mistakes are made. Â Two weeks ago I ordered both dry dog food and cat food. Â They brought me a fairly large bag of dog food but no cat food. Â Good thing I order before I am down to two weeks worth of food for the animals, so Kizzie the cat did not run out of food. Â Kizzie running out of food is not a good thing. Â She whines and fusses when her bowl is down to half full. Â An empty dish would make life unbearable for both her and me! Â Lily, however, now has enough dry food to probably last the rest of her natural life! Â Guess that is a good thing.I don't often indulge myself, but a buy 1 - get 1 free sale on ice cream was just too good to pass up. Â I ordered two old fashioned vanilla and will make a batch of chocolate sauce and a batch of butterscotch topping. Â Ice cream is one of my favorite things, even in the middle of winter.There were rumors of snow in our forecast, but it looks like it bypassed us again. Â Not that I'm complaining, mind you. Â I look at the reports of those folks in New York, opening their doors only to find a wall of snow outside, and I find I have much to be thankful for. I have given up looking for exciting things to blog about. Â Exciting just doesn't happen in my world. Â I got rid of the drama in my life years ago. Â But I can continue to write about the everyday happenings here in my little corner of the world. Â And as this is more or less a record of what is going on in my life, as well as a place to remember the "good old days," that's OK.

title: Heat Wave
text: Woke up this morning to a temperature of 49 degrees. Â Moisture is on the way but it is in the form of rain. Â You don't have to shovel rain. Â Or scrape it off your car windshield.Life is good.

title: Grow Up
text: I'm tired. Â I'm tired of hearing politicians pass out the blame but take no responsibility themselves. Â I'm tired of listening to the Democrats bad mouth Republicans and Republicans responding in kind. Â I'm tired of bickering. Â I'm tired of the constant struggle to get one up on the opposing party. Â I'm tired of the name calling. Â I'm tired of the lies. If my children, when they were young, had acted like our congress and leaders act, I'd have blistered their bottoms and sent them to bed without supper.For God's sake. Â Grow up. Â Take a look at what is really wrong with this country.And then fix it.That's what we pay you for.

title: Dehydrated Potato Slices
text: So I had this 10 lb. sack of potatoes from my last grocery order. Â Should I eat them or preserve them to add to my food storage. Â I guess you know you are one of those crazy preppers when the decision is to preserve for later use.Peeled 10 lbs. of potatoes. Â Sliced them on my mandolin slicer. Â Blanched the slices for 3 minutes. Â Arranged the potatoes on my dehydrator trays, set the temperature for 135 degrees. Â Wound up with about a gallon of dried potato slices.My favorite way to use these potatoes is for scalloped potatoes. Â Ahead of time I make up packets of sauce mix:Basic Scalloped Potato Sauce Mix1/3 C. + 2 Tbsp. powdered milk2 Tbsp. flour2 Tbsp. cornstarch1 Tbsp. dried onion1/8 tsp. pepperEach recipe goes into a small zip bag and lots of them are stored in a gallon freezer bag next to the bags of potato slices.To make scalloped potatoes, dump 3 cups of dried potato slices into a crock pot. Â Add one packet of sauce mix, 3 cups hot water and 3 Tbsp. butter. Â Stir it a bit, set the crock pot on High and let it cook all afternoon, Â stirring once in a while to make sure all of the potato slices are covered with the sauce to rehydrate evenly. Â I might add a little bit more onion or some parsley flakes or maybe a little garlic or anything else that sounds good to me at the time.About a half hour before serving I sometimes add a pint of my canned ham cubes or bacon bits. Â I've also tossed in a cup of shredded cheddar cheese and let it melt, stirring it in.The original recipe called for baking the scalloped potato dish in the oven. Â I found that sometimes the potato slices wouldn't rehydrate fully. Â So after experimenting using the crock pot, I decided I like that method of cooking scalloped potatoes much better than the oven method. Â The potatoes are tender and you would never know that they were dehydrated and not fresh.And now that I've made myself hungry writing this, I'm going to go get a batch of scalloped potatoes going for supper.

title: Once When We Were Free
text: â€œOnce When We Were Freeâ€By Jon Rappoport"Weâ€™re so much more sensible now. We donâ€™t live our lives as much as we arrange them and organize them. B follows A. D follows C. We take our medicine and our shots because the doctor says so. Weâ€™re careful, because accidents happen. We donâ€™t say whatâ€™s on our minds a lot of the time, because other people might pass that on, and who knows? We might get into trouble.But once upon a time, when we were young, we were free. We didnâ€™t take any shots and when we got sick we recovered. We were stronger than kids are now. We didnâ€™t ask for much protection and we werenâ€™t given much, and we survived.There was no talk about the needs of the group. When we went to school, we werenâ€™t told about ways we could help others. That was something we learned at home. We werenâ€™t taught about The Planet. Instead, we learned to mind our own business, and it wasnâ€™t considered a crime.When we played games, adults werenâ€™t hovering or coaching every move we made. We found places to play on our own, and we figured it all out. There were winners and losers. There were no plastic trophies. We played one game, then another. We lost, we won. We competed. Losing wasnâ€™t a tragedy.There were no childhood â€œconditionsâ€ like ADHD or Bipolar, and we certainly didnâ€™t take any brain drugs. The idea of a kid going to a psychiatrist would have been absurd.People were who they were. They had lives. They had personalities. They had eccentricities, and we lived with that.There was far less whispering and gossip. There were fewer cliques. Kids didnâ€™t display their possessions like signs of their identity. A kid who did was ignored, even shunned.Kids never acted like little adults. They didnâ€™t dress like adults. They didnâ€™t want to be fake adults.Our parents didnâ€™t consult us about what we wanted. We werenâ€™t part of the decision-making process. They didnâ€™t need us for that.We werenâ€™t â€œextra-special.â€ We werenâ€™t delicate.No one asked us about our feelings. If they had, we would have been confused. Feelings? Whatâ€™s that? We were alive. We knew it. We didnâ€™t need anything else.We could spot liars a mile away. We could spot phonies from across town. We knew who the really crazy adults were, and we stayed away from them.We didnâ€™t need gadgets and machines to be happy. We only needed a place to play. If you wanted a spot to be alone, you found one, and you read a book.There was no compulsion to â€œshare.â€School wasnâ€™t some kind of social laboratory or baby-sitting service. We were there to learn, and if we worked hard, we did. Teachers knew how to teach. The textbooks were adequate. Whether the books were new or old didnâ€™t matter.Kids werenâ€™t taught how to be little victims.Sex was a private issue. You were taught about that at home or not at all. You certainly didnâ€™t learn about it in school. That would have been ridiculous.Some of us remember being young, and now, we still have that North Star. We still donâ€™t take our shots and medicines. We still donâ€™t take every word a doctor says as coming from God.
