title: What Are Those
text: So I was going through the check-out at the grocery the other day. Â My purchases included boxes of canning lids...about a dozen of each size. Â The sweet young thing behind the counter asked me what they were. Â I told her they were canning lids. Â She said, "Oh, cool. Â I didn't know there were lids for closing an open soup can."Sigh.I have to wonder how many folks have no earthly idea about home canning. Or how to sew on a button. Or how to patch a pair of jeans. Or how to darn a sock. Or how to dehydrate food. Or how to wash clothes without a washer and dryer. Or own clothespins. Or how to wash dishes by hand. Or how to plant a garden. Or how to forage for wild berries. Or how to knit a pair of mittens. Or how to crochet a warm scarf or hat. Or how to cook from scratch.Or how to bake a loaf of bread.Or how to write a letter using paper and a pen. Or how to do much of anything that doesn't involve electronics.They had better learn.

title: The Dogs Know...
text: how to take care of one another.Little bitty Lily the Yorkie has been having eye problems lately. Â She either has a sort of cold that settled in her eyes or it is allergies. Â At any rate, her eyelids become matted with gook. Â If it gets to the point where her sight is hindered, she will come to me and pester me until I take her to the kitchen, set her on the table, wash the gook from her eyes and administer the drops from the vet. Â Then she goes bouncing away, a happy pooch again.She will also pester me if she decides whatever I am doing isn't nearly as important as pets, ear scratches and belly rubs. Â Yesterday I noticed when she wanted attention, the fur around her eyes was wet and there was no eye gook. Â Same thing this morning. Â So I started watching both the dogs closely.It appears that Jessie Jane has taken it upon herself to keep Lily's eyes clear. Â She spends a lot of time cleaning them. Â Lily just sits there and lets her. Â Almost like mama cleaning her pup.I have two kennels. Â A smaller one and a larger one. Â I don't lock the dogs in unless there are people here. Â They are free to come and go and they sleep in them. Â Both of them love the smaller kennel and there is always a race to see who gets to it first. Â Jessie Jane usually wins. Â But the past couple of days, Jessie Jane sits and waits to see which kennel Lily wants, and lets her have the small one with no fuss at all. Â  Under normal circumstances the one who loses the kennel race will come to me and tattle, but not lately. Â Lily's eyes are much improved and I expect the problem to be cleared up soon, at which time I have no doubt that the great kennel race will be on again.Whoever says that dogs can't figure things out for themselves has had either really dumb dogs or never had one at all.

title: My Son...
text: left his home in Minnesota this morning. Â He checked in via Facebook from the other side of Omaha this afternoon. Â I pray that he has a safe trip and finds what he is looking for at his destination in Phoenix.Even though I want happiness and contentment and all good things for him, my heart hurts a little.I hear that excuse for not preparing often. Â Usually from folks who have large homes. Â I'm here to tell you that you do have room and here's why.I live in a 1-bedroom apartment that measures a little over 500 square feet - about half the size of your average 3-bedroom rambler. There have to be a lot of people like me living in similar conditions. Â Now if you are one of those people who has to have the perfectly decorated living space then read no further. Â This is not for you. Â But if you are more interested in staying alive when things get really bad - and I have no doubt they will - then read on.My living room couch is pulled out about 8 or 9 inches from the wall. Â Behind it are 2-liter soda bottles full of water. Â I will be laying a board or heavy cardboard across the tops of those bottles in order to stack another row on top. Â You can't tell that there is anything behind the couch. Â Water bottles also live in a corner behind my TV stand. Â More reside on a closet shelf. Â Water is important. Â You can live a while without food, but lack of water will kill you fairly quickly. Â When you have no room for the large water barrels, find another solution. Â This is mine.My bedroom holds two heavy duty shelving units, each four feet long and seven feet high. Â These hold all of my home canned food. Â There is another smaller shelving unit that fits behind my bedroom door that holds all of my dehydrated food plus extra canning jar rings. Â My bedroom stays fairly dark and cool. Â This is important for the food stored there. Â Light and heat are the enemy of home canned foods. Â Light and moisture are not friends to dehydrated food. Â My bedroom will never make the pages of House Beautiful. Â I don't care. Â I will be able to eat tomorrow.I have two closets in my bedroom. Â One is small but deep and that holds clothes and odds and ends in plastic tubs. Â I got rid of the junk. Â I don't need stuff. Â I need space. Â The other closet is a standard double door sized closet. Â The top shelf holds more water bottles. Â Because this is a rental unit, filling it with built-in shelves was not an option, so I bought several small, free standing, stackable shelves and set them against the back closet wall. Â There is space on one side of the shelves for buckets of sugar and flour. Â The shelves hold things like baking powder, peanut butter, powdered milk, etc. Â Even though it is not really handy, there is room in front of the shelves to stack boxes containing rice, beans, pasta, etc., so I bought cardboard banker's boxes and they work well. Â Yes, I have to move them to get to the shelves. Â I can live with that.The one storage area that I can not use at present is under my bed. Â My spring and mattress sit on a wooden box frame so I can't access that space under the bed without lifting up the spring and mattress. Â Next year I will be ready to replace the bed. Â At that time I plan to use the space underneath for storing toilet paper, pet food, kitty litter, etc. Â Cases of store bought canned goods will also slide easily into that space.If a person does home canning, there are always empty canning jars to deal with. Â I use my canned food almost daily and that rotates out the older food which is replaced with newer. Â But what to do with the jars. Â My cupboard space is extremely limited. Â What is here holds dishes, pots and pans and the items I regularly use for baking and cooking Â I bought three free standing units that are about six feet tall and 18 inches wide. Â Each has two small cupboards with doors and three shelves. Â These units hold everything from my cookbooks, spices, packages of jello, etc. Â I make a lot of my own seasoning like taco and chili seasoning mixes, and those are in jars on the shelves along with other mixes like for scalloped potatoes or gravy. Â Canisters for brown sugar, powdered sugar, coffee and flour are in those cupboards, handy when I need them. Â When I run out of something, I just go to my closet pantry and grab whatever I need to replace it. Â No running to the store.Back to the canning jars. Â The only solution I have found is to neatly stack the jars in their original boxes. Â I have space beside the free standing shelves in the kitchen and the jars are stacked there. Â It may not be aesthetically pleasing, but they are neatly stacked according to size and they are clean. Â I need the jars for my survival more than I need a picture perfect kitchen.There are lots of ideas for small space storage on the internet. Â This is just some of what works for me in my situation. Â I like to have things pretty, but I am way less concerned about house beautiful than I am about staying alive when disaster strikes. Â There are those who think the stores will always be there, full of food. Â We all saw a while back what happened when there was a glitch in the welfare system and EBT cards didn't work for a few hours. Â How long do you suppose it would take, should those cards be cancelled altogether, for the riots to start and grocery shelves to be cleared. Â If we don't remember the Katrina debacle, we should. Â The pictures of people looking in dumpsters for food after Hurricane Sandy are still fresh in my mind. Â So are the interviews of irate citizens complaining that the government wasn't there to take care of them.I'll be damned if I will be one of those people. Â As long as I am able to care for myself, I will. Â I will endure the glazed look that appears on faces when I mention food storage. Â I will put up with those who ridicule my efforts, believing that nothing will ever change. Â But in the end, I will survive. Â And attain my goal. Â Which is to live long enough to be a problem to my children.I think I am close to achieving that goal!

title: Don't Forget the Pets
text: I've pretty much figured out how much food I need to store for myself for one year. Â And I go over that amount a bit to take into consideration the jars of peaches, pears and other goodies that walk out of here with my kids.But I hadn't figured out how much pet food I needed for the same amount of time. Â I hate to say it, but I only plan to store six months worth of dog food at a time because my Yorkies are getting up there in age. Â At 13 - 14 years each (I never knew their exact birth dates), they already have had long lives. Â Both are healthy, but Jessie Jane has slowed down considerably and Lily is prone to catching colds or coming down with other doggie related health problems. Â They may fool me, though. Â My last Cocker Spaniel lived to the ripe old age of 16.Anyway, the last time I bought dog and cat food, I got small bags of each. Â I kept track of how long each bag lasted to give me an idea of how much to buy before winter sets in. Â I wound up shivering at the bus stop more than once last winter just because I was low on their food. Â Not gonna happen this winter.What I discovered was that, pound for pound of food, Kizzie the cat consumes as much as both dogs put together.I wonder if they make exercise machines for cats.

title: An Interesting Start To My Day
text: Now and then sleep eludes me. Â Last night was one of those. Â I went to bed around 11:30 and finally gave up on sleeping over an hour later. Â I got up and came into my living room where my computer is located, sat down and decided to write for a while. Â I had a couple of ideas for blog posts, so I worked on them. Somewhere around 2 AM I shut the computer off and settled down in my recliner. Â Sometimes I sleep better there than in bed. Â I was just starting to doze when I heard a sound that resembled a thud. Â I remember thinking that some damn fool drunk had run his car into the corner of the building beneath my open window. Â My nine pound early warning system, Lily the Yorkie, was peacefully snoozing in her kennel. Â I knew there was nothing in the hallway to worry about or she would have been loudly protecting her food dish. Â She can go from a sound asleep to standing stiff-legged barking like mad in about three seconds if anyone lingers outside my apartment door. Â I listened for a minute or two for any other sounds, heard nothing, and then fell asleep.About 6 AM Lily wakes me. Â She is loudly guarding her food. Â Between barks I catch the sound of a sharp rapping on my door. Â I ask who is there and a voice identifies himself as a police officer. Â A look through the peephole confirms this. Â His face is familiar to me so I ask him in. Â He says they noticed my open window and wondered if I had heard any noises during the night. Â I describe what I heard. Â He wants to know if I heard anything that sounded like breaking glass and I reply that I did not. Â He is particularly interested in the time of night I heard the sound. Â He then explains to me that during the night someone broke into the bicycle shop beneath my apartment and stole a particularly expensive bike from the show window. Â He apologizes for waking me at such an early hour, Â asks me to call if I remember anything else, apologizes again and leaves.This is the second time this summer that something has occurred here that involved the police. Â Earlier my neighbor's grandson had broken into the bar behind my building, had cut himself up in the process and had then raised all sorts of hell trying to get his drugged up self to his grandmother's apartment to hide. Â And now this. Â Even with a bar next door and another behind the building, it is a fairly quiet neighborhood. Â There is the usual Saturday night whooping and hollering from the younger set who, after a few beers, don't seem to have the sense that God gave a goose. Â There is an occasional fight but even those are few and far between.My slightly paranoid, tin foil hat wearing self has to wonder if this might not be a sign of things to come.

title: So True
text: I saw this a while back and stole it. Â I forget who I stole it from. Â With a bitter winter predicted for us here in Minnesota, I thought perhaps those of us living in the tundra might want to rethink our plans.Well, nobody but my friend Rob who moved with his family back home from Florida.And me, who came home from southern Missouri.I said goodbye to my oldest son this morning. Â We had breakfast at the little family restaurant where he worked years ago and where he and I have shared breakfast many times. Â He is on his way to pick up the trailer and will load it up with the help of friends, and will be on his way to Arizona in another day or so. Â I'm sad because he is leaving, but at the same time glad that he won't have to suffer through another Minnesota winter.He tried to give me back his keys to my apartment. Â I wouldn't let him. Â I want all of my kids to know that no matter what, they can always come home.

title: Monday Smile
text: "And it was my idea to plant sunflowers, Dad."Dad said he would probably need a bobcat to pull out the roots.

title: More Surprises
text: I had just taken a pan of biscuits out of the oven when there was a knock at my door. Â It was my next-door neighbor. Â She wanted to borrow a light bulb.I asked her in while I went to my stash of bulbs to find the size she needed. Â When I returned to the kitchen, I asked her if she had eaten supper yet. Â She said she hadn't, so I dished up a plate of stew and biscuits for her. Â After we ate, she said she had to get home as she was waiting for a visitor to show up. Â When I opened the door for her, she said that I should look out in the hall near the door - that she almost forgot what she had set down there. Â This lady had a stroke a while back, and as a result she sometimes forgets things, and has to do things like set down a parcel in order to be able to knock on a door.When I stuck my head out to look, I spotted a pile of fabric. Â She said that she knows I sew and thought I could use it. Â She said she can't sew any more and she wanted me to have it. Â I tried to pay her, but she wouldn't hear of it.After she went back home I took a closer look at the fabric. Â There are at least 6 yards of a lighter blue denim and another 8 yards of navy denim. Â Wow! Â What a wonderful addition to my fabric stash. Â I'm not sure just how I will use it all yet, but no doubt it will be put to good use.Bless her heart. Â You just don't find neighbors like Alberta every day.

title: Some Things Are Just Wrong
text: The parents of Bowe Bergdahl were given a huggy love fest in the rose garden.The parents of James Foley were given five minutes of insincere platitudes followed by a rush to get to the golf course.And we wonder why this handbasket we are in is headed straight for Hell.

title: The Ugly Quilt
text: While digging about in my closet I found, back in a corner, a box full of fabric fat quarters. Â For the non-sewing folks, a fat quarter is a 1/4 yard piece of fabric that measures about 18 " x 21 ", Â and is usually sold for crafty projects or for quilt projects where a small amount of one color fabric is needed.At any rate, here was this box of fat quarters. Â I suppose that I had a reason for collecting so many of them over the years, but whatever that reason was, it now escapes me. Â Lots of things escape me these days.Being a frugal person (read "cheap") I can't just throw them out. Â I have been sewing since age 12, and as someone who sews, throwing out good fabric, even if it is just scraps, is just wrong. Â After digging a bit further into the depths of the closet, I came up with a bag of quilt batting. Â And there was my "Aha" moment. Â Rag Quilt.To make a rag quilt, fabric is cut into squares. Â Squares of quilt batting are sandwiched between two layers of fabric. Â An X is sewn, corners to corners, securing the batting within the fabric squares. Â The sandwich squares are sewn together with the seams to the outside of the quilt top. Â When completed, the seams are clipped with a scissor at about 1/4 inch intervals, creating a sort of fringe. Â When the finished quilt is washed and then dried in a dryer, the seams fluff up and look sort of raggedy. Â Thus the name Rag Quilt.Took me two days to cut the pieces, sew the X on each square and sew the squares together. Â Clipping the seams took another evening. Â I wasn't going for pretty. Â The placement of the fabric squares was completely random. Â I was going for quick and easy, for using up otherwise useless fabric, and especially going for warm. Â Nothing like a hand made quilt to snuggle up with when the snow falls and the wind howls. Yes, I know. Â It would be much more fun to have a honey to snuggle with, but that's not likely to happen here, so I will settle for a quilt. Â Even an ugly one.I haven't run it through the washer and dryer as yet, but you get the idea.A few years ago I made six of these - one for each grandkid - for Christmas. Â Those were both pretty and warm. Â I'm thinking that maybe I should make a couple more of them from flannel. Â But until then, I sort of like my Ugly Quilt. Â It is kind of like falling in love with the runt of the litter. Â The little ugly ones need to be loved, too.

title: Feminist Demands
text: I was scanning the headlines on one of the alternative news sources I read when I came across this one:Feminist Demands Free Tampons for AllThe article with a link to the original column can be found Here.And all I could think of was that we have finally reached the ultimate in expectations of government taking care of us from cradle to grave. Â The argument was that women need these products for several days each month over the course of approximately 30 - 40 years. Â Many poverty level women can't afford to buy tampons. Â Some are selling their food stamps in order to get the money to purchase these items. Â So naturally it follows that the government needs to supply women with tampons because they are a necessity.And with that, I shut off my computer and went for a long walk down by the river. Â It was either that or sit there and wait for my head to explode.As I walked I thought about this new bit of stupidity. Â I wonder what this columnist thinks women through the ages have done about dealing with this natural female cycle. Â I mean long before the invention of feminine hygiene products. Â Nowhere else have I seen that any woman ever in recorded history expected someone else to provide for these needs. Â I expect that if anyone believes that taxpayers should pay for tampons, there is a whole list of other necessities those same people will believe should be free to them. Â Perhaps each person should be given a lifetime supply of toilet paper. Â Or food. Â Everyone needs food to survive. Â Oh, wait. Â Government already has food covered for millions. Â How about coffee. Â I consider coffee a necessity, so shouldn't it be free? Â Or as one of the people who left comments about this article said, "I'll take my free beer now."Oh how my sweet little Grandmother would have scoffed at the notion of the government providing anything. Â She and her daughters used clean strips of cloth that they washed and reused each month, as did most women of her era. Â Her outhouse held the previous years Sears & Roebuck catalog. Â If she wanted coffee, she sold eggs from the chickens she kept and butter she made from the cream that came from the few cows they milked, and she bought coffee. Â She and her sons raised a couple of pigs each year and a steer for meat. Â She butchered some of her chickens every fall and hatched out more each spring. Â She raised vegetables in her garden. Â The surrounding woods provided blueberries and wild raspberries and strawberries. The government should provide tampons? Â I don't think so. Â And those who do could stand to learn a thing or two about taking care of your own self from Grandma.

title: Nice Surprises
text: So this morning my phone rings. Â It is Youngest Son. Â He wants to first tell me about my granddaughters. Â They had auditions for the competition dance teams last week. Â Boston was with her Dad when he called, so she told me that both she and her sister made the top teams for their age groups. Â They have worked hard for those spots on the teams and I am so proud of them both.Then David wanted to know if I would be home around noon today. Â I said I would. Â He said he had something he wanted to drop off for me. Â I love those kinds of surprises.David arrived carrying a bucket that was full of beautiful red tomatoes from his garden, three cucumbers and a handful of carrots. Â He said the carrots were pretty small as he planted them too close together this year, but it doesn't matter to me. Â I'll cook them for supper tomorrow. Â Homegrown carrots are so good tasting. Â And there was a big bowl of cherry tomatoes - my favorite. Â I've been snacking on them all day!Then out the door he went, calling over his shoulder that he almost forgot something. Â He returned with two jars of the bread & butter pickles he and his kids had canned and another jar of his home canned pasta sauce. Â I'm going to be eating well this week! Â Thank you, Son.So now I have cucumber chips drying in one dehydrator and tomato slices drying in the other. Â I saved out two of the large tomatoes for BLTs and will see about getting a bank loan to buy a pound of bacon tomorrow. Â Aren't meat prices getting out of sight?Dana over at Witless Relocation Program had a good post today about living within your means. Â There are so many who think they have to have the newest and best of everything and then can't figure out what happened when they can't pay for it all.Me...I'm happy with a bucket of tomatoes and some homemade pickles. Â And I'm even happier that I have kids who know that these things will make their Mom smile.

title: Taking a Break
text: Between a list of stuff that I need to accomplish, the need to spend some time with my son before he heads to Arizona and the fact that the words just aren't there at the moment, I think a brief hiatus is called for. Â So to my blogging friends and family, all is well here, but I just need a bit of a break. Â I shall return in September, hopefully refreshed and recharged, and with something worth writing about.

title: Fishin' and Flippin'
text: There is nothing blog worthy going on here in my little Home Sweet Apartment this week. Â Just the usual scrub and buff, laundry, etc. Â I am using this week to get all of those long neglected chores finished so that next week I can do some serious grocery shopping, canning and dehydrating, without feeling guilty about leaving stuff undone, or having to look at stuff undone. Â My closet pantry needed rearranging to accommodate the items on my shopping list, so that has been a priority. Â I sure wish I could work as fast as I once could, but a person can't have everything, I suppose. Â On the bright side, now that my pace has slowed, I find that I take more time to stop and smell the roses, as it were, than I did when I kept up a breakneck pace. Â That isn't a bad trade-off.So until I am actually doing something worth writing about, I give you "Fishin."Youngest son took his son fishing the other day. Â Jacob loves to go fishing. Â He really wanted to catch enough for supper that night, but it was not to be. Â I'm thinking that the time spent drowning worms with his Dad was pretty good, in spite of the lack of fish.And here is the "Flippin'" part:Boston has been working really hard to master the ariel, and she did. Â Determination and practice paid off. Â I've noticed that she is really good to help her younger sister with these gymnastic moves they are learning, so I was pleased to see that she nailed this one herself. Â Good for you, Miss B.Yep. Â I'm bragging. Â Grandmas get to brag. Â It's in the contract.

title: Bread & Butter Pickle Recipe for David
text: My youngest son's garden is producing a little bit later than last year, due to the cooler summer, I suppose. Â At any rate, the cucumbers are coming on like gangbusters now. Â He brought me a couple of jars of dill pickles this past weekend. Â When I talked with him this evening, he said he needed a good recipe for Bread & Butter pickles. Â He likes trying new recipes.Years ago I made some good sweet pickles. Â I wish I still had the recipe. Â I scoured my recipe file and my parent's old recipe box to no avail. Â However, I found this recipe that if it isn't the same, it is really close. Â It came from one of those old church Ladies Aid cookbooks. Â Those church ladies really know how to cook. Â So here you go, David.Bread & Butter Pickles4 pounds cucumbers, sliced thin8 small onions, sliced thin1/2 cup canning salt5 cups sugar4 cups white vinegar2 tablespoons mustard seed2 teaspoons celery seed1-1/2 teaspoons ground turmeric(If you're feeling adventuresome, you can add 1/2 teaspoon of ground cloves.)In a large container, combine the cucumbers, onions and salt. Cover with crushed ice and mix well. Let stand for 3 hours. Drain; rinse and drain again.In a Dutch oven, combine the sugar, vinegar and seasonings; bring to a boil. Add cucumber mixture; return to a boil. Remove from the heat.Carefully ladle hot mixture into hot pint jars, leaving 1/2-in. headspace. Remove air bubbles, wipe rims and adjust lids. Process for 15 minutes in a boiling-water canner. Yield: 7 pints.Let them sit on the shelf for three or four weeks before opening a jar. Â And, by the way, son...I'll be more than happy to taste test those pickles to make sure they are good enough for your family. Â Just sayin'.....

title: I Am Encouraged...
text: when I see four of my grandchildren sitting on the floor, playing a board game, talking and laughing with one another...and not a cell phone in sight. Â There may yet be hope.

title: Sunflowers
text: Last evening I was curled up in my recliner reading when the phone rang. Â It was Youngest Son. Â I asked if he was checking up on his Mom. Â He said yes he was. Â I like that.He was on his way to help a friend with a lawn project. Â He said that actually, he was escaping. Â His daughters had two friends for a sleepover. Â He said those four girls talked - loud - fast - continually. Â I said he was a craven coward. Â He said that was true.He asked me to check Facebook. Â He had posted a picture. Â This one.My grandson Jacob wanted to plant sunflowers this year, so David added on to his raised bed garden to accommodate them. Â He said they had grown so tall that he had the kids pose in front of them for reference. Â The fence in front of the kids that Jacob is peeking through is for the cucumbers to climb on. Â I'd say, if they flower, the sunflowers are a huge success. David said he didn't know what to do with the sunflower seeds, should they wind up with many. Â I suggested putting a bird feeder on the railing of their deck outside of the sliding glass door in their dining area. Â He said he didn't want bird poop all over his deck. Â I said he could power wash the deck in the spring. Â It would be worth a little bird poop for all of the enjoyment the kids would get, especially Jacob who loves watching the birds. Â He said he would put up a bird feeder. Â You know you have lost the argument when it is three kids and Grandma you are up against.I think I might have to look for a copy of "Birds of North America." Â The kids will probably just run an Internet search to identify the different birds, but I always liked the book reference. Â Who knows. Â Maybe they will, too.

title: Odds and Ends
text: I haven't been posting much lately. Â There has been nothing exciting going on in my little corner of the world. Â Just catching up on odds and ends of household stuff that needs doing before winter. Â Scrubbing the outside of the fridge. Â Vacuuming accumulated cat hair from the backs of appliances. Â Washing windows. Â You know. Â All that fun stuff.I'm working on building up my food pantry. Â Luckily, I still have a good amount of home canned food left from last year, so there are only a few things there to replenish. Â I transferred all of my dehydrated food to canning jars and got them arranged on shelves. Â The only thing I am low on is dried onions, so I will work on that until I have enough. Â I'm surprised that none of my neighbors have complained about onion smell. Â I set both dehydrators in front of open windows in my bedroom and shut the door, and I guess that helps. Â So it's just the odds and ends of store bought foods to stock up on, and I should be able to finish before winter sets in.I also spent an afternoon going through my scrapbooking supplies to see what I have on hand and what I need to buy. Â I enjoy making the mini albums and winter is a good time to work on that, although it isn't work for me. Â It is more like fun playing!I'm sort of taking it easy today so I can go tomorrow to a family get-together. Â My oldest son is moving to Phoenix at the end of this month. Â His sister is hosting family so they all can see him before he leaves. Â I understand completely why he doesn't want to spend another winter here in the frozen north. Â He lived in Phoenix many years ago and loved it. Â And even though he hasn't lived with me for many years and even though I understand why he is moving, I will still miss him.

title: There is One Thing...
text: and one thing only that keeps me from jumping on the Impeachment Bandwagon. Â And that is the thought of...President Biden.

title: Conversation With a Gentleman
text: I watched him walk across the parking lot toward the bench in front of the store where I sat, waiting for the bus. Â It was obvious he was not from these parts. Â His jeans were faded but clean and held up by a belt. Â His cowboy hat had seen many miles of protecting him from the sun and rain. Â His walked in his boots like he had been born to them. Â As he got closer I could see that if he had not yet passed the 80 mile marker, he was close. Â His face was as weathered as his hat, but many of the lines had been put there with smiles.He stopped in front of me and said, "Excuse me, Ma'am. Â I have some waiting to do. Â Would it be alright if I sat here and waited with you?" Â I said I would be honored.He wasn't a jabberjaw type of man. Â When he spoke in his soft drawl, he chose his words carefully. Â We talked of many things. Â We watched the people come and go. Â We smiled at a naughty little boy staying just out of reach of his mother and at a little girl of about three years of age who obviously had just learned to dress herself, judging by the clashing colors and gaudy accessories.He allowed as to how he liked the world better when a man's word meant something. Â He said that he didn't understand why more people weren't interested in what was going on around them. Â And more than that, why so many didn't bother to get ready for bad times.He apologized for being nosy, but that he couldn't help noticing that my handy dandy little old lady shopping cart was filled to the brim with bags of rice, sacks of onions and jars of peanut butter. Â On top was a sack full of canning lids. Â He said those canning lids reminded him of his mother, working all summer and fall, putting up vegetables, meat and fruit to get her family through the winter. Â He said that people now think that these big grocery stores will always be there, open and full of food. Â He said he could see that I was thinking ahead and would probably be all right, but so many wouldn't. Â He said it was a shame that the old ways were being forgotten, but was glad to see that some of us remembered.I was sorry to see my bus pull into the parking lot. Â I never learned that man's name nor does he know mine. Â But I think I will be a long time remembering a conversation with a gentleman, sitting on a bench, on a beautiful summer morning.

title: In Lieu.....
text: of any real content, which I can't seem to come up with lately, I give you the following for your consideration. Â The blog where I stole it is no longer in existence, so I can't give credit. Â In the meantime.....An Old Farmer's AdviceÂ Author Unknown* Your fences need to be horse-high, pig-tight, and bull-strong.* Keep skunks and bankers and lawyers at a distance.* Life is simpler when you plow around the stump.* A bumble bee is considerably faster than a John Deere tractor.* Words that soak into your ears are whisperedâ€¦not yelled.* Meanness donâ€™t jesâ€™ happen overnight.* Forgive your enemies. It messes up their heads.* Do not corner something that you know is meaner than you.* It donâ€™t take a very big person to carry a grudge.* You cannot unsay a cruel word.* Every path has a few puddles.* When you wallow with pigs, expect to get dirty.* The best sermons are lived, not preached.* Most of the stuff people worry about ainâ€™t never gonna happen, anyway.* Donâ€™t judge folks by their relatives.* Remember that silence is sometimes the best answer.* Live a good, honorable life. Then when you get older and think back, youâ€™ll enjoy it a second time.* Donâ€™t interfere with somethinâ€™ that ainâ€™t botherinâ€™ you none.* Timing has a lot to do with the outcome of a rain dance.* If you find yourself in a hole, the first thing to do is stop digginâ€™.* Sometimes you get, and sometimes you get got.* The biggest troublemaker youâ€™ll ever have to deal with, watches you from the mirror every mornin'.* Always drink upstream from the herd.* Good judgment comes from experience, and a lotta that comes from bad judgment.* Lettinâ€™ the cat outta the bag is a whole lot easier than puttinâ€™ it back in.* If you get to thinkinâ€™ youâ€™re a person of some influence, try orderinâ€™ somebody elseâ€™s dog around.* Don't pick a fight with an old man. title: What If...
text: I couldn't get down to the basement where the washers and dryers are located. Â Or what if there was no electricity and I ran out of clean knickers. Â How would I handle that?I've been experimenting with several "What If" situations lately. Â For a few weeks I couldn't get to the basement and I've been washing by hand what I needed, but what if there was a prolonged period of time where hand washing of clothes was necessary. Â Rinsing out items in the sink isn't good enough.I think at one time or another we've all seen the videos of various methods of doing laundry in a grid down situation. Â I have buckets. Â I have a new - never been used plunger. Â So I gave it a shot. Â I cheated by using tap water as I didn't want to mess with my stored water. Â And I found the bucket - plunger method works. Â The clothes came out as clean as if they had been washed in an automatic washer.I've been making my own laundry soap for years. Â I can make 3 gallons, enough for 60 washer loads, for about a dollar. Â The only drawback is storing 3 gallons of laundry soap. Â I found a recipe for powdered laundry soap that I decided to try. Â It is basically the same ingredients as the liquid, minus the water. Â Here's the recipe:2 cups finely grated Fels Naptha bar soap1 cup washing soda1 cup BoraxCombine and run through a food processor or blender to break the grated Fels Naptha down into powdered form and further combine. Â Use 1 Tablespoon per washer load or 2 Tablespoons for extra dirty clothes. One recipe will fit into a quart jar. Â That works better for me storage-wise than does 3 gallons of liquid, and it works just as well.I need a better way to wring water out of the clothes. Â I'm thinking that one of those yellow janitorial mob buckets with the attached piece that is used to wring water out of a mop might work. Â I could probably use the bucket for washing and rinsing and the attachment for wringing.Now all I need is one of those wooden drying racks - the ones with a framework on each side with dowels running across. Â I think I know where I can get both the bucket and the rack. Â Seems to me it is worth a try, especially when stairs are my enemy.I love it when an experiment actually works.

title: Another Ramble
text: I chuckled to myself this morning when I checked Facebook to see if Youngest Son had posted any more vacation pictures. Â He had.They are in San Diego. Â His comment was "This place is beautiful. Â I think my kids would like to call it home!" Â Earlier, he said he wasn't thrilled with the $4.19 gas prices. Â David and Staci work so hard. Â I'm glad to see them relaxing and enjoying themselves with their children. Last evening was relatively quiet for a 4th of July. Â The main fireworks display at Valley Fair is a few miles away, and I could see some of it from my window, but had none of the crowds and traffic. Â In fact, the town pretty much emptied out about dusk.Except next to my building.I had just curled up on the couch to read for a while, about 10 PM, when a series of small explosions got my attention. Â The explosions were followed by laughter. Â And more explosions. Â And more laughter. Â Of course I had to mutter the obligatory "Darned kids!" Â Sounded like the noise was coming from the alley between my building and the one next door. Â Finally I got up to take a look.Here in the middle of the alley were two boys about 15 years of age. Â They had a bag of fireworks and were setting them off, one by one. Â Some had a little bit of sparkly effect and others just went "Boom." Â The sound bounced off the walls of the buildings making sort of an echo. Â They would set off something from their bag, and then laugh with delight. Â Repeat. Â Repeat. Â They were having so much fun with their little fireworks stash that I couldn't get mad at them. Â I watched them for a little while, smiling at their antics. Â I figure there are a lot worse things 15 year old boys could be doing on a pleasant summer evening. Â After about a half hour their supply ran out and off they went.I'm going to have to kick the canning into high gear. Â I think I have more empty jars than full ones and I am running out of places to stack them. Â I need more hamburger and turkey for sure. Â And a couple of cases of Amish Coleslaw. Â The recipe comes from Jackie Clay, and it is delicious. Â I either drain it and mix with mayo for a regular coleslaw, or I use it as a relish. Â Love the stuff. Â Here's the recipe:1 - 1/2 cups vinegar2 cups sugar1/2 tsp. celery seed1/2 tsp. mustard seed2 tsp. salt1 large head cabbage1 cup diced celery1/2 cup diced onions2 cups shredded carrotsMix vinegar, sugar, and seasonings. Mix with vegetables. Stir very well. Pack into sterile jars and process in a water bath canner for 10 minutes.Note: Â You can shred the cabbage if you like. Â I chop it and the other vegetables fairly fine because I like to use this as a relish sometimes. Â I have also tossed in a few chopped green peppers and adjusted the ingredients accordingly.I have goofed off long enough. Â On to the fun stuff, like shampooing the carpet. Â (Yuck) The cat will disappear for a couple of hours at the sound of the shampooer and the dogs will hide in their kennels, but I expect they will forgive me about suppertime.

title: It's a Start
text: So yesterday Youngest Daughter made a grocery store run for me. Â Strawberries were on sale and she brought me 6 quarts. Â Five of those are hulled, cut in half and in the freezer. Â I am leaning toward making strawberry jam with them, but I think I will wait and see if they go on sale again before using them. Â The other quart is in the fridge, minus a bowl I ate last evening. Â I love fresh strawberries.Hamburger was on sale as well, and she brought me 18 lbs. Â This morning I browned all of it, drained it and packed it into pint jars. Â One pound of hamburger fills one narrow mouth pint jar. Â When I first started canning hamburger I added liquid - either beef broth or water - to each jar, but I wasn't happy with the results. Â It sort of reminded me of dog food and that's where most of it wound up. Â But canning it without adding liquid gives me hamburger that looks and tastes like I had just cooked it. Â All 18 jars are merrily bubbling away in my pressure canner.Note: Â If you are thinking about starting to can your own food, and you are looking to buy a pressure canner, get the biggest one that you can. Â I am told that the best brand is the All American. Â The big advantage is that the All American doesn't need a rubber gasket where other brands do. Â But for me, the price was prohibitive.The first pressure canner I bought when I started canning again about 4 years ago, was a 16-quart Presto, bought at Walmart for around $60. Â It has been a workhorse and I have had no problems with it. Â It holds 9 pint jars or 8 quart jars. Â For Christmas last year, Oldest Son gave me a 22-quart Mirro that holds 18 pint jars or 8 quart jars, having a divider that makes it possible to stack two layers of pints. Â When I have a large amount of food to can and am using pint jars, this cuts my time in half. Â It is getting a workout, and so far, I really like this canner as well.Being housebound does have its advantages. Â In the winter I rarely go out by choice. Â This chubby old woman just doesn't ice skate as well as I used to, and the thought of slipping and sliding on ice covered sidewalks is not pleasant. Â And the cold isn't much fun, either. Â Add being housebound part of this spring and summer and I have the perfect opportunity to see just how much of my food storage I had used between Christmas and the present. Â I had taken an inventory the first of the year, so I know what I had. Â I know what I ran out of and what is running low. Â And now I know how much of each item I need for one years worth, which is my goal.Tomorrow morning I will wash the jars of hamburger, label them with the date and add them to my shelves. Â Every little bit is one step closer to having what I want to have put back. Â Eighteen jars of hamburger may not seem like much, but it's a start.

title: Sometimes You Have to Just Bite the Bullet
text: I have always been a fairly independent person. Â Unless moving a refrigerator or a piano is involved, I try to do what needs to be done by myself.I am no longer young, but my mind is still in fairly good working order. Â I manage my own finances. Â Under normal circumstances I do my own shopping. Â I clean my own apartment. Â I do my own laundry. Â I haul out my own trash. Â Unlike some of my vintage that I have seen, I do not spend my days with a remote in my hand. Â I am into being as prepared as possible for whatever comes along, so I can and dehydrate food and little by little, stock up on other needed supplies. Â I have hobbies that keep me interested. Â I have pets that keep me smiling. Â I usually take care of myself pretty well.My kids have been really good to see that my needs are taken care of. Â One will call and tell me they are going to the Farmer's Market and what would I like them to pick up for me. Â Other times when something like a bad cold keeps me home, they will pick up a few groceries for me and drop them off. Â If I need to go somewhere that I can't get to by bus, they are more than willing to take me there. Â I have good kids.I will not here go into a litany of physical complaints. Â Anyone who reads regularly knows what they are, for I have been known to whine now and again. Â This spring and summer, however, have been a bear. Â It has been one thing right after another. Â I have been dealing with arthritis since age 15. Â By now I know that no matter how many pretty little pills my doctor prescribes, it isn't going away. Â I will have good days and bad days, but it is not going away.Asking for help with anything is one of the toughest things for me. Â I hate it. Â But a couple of days ago, my youngest daughter read me the riot act. Â Poor thing, she called me right after I had spent a considerable amount of time trying to shove swollen feet into shoes, with no success. Â I was grumpy. Â When she asked what was wrong, I told her. Â Wouldn't have, had I not been in such a foul mood, I suppose, but there you are.That's when she reminded me that I have grown children who are happy to help. Â And she let me know in no uncertain terms that they can't help if I don't tell them when I need help. Â I'm not sure, but I believe I have been verbally spanked.So, with help from my offspring (I thank God every single day for them.), we will work out a plan for the bad days. Â Ideally, I should live in an apartment either on ground floor or where there are elevators. Â My landlord has talked about installing a chair lift device on the front stairs. Â I will talk with him about that, because I really don't want to move. Â My bank is within sight of my building. Â The bus stop is less than half a block away. Â The post office and library are within two blocks. Â Everything I need is right here. The stairs are the big problem right now. Â Going down is easy. Â Coming back up - not so much. Â In any event, some decisions will be made soon. Â And I will work on asking for help when necessary. Â But I will still hate it that I have to do so.Getting old really ain't for sissies.

title: Guess...
text: where my grands spent the day.They are on vacation in California.They went to see the mouse.Their Mom and Dad are sharing photos on Facebook so I can keep up with their activities. Â So far it looks like they are having a ball.I wonder how I would look in mouse ears.....So last evening I'm sitting in my chair with a skein of yarn and a crochet hook in hand. Â I have made a bunch of afghans and am tired of them. Â I decided I needed a throw rug for my living room. Â The last rugs I bought at Target fell apart the first time I washed them, so I decided to try my hand at crocheting one. Â I think it will look kinda cool when finished.Anyway, I'm crocheting away, soothing music is playing and all is well in my world. Â Right up to the time I hear a ruckus outside my window. Â Nosy person that I am, I get up and sneak a peek through the window blinds. Â Sure enough. Â There in the middle of the street are two guys who have obviously extended Happy Hour far beyond an hour. These two geniuses are nose to nose. Â One is hollering, "You hit like a school girl." Â The other responds, "Don't you ever say that to me." Â Round and round they go until before long both are on the ground, trying to beat the tar out of one another. Â Their friends try to pull them apart, but give it up after a while and just let them go. Â The whole time they are still yelling, "You hit like a school girl," and "Don't you ever say that to me." Â Both are too drunk to do any real damage.About this time a cop car pulls up. Â Two officers get out and survey the scene. Â They stand and watch these mental giants for a minute and then wade in. Â One scoops up "You hit like a school girl." Â The other grabs "Don't you ever say that to me" by the scruff of the neck. Â Both combatants are given shiny new bracelets to wear and both are poured into the cop car. Â Off they go to spend a fun filled night in the drunk tank.And who says my life isn't exciting!

title: Monday Morning Ramble
text: Sleep has eluded me. Â I have to wonder why I am bright-eyed at 4 AM, after only three hours of sleep. Â Good thing I am a firm believer in naps.I glance around my living room as the sunlight begins to stream in. Â In one corner, next to a window is an overstuffed chair. Â It serves to hide in the corner behind it, two stacks of buckets from the bakery, waiting for me to fill with rice and beans and sugar and flour. Â But that's not why I keep that ratty piece of furniture. Â It is Kizzy the cat's chair. Â The front and side of one arm have been shredded. Â Kizzy has claws. Â There is a cat-sized indentation at the top of the chair back. Â Kizzy likes to sleep there, and when awake, likes to keep watch on whatever is going on outside of the window. Â How she can sleep there and not slide off is beyond me, but she does. Â I wonder if it is a sign of senility, to keep a disreputable looking chair just because the cat loves it.I gripe about being awake so early, but truth be known, I love the early morning hours. Â The breeze flowing through my open windows is cool. Â The street below is quiet. Â The cars with folks on their way to their jobs and the delivery trucks have yet to make an appearance. Â The birds are singing their little hearts out. Â Sometimes Kizzy joins me in watching the sky turn from black to blue to pink and gold. Â Or maybe she is trying to figure out how to get one of those birds. Â But that would require expending some energy. Â Unless a bird had a death wish and landed on her head, Kizzy isn't going to get excited. Â About anything. Â Lazy cat.Sometimes I wish I were more like the bloggers who cook fabulous meals and share recipes and photos. Â I find, at those times when I am honest with myself, that I eat for two reasons. Â One is because I truly love a particular dish, so I don't mind the fuss and bother it takes to prepare it. Â But mostly I eat for the second reason, which is that a body needs fuel. Â I suppose that if I didn't have so many other interests I might be willing to spend hours chopping and dicing and sauteing. Â I don't mind doing all of that when I am preparing food to be pressure canned for later use. Â But I find that I would rather be sewing or crocheting or scrapbooking or researching family history than spending time cooking elaborate meals for myself. Â Or maybe I am just lazy. Â I haven't quite decided.Enough rambling. Â As long as I am not going to sleep until afternoon nap time, I might as well finish up the few chores I have left over that didn't get done when I was sidelined. Â The grocery store has hamburger on sale this week and tomorrow I want to get enough to can. Â Canned hamburger is one item I love to have on my shelves. Â I can it in pint jars, which is just right for adding to hot dishes or spaghetti sauce or for making Sloppy Joes. Â And I want to do a few jars of meatballs in mushroom gravy. Â Those are really good over rice or potatoes. Â And they make a quick, easy meal for those times when I am busy (or lazy).
