title: The Bicycle Thieves
text: So this morning I'm messing about on my computer with the channel for the Minneapolis Police Department on in the background, when I hear a call come in. Â There are about half a dozen kids, approximate ages 12 - 16, who are stealing bicycles from a bicycle shop display in front of the store. Â Each kid grabs a bike and stashes it down the outside stairwell of a building close by, and then goes back to steal another. Â The kids are having a right good old time, laughing and swiping bikes.Unbeknownst to the kids, there is an old man who is a guard. Â He is inside the shop, monitoring the outside activity that is showing up on the security cameras. Â He can identify each kid, which bikes they stole and where the stolen bikes are.Police are on the way. Â And I'm guessing that these little hoodlums won't be smiling shortly.But I am, for all I could think of was:"Old age and cunning will triumph over youth and enthusiasm every time."So many times we hear of people who are successful on a grand scale...multiple homes, bags full of money, all the latest electronic gadgets, every toy known to man. Â But they got nothin' on me.There is enough of an improvement in the condition of my hip so that this morning I was able to climb in and out of my tub/shower, all by myself, no assistance required. Â No more sponge baths. Â Woo Hoo!!My next mountain to be climbed is the stack of dirty dishes waiting patiently for me in my kitchen sink. Â I'm betting that later on today, they will be washed, dried and put away.Sometimes it is not the huge successes that matter. Â Sometimes the tiny successes mean more. Â For me, at this time, I'll take the tiny ones, happily!

title: Rethinking Preps
text: When we think about being prepared, most will cite the upcoming collapse of our economy or the tyrannical direction our government is headed or the loss of our freedoms or the real possibility of the grid going down or a zombie apocalypse as reasons to prepare. Â Well, maybe not the zombies so much.This past week or so I have found that although I prepare for whatever is looming on the horizon, I might be a little better off to look a bit closer to home, and plan accordingly. Â I give you the following as an illustration of what can happen in day to day life, never mind the zombies.First, let me say that I tell you my little story not looking for sympathy, but to illustrate a point. Â I don't feel sorry for myself and I don't want anyone else feeling sorry for me. Â That isn't the point. Â The point is that things beyond our control can happen and sometimes we miss the small stuff by looking only at the big picture.I am not recovering as quickly as I had hoped for from my arthritis flare-up. Â Walking at this point is painful and difficult at best. Â The stairs - not gonna happen. Â Although I am very slowly getting better, most everything I do at this stage is in a seated position, for standing is also not much fun.I have had to call for help just once. Â I was out of bread and unable to physically make any more myself, so my son-in-law, God love him, brought me some loaves and some lunch meat from the store. Â He also hauled out my trash and brought up my mail. Â I learned that it might be better to swallow a little pride and ask one of my neighbors if they would, in an emergency, help me with the trash and mail, in trade for some homemade bread or rolls when I am better. Â And I learned that I not only need to store flour, yeast, etc. for baking bread, but I need to have several loaves, either in dough form or already baked, in the freezer. Â The actual baking requires little walking or standing. Â It's the stirring up and kneading that is difficult.Luckily, last year I canned several varieties of soup - split pea & ham, ham & bean, turkey vegetable, vegetable beef, and chili. Â These have been a life saver for me, and I need to find more ideas for meals that can be home canned. Â Standing next to the stove to cook from scratch just isn't going to happen right now, so anything that I can just heat up keeps me fed with the least amount of fuss and bother. I really need to become better organized. Â For instance Â I canned some homemade pork and beans. Â They are really good. Â At least I remember them as tasting really good. Â They are on the top shelf of one of my shelving units where I store canned foods. Â I can't reach them without climbing on my little step ladder. Â Not gonna happen this week! Â So I found that I need to have a variety of easy to heat up canned food in jars in a cupboard that is handy to my stove and microwave. Â If movement is a problem, then things like jar meals need to be within easy reach.A few years ago, one of my daughters had been involved with a group that got together and made up freezer meals. Â Everything needed was assembled and put into freezer bags. Â She had given me a couple of them, and they were really good. Â I think it might be a very good idea to find recipes for this kind of thing and make up a couple of weeks worth of meals, so all I would have to do is take out a bag, thaw the contents, dump into a casserole dish and bake. Â As long as I am spending most of my days right now sitting on my backside, I might just as well sit in front of my computer and research this for when I am well again. Â I have seen blogs where people do this, and now I just need to pay attention and take notes.I realize that there are other steps that can be taken to make life easier in a situation like mine. Â But I found that feeding myself was the most wearing on me, so I am concentrating on making that aspect of life a little less trying.The whole point of this post is to say that sometimes things happen when we least expect it. Â I didn't even entertain the possibility of being sidelined for so long a time. Â And I wasn't ready for it. Â There may be a next time, or I may get lucky and not have to deal with this kind of thing again. Â Who knows. Â But if there is a next time, at least I will be more ready to take care of myself than I was this time. Â And if I can help someone else who might go through a similar experience, then I have done my job.

title: When You Are Six
text: When you are six, it doesn't take much to have a bad week.It starts when six year old boy and the neighbor girl, same age, decide to relieve themselves in the yard rather than take time to go inside to the bathroom. Â Girl's daddy doesn't seem to possess a sense of humor. Â Boy's daddy knows that the kids are only six years old and when you are six, peeing outside is fun. Â Boy's daddy kinda wishes the kid would have found a bush to hide behind, though. Â Six year old boy learns that there is less trouble involved if he just goes inside when nature calls.Then six year old boy comes home spouting a brand new word. Â It is unfortunate that this particular word is not one that should be used in polite society. Â Boy's daddy wants to know where he heard this particular word. Â Six year old boy says that the neighbor boy said it to another kid. Â Boy's daddy wants to know if six year old boy knows what this word means. Â Six year old boy does not. Â Boy's daddy explains that this word is not a nice word. Â It is a word that nice people don't use. Â He tells six year old boy that if he doesn't know what a word means, he shouldn't say it. Â And if he does know what a word means and it is a word that is naughty, he shouldn't say it then, either. Â Six year old boy learns a lesson about bad words.I really like the fact that my son didn't come all unglued when his son added a bad word to his vocabulary. Â He patiently explained, without having to go into detail about the meaning of the word which the kid is probably too young to totally grasp, that there are words that are not nice and he would not like to hear those words spoken in their home, or away from it, for that matter. In these days of extreme political correctness and free speech zones, I am glad that my grandson is being taught right from wrong and not being taught that certain words are not allowed. Â The kid, while growing up, is going to be learning lots and lots of new words - not all of them nice. Â I believe that learning what is right and what is wrong will serve him much better than an outright banning of words. Â And I am certain that if this same kid decides to spout off words he knows are wrong, there will be consequences. Â Which makes a lot more sense to me than censoring speech or creating free speech zones.As for the peeing on the lawn thing, I'm pretty sure that when my grandson has grandchildren of his own, he will probably still be peeing outdoors now and then. Â But by then he will have gained enough common sense to at least go find a tree to hide behind.

title: A Fairy House
text: A year or two ago, my granddaughter Boston had as one of her class projects the designing and building of a fairy house. Â Don't ask me why the class built fairy houses, for I don't know. Â I just know that she had fun building it.This year Maddie Mae has the same teacher that her sister had, and Maddie was excited because that meant she got to build a fairy house, too. Â When we were having lunch on Mother's Day, she told me all about it, describing how she was building it. Â Today was the big day when she took her finished project to school.Dad helped her just a little bit with the construction, but the ideas were Maddie's as were the decorations and most of the construction. Â My favorite is the Jello pool in front with the Peeps floating in it. Â She decided that fairies, after all, like Peeps as much as she does.That is one pretty cool fairy house, Maddie! Â You did a great job.Love, Grandma

title: Your Own Paradise
text: Earlier this week I posted about spending a quiet day, and mentioned that I had a beef stew bubbling on the back burner and that biscuits were about to go in the oven. Â One of my regular readers and one I consider to be a friend, Jess over at "Scratching to Escape," left the following comment: Â "A quiet day? With homemade stew and biscuits? Sounds like a small piece of paradise."By the way, if you aren't already reading Jess' blog, you are missing out. Â He voices opinions, writes well about a variety of subjects and his stories of fiction that he posts now and then are gems.Anyway, his comment about my small piece of paradise got me to thinking. Â For many years I was a restless person. Â I was never quite satisfied with my life. Â It wasn't so much about financial matters, for fortunes have never impressed me much. Â It was more about that time-worn notion that the grass is always greener over there, just beyond that fence. Â I felt that I just could never quite get to the greener grass.It took me well over 60 years to discover that it had nothing to do with green grass. Â It had to do with my own shortcomings. I have never been one to covet my neighbor's belongings. Â If the guy down the street drove a nicer car than I did, I didn't care. Â If the next door neighbor had a big screen TV delivered, I was happy for him, but didn't rush out to buy one bigger and better. Â If friends belonged to prestigious clubs or organizations, well good for them, but I wasn't interested.Most folks wouldn't think that living in a three room apartment in a city suburb could be even close to paradise. Â For a long time, I didn't think so, either. Â But in the past few years, I have come to realize that a person's personal paradise is what they make it. Â It is where "Home" is. Â It is where you can just be yourself. Â Nobody needs to be impressed with your lifestyle if you are happy with it. Â In my little apartment, I can do what I like. Â I can run my pressure canner to help stock my shelves. Â I can spend time making afghans for grandkids. Â I can sew a quilt if I choose to. Â I can read all night if I want. When I go outside, I am reminded that I live in a town and I would very much like to live in the country again. Â But I refuse to dwell on that aspect of my life, or to let it spoil a perfectly good day. Â Oh, there are times when I daydream about a cabin in the woods or on a lake, but now I can see those for what they are - pleasant daydreams. Â That's not going to happen at this stage of my life, but it is alright to dream just a bit.Sometimes I can be pretty slow on the uptake. Â It took me so very long to remember some advice I was given years ago. Â I wish I had remembered sooner."Bloom where you're planted."I am so excited! Â M. E. Masterson over at her blog, "Adventures of Life!," just held a giveaway. Â The drawing was for a beautiful beaded barrette, handmade by herself. Â As a lover of all things handmade, I am thrilled to have won the drawing. Â When it arrives, I will take pictures to post here.If you aren't a regular reader of "Adventures of Life!" you should be. Â Many thanks to her for this lovely gift.Anybody stopping by to see me today will be greeted with my grin, which is sure to last all day!

title: Grumpy
text: It has been becoming increasingly obvious that this disease called arthritis is not going to allow me to sit through several hours of dance recital tomorrow. Â After doing everything I know how to do, I finally threw in the towel and called Youngest Son to let him know.Sometimes I wish that if I had to have a disease, it would be something more predictable and treatable - something that would allow me a medication regimen or exercise plan or something that would help control it. Â Instead I have flare-ups and not always in the same joints. Â Sometimes it's in the knees - sometimes hips - sometimes my back. Â And then it will tease me into thinking that it is getting better before it nails me again.This doesn't happen all the time. Â Just once in a while. Â I can go for weeks at a time with very little problem. Â And I am thankful for that. Â And I can usually work around the stiffness and pain. Â I am slower than I used to be, but still usually able to get around alright. Â Except now. Â When I really want to watch my sweet granddaughters dance.OK. Â I got that out of my system. Â Sometimes it helps to just rant a bit. Â I'm still grumpy, but that, too, shall pass.Thanks for listening.

title: A Nice Quiet Day
text: Sometimes a nice quiet day is just what is needed. Â The effects of the arthritis flare-up are lessening, but I may just postpone anything very strenuous the rest of the week. Â Saturday is my Granddaughter's annual dance recital. Â I have been there every year since they started dance, and I sure don't want to miss this one. Â I got to watch them perform their solo dances at a competition, but not the group dances, which they will do at the recital. Â I look forward to watching them dance on stage every year. Â And at each recital there is a Daddy-Daughter dance that is always fun. Â Definitely don't want to miss that one!So today I just puttered about. Â I had a good excuse not to get too carried away, as I have no hot water today. Â A neighbor has a broken hot water tap in her apartment, so the hot water to the entire building has been shut off until a new tap can be installed this evening. Â Yeah, I know that if I wanted to, I could just heat water on the stove, but I will take the excuse to be lazy today instead!So today wasn't a total loss, I spent the morning finishing up sewing crocheted granny squares together to form long strips, and am in the process of sewing those strips together to form the afghan. Â The pooches are happy, for they have been taking turns curling up in my lap for pets and belly rubs. Â The sun is shining. Â A slight breeze is coming in my open windows. Â A beef stew is bubbling on the back burner and soon I will stir up a pan of biscuits to go with it.There is something to be said for spending a nice, quiet day.

title: Sidelined
text: Today I am sidelined. Â Arthritis has decided to take up residence in my hip. Â So I am taking things slow and easy and with any kind of luck, tomorrow will be a better day.In between taking care of the necessaries - washing dishes, getting a crock pot meal going for supper, sweeping the kitchen floor - I am working on Granddaughter's afghan, which seems to have taken on a life of it's own! Â But I think the end may be in sight. Â It is a lot bigger than planned, but that's OK. Â Just taking more time to complete than I thought.So as a diversion from the boring aspect of sewing together all of these little granny squares, I flipped on the police scanner for Minneapolis. Â I am always astounded at the things people will do in order to gain the attention of the police. Â The following are the dispatcher's calls from between noon and 2 PM.Two black males breaking into a patio door using a crowbar.One black male in the center of an intersection, suspected to be high on drugs, trying to take his clothes off.Welfare check on a person who is likely on crack.Report of three small children sitting on the front steps of a home. Â Parents are inside and won't let the kids in. Â (temp is 46 degrees)One white male picked a fight with a construction worker.Group of five individuals shoplifting at a major department store.Unidentified person driving off without paying for gas. Â License plate numbers don't match the car.Intoxicated black male harassing shoppers trying to enter or leave WalMart.Black male stopped for careless driving. Â Identification comes back to person wanted in Illinois for forgery. Â Known to be armed and dangerous.White male wearing a trench coat (I'm not making this up!) reported for public urination and indecent exposure (on a busy street corner).Female juvenile detained at a store for shoplifting.Two male bus passengers, harassing and threatening other passengers.Out of control 14 year old female - breaking furniture, destroying objects in her home.Two black males, both wearing black hoodies, seen breaking into a house. Â One is carrying a bag. Â Caught trying to escape in a waiting van.These calls didn't include the usual traffic stops or calls about domestic abuse. Â Neither did they include fire calls or those involving medical issues. Â These were just the ones that caught my attention.I guess there really is no cure for stupid.

title: Monday Ramblings
text: I was checking the weather forecast this morning while planning my week. Â Seems I might as well just tuck an umbrella under my arm and go out to do what needs to be done. Â Cool and damp are the common words in the forecast. Â No sense in complaining. Â Other parts of the country are experiencing drought conditions, while here everything is turning green. Â There is a small tree outside my front windows. Â Tiny leaves are forming and soon it will be lush and green again, giving shade for me while I sit on the front steps enjoying the fresh air with Jessie Jane and Lily. Â We like to sit there from time to time, watching the world go by. Â Although there isn't much to watch during the daylight hours, when the streets are fairly quiet. Â Sometimes the owners of the bicycle shop in my building will come out to chat and give Lily a pet or Jessie Jane an ear scratch. Â There are some nice things about living in a town.Although fall is my favorite time of year, spring runs a close second. Â The bitter cold and the drifts of snow are but a bad memory. Â The lilac bushes in the next block are starting to form buds. Â The lady who owns them lets me cut as many of the flowered branches as I want to bring home. Â Lilacs are one of my favorite flowers, and for the short time they are in bloom, I have mason jars full all over my apartment. Â I think that nearly every farmhouse in the state has lilac bushes. Â They remind me of the ones by the old farmhouse where I grew up. Â Those ranged in color from white to deep purple, and a huge bouquet always sat on the dining room table in the spring, giving the house a wonderful scent.I think it may be the sounds of the birds I like most. Â During the winter, most have the common sense to flee south when the first snowflakes hit the ground, and those who aren't quite as smart spend the winter huddled in whatever shelters they can find. Â But come springtime, they are all out and about and in full voice. Â Some days when my windows are open, the sound of birdsong nearly fills my apartment. Â This confounds Lily, who can't decide if the birds are friend or foe. Â Fortunately, Kizzie the cat is way too lazy to be bothered with scaring them off. Â I don't need any radio music going when I can listen to the birds sing.I have rambled on long enough. Â Time to get a few odds and ends done this afternoon, for tomorrow it is back to my quest to restock my pantry shelves. Â There is a good sale this week on celery and on mushrooms, both of which I like to dehydrate. Â Whole chickens are on sale, too, and I like to have a few in my freezer. Â Roast chicken is a favorite meal, and there is so much I can do with the leftovers. Â One chicken can feed me suppers for several days. Â I've almost given up on finding hamburger, or any beef, at a reasonable price. Â I may just have to pay the price to get as much canned as I will need for the next year. Â I just don't see prices falling any time soon - or at all, for that matter.I guess all we can do is continue on and do the best we can with what we have to work with.

title: What a lovely day...
text: I had today!Those kids who couldn't be here called this morning to wish me a Happy Mother's Day. Â One had to work and the other was spending the day with her grown-up son. Â Oldest daughter had another commitment, but when she brought my vac to me last week, she gave me a Mother's Day present of a gift card good for four haircuts.David, Staci and the Grands took me out for lunch. Â That was a real treat, as I rarely go out to eat. Â The best part was sitting with my grandchildren and listening to them tell me all about what they have been doing.They wanted to take me to get my hair cut. Â They said that way I wouldn't have to take the bus to get it done. Â They said that the girls wanted to watch when I got all of my long hair cut off. Â So off we went.The lady who cut my hair was so very nice. Â She let my granddaughters stand right there by me so they could see. Â I wanted to donate my hair to Locks of Love, so the beautician put my hair into two braids. Â Boston and Maddie were astounded that the braids measured 18 inches long. Â Their eyes were big as saucers when with a few snips of the scissors, the braids lay on the counter in front of me. Â I've got to say that my head feels considerably lighter!Afterward the kids wanted their picture taken with Grandma, so we went outside for that.Then the beautician who cut my hair asked if my son would take a picture of me holding the braids. Â So he did.It seems the shop wanted it for the part of their website about Locks of Love. Â Boston and Maddie were impressed!!And then we headed for home. Â The kids came upstairs so they could pet the cat and feed treats to the dogs, who were in ecstasy. Â Kids and treats. Â Their lives don't get much better than that.I am blessed with children who remember me on Mother's Day, even if they can't be with me. Â I am truly one of the lucky ones.I received one more gift - a gift card for Kindle books from Amazon, so I believe I will browse and pick out some books to add to my collection. Â And then I think it will be time for a nap.It was such a good day.

title: Mother
text: Eighteen years have passed since my mother died. Â Whoever said that time heals all wounds obviously hadn't yet lost his mother.I wonder why it is that we sometimes develop an appreciation for our mothers when it is too late to tell them so. Â I am so very grateful to her for her patience in teaching me all there was to know about keeping a home, for that is what she did.Â She married right after WWII, in an era where Dad's went off to work in the morning and Mom's stayed home and washed the clothes and scrubbed the floors and baked the cookies and cooked the meals. Â She sewed our clothes and mended them when we were careless and put holes in them. Â She saw to it that we went to church. Â She made sure we understood the importance of family. Â And she made sure that I learned the lessons well.When we are young, we tend to resent having to stay home to help with the Saturday house cleaning ritual (Just in case we get company on Sunday.), or to help with the canning of garden vegetables and cases of peaches (If we don't do this now, we won't eat this winter.), or to learn how to sew a dress (If you can sew, you will always have nice clothes to wear.). Â We want to be with our friends instead of sitting on the back steps shelling a tub full of peas. And when we get to be young adults, we are way too busy and way too self-important to even think about the person who taught us the things that now make our lives better. Â When money is tight and we refrain from buying a new blouse, but sew one for ourselves, it doesn't occur to us to thank the person who spent hours showing us how it was done. Â When we have children of our own to feed, we don't think about the person who taught us to fry a chicken without burning the daylights out of it or how to roast a piece of beef without winding up with a chunk of shoe leather.It is now, when I am in the twilight of my life, that I think the most about the woman who raised me. Â If she had not taken the time and had the patience (Lord only knows, she needed a basketful of patience with me.), I would not be enjoying this time of my life nearly as much as I do. Â I wouldn't know how to do so many things that now occupy my time and that I enjoy. Â I wouldn't have as great an appreciation for my family as I do. Â And I wouldn't have the values that are important to me.I wish I had told her more often than I did. Â I hope she knows that the rebellious girl-child she dealt with has come full circle, and has acquired an appreciation for all of the hard work it took to get me to this point. Â And that even though I have, over the years, strayed far afield from my mother's teachings, I never forgot. Â She taught me well.Thank you, Mom. Â I love and miss you.

title: Storms
text: Last evening I knew a storm was approaching even before I checked the weather radar. Â My smallest Yorkie, Lily, was in full "something is coming and I don't like it" mode. Â She paced the living room. Â She kept an eye on the windows. Â She pestered me in between pacing and watching. Â And as soon as the first flash of lightning and the first roll of thunder occurred, she curled up in her kennel and went to sleep. Â Sometimes I think she is more accurate in her predictions of approaching storms than is the weatherman.Up until recently, Jessie Jane would accompany her partner in crime in her pacing and watching and pestering. Â But age seems to have caught up with my Jessie. Â I'm not sure of her exact age, but it is around the 13 year mark. Â She has adopted a "whatever" attitude and only gets excited when there is a treat in her immediate future. Â Last night she stayed in her kennel, which seems to be her favorite place to be now, and watched Lily's frantic pacing from there. Â It was kind of like "Fine. Â Whatever. Â Wake me when it's over."The storm didn't last very long and produced just a little pea sized hail. Â The sun is shining now, but more storms are headed this way in the afternoon and evening hours. Â I had thought about making a grocery run today, but think I will wait until tomorrow when the storms will have passed. My daughter did an excellent job in choosing a vacuum cleaner for me. Â I test drove it yesterday. Â I thought that my bedroom carpet was pretty clean with the exception of a few little bits and pieces that find their way onto a rug, but when I went over the carpet, the new vac picked up enough cat hair to build a whole new cat. Â My living room carpet will be cleaned this afternoon, and if the new carpet scrubber works half as well as the new vac, I will be happy.I sometimes wonder what it says about my personality that I am content to watch weather predicting dogs and am happy about the performance of a new vacuum cleaner. Â Most would probably say that my life is about as exciting as watching paint dry. Now that warmer weather is here, my windows are open some to let in all that lovely spring air. Â The down side is that I can more clearly hear the voices of some of the patrons of the bar next door. Â It isn't a rowdy bar - more of a neighborhood place. Â But I hear quite often the nearly hysterical laughter of some who seem to have a need to have a good time, no matter what. Â And I hear the harsh words of arguments, usually fueled by too much to drink. I don't drink. Â There was a time when I did. Â A lot. Â It was in my best interest to stop drinking altogether, for I didn't like that person very much. Â The one who didn't know when to stop. Â That being said, I have no problem with those who enjoy an adult beverage. Â Or with those who like to go out on the town. Â But in the past year or two, it seems that things have changed. Â For the 17 years I have lived here, I have heard those voices, especially on the weekends. Â And it seems to me that the voices that once were those of every day folks having a beer or two, laughing and joking and just enjoying an evening out with friends, now are almost frantic in their quest for a good time. Â The laughter seems forced. Â The fights are a nightly occurrence. Â And instead of the friendly banter among friends, I hear a lot of hate and discontent.I thought perhaps it is because I have gotten old. Â But I really don't think it is. Â I thought maybe it was because I no longer drink, but that's not it, either. Â People have changed. Â Or at least, the attitudes of society have changed. Â It is almost like people know, deep down inside, that bad things are coming, and they have a need to raise as much hell as possible while they still can.I hope I'm wrong.

title: Rattle, Clunk and Smoke
text: So I was in Suzy Homemaker mode. Â Drug out the vacuum. Â Started sucking up the debris on my bedroom carpet. Â And I soon smelled smoke.Oh, crap. Â Please don't anybody tell me that there is another fire in my building. Â About that time I hear a noise that sounds like somebody is shaking a tin can full of marbles. Â I look down and discover the smoke and noise is coming from the business end of my vacuum.Laid the vac handle down flat on the floor so the smoking part is in the air. Â Don't really want to burn a hole in the carpet. Â Unplugged the offending machine. Â The smoke slowly drifted out the open window. Â Took a look at the bottom of the vac and found metal and plastic bits and shavings. Â This is not good.The vacuum belonged to Youngest Daughter before I got it several years ago. Â It has had a workout. Â It owes me nothing. Â Sometimes a piece of equipment just isn't worth fixing. Â This is one of those times.On to the next project. Â Grabbed the carpet cleaning machine and headed for the living room. Â Wanted to give the carpet a good cleaning before I get busy with other things. Â I managed to get about three square feet of carpet cleaned when there was a whine, a clunk, and then the machine just died. Â Checked the belt. Â OK. Â Made sure I hadn't tripped a breaker. Â Nope. Â Plugged into a different outlet. Â Nothing. Â Messed with the on-off switch. Â It finally came to life, only to clunk two or three more times and die again.I am a fairly patient person. Â Not completely patient, but fairly patient. Â But by this time I had had enough. Â Wrestled the carpet cleaner down the stairs and tossed it into the dumpster. Â Came back in and made the same trip with the vacuum. Â Came back inside and called my oldest daughter. Â Asked her if she would go to the store, buy a vacuum cleaner and a carpet cleaner and bring them to me. Â I knew that the boxes would never fit in my cart. Â Trying to carry them on the bus was not an option. Â She asked me if I needed them right then or would tomorrow be alright. Â Tomorrow would be just fine.The vacuum cleaner in the box and the carpet cleaner in the box are sitting in my kitchen. Â Tomorrow I will put them together. Â And vacuum my carpets. Â And shampoo my carpets. Â I've been working hard to stick to a budget, and it has paid off. Â Of course, it helped that I pretty much stayed home all winter. Â When you don't go anywhere, you don't spend money. Â So I could replace the worn out vac and carpet cleaner without ripping my finances to shreds.And tonight I will say a prayer, thanking the good Lord for giving me yet another daughter who is willing to come riding in on a white charger to save the day for her mother.

title: A Bit of a Break
text: Now and then we all need a bit of a break. Â All is well here in my little corner of the world, but there are things that need my attention. Â And sometimes it is easier to concentrate on those things if my computer is shut off. Â I will return soon, hopefully refreshed and renewed.

title: Minneapolis Protest
text: I guess I'm just too dumb to understand the reasoning behind some political protests. Â I understand why people protest, but sometimes the way they go about it makes little sense to me.For instance: Â I was listening to the scanner website this afternoon while attending to a few household chores. Â Apparently there is an immigration bill being debated in our federal legislature. Â There was a protest staged in downtown Minneapolis concerning this proposed legislation.The police were scrambling to deal with several buses carrying protesters converging on the downtown area. Â Downtown Minneapolis is a traffic hell under the best of conditions. Â Then they were dealing with the protesters themselves, who were doing their level best to stop all traffic downtown, right at rush hour. Â They had to block off streets and re-route traffic, while trying to keep the protesters under some sort of control. Â It made for a nightmare of a mess.Now I can understand people protesting legislation that they don't agree with. Â I believe that folks should be engaged in what is happening that affects their lives. Â I will have to confess that I am not up to speed on the current immigration legislation being debated. Â There is so much garbage being thrown at the people of the United States these days that keeping abreast of all of it is a full time job.But I'm willing to bet that those folks who, at 5:00 this afternoon, just wanted to get home to their families, have dinner with their kids, walk the dog or just relax with an adult beverage after a day at the office, but were delayed in a huge traffic snarl caused by several bus loads of people sitting down in the middle of the streets of downtown Minneapolis and thus preventing the working public from going home, are not going to be too sympathetic to the cause of these protesters.If you want support for your cause from the general public, I'm thinking that there are better ways to do it than to tick off those very people you want to help you. Â Just saying......

title: Perpetual Three Year Olds
text: So I'm sitting at my kitchen table writing out a grocery list. Â The littlest of my Yorkies, Lily, is standing in front of her open kennel door, fussing. Â Then over to me, front paws up on my leg, fussing some more. Â Then back to the kennel. Â I think she is just being needy, wanting some pets and belly scratches. Â But she keeps it up, becoming more agitated the whole time.So finally I call the other one, Jessie Jane, who, probably thinking there is a treat awaiting, pops out of Lily's kennel.I didn't realize that dogs have the ability to tattle on one another. Â But as soon as Jessie Jane is away from Lily's kennel, Lily struts, head and tail held high, to her now vacant kennel, enters, turns in circles, curls up and promptly goes to sleep.Jessie Jane is left standing in the kitchen going, "What?"Yep. Â I am living with perpetual tattling three year olds. Â And it still takes very little to amuse me.

title: They Call The Wind Mariah
text: I've always liked that song. Â It's kind of melancholy and lonely and sometimes, not often, but sometimes it fits my mood.It has been raining off and on since Sunday. Â The wind sometimes howls down the streets and around the corners and then lets up for a while, like it is catching its breath for another hard blow.I wonder if the never ceasing sounds of wind can really drive a person over the edge. Â My Dad thought so. Â He claimed that someone he knew was driven mad by the constantly blowing winds in the Dakotas during the Great Depression. Â It may have been the wind. Â It may have been living with the hardships of that time. Â I never knew for sure. Â But Dad was convinced that the wind was the cause of the madness.But then my Dad had one or two other somewhat strange ideas. Â I found it sort of hard to explain these ideas coming from a man who was so practical and grounded. Â He had only an eighth grade education, which was normal for boys of his generation. Â Born on a farm in 1911, he went to school in the one room schoolhouse near the farm where he grew up until he had completed the highest grade possible there. Â Then he worked, either on the farm or hiring out to make money to help the family. Â And he continued to work hard the rest of his life. Â He wasn't given to flights of fancy.I called him when I first became interested in tracing my family history, to ask him some questions about his grandparents. Â He told me what I wanted to know and then he said, "Now, you be careful. Â You know that _____ went crazy when she was working on that genealogy stuff." Â I could never convince him that _____ suffered from dementia, and that the genealogy had nothing to do with it. Â After that, when I would question him about this ancestor or that, he would always caution me to "Be careful that you don't go crazy."I find it interesting, the little snippets of life that remain in our memories. Â Whenever I take the time to research my family history, I smile to myself when I always recall Dad's words of warning about "that genealogy stuff."And if this wind doesn't let up soon, I may be able to test his theory that the sound of the wind really can drive a person a bit mad!I think I now have some idea of what it took for my small in stature grandmother to make bread for her family of nine children. Â She had to have stirred up and kneaded vast amounts of bread dough to feed that crew. Â None of them were shy about their appetites. Â But she did it on purpose.I did it because I am a dunderhead.I was happily measuring yeast into the warm water for the bread. Â Thinking about God only knows what. Â It wasn't about the task at hand. Â And that is where my inner dunderhead took over, and I found I was spooning Tablespoons of yeast - not the teaspoons I should have been using.Duh!A quick calculation told me I would have to double the recipe to use the yeast already in the water. Â I usually double the original recipe, so now I am making a quadruple batch of bread. Â Yikes!Kneading bread dough that contains 22 cups of flour is not a job for the faint of heart. Â Or the weak of muscle. Â Took me 20 minutes over the normal ten. Â Wore me down to a frazzle. Â Dunderhead.On the up side, I don't have to bake for a while. Â I have 4 large loaves, 3 dozen buns and two large pans of cinnamon rolls.I guess there are some advantages to being a dunderhead.

title: Productive Weekend
text: The soft spring rains were nice on Sunday, right up to the time the wind picked up and started to howl down the alley and around the corners of my building. Â It's funny how even though the inside temperature remains constant, it feels colder when I can hear the whistle of the wind and the sound of the rain being blown against the window panes. Â So I grabbed a flannel shirt and a heavy pair of socks to ward off the imaginary coolness of my apartment, and got busy.Sams Club has fresh chicken breast at a good price, so I bought several packages, cut the chicken into chunks and canned them. Â 27 pints of chicken are now on the shelves, making a total of 54 pints with what I had canned earlier. Â Took the pieces of fat and scrap meat I had cut off the chicken before canning, boiled them up with a bit of seasoning and got 4 quarts of rich broth. Â The cooked scraps are used for dog treats that make my two ankle biters jump for joy! Â The chicken fat gives fried potatoes a wonderful flavor. Â I had planned to buy hamburger to can, for I use that a lot, but their price was no better than the grocery store's, so I will wait for sales.Sam's carries the huge 6 lb. packages of frozen hash browns, so I got three. Â They dehydrate down to less than half the bulk which frees up my freezer space. Â I put the last bag on dehydrator trays this morning. Â I really like having the dry hash browns on my pantry shelf. Â Takes only about 15 minutes to rehydrate them in boiling water and they are ready to use.The price of butter is good - just a bit over $2 per pound, as opposed to $3.59 a pound at the grocery, so 24 pounds are in the freezer. Â Yeast is really cheap in the vacuum sealed 2 lb. packages, and because I bake all of my own bread, I bought 8 lbs. Â That should last me a very long time.I believe that it is necessary to my happiness and well being to have an occasional treat. Â I bypassed the barrel o' cheese puffs (although I was tempted) and went for the frozen blueberries. Â Sams sells a 3 lb. bag for $6.88. Â It would be tough to find a pound of fresh at the grocery for the price. Â I bought three bags. Â One I will just eat. Â I like them as an evening snack once in a while, about half thawed. Â The other bags will be used for baking or desserts or blueberry pancakes.There was a lot more that my poor daughter huffed up the stairs for me. Â The stairway I usually use is wide and gradual, with a landing half way up. Â Had that stairway not been a crime scene that morning, she would have hauled the groceries to the landing where I would have loaded my cart and easily taken them the rest of the way. Â As it was, we had to use the front stairs which are very steep and narrow. Â She wouldn't let me try to carry anything up those awful stairs, but carted all of it herself. Â Without complaint. Â She has one knee that gives her trouble, and I'm pretty sure she had to go home and ice it down for a while. Â How on earth I wound up with kids who help, even when it hurts, is beyond me. Â I am so very grateful.With all of the bad things going on around us, with a government that seems to delight in making us dependent upon it and with the same government that seems hell-bent on destroying our Constitutional rights, I tend to become a bit anxious when I know that I am not as prepared to take care of myself as I would like. Â So even something like this grocery haul eases my mind a bit. Â I will continue to do whatever I can to be as prepared as possible for whatever new and worrisome cards are dealt us. Â I don't know how others feel, but it seems to me that the downward slide is escalating. Â I refuse to be one of those fighting for the last loaf of bread on the shelf.

title: The Sound of Rain
text: The building I live in was constructed in the late 1800's or very early 1900's. Â There is a ledge, maybe 18 inches wide, that runs along the entire front of the building, right under my living room windows. Â It serves no purpose except as an architectural design element.It is raining today. Â If I crack my windows just a bit, the sound of the rain hitting the ledge reaches my ears. Â It's not as good as rain hitting a tin roof, but it will do.Later I may have to doze in my recliner next to a window and just listen. Â The sound of rain is good for the soul.

title: Crime Scene
text: It appears my building is a crime scene. Â And I missed all the excitement.This morning my daughter came here and we went merrily on our way to Sam's Club. Â An hour and a half later, when we returned, we found the door I normally use to enter the building tied off with crime scene tape. Â The door was propped open. Â There was a large smear of blood on the door. Â There were large drops of blood outside the door on the cement. Â The rug inside the doorway looked like someone had bled out on it.Shortly after my daughter had hauled my groceries up the stairs of the second entrance to the building, one of my neighbors came knocking at my door. Â It seems that the grandson of another neighbor (he is in his mid-20's) had robbed the little bar that sits behind my building. Â He then ran here, trying to get in. Â I don't know if he cut himself breaking into the bar or if he did it trying to break the glass on the door to my building. Â But about the time the neighbor who was telling the story got home from taking her boyfriend to work this morning, the thief confronted her and threatened to kill her if she didn't let him in. Â She instead called the police. Â I would imagine that the thief is either at the hospital getting sewn back together or sitting in jail.I guess you never know what is going on in the minds of people. Â I had talked to this guy several times before when he had been here to see his grandmother. Â He seemed a decent sort and I had never heard anything to the contrary. Â I feel bad for his Grandma. Â She is a widow who last year fought and won a battle with cancer that left her in a weakened condition. Â She is devastated by the actions of her grandson. It is my opinion, wounds or not, the punk should be horse whipped just for the agony he has caused that poor old lady.

title: Good Parenting
text: Today has been cool and rainy. Â It was a good day to spend on quiet projects. Â Did a bit of sewing, a little reading, a little puttering about in my kitchen. Â Nothing very noteworthy, but satisfying nonetheless.This evening I settled in to work on sewing together the crocheted squares for an afghan. Â Brought up the police scanner website to listen to while sewing. A little while ago I heard one of the dispatchers announce that there was a father at the police station with his 15 year old son. Â The father had discovered that his son had been buying drugs from another student at his school, and had promptly brought the son to the station to talk with police about who had sold the drugs.That had to be hard for a parent to do. Â And young boys really don't like to rat out their peers, especially if those peers are the source for their drugs.All I know is what I heard in the police transmissions, but it sounded to me like the father was determined to put a stop to his son's drug use. Â And in the process, he is giving his son a lesson in consequences for actions.With a parent who cares enough to do what this father is doing tonight, perhaps the boy has a fighting chance. Â Too many parents, it seems, don't want to be bothered or make excuses when their children do something stupid. Â I wish both the father and his son well, and commend them for what they are doing.

title: Daughter Arrives Bearing a Gift
text: Sunday was a really nice day, made nicer by spending it with children and grandchildren. Â A good meal, good conversation and lots of hugs. Â Doesn't get much better than that.Except when Oldest Daughter brings a gift.Sunday morning I had worn a sweater on the way to my daughter's home, to ward off the last of the morning chill. Â And because the day was so warm and sunny, I didn't think about the sweater until I was nearly home again. Â Last evening Daughter called, wanting to know if I would like her to drop off the sweater. Â When she arrived, she had a present for me. Â With a grin, she handed me a bag containing the ham bone left over from dinner. Â She knows how I dearly love a meal or two of ham and beans.So the beans, the bone with a goodly amount of meat left on it, and generous handfuls of dehydrated onions and carrots are in my cast iron dutch oven, simmering on the stove. Â They will simmer there all day. Â The apartment is already starting to smell wonderful. Â And tonight I will have a feast.Some might say that a leftover ham bone isn't much of a gift. Â But for me, who enjoys the simple pleasures in life, it is just right. Â Thank you, Jill.

title: Peep Art
text: My youngest grandkids love to make things. Â It's always fun to see where their imaginations will take them. Â This year their contribution to Easter dinner were Peep Cupcakes and Peeps floating on a Jello lake.And they were delicious!

title: Mom's Buns
text: A couple of years ago, one of my children remembered that their mother knows how to make bread. Â Since then it has been my job to supply the family gatherings with homemade buns. Â The dough is nearly ready to shape and put onto the baking sheets. Â Soon my apartment will smell delicious. Â And I will snitch a couple of them for my supper.Here's wishing all of you a blessed Easter.

title: Daughter Saves the Day
text: So my youngest daughter called me last evening. Â She wanted to know if she should pick me up to go to her sister's house for Easter. Â We talked for a while and I mentioned to her that I was planning on renting a car for a couple of days. She wanted to know where I was going. I said I was going grocery shopping.She wanted to know why I needed to rent a car for that.I said I was planning to buy lots of groceries - too many to carry home on the bus.She asked me where I wanted to go.I told her.She said that the Saturday after Easter she would come get me and we would go to the first store where I wanted to shop.She said that the Saturday after that we would go to the second store.She said that I didn't need to rent a car when I have children and grandchildren.Bless her!

title: Just Say No
text: So I'm standing at the kitchen counter, building myself a sandwich. Â As usual, my two little ankle biters are by my feet, waiting for me to drop a piece of meat or cheese. I'm afraid I might step on one or the other. Â They have such small bones that being stepped on could have disastrous results. Â And if I should trip over them, I could easily do myself a mischief. Â So I've been trying to break them of this habit, to no avail.Today I gave up on everything else I have done, trying to discourage them from being underfoot. Â I just said, "No." Â I didn't yell. I didn't raise my voice in any way. Â Just a firm "No."To my complete amazement, they turned in unison, left the kitchen and entered their respective kennels in the living room.They really scare me sometimes.

title: I Should Have Known...
text: better than to plan anything. Â Went to the store yesterday for necessaries. Â Was chilly outside but calm and sunny. Â Woke up this morning to 25-30 mph winds and the threat of snow flurries. Â Cancel the bus trip that includes standing outside waiting.I have pretty much decided to wait until the middle of May, rent a car, take what money I have set aside to restock my pantry and do it all in a couple of days. Â No waiting in the rain for a bus. Â No limits on the amount I can carry home at one time. Â Sounds good to me.I figure that what I spend on a rental car for two days doesn't even come close to what it would cost me in car payments, license, insurance, tires, gas and upkeep to own a car. Â And I could get to stores I have been wanting to visit that aren't on the bus route. Â Aldis has good buys most of the time and Fleet Farm carries canning jars and Foodsaver bags for less than anywhere else. Â But I can't get to either by bus.Now if I can just find a pack mule to haul stuff up the stairs to my apartment.....

title: Odds and Ends
text: Yesterday was one of those days to attend to some of the piddly little chores that if left undone will turn into big jobs. Â Got enough accomplished to satisfy my inner Susie Homemaker. There was one jar of chicken breast in the fridge that hadn't properly sealed when I canned the chicken, so I turned that, along with a quart of turkey broth and some veggies and seasonings, into soup. Â And then thought, "What the heck," and tossed in a cup of rice to turn it into a nice chicken rice casserole. Â Tastes really good even though it looks suspiciously like the dog food I make for my two little ankle biters. Â Wound up with enough for supper tonight and a couple of containers to freeze for later.Also had a half a quart jar of home canned peaches that needed to be used, so I made a batch of peach muffins. Â They were good as dessert last night and even better as breakfast this morning. This week's grocery advertisement has some pretty good sales going on, including ham. Â The bad part is that the store will only allow one ham to be sold per coupon per purchase, and as I want at least three to can, I will be seeing more of my friendly neighborhood bus driver than I care to. Â But then, strawberries are on sale this week, too. Â My supply of strawberry jam has dwindled over the winter, so I can buy enough for two or three batches of jam and enough to freeze a few containers for later. Â They will be really good over ice cream this summer.Looks like rain is headed my way today. Â It is a good day to give these old arthritic bones a bit of a rest. Â I'm working on finishing up the last of the crocheted granny squares for the afghan I'm making for oldest granddaughter. Â That turned into a bigger project than originally planned, but it is for my granddaughter. Â She is worth the extra time and effort.And later I will dive head first into an 1800's murder mystery. Â I love those old mystery stories. Â There are all sorts of twists and turns in the plot and the descriptions transport me back in time. Â And that is a pretty good place to be on a rainy Sunday afternoon.

title: Food Preservation...
text: is ongoing here in my little apartment.My local grocery had boneless, skinless chicken breast on sale for $1.99/lb. Â 14 pints are in my pressure canner.Frozen hash browns were on sale for $1.99 per 2 lb. bag. Â I bought 4 bags. Â They filled 11 dehydrator trays and are drying as I write. Â I really like having the dehydrated hash browns on hand. Â I put about 2/3 of a cup of them in a bowl, cover with boiling water, and within about 15 minutes they are ready to fry up for one generous serving. Â I've tried making my own from raw potatoes, but without success. Â Potatoes have to be blanched before drying. Â The thin slices and 1/2 inch cubes work well, but the homemade hash browns tend to fall apart. Â The frozen ones are already blanched, so all I need do is spread them out on the screened trays, set the dehydrators at 135 degrees and let them go.I'm working on building my food storage back up. Â I used a lot of it over the winter when I was staying home most of the time. Â And I was really glad to have it. Â So each week I'm buying the sale items I can use. Â Prices are going up at an alarming rate, so whatever I can preserve now will save me money in the long run. Â As I no longer own a vehicle, this kind of shopping figures out to lots of bus rides, but it is worth it for me.Having your own land and raising your own food is wonderful. Â I would much prefer to be doing that. Â But when in a place where that's not going to happen, there are still ways to preserve food. Â It is called doing the best you can with what you have to work with.

title: Signs of Dementia
text: Do you remember those TV commercials that depicted symptoms of dementia in the elderly?The one I remember showed an older lady who couldn't find her keys because she had put them in her refrigerator.Well, I just caught myself putting the loaf of bread into the cupboard that holds bags and waxed paper and plastic wrap. Â And then I put the box of bread bags into the freezer.I think I may be in trouble...

title: Another Gorgeous Day
text: That's two in a row. Â We are on a roll!Today was grocery shopping day. Â Time to catch up on a few things I was running low on. Â I had been putting off going to the store because I so dislike going out when it is so icy cold. Usually I treat myself to a meal out once a month about the time my check arrives. Â I decided to skip that treat in favor of a few grocery items I had been craving. Â Bananas. Â Grapes - two varieties. Â And my new love - bacon flavored crackers. Â Yes, I know. Â They aren't good for me. Â I don't care. Â They are good. Â With cheese. Â If they kill me, I will die happy.After the groceries were put away, Jessie Jane and I went for a walk down along the river. Â I thought for sure it would overflow its banks this year, what with all of the snow we had, but although the water level is high, it has a ways to go before flooding. Â I am always grateful that whoever planned this town had the good sense to build far enough up the hill above the river so the flood waters never reach us.And now I'm off to tackle the pile of laundry that kind of got away from me while I was a bit under the weather. Â And I sometimes think the weather can bring on bouts of illness. Â Especially if a person is cooped up for months at a time. Â I know that all it took for me to get back to normal were a couple of warm, sunny days.Oh, yeah. Â Peeps. Â I bought Peeps. Â Just because I could!

title: Sunshine
text: The temperature is 58 degrees. Â The sun is shining. Â The snow is nearly all melted. Â The windows in my apartment are open enough to let in some of that wonderful fresh warm air. Â Just came back from a stroll around my neighborhood. Â Folks are smiling. Â Waving to one another. Â Talking about how glad they are that the winter seems to be over.I am so looking forward to getting out and about tomorrow without having to wear a stocking hat and mittens. Â Or worry about slipping on the ice. Â Or frostbite.It is amazing what a bit of sunshine and warmth can do for one's outlook.

title: Morning Musings
text: Woke up this morning a wee bit before 5 o'clock. Â Went to the windows facing the street to see what kind of gifts Mother Nature had left. Â It was still snowing lightly. Â There appeared to be between 6 and 8 inches of snow, judging by what was piled on top of cars and on the roofs of the buildings.Looking at the snow reminded me of the last job I worked before retirement. Â I liked the job itself, for I spent my day working with dogs. Â But I liked it even better for the fact that it was located next door and I didn't have to try to start a freezing cold car, scrape ice and snow off the car windshield and windows or fight the morning commuter traffic.In the winter after a snowfall, I would go to work early, grab a shovel and clear the sidewalk of snow. Â Some days it was an easy job of sweeping. Â Other days like today, when the snow is wet and heavy and especially if it was deep, it was a job for a much younger person. Â But you know how it is when you are pretending that you really aren't getting old. Â You do it anyway and pay later.This morning I can admire the beauty of the snow by looking out my window. Â Instead of being outside shoveling, I am still in my jammies, coffee cup in hand, thanking the good Lord that I don't have to do that any more. Â I love retirement.Lily the Yorkie, the one who was so sick, has recovered nicely. Â She is back to her bouncy self, barking at the snow removal equipment in the street below. Â But since being sick she has, for reasons known only to her, decided that I can not be out of her line of vision. Â If I go to the kitchen, she is right behind me. Â If I am at my desk, she is standing next to my chair with her little paws on my leg. Â If I am in my recliner reading, she is curled up at my feet. Â I keep my bedroom door closed, for the other one, Jessie Jane, will sneak in and potty on the rug if given the opportunity. Â Can't break her of that nasty habit. Â So when I go to my bedroom and shut the door behind me, Lily stands outside the door and raises all sorts of a fuss. Â She is needy.I am sick and tired of being sick and tired. Â I do not like forced inactivity. Â Yesterday I was still experiencing cold chills, but I had slept all that I possibly could. Â So I wrapped myself in my fuzzy blanket, plopped myself down in front of my computer and dug into my genealogy program. Â I still have lots of information to enter. Â For some, the study of generations past is dry as dust. Â For me, it is fun to learn about those ancestors of mine. Â As I worked on transcribing past census records I found that one great-great-great aunt ran a hotel in a small Minnesota town. Â Many were farmers. Â One branch of the family moved from Minnesota to Washington and Oregon, where they held a variety of jobs. Â And another spent her last years in an Alms House, which I found sad. Â The entering of information into my program is tedious, but the detective work to find that information is fascinating. Â I think that we are the sum total of those who came before us. Â I want my children and grandchildren to know who they are.So I will take it easy over the weekend, doing what needs to be done but refraining from starting any big projects. Â The local weatherman tells me that by Monday the sun will shine and the temperature will get into the mid-sixty degree range. Â By that time I will either be well again or stark raving insane from inactivity. Â I vote for well.

title: Son's Weather Report
text: David receives weather updates because of his job. Â He usually posts them on Facebook for friends and family. Â Here is this morning's report."I'm am sorry my friends, but here it is:A strong spring storm to affect us over the next 36 hrs. First, mainly just a rain event today with patchy snow mixed mainly before 9 am. No accumulations through the day with a high in the middle 30's. The rain will turn to heavy snow northwest metro 7 pm and southeast 10-11 pm. Heavy snow tonight with 5-9â€ likely by 6 am. Another 1-3â€ likely before fully ending around 2 pm for totals of 6-12â€. The heaviest amounts will be northwest and least southeast as the change over to snow will occur later over the southeast."I'm southwest of the city, so I'm not sure how this latest storm will impact my area. Â For me, it doesn't really matter. Â I'm not going anywhere. Â I have plenty of food and supplies. Â The critters have lots of food and treats. Â Got enough coffee to last a year. Â I have loaded over 600 books onto my Kindle. Â I'm ready.This is my Dad's car after a snow storm in about 1953.And I am truly grateful, especially since I'm still feeling kinda crappy, that I won't be one of those standing in line at the grocery store today. Â Think I'll take a nap instead.

title: No Joy Today
text: Whenever we get sick, we usually refer to it as the flu. Â Whether it is or it isn't doesn't matter. Â It is miserable. Â Chicken soup is in the crock pot. Â Hibernation is on my schedule. Â See you later.

title: Pilot in Training
text: My grandson Zach takes lessons to become a pilot. Â I'm not sure when he started, but his Mother says she remembers when he could stand upright under the wing of the plane and he needed to sit on a cushion to see out the front window. Â He's grown some since then.Zach isn't quite 14 years old yet. Â He has had a love of flying since he was small. Â His Dad has a pilot's license and I suspect that may have had something to do with his wanting to learn to fly. I love this photo of him, taken a couple of days ago. Â It reminds me a bit of the old photos of barn storming pilots back in the day. Â He just has that look about him.I don't care that much for commercial flying, but I love riding in the small planes. Â My Dad wasn't a pilot, but he loved that kind of flying and he passed that along to me the first time he took me to go for a ride in one of the planes that gave tours in Bemidji, Minnesota. Â I was just a young girl, but I was hooked. Â One of the most fun birthday presents I ever received was when Zach's parents (my daughter and son-in-law) rented a plane and I got to go for an hour's ride. Â I loved every second of it.I hope that when Zach gets his license, he will remember that his Grandma dearly loves to fly.Spring is here. Â I can tell by the sound of the neighborhood kids skateboard wheels on the street. Â And by the long legged teen aged boys doing tricks on little bikes in the alley across the street.Actually, it's kind of fun to watch them.

title: Think About the Pets
text: I got to thinking the other day about how we are so accustomed to having the services we need only an email, text or phone call away. Â But what would we do if this changed.In my case, it concerned the care of my dogs. Â Twice a year I take them next door to my friend, the dog groomer. Â They are given baths, hair cuts, the excess hair is removed from inside their ears and their nails are trimmed.One of my Yorkies, Jessie Jane, has weird nails. Â The quick (the part inside the nail that has nerves and blood vessels) grows unnaturally long, so her nails can never be trimmed short. Â Cutting into the quick causes pain and bleeding. Â So as her nails grow, they curl sideways. Â This doesn't seem to bother her or slow her down any. Â Until yesterday.Jessie Jane was holding up one of her front paws when she came out of her kennel for her morning cookie. Â So as soon as she ate her treat, I picked her up and checked her paw. Â Sure enough. Â One of her nails had gotten so long that it was poking the adjoining pad on her foot.Like most people, my first thought was to call the groomer and make an appointment to get Jessie's nails cut. Â But then I got to thinking, what if I didn't have access to a groomer. Â What would I do?I don't have a proper nail trimming tool, but I do have a small wire snipper. Â So I got it out and carefully trimmed the offending nail as well as the rest of them on that foot. Â It wasn't a professional looking job, but she could run without pain, and that was what I wanted.I am big on having a variety of foods on hand - store bought, home canned and dehydrated. Â I have extra water stored. Â I either have or plan on buying in the near future, alternative methods of cooking, heating at least one room of my apartment and light sources. Â But, shame on me, aside from stocking up on food and water for them, I hadn't thought ahead for the care of my fuzzy buddies who share my life.So this weekend I will do the research to see what I should have on hand for their proper care. Â And next week I will go to a pet supply store that I trust to have good quality merchandise, and buy a nail trimmer, a good quality clipper for hair cuts, and whatever other supplies I need. Â There may come a time when I won't have a veterinarian three blocks away as I do now, so I need to think along the lines of what to have on hand should they become sick, as Lily was the past couple of weeks, or injured.Our pets give us so much. Â They love us even when we are not lovable. Â They are glad to see us even when we are cranky. Â They only ask to be fed, have clean water and occasional pets, snuggles and belly rubs. Â I will still take them to the vet when needed. Â But if the time comes when that's not possible, I want to be able to do the very best for them that I can. Â They deserve no less than that.

title: Sometimes No News is Good News
text: I think I need to stay away from news reports for a little while. Â Both mainstream, although I pay little attention to it anyway, and the alternative news sources I read daily. Â I think my brain is on overload. Â And about to explode.The Democrats are sniping at the Republicans and the Republicans are taking pot shots at the Democrats. Â Neither one is doing anything constructive. Â But they are blowing enough hot air to bring on real global warming.There are Congressional Investigative Committees questioning various and assorted witnesses about many of the latest scandals. Â The Congressmen thump their chests, pound their desks and make speeches designed to make the public think they actually care. Â After which they stand in front of the news reporters and pontificate, throw stones at the other political party and express outrage. Â But nothing changes. Â Next week most people, whose attention span is similar to that of a gnat, will have forgotten all about that particular scandal and will be more interested in their favorite TV sitcom character or sports team than they are in the fact that everything they say or do is now recorded and stored. Â To keep them safe. The king of America who lives in the White House continues to thumb his nose at the Constitution. Â The pundits continue to offer up their opinions on panel discussions. Â And promote their latest book. Â Nobody dares call the President out on his lawlessness for fear of being labeled racist. Â Or audited. Â And nothing changes.Although once in a great while there is a glimmer of hope, as in the state of Georgia, where legislation was passed that contains pro-gun reforms. Â But then there is my state of Minnesota, who is working to pass legislation to take guns away from those involved in domestic abuse. Â Those promoting this bill say that abusers "don't deserve to own a gun." Â Now, I have no sympathy for abusers of any kind. Â But my question is this: Â Who will be the next group who "don't deserve" gun ownership? Â Will it be the bloggers who write articles that question this country's leadership? Â Will it be the veterans who, while in service of their country have seen things that now give them nightmares? Â Will it be the person who has been under a doctor's care for depression? Â Who is next?And then there is the Obamacare train wreck. Â And don't forget the Russians who are busy rattling their sabers.I think I will, for a while, confine my reading to the blogs listed on the right. Â Even though many of those folks address issues concerning the horrors going on around us and the major loss of our freedoms, they also provide helpful information on how we can survive this mess. Â Some have offered good advice on various problems that have come up in my life. Â Others show me tasty foods and how to prepare them. Â Some take me on wonderful trips down memory lane or show me the beauty of nature in their corner of the world. Â And still others just make me laugh.Yep. Â I think that is the game plan for a while. Â I will never bury my head in the sand, for I do need to be aware of what's coming at us. Â And I will never be like so many who blithely skip through life, pretending that everything is just fine and of course, nothing bad could ever happen here. Â But sometimes I just need to back off for a time. Â Before I become totally overwhelmed. Â And completely frustrated with government insanity. Â Or at least until my head is no longer in danger of blowing up.

title: I'm Ready
text: The blinds are down on all of my windows. Â I refuse to watch at any more snowflakes falling.The ingredients for peanut butter cookies and molasses cookies are waiting on the kitchen table. Â The first pot of coffee of the day is steaming and delicious.The Kindle is charged and ready to go. Â The fuzzy blanket waits on my recliner.Chicken soup is cooking in the crock pot. Â Hot ham and cheese sandwiches are planned for lunch. Â Soup and cornbread for supper.Bring it on, Mother Nature. Â Throw a temper tantrum. Â Dump icy rain and snow on us. Â See if I care. Â I'm ready for you. Â You can't wreck my day. Â I'm going to have a good one in spite of you.

title: And This Girl...
text: loves to dance, too.I know I wasn't going to do any more posts about bread making. Â But I just had to share one more recipe.Take any other white bread recipes you have, whether they are Grandma's or mine or from anybody else, and toss them. Â Yesterday I was digging through an old recipe box of mine, looking for something else entirely, when I stumbled upon the following.Amish Bread2 Cups warm water1/3 Cup sugar2 packets dry yeast (or 4 1/2 teaspoons bulk yeast)1 1/2 teaspoons salt1/4 cup vegetable oil (or melted shortening)5 1/2 cups flourDissolve the sugar in the warm water. Â Stir in the yeast. Â Let it sit for 10 minutes. Â Add the salt and oil. Beat in 2 cups of flour until smooth. Â Then stir in flour, one cup at a time. Â Turn out on a floured surface and knead for 10 minutes. Â (Don't cheat. Â 10 minutes.) Â The dough should be fairly soft but not sticky, and should be smooth and satiny to the touch.Grease a large bowl. Â Place dough in bowl, turning so all sides are coated. Â Cover with a towel and let rise until doubled in size. Â Punch down. Â Form 2 loaves and place in greased bread pans. Â Let rise again until doubled in size. Â Bake at 350 degrees for about 25 minutes or until a deep golden brown.Turn bread out onto cooling racks. Â Brush sides, top and bottom with melted butter. Â Let cool completely. Â (Except for the heel of one of the loaves. Â Cut that off while the bread is still warm, slather it with butter, and enjoy!)I doubled the recipe and got four nice sized loaves. Â Three went into the freezer and part of the fourth was for supper.That bread came out just as soft as any good bakery bread. Â The crusts were soft as well. Â Often homemade bread will be a bit dry the next day. Â This stayed soft.So this morning I used the same recipe, doubling it, and made buns and cinnamon rolls. Â As with the bread, I brushed the tops with melted butter as soon as they came out of the oven. Â I froze most of them, but kept out enough for a couple of meals. Â Both the buns and the cinnamon rolls are soft and delicious.I can see no reason to use any other white bread recipe. Â I am just amazed at how good this bread is. Â I'm going to experiment a little bit and see if I can't adapt the recipe for wheat bread.Thus endeth the bread making posts. Â Amen.

title: Irish Soda Bread
text: So this morning I went to slice some bread for toast and discovered there was none to slice. Â Sometimes when I get busy I focus on the job at hand, ignoring other things around me. Â It didn't register with me that when I made a sandwich for lunch yesterday, I used up the last loaf of bread. Â I didn't want to take time this morning to make regular yeast bread, so I dug out a recipe I've been meaning to try. Â Irish soda bread. Â No yeast. Â Minimal kneading. Â No waiting for the bread to rise. Â Perfect.Irish Soda Bread3 tablespoons butter or margarine, softened2 1/2 cups all-purpose flour2 tablespoons sugar1 teaspoon baking soda1 teaspoon baking powder1/2 teaspoon salt1/3 cup raisins, if desired3/4 cup buttermilk*Note: If you donâ€™t have buttermilk on hand, a fair substitute is to add 1 tsp. lemon juice to each cup of regular milk, wait 3-5 minutes, then use wherever buttermilk is called for.Heat oven to 375ÂºF. Grease cookie sheet.Cut butter into flour, sugar, baking soda, baking powder and salt in large bowl, using pastry blender, until mixture resembles fine crumbs. Stir in raisins and just enough buttermilk so dough leaves side of bowl.Turn dough onto lightly floured surface. Knead 1 to 2 minutes or until smooth. Shape into round loaf, about 6 1/2 inches in diameter. Place on cookie sheet. Cut an X shape about 1/2 inch deep through loaf with floured knife.Bake 35 to 45 minutes or until golden brown. Brush with butter or margarine, softened, if desired.Legend has it that the X cut into the top serves to ward off evil spirits. Â I cut in the X. Â I'm taking no chances!I am not fond of buttermilk so I always use the lemon juice method substitution for baking. Â I may have to see if I can find some powdered buttermilk to keep on hand. Â Keeping fresh milk requires trips to the grocery, so I use powdered milk for everything except drinking.The Irish soda bread turned out great. Â It is heavier than yeast bread - kind of a cross between bread and biscuit. Â Or maybe like a crusty artisan bread. Â At any rate, it works for toast in my little toaster oven, for sandwiches and for just plain eating with a meal. Â Some add raisins to the recipe, but I wanted it for use in place of a yeast loaf. Â I may try it with raisins the next time I make it. Â Soda bread isn't something I would make on an every day basis, but it served my purpose for quick bread to last until I make regular yeast bread tomorrow morning.I love it when a plan comes together.

title: Looking Good
text: I hope I'm not celebrating too soon, but it seems that Lily the Yorkie is much improved. Â The nasty stuff at both ends has stopped. Â She spent the better part of the past two weeks sleeping, and today she is alert, barking at whatever she perceives as a threat to her food dish and is following me around like, well, a puppy dog. Â Wherever I am, that's where she is. Â I have to be really careful not to trip over her. Â I won't complain about that one bit. Â For a while there I thought I would lose her, and it wouldn't have been surprising considering her age and the fact that a dog that starts out at 9 lbs really doesn't have any weight reserves when it gets sick. Â She is skinny, but has an appetite now. Â I have spent time today holding and cuddling and petting and telling her what a good girl she is, even though for the most part, she is not. Â She is mouthy and can be obnoxious and wakes me up before sunrise to give her a treat and tries to chew on the landlord's ankles whenever he stops in. And I would be kinda lost without her.After the fire in my building last summer, new smoke detectors were installed throughout the building. Â I hate them.My apartment is laid out with the living room on one end, bedroom on the other, with the kitchen in between. Â Because of the building codes, there is a smoke alarm in the kitchen and another in the bedroom. Â There is about 4 feet of space between the two. Â I know. Â Makes no sense. Â Building codes are a government invention and therefore don't have to make sense.The smoke alarm in the kitchen goes off whenever I open my oven door while said oven is in use. Â It goes off when I fry potatoes for supper. Â It goes off when I boil water. Â It goes off whenever I use the stove at all. Â This is annoying, both to me and my neighbors. Â I finally reached my breaking point. Â I ripped the thing from the ceiling. Â Took out the battery. Â Set the alarm on a shelf. Â Capped off the wires on the ceiling and called it good.All was peaceful in my little apartment. Â I could bake bread, cook supper and boil water for coffee without the ear-shattering screech from the alarm. Â I still was protected by the smoke alarm in my bedroom and another in the hallway, right outside my kitchen door. Â Life went back to being fairly pleasant. Â It remained so for several weeks.And then, in the middle of the night, I was awakened by a BEEP and a feminine voice telling me, "No battery." Â I grumbled, rolled over and was nearly asleep again when BEEP, "No battery" again assaulted my ears. Â Every half hour the smoke alarm informed me that it needed a battery. Â Dawn was just breaking when I picked up the offending alarm, opened my closet door and stuffed the thing into a box and covered it with two bags full of yarn. Â Closed the closet door. Â Breathed a sigh of relief. Â And then heard a distinct BEEP "No battery."About that time I passed from annoyed right on to lunatic. Â Pulled open the closet door. Â Tossed the bags of yarn out of the way. Â Grabbed the smoke alarm and headed for the living room. Â I wrapped the alarm in a blanket. Â I could still hear it, with the added feature that it set the dogs to barking whenever it went BEEP "No battery," which it was doing every couple of minutes now. Â Got a comforter from the closet and wrapped it around the alarm and the blanket. Â BEEP "No battery," bark, bark, bark.
