This means, among other things, that you and your teachers will dress accordingly. Many people in our society dress more formally for Hollywood events than for church or school. These people have their priorities backward. Therefore, there will be a formal dress code at this school.Fourth, no obscene language will be tolerated anywhere on this schoolâ€™s property â€” whether in class, in the hallways or at athletic events. If you canâ€™t speak without using the f-word, you canâ€™t speak. By obscene language I mean the words banned by the Federal Communications Commission, plus epithets such as â€œNigger,â€ even when used by one black student to address another black, or â€œbitch,â€ even when addressed by a girl to a girlfriend. It is my intent that by the time you leave this school, you will be among the few your age to instinctively distinguish between the elevated and the degraded, the holy and the obscene.Fifth, we will end all self-esteem programs. In this school, self-esteem will be attained in only one way â€” the way people attained it until decided otherwise a generation ago â€” by earning it. One immediate consequence is that there will be one valedictorian, not eight.Sixth, and last, I am reorienting the school toward academics and away from politics and propaganda. No more time will be devoted to scaring you about smoking and caffeine, or terrifying you about sexual harassment or global warming. No more semesters will be devoted to condom wearing and teaching you to regard sexual relations as only or primarily a health issueâ€¦ There will be no more attempts to convince you that you are a victim because you are not white, or not male, or not heterosexual or not Christian. We will have failed if any one of you graduates this school and does not consider him or herself inordinately fortunate â€” to be alive and to be an American.Now, please stand and join me in the Pledge of Allegiance to the flag of our country. As many of you do not know the words, your teachers will hand them out to you."I know that I no longer have children in our school systems. Â But I do have grandchildren in public schools, and I fear for what they are being taught. Â Seems to me that our schools could greatly benefit from principals and teachers who were free to teach in the manner described in Dennis Prager's speech, rather than having to abide by the rules set down by government.And I think that the Pledge of Allegiance is a good place to start.

title: Dad's Apple Pie (for Stephen)
text: I have often said that my Dad's apple pie was the best I have ever had. Â Now, part of my love for that pie could be because it was my Dad who made it. Â But for the most part, it is seriously good pie. Â Stephen from "Standing Outside Looking In" left a request in the comment sections of one of my posts. Â He said he would like the recipe for Dad's apple pie. Â So here it is.This is the pie crust recipe that my family has used for well over 60 years. Â Maybe longer. Â It is the one I used when Mom first taught me how to make a pie and it is the one I still use.Crust:3 cups flour1 tsp. salt1 cup lard1 egg, slightly beaten1 Tbsp. vinegar3 Tbsp. waterStir the salt into the flour. Â Cut in the lard until the mixture resembles coarse cornmeal. Â Combine the egg, vinegar and water and stir into the flour mixture. Â Makes enough for 2 two-crust pies.Dad's Apple Pie:6-7 tart apples (Dad just kept peeling and slicing apples until he had enough to fill a pie pan to nearly overflowing. Â Don't skimp on the apples.)3/4 - 1 cup sugar2 Tbsp. flour1 tsp. cinnamondash nutmegdash saltStir the above ingredients to combine. Â Pour over apples and stir just to coat them. Â Fill a pie pan that holds the bottom crust.Dot the apples with about 2 Tbsp. butter and add the top crust, cut vents and sprinkle with a little sugar.Bake at 375 degrees for 50 - 60 minutes. It took me a while to find the recipe. Â It was in my parent's old recipe box, and you don't just find a recipe quickly in there. Â You have to wade through handwritten recipe cards and typewritten recipe cards. Â Recipes were jotted down on the backs of envelopes, on pieces of folded notebook paper or just on scraps of whatever paper was handy at the time. Â There are pieces of plastic cut from coconut or chocolate chip bags, and one from a Butterball Turkey bag. Â Then there are the newspaper clippings. Â Lots of those. Â It is a time capsule of sorts. Â One of the envelopes was dated 1973 and another sometime in the 1960's.It is sort of like looking at old photos of family and friends. Â There is a recipe for something called a Campari Sandwich that I remember a neighbor girl making for a 4-H demonstration. Â There is one for Christmas date cookies written by my Aunt Etta who departed this earth years ago. Â There are several recipes from my Aunt Em, Mom's sister. Â Everything she made was oh, so good. There is one recipe that Dad would never show me. Â He said I could have it after he died, because he had given his word that he wouldn't share it with anyone. Â That was a donut recipe using a donut maker. Â Dad was a grain sampler, which means that he spent his days climbing into boxcars at the railroad yard and taking samples of wheat, oats and barley to be tested. Â He would go for coffee with the other fellows on his crew to the local donut shop, where he pestered the owner for her recipe - for years. Â She finally gave it to him the day she closed up shop and retired.One day when I am feeling ambitious, I need to type up all the recipes so I can find the one I need without going on a treasure hunt. Â But I intend to leave the recipe box just as it is. Â It just wouldn't be right if it was all neat and tidy. Â The jumble is half the fun.Chocolate chip cookies are good for breakfast, right? Â I mean, they contain eggs and grain, just like pancakes. Â And I dunked them in a glass of milk, so there was dairy involved. Â And I washed them down with a cup of coffee, just like any other breakfast. Â So it should be OK to have three chocolate chip cookies for breakfast, right?I thought so.

title: Confession
text: I have a confession to make. Â My name is Vicki and I am a list maker. Â I hang my head in shame.OK. Â Ignore the hanging head part. Â I have always been prone to making lists, but in my defense, it has been because I have never had a really good, razor sharp memory. Â Which has probably kept me from being a world class liar. Â I would have too hard a time remembering which lie I told to which person. Â The truth, now that I can remember.But I digress. Â I started thinking about list making this morning as I was busy writing yet another list. Â Some of the bloggers I read have been talking about perusing seed catalogs and making their seed order lists. Â I can't do that. Â I used to, when I lived further north and had a huge garden every year. Â Love those seed catalogs. Â But now I live surrounded by concrete and asphalt. Â Tomatoes and potatoes and carrots just don't grow well here in my parking lot. Â So I look to the Farmer's Markets. A couple of weeks ago I took stock of my shelves of home canned goodies. Â Made a list (yeah, I know) of what was left and what I would need to replace. Â Did the same with my shelf full of dehydrated foods. Â Using those lists as a guide, I figured out what I would need to buy at the Market this year. Â Number One Son does Farmer's Market runs for me. Â I'm kind of scared to show him my list for this year. Â It is sort of lengthy. Â Which translates into heavy boxes and bags of stuff that will need to be hauled up the stairs to my apartment. Â So do I show him my list now so he has time to work out and build up his muscles for all of that heavy lifting, or do I wait until it is too late for him to back out.I think there is something in the air. Â And not a good something. Â I am not the only one who is ramping up the preps. Â I see it on the blogs I read. Â I see it in the comments to those blogs. Â I read the alternative news sources and even once in a while on main stream news, where this uneasy feeling is being spoken of more often. Â It isn't panic. Â It is more like folks are feeling that whatever they need to do to take care of themselves, they had better not put it off any longer. So I make my lists. Â And each time I can check something off those lists as done, it makes my future look a bit better. Â Maybe being a confessed list maker isn't such a terrible thing after all.

title: First Loaf of Bread
text: So this morning I check my email and find pictures. Â I love it when I find pictures.Last evening my son and his family made their first loaf of bread. Â David remembered watching me knead bread when he was a kid, but just to refresh his memory, he found a YouTube video on kneading bread. Â Isn't YouTube wonderful. Â There is almost nothing you can't learn how to do just by searching for videos on the subject. Â Anyway, Boston, the oldest, Â was in charge of the kneading.After the dough rose once in a bowl, they made it into a loaf and put it in the pan to rise.Now comes the bad part. Â The bread took longer to rise than they anticipated. Â It was a school night. Â The kids get up early in the morning. Â So they had to go to bed before the bread was baked. Â But isn't this a lovely loaf of homemade bread? Â Yes it is!I'm just so proud of them. Â And it is good that they have learned a new skill that can help them feed themselves should the need arise. Or just to know how to make a treat of a loaf of homemade bread. Â With lots of butter. Â And homemade strawberry jam.Drat. Â Now I'm hungry.

title: Never, Ever Make Plans
text: I had planned to hop on the bus and ride it to the grocery store today. Â After what seems like weeks of damnitscold weather, the prediction was for a balmy 27 degrees today. Â That is on the plus side of zero - not the minus side. Â I even thought about treating myself to a small bag of chocolate stars from the bulk candy section, and getting a couple of the ingredients I need to make the pooches a batch of the peanut butter treats they love so much. Â And then Fate stepped in and said, "I don't think so."Anyone who reads this blog is probably aware that a short while ago I spent time whining about the lack of heat in my apartment and voicing my opinions about the furnace guy from Hell. Â I was thrilled when heat started to flow from the vents and my toes thawed out. Â Well, over the weekend I noticed that something was amiss. Â Even with the temperatures in the sub-zero range and the howling wind, my apartment kept getting warmer.....and warmer.....and warmer. Â I can't regulate the temperature. Â My landlord sets it and controls it. Â But it is set at a comfortable setting. Â Except that now it doesn't want to shut down. Â When it reached 77 degrees I started opening windows.Anyway, enter the furnace guy from Hell. Â Right away this morning he is slogging through my apartment, checking the vents, looking at the thermostat and scratching his head. Â Because I am not fond of the idea of strangers traipsing in and out while I am gone, I decided to spend the day getting caught up on fun stuff like laundry, trash hauling and floor scrubbing. Â Scratch the chocolate stars, at least for today. Â I will go to the store tomorrow.Or maybe not. Â Oldest son calls me a couple of times a week. Â He says he just calls to see what I am doing, but I know he is calling to check up on me to make sure that I am OK. Â I am grateful that he does. Â Anyway, he says that there is a winter storm headed our way tomorrow. Â Then, as soon as I hang up the phone, it rings again and it is youngest son. Â He didn't get around to the bread baking with his kids until this evening, and he has questions. Â I tell him what he needs to know about the process, and he then says that he just received a weather alert. Â Part of the duties of his job have to do with managing the snow removal crews, hence the weather alert. Â Seems the aforementioned winter storm is supposed to drop 3 to 6 inches of snow on us by noon tomorrow.I think I will stop trying to plan anything in advance. Â The gods of winter have a mean streak. Â If I plan a day out, they drop the temp down into the freeze my keister off range or they dump snow on me. Â Maybe in April...........

title: Coffee is the Elixir of Life
text: I didn't used to drink much coffee. Â Just a cup now and then to be polite. Â But in recent years, I find myself brewing a pot of coffee first thing in the morning, right after I feed my dogs and cat. Â I prefer coffee over tea or soda. Â I have never tried those "high energy" drinks that the commercials say will make me more alert and probably smarter, and if I don't use them, I will most assuredly fall asleep in my tracks about two o'clock in the afternoon. Â No thank you. Â I'll stick with coffee.So my coffee stash is getting a bit low. Â Time to fill the shelf. Â I am not a coffee snob. Â I don't need flavored gourmet coffee. Â (Although, youngest son gave me some hazelnut and some chocolate flavored coffee that was awesome!) If it looks like coffee and smells like coffee and isn't bitter, it's all good.I could go to my local grocery and buy coffee. Â They have a large selection and a large price. Â Dollar store coffee works just fine. Â And it is on sale this week. Â Six cans of the stuff will reside on my shelf tomorrow. Â (After the temps warm up enough for me to stick my nose out!) Â And as that won't leave a gaping hole in my budget, I probably will add another six cans the next time it goes on sale. Â It is good to have rice and beans and all the other staples in food storage, but I firmly believe that in times of trouble, a person also needs some of the familiar comfort items, and coffee fills that bill for me. Â (That and a goodly supply of chocolate.)I don't need to spend a ton of money on fancy coffee makers, either. Â Years ago my Dad gave me this one.I don't know what the real name of this style of coffee pot is, but he always called it a "drip-o-lator." Â I wonder if that is even a word. Â This coffee pot has been around at least as long as I have been, and that is a long time. Â We are both showing our age. Â I think my parents got it when they were first married in 1945. Â Over the years I have had a series of Mr. Coffee type electric coffee makers. Â And one by one, each has died. Â This silly coffee pot will probably out last me. Â And it makes better coffee than the fancy electric ones with their clocks and timers and buttons and digital numbers that always flash "12:00" because I can't seem to program them correctly.So now, if you will excuse me, my cup is empty and that is not a good thing.

title: Winter Day Ramblings
text: French toast made with Grandmother Bread, topped with butter and homemade plum jam. Â Bacon on the side. Â A cup of fresh brewed coffee. Â Two dogs of the ankle-biting variety cruising my kitchen in hopes of a piece of bacon coming their way. Â Fat Cat stretched out on top of the chest freezer, patiently waiting to supervise whatever action is happening in the kitchen today. Â Life doesn't get much better than this.I know I said that I wasn't going to talk about the weather any more, but damn! Â It is 10:30 AM and it is still minus 14 degrees outside, with a wind chill of minus 37 degrees. Â Here in town we don't have the white-out conditions of blowing and drifting snow like they do on the open prairie. Â I live in an old building with walls that are maybe 8 inches thick. Â I can still hear the wind howling down the alleys and around the corners. Â City Hall is right across the street. Â The flag on top of that building isn't waving like flags in the wind usually do. Â It appears stiff as a board.You know those dust devils that you see in the summertime? Â Where the wind picks up dust from the fields and swirls it around like mini tornadoes. Â I look out my window and watch snow devils dancing across the roof of the building next to City Hall. Â It looks like the building could be on fire, but it is not. Â Warm air escaping from doors and windows freezes immediately and looks like plumes of smoke. Â I am glad my building has thick walls and lots of insulation.Even with the cold and wind, my apartment stays toasty. Â And I am ever so glad that I spent all of those hours canning food last summer and fall, for I want for nothing. Â The only thing I have run out of that I can't make for myself is yarn. Â I am working on a couple of afghans and I used up the last of the colors of yarn for those projects. Â But that can wait until the temperatures get above the zero mark again. Â I still have lots to keep me busy.I hear other retirees complain about being bored. Â I am never bored. Â I seem to never have lost my yearning for learning. Â When a subject catches my interest, I can spend hours in online research. Â Last week I learned how to make some types of cheese from the powdered milk I keep in stock. Â Before that I found all sorts of information on healing herbs and how to use them. Â This week I am looking for tutorials on how to crochet scarves and mittens, to use up the leftover yarn from the afghan projects. Â And after that I want to find recipes to make things like my own taco seasoning or pumpkin pie spice or other combination seasonings I can make from the basic seasonings I keep on the shelf. Â And as a bonus, I stumbled across a YouTube channel with a bucket load of hour long Sherlock Holmes mysteries. Â Yippie Ki-Yay! Â I can watch those in the evening while I crochet or sew. Â There is always something. Â How can a person ever be bored?And now I think I have rambled on enough - or too much - depending on your point of view! Â On to the little dab of housework that awaits my attention, and then the fun stuff. Â Even with the cold and wind, my life here in the frozen north is pretty darned good. Â Oh, I still get worked up over the insanities in the world around me. Our government officials in particular tend to tick me off. Â Even though I never forget the threats to our freedoms and the threats to our way of life that we cherish and I continue to prepare, I choose to enjoy my life as much as possible. Â Those words, "Life, Liberty and the Pursuit of Happiness" are as true today as they were when written. Â And I believe in them.

title: A Good Bread Baking Day
text: While the wind blows and the snow swirls around, everything is toasty warm here in my little corner of the world. Â I just got off the phone with youngest son who is out helping his crews move snow. Â He asked what I was doing today and I replied that it was a good day to bake bread. Â He said that he would be home in a couple of hours and would like his kids to learn to bake bread, but that he had never tried that skill. Â He remembered watching me knead bread when he was a kid. Â He wanted to know if I had a good recipe. Â Because my email has been a bit wonky lately, I told him that I would post the recipe here. Â Perhaps someone else will find it useful, too.This is the recipe that I use most often. Â It makes a good tasting loaf and requires only basic ingredients. Â I got the recipe from Suzanne McMinn's blog, "Chickens in the Road," and have included her instructions, word for word."Grandmother BreadSubmitted by: Suzanne McMinnDeliciously simple and simply delicious, Grandmother Bread is a daily staple in our farmhouse. This is a heritage recipe, tested by time and the hands of mothers and grandmothers for over a hundred years. This secret family recipe is different from many standard white bread recipes in that it contains no milk, egg, or oil, and its very simplicity produces a bread of light but sturdy texture that yields loaves for perfectly sliced sandwich bread (the best sandwich bread youâ€™ll ever taste! also makes excellent french toast!), plus the same dough can be used to create dinner rolls, cinnamon-swirl loaves, sweet rolls, crispies, and apple-strudel ladder loaf.Once youâ€™ve grasped the concept of the standard Grandmother Bread recipe, you can create variations of your ownâ€“the possibilities are limitless!Two-loaf standard recipe3 cups warm water1 tablespoon yeast (1 packet)1 teaspoon salt1/4 cup sugar7 cups all-purpose flourOne-loaf standard recipe1 1/2 cups warm water1 teaspoon yeast1/2 teaspoon salt2 tablespoons sugar3 1/2 cups flourSee step by step instructions on How to Make Bread:In a large bowl, combine water, yeast, sugar, and salt. Let sit five minutes.Stir in first three cups of flour with a heavy spoon. Add the next cup of flour a little at a time as needed, stirring until dough becomes too stiff to continue stirring easily. Add a little more flour and begin kneading. The amount of flour is approximateâ€“your mileage may vary! Continue adding flour and kneading until the dough is smooth and elastic.Let dough rise in a greased, covered bowl until doubled. (Usually, about an hour.) Uncover bowl; sprinkle in a little more flour and knead again before dividing in half. With floured hands, shape dough into loaves and place in two greased loaf pans. Tear off two pieces of waxed paper and grease with oil spray (to prevent it from sticking to the loaves as they rise) and cover loaf pans. Let rise till loaves are tall and beautiful! (About an hour, depending on the temperature in your kitchen.)Bake for 25 minutes in a preheated 350-degree oven."The only thing I don't do is use the waxed paper to cover the loaves while they raise. Â A clean dish towel works fine for me. Â And I will add that when tapping on the loaf produces a hollow sound, the bread is done.It does my heart good to see skills like bread baking passed down from one generation to the next. Â I am grateful that my mother taught me as it is a skill that I use every week. Â Today I can make my own bread and I don't have to brave the cold and the wind just to go to a store for a loaf. Â And it just tastes so good.To my grandkids - let me know how your bread turns out. Â I know it will be good. Â Make sure Mom and Dad give each of you a slice with lots of butter while it is still warm. Â And have fun!Love, Grandma

title: Yes, It Did Freeze Over
text: It is January. Â It is Minnesota. Â It's not like this is anything new. Â So that is the last I am going to say about the cold. Â It is time to think Spring.Ah, yes. Â Much better!So this morning, I'm a happy camper. Â There is this big yellow ball in the eastern sky. Â Haven't seen it for a while. Â Sunlight is streaming through my living room windows. Â The cat has positioned herself to take full advantage of a sunbeam. Â Even the dogs seem more energetic. Â Lily has gathered half a dozen small tennis balls, waiting for me to toss them. Â She won't bring them back to me, but she loves chasing them, and that is enough. Â Jesse Jane, "she of little energy and big appetite," is cruising the kitchen, waiting for me to cook or bake something, and possibly drop some tidbit on the floor for her to snag.Then I check the latest weather report."Minnesota Issues Blizzard Warning."Here in the Frozen North, it doesn't have to be snowing to create a blizzard. Â It is enough that an inch or two of fluffy cold white stuff fell yesterday. Â The winds are picking up and will blow the snow around later today. Â And temps will again drop from a few degrees above zero back down to -15.Sigh.

title: There Comes a Time
text: In my travels through the Internet, I happened upon the following quote from Martin Luther King, Jr. Â I realize that he was talking about the fight for Civil Rights for black Americans, but I think it applies just as well today.â€œYou know, my friends, there comes a time when people get tired of being trampled by the iron feet of oppression. There comes a time, my friends, when people get tired of being plunged across the abyss of humiliation, where they experience the bleakness of nagging despair. There comes a time when people get tired of being pushed out of the glittering sunlight of life's July and left standing amid the piercing chill of an alpine November. There comes a time.â€- Martin Luther King, Jr.I have to wonder, when will the time come when we as American citizens will get tired of the insanity coming from Washington. Â How many more intrusions into our personal lives will we put up with? Â How many more of our God given rights do we have to watch disappear? Â What, exactly, has to happen before we say, "Enough."

title: Puttering
text: The cold snap that was forecast is upon us. Â This morning started out at 20 degrees and by supper time the temperature had fallen to 6 degrees. Â As my joints are still protesting, I spent my day puttering. I cleaned out the drawers in my desk. Â It is amazing the stuff I found...stuff that I dropped into a drawer thinking I would find a home for it later but never did. Â Does any sane person really need that many pens and pencils? Â I doubt it! Â I think I found enough of them to last the rest of my natural life. Â And I found a bunch of other stuff that I had totally forgotten I had. Â It was sort of like a treasure hunt without any treasure of real value. Â Truth be told, it was more like an archaeological dig through a trash heap.I sorted through some old photos and genealogy notes that had accumulated but hadn't as yet been filed or entered into my genealogy program. Â I love reading the old letters and stories that I have collected over the years. Â They give me a peek into what life was like in the late 1800's and early 1900's. Â One told about a pair of boots that were made at home, using wooden pegs to attach the soles. Â When one child outgrew the boots, they were passed on to the next in line. Â They were so well made that they went through half a dozen kids and never did completely wear out.Last fall when I turned 50 lbs of cranberries into juice and canned it, I had a quantity of what I call cranberry sludge left over from the process. Â It is the skins and pulp that were left from straining the juice. Â As I hate to waste anything, I had bagged it all up and tossed it into my freezer. Â Last evening I got the bags out and laid them out to thaw. Â Today I spread the sludge out on the fruit roll-up sheets for my dehydrators and dried it. Â When it was crispy, I broke it up into small pieces and put it into quart jars. Â Later I will run small batches of it through my little grinder and use the powder to flavor baked goods or mix with dried apple peels for a really good tea.It has taken me a lot of years to own up to my limitations. Â Not all that long ago I would probably have been ranting and raving because I am sidelined for a time. Â And would have been irritated because I can't do what I would like. Â I guess that sometimes a person just has to accept what is. Â And spend a day or two just puttering. Â Actually, it was kind of fun.

title: The Best Laid Plans...
text: I just should have known better than to make plans. Â I woke up this Â morning with more creaking bones than is normal for me. Â Within an hour or so my lower back had given up the fight and said to me, "Just go find someplace warm and comfy. Â And dig out that heating pad. Â You're gonna need it."I checked our local weather forecast and sure enough. Â Another cold front is headed our way. Â Not as severe as the last one, but enough to send temperatures into the sub-zero range by tomorrow evening. Â Maybe I should rent out my arthritic joints to the weather service. Â My predictions, based on my joints, are usually more accurate than the professionals predictions.I am beginning to better understand the advice my Dad gave me. Â On the occasion of his 90th birthday he said to me, "Sis, if you get the chance to live to be 90, don't do it!" Â By that time Dad had gone from a strong, vibrant man to one who was unsteady on his legs and who, within another year or so, found it necessary to live in the nursing home. I have to say this for Dad. Â He never lost his sense of humor. Â When he still lived in his own home and I lived a couple of hundred miles away, he would make sure during our phone conversations that I knew about the apple pie cooling on his counter. Â He knew how much I loved his apple pie. Â For years I tried to get him to mail me a piece and for years he would tell me that he would, but he just couldn't fit it into the envelope. Â Even after leaving his own home, he kept his sense of humor, joking with the nurses and aides and teasing with his older sister who lived in the same nursing home.So I think I will ignore Dad's advice and strive for that 90 year mark. Â But I will follow his example and keep my sense of humor that has to laugh at the absurdities of the Universe tossing a monkey wrench into my best laid plans. Â After all, it's not like I have a schedule. Â If I get out to play this week or next week isn't important. Â What is important is that I woke up this morning. Â Even with aches and pains, I still woke up. Â The stairs in my building may be a temporary problem, but I can still get around well enough to put a pot of soup on to simmer and bake a loaf of bread. Â And a pan of brownies may be just the thing.Never give up. Â And keep on smiling. Â And chocolate makes everything better!

title: Winter Doldrums
text: dolÂ·drums, noun plural1: a state or period of sadness or depression2: a state or period in which there is no activity or improvementI am not sad nor am I depressed. Â So I think the second definition probably applies.Since the first of the year I have had little ambition. Â I don't know why. Â I chalk it up to winter with its short, cloudy days and long, cold nights. Â I find myself spending more time with my cup of coffee and my books than I usually do. Â Daily chores that I zip through at other times of the year seem to take considerably longer now. Â If they get done at all. Â Procrastination is the watchword of the day.So last evening I was thinking about this blah feeling that has come over me, and decided that it was high time to do something about it. Â I acknowledged the fact that there is no fairy godmother waiting in the wings to wave her magic wand and fix everything. Â I have no pumpkins to turn into coaches and no glass slippers. Â If anything is going to be changed, it will be changed by me.I tend to procrastinate doing my laundry more than anything else. Â My building has two washers and two dryers in the basement. Â Both of the washers are merrily washing away with another two loads waiting to go. Â My refrigerator is sparkling clean and devoid of all leftovers that resembled science experiments gone bad. Â My "To Do" list has several more tasks to be checked off over the weekend. Â And after that, come Monday morning, I have a Plan.The plan includes some play time. Â Yes, even 67 year old grandmas need serious play time now and then. Â And no, my play time has nothing to do with a night on the town or a visit to the local watering holes. Â I don't drink alcohol any more, (Not that I wouldn't like to - I just can't.) so those activities are not on the agenda.My play time includes things like a meal out at my favorite Chinese restaurant. Â And a trip to the yarn store for the yarn to finish two afghans I am working on. Â And a trip to the Goodwill store just because I like to poke about in thrift shops. Â And a trip to the craft store for the scrapbooking supplies I need to complete some photo albums I am working on.For someone who is not fond of shopping, my Plan seems to include too many stores, but I figure that the supplies I get will keep me busy and happily crocheting and crafting until spring.There. Â I feel better already!

title: He is 6 Today!
text: He never walks when he can run. Â The training wheels are off of his bike and he rides like the wind. Â He is a superhero with a blanket for a cape. Â He runs to me with a twinkle in his eye and a grin and gives me bear hugs. Â He is funny and smart and loving, all rolled up in an all boy package. Â He is my youngest grandson and I love him to pieces.Happy Birthday, Jacob!

title: Final Ice Fishing Post
text: Youngest Son posted this morning that in spite of a temperature of -36 degrees, his fishing trip was a success.And then he posted this.....with the following comment."Brrrrrrrrnickle!"

title: The Perils of Ice Fishing
text: When my son goes ice fishing in the winter, he often posts photos on Facebook.The ice road leading out to the fish house yesterday.Sunset on Upper Red Lake.The ice road this morning. Â It was snowing lightly with a pretty strong wind.And then there was this:"I have successfully fished my truck keys from the bottom of Upper Red Lake!"The keys were found through this hole in the ice.I can't wait to hear the story he has to tell about that one!Years ago there was a local weatherman who, when the temperatures dropped to well below zero, would warn his audience that they should bring their brass monkeys indoors out of the cold. Â Now if you live in a warmer climate, you may not have heard that brass monkeys are in peril of having certain parts of their anatomy frozen off. Â Well, here in Minnesota that threat is a real possibility the next few days.Youngest Son is ice fishing in northern Minnesota. Â He posted a picture of the temperature reading on the lake where he and a friend are fishing. Â It read -33 degrees. Â Good thing they have a heated ice fishing house. Â Me, I'll wait until the lakes here are in liquid form rather than solid.According the the guesses of our local forecasters, temperatures are supposed to stay bitterly cold for the next three or four days. Â They say that by Monday we should see a daytime high of -17 degrees. Â I am happier if I don't know how cold it will be at night.Global warming? Â Humph!

title: Ham and Beans
text: So yesterday morning my phone rings. Â It is Youngest Son, wanting to know if I will be home a little later. Â Seems he has this left-over ham bone. Â He doesn't want to toss it, for he doesn't like waste. Â He knows Mom will make good use of it.The beans soaked overnight. Â Tossed a handful of dehydrated carrots in with them along with a couple handfuls of dehydrated onion. Â They are simmering, along with the ham bone, on the back burner. Â Lots of meat left on that bone, so later I will remove the bone, leaving chunks of ham in with the beans. Â And simmer some more.I'm nearly out of bread, so after a while I will bake a couple of loaves and have some with my supper of ham and beans. Â I'd say that is a pretty good way to start off the New Year.

title: A Bit Nippy
text: 8 AM finds the temperature here in Minnesota at -10 degrees, up from the -18 degrees reported by Youngest Son earlier this morning.Fresh brewed cup of coffee - check.A good mystery novel - check.Snuggling down under my new green fuzzy blanket (Thanks David, Staci and kids!) - check.I think a pot of chicken vegetable soup and cornbread is on the supper menu.Works for me.

title: My Version of Turkey Day
text: Yesterday I cooked the three turkeys that Number One Son had brought me a while back. Â Before de-boning, they together weighed a little over 42 pounds, which translated into 22 pints of turkey.My family refers to Number One Son as "Mom's Enabler," due to the fact that he is the one who brings me Farmer's Market produce and meat on sale from the grocery, all to can or dehydrate. Â Well, he did it again. Â He brought me a new pressure canner. Â The one I have been using holds 8 pints. Â The new one holds 16 pints. Â Both are merrily cooking away as I write.Many times I have worked far into the night canning 8 pints of meat at a time. Â Meat in pint jars require an hour and 15 minutes of pressure time, plus 45 minutes of heating up time and another half hour to 45 minutes of cool down time. Â It is such a treat to be able to can all 22 pints at once. Â I still have my biggest stock pot full of turkey broth to can, but I should be able to finish all of it by supper time, as opposed to the wee hours of the morning as I have done in the past.So thank you, my enabler son. Â My life has suddenly become easier.

title: Gentle Snowfall
text: I glanced out my window a little while ago and saw huge snowflakes drifting down. Â It is beautiful to watch, even in the city. Â Driving in it - not so much. Â Looking at the weather map, it doesn't look like it will amount to much.Those flakes floating down reminded me of days building snowmen with my young children, of snow forts built by those same kids and of snowball fights. Â And of days I lived among the tall pines where a walk through the woods during a snowfall such as this was like walking through a fairy land. Â And of crisp, cold nights where the light of a full moon made the snow sparkle like diamonds. Â And of the taste of hot cocoa made from real milk with marshmallows floating on top that was so good after an afternoon of playing in the snow.It is amazing to me what memories can be triggered just by the falling of a few large flakes of snow.

title: The Best Presents
text: Christmas presents are nice. Â I like them as much as the next person. Â But I received two presents this year that are the best of all.The first was when each of my grandchildren were genuinely happy to see me and showed me with hugs. Â Lots of them. Â You know how sometimes a kid needs to be prompted to hug a relative? Â None of that here. The second was being surrounded by my children and grandchildren. Â Sometimes, what with busy schedules, we as a family have a hard time accomplishing this feat. Â So when we all can get together at the same place and at the same time, it is a special treat for me.I enjoyed every second of it. Â Thank you, my family, for such a lovely day.Love, Mom / Grandma

title: After it Snows...
text: in my neck of the woods, there arrives on the scene a small army of Bobcats, large front end loaders and dump trucks. Â The Bobcats scurry about pushing snow from curbs into the middle of the street. Â The front end loaders scoop up the snow and deposit it into the dump trucks. Â The dump trucks haul it away to a vacant lot to await the spring thaw. Â In addition to the sounds of engines and buckets scraping on the street, there is the "beep-beep-beep" whenever a piece of equipment reverses direction. Â All of this activity takes place in the wee hours of the morning.In the world of Lily the Yorkie, that little 9 lb. bundle of Energizer Bunny on steroids,each and every scrape and beep is a direct threat. Â It is not a threat to the person who takes care of her and pets her and feeds her. Â Nope. Â She could care less if the big bad beeping machines drive up the stairs and through the door of our apartment to haul me away. Â Not a problem.Those big bad noisy machines are going to come in and empty her food dish. Â The only solution to this horror is to bark like mad and scare them away.At 3:45 AM.So after I got out of bed to quiet her down, I sat back and watched her for a while. Â Lily has a little doggie bed that she loves. Â The bed has a couple of pieces of old blanket in it. Â Lily likes to sleep with her nose buried in the blanket. Â This morning she pawed at the blanket until a corner of her bed was clear. Â Then she went to her food dish, grabbed a mouth full of kibble, and deposited it in her bed. Â Repeat. Â Repeat. Â Repeat. Â When in her estimation she had enough, she covered the kibble with the blanket. Â All the while, fussing at the noisy machines in the street beneath my windows.Might as well put on a pot of coffee. Â I'm wide awake now. Â The noisy, beeping machines have moved on to the next street needing to be cleared. Â And Lily is fast asleep atop her pile of kibble.Lily is the most annoying, out of control, over the top, naughty dog I have ever had. Â And I just love her to pieces. Â She makes me laugh, even at 3:45 AM.

title: The Christmas Story
text: Every Christmas Eve, my Dad read the Christmas Story from the Bible. Â He and Mother wanted to be sure that we understood what Christmas was really all about. Â So this is for you, Dad. Â I love and miss both you and Mom. Â Thank you for teaching me the true meaning of Christmas.From Luke 2: 1-202:1 And it came to pass in those days, that there went out a decree from Caesar Augustus that all the world should be taxed.2:2 (And this taxing was first made when Cyrenius was governor of Syria.)2:3 And all went to be taxed, every one into his own city.2:4 And Joseph also went up from Galilee, out of the city of Nazareth, into Judea, unto the city of David, which is called Bethlehem; (because he was of the house and lineage of David:)2:5 To be taxed with Mary his espoused wife, being great with child.2:6 And so it was, that, while they were there, the days were accomplished that she should be delivered.2:7 And she brought forth her firstborn son, and wrapped him in swaddling clothes, and laid him in a manger; because there was no room for them in the inn.2:8 And there were in the same country shepherds abiding in the field, keeping watch over their flock by night.2:9 And, lo, the angel of the Lord came upon them, and the glory of the Lord shone round about them: and they were sore afraid.2:10 And the angel said unto them, Fear not: for, behold, I bring you good tidings of great joy, which shall be to all people.2:11 For unto you is born this day in the city of David a Saviour, which is Christ the Lord.2:12 And this shall be a sign unto you; Ye shall find the babe wrapped in swaddling clothes, lying in a manger.2:13 And suddenly there was with the angel a multitude of the heavenly host praising God, and saying,2:14 Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace, good will toward men.2:15 And it came to pass, as the angels were gone away from them into heaven, the shepherds said one to another,Let us now go even unto Bethlehem, and see this thing which is come to pass, which the Lord hath made known unto us.2:16 And they came with haste, and found Mary, and Joseph, and the babe lying in a manger.2:17 And when they had seen it, they made known abroad the saying which was told them concerning this child.2:18 And all they that heard it wondered at those things which were told them by the shepherds.2:19 But Mary kept all these things, and pondered them in her heart.2:20 And the shepherds returned, glorifying and praising God for all the things that they had heard and seen, as it was told unto them.From my cozy little Home Sweet Apartment to you:May you all have a truly blessed Christmas.

title: Words to Live By
text: "People are often unreasonable and self-centered. Â Forgive them anyway.If you are kind, people may accuse you of ulterior motives. Â Be kind anyway.If you are honest, people may cheat you. Â Be honest anyway.If you find happiness, people may be jealous. Â Be happy anyway.The good you do today may be forgotten tomorrow. Â Do good. Give the world the best you have and it may never be enough. Â Give your best anyway.For you see, in the end, it is between you and God. Â It was never between you and them anyway."--Mother Teresa of Calcutta

title: Canning Season Never Ends
text: So this past Sunday I am just sitting around, sort of being a slug, reading a murder mystery novel that I had downloaded from "Project Gutenberg." Â (Those mysteries from the late 1800's sure can be fun!) Â And my phone rings. Â It is Number One Son. Â He wants to know if I have any space in my freezer and I tell him that I do. Â Not more than a couple of minutes later he walks through my door with a box that is about 18 inches square and maybe 6 inches high. Â And three frozen turkeys.The place where my forklift driver son works manufactures a large variety of egg and potato foods, mostly for institutions or restaurants, although some are sold in stores. Â At Christmas time, the company hands out to the employees a variety of product. Â He said that he still had lots of food that he had received, but he knew that I would like what was in the box. Â Turns out the box was filled with frozen egg omelets with ham, onion and peppers. Â Son isn't fond of onions or peppers and I am, so this worked out well. Â I have tried a couple of them since, and they are good, especially with grated cheese on top. Â And plain, they make a great egg sandwich.Anyway, it seems that the store where he shops had the turkeys on sale for 58 cents a pound. Â When I tried to pay him for the turkeys, he just laughed at me. Â He says that after I get them canned, he will be taking a few jars home with him, and that if he buys the meat and I do the work of canning them, we both benefit. Â Makes sense.So as soon as I have enough empty pint jars again, I will be canning turkey. Â I have lots of quart jars now, so I think I will make some turkey broth to can as well. Â Broth is something I like to have in my pantry for soups or casseroles or chicken and biscuit dishes.And I thought canning season was about over. Â Not hardly!

title: We're Having a Heat Wave.....
text: The temperature in my little Home Sweet Home this morning is right where it should be. Â And as I have no desire to go outside and play in the snow, it looks like I can put away the long johns and wool socks. Â Although I am going to keep them handy and keep an eye on the temp for a few days just to be sure. Â It seems that the night before last when the furnace man put the outer covering back on the furnace, he accidentally knocked a wire loose, which shut down the heat to several apartments. Â But it is fixed. Â I am a happy apartment dweller again!Note to Jess: Â The problem was just what you said. Â The door in the duct that regulated heat to my apartment was not working right. Â I had passed that information on to my landlord, who, in turn, told the furnace guy and he either fixed or replaced it. Â So thank you for your help!It is really nice not to have to wear several layers of clothing inside. Â And even better, I can feel my toes again. Â Life is good.

title: Once Upon a Time...
text: there was a family who lived in the woods of northern Minnesota. Â Their old farmhouse was drafty and starting to crumble. Â This old house was heated with a potbellied wood stove in the kitchen area and a wood stove made from a barrel that sat in the basement. Â It was the spring of the year, and the melting snow was seeping through cracks in the basement wall, leaving a couple of inches of water all over the floor.While the mom in this family was wringing her hands and worrying about patching the basement walls when there was no money for said patching, her daughter reminded her that life wasn't all that bad.While sitting at the table next to the potbellied stove, the mom heard a flap, flap, flapping sound coming down the stairs from the bedrooms above. Â Slowly a pair of feet wearing swim fins appeared, followed by a bathing suit clad body. Â Finally the head became visible, complete with swim cap, nose plugs and a snorkel.This apparition then said, "Mom, could you go start a fire in the barrel stove? Â I've invited my friends over for a pool party and I want the water in the basement to be warm."After the mom picked herself up off the floor and Â wiped the tears of laughter from her eyes, she realized that most things can be made better with a good sense of humor.The mom seems to have forgotten that lately, and she is glad that this memory surfaced, for she needed to be reminded that the world will not end just because there is water in the basement.....or that the furnace doesn't work right. So yesterday the furnace man comes into my apartment. Â Yep, the same guy who was looking for heating ducts in the attic that doesn't exist. Â As he deposits black mud from his boots all over my kitchen floor and on the carpet in the other two rooms, (Where does he find this mud? Â The ground is covered with clean, white snow.) he proudly tells me that he has found the problem with the heating system and my living room should now be warm.This morning it is 58 degrees in here. Â That is a nice temperature if you are going for a walk along the river on a beautiful fall day. Â It is not a nice temperature for an apartment in the winter.I think I will go make another pot of hot coffee, turn on my oven, open the oven door and sit in front of it until my toes thaw out.I may have to flay someone before the day is out. Â And maybe borrow Number One Son's new hat!Grumble, dirty swear words, grumble some more!

title: The Hat
text: Number One Son hates winter. Â Well, it isn't so much the winter part, for the snow on the ground and the frost on the evergreen branches are beautiful. Â But he would be happy if he could have the beauty without the cold that goes with it.He usually wears a baseball cap. Â Or if it is really cold, a stocking cap. Â But this year the cold must really be getting to him, because he went out and bought the winter hat to end all hats. Â And it is a good thing that he has a well developed sense of humor, for he needs one to wear this hat!I like it!

title: Then and Now
text: As I was reading some of the news articles this morning from both mainstream and alternative news sources, I got to thinking how different our lives are today from those of my paternal grandparents. Â They homesteaded land in northern Minnesota in 1907. Â They first put up a log cabin and later built a larger house, a barn and a few smaller outbuildings. Â They raised nine children, all of whom grew into responsible adults. They didn't worry about their food being full of chemicals - they raised most of it themselves.They weren't concerned about meat being full of growth hormones and other chemicals, or about the animals being raised in the unhealthy environment of a factory farm. Â They raised their own beef cattle, milk cows, hogs and chickens. Â They butchered and processed their own meat animals and supplemented this with venison.They weren't terribly concerned with grocery prices for they traded milk, butter and eggs for the staples they couldn't raise themselves. Â They scoured the woods and fields for edibles like wild plums and blueberries to add to their diet.None of the nine children were ever involved in a Knockout Game. Â The very idea of hurting another person for no reason was abhorrent to them.Not one of their children took medication to control their behavior. Â Their behavior was controlled by their parents. Â Sometimes with a trip to the woodshed, if the offense was serious enough, and most times with extra chores to keep them too busy for mischief.Their education was not of the Common Core, government controlled variety, but of the basics that included reading, writing, math, and history. Â Most of the nine children went through eighth grade in the little one room schoolhouse a quarter mile from their home. Â The one their father helped to build. Â Three of the girls went on to high school in the largest town about 20 miles away, where they earned teaching certificates. Â All were able to use their education, along with common sense, to keep their families out of poverty.They never signed up for government welfare programs when they became available. Â It was considered a sign of laziness to expect someone else to take care of your family. Â They would have been shamed to do so.They didn't feel the need to provide entertainment for their offspring. Â These kids made their own fun. Â They went swimming in the lake near their farm. Â They went fishing in the river. Â In winter, they went sledding down the hill in the pasture or went ice skating on the frozen pond. Â Most of their toys were homemade. Â They made music and played games, both indoors on rainy days or outdoors on sunny ones. Â Their mother had a hard time getting them to come inside for supper as opposed to kicking them outdoors to get a little exercise, as many do today.They taught their children what was important. Â Good manners. Â Respect for others. Â Love for and duty to family. Â Right from wrong. Â A belief in God and the teachings of the Bible. Â A work ethic second to none.These people weren't perfect. Â Not by a long shot. Â They messed up from time to time as we all do. Â But they had a foundation for their lives that was solid and strong, so when things did not go well and they knew that they had strayed from what they had been taught, they got themselves back on track. Â By their own bootstraps.I understand that times have changed since my parents were young. Â One can no longer trade for grocery staples. Â Raw milk has been outlawed, for the most part, gardens are not allowed in some cities, and God forbid that a person should live, work or raise a family without being told how by politicians. Â The government seems determined to control all parts of our lives that they don't already. Â So I am aware of the sad fact that the way of life that I long for is gone. Â Isn't it amazing that my grandparents were able to raise their family and live a life, not of wealth and privilege, but one that was good and had meaning,Â using the Bible as a how-to guide along with the lessons learned from their parents, and not by government regulations.Sometimes I am convinced that we could use a bit more of the woodshed and a whole lot less of the feel-good politically correct. Â And a bit of old-fashioned common sense thrown in for good measure wouldn't hurt, either.

title: Lid Test Results
text: I just finished checking the jars of meat that I canned yesterday to make sure they had properly sealed. Â I used equal numbers of the regular lids and Tattler lids. Â The results are:Regular lids = 2 failuresTattler lids = zero failuresMeat is the easiest product to can as far as prep work goes. Â Just cut into pieces, fill the jars, add lids and rings and process. Â Meat is also the one product that gives me the most problems with seal failure. Â I think that may be because during the canning process, the jars will vent out any air that is in them, and along with the air comes a bit of grease from the fat within the meat. Â Some of the grease gets trapped between the lid and the rim of the jar, causing the lid to fail to seal.I will check the jars in a week or so to make sure they stayed sealed. Â For now, I will be buying three or four boxes of the Tattler lids each time I go to the store, until I can save enough money to order a case or two. Â Eventually, I would like to have enough of these lids for most of my jars. Â And, boy howdy, that's a lot of jars! Â When I ran out of shelf space last summer, my youngest son picked up two heavy duty shelving units for me. Â Each is 6 ft. high, 4 ft. long and 2 ft. deep. Â And now those puppies are both nearly full.I know that this sounds like an awful lot of canned food for just one person. Â But home canned food will stay good in the jars for a very long time - years. Â And I use it almost daily, rotating it out. Â I figure that whatever I buy this year to can up is going to cost more next year. Â And then there are the times when my kids will go shopping in Mom's canned goods section! Â They know that they need to bring the empty jars back to be refilled. Â And they are pretty good about doing that.The Tattler lids lived up to my expectations. Â I love it when a plan comes together!

title: Tattler Lids
text: Woo Hoo! Â I discovered yesterday that my local Cub Foods grocery, the only grocery I can get to by bus other than WalMart, now carries Tattler canning lids. Â I bought one each of the large and small sizes. Â I have four pressure canner loads of meat to process today, so I am giving them a test run.I have heard about these reusable canning lids for quite some time, and most reports have been good. Â The only place to buy them, at least in my area, was online. Â I don't do plastic - cash only, so ordering online was not an option for me. Â My daughter tells me that many Cub Foods stores will order case lots for a customer if it is requested. Â So that may be an option. Â If the experiment works.Tattler lids are not cheap. Â But neither are the metal lids that I have used for years. Â I did the math, and found that just using the Tattler lids twice would pay for the metal lids to process the same number of jars. Â And the Tattler lids can be used many more times than that.Does it say "pathetic life" when I get excited about canning lids? Â Probably!

title: Patience...
text: is not one of my virtues, although I think I have gotten better with it over the years. Â When I was young, my Dad gave me a little sign that said, "God, grant me patience NOW!"My patience is being sorely tested at present. Â My smoke alarm is still disconnected. Â There is a second alarm in my bedroom and another right outside my apartment door, so I am not totally without that protection. Â The water issue was resolved the following day, but the furnace issue has not. Â My apartment is the only one in the building that is cold. Â The furnace man has been in and out several times, checking the thermostat and registers, but so far he hasn't found the cause of the problem.I can't complain too much, however. Â It is not like the electric was out and there was no heat at all. Â The temp hovers around the 61 degree mark, so I am not exactly freezing to death. Â I have warm clothes and heavy socks and I will survive just fine. Â I have enough empty canning jars now so that tomorrow I will can up some pork and beef that I froze for that purpose, along with the two venison roasts my son brought to me. Â That should keep things fairly warm most of the day. Â Sunday I will need to bake bread again, and although it takes longer to rise, the oven heat will help.Unfortunately for my Yorkies, I took them to the groomer about a month or so ago for their semi-annual haircuts, so they don't have the long fur they had before to keep them warm. Â They have been spending lots of time snuggled down in their blankets. Â I may have to break out their little turtleneck sweaters if it gets any colder in here. Â (Yes, I am one of those people who buys doggie sweaters. Â I hate to admit it, but there it is.)Sometimes a person just needs to moan and groan a bit. Â Doesn't do any good whatsoever, but it makes you feel a bit better. Â I know that all of this will be fixed as soon as possible. Â And being impatient about it will only make it worse. There are folks who are going through some horrible times (Mystic Mud) that make my problems look pretty tiny by comparison. Â I'm pretty sure that if you are of a mind to remember this family in your prayers, it would be a good thing.

title: Chippy is a Busy Boy
text: My grandkids are expected to do chores. Â I applaud my kids for teaching them responsibility. So it stands to reason that Chippy would do his share. Â His job this morning was cleaning the bathroom mirror.And when he has finished his chores, a rousing game of Candy Land is in order.Followed by kicking back and watching a movie.Heh, heh, heh.

title: No Water
text: I don't have room to store water barrels in my apartment, so I fill empty soda bottles and stash them wherever I can.....on a closet shelf, behind my couch, in a corner behind my TV stand and behind my bedroom door.One of my children was asking me about the bottles of water. Â I explained that any number of things could knock out my electricity - summer storms or winter blizzards, for example - and that this could affect my water supply. Â She mentioned that the town where she lives was once without electricity for several days, but they had water. Â The problem is that I don't know if the same would hold true in my town. Â Their water delivery systems may not be the same. Â I am responsible not only for myself, but also for the three furry buddies who live with me and we all need water.So this morning I went to make my coffee, turned on the tap at the kitchen sink only to find nothing but air coming from it. Â Same with the bathroom sink and tub. Â Nothing. Â Grabbed one of my water bottles and made my coffee. Â Simple as that.I have no idea what is causing this water problem. Â It may be that someone is working on the hot water heater in the basement. Â It could be something to do with the city water system. Â It is -6 degrees outside today, but I doubt that pipes have frozen. Â That has never happened in the 17 years I have lived here and during that time there have been much colder days. Â So for now, I will just wait and see what happens. Â If I don't have water in my apartment tomorrow, I will call the landlord and he will deal with it.The point of all of this is that even without water flowing from the taps, I am merely inconvenienced a little bit. Â I have enough water to last at least a couple of weeks and longer, if I am careful. Â I planned to do a couple of loads of laundry today, but it isn't going to matter that I don't. Â I have a plan in place to take care of everything that needs taking care of with the exception of a shower, and although I like my hot showers, I can manage just fine without.When we think about being prepared, we often think only about the food aspect of preparedness and sometimes forget how important water is. Â And if I didn't have water with which to make my coffee, well, life just wouldn't be worth living!

title: Chippy the Elf
text: My youngest son's family has the Elf on the Shelf. Â My Kindergarten aged grandson, Jacob, named the elf "Chippy." Â Every day my son posts a photo of Chippy on Facebook , showing where he is each morning when he returns from Santa Land.Chippy is a pretty inventive little guy. Â He was in the silverware drawer, in the butter keeper inside the refrigerator and this morning he was on the couch, wearing headphones and listening to Christmas music.But the best one so far was this one.When Jacob asked his Dad how Chippy got the lid back on, David replied, "Magic."When I talked with my son a couple of days ago, I told him that it was probably pretty pathetic that his mother, the grandmother of his children, had to check Facebook each morning, first thing, to find out where Chippy was that day. Â I also warned him that if he should get word that his mother was locked away in a rubber room, clad in a huggy jacket, it would probably be because her neighbors had heard her, laughing out loud, all by herself and figured she had finally gone off the deep end. Â And it would be all his fault! Â And Chippy's.

title: New Is Not Always Better
text: Every year my granddaughters sell various items to raise money for their dance classes. Â I always buy a couple of the fruit and cream cheese filled bread braids. Â They come frozen and I took one from my freezer early this afternoon and put it on a baking sheet to thaw and raise. Â My apartment was cool today, so it wasn't ready for the oven until after 10:30 this evening.Earlier this morning an installer came around to put in new smoke alarms throughout the building. Â The old alarm in my kitchen had never given me any trouble and worked just fine. Â But when I opened my oven door a little before 11:00 to check on the bread braid, the new alarm started wailing and yelling "Fire! Â Fire!" Â I shut the oven door and opened the window next to my stove, although there wasn't a whiff of smoke anywhere. Â I did everything I could think of to shut that alarm up. Â There are working folks living in my building who go to bed a lot earlier than I do. Â I had visions of irate, sleepy people lined up outside my door. Do you suppose that I could shut the darn thing off? Â Not a chance.I finally set up my little mini step ladder, climbed up and tore it from the ceiling. Â It must have a battery backup, for it continued to scream "Fire! Â Fire!" long after I stuffed it under the pillows on my bed.I poured a cup of coffee and sat down to wait for the bread braid to finish baking. Â And I started to giggle, thinking about how silly I must have looked, rushing about and trying to get the alarm to be quiet. Â Sort of like an old Laurel and Hardy movie.I have a good landlord, and when I see him this weekend and tell him about my smoke alarm adventure, he will more than likely smile. He also knows that I use my oven often, for I bake my own bread every week as well as other baked goods and I use it for many of my meals, so I know that he will find a solution.I have often joked that dinner is done when the smoke alarm goes off, but I didn't think it would be a reality. Â Sometimes the old thing that works should just be left alone.

title: Brrrrr
text: Temperature this morning sits at -5 degrees. Â Geez, I love Minnesota!My landlord is not going to be happy when I tell him that the new furnace for the building is not keeping up. Â I should not have to wear long johns in the house.We Minnesotans feel that it is our God-given right to complain about the weather. Â I mutter under my breath as I dig in my closet for a flannel shirt. Â I will mutter just as much in the summer when the heat and humidity both approach 95. Â We have two days the end of May and another two days in September when the weather is perfect. Â Other than that....not so much.I sure must love my kids and grandkids, for they are the only reason I am here.All things considered, that's a pretty good reason.

title: Supper
text: Pot of chicken soup simmering on the back burner all afternoon.Cubes of cheddar.Venison summer sausage made from the deer that youngest son shot.Thick slices of warm homemade bread slathered with butter.Fit for a queen.No pictures. Â Ate it all.

title: Warning!  Grandkid Photo Ahead!
text: Yep, these are my Grandkids. Â All six of them. Â  It isn't often that we can get them all together in one place, so I was really happy to get this photo from Thanksgiving.Grandmas get to brag. Â It says so in the bylaws.

title: Christmas Spirit or Lack Thereof
text: The Christmas Spirit is sort of passing me by at the moment. Â It may be that because shopping for useless stuff that nobody cares about isn't high on my list of priorities. Â Or perhaps that shopping for me involves several hours spent on a bus. Â I think mostly it is because of my disgust for the commercialism that has become Christmas.Christmas when I was a kid was a wondrous time of year. Â There was the tree that always filled the house with the scent of pine, except for that unfortunate year when Dad bought one of those silvery aluminum trees popular in the late 50's - the ones that looked like several rolls of aluminum foil had exploded! Â There was the smell of cookies and breads and pies baking. Â There was the careful placing of the nativity set that reminded us of why there was a holiday in the first place.There was the planning for Christmas Day when relatives would gather at our big old farmhouse. Â Mother, ever the perfectionist, planned down to the last detail. Â The good china was washed and dried and silver was polished. Â The good lace tablecloth was covering the dining room table, with a red cloth underneath to show through and look festive. Â Pine branches decorated every available space, adorned with ornaments and ribbon.There were hours spent in secret, making gifts for parents, grandparents, siblings, aunts, uncles and cousins. Â Sometimes we would buy Grandma a bottle of her favorite perfume, but more often the gifts were made with our own two hands. Â One year it was hand knitted slippers for everyone, and another it was some crafty thing that Mom had us make. Â Later in my life when cash was scarce , I would fill boxes with the home canned goodies I had made and give those.Oh, there were purchased gifts as well, but it seems as though those times of going to town to shop for Christmas were enjoyable as opposed to the frantic, hectic shopping of today. Â I guess we weren't trying to out-spend our neighbors. Â Big ticket items were not on the list. Â I remember saving my money for a box of monogrammed handkerchiefs for Dad to use in the pocket of his Sunday suit. Â Or finding the perfect fancy teacup and saucer to add to those Mom collected.Those shopping trips to town always included a drive around after dark to look at all of the beautiful Christmas lights decorating people's homes. Â Or walking up and down the streets admiring the Christmas scenes set up in store windows. Â There were the usual Santa and elves displays, but there were also scenes of the baby Jesus in the manger, with Mary, Joseph, shepherds and angels. Â Of course, this was long before anyone took offense to this depiction of Christmas.I guess I really am getting old, for I find that the memories of Christmas Past have much more appeal to me than Christmas Present. Â And I can complain about it until the cows come home and nothing will change. Â Unless I change it.I have been under the weather for the past three weeks, so little has been done here in the way of actual physical work. Â But I did spend time searching the Internet for ideas and patterns for homemade gifts. Â I didn't do a very good job of planning ahead for this Christmas, and there isn't time to put to use those ideas. Â But there is a long, cold winter in my near future here in Minnesota, and I can't think of a better way to spend it than in making things for those I love.Maybe my Christmas Spirit isn't dead after all. Â Maybe it has just been postponed for a bit.

title: Thanksgiving Thoughts
text: So I Â was sitting here today feeling a bit sorry for myself. Â The creeping crud that I have been dealing with this month has kept me home bound. Â I am feeling better than I did, but not well enough to go out. Â My children and grandchildren are together eating turkey and talking and laughing and I am here. Â Alone. Â Poor me.And then I got to thinking about all that I have to be thankful for.I have a roof over my head and I can still afford to pay rent on it. Â There is heat flowing out of the registers on my floors. Â I have a bed with clean sheets and quilts to keep me warm at night, a pantry full of food and an oven in which to bake my bread. Â I wonder how many are without those things today.I was blessed with four children who, with just a phone call, would be here and have been here in the past to help me if I need help. Â I work at being as independent as possible, but it is a comfort to me to know that if things go all wonky in my life, they have my back. Â I love them all, but I like them as well. Â They have grown into adults that make me proud to be their mother. Â Between them they have given me six grandchildren who are the lights of my life.I am thankful to have had parents who taught me so many things that have helped me over the years. Â Mother taught me the practical things - how to cook and preserve food, how to sew and how to do all the daily chores that need to be done. Â Dad instilled in me a work ethic second to none. Â He worked hard all of his life and I never once heard him complain. Â He also taught me the value of laughter, for if you can't laugh at yourself or the absurdities of the world around you, then life is nothing more than drudgery.My parents also raised me to have a strong faith in God. Â There have been times in my life that this didn't seem too important to me, but it seems that the older I become, the more important it is to me to remember the teachings of my youth. Â And more important, to do my best to live by them.I am thankful that I have reached a place in my life where I am relatively happy. Â That wasn't always so. Â I have been lucky to discover that my happiness lies within me and not with others. Â I can decide each morning whether I am going to spend my day being happy or grumpy. Â I vote, for the most part, for happy. Â Oh, I still rant about the injustices in our world and will probably continue to do so, for some things just need to be said. Â But that inner peace is what keeps me going, and I am thankful to God for it.So instead of wallowing in self pity, I have thawed out a chicken, stuffed it and it is roasting in my oven, filling my little apartment with delicious smells. Â A small casserole made with squash I canned this fall is ready for the oven. Â One of my daughters brought me a pail of ice cream a couple of days ago, and I will whip up a batch of chocolate sauce to go with it for dessert. Â And I will think about my children and grandchildren who are together today as a family, and be thankful that they consider family important.And I will wish you all a blessed Thanksgiving Day.

title: Black Friday
text: Black Friday has turned into Black Thanksgiving in my area, with more stores opening on Thanksgiving Day so crazed shoppers can fight each other for whatever electronic device is on sale. Â Some people have even pitched tents at the front doors of stores more than a week ago in order to be at the head of the line to spend money. There are a few retailers, however, who refuse to give in to this insanity. Â The article about it is here.Kudos to those stores who will not cave and will allow their employees to have the entire Thanksgiving Day to spend with their families. Â Those are the businesses that will receive my money throughout the year and not just on one insane, greed driven day.

title: Long Hair
text: When I was a young girl, I wished for long hair. Â Movie stars had long, luxurious, beautiful hair. Â Television ads for shampoo featured models with long hair that could obviously be gorgeous just by using the right hair products. Â Yep. Â That was for me.My mother didn't think so.In her younger years, Mother had a talent for cutting hair. Â The ladies in our neighborhood didn't go to a beauty shop but came to my mother for their haircuts. Â So it was natural that she would cut my hair. Â I think she just didn't have time to mess with a daughters' long, flowing tresses. Â Once, when I threw a hissy fit about home haircuts, whining that other girls didn't have haircuts given them by their mothers, she loaded me into the car, hauled me to town and I got a haircut. Â Not at a beauty shop, but at a barber. Â I came out looking sort of like Alfalfa from the Little Rascals.I'm not sure I ever forgave her, but I never again complained about a home haircut, and I expect that was the desired result.Out of habit, I suppose, I have kept my hair fairly short most of my life.I'm sort of a no-frills kind of gal. Â When a beautician asks me how I want my hair cut, my reply is usually, "Wash and Wear." Â I have no patience for fussing in front of a mirror to make sure every hair is in place. Â So about four years ago I decided to just let my hair grow. Â It is now about two inches above where my waist used to be. Â And I now realize that Mom knew what she was talking about. I know this because nearly every morning I spend time brushing rats nests out of my hair. Â I should braid it before going to bed at night to prevent this, but I can't seem to get the hang of it.I know this because if I don't tie my hair up before cooking, I wind up pulling long gray hairs from my food.I know this because I dragged the ends of my hair through the dishwater today, three times in as many minutes.And I especially know this because just the other day I had to untangle a cat from these long, flowing tresses. Â Cat still has claws on all four feet. Â It was not pretty.I will wait until spring and then off to the beautician I will go. Â I will ask for a Wash and Wear style. Â And I will donate these long, flowing tresses to "Locks of Love," an organization that makes wigs from donated hair for cancer patients .I wish for many reasons that my mother were still alive. Â But one of the best reasons is that she would get such a chuckle from hearing me tell her that she was, once again, right.We are totally without common sense.I just read an article that explains that peanut butter and jelly sandwiches are racist. Â You can read about it here.Really? Â Racist? Â Give me a break. Â Basically, the article states that the American tradition of PBJ sandwiches may offend those who do not eat sandwich bread because other cultures may eat different forms of bread such as pita. Â So a PBJ sandwich is racist because it is all about "white privilege," and Â schools should be sensitive to the customs of those students whose birthplace was not America.I have an idea. Â How about we teach American customs in American schools. Â And while we are at it, why don't we insist that people of other nationalities who chose to become American citizens learn our customs and traditions and language. Â I have nothing against those who come to our country seeking citizenship and a better life for themselves and their families. Â Had I found myself in their position, I would probably have done the same. Â  We all want a better life for our loved ones. Â But I am getting really tired of being told that I should consider American customs and traditions "racist."So now, if you will excuse me, I think I will go fix myself a PBJ sandwich. Â And I refuse to apologize for it.

title: Kicked My Butt
text: Whatever this is that I thought was just a head cold has really kicked my butt. Â I am not sick enough to stay in bed, but I will admit that for a few days, my idea of getting dressed was to put on a fuzzy robe over my nightshirt and call it good. Â I'm sort of getting caught up on the household chores that went by the wayside when I wasn't feeling all that perky, but it is a slow process and one that leaves me out of breath. Â My daughter told me that she had something similar that took her a month to get over. Â I have only two weeks invested in this crud, so I won't complain.My Yorkies seem delighted that I am not so busy as I usually am. Â I have spent a considerable amount of time in my recliner listening to music or audio books. Â They have spent a considerable amount of time on my lap. Â I am afraid I have created a couple of pint-sized monsters, for they now fuss at me from time to time until I sit down and give them pets and snuggles.I suppose I could have run to the doctor, but I tend to avoid clinics as much as possible. Â A few years ago I came down with something similar, spent the better part of a day being poked and prodded and X-Rayed and was given expensive prescriptions that did no more for me than my home remedies do. Â So I will keep in my own pocket the $75. I have to pay just to walk through the door of the clinic, the fees for poking and prodding and X-Raying and the steep price of prescriptions, and stay with the tried and true remedy of rest, aspirin for aches and pains, and my apple-cranberry tea laced with honey. Â Seems to be working.

title: A Doozey
text: I don't often get sick. Â Which is a good thing because I am probably one of the worst kind of patient. Â Good thing I live alone. Â Anyone living with me would more than likely want to suffocate me after two days. Â Grumpy takes on a whole new meaning when I am sick.So anyway, it seems as though I can't make the transition between fall and winter without catching a cold, and this year it is a doozey. Â I had a friend who had some medical training and he told me that it doesn't matter what you do, a cold takes 10 days to run its course. Â I am on day 4. I will return when I am all done coughing and hacking and sneezing and using up all the Kleenix in the house. Â I don't care what my friend said. Â I am making a big pot of chicken soup.Can't hurt.

title: Ho Ho Ho!
text: So I am shopping for a few groceries this morning, and instead of the usual elevator music in the background, I hear Christmas carols. Â I shouldn't have been surprised, considering the display of Christmas wreaths outside the main doors of the store. Â But give me a break. Â Halloween is only one week past and Thanksgiving is barely on the horizon. Â I mean, seriously? Â We are pushing Christmas shopping up to Halloween?
