Â Kind of makes me want to just hibernate until the New Year.So as long as I am going to have to endure being assaulted with Santas and mistletoe for two months, I thought I would share the following. Â I don't know where I found it. Â If it is yours, let me know and I will give you credit.Dashing through the SnowPlease be advised that all employees planning to dash through the snow in a one-horse open sleigh, going over the fields and laughing all the way are required to undergo a Risk Assessment addressing the safety of open sleighs.This assessment must also consider whether it is appropriate to use only one horse for such a venture, particularly where there are multiple passengers. Please note that permission must also be obtained in writing from landowners before their fields may be entered.To avoid offending those not participating in celebrations, we request that laughter is moderate only and not loud enough to be considered a noise nuisance. Benches, stools and orthopaedic chairs are now available for collection by any shepherds planning or required to watch their flocks at night.While provision has also been made for remote monitoring of flocks by CCTV cameras from a centrally heated shepherd observation hut, all facility users are reminded that an emergency response plan must be submitted to account for known risks to the flocks.The angel of the Lord is additionally reminded that prior to shining his/her glory all around s/he must confirm that all shepherds are wearing appropriate Personal Protective Equipment to account for the harmful effects of UVA, UVB and the overwhelming effects of Glory.Following last yearâ€™s well publicised case, everyone is advised that EU legislation prohibits any comment with regard to the redness of any part of Mr. R. Reindeer. Further to this, exclusion of Mr. R. Reindeer from reindeer games will be considered discriminatory and disciplinary action will be taken against those found guilty of this offence.While it is acknowledged that gift-bearing is commonly practised in various parts of the world, particularly the Orient, everyone is reminded that the bearing of gifts is subject to Hospitality Guidelines and all gifts must be registered. This applies regardless of the individual, even royal personages.It is particularly noted that direct gifts of currency or gold are specifically precluded under provisions of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. Further, caution is advised regarding other common gifts, such as aromatic resins that may initiate allergic reactions.Finally, in the recent case of the infant found tucked up in a manger without any crib for a bed, Social Services have been advised and will be arriving shortly.Happy Holidays,The Risk Management TeamJust for the record.....I refuse to utter the words, "Happy Holidays." Â It's Christmas, dammit. Â I don't get my knickers in a twist over all the ethnic holidays during the course of a year that have nothing to do with my ancestry. Â So if "Merry Christmas" is found to be offensive, that's just too bad.Bah, humbug!

title: Sauerkraut Taste Test
text: About three weeks ago I did a sauerkraut canning experiment. Â I needed an alternative to the old-time tried and true method of fermenting sauerkraut in a crock and then canning it. Â The recipe I used called for packing shredded cabbage in quart jars and adding a teaspoon each of canning salt and sugar to each jar and topping them off with boiling water. Â Then the lids and rings are put on the jars loosely and they are left undisturbed for three days. Â After that time any film that has developed on the sauerkraut is skimmed off, lids and rings are applied more tightly and the jars are run through a water bath canner for 20 minutes. Â The directions say to let the jars sit for three weeks before using.The three weeks is up. Â I opened a jar yesterday. Â I found that it tasted good, but much more mild than store bought sauerkraut. Â It doesn't have that pucker up quality of commercially canned sauerkraut.I buttered a casserole dish, drained the sauerkraut and dumped it in. Â Then I topped it off with a pint of pork roast I had canned earlier and put it in the oven at 350 degrees for 45 minutes or so. Â I have to say that it was pretty good. Â It tastes more like a cross between regular cooked cabbage and sauerkraut. Â I like cooked cabbage as a side vegetable dish, so I liked it. Â I only made three quarts of the stuff, so I am going to leave the other two on the shelf for another month or so to see if there is any difference in the taste.I will probably experiment with other similar recipes to see if I can find one that is a bit more sour. Â I know that I could just go to the store and buy a can or two, but I really like the idea of making my own. Â I'm funny that way. Â The more I can do for myself without running to the grocery, the better I like it. Â This experiment hasn't turned out exactly as I would have liked, but it isn't a dismal failure, either. Â Live and learn. Â And keep on trying.

title: Day of Rest
text: While I was growing up, I remember that my mother was quite insistent that Sunday be a day of rest. Â So today I honored her beliefs.I rested. Â I read. Â I played with the pooches and shared a bit of my popcorn with them this evening. Â I napped in my recliner with Kizzie the cat. Â I stayed away from the news, both mainstream and alternative. Â I didn't read any blogs or watch any videos that had anything to do with the insanity in our world.Sometimes I feel a bit overwhelmed. Â It seems that every day brings a new scandal or crisis, either real or manufactured, in our government. Â The Democrats are busy blaming the Republicans for whatever their agenda of the day is, and in turn, the Republicans and busy blaming the Democrats. Â Sometimes I just get tired of the whole mess. So today I just unplugged from it all. Â It was wonderful. Â I think Mom had the right idea. Â After all, God rested on the seventh day, and so should I.

title: The Great Cranberry Marathon...
text: has come to an end. Â Started out with 50 lbs. of cranberries and ended up with 84 quarts of juice. Â Number one son will pick up his share the next time he is in town. Â I'm still trying to find space to store mine. Â I have tried other recipes before with less than spectacular results, but this one makes a delicious drink. Â I don't know where I found the recipe, so if it is yours, let me know and I will give credit where credit is due.Cranberry Juice4 quarts (4 pounds) cranberriesWater3 to 3-1/2 cups granulated sugar Â (I used 2-1/2 cups sugar)Bring cranberries and 4 quarts water to a simmer in a large pot. DO NOT BOIL. Simmer 5 minutes, or until most berries burst.Pour berries and juice into damp jelly bag or a colander lined with four layers of clean cheesecloth. Let juice drip into a large bowl. DO NOT squeeze the bag.When you have extracted as much juice as possible from the pulp, return pulp to pot with 2 quarts water. Simmer 2 minutes.Pour this pulp and juice through jelly bag again to extract remaining juice.Place the 2 batches of juice in a large pot.Add sugar to suit your taste and 1 more quart water. Heat to dissolve sugar completely, but do not boil.Quickly pour into clean, hot jars, leaving 1/2-inch headspace; seal.Process in boiling water bath for 15 minutes.Yields 6 to 7 quarts.Note: Â I did not use cheesecloth as that is really time consuming and I had so many berries to process. Â I used a strainer, which leaves a bit of pulp, but that doesn't bother me in the least. Â The juice is for family consumption, not for entering at the fair. Â It doesn't have to be perfectly clear to taste wonderful.I hate to see anything go to waste, so I am dehydrating the leftover cranberry pulp. Â When dried, it can be ground into small bits and added as flavoring for muffins, quick breads or cookies. Â I dehydrate the peels when I am canning apples, and when mixed with the cranberry bits and a little sweetener, they make a really lovely tea.I think I have just enough jars left to can up the butternut squash that Son brought me from the Farmer's Market. Â And then I will give it a rest for a while. Â Unless, of course, I find another really good sale...

title: You Know You're Getting Tired...
text: when you can't figure out why the pot of cranberries on the stove hasn't come to a boil after 20 minutes, and then you discover that it really helps if you have remembered to turn the burner to the ON position.I think it may be time for a short nap.

title: Past the Elbows and Up to the Neck
text: I wasn't planning to do much more canning this season. Â But, the best laid plans, etc. Â Number One Son went back to the Farmers Market yesterday. Â Last year I had bought a 15 lb. box of cranberries and made them into juice. Â Between Son and me, it didn't last long. Â With that in mind, he brought me two 25 lb. boxes of cranberries. Â I was glad that he found the same vendor, for the berries are beautiful. Â Not a bad one in the entire box. Â Makes the cranberries in the store look like they belong in a dumpster. Â As I take a break here, I am about finished with the first box. Â There are jars of cranberry juice covering the table, my wee bit of counter space, the top of my freezer...And he brought me half a dozen butternut squash. Â I had tried canning some last year and liked it, so those will go in the pressure canner after I finish the cranberries.After Son hauled the cranberries and five more cases of quart jars up the stairs, we sat and talked for a bit. Â I mentioned to him that my local grocery has pork loin on sale again, along with boneless beef roast. Â He said that he needed to do a bit of grocery shopping and would take a look at them. Â He did more than look. Â He brought me 30 lbs. of pork, at least 50 lbs. of beef and 10 lbs. of bacon ends and pieces, just for fun, he said! Â I dice the bacon, brown it and can it in half pint jars for adding to scrambled eggs or egg and potato casseroles or beans or any number of dishes. Â The meat is in the freezer until I finish with the great cranberry marathon.Even though I hadn't planned to do any more canning other than the juice, I was really glad to get the squash and meat. Â Son said that it was easier for him to bring it to me rather than my trying to haul it all home via the bus. Â As he only has two days off from work every two weeks, and as he lives at least 45 minutes away from me, I really appreciate his time and effort. Â And a good share of the time, he won'tlet me pay for what he brings me. Â He says it is worth it because he doesn't have the time to do the canning and he gets to go shopping from my pantry shelves!I love it when family works together, sort of like my parents and grandparents did things. Â That's the way it should be.

title: Say It Isn't So
text: Our weather forecast for the coming week.I was really hoping not to see the word "Snow" in our forecast for a while yet. Â Yes, I know that it is too warm for snow to stay and it will melt right away. Â But there is something about seeing white flakes falling from the sky this early that is just depressing.I know that I have nothing to complain about. Â Those poor folks in the Dakotas who lost so many of their livestock in the recent blizzard are the ones that have something to complain about. Â They are the ones who are tough. Â They bury their losses and keep on going. Â I admire their pioneer spirit that is still alive and well. Â We need more like them.So if I see a few flakes in the air in the next few days, I will keep my whining to a minimum. Â I just would like to see the leaves finish turning from green to red and gold before I see the ground covered with white.Mother Nature seems to have a mean streak.

title: Wake Up Call
text: As much as I joke about Kizzie the cat's supposed reaction to running out of food, that incident served as a bit of a wake up call. Â I have been faithfully shopping sales and canning and dehydrating everything I can lay my hands on. Â But after taking an inventory of my food storage, I find that there are gaping holes that need to be filled - mostly items that I can't make at home but have to purchase.I have no idea what our government is going to do. Â They may come up with an eleventh hour temporary solution - or not. Â What I do know is that those in power have done their level best to inflict as much pain as possible on our citizens. Â It is a level of meanness that I didn't think possible in my homeland. Â And along with those acts of cruelty come the threats to the most vulnerable of citizens. Â I don't care what your opinion is of those relying on the EBT program to feed their families or of those who rely on Social Security or of those receiving veterans benefits. Â These people should not, under any circumstances, be used as pawns by those who are supposed to have the best interests of all Americans at heart.So I have some decisions to make in the next few days. Â Do I hold on to the wee bit of cash I have been able to put aside so that I will be able to pay my rent for a while should my Social Security check not arrive, or do I fill the holes in my food storage. Â Can't do both.I think what irritates me the most is that I have worked hard my whole life without making use of government welfare programs. Â Even when times were tough, I refused to give in, but worked harder and made do with what I had. Â And now my very survival is being threatened so that some politician can blame some other politician for the fix we are in. God help us.

title: The Things We Do For Our Pets
text: So this morning I'm standing at the bus stop. Â It is cloudy. Â The wind picks up a bit. Â It starts to rain. Â My umbrella is back in my apartment. Â And why am I going out in the wind and the rain?The miserable cat is out of food. Â I told her that fasting for a day or so wouldn't hurt her any. Â She didn't see it that way. Â She gets cranky if her food dish is only half full.It's my own fault. Â I wasn't paying attention. Â I have been busy stocking up on people food and didn't notice that I was low on cat food. Â When I got to the store, I filled my handy dandy little old lady shopping cart full to overflowing with cat food and kitty litter. Â Don't want to run out of litter, either.I am a coward. Â I'm not gonna tell her that her food is gone.Kizzie scares me sometimes.

title: Gold-Plated Apples
text: Yesterday was cloudy and cool and windy. Â But we went apple pickin' anyway.Number one son met us for lunch at the restaurant connected with the orchard. Â We don't often get to spend time with my brother and his lovely wife. Â Brother's job keeps him away from home much of the time, and his home is over two hundred miles north of mine, so time spent together is precious. Â We were able to share a meal and talk and laugh and get caught up on what the assorted kids and grandkids were doing. Â Son had to head for his home after the meal, for he needed to sleep a bit before going to his job that evening.If we do this again next year, I will do some research before. Â I didn't this time. Â I just picked the orchard that is most well known in our area. Â I had never been there before. Â Turns out that the place has its own restaurant, motel and gift shops. Â There are activities for the kids including pony rides and camel rides. Â Yep, you heard me right. Â Camel rides. Â We had to hold my brother back!And people. Â Crowds of people. Â And kids. Â Lots of them, too. Â And apples. Â Highly over-priced apples. Â We stood in line to pay for our apples, headed out into the orchard and filled our bags. Â And even with the crowds, which I usually would rather avoid, and the blustery weather, we still had a wonderful time.We came back to my place where we sat around the kitchen table, ate donuts and drank coffee, and talked and laughed. Â I put together a pot of beef stew and made biscuits, and we shared another meal, and talked and laughed some more.Even though the original idea was that my sister-in-law, who is more sister to me than in-law, wanted to go pick apples, it wasn't really about the apples. Â It was family and love and laughter, which is what it always is about when we get together.And now I think I will go peel a few of those gold-plated apples and make a pie. Â And think about the man who was father to me and my brother and who made the best apple pie in the entire universe. Â And who raised us to love and appreciate one another. Â For that is truly what it is all about.

title: The Truck and the Step Stool
text: So this evening Number One Son calls me. Â We are talking about where to meet to go apple picking tomorrow with my brother and his lovely wife. Â During the course of conversation, I mention that it would be nice if he could pick up a box of apples from a different orchard than we are visiting tomorrow. Â The different orchards sells large boxes of what they call "seconds." Â He brought me a box full last fall. Â These apples may have a blemish or be a bit odd shaped - in other words, they are not perfect. Â I don't care. Â They are just as good as the ones we pick from the trees, and they are cheaper. Â I might have to cut out a slight bad spot here and there, but that doesn't matter for applesauce or canned apples.Anyway, my son said that he could take me to the other orchard tomorrow, if I wanted. Â Son has a truck. Â The truck is high off the ground. Â My legs don't work well enough any more to be able to climb up into the truck. Â I reminded him of this fact."But I got you a step stool," was his reply.You just gotta love a son who will buy a step stool so his mom can get into his truck so he can take her to buy more apples that he will wind up hauling upstairs!

title: Let Them Be Kids
text: I read with interest an article about a school banning the use of footballs, soccer balls, baseballs, etc. on the playground at recess. Â This same school is also banning games of tag and cartwheels. Â Really? Â Cartwheels? Â I have an idea. Â Let's just wrap these kids in bubble wrap until they turn 21. Â What ever happened to "go outside and play?" Â The most exercise some kids get is downloading an app. Â I see kids outside who are wearing more protective gear than a NFL linebacker, for goodness sake. Â How on earth are they ever going to toughen up and learn if adults are afraid that their kid might break a nail.I don't like to see a child get hurt any more than the next person. Â My own brood had their share of bumps, cuts and bruises while they were growing up. Â But they learned. Â And they toughened up. Â And they grew into adults that I am proud of. Â  Adults who can handle most anything that life throws at them. Â And they didn't learn this by being over-protected.And then there is the elementary school that is not allowing their students to participate in any Halloween activities because someone might be offended. Â The school principal sent out a letter to parents that reads in part:"Some holidays, like Halloween, that some see as secular, are viewed by others as having religious overtones. The district must always be mindful of the sensitivity of all the members of the community with regard to holidays and celebrations of a religious, cultural or secular nature. The United States Supreme Court has ruled that school districts may not endorse, prefer, favor, promote or advance any religious beliefs...."If you are so flipping sensitive that a bunch of elementary school children dressed up as ghosts, fairy princesses and comic super heroes offends you, then you need to do something about that thin skin of yours. Â And I can't think of one good reason to change a long standing American tradition of celebrating Halloween. Â These are just kids. Â And the adults in charge seem to be bound and determined to suck the fun out of their lives. Kids are kids for a very short time. Â How about just letting them be kids.

title: Fall is in the Air
text: It is such a glorious season here in Minnesota. Â Summers can be hot and humid - winters cold, snowy and blustery. Â Spring is nice, for the ice and snow disappear. Â But nothing can beat Fall. Â The air is crisp and clean. Â In another week or two the leaves will be in full color. Â I really need to get out my camera and take some pictures.Fall is the time of year for Farmer's Markets. Â I have already canned up produce that my son brought when he made a Market run, and there is another planned to get cranberries. Â I have lots of cranberry sauce on my shelves, so this years bounty will be made into cranberry juice that both of us enjoy. And it is Apple Pickin' Time. Â There are several pick-your-own orchards near my home, and this year my brother and his lovely wife plan to join however many family members can go with us this coming weekend. Â It is one of my favorite outings of the year.Whenever I think about apple pickin' time, I think of the last apple excursion that my husband went on. Â We were with my youngest son and his family. Â Our granddaughter, Maddie, stuck pretty close to Poppa. Â She was small and he was tall and Poppa could reach the best apples that were high in the tree. Â Mike left us the following summer. Â It warms my heart to remember how he remarked after we came home, that the day had been one of the best he could remember.I love the fall days that turn into such good memories.

title: Nearly Finished for Now
text: The sausage is all canned and on my shelves. Â I ran the sauerkraut experiment through the pressure canner yesterday morning. Â The directions say to let it sit for three weeks before using, so I will see how well this method works then. Â Both dehydrators are humming away filled with sliced and diced potatoes. Two of the half pint jars of sausage didn't seal. Â That happens sometimes, though not very often, thankfully. Â I don't mind this time, as I have a hankering for biscuits and sausage gravy. Â I may live in the city, but I can still enjoy a good, old-fashioned country breakfast.Sometimes in the midst of the trouble and turmoil around us, it is good to be able to enjoy some of the more simple things in life. Â Biscuits, gravy and a steaming cup of coffee won't take away those ugly things that threaten our way of life. Â But they will make them a bit easier to bear.

title: Dear Mr. President:
text: Let me say right off the bat that I love my country. Â I would choose to live in no other country in the world. Â America is my home and America is where I will stay.That being said, I am not so enamoured with the leaders of my country. Â I expect adult behavior from them and I have seen very little of that for quite some time.Mr. President, how dare you bully 80 and 90 year old WWII veterans who want nothing more than to visit the memorial in Washington that is theirs. Â It is not yours. Â You did not fight and bleed for the right to visit a memorial dedicated to the heroism and patriotism of those who did. Â They were there. Â They fought. Â They suffered things that you can't even imagine. Â Many of them died. Â And if they want to pay their respects to their comrades who didn't get to come home, who are you to say they can't. Â Shame on you.And then, Mr. President, I hear you giving a speech in which you tell me that if you don't get your way with the debt ceiling, I can forget about receiving my Social Security check. Â Do I need to remind you that I paid into Social Security all of my life? Â I get no welfare benefits. Â Nobody gave me a phone before the last election. Â I get no government subsidised anything. That check is all I have, because I was promised that it would be there for my old age as long as I worked hard and kept paying into the fund. Â I did. Â And you want to take that away from me and so many others like me so you can score political points.If I were your mama, I would be thoroughly ashamed of you and of your colleagues. Â God help us as a nation when we find ourselves governed by schoolyard bullies.

title: Still At It
text: So this morning I added 32 pints of chicken breast and 10 half pints of sausage crumbles to my shelves. Â 20 lbs. of potatoes have made their way through the dehydrators. Â I still have 12 lbs. of sausage waiting for me, and another 30 lbs. of potatoes. Â Should be able to finish up by Saturday evening.But today I took a bit of a break. Â I live in a very old building that was, like many similar old buildings, divided into apartments. Â Whoever designed this apartment must have thought that the resident would never cook or bake or anything else in the line of processing food, for they put only about 18 inches of counter space on either side of the kitchen sink. Â There are no other counters. Â Because of the lack of counter space, my kitchen table gets a workout, and anyone who has done food preservation will attest to the fact that it is a messy process. Â So I spent the day getting my kitchen back in order, finding the top of the table again and putting away the jars and bags of food already processed. And then I took a nap. Â Just because I could.

title: Up to My Elbows...
text: in Farmer's Market goodness.Number One Son made a Farmer's Market run for me on Saturday. Â He came back with a half bushel of green bell peppers, 5 HUGE heads of cabbage, a good sized bag of carrots and 50 lbs. of potatoes. Â And 5 more cases of canning jars. Â In anticipation, I had made a grocery store run on Friday for the ingredients I needed to go with the cabbage and peppers to make Amish coleslaw. Â 25 pints of that deliciousness now reside on my shelves, along with another 28 pints of carrots. Â There are 2 pots of cabbage heating up on my stove with lots more waiting. Â (Yep, my neighbors are going to be loving me by the time I finish cooking and canning cabbage!) Â That will go into quart jars to be processed. Â I'm hoping to score a sale on corned beef come spring to go with the cabbage. Â I have never made sauerkraut before, so am giving that a go as well. Â The potatoes will be sliced and diced and dehydrated. Â They work well for scalloped potatoes and in soup and stew. Â The leftover peppers were dehydrated as well.So I had better stop playing here at the computer and get busy, because tomorrow my daughter and granddaughter are taking me to Sam's Club to stock up on meat, most of which will be canned as well. Â Other people make hay while the sun shines. Â For me, it is canning and dehydrating.I am truly lucky to have kids and grandkids who are willing to fetch and carry and haul it all up the stairs to my apartment. Â God bless them all!

title: People are Funny...
text: in a miserable kind of way.So I was at the grocery store this morning. Â Thought I would take advantage of the sale on beef roast. Â I had bought four packages earlier in the week and canned them. Â I wanted to can another six packages worth.As I am putting the roasts into my cart, a woman comes up along side me. Â As the third package went into my cart, she sort of starts to edge me out of her way. Â When I didn't move, she reaches over me, grabbing packages like she thought there wouldn't be any more. Â I just stood back and watched her. Â A package of meat at a grocery store just isn't worth the hassle of dealing with an obnoxious woman.When she had what she wanted, off she flounced, triumphant in her winning whatever game she thought she was playing with me. Â Guess she didn't realize that she was playing alone.I have to wonder what would happen if the poo really did hit the fan and there were fifty people just like that woman, all wanting to get their hands on the last loaf of bread in the store. Â I think I am glad that I have thought far enough ahead so that I will be home, baking my own bread.

title: Shopping Fool
text: As much as I dislike shopping, I am thinking that I will wind up a shopping fool this week. Â My local grocery has sales on beef and pork loin. Â I bought four packages of each this morning. Â They are all cubed, jarred up and a pressure canner load is cooking away, with several more waiting. Â Beef rarely is at an affordable price here, so I will be going back at least once more - maybe twice - to take advantage of the sale. Â The home canned beef makes the best beef stew as well as lots of other tasty dishes. Â This winter. Â When it is cold outside. Â And the ground is covered with ice and snow. Â And I won't have to venture out in it.I just wish I could get all of the shopping done at once, but there is only so much I can haul home on the bus in my handy dandy little old lady shopping cart that I use for groceries. Â I'm not complaining, though. Â Every day that I wake up in the morning is a bonus. Â And every day that I still can get around well enough to do my own shopping is even better. Â And every day that I still have the strength to haul my cart up the stairs to my apartment is awesome.Life is still good.

title: All I Wanted Was a Nightgown
text: So why are the clothes in the retail stores made for age 25 and under women. Â Isn't my money as good as theirs? Â Why can't they sell clothing that we grannies would be comfortable wearing!Now that the weather has cooled somewhat and fall is just around the corner, summer clothing is on sale. Â All I wanted were a couple of thin, cotton nightgowns. Â I suffered through about two weeks of heat and no air conditioning recently. Â I own winter sleepwear. Â I own a t-shirt style nightshirt that was uncomfortably hot, even with a fan going in my bedroom. Â I don't own any thin cotton sleepwear. Â So I went to buy some. Â I may not use them any more this year, but I surely will next summer, and I wanted to take advantage of the sales.I don't want t-shirts with matching pants. Â I don't want t-shirt style nightshirts in purple and orange stripes. Â I don't want some slinky lacy evening gown looking thing to sleep in. Â I am neither slinky nor am I the lacy type. Â I could care less about looking fashionable when I retire for the night. Â I have nobody to impress with my fashion sense at bedtime. Â It is just me and sometimes the cat in my bed. Â So why should I have to make a fashion statement to impress the cat!In my frustration with the retail industry that caters to the tastes of the young, I dug around in my closet and found the bin where I keep my fabric stash and sewing supplies. Â Found a pattern for sleepwear. Â Dug out some fabric that I bought a long time ago for a purpose long since forgotten. Â Cut out a couple of simple night gowns. Â Spent a day at my sewing machine. Â I now have what I couldn't find in the stores. Â For less money, even if they had what I wanted.I had forgotten about the benefits of home sewing. Â You get a garment that fits, that is well made and doesn't fall apart the second time it is washed. Â You don't have to waste time shopping. (I hate shopping. Â I have never understood women who treat shopping as a form of recreation.) Â You can get the colors and patterns you like in the fabric as opposed to whatever dreadful choices are on the racks at the stores. Â And if you watch for fabric and pattern sales, home sewn clothing costs far less than buying ready made.I learned to sew well over 50 years ago. Â There was a time when I sewed most of my own clothing as well as much of my children's. Â I think I stopped while I was still in the working world, for time was at a premium. Â Now I have all the time in the world. Â I could use some new shirts and slacks for winter. Â And a fall jacket. Â Think I will go now and peruse the fabric store sale ads.

title: Going Home
text: While reading some of my favorite blogs this morning, I ran across a post about going home again. Â The writer talked of visiting various places where she had lived only to find them all changed. Â Other people now live there, houses have been remodeled and yards and gardens done over. Â Most bore little resemblance to her memories of them.I get restless sometimes. Â I wish I could move out of the city. Â I wish I could go back to the north country I love. Â Or to the drafty old farmhouse that I mostly grew up in. Â But if I take a long, realistic look at things, I know in my heart of hearts that this will not happen. Â The dubious joys of my "golden years" make it nearly impossible.I love the northern part of my state because my family roots are there. Â I have such good memories of time spent as a child in the house my grandfather built for his large family. Â I can see in my mind the kitchen with it's worn plank floor and wood burning stove and the ice box in the corner and the stool by the back door that held a bucket full of well water and a dipper for drinking. Â I see the upright piano in the corner of the main room that my grandfather played, and although I never knew him or heard his music, I see him through the tales told me by my father. Â I can visualize my grandmother sitting in the chair that was hers, reading or smiling at the shenanigans of her grown children and grandchildren. Â I see her in the early morning, long black braid, only touched with gray even in her later years, down her back, stoking up the stove firebox to cook breakfast. I sometimes think about the farmhouse where I spent the better part of my youth. Â I remember the warmth of the kitchen where it seems, in my memory, there was always something good baking in the oven. Â I remember bedroom walls that were papered, for underneath was lath and plaster that couldn't be painted. Â I recall warm summer nights spent sleeping on the screened front porch, and the storm clouds Dad and I watched from that same porch, rolling over the fields. Â I think of the hours spent roaming the woods and fields behind the house and the dog that was always at my heels and the orchard and the garden. And the long row of peony bushes that were a riot of white and pink while in bloom.My grandparents house is no longer there. Â A number of years ago it was donated to the local firefighters to burn as a practice drill. Â The farmhouse is gone as well, torn down to make way for a new house built on the property.And then the realization comes to me that it is not the buildings that are important. Â It is the memories of life in those buildings. Â It is the laughter of my aunts and uncles and cousins when we all got together in the north. Â It is following my uncle to the barn when he went to do the milking and playing with the latest batch of barn kittens. Â It is the soft lap of my grandma and the absolute knowledge that she loved me. Â It is my Dad's silly jokes and Mom's homemade bread. Â It is the time and patience my parents put in to teach me so many things that have helped me over the years. Â It is taking care of my baby brother when Mom couldn't, and loving every minute of it. Â It is memory of a two-room country schoolhouse and bike rides down gravel roads and nearly burning my eyebrows off trying to smoke corn silk with the neighbor girl.I have heard it said that you can't go home again, and that is true. Â But every now and then, when city life comes close to being unbearable to this country girl, I can go home. Â For it is not the houses, but the people. Â Most of them are gone now, but they still live in memory. Â And I think that may be enough.

title: Beans and Cornbread
text: I soaked a bag of beans overnight and got them to cooking this morning for a pot of old-fashioned baked beans, just because I was hungry for a bowl of them. Â My kids will probably laugh at me when I tell them that the first time I tried to make from scratch baked beans, they turned out terrible. Â Baked beans aren't supposed to be crunchy. Â I was still very young and still cared about what other people thought, and I didn't want anyone to know what a dismal failure they were, so I took them out back into the woods, dug a hole and buried them. Â They were so bad that the dog didn't even try to dig them up.I dehydrated a bunch of sweet corn last year when I found a really good sale on frozen corn. Â It turned out great and rehydrates really well. Â But I found that when I run the dry corn through a little electric chopper, it turns into cornmeal that makes the best cornbread I have ever made. Homemade beans and cornbread. Â Simple comfort food. Â And oh, so good. Â Don't think I will have to give any of it a decent burial this time.

title: Flying Geese
text: The eastern sky was just beginning to turn pink this morning. Â Sitting next to my open window to catch a bit of morning breeze, my first cup of coffee in hand, I heard the honking of geese. Â Lots of geese.The geese come back here each spring from wherever they go for winter months. Â The nest on the shores of the many lakes and ponds and streams, raise their young, and then head back south.I will hear them from time to time, going out in the mornings during the summer in search for food and returning to their nesting areas in the evening. Â But this honking was louder and more prolonged than a normal food run. Â As I looked out and up, I saw at least a dozen V-shaped formations heading south. Â This was followed closely by another group just as large. Â I usually don't see these large flocks until mid-October.The Farmer's Almanac has predicted a cold, nasty winter for us here in the north. Â I wonder if the geese know about it. Â Looks like they just might.

title: Big Sister
text: Having your big sister in the same school you go to is cool.Having your big sister walk with you to your first kindergarten class is priceless.It is that time of year again. Â My grandkids started school for another year.Zach is in eighth grade this year.Boston started sixth grade.Maddie is in fourth grade.And Jacob started kindergarten.I have one more school-aged grandchild, Nicki who started her Junior year of High School. Â I think she considers herself too grown up for first day of school pictures. Â Nicki, you need to send your Grandma some new pictures. Â This one is a couple of years old.The kids all seem glad to get back to school, and this year will be an adventure, especially for Jacob, who is just starting down the path of learning. Â I hope their enthusiasm continues.

title: What a Difference a Day Makes
text: Woke up this morning to an outdoor temperature of 58 degrees. Â The cat was pretty much Velcroed to my knees for warmth. Â The dogs had to be persuaded to leave their warm beds for breakfast. Â What a difference a day makes.Find my warm, fuzzy robe - check.Move the long sleeved shirts to the front of the closet - check.Add the ingredients for the best malted hot chocolate mix in the world to my grocery shopping list - checkStart a pot of homemade chicken soup to simmer all day - checkOh, I know that in a day or two we will be back to summer weather, but just for today, I will pretend that fall is here to stay. Â And I will enjoy every minute of it.

title: Rain
text: It doesn't seem like we have seen very much rain here over the summer. Â But this evening the rain is falling. Â After another hot day - not as bad as earlier this week, but hot nonetheless - the temperature has dropped 12 degrees in the past hour. Â A cool breeze flows from one end of my apartment to the other. Â I can turn off the fans and just listen to the music of the rain.

title: Mini Heat Wave is Over
text: I think our mini heat wave is over. Â This morning I have cooler breezes blowing through my apartment. Â The constant panting by the pups has ceased. Â Their appetites are back to normal. Â That is a good thing, for they ate little over the last few days. Â They are so small, 12 lbs. and 9 lbs. respectively, that I am concerned when they won't eat. Â Especially Jessie Jane, who is the consummate garbage hound. Â When she refuses food, I know that things are not well in her world. Â My appetite seems to have returned as well, which is probably not so good.As long as my kitchen was cool early this morning, I baked bread. Â I had been out of bread for a couple of days, but didn't want to make the apartment any more miserably hot than it already was. Â Six loaves and two dozen buns are cooling on my kitchen table. Â I try to bake my own bread as often as possible. Â The wonderful smells that fill my home remind me of coming home from school to find my mother taking bread from her oven. Â There is little that smells so wonderful as bread baking.I hope that the cooler days continue. Â I love the fall of the year. Â I live near the Minnesota River, and I so enjoy walks with the dogs on the paths along it's banks. Â I wish that the city still allowed folks to burn the leaves raked from their yards, for that smell was one I always associated with autumn. Â But soon the smells of canning apples, cooking applesauce and apple butter will fill my little home, and that is just as good.Isn't it funny how different smells in the air can bring on such pleasant memories.

title: A Dog's Purpose
text: It has been hot today. Â My air conditioning is out. Â Doesn't look like it will be fixed soon. Â I have been a bit concerned about my dogs, who have been spending time on the cool kitchen floor. Â They have been panting a lot, which is unusual for them. My thermostat has read 87 degrees most of the day, even with four large fans running. Â I'm pretty much just pushing the hot air around rather than cooling anything off. Â Earlier this evening I put both of my Yorkies in the shower and let cool water spray them for a while. Â You would think that I had given each of them a T-bone steak, they seemed that happy to be cooler. Â It made me think about how much joy they give me and how little they ask in return.I have been pretty quiet today. Â Heat, high humidity and I are not friends. Â I read some, entered some things in my genealogy program and messed about on the internet, catching up on some blog reading and researching some things of interest to me. Â In my travels through cyberspace, I stumbled upon the following. Â I recall seeing this before but had not saved it. Â I decided to share it with you because of the truth it contains.A Dog's Purpose, From a 6 Year OldPost by ThegreenmanBeing a veterinarian, I had been called to examine a ten-year-old Irish Wolfhound named Belker. The dog's owners, Ron, his wife Lisa, and their little boy Shane, were all very attached to Belker, and they were hoping for a miracle.I examined Belker and found he was dying of cancer. I told the family we couldn't do anything for Belker, and offered to perform the euthanasia procedure for the old dog in their home.As we made arrangements, Ron and Lisa told me they thought it would be good for six-year-old Shane to observe the procedure. They felt as though Shane might learn something from the experience.The next day, I felt the familiar catch in my throat as Belker's family surrounded him. Shane seemed so calm, petting the old dog for the last time, that I wondered if he understood what was going on. Within a few minutes, Belker slipped peacefully away.The little boy seemed to accept Belker's transition without any difficulty or confusion. We sat together for a while after Belker's death, wondering aloud about the sad fact that animal lives are shorter than human lives.Shane, who had been listening quietly, piped up, ''I know why.''Startled, we all turned to him. What came out of his mouth next stunned me. I'd never heard a more comforting explanation. It has changed the way I try and live.He said, ''People are born so that they can learn how to live a good life -- like loving everybody all the time and being nice, right?'' The six-year-old continued,''Well, dogs already know how to do that, so they don't have to stay as long.''Remember, if a dog was the teacher you would learn things like:When loved ones come home, always run to greet them.Never pass up the opportunity to go for a joyride.Allow the experience of fresh air and the wind in your face to be pure Ecstasy.Take naps.Stretch before rising.Run, romp, and play daily.Thrive on attention and let people touch you.Avoid biting when a simple growl will do.On warm days, stop to lie on your back on the grass.On hot days, drink lots of water and lie under a shady tree.When you're happy, dance around and wag your entire body.Delight in the simple joy of a long walk.Be loyal.Never pretend to be something you're not.If what you want lies buried, dig until you find it.When someone is having a bad day, be silent, sit close by, and nuzzle them gently.ENJOY EVERY MOMENT OF EVERY DAY!

title: Heat
text: I was going to complain about the heat wave here in Minnesota.I was going to whine about the fact that the central air in my building isn't keeping up and the temperature in my living room this morning is the same as the outside temperature.And then I read a news article that told about kids that went back to school yesterday in buildings that have no air conditioning. Â Some needed medical attention because of the heat.And I remembered that my oldest grandson works for a lawn care/landscaping company. Â He works outdoors. Â The operative word there is "work." Â Not sit on the beach under an umbrella, but "work."Never mind.

title: Reasons to Prepare
text: I rarely, if ever, delve into current events or political opinions on this blog. Â I don't completely understand politics or economics or global events. Â I don't even pretend to. What I do know is this:I know that if a politician is speaking, chances are more than pretty good that he or she is lying to me. Â Sincerely and with a straight face.I know that little by little my rights as an American citizen are being undermined by those who believe that the Constitution is just an old piece of paper.I know that the government thinks it is OK to spy on all of us.I know that "Of the People, By the People and For the People" no longer matters to anyone in power.And I know that very few people really care. Â They are way too busy with their own lives and interests to see that the train is ready to jump the track. Â And take all of us right along with it.I am into preparing for whatever does come down the pike. Â I have no idea if war or economic collapse or civil unrest will make it necessary for me to live for a time on what I have put by, as well as feed any of my family that needs to be fed. Â I just know that the world has gone mad and something will happen, probably sooner than later, that will make life a lot tougher for folks than it is right now. Â As the child of depression era parents, I was taught that if I didn't stock up in the summertime, I would probably be pretty hungry in the middle of the winter. Â So I stock up as much as I can.I don't have a retreat to go to like so many in the "prepping" world do, when things get bad. Â I am a retired widow living on Social Security. Â My husband was epileptic and diabetic. Â He died from a heart attack 5 years ago. Â Doctor and hospital visits, $1,400 ambulance rides that were a mile and a half long between our apartment and the local hospital and the price of the several medications he took made saving for retirement only a pipe dream. Â  I do not begrudge one dime spent on his health issues. Â But there was nothing left over for retreats or bug-out vehicles or cases of freeze dried foods or many of the other things that modern day preppers find necessary. Â My point is not that my life has been tough. Â Many people have lives that have been much more challenging than mine. Â My point is that even with challenges, whether it be limited income or chronic illness or anything else, it is possible to prepare for the future. Â We just do the best we can with what we have to work with. I do worry some about those who ignore the signs that things are woefully wrong in our country. Â I understand that it is much nicer to live in a world viewed through rose colored glasses, where everything is unicorns and sunshine. Â Nobody likes to see the storm clouds on the horizon. Â I just think that it is better to get ready for the storm than to pretend it isn't there.Others can do whatever they wish. Â I can't seem to get anyone to really pay attention. Â So I will just continue to do what I have been doing - pray and prepare as best I can.

title: It's My Own Fault
text: It is my own fault. Â My Yorkies love, love, love the homemade dog food that I am feeding them now. Â They get fed morning and evening. Â It is not like they are starving, for I leave dry food down for them all the time, should they want a nibble in between feedings.Supper time is between 5:30 and 6 PM. Â Lately they have started pestering me around 3:30 in the afternoon. Â A human being with a heart can only take so much of the soulful staring. Â Or maybe they are giving me the evil eye. Â I'm not really sure.Anyway, the last couple of afternoons I have caved by 4:30 or so.Which means that now they think they should be fed earlier in the morning. Â Yesterday and today it was at about 4:45 AM that they started fussing outside my bedroom door. Â I don't mind getting out of bed at an early hour, but come on. Â I'm retired. Â I don't have to get up if I don't want to. Â The birds aren't even awake at 4:45 AM.So now they have had their breakfast and are fast asleep - Lily in her little bed and Jessie Jane in her kennel. Â That's where they always sleep. Â And here I am, at 5:15 AM. Â Wide awake.Guess I'll go make a pot of coffee.And yes, I know. Â It is my own fault! Â I'm such a pushover.

title: To Cook or Not to Cook...
text: I prefer Not to Cook. Â It's not that I can't cook. Â I can. Â Very well, as a matter of fact. Â I just do not enjoy the process.There are some YouTube channels hosted by some very good cooks. Â I enjoy watching them from time to time. Â And now and then I see a dish that I might try making for myself. Â But not often. Â I keep a pretty basic pantry. Â A fixed income doesn't include specialty items. Â And cooking for just one person isn't much fun, so I try to make it as simple as possible.I am a back to basics kind of cook as opposed to one of the gourmet variety. Â I live in pork and beef and poultry country. Â I have never seen leg of lamb in the meat department of my local grocery store. Â I grew up on basic, good tasting simple and filling meals of meat, potatoes, vegetables and probably homemade pickles. Â The closest thing to a gourmet dish that I remember from my childhood was when Dad's pancake batter got a little bit runny, resulting in very thin pancakes. Â He plopped some strawberries on them, added whipped cream, rolled them up and convinced his children that they were eating "high-classed crepes."I home can much of my own food. Â I don't have a garden. Â My apartment is surrounded by asphalt and concrete. Â There are no community gardens in my area. Â I thought about growing tomatoes and herbs in pots on the communal deck of my building, but others have tried this in the past and the pots were stolen within a couple of weeks of planting.What I do have is a son who is willing to go to the huge Farmer's Market in Minneapolis and bring me boxes of tomatoes, huge heads of cabbage, bags of carrots and boxes of potatoes, all grown locally. Â What is even better, he is willing to huff all of that produce up the stairs to my apartment, along with the jars that I need to can it all. Â God bless him. Â I hope his back holds out!I can the usual suspects - corn, green beans, carrots, peas, potatoes, etc. Â I also buy meat on sale and can that as well. Â I am able to open a jar of mixed vegetables and another of canned turkey and dump them into a casserole dish. Â Top it off with homemade biscuits, pop it in the oven, and - easy, peasy - dinner is served. Â Or I take a jar of beef roast chunks and a jar of potato and carrot cubes, plop them in a pan, season and bake for a half hour and I have a meal.I have started canning a variety of soups as the basis for quick and easy lunches. Â So far I have canned vegetable, chicken vegetable, ham and bean, split pea and ham, and chili. Â A pint jar is just right to fill a soup bowl.I didn't start canning as part of the prepper movement. Â I have done this most of my life. Â In my family, the rule was, "If you don't work, you don't eat." Â And that included working hard summer and fall, preserving the garden produce and seasonal fruits. Â Dad worked a job and Mom and I worked canning and preserving. Â I grew up on home canned foods and I still like them far and away better than anything I buy in the store. Â The added benefit is that I know what is in them, as opposed to the ingredient list on a can that includes items that I cannot pronounce.Some of my grown children think that I have gone off the deep end when it comes to the preservation of food. Â They also believe that my tin foil hat is on a bit too tight. Â That opinion notwithstanding, I continue to add home canned food to my shelves as often as is possible. Â My goal is to have a one year supply of food put away. Â I am nearly there. Â Winters here in Minnesota can be very cold, very snowy, very icy and totally miserable. Â Last winter I only had to venture out in the bitter weather three times for a grocery store run. Â I hope to avoid trips to the store altogether this coming winter. Â I do love winter, but only when viewed from the comfort of my rocking chair in front of my window, with a cup of steaming coffee or hot chocolate in hand and one of my crocheted afghans over my shoulders. Â Add a cat in my lap and my dogs at my feet and I am one content lady.

title: Home Town Celebrations
text: This week my town has its annual summer celebration. Â Many towns across the country have them. Â There are activities and contests for young and old, music in the bandstand, food booths and arts and crafts booths, a fireworks display Saturday night and a parade on Sunday afternoon. Â And many of the local businesses have sidewalk sales going on. Â Because I am more inclined to a hermit kind of lifestyle as opposed to being a social butterfly, I will probably skip the crowds. Â I tend to gravitate more to the book sale at the library. Â I probably will wander down to the park tomorrow and check out the crafty things for sale, for I always like most anything handmade. Â And the fireworks display is just a block away on the river and I can see it from the deck on my building. Â The kid in me loves the fireworks.The crowds of people coming and going to the various activities reminded me of the small town celebrations in years gone by. Â The town where I grew up had the Kaffee Fest. Â It was a big deal for us country kids who didn't get to town that often. Â A couple of streets were blocked off and a small carnival complete with Merry-Go-Round, Ferris Wheel and Tilt-A-Whirl (my favorite) was set up there. Â I always felt kind of sorry for the ponies going round and round with shrieking kids in the saddles. Â A couple of churches had food booths that served hamburgers and fries or foot long hot dogs, and because we were in dairy country, there was a large "all you can drink for a dime" milk bar. Â It was pretty small stuff compared to the countless entertainments going on here this weekend, but it was great fun for kids of my era.I remember hearing my parents talk about activities in the small town where they both grew up. Â They talked of ice cream socials and outdoor band concerts on summer evenings. Â They reminisced about pot luck picnics at the church and pageants put on by school children. Â They told about tug-of-war contests and softball games and of hayrides in the fall of the year and sleigh rides in the winter. Â But mostly they talked about the people who attended these gatherings that seemed to be more about friends and neighbors and families than about the entertainment. I think I would have enjoyed those times.

title: Stun Gun Guy
text: So last evening I'm sitting at my computer writing and minding my own business. Â My windows are open as I am enjoying a cool evening breeze. Â All of a sudden I hear a sound that I can only describe as sort of electrical, like when a wire breaks and sends sparks in all directions. Â This is followed by loud yelling voices. Â I thought maybe a street light had shorted out so I go to the window to see if that is the case.It isn't. Â What I see is a crowd of about eight young men on my side of the street. Â Across the street are three more, and it looks like two of them are trying to fight with the third. Â But the third is holding a stun gun. Â That was the sound I heard. Â The two are jumping around the stun gun guy like they are in a boxing ring. Â The group across the street are yelling, egging them on. Â Eventually the guy holding the stun gun flashes it a couple more times, turns and walks up the alley. Â The would be combatants are left yelling Â all sorts of words that were disparaging to the stun gun guy's ancestry. Â I thought that the taunt, "I double dog dare you" wasn't used much after grade school.But then, it doesn't appear that any of these people have progressed beyond the age of seven. Â I really had to laugh when all of a sudden one of them yells, "Scatter! Â Here come the cops!" Â I haven't heard those words since high school.I really need to find a more quiet place to live.

title: Enough Already
text: To the guy who parks his truck in the street just below my windows and plays his music so loud that the windows rattle and the floors vibrate, enough already.I don't force you to listen to the country music or the bluegrass or the old rock & roll that I like, so don't feel that you have to share yours with me. Â Or things might have to change.I can show up on your front lawn at dawn with some really good speakers and play Lawrence Welk's Greatest Hits at full volume. Â Or if you tick me off any more than you already have, I know where I can lay my hands on some Whoopee John Polkas.Sheesh!I don't have a lot of pictures of my Mom's younger years. Â As far as I know, there are no pictures in existence of her before the age of 6 years or so. Â With the exception of this one.Mom always joked that this was the first picture ever taken of her with her parents. Â She hadn't been born yet, but would be in a month or so after the picture was taken.Mom on the left with her sister Margaret, in the mid 1930's.This was taken after one of my Grandpa Paul's church services in Nebish in the early 1940's. Â Grandpa and Margaret are in front with Mom behind Margaret. Â In the back are her brother Duane, Grandma Paul, Duane's wife Mildred and Mom's sister Elaine.Between the time Mom's family moved to St. Paul and the time she married Dad, Mom worked as a nurses aide at the N. P. Hospital in St. Paul.Mom at about age 16.This is my favorite photo of Mom. Â It was taken in 1945 before she and Dad were married.Mom in the back with Margaret and her sisters Elaine and Adella and brother Duane in front. Â Taken in the mid-1930's.This is the youngest picture of Mom that I have. Â She is the little girl with the lace-up dress on the far left. Â I think this must have been a school or church pageant.Mom in Blackduck, about 1947.Mom about 1990.I love going through the old family photos. Â They bring back so many memories. Â Sometimes good ones that make me laugh and others that bring tears. And they give me a glimpse of what life was like way back when. Â I am glad that I have collected these through the years and that I can show my children and grandchildren a little bit of what their grandparents were all about.

title: Pictures of Dad
text: I have stuff to get done the next couple of days while the temperatures here are a bit lower and my apartment is a bit more comfortable than it has been lately. Â Yes, even those of us who are retired still have stuff to do. Â The laundry lady is on strike and the cleaning fairy quit. Â The dogs will be out of food in a couple of days if I don't get busy and make another batch. Â And the grocery store has turkeys on sale again so I need to hop on the bus and go get some to replenish my supply of home canned turkey. Â I seem to go through the canned turkey faster than anything else on my shelves.So here are some pictures of Dad in no particular order. Â Enjoy.Dad was about 20 years old in this photo.Dad at the gas station in Blackduck where he worked in about 1947.Dad at the top of the ladder and his brother Bruce at the bottom - about 1919.Dad with some of his great-grandchildren - Nicki, Zach and Chris. Â This must have been in about 2000.Dad with his sister, Clarice. Â Date unknown. Â I like this picture because of Dad's smile, which was so typical of him.Dad with Mom's sister, Margaret. Â I love this picture just because.Dad with his great-grandson, Zach.This picture was taken around 1916 at the one room White Pine schoolhouse where the Matheny children attended school. Â The three boys in back, from tallest to shortest are Dad's brothers, Keith, Kenneth and Bruce. Â His sister Clarice is the little girl in the darker dress and Dad is the little boy in the overalls on the end.Dad and the Giant TomatoDo any of my children remember the monster tomato plant? Â Dad grew tomatoes on the balcony of his apartment in Blackduck. Â He brought this one in the house before the first frost and the silly thing just kept on growing. Â There was even a write-up in the local newspaper with this picture. Â I teased Dad that it must have been a slow news day when the article appeared. Â He was pretty proud of that tomato plant.That's all for now. Â I will post some pictures of Mom tomorrow.

title: A Sense of Humor
text: I sometimes think that the only way to get through this crazy life is to keep a sense of humor in good working order. Â Both sides of my family were able to do that, and if I could have inherited just one thing, the sense of humor would have been what I would want.Dad's side of the family pretty much had a dry sense of humor. Â Any of Dad's siblings could say something totally outrageous and keep a straight face until it dawned on you that your leg was being pulled. Â They pulled silly little pranks on one another, even when they were full grown adults, like Uncle Bruce stealing a part of a slice of pie off Dad's plate when his back was turned. Â They teased one another, but never in a vicious way. Â Dad liked to remind his siblings that he was the last child born in that family, so he was sure that his parents had saved the best for last.They only got into trouble when the five boys got together and plotted some devilment, usually for Halloween. Â At that time, indoor plumbing was rare, and everybody had outhouses. Â The Matheny boys wouldn't tip over outhouses, as was the custom for boys to do on Halloween night. Â They merely moved them over a foot or two so that the hole dug underneath wasn't where it was supposed to be, and if a person stood in the wrong spot, the outhouse might suddenly lean toward the direction of the now exposed hole.The prank that became legendary in the family involved a Model T Ford car. Â There was a man who lived in town who had a new Model T. Â He was proud of this car to the point of being a bit obnoxious in his bragging. Â This was something that the Matheny boys just couldn't let pass. Â They managed to get that car up on the roof of the man's garage, and there it sat when he came out to drive it in the morning. Â Dad would barely acknowledge to me that he and his brothers had anything to do with this, saying, "Somebody...I don't know just who..." did this. Â And he would never tell me just how they got the car on the roof. Â It wasn't until just a couple of years ago when I was talking to my brother that he told me Dad had once told him that he and his brothers had sort of dismantled the car, hauled the parts up to the roof and put the car back together. Â They went to an awful lot of work for a joke, but I think it was probably worth it!Dad's sense of humor stayed with him to the end. Â He and his sister, Clarice, both resided in the same nursing home where Mom had lived. Â Both were over the age of 90. Â It seems that there was an exercise program for wheelchair bound residents, where they sat in their chairs and did arm and upper body exercises to keep up their strength. Â Dad and his sister usually sat next to one another. Â They would be dutifully doing their exercises when Dad would lean over and gently tap Clarice on the back of her head. Â They would exercise some more and Clarice would reach over and lightly punch Dad on his shoulder. Â After which he would retaliate, and so would she, until the staff member who was leading the group would say, "Now you two Matheny kids just behave yourselves!" Â And they would, but only for a little while.Clarice and DadMy mother's only brother was the prankster in their family. Â I have been told by cousins that he would wait until his parents had gone out of an evening, and then as soon as it got dark, he would conjure up a story or a creaking door or some crash-bang noises to scare his sisters. Â He did this just to see if he could get them to run upstairs to their bedrooms, screaming all the way. Â And it usually worked. Â I think that must have been his revenge at being the only boy in a house full of girls.Another time Uncle Duane convinced some of his visiting cousins that it would be fun to go out at night and steal some muskmelons from a neighbor's garden. Â He lead them all over town, through back yards and down alleys and got them thoroughly turned around in direction until they came to the muskmelon patch. Â It wasn't until the cousins each had a good sized melon in hand that they realized they had just stolen melons from their own family garden.Mom and her sisters weren't big on playing jokes. Â But when they all got together, there was always lots of talk and even more laughter. Â I always enjoyed listening to them.This isn't a very good photo, but it is the only one I have of Grandma and all of the Paul siblings.Mom did, however, like to get one up on Dad every now and then. Â This was a time when Fuller Brush and Kirby Vacuum Cleaner salesmen went door to door. Â Dad went to work early in the morning, so he usually got home in the middle of the afternoon. Â One afternoon he was greeted by Mom calling out as he came in the kitchen door that he should come into the living room, as there was a Kirby Vacuum Cleaner salesman there. Â Mom later told me she knew how Dad would react and she wasn't disappointed. Â He thought she was joking and called back to her that he didn't want to see any durned old salesman and that he had better hightail it out of there if he knew what was good for him. Â And then he entered the living room and found himself face to face with the white-faced, wide-eyed salesman, vacuum in hand. Â Dad told me later that he just sat there meekly through the whole demonstration. Â He figured he owed the salesman that much for scaring him.I don't know how some folks can go through life all grouchy and cranky. Â Life, after all, is full of absurdities, and if you can't sit back and just laugh at yourself and the world around you, then it seems to me that you are in for a long and miserable life. Â I'd rather laugh.

title: About Mom
text: My mother's upbringing was very different from my father's. Â Where Dad's family was just a bit rowdy, Mom's family was more reserved. Â They say that opposites attract and I think in my parents' case, it was true.Mom was raised in Blackduck where her father was the depot agent for the railroad. Â My grandfather's first wife had died the day after giving birth to their daughter, Dorothy. Â A couple of years later he married my grandma, Gladys Morehouse. Â Mother had one brother and four sisters besides Dorothy, the fifth sister being stillborn. Â She was next to the youngest in age.Born in 1924, Mom grew up during the Great Depression. Â The family was fortunate in that my grandfather had a job and was able to keep it during that time when so many were out of work, and was able provide for his family. Â They lived a life typical for small town America with all of the children going to school and graduating from high school, where many other less fortunate children had to quit school and help out on family farms or look for other means to financially help their families. Â Mom's family was not rich by any stretch of the imagination, but neither were they destitute.My mother's family was musically inclined. Â All of the children except the youngest played the violin and some played piano. Â Mother learned to play violin, cello, guitar and piano. Â I was lucky to have been born first in my family, for I was able to hear Mom play all the instruments before the crippling in her hands made it impossible. Â My sister may have heard her play, but my brother who is 15 years my junior, never did.In addition to my grandfather's work for the railroad, he was a lay minister. Â To my knowledge he was never ordained, but he held church services in the nearby community of Nebish for many years. Â My mother and her siblings, who all had good singing voices as well as a talent for playing instruments, went with him to provide the music for the services. Â As a side note, my Grandfather Paul preached the funeral service for my Grandfather Matheny in October of 1936.Sometime in the early 1940's, the family, with the exception of the two oldest who had married, moved to St. Paul. Â Mom's father had problems with his heart (I don't know what the actual diagnosis was. Â At that time it was just referred to as "heart trouble.") and because of his employment with the railroad, the logical place for his treatment was the Northern Pacific Hospital in St. Paul. Â It was there he passed on in October of 1947. Â I was only 16 months old when my grandfather died, so I have very little in the way of memory of him. Â I once asked my Dad what Grandpa Paul was like, and his description was that he was a stern but fair man.Mom and Dad were married in St. Paul in July of 1945. Â Mom's father wanted her to wait until she was 21 years of age before marrying, so she honored his request by setting the wedding date for one week after her 21st birthday. Â Mother was married to Dad for nearly 51 years.My mother was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis shortly after my birth in 1946. Â It began with swelling and pain in her hands and eventually spread to her entire body. Â I find it sad that so much of her life was defined by pain and doctors and hospitals, ending in a nursing home. Â We were so blessed to have her in the small facility in her hometown, where she was known and loved by family and staff alike. Â Mom and Dad had moved to an apartment within a block of the home, and after she could no longer live there, Dad was able to walk over and spend his days with her.Mom loved pretty things. Â I remember watching her crochet beautiful doilies to adorn the backs of chairs or table tops. Â She did fancy embroidery and taught me this skill. Â Holidays were her favorite times. Â She took a small tree branch, painted it white and attached red and pink paper hearts to the branches with gold thread, for a Valentine's Day centerpiece for our dining room table. Â She did the same at Easter, using the egg shells that we had blown the insides out of and decorated. Â She was always crafting something pretty out of practically nothing. Â Christmas was her absolute favorite time of year, and there was hardly a surface in our home that wasn't adorned with pine bows, brightly colored glass ornaments and candles. Â Even when she could no longer do the decorating herself and was in a wheelchair, I remember her sitting in the middle of the living room, directing the decorating of the room by the rest of us, like a queen on her throne.I didn't realize how far Mother's love of pretty extended until much later in my life. Â The family had gathered for the celebration of some event - perhaps a special birthday or anniversary. Â For special occasions she would often serve as part of the meal a shrimp salad that contained tiny pasta rings, baby shrimp, diced celery and sliced olives in a dressing. Â I loved the stuff. Â When someone offered to get a plate of food for Mom and asked if she wanted some shrimp salad, Mom replied no, that she did not like it. Â When I asked her why she served it for occasions if she wouldn't eat it, she said that the only reason she had made that salad was because it looked pretty in the bowl.Over the years, the disease that ravaged her body slowly became worse. Â She had surgeries to replace joints that had worn away and eventually had a permanent trach tube in her neck so she could breathe after bones in her neck disintegrated. Â Where a cold is an annoyance to most of us, it often was the cause of another hospital stay for her. Â Mom was a very religions person and I think it was her faith that kept her going when most would have given up. Â After the surgery on her neck, the doctors told her to go home and get her affairs in order. Â Twenty years later, she was still thumbing her nose at them.I am so grateful to her for all that she taught me. Â How she had the patience to deal with a semi-rebellious tomboy of a daughter, I will never know.Mom died in April of 1996. Â I felt great sadness, but also relief that she was no longer in pain. Â I will always miss her.

title: For Your Viewing Pleasure
text: At 8:30 this morning the temperature in my little apartment was already up to 84 degrees. Â My computer is located in the warmest room and as it is not a laptop, I can't move to a cooler spot. title: About Dad
text: Dad grew up in a large, poor farm family. Â He was the youngest of nine children. Â As soon as the children were old enough, they worked, and my grandparents worked right along side them. Â The boys fed the hogs and milked the cows. Â They plowed the fields behind a team of horses. Â They cut hay by hand and loaded it onto hay wagons with pitchforks and stored it in the barn. Â In the winter they cut and split firewood to heat their house. Â They cut blocks of ice from the lake, hauled it home on sleds pulled by horses and covered it with straw in the root cellar that was dug into a hill near the house, so they would have ice for the ice box to keep their food cool year round. Â They couldn't go to the corner grocery and buy ice then, for there was no store within 10 miles, and no ice and no money even if there had been ice. Â They had no refrigerator as that was a luxury. Â Whatever they needed, they pretty much had to figure out a way to do it or get it themselves.When the girls were old enough, they took care of the younger children. Â Their mother worked hard every day just to keep food on the table and keep her family clothed. Â She washed clothes in a washtub, rubbing the dirt from them on a washboard. Â She ironed the clothes with a flatiron that she heated on her wood burning kitchen stove. Â I can't even imagine how many loaves of bread she had to make each week for a family of eleven people, and sometimes twelve, when my great-grandfather or one of her brothers was staying with them, as they did frequently. Â The girls worked in the garden. Â They picked wild raspberries and blueberries in the summer, along with whatever other wild fruits could be found. Â They helped with the cooking and the cleaning and the canning of vegetables from the garden and the preserving of fruit and the making of jam and jelly and pickles. Â They churned cream to make butter and gathered eggs from the chickens. Â My Dad's oldest sister once remarked that she didn't have a childhood, because she was taking care of her baby brothers and sisters while she was growing up. Â That was no easy task in itself, for there were two sets of twins in that family.When the boys were young men, it was in the middle of the Depression. Â Money was scarce. Â So some of them headed west to the Dakotas and Montana to work. Â Dad and his brother Kenneth got jobs picking potatoes in Montana. Â Dad told me that there was a machine that was pulled by a team of horses or mules. Â That machine dug the potatoes out of the ground and deposited them on the surface. Â He and Kenneth went behind, bent over and picked up the potatoes and tossed them into a large wagon. Â It was a backbreaking job, but it provided money for the family. Â Dad and some of his brothers rode a train to the Dakotas to work on wheat thrashing crews. Â Riding in a passenger car was out of the question as there was no money for tickets, so they rode in empty boxcars. Â There were huge machines that did the same job that a combine does today, but there was a lot more physical work involved.In the winter the boys would work in the woods. Â They felled trees and loaded them on horse drawn wagons or sleds to be taken to the sawmill where they were cut into lumber. Â Dad was working in one of these lumberjack camps when he hurt one of his arms. Â The boss was going to send him home, but Dad convinced him that he could cook, so they kept him on. Â He said that he had to learn how to cook in a real big hurry, as a room full of hungry lumberjacks could get mean really fast! Â He must have figured it out because he was one of the best cooks I knew, next to Mother.Three of the girls became teachers to earn money for the family. Â At that time a college education wasn't necessary. Â All they needed was a teaching certificate. Â Each of them taught in country schools until they married.Even though all of Dad's family worked hard, they still had time for fun. Â In the summer they would go swimming in Twin lake close to their home. Â There was a small river that ran about a mile from the house, and they would go fishing. Â They would go to barn dances and house parties. Â My grandfather had a good singing voice and he could play the piano, so he entertained his family in that way from time to time. Â In the winter they would go sledding on the hill in the pasture across the driveway from the house. Â They visited relatives and relatives came to visit them. Â There was no television and I think it was after most of the kids had left home before they had a radio. My Dad and all of his siblings had wonderful senses of humor. Â Dad has told lots of stories about the pranks they would play, and I will tell you about those later.My Dad had a work ethic second to none. Â He worked in a filling station in Blackduck after he married Mom. Â He drove a gas truck, delivering gas or fuel oil to farms in the area. Â He drove a school bus for a time. Â He and Mom moved to St. Paul and stayed with my Grandma Paul when it became clear that Dad just couldn't make a living in the North. Â He worked for a time in a factory that made refrigerators and then found the job as a grain sampler in Willmar, where he worked until he retired. Â Even when he took on extra work in order to take care of Mom when she needed so much medical care, I never once heard him complain. There was a day that Dad came to see me while I still lived on the Eddy farm. Â I was hot and sweaty and dirty from working cleaning the hog barn. Â And I was roundly complaining about being so dirty. Â He just looked at me and said, "There is no shame in being dirty from hard work. Â The only shame is for being dirty from laziness." Â Another time when I had a job that I really disliked, he told me that even if I was digging a ditch, I should dig the best ditch that I possibly could. Â And that I should not do it to please a boss, but I should do it for the satisfaction of a job well done.I think that pretty much sums up my Dad.

title: Seamstress Extraordinaire
text: My Mother had a talent for sewing. Â I am not sure where she learned to sew, for she never said, but I suspect that it might have been from her mother, although I have never heard it mentioned that Grandma sewed.
