Â I just assume so, because at that time girls were taught homemaking skills. Â Most folks, particularly those who lived on farms or in small towns where clothing stores were scarce, made most everything they wore. Â This was in the Great Depression years and for many, there just wasn't money to spend on clothing. Â It was much more economical to buy or barter for fabric and sew what one needed.Mom didn't make quilts, but turned her talent to sewing clothing. Â I don't know what sewing machine she might have had in the early years of her marriage to Dad, but in the mid 1950's while we were living on the farm, I remember that Dad bought Mother a new Singer Sewing Machine. Â That was an event in our household. Â The sewing machine came in a wooden cabinet. Â The lid opened up and the machine was lifted up into place. Â The lid folded out so that it provided work space for holding fabric while it was being sewn. Â I still have that machine, but during the years it sat in storage, it has rusted some. Â I sure would like to get it refurbished, as it worked better than any machine I have had since.Mother and I were once looking at old photos. Â She pointed to this one and told me that she had taken an old coat of hers, ripped the seams apart and used the fabric to make me this little coat and bonnet. Â She remembered that it was sort of an aqua blue.She sewed these little dresses for me as well.I don't recall having any store bought outer clothing until I was well into high school. Â Each summer Mother would buy fabric and patterns on sale and sew my school clothes. Â One year when money was really scarce, Dad bought flour in cloth sacks that were printed fabric. Â Mom washed the flour sacks and made skirts and blouses for me to wear to school. Â At that time schools had a dress code and skirts were required for girls. Â Below are some photos of the dresses she made for my sister and me.After we moved to the farm, my family became involved in 4-H. Â Mom had taught me to sew, and she must have had the patience of Job to do it, as I would much rather have been out climbing trees or catching frogs or digging worms for fishing than sitting inside sewing. Â But teach me, she did. Â My 4-H projects each year were always sewing and gardening. Â One of the requirements for the sewing project was to make an outfit, and then there was a "fashion show" where 4-H members modeled their creations. Â Mom didn't sew a single stitch in the skirt and blouse that I made one year, even when I whined and cried that I couldn't do it right. Â She watched me sew, told me just what to do and made me rip out seams and sew them again when I didn't listen. Â That outfit won a blue ribbon at the fashion show and went on to win another at the State Fair. Â I gave the ribbons to Mom because I figured that she had earned them much more than I had!This is a photo of Mom wearing one of the dresses she sewed for herself and Dad wearing a shirt she made for him.I have always been in awe of Mom's sewing skills. Â What seemed to be easy for her were the things that I struggled to do. Â I will always be grateful to Mom for having the patience to teach me a skill that I learned to love. Â I have spent many happy hours at a sewing machine, and will probably continue to do so until I can't any more. Â Thank you, Mom.

title: Parents
text: There is a blog that I found recently that is written by a man who writes well on a variety of topics that I find interesting. Â He has been kind enough to comment on this blog, particularly expressing his good wishes after the fire in my building. Â He is going through a difficult time right now, as his mother is deteriorating in both physical and mental health and decisions have to be made. Â He remarked that he has come to the realization that he has only memories left.This caused me to think about my Dad. Â I think of him often. Â The last time I saw him, he was near death and didn't know who I was until I told him, nor did he recognize his grandson who was with me. Â That memory is not what I want to keep in my mind and heart, for at that time he bore little resemblance to the man who raised me.The man I choose to remember is the one who came home with a new lawn mower and had me convinced that it was my birthday present that year, before giving me the softball glove that I had been hounding him to get for me. This same man who, when I took the family car for a drive at age 16 and ran it out of oil, frying the engine, didn't get angry and yell, but patiently explained the inner workings of engines and that checking the oil was a good thing and those red lights had meaning that I needed to pay attention to. Â He then made sure that I knew how to check all the fluids in a car and how to change a tire, skills that have helped me since.This same man instilled in me the love of gardening. Â He worked along side me, tilling and planting and weeding. Â He sat with me in the middle of the tomato patch, salt shaker in hand and with me, ate tomatoes until we could eat no more. Â He showed me the fun of trying new things, and each year that we had a garden, we tried some new plant that we had not grown before, just for the fun of seeing what would happen.This same man took me fishing, renting a boat for the day and using the old, temperamental motor that he kept in the trunk of his car all summer long. Â He showed me how to choose tackle, how to bait a hook and taught me the patience needed to catch fish. Â And in the process, he showed me the beauty of nature around me.This same man took me back of the grove of trees at our home in the country and into the field, set up targets and showed me how to use a gun. Â He laughed at me when his old shotgun that I insisted I wanted to try set me back on my butt and he praised me when I hit the target. Â Although I don't hunt, he showed me how to safely carry a gun, how to make sure there was nothing beyond a target that a bullet would damage and to make sure I knew exactly what I was aiming at before I fired. Â He taught me how to cut up a deer and I have used that skill many times over the years, for sometimes, venison was all that we had to eat for meat.This same man kissed me goodbye every morning before he left for work, for the entire time I lived under his roof. Â And when I no longer lived close to him and communicated by telephone, he never failed to end a conversation by saying, "I sure love you, Sis."This same man worked sometimes three jobs at once to care for my mother who was so badly crippled with arthritis. Â And the same man who cared for her at home for many years after his retirement until she required more specialized care than he could give. Â When I once asked him how he could do this for all those years, he replied, "I love your mother." Â That was the only reason necessary for him.This is the man I remember, much more than the frail one in the nursing home. Â I think I may have to take the time to write down more of my memories of him, for myself, for my children and for my grandchildren who didn't have the privilege of knowing him.

title: Easily Amused
text: I don't have to watch TV or go to the movies for my entertainment. Â My neighborhood has four bars - one next door, one behind my building and two more in the next block. Â On any given night, but especially on the weekend, I can sit in my rocking chair next to a window that looks down onto the street below and be entertained.One of the establishments just recently added one of those rolling bars that is set up like a regular bar with a bartender and bar stools, except it is outdoors and the patrons on the stools sit, drink and pedal like mad as if they were on a bicycle. Â I don't know what the name of the contraption is, but it is the silliest looking thing. Â It gets even more silly when the patron sitting in the back forgets where he is, slides off his stool and winds up sitting in the middle of the street watching his ride and his drink disappear around the corner.Not very long ago we had a hard rain that left a big puddle in the middle of the alley that is across from my window. Â Folks use that alley to walk from one of the bars in the next block to the bar next door to my building. Â As I was sitting in my rocking chair in front of my window enjoying the cool evening breeze, I noticed two men walking my way. Â The walking part may be exaggerated. Â They were more shuffling along, holding each other up, taking extreme care to avoid the rain puddles, right up to the point where they came to the aforementioned big puddle. Â One man went to the right and the other to the left. Â Now that each no longer had the other to hang onto for support, both started to weave and side-step and both tried really hard to maintain balance.....until both finally gave up and sat down - in the middle of the puddle. Â The last I saw of them, they were happily splashing each other like a couple of kids in a bathtub.My all time favorite happened a couple of winters ago. Â Snow had been falling steadily all day. Â I like to watch the street below, with its old-fashioned looking street lights, turn Christmas card pretty with the snow. Â A fellow came out of the bar next door, made his way across the street and started to clean the snow off a car. Â He was meticulous about it, making sure the headlights and tail lights were clear of snow, getting the ice off of the windshield wipers and making sure that there was no snow on the hood, roof or any of the windows. Â It took him a while, as there had been about a foot of snow on the car, and he was having a time for himself, trying not to slip and slide. Â He had just finished, having done a really good job of it, when another fellow came along, looked at the first man, then at the car, shook the first man's hand, slapped him on the back, got into the car and drove away. Â The fellow who had spent so much time removing snow from the car just stood and looked at the empty parking space for a time, then put his hands in his pockets and slowly walked away. Â I wondered if he had forgotten that he had walked downtown and left his car home in his garage.I have always enjoyed people watching and my location makes it just that much more fun. Â I guess I really am easily amused.It is hot here. Â Not Texas or Oklahoma hot. Â Or desert hot. Â But hot for Minnesota. Â But then we whine when temps go above 85 degrees. Â We are heat wimps.And my air conditioning doesn't seem to be working all that well, due to the wiring that burned in the fire. Â I won't complain, however. Â I still have a home and it is a bit cooler in here than outside. My landlord's insurance people have been here. Â One of them ran a finger over the top of my freezer in the kitchen, which I had already washed down, and another checked out the top of my kitchen table. Â Did they really think that I would eat my meals on a table covered in gray smoke film for the four days that passed before they arrived? Â My living room got the worst of the smoke, and the gray film on the walls and woodwork is thick enough to write my name in, but that was ignored. Â Sigh.They declared my apartment in perfect condition so there will be nobody coming in to do any cleaning. Â I had hoped to at least get my carpets done, but it isn't to be. Â So I clean in the early mornings and after sundown in the evenings. Â I am way too old and too fat to be climbing up and down washing walls during the heat of the day. Â Which gives me a really good excuse to take a nap or read or sew or to do something else that is quiet and doesn't expend a lot of energy. Â I can live with that!

title: Fear
text: Fear is a strange thing. Â I have found that over the years, I am one of those people who is pretty good in a crisis. Â A friend is in a fearful situation and I can find the calming words to help. Â A kid comes into the house with blood dripping and I know just what to do. Â And I do it. Â And when the crisis has passed and the fear is gone, only then will I quietly fall apart.I have also found that as I get older, my reaction to the fear in a crisis manifests itself in altogether different ways. Â Time was that a few tears would dissolve away the fear, but now, my body betrays me. Â This was brought home to me this past weekend. Â I thought I was just fine, although my apartment building was on fire. Â One of the other tenants was in hysterics and another seemed to deal with the fear by becoming angry. Â I was calm. Â I had escaped the smoke that had threatened to take away my ability to breathe and had survived to see my grandchildren grow up and I would probably achieve my goal of living long enough to be a problem to my children, although some of them might say that I have already attained that goal. Â (I once told my youngest daughter that my goal in life was to live long enough to be a problem to my children. Â She replied that my work here was done. Â I love her sense of humor.) Â And then, while I was standing with a police officer, discussing options should I be unable to return to my apartment, my legs began to shake, uncontrollably. Â You remember those old Saturday morning cartoons where the hero is afraid and he stands there with his knees knocking? Â Yep, I found that it really happens.I think that my children were a bit fearful as well. Â Since the fire, they have been calling often, sometimes a couple of times a day. Â Checking up on Mom. Â Making sure that I am alright. Â The daughter living closest to me brought fans to help remove the smoke smell, as well as my supper so I didn't have to worry about cooking anything. Â She asked if I wanted to go home with her, but I declined even though I appreciated the offer. Â They have all offered to come and help with the scrubbing and cleaning and I know that if I needed help with that, they would be here. Â They have all done things like this for me in the past.I won't ask for help this time. Â They all have kids to care for and jobs to deal with. Â I am retired and have all the time in the world. Â And I think that the physical work of getting my apartment back to normal is a good way to work through any lingering fear. Â My legs no longer shake. Â I am calm. Â But my body is still reacting by waking me up a couple of times during the past two nights, telling me that I have to get out of bed and check to make sure all is well. Â I expect this will go away after a time. Â I have learned a lesson about fear. Â It enters my being unannounced and unwelcomed. Â The trick is to not allow fear to take control. Â I Â refuse to live a life in fear of what might happen, for that is probably worse than the actual event. Â Now if I can just convince my aging body that all is well, I can get back to working at being a problem to my children!

title: Fire
text: How quickly a persons Â life can change. Â One minute I am washing a sink load of dishes and the next I am sitting across the street watching our local firemen fighting the fire in my Â building.I first smelled the smoke. Â I didn't think too much about it. Â I live in a downtown apartment and all sorts of smells reach my windows from time to time. Â But then I could see the smoke pouring out of the vents in my floors, so I ran into my bedroom to call 911 and get dressed. Â By the time that was accomplished, the smoke was so thick that I couldn't find my dogs, who were at the other end of my apartment. Â I could barely breathe and I had to leave them. Â Once outside, a policeman was asking me about the other tenants, as some weren't responding to knocks at their doors. Â When all of the people were accounted for, I told them that I'd had to leave without my Yorkies. Â Bless them, they went upstairs, found the dogs and brought them down to me. Even before the smoke had cleared, there were firemen in my apartment looking for my cat, Kizzie. Â They looked everywhere, as I have since, and so far she is nowhere to be found. Â I don't know if she is really well hidden or if she got out of the building. Â All I can do is keep looking. I am extremely fortunate that my apartment is still usable. Â My daughter went to the store, bought box fans and brought them to me. Â They are in my windows as I write, trying to get rid of the smoke smell. Â I will have to wash everything down, but at least I still have walls to wash. Â The poor lady in the apartment where the fire started has nothing. I have learned a couple of things from this experience. Â I don't have a cell phone to keep family phone numbers handy, so I need to write them down and put them, along with my most important papers somewhere near the door of my apartment. Â I need to make sure that there is enough cash included to get me through a few days. Â I have put the dogs' harnesses on them so if I should ever again have to leave quickly, all I have to do is snap on the leashes and go. Â And as soon as I finish washing the smoke from my walls, cupboards, etc., I will get all of my photos onto DVDs and give each of my children a copy.I thought I was prepared, but it only took one incident like this to point out to me that I had left my home with only my keys and the clothes I was wearing. Â I had no phone numbers, no money and no pets. Â I will have to do better than that.P.S. Â About midnight, Kizzie the cat turned up. Â I have no clue where in the apartment she had been hiding, but she is alive and well with no apparent problems from all of the smoke. Â So all of us in my little Home Sweet Home are accounted for and are doing just fine. Â Thank you, God.

title: What has America Become
text: I recently ran across this letter to the editor. Â I don't know the gentleman who wrote it, but in my opinion, he is spot on and expresses much better than I can the thoughts I have had since I stopped looking at the world through rose colored glasses and started paying attention to what is going on around us."What has America Become?Editor,Has America become the land of the special interest and home of the double standard?Lets see: Â if we lie to the Congress, it's a felony and if the congress lies to us its just politics; Â if we dislike a black person, we're racist and if a black dislikes whites, it's their 1st Amendment right; Â the government spends millions to rehabilitate criminals and they do almost nothing for the victims; Â in public schools you can teach that homosexuality is OK, but you better not use the word of God in the process; Â you can kill an unborn child, but its wrong to execute a mass murderer; Â we don't burn books in America, we now rewrite them; Â we got rid of the communist and socialist threat by renaming them progressives; Â we are unable close our border with Mexico but have no problem protecting the 38th parallel in Korea; Â if you protest against President Obama's policies you're a terrorist, but if you burned an American flag or George Bush in effigy it was your 1st Amendment right.You can have pornography on TV or the internet, but you better not put a nativity scene in a public park during Christmas; Â we have eliminated all criminals in America, they are now called sick people; Â we can use a human fetus for medical research, but its wrong to use an animal.We take money from those who work hard for it and give it to those who don't want to work; Â we all support the Constitution, but only when it supports our political ideology; Â we still have freedom of speech, but only if we are being politically correct; Â parenting has been replaced with Ritalin and video games; Â the land of opportunity is now the land of hand outs; Â the similarity between Hurricane Katrina and the gulf oil spill is that neither president did anything to help.And how do we handle a major crisis today? Â The government appoints a committee to determine who's at fault, then threatens them, passes a law, raises our taxes and tells us the problem is solved so they can get back to their reelection campaign.What has happened to the land of the free and home of the brave?--Ken HuberÂ  Tawas City"I'm not sure just when this was written, but in light of the many government scandals of late, I'm thinking that the rabbit hole into which we are falling has been dug much deeper recently. Â God help us all.

title: Schedule for Tomorrow
text: I thought I would give you government types a bit of a break tomorrow. Â Lord knows, you must be working really hard, keeping track of our conversations, internet activity and movements. Â So here is my schedule for tomorrow.8:50 AM - leave my apartment and walk to bus stop9:00 AM - enter bus9:35 AM - transfer from one bus to another (You might want to keep an eye on this. Â Transfer may or may not occur, depending on the drivers schedule.)9:50 AM - depart bus for grocery store (This one may be a bit difficult for you as I pay cash for my purchases, so there will be no credit card transactions to consult to let you know what I buy. Â To help you out with this, my grocery list includes cat food, carrots, frozen green beans, fresh strawberries and maybe a frozen turkey. Â I haven't decided for sure about the turkey. Â But I am sure if you study the information from all of the cameras inside the store, you can find out what I buy.)10:50 AM - enter bus at bus stop outside store11:00 AM - arrive at bus stop near my apartment Â (Now, at this point, I may or may not stop to talk with a friend who has a small business close by. Â You are screwed there, as she has no surveillance equipment in her shop, but I have no doubt that you can overcome that problem.)11:20 AM - enter apartment building and check my mailbox Â (If I have any mail, chances are pretty good that it will be junk mail. Â I don't mind the grocery store ads or even the ones from the people who want to fix the crack in the windshield of the car that I do not own, but I am getting really irritated with the Cremation Society wanting me to sign up and pre pay. Â I am not ready for their services as yet, so they can just leave me alone, thank you so much.)The rest of my day will be taken up with household chores (My kitchen floor really needs a scrubbing and I have a basket of clothes to fold.) and I will be canning the carrots and green beans to use when I make my next batch of food for my dogs. Â I probably will forget about my afternoon nap as I can not leave my pressure canner unattended.However, here is a heads up for the evening. Â I will most likely be checking Facebook to see if any of my children have posted new photos. Â And I will be reading Drudge Report, so just get over it. The rest of my evening will be taken up with some hand sewing on a quilt that I am working on, and I will most likely, between 8:00 PM and 9:30 PM be watching Masterpiece Mystery on PBS while I sew.So there you have it. Â Now that you know what my schedule is, you can go spy on someone else. Â Have a good day.

title: Breakfast From Food Storage
text: I was in a hurry this morning. Â I needed to finish a few things around the apartment before watching my granddaughters dance this afternoon via live feed from Nationals in Kansas City. Â (Who am I kidding. Â I am retired. Â I don't have a schedule. Â Just makes me sound important to pretend to have one.) Â At any rate, I decided to go with quick and easy for breakfast, which turned out to be lunch as well.I buy very few convenience foods, so the ones I have are usually homemade. Â Today I had a hankering for biscuits and sausage gravy.A few weeks ago I made some homemade Bisquick mix, so I used it to stir up a pan of biscuits. Â They were good. Â Not as good as my homemade from scratch biscuits, which are awesome, but good, none the less. Â While the biscuits were baking, I got out a jar of homemade chicken gravy mix and got a couple cups of gravy heating on the stove. Â When it had thickened, I added a half-pint jar of home canned crumbled sausage and let it simmer. Â Some say that you should not can sausage that contains sage, but this sausage has sage in it, and it turned out really good. Â In the time it took to bake the biscuits, breakfast was ready.I love my food storage. Â It makes life so much easier for me. Â I now go to the grocery only to replenish what I have used or if there is something on sale that week that I want to buy. Â Last winter when the snow was falling and the sidewalks were full of ice, I only had to go out to the store a couple of times, and that was by choice and not by necessity. Â Sometimes folks laugh at me when I am busy canning hamburger or tomato sauce or peaches. Â They can't figure out why I bother. Â After all, those things are on the store shelves, so why go to all that work.In the middle of winter when it is cold and windy, or in the summer when storms are predicted and people are standing in line to buy a loaf of bread or a gallon of milk, that is when I have the last laugh, because I am snug in my little apartment, happily doing whatever I want to do without having to run to the store.Here are the recipes for my homemade convenience foods. Â I have gleaned these recipes from the internet and have no idea of their original source.Homemade Bisquick Mix9 cups sifted all-purpose flour1/3 cup double-acting baking powder1 tablespoon salt1 teaspoon cream of tartar1/4 cup sugar2 cups shortening which does not require refrigerationWhisk together the dry ingredients. Â Cut in the shortening (I used a hand held electric mixer) until the mixture resembles cornmeal. Â Store in an airtight container.To make biscuits, stir together 3 parts Mix and 1 part water. Â If too sticky, add more mix. Â If too dry, add more water. Â Gently knead about 10 times. Â Cut biscuits, place on baking sheet and bake at 350 degrees until lightly browned.Homemade Chicken Gravy MixMakes about 2 cups of mix.1-1/3 cups powdered milk3/4 cup flour3 tablespoons chicken bouillon granules1/4 teaspoon sage1/4 teaspoon onion powder1/4 teaspoon garlic powder1/8 teaspoon pepperMix well and store in an airtight container.To use, whisk together 1 part Mix with 2 parts water. Â Stir over medium heat until thickened and bubbly.Note: Â I usually quadruple this recipe and store it in quart size canning jars. Â I use it not only for gravy, but to thicken chicken stew or chicken pot pie, and often will use it in place of a can of cream soup in a casserole recipe.Food storage - Makes all the sense in the world to me.

title: Brother of Dancers
text: This Dance thing doesn't involve just my granddaughters. Â It is a family affair. Â Mom, Dad and little brother Jacob are at the competitions, and I think Jacob does well with it all. Â But sometimes it just tires a fella out.I've got the live feed thing for the Nationals competition figured out. Â I was able to watch, from my computer, Boston do her solo dance.This is Boston with her dance teacher, Katie, right after Boston's performance.Boston was awesome! Â She nailed it! Â I am so proud of both Boston and Maddie. Â (Yes, Grandma is bragging. Â It is what we Grandmas do. Â It is our job.)Maddie has one performance with a group on Friday and both have several dances Saturday and Sunday. Â And you can bet that this Grandma will be spending the weekend at her computer, cheering both of them on!Sometimes.....not always.....but sometimes I can be such a dunderhead. My son, daughter-in-law and their three children are in Kansas City for Boston and Maddie's dance competition at Nationals. Â Incidentally, the kids thought it was really cool that they drove in four states on their way to Kansas City. Â Anyway, David called to let me know what time Maddie and Boston would be dancing last evening and this morning. Â Maddie was first last evening. Â And this is where the dunderhead part comes in.Staci had left a link on Facebook so those interested could watch the girls dance on a live feed. Â I found the site, got logged in and was really excited to watch my beautiful grandbaby dance. Â I love to watch her dance. Â She so clearly loves what she is doing. Â But there was a monkey wrench thrown into the works. Â This competition is so huge that there are three stages of performers going on at one time. Â And the live feed that I had in front of me was not the stage where she was scheduled to dance. Â I clicked on links, searched the entire website and finally found the feed for the stage where she was performing.....10 minutes after she and the two girls in her trio had completed their performance. Â AAARRRGGGH!Here is Maddie in the center, with the other girls who form the trio, just before they went on stage. Â I know that Maddie will forgive me for being a dunderhead and missing her dance, because she loves her Grandma. Â Her Dad tells me that the girls did an awesome job.Boston's solo performance is scheduled for later this morning and I am ready. Â I have bookmarked the page I need to open to see her dance, I have a fresh pot of coffee brewing and there are appropriate snacks at my elbow. Â I'm not gonna miss this one!Good luck, girls. Â Knock their socks off!

title: Lazy
text: I have gotten lazy. Â I freely admit it after reasoning this morning that there was no other word for my behavior.A couple of years ago I took the time to make my own dog food. Â Then I got lazy and went back to buying the dry kind at the grocery. Â Even the increase in the price of commercial dog food didn't deter me. Â Until today.I have two Yorkies. Â They need to be fed. Â I am nearly out of dry dog food. Â To get more food, I need to put on shoes along with the rest of my clothes and take the bus to the store. Â I have arthritis, which has been a bit worse than usual this spring. Â The kind of arthritis I have causes joints to ache and my feet and ankles to swell. Â My back tends to go out more often than I do. Â This isn't a complaint, just a statement of fact. Â Lots of people are in far more pain with problems much worse than mine. Â This morning I couldn't get my fat foot into my left shoe. Â No way. Â Wasn't going to happen. Â That's when I decided that I had gotten lazy.As I sat grumbling about the fact that I just wasn't going to be going anywhere barefoot today I got to thinking that if I hadn't gotten so lazy and stopped making my own dog food, I wouldn't be sitting here grumbling about the fact that I couldn't go anywhere today. Â After all, I am forever preaching about being prepared, and I am at least in the food department. Â Time to put my money where my mouth is. I dug into my stores and got out a bag of rice. Â Next I went to my canned goods shelves and got two quarts of home canned sliced carrots along with four pint jars of diced pork butt. Â I had experimented with canning pork butt when it was on sale and was less than thrilled with the results, but I'll bet the dogs will love it. Â I can't stand to waste anything. Â Also grabbed a jar of turkey broth. Â Dumped the broth and some water into a pot. Â Added the rice and cooked it until it was done and fluffy. Â I think the broth will add to the flavor and make the dogs happy. Â When the rice had cooled down some I tossed it into a big bowl and added the carrots and pork. Â Got in there with my hands and mixed the whole works together. Â Hands are the very best kitchen tools ever made.By this time Lily and Jessie Jane were dancing around my feet. Â They sure did like the smells coming from this big bowl. Â Time to see if they liked the taste as well as the smells. Â Put about a half a cup in each of two small bowls and set the bowls on the floor. Â I'm not really sure if they ate the dog food or just inhaled it, but it was a rousing success.So now I have a couple of quart bags of dog food in the fridge for their meals in the next few days and another eight bags in the freezer. Â I don't know why it took me so long to get back to making their food. Â (Yes, I do. Â I got lazy.) Â It is much better for them than the stuff that I was buying. Â I am not sure of the ages of my Yorkies as I got them when they were already older, but I am guessing they are between 10 and 12 years. Â Maybe if I continue giving them good homemade food, I just might be able to enjoy them for many more years.

title: Good Morning...or Not
text: So.....I wake up early this morning, not to the sounds of cute little birds singing outside my window, but to wave after wave of sirens going by. Â I have no idea what is going on. Â I can't see anything unusual from my windows, nor do I smell any smoke. Â I guess that is a good thing. Â I won't have to evacuate.The sounds of the sirens have awakened my little nine-pound bundle of energy named Lilly, the Yorkie. Â She doesn't bark at sirens. Â But she is awake and she wants the dog biscuit she gets upon my awakening each morning. Â And she wants it now! Â She has me well trained. Â I tell her that in doggy years she is at the very least, a seventy year old woman who should be asleep at this hour, rather than yipping at my bedroom door. Â She ignores me. Â So to keep her from annoying my neighbors, I get up.On my way to the treat jar in the kitchen, I slip and slide in a pool of hair ball cat puke. Â Thank you so very much, Kizzie the cat. Â Kizzie has been leaving me similar gifts this week. Â I know that this is fairly normal for a cat to hack up a hair ball now and then, but I really hope she is finished with this for a while.By the time I clean off the bottom of my foot and wipe up the mess on the floor, Lilly is in a frenzy of what I call the Yorkie Dance Team Cookie Dance. Â Her sister, Jessie Jane, having been awakened by all the commotion, has joined in the dance. Â The only good thing I can say is that Jessie does her Cookie Dance silently. Â I don't think I have ever heard her bark. Â I will never understand why they get so excited about a tiny bit of rock hard, foul smelling dog biscuit. Â But they do. Â Every morning.My little old lady pooches settle back down in their beds for a nap, which will last pretty much the whole morning. Â Kizzie takes her place in the chair by the window to keep an eye on the world outside. Â I am left here............. without a calming cigarette.The legislature in my state has decided to double the tax on cigarettes to help pay for a Â fancy new football stadium. Â And because I am ornery enough to refuse to contribute one thin dime towards a stadium being built for a bunch of over paid jocks that I will never see play in said stadium because I can't afford the price of a ticket, I will buy no more cigarettes. Â I don't know which is worse - the withdrawl that I am going through or listening to the self-righteous non-smokers pontificate about how healthier I will be because I can't afford cigarettes any more.I don't know about you, but I am really tired of government "helping" me. Â I have known for quite some time that quitting smoking was in my near future. Â But I resent the hell out of government forcing me to quit by jacking up the price of a pack. Â I think that this would have been much easier for me if I had the choice of making that decision on my own, in my own time. Â I probably would have, left to my own choices in the matter, been much less grumpy.So....how is your day going so far?

title: Cranky
text: I will be back in a week or so, when hopefully I won't be nearly as cranky as I am right now.Talk among yourselves.

title: Scoundrels
text: I have been enjoying working on my family history these cool and rainy days when I really don't want to get wet unless it is by taking a nice hot shower. Â I have been told, over the years, that I should not worry about going out in the rain because I most definitely am not made of sugar, and therefore will not melt, but all the same, walking in the rain is not a favorite pastime of mine. Â So here at my computer I sit, delving into the lives of so many who have gone before me.I marvel at the strength of some of these people. Â Those who, in the early 1600's, came to these shores by ship from Scotland and England, others who traveled by covered wagon from Indiana to Minnesota, and later, those who left the southern part of this state to make a home in the forests of northern Minnesota, at a time when roads were nearly nonexistent. Â Their courage is amazing.Unlike many who seek their ancestors, I don't do it through rose colored glasses. Â Most were fine, upstanding individuals who went on to raise families and have descendants of whom they would be proud. Â But now and then I come upon a scoundrel, and it is fun for me to gather information about these folks. Â Especially if said scoundrel belongs to a branch of my family that has become name proud and firmly believes that each and every member of this family would qualify for sainthood. Â I can't help it. Â My sense of humor gets in the way of that sort of pride.Another family researcher wrote about the sterling qualities of an ancestor who fought in the Civil War. Â Granted, he fought in many major battles, many of which are written into books on that subject. Â But this particular researcher neglected to mention that this same ancestor was busted down to Private and lost three months pay for being drunk on guard duty.Another ancestor was such a nasty drunk that he was forced to leave the village where he lived. Â According to various court records, he had numerous altercations with neighbors and it seems that they got tired of dealing with him. Â I am happy to report that that was the only instance I have found of a family member being ridden out of town on a rail.One branch of my family had an inclination to marry within the family. Â I realize that a couple of hundred years ago the gene pool was pretty small and there may not have been all that many to choose from. Â But many in this family seemed to prefer cousins. Â I sometimes wonder why I wasn't born with one eye in the middle of my forehead and three ears. Â But it seems that this inclination died out in later generations.There is no disrespect for these ancestors of mine. Â But while looking for facts from the past I have found that many genealogists brag that their ancestors came over on the Mayflower, traveled west with Lewis and Clark, were heroic beyond belief in war time, or were sired by royalty. Â My scoundrels tend to keep any bragging to a minimum. Â They keep me grounded and make them more real to me as people who were human and had the faults of humanity.And they most definitely make things more interesting.

title: Who Will Take My Place
text: Usually, of an evening, after my dishes are done, after the dogs have had their nightly snoogles and pets and the cat has had my undivided attention for a time, I will settle down to a few hours of relaxation. Â I don't care to just sit, for that makes me a bit crazy, so I will sew or crochet or read others blogs or maybe a good book. Â But lately I have felt the need to get back to working on my family history. Â I have shamefully neglected it for quite some time and in an ill-conceived idea of combining two of my genealogy programs into one, I pretty much screwed up both of them yesterday, making it necessary to start again with the entering of information. Thankfully, I have an external hard drive that contains most of what I messed up, along with the files and photos stored in my computer, so the job isn't all that daunting.....just time consuming. Â After I had grumbled a while about my lack of foresight as to what would happen when combining programs, and about the time it takes to enter everything the right way, I got to thinking that some of my ancestors have waited several centuries to be acknowledged. Â I guess with that in mind, a few days of work on my part isn't all that important.I also found the following on my external hard drive. Â I saved it a few years ago and had forgotten about it. Â I thought I might share it, for it expresses how I feel about my family history.We Are The Chosen In each family there is one who seems called to find the ancestors. Â To put flesh on their bones and make them live again, to tell the family story and to feel that somehow they know and approve.Doing genealogy is not a cold gathering of facts but, instead, breathing life into all who have gone before.We are the story tellers of the tribe. Â  All tribes have one. Â We have been called, as it were, by our genes. Â Those who have gone before cry out to us, "Tell our story." Â So, we do.In finding them, we somehow find ourselves. Â How many graves have I stood before now and cried? Â I have lost count. Â How many times have I told the ancestors, "You have a wonderful family; you would be proud of us." Â How many times have I walked up to a grave and felt somehow there was love there for me? Â I cannot say.It goes beyond just documenting facts. Â It goes to who am I and why I do the things I do. Â It goes to seeing a cemetery about to be lost forever to weeds and indifference and saying I can't let this happen.The bones here are bones of my bone and flesh of my flesh. Â It goes to doing something about it. Â It goes to pride in what our ancestors were able to accomplish, how they contributed to what we are today. It goes to respecting their hardships and losses, their never giving in or giving up, their resoluteness to go on and build a life for their family. Â It goes to deep pride that the fathers fought and some died to make and keep us a Nation. Â It goes to a deep and immense understanding that they were doing it for us.It is of equal pride and love that our mothers struggled to give us birth, without them we could not exist, and so we love each one, as far back as we can reach. Â That we might be born who we are. Â That we might remember them. Â So we do. With love and caring and scribing each fact of their existence, because we are they and they are the sum of who we are. Â So, as a scribe called, I tell the story of my family.It is up to that one called in the next generation to answer the call and take my place in the long line of family storytellers. That is why I do my family genealogy, and that is what calls those young and old to step up and restore the memory or greet those whom we had never known before.(Unknown Author)As each of my years fly on by, and indeed they do seem to fly these days, it becomes more important than ever to me to complete as much of this family research as I can. Â I worry sometimes that none of my descendants will care enough to continue this journey after I am gone. Â I hope and pray that at least one will be "The Chosen."

title: Dance Recital 2013
text: It's that time of year again for one of my most favorite things to do - attend my granddaughters dance recital. Â This year, there were a couple of bonuses for me.The first was when David and Jacob picked me up about noon. Â After we arrived at their home, Jacob and I had a great afternoon. Â We helped his Dad plant corn in the garden. Â Well, Jacob helped and Grandma did what she does best - supervise. Â Jacob showed me how high he could go on his swing and how far he could fly when he jumped off. Â He flies pretty well. Â And he showed me how high his toy rocket could fly and how well he can catch a ball with his baseball glove. Â We played some board games and I was trounced, and we read books and watched a little TV together. Â It was a busy afternoon that I thoroughly enjoyed. Â And in between all the activities that Jacob had for us, it was really nice to be able to sit with my son and just talk. Â We don't get a chance to do that very often.Then, after a grilled chicken supper, it was on to the recital. Â David was running a few minutes late, which is understandable when you are dealing with a slow Mom and an active 5 year old! Â Unfortunately, about half-way to the school where the recital is held, we discovered that our tickets were sitting on the kitchen counter back at the house, which did us no good at all. Â So after backtracking to retrieve the tickets, we still managed to arrived in time.The recital was wonderful. Â Both of my beautiful granddaughters (Yes. Â I am bragging. Â Grandmas get to brag. Â It says so in the bylaws.) are on competition teams, and this year I got to see some of the dances they performed at the various competitions. Â I think that this recital featured more of the competition teams dances than had previous recitals. Â Because I can't get to their competitions, this was extra special fun for me to see them dance these dances in person. Â They were great! Â I loved every second of it. Â I am so proud of these two girls, who put their hearts and souls into their art, and it shows.A lot of credit has to go to Boston and Maddie's parents. Â Not only do they run them back and forth for practice sessions and lessons at the Jete Dance Centre, but they spend many weekends at competitions with them. And Staci is with the girls backstage, helping with costume changes and hair styles for each number. Â David always participates in the "Daddy - Daughter Dance" which is really fun to see. There is another bonus for me at recital time. Â I get to see people that I rarely have the chance to see at other times. Â Staci's parents were there and it is always good for me when I can see them. Â This year, two of the girls Great-Aunts attended as well. Â They were seated in a location too far away for conversation, but afterward Janet took her sister, Jeanine home, and then drove me home as well. Â We all had time then for a nice chat. Â I was so glad that they were able to be there.I just can't think of a better way to spend a Saturday, and I am making my reservation for next year. Â Wouldn't miss it for anything!

title: Phone Company
text: I had to call my phone company yesterday. Â I hadn't received my bill in the mail for this month. Â The girl who answered my call was very helpful and within a couple of minutes I had the problem straightened out.But then came the obligatory selling of new and improved services to the customer, which is me! Â The poor girl didn't know who she was dealing with.She wanted me to switch from whatever television cable service I had, to the one her company was offering. Â I told her that I didn't subscribe to a cable service. Â She said that I must have aÂ satelliteÂ service, to which I replied that no, I didn't haveÂ satellite, either. Â Well, how did I watch TV without cable orÂ satellite? Â I told her that I have an inside antenna that picks up a couple of local stations and PBS. Â Well, she said, don't you have favorite shows you want to watch every week? Â I told her that I run my TV maybe a couple of hours each month and that I don't have favorite programs except maybe Antiques Roadshow, and I watch that on my computer.So we moved on to the telephone services offered, which are many. Â She carefully explained each one and told me about the huge savings that I would have by spending more money on more services. Â When she was finished, I gently told her that I was completely happy with the few services I ordered originally, thank you very much.Then we talked about cell phones. Â She explained to me about all of the wonderful services that could be mine for my cell phone. Â I thought she was going to cry when I told her as nicely as I could that I didn't have a cell phone. Â But everyone has a cell phone, she told me. Â Not me, I told her. Â But what happens when your car breaks down on the freeway, she wanted to know. Â I think I pushed her over the edge when I told her that I don't own a car, either.

title: Sugar Glider
text: This is a Sugar Glider.And just so my family doesn't panic... no, it is not mine. Â I know that I have dragged home a variety of four-footed furry friends over the years, but not this time.My friend and former employer, Starla, got the Sugar Glider a couple of weeks ago, so I had to go down to her shop next door to see it. Â I didn't think that there was anyone worse than me for dragging home animals, but I think she has me beat. Â She told me that Sugar Gliders stay small and that they can glide through the air like a flying squirrel. Â They also like to spend time in pouches. Â She had found some, but they were expensive, so she asked me would I sew up some pouches for her if she bought some fabric. Â So that's what I've been doing for the last couple of days.The pouches are lined and the strings are long enough for Starla to tie around her neck to carry the Glider that way to help it bond with her, or they can be tied to the top of the cage for it to sleep in. Â It is a good thing that I made fourteen of the pouches, for by the time I finished them, she had gotten a second Glider. Â It seems that they do better if there are more than just one. Â It was kind of fun to do something a bit different from the routine, and gave me an excellent excuse to put off the rest of my spring cleaning for a couple of days!I won't be getting a Sugar Glider because I have visiting rights. Â And that is enough.

title: Dear Mother Nature...
text: Just in case you hadn't noticed, it is Spring. Â It has been Spring now for several weeks.There is a little poem that I am sure you have heard:"March windsAnd April showersBring forthMay flowers."Nowhere does it mention May SNOWS!Enough, already!Love, Vicki

title: Shelter in Place
text: Apparently, that's what I did today.It seems that about a half hour after I got home from the grocery store, there was an explosion and fire at the malting plant located about four blocks from my home. Â According to the news reports I read online later, the explosion shook neighbors houses. Â I didn't feel a thing. Â I saw no smoke, but I did hear lots and lots of sirens, and then the sound of helicopters, which I think must have been local news people checking out the fire. Â Later in the day I saw that there was a message on my phone, and when I checked it, I found that it was an automated call from the sheriffs office telling residents within a mile radius of the plant to shelter in place and stay indoors.The malting plant has several large grain silos, and I expect that a fire in even one of them could be nasty. Â I am told that grain dust is extremelyÂ flammableÂ  Â I am glad that it was a relatively minor event. Â There have been way too many things blowing up lately.So... I sheltered in place and didn't even know it.

title: Music Sooths the Soul
text: Today I have been busy doing those nasty jobs that just don't seem to get done by themselves. Â I would rather be doing about a dozen other things instead of scrubbing and cleaning and rearranging cupboards and closets. Â As my cleaning fairy is on strike, the only way this spring cleaning is going to get done is if I do it myself. Â Darn.Usually I like the peace and quiet of my little apartment. Â But today I needed something to distract me from the dust and grime that tends to accumulate over the winter. Â When I couldn't find a radio station that I liked, I remembered that my computer came with the Pandora program, so I set it up to play the kind of music I like. Â I had been grumbling under my breath about baked on spills in my oven and cat hair that clings to every surface. Â I think I have washed away enough hair for a whole new cat. But after about a half hour of music, I found that I really didn't mind the scrubbing and mucking out. Â I found myself singing along with the music. Â That is kind of scary because I can't carry a tune in a bucket. Â I get that from my Dad. Â My sister and I never fought about who got to sit next to Dad in church. Â We fought about who had to sit next to him, because when the hymns were sung, he was always out of tune. Â Which is kind of sad, because he loved to sing. Â I can still remember him singing to me when I was just a itty bitty girl. Â He loved old cowboy songs and many a night he would rock me to sleep to the tune of "Red River Valley" or some other old timey song. Â Funny, I never noticed that he sang out of tune then. Â But then, I was just a little girl who loved to have her Daddy sing her to sleep and not a judgemental teenager who found fault with her parents at every opportunity. Maybe that is the sad part, that when we grow older, we look for the bad and don't take the time to just enjoy the good, whether it is slightly out of tune or not.

title: Ice Age?
text: So...it is Monday morning and there is snow in the forecast - again. Â What to do, what to do. Â I could stand outside, shake my fist at the sky and yell all sorts of words that if I heard my grandchildren say them, I would strongly suggest washing their mouths out with soap. Â Or I could let down the blinds so I can't see flakes falling - again, and curl up with a good book and a cup of hot chocolate.I vote for the book and hot chocolate. Â I really wish now that I hadn't watched a PBS documentary last evening that had to do with the possibility of another Ice Age. Â I am beginning to be a little bit afraid.

title: 39 Things...
text: The third week of April is nearly over. Â Snowflakes are gently falling outside my window. Â I am told by a grinning weatherman that by tomorrow I should be ankle deep in snow and slush. Â It is the kind of day that could use a chuckle or two. Â I got the following from a blog. Â My fantastic memory, or lack thereof, can't remember whose blog it was, so I can't give credit. Â If it was yours, let me know and I will be happy to mention it.Â 39 Things..."WE" should have learned by now...1. Never, under any circumstances, take a sleeping pill and a laxative on the same night.2. Don't worry about what people think, they don't do it very often.3. Going to church doesn't make you a Christian anymore than standing in a garage makes you a car.4. Artificial intelligence is no match for natural stupidity.5. If you must choose between two evils, pick the one you've never tried before.6. My idea of housework is to sweep the room with a glance.7. Not one shred of evidence supports the notion that life is serious.8. It is easier to get forgiveness than permission.9. For every action, there is an equal and opposite government program.10. If you look like your passport picture, you probably need the trip.11. Bills travel through the mail at twice the speed of cheques.12. A conscience is what hurts when all of your other parts feel so good.13. Eat well, stay fit, die anyway.14. Men are from earth. Women are from earth. Deal with it.15. No man has ever been shot while doing the dishes.16. A balanced diet is a biscuit in each hand.17. Middle age is when broadness of the mind and narrowness of the waist change places.18. Opportunities always look bigger going than coming.19. Junk is something you've kept for years and throw away three weeks before you need it.20. There is always one more imbecile than you counted on.21. Experience is a wonderful thing. It enables you toÂ recognizeÂ a mistake when you make it again.22. By the time you can make ends meet, they move the ends.23. Thou shalt not weigh more than thy fridge.24. Someone who thinks logically provides a nice contrast to the real world.25. It's not the jeans that make your bum look fat.26. If you had to identify, in 1 word, the reason why the human race has not achieved, & never will achieve, its full potential, that word would be "meetings".27. There is a very fine line between "hobby" and "mental illness".28. People who want to share their religious views with you almost never want you to share yours with them.29. You should not confuse your career with your life.30. Nobody cares if you can't dance well. Just get up and dance.31. Never lick a steak knife.32. The most destructive force in the universe is gossip.33. You will never find anybody who can give you a clear and compelling reason why we put the clocks back.34. You should never say anything to a woman that even remotely suggests that you think she's pregnant unless you can see an actual baby emerging from her at that moment.35. There comes a time when you should stop expecting other people to make a big deal about your birthday. That time is age eleven.36. The one thing that unites all human beings, regardless of age, gender, religion, economic status or ethnic background, is that, deep down inside, we ALL believe that we are above average drivers.37. A person, who is nice to you, but rude to the waiter, is not a nice person.38. Your friends love you anyway.39. Never be afraid to try something new. Remember that a lone amateur built the Ark. A large group of professionals built the Titanic.I hope wherever you are that there are blue skies, warm sunshine, gentle breezes and spring flowers. Â Send some my way, please!

title: Is It Spring Yet?
text: The calendar says it is, but looking outside, I'm not so sure. Â I saw a couple of snowflakes drift past my window earlier, and it looks like there may be some more of that nasty white stuff headed this way. Â Mother Nature has a mean streak!I can't complain too much. Â Well, actually, I can, but it does no good, so why bother. Â Yesterday was one of the nicest days I have seen in a while, so I took advantage of it and was out and about. My local grocery had whole boneless hams on sale, as well as sausage, so I got some of each and canned it up today. Â I wound up with 11 pints of ham cubes, which will be really good in ham and scalloped potato dishes, and 26 half pints of sausage. Â Sausage gravy over homemade biscuits, here I come. Â Love the sausage mixed with scrambled eggs and topped with a little cheese, too.Tomorrow morning I'll remove the rings, wash the jars and label them. Â Then onto the shelves they go until I get a craving for something delicious and homemade.The Cub Foods store here has been recently carrying products different from what was offered in the past, and yesterday I saw something new. Â They had large packages of sliced pepperoni for cheap, and as I like to make my own pizzas, it looked like a good deal. Â I found that the packages included some chunks from the ends of pepperoni sticks, but that was fine with me. Â I've got 10 half pint jars of pepperoni on my shelf now. Â I probably wouldn't have thought about canning pepperoni if it weren't for Jackie Clay at Backwoods Home Magazine online. Â She and her husband homestead north of Duluth, and some time back she wrote about canning pepperoni and other sausages of that type. Â Following her instructions, I found that it worked well. Â Using this pepperoni along with the pizza sauce I canned last summer, I can have pizza whenever I want, without paying to have it delivered.Not much else going on here in my little apartment. Â I thought about doing some serious spring cleaning, but so far it is in the planning stages. Â I just can't get too excited about washing walls and cleaning cupboards until it is warm enough to have my windows open and have fresh air blowing through. Â At the rate it is warming up here in Minnesota, we're looking at maybe July?"Before our white brothers arrived to make us civilized men, we didn't have any kind of prison. Because of this, we had no delinquents. Without a prison, there can be no delinquents. We had no locks nor keys and therefore among us there were no thieves. When someone was so poor that he couldn't afford a horse, a tent or a blanket, he would, in that case, receive it all as a gift.We were too uncivilized to give great importance to private property. We didn't know any kind of money and consequently, the value of a human being was not determined by his wealth. We had no written laws laid down, no lawyers, no politicians, therefore we were not able to cheat and swindle one another.We were really in bad shape before the white men arrived and I don't know how to explain how we were able to manage without these fundamental things that (so they tell us) are so necessary for a civilized society."- John (Fire) Lame Deer, Sioux Lakota, 1903-1976We should be so civilized.

title: Noodle
text: (The following occurred right after I posted about taking a blogging break. Â I need to post this now, rather than waiting until spring.)NoodleNoodle was a one-of-a-kind cat. Â Not in his breed, which was everyday Tabby, but in his personality. Â He was lively, mischievous and an all around pain in the whatever. Â And I was silly in love with him.Noodle came to live with my son when he married Staci. Â Sort of a package deal. Â They also had Charlie the Beagle, who was kenneled during the day while they were at work, because he had a passion for chewing on cupboards. Â Noodle spent his days harassing poor Charlie, who couldn't get to Noodle to teach him some manners. Â Eventually it was decided that Noodle might be happier living with me. Â Charlie would certainly be happier.I don't know for sure whether a cat has the capacity for revenge, but I would almost swear that Noodle did. Â When I wouldn't share a pan of brownies with him, he stomped through the middle of them.When I banned him from my bedroom because he thought that chewing on my hair was lots of fun, he would sit outside the bedroom door and yowl at the top of his lungs - at 2:30 AM. Â When I left the house without his permission, he made sure that he knocked my computer mouse off the desk and onto the floor. Â (I finally got a wireless mouse and hid it in the desk drawer when not in use.) Â He has been known to knock all sorts of things off onto the floor, but he was particularly fond of my mouse.My Yorkies loved Noodle. Â The cat food dish is kept on top of my chest freezer in my kitchen. Â This is to keep the dogs out of the cat food. Â But Noodle didn't mind sharing. Â He would flip pieces of the dry food out of his bowl and onto the floor. Â As long as the dogs were there scarfing up the cat food, he would keep on flipping it to them.I have a pillow behind me on my computer chair for back support. Â On top of that pillow was Noodle's favorite spot to sleep. Â But only when I was sitting in the chair. Â When I got to the point where I was in danger of sliding off the chair, I would reach behind me and scoot him off the chair and onto the floor. Â That didn't bother Noodle in the least. Â He just strolled under my chair and hopped back up on the side opposite of where he had been unseated. Â Time and time again. Â He could have played that game all day.I am not sure of Noodle's actual age, but he was no longer young. Â For that reason I kept an eye on him. Â The Sunday evening after Thanksgiving, I noticed that he was acting a bit odd. Â He didn't try to jump into my chair, or any of his other sleeping spots, but would lay quietly on the floor next to me. Â He yowled once or twice, and I put him on my recliner, his usual nap spot. Â The next morning I couldn't find him. Â He was usually waiting for me by his food bowl every morning. Â I hunted for him and finally found him sleeping behind my TV stand in the living room. Â As he was sleeping, I left him alone. Â When he came out in the early afternoon, it was obvious he was in distress. Â It was then I called David, who came right away and took him to a vet. Â There was nothing to be done for him.Noodle lived with me for at least 8 years. Â Maybe longer. Â He was like a naughty little boy who, when he does something bad (but never really bad), you have to try really hard not to laugh while scolding him.I hope that Kitty Heaven has lots of things to knock onto floors and lots of dogs to harass. Â And most of all, lots of pillows to snooze on.

title: Time Off
text: I have decided to take some time off from blogging. Â I find that the well is pretty much dry. Â I find myself with ideas for posts, write them, and then draw a blank for a week or two. Â As I have several projects planned for the cold winter months when I rarely go out, I think I will concentrate on those. Â Thank you to all who read and especially to those who comment and let me know that I am not writing just for myself.See you in the Spring.

title: Brothers
text: Brothers are full of surprises. Â At least mine is.Kelly called me late this afternoon. Â Asked how I was doing. Â Said it had Â been a little while since we talked. Â Wanted to know if I was going to be home. Â Said he would see me in about 45 minutes!I always love spending time with my brother, whether it is for a day or two, or whether it is just for a couple of hours, like today. Â He had some time before a scheduled meeting and wanted to spend it with me. Â We drank coffee and talked and looked at some old photos and talked and ate spaghetti and talked some more. Â I was having so much fun that I didn't even think about taking any pictures.Now that is the kind of surprise that I really like. Â I hope that he will continue to surprise me like that. Â I love you, Brother.

title: Aunt Em and Me
text: My mother's youngest sister, Emily, spent lots of time with me when I was very young. Â She once told me that she thought we were more like sisters than aunt and niece. Â I think this was because we were only 10 years apart in age, and because she considered her sister (my mother) to be a second mother to her.I consider myself very blessed to have had an aunt/sister like her.

title: Homemade Bread
text: I really love homemade bread. Â I don't make it very often in the summertime. Â The oven heats up the apartment to nearly unbearable. Â But yesterday morning the temperature outside was in the teens, a few snowflakes were blowing past my window and it seemed like a good day for baking.My Mom made the most delicious yeast rolls in the world. Â So using her recipe, I stirred up a batch. Â I could tell that it had been a while since I kneaded bread. Â A hot shower got rid of the aches in my arms and shoulders! Not content with just rolls, I made another large batch of bread dough.....enough for two loaves and a pan of cinnamon rolls. Â If I am going to make a mess, I might as well make it worthwhile. Â All of it turned out really good.I miss having kids around to swipe hot rolls just out of the oven, slathering them with butter. Â Or fighting over who gets the heel from a warm loaf of bread. Â Eating the heel isn't quite as much fun if you can't beat a sibling to it.

title: Digital Books
text: I have been having a bit of fun lately, downloading digital books. Â I found several websites that have free downloads of books where the copyrights have expired. Â They are old books - many from the early 1900's, but they are interesting to me. I love the old cookbooks. Â You need a bit of an imagination to figure out some of the instructions: Â "Take a cupful of flour and a spoon of fat..." Â  "Cook until it resembles cornmeal mush..." Â  I particularly like this recipe for butterscotch:Butter Scotch1/2 Cupful of Molasses1/2 Cupful of Sugar1/2 Cupful of ButterBoil until it strings. Pour into buttered tin and when cold break into pieces. This is very nice when cooled on snow.I have downloaded novels and biographies and poetry as well as old cookbooks. Â I don't have a Kindle as I just can't justify spending that much money, but I did download a free Kindle Reader that works well on my computer. Â Some books I have in a text format. Â They are all fun to read. Â The only drawback is that it is sort of hard to curl up in a comfy chair to read from a computer that is not a laptop!I also have built up a library of audio books from some of these same websites. Â My computer is located next to my kitchen. Â I take a speaker, set it on a little table around the corner from my computer, and listen to books being read to me while I work in my kitchen. Â Even though these books are old, they are still interesting and I don't have to go out and buy reading material. Â Which is a good thing because for me, being without something to read is a disaster.Here are some of the websites where I found books:http://freekindlebooks.org/http://manybooks.net/http://www.gutenberg.org/The Â free Kindle for PC came from Amazon.com.As a person who loves a good sale, I can testify that free is even better, especially when it comes to books. Â And given the fact that space is very limited in my apartment, this works well for me.So go.....download a book.....turn off the TV.....and read something.

title: Beauty Contest Winner
text: When I was a little girl, my Mom entered a photo of me in a kiddie beauty contest.I won 3rd place.You are impressed, aren't you!

title: Unhappy Pooch
text: Jessie Jane is not happy.She is learning that just because it is my dinnertime, that doesn't mean that it is her dinnertime. Â I do not share. Â At least, I do not share spaghetti with my dog. Â Not unless I want to spend time in the not too distant future cleaning my rug, as spaghetti doesn't settle well on Jessie's stomach.I really didn't mind so much the standing and staring at me as I ate. Â I didn't even mind the way her little eyes followed every movement of my fork. Â I could live with that.But when she started barking at me to cuss me out for not giving her part of my meal, it was time to draw the line in the sand.I now eat my dinner in peace.Jessie now spends my dinnertime in her kennel. Grumbling. Â And pouting. Oh well!

title: Simple Happiness
text: One of the advantages of living a simple lifestyle is that it takes very little to make me happy. Â My happiness doesn't come from the amount of money I have or the stuff I own. Â It comes from the little things.Like today. Â While at the grocery store I checked the price of hamburger. Â The kind I usually buy was $2.59 a pound. Â I put a 5 lb. package in my cart. Â About 20 minutes later I was back at the meat counter looking for something I had forgotten, and found that the hamburger had been reduced to $1.29 a pound. Â Today was the "Sell By" date. Â So this time I put 30 lbs into my cart. After I got home, I browned it all and packed part of it into pint jars. Â The third canner load is processing as I write. Â Will finish canning the rest tomorrow morning. Â I should wind up with at least 35 pints of hamburger. Â That amounts to close to 70 meals for me, as I can generally get two meals out of one pint jar.Yep.....it's the little things.By the way.....if anyone is interested in canning hamburger, I have tried a couple of different methods. Â The first hamburger I canned, I browned the meat, packed it into jars, added broth and canned it according to the directions for ground beef. Â When I tried a jar of that hamburger, I wasn't at all happy with it. Â It turned out with sort of the taste and consistency of dog food. Â Which is what I will use thatÂ batch for.Then I read a post by Jackie Clay on the Backwoods Home blog. Â She is a canning goddess and many of the methods and recipes I use successfully come from her blog. Â (The link is in the sidebar.) Â She said that the method she uses for hamburger is the same process I used, except she doesn't add any liquid to the jars. Â I tried it and it worked like a charm. Â The hamburger turns out just like it was cooked fresh.Another of those simple things that make me happy.

title: Back From Blogging Break
text: I have taken a bit of a break from blogging. Â This fall I had fruit and produce coming at me from all directions. Â It seemed that I no sooner was done with one batch when another would appear.I canned ten crates of peaches and eight of pears. Â There were two batches of tomatoes, 150 lbs in each batch. Â Then there was 200 lbs of potatoes and 30 lbs of carrots, not to mention a big box of cranberries and some huge cabbages and a dozen big green peppers. Â Oh, and don't forget the apples.....at least 40 lbs of them. Â God bless Duane who made a couple of extra trips with the fruit for me and both Duane and Becky for the trips to the Farmer's Market. Â And most of all for huffing all of it up the stairs for me. Â To say nothing of the cases of canning jars. Â I never would have been able to do all of this had they not helped me so much.I lost track after a while of how many jars of fruit and produce I got out of all of that. Â But I made peach and pear sauce and a little peach jam, about a dozen jars of canned cabbage, many quarts of potatoes and carrots combined, and many more jars of cubed potatoes. Â There are jars of pasta sauce, pizza sauce and tomatoes with green peppers and onions and more of tomato juice. Â And jars of homemade vegetable soup.I had wanted to try making cranberry juice, so I did that this year and it turned out great. Â I think I had over 50 jars of juice. Â Before I drank some of it! There was lots of pulp left after making the juice, so I ran that through my food mill and added an equal amount of cooked apples and some sugar to sweeten it a little. Â Made really good cranberry applesauce.I dehydrated about two quarts of chopped cranberries to use in cranberry bread and muffins, and dried more apples. Â I also dried some of the cabbage as it works really well in soup. Â And dried cranberries and apple peels, ground into a powder, make a good, soothing tea.I still have lots of tomatoes that have been peeled and diced, in my freezer. Â Some of that will be made into chili to can and the rest used for pasta sauce and tomato juice.So now I just need to concentrate on canning meat. Â I have been hearing rumors that prices may go down some, so I hope to get some good sale buys. Â I don't cook big meals the way I did when my family was home. Â Now that I live alone, I really like being able to open a jar or two and have a good meal.I realize that some in my family think that I go way overboard on the canning and dehydrating. Â But then I watched news stories last week about the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy and saw the pictures of people standing in line for food and heard the stories of grocery stores either stripped bare or cash registers not working due to the lack of electricity. Â And the pictures of people digging in dumpsters looking for food. Â Now, here in the upper Midwest we don't get hurricanes. Â What we get are straight line wind storms, rain storms with lots of thunder and lightning, tornadoes and blizzards, all of which can knock out electric service.If a tornado takes the building I live in, then I am out of luck. Â But if not, I am ready. Â Nobody in my family will have to stand in line and beg for food or go dumpster diving in order to eat. Â That is a comfort to me, gives me peace of mind and is well worth all of the work that goes into preparing and canning food.And then I took a week and pretty much did nothing. Â Life is good.

title: Home Canned Tomatoes
text: When I told my youngest son that I was going to buy tomatoes to can at the Farmer's Market, he said that his tomato plants were producing more fruit than he knew what to do with, and offered to can some for me. Â And because I am not a completely stupid woman, I readily agreed.Today David showed up at my door with 20 quart jars of canned tomatoes and four quart jars of homemade pasta sauce. Â I am impressed. Â They really look good. Â I couldn't wait to try the pasta sauce, so I had spaghetti for supper. Â I called him later and told him that the sauce tasted just like good homemade pasta sauce should taste. Â It really was a treat for me. Â I would have taken a picture, but the spaghetti just didn't last long enough. Â Because the sauce was canned in quart jars, there is enough left for a good kettle of goulash for supper tomorrow night.And there was a bonus. Â It seems that Boston was in the garden picking cherry tomatoes, and sent two ice cream pails full for me. Â Thank you, Boston. Â I cut most of them in half and filled four dehydrator trays. Â The rest, a good-sized bowl full, are all mine, for snacking. Â They taste so good. Â I sent some quarts of peaches that I had canned a few weeks ago, home with David. Â I had promised Boston that I would trade peaches for tomatoes. Â I think that I got the better of that trade!

title: Just a Cat
text: Some would say that she was just a cat. Â And maybe to some, that would be true. Â But she was much more to me.She was the cat who had to be in charge and always, always be first in everything. Â First to eat when the food dish was filled each morning. Â First to use the clean litter box, whether she really needed to or not. Â First to jump up on my bed at night to be petted and have her ears scratched and belly rubbed.She was the one cat, out of my three, who claimed my lap if I sat in my recliner. Â She was the one who would nudge the others out of the way because, after all, it was her right as top cat to have my undivided attention. Â And if she didn't get it, I got a head bump to remind me of my duties to her.She had a need to help me, whether I needed her help or not. Â If I cleaned out a cupboard, she was there to inspect it to make sure it was done right. Â She spent countless hours laying on top of the chest freezer in my kitchen, supervising whatever I was doing. Â She was the only one who didn't run and hide when the vacuum cleaner came out. Â She was fearless.So when she became so ill that there was no hope for her, a decision had to be made. Â I didn't want to make that decision, but neither could I stand having her suffer. Â When she could no longer eat and showed no interest in what was going on around her, it was time.Kiley was a good old cat. Â She was my buddy. Â While she lived with me, she was a happy, contented cat, in all her queenly glory. Â She was affectionate and she made me laugh...out loud. Â I will miss her.I wonder if farming genes are passed from one generation to the next. Â My children come from farming ancestors on both sides of their family, and it seems that my grandchildren are really enjoying the process of planting a garden, taking care of it over the summer and most recently, harvesting all sorts of good things to eat.Their Dad says that his little garden is a long way from the kind of farming that his father and grandfather did, but I think that it doesn't matter if the land is measured in acres or square feet. Â The love of working the soil and watching plants grow and the satisfaction of a good harvest is the same.And it does this old heart good to see these values and traditions being passed on to yet another generation.

title: Another Phone Call
text: Got another one of those phone calls I love so much. Â Boston called me a little before supper time to tell me to check my email. Â They had sent me another picture!Boston said that she had been in the garden picking vegetables. Â They have tomatoes growing along a little fenced in area that is a run for Charlie the Beagle, and she said that she had to go to the other side of the fence to get some of the tomatoes. Â It seems that the vines had grown through the fence. Â Boston said that she and her Dad were going to can some pickles this evening. Â I'm not sure what they are going to do with all those beautiful tomatoes. Â She said there are lots and lots more waiting to turn red.Boston also told me that there were some more cherry tomatoes with my name on them. Â I asked her if she would like to make a trade. Â Duane had brought me ten cases of peaches and I spent today and will spend the next couple of days canning them. Â Am thinking about some peach jam and peach butter as well. Â I have been canning in half pint jars for Duane, as he likes that size to take to work. Â And pint size jars of peaches make a couple of meals for me. Â So I told Boston that if I could have some more cherry tomatoes, I would can up some peaches in quart jars so there would be enough for her family, and I would trade the peaches for the tomatoes. Â She thought that sounded like a pretty good trade. Â It is, too. Â The peaches are delicious!Boston said that her Dad thought it might be good for her to spend a day with me and learn to can things like peaches or jam. Â I thought that was a pretty good idea . Â My mother taught me.....her mother taught her. Â I like the idea of passing along those skills to another generation.

title: Monday Morning Surprise
