text: Monday mornings aren't known for good surprises. Â I remember when I was still in the job market, Monday mornings weren't my favorite part of the week. Â It was hard to get back into the swing of things after a couple of days off. Â It seemed as though if anything bad was going to happen, it would be on a Monday morning.However, this morning I had a good surprise. Â My phone rang and my youngest son asked if I was busy and was I going to be home. Â I told him I would check my calendar.That's a joke. Â These days my calendar is whatever I want it to be. Â I love retirement.He said that he would be in my neighborhood within the hour and would stop by. Â That's the first part of my good Monday morning surprise. Â Any time I see one of my kids it is a good day.The second part was when he unloaded from a cooler a dozen canning jars. Â They had been full when he got them and I was really glad to see the empties. Â Canning jars are like gold to me. Â The Farmer's Markets in my area are gearing up with all sorts of home grown produce and I hope to fill lots of those jars before the snow flies.The third part was when he handed me a container of home grown cherry tomatoes! Â Fresh off the vine. Â And super delicious. Â I snacked on them through the morning, had a few with my lunch and more with supper. Â By the time I thought about taking a picture, there weren't enough left to photograph. Â Since David started growing tomatoes, and especially since he shares them with me, I have a hard time eating tomatoes from the grocery store. Â The difference in taste is incredible.And then there was a bonus. Â David's garden includes cucumbers and he had made dill pickles. Â And I got a jar of them! Â I haven't opened the jar yet, but if they taste anything like the ones he made last year, I have a treat waiting for me. Â Last years pickles tasted like the ones Aunt Em used to make. Â And that is pretty high praise, considering that as a kid I begged her for her dill pickles whenever I went to her house for a meal.I'd say it was a pretty good Monday morning. Â Thank you, David!

title: Fruits of Their Labor
text: Yesterday I got another of those phone calls I love so much. "Grandma, we emailed you a picture!"Boston told me all about picking fresh vegetables from their garden and that her Dad was making stir-fry with them for supper. Â She told me how well the garden was doing and about how the tomato plants had fruit on them and how the kids had been helping Dad in the garden. Â I am amazed that with the heat wave we have going on here, the plants haven't just burned up. Â They must be doing something right.I am so glad that my grandkids are learning that vegetables are grown in the ground and don't just appear on store shelves in cans or wrapped in plastic. Â I am reminded of a story told by a member of a home canning email group I belong to. Â This fellow raises a big garden every year and sells at a Farmer's Market in his area. Â He said that a woman was looking at the potatoes he had dug the night before, which had a little dirt left on them. Â She complained about the dirt and when her small daughter asked why the potatoes were dirty, the mother told her that they shouldn't be, because everybody knows that potatoes grow on trees.After talking to Boston, Jacob took the phone. Â He told me all about the bunny that was trying to eat their green pepper plants, but he chased the bunny away and he didn't know where the bunny went, but he chased it away from the peppers and it ran away so it won't eat any more peppers!They promised to save a few cherry tomatoes for me. Â I'm gonna hold them to that promise!

title: Old Folks Dictionary
text: I think someone should publish an old folks dictionary. Â Fill it with terms that have meaning to nearly everyone over the age of fifty. Â It would be a big help to grandchildren who have never heard of the terms and would make it easier for them to understand us. Â For instance.....Sunday Afternoon Ride: Â When Dad would pile us kids in the car and we would just take off for parts unknown, usually within a ten mile radius of home. Â We would look at the crops or the beautiful fall leaves or maybe wind up at the river, looking for huge clam shells. Â If we were really good, there might be a stop for ice cream.Going Visiting: Â Sometimes a Sunday afternoon ride would end up at a friend or relatives house, where we would play with the kids and the grown-ups would visit. Â There was usually lemonade and cake involved.Sunday Company: Â That's when somebody else's Sunday afternoon ride wound up at our house.Visiting: Â That's when friends or relatives sat on the front porch of a summer afternoon, and talked. Â Not on cell phones. Â No texting. Â Nothing remotely computer related. Â They talked. Â As in have a conversation. Â Which seems to be a dying art.Play Outside: Â That's what we did, as kids, from morning to night. Â Without parents hovering over us. Â Without helmets and a ton of other gear to protect us. Â We played ball or hide and seek or any number of outdoor games. Â Nothing was pre-planned. Â We didn't make play dates. Â We just played, which is what kids are supposed to do.School Picnic: Â That's when the entire neighborhood would gather at the two-room country school I attended. Â Each family brought something good to eat for a potluck picnic. Â The Dads would usually get up a softball game and the Moms would catch up on the neighborhood gossip. Â And the kids ran around and played, which is what kids are supposed to do.Potluck: Â Everybody brings a dish to share. Â Usually a casserole or salad of some kind. Â And a pie or cake or cookies. Â Nobody worried about the number of calories or fat grams, or whether there was a balance of "healthy" food. Â We just ate and enjoyed.Christmas Pageant: Â That's when the school kids would put on a program Â for the parents. Â It wasn't a "Holiday Pageant." Â It was a Christmas Pageant, with usually a combination of Santa Claus, Angels and the Baby Jesus. Â Nobody thought about it being politically incorrect. Â Of course, at that time, Christmas was still Christmas.OK. Â So when I write my Old Folks Dictionary, I suppose I had better change the title to Grumpy Old Folks Dictionary. Â I tend to get a little grumpy when I see so many of the simple pleasures in life go by the wayside in favor of technology. Â I am not such a Luddite that I can't see the distinct advantages to todays technology. Â After all, this blog is written and published using a computer. Â But I sometimes think that technology is taking over our lives. Â Some of us go through withdrawl if we can't send or receive a text every few minutes. Â Others can't live without their laptop. Â We rarely have verbal, face to face conversations any more. Â It is sort of sad, really.I will get off my soapbox now.And go for a walk: Â That's when a person leaves the house, goes somewhere that doesn't require transportation, and enjoys seeing the green grass and trees, the flowers, the eagles that soar over the river, and breathes in fresh air. Â And leaves the phone at home.

title: Good Kitty Drugs
text: My cat, Kizzie, has been really needy lately. Â She either parks herself wherever I happen to be, or she meows at me whenever I walk by where she is laying. Â She clearly needed a diversion.....something to do besides focusing on me.I remembered a small jar of dried catnip that I had on a shelf. Â So I took an old sock, tied a knot in the toe end of it, filled the heel with catnip and tied another knot above the catnip. Â Kizzie wasn't too hard to find. Â She was laying on the kitchen floor next to the chair I was sitting in while making her new toy.When I tossed the toy on the floor for her, she went nuts. Â She loved it. Â I took some pictures because it was so funny to watch her playing with that silly catnip toy.Noodle tried to get in on the act, but Kizzie just wasn't into sharing.After Kizzie had played with the toy for most of the morning, the other two took a turn. Â That one silly catnip sock toy has kept all three cats busy and amused and out of my hair all day. There is some catnip that grows wild along a fence in my neighborhood. Â I guess I will have to go pick some and dry it and make a couple more toys. Â Who knew that such a simple thing as a catnip-filled sock would keep three felines so busy. Â I wonder if they need to go to Kitty Detox?

title: Chris Graduates
text: I guess what they say is true. Â The older you get, the faster time passes by. Â It seems like it wasn't all that long ago that I received a phone call telling me of the birth of my first grandson. Â And just a couple of weeks ago, that same grandson graduated from High School.This past Saturday afternoon friends and family gathered to celebrate Chris' accomplishments. Â His Mom planned the party and it was a huge success. Â Relatives from both sides of his family were in attendance and there was enough food to feed a small army. Â I think everyone there enjoyed themselves. Â I know that I did.Congratulations, Chris. Â I am so very proud of you, as I am sure are the rest of your grandparents and your parents. Â It just doesn't seem possible to me that you are now old enough to go to college this coming fall. Â It is that time flying by thing again, and I have to accept it, especially now that you are so tall that you tower over me! Â I wish you all the best while you continue your education. Â I know that you will do well in whatever you decide to do.Love, Grandma

title: Real Life
text: While cleaning out some files on my computer, I ran across the following. Â I wish I could remember where I found it so I could give credit, but alas, I can not. Â I am going to post it anyway and if anyone claims it, I will be happy to credit them.Bill Gates gave a speech a while ago at a High School about 11 things they did not and will not learn in school. Â He talked about how feel-good, politically correct teachings created a generation of kids with no concept of reality and how this concept set them up for failure in the real world. Â Love him or hate him, he hit the nail on the head.Rule 1: Â Life is not fair - get used to it!Rule 2: Â The world won't care about your self-esteem. Â The world will expect you to accomplish something before you feel good about yourself.Rule 3: Â You will not make $60,000 a year right out of high school. Â You won't be a vice-president with a car phone until you earn both.Rule 4: Â If you think your teacher is tough, wait till you get a boss.Rule 5: Â Flipping burgers is not beneath your dignity. Â Your Grandparents had a different word for burger flipping; Â they called it opportunity.Rule 6: Â If you mess up, it's not your parents' fault, so don't whine about your mistakes, learn from them.Rule 7: Â Before you were born, your parents weren't as boring as they are now. Â They got that way from paying your bills, cleaning your clothes and listening to you talk about how cool you thought you were. Â So before you save the rain forest from the parasites of your parent's generation, try delousing the closet in your own room.Rule 8: Â Your school may have done away with winners and losers, but life has not. Â In some schools, they have abolished failing grades and they'll give you as many times as you want to get the right answer. Â This doesn't bear the slightest resemblance to anything in real life.Rule 9: Â Life is not divided into semesters. Â You don't get summers off and very few employers are interested in helping you find yourself. Â Do that on your own time.Rule 10: Â Television is not real life. Â In real life people actually have to leave the coffee shop and go to jobs.Rule 11: Â Be nice to nerds. Â Chances are you'll end up working for one.

title: My Dad
text: My Dad wasn't big in stature. Â He claimed to be 5' 5" tall. Â We all doubted it. Â But even though his stature was on the small side, he was big in so many other ways.When I was growing up, Dad often worked two and sometimes three jobs in order to take care of his family. Â His main job was as a grain sampler for the State of Minnesota. Â This job involved climbing into boxcars and taking samples of the grain in them, to be tested. Â It was a hot, dirty job in the heat of the summer and a cold dirty job in the middle of winter. Â I never once heard him complain. Â He often took side jobs to make ends meet. Â He fed and watered turkeys at a nearby turkey farm and cleaned our church and other buildings around town in the evenings. Â He had a work ethic second to none.When my mother needed special care due to arthritis, he took care of her and took over the household chores that she could no longer do. Â As anyone who has ever taken care of someone who is chronically ill knows, this isn't always a pleasant task. Â But he did it, every day, without a whimper or complaint. Â I once asked him how he could do this, day after day. Â His reply was, "I love your mother." Â That was all the reason he needed.Dad's life was not an easy one, even from the beginning. Â He and his family lived on a farm in northern Minnesota. Â He told of plowing fields behind a team of horses, of loading hay onto a hay wagon by pitchfork and of milking cows by hand. Â He told these stories of his youth, not so anyone would feel sorry for him, but because he felt we would be interested in what life was like on a farm before tractors, combines and hay balers. Â He talked of ice skating on the frozen lake near his family home, and of how one windy winter day, he held out his arms like wings and let the wind carry him to the other side of the lake. Â Then he said he wished he had thought about how he was going to get back, against the strong wind, but that the struggle to skate back was worth the ride.He told of using saws to cut huge blocks of ice from the lake in the winter and packing them in straw in the root cellar, for use in their ice box during the summer. Â He told of hopping a freight train with some of his brothers to ride out to the Dakotas to work on grain thrashing crews in order to make a little money to help the family. Â He told of going to Montana with his brother, Kenneth, to pick potatoes for the same reason. Â Dad was never afraid of work and would do anything for the family.Dad was always there for me. Â It didn't matter what the problem was, he always had time to listen. Â He was a soft touch for his kids, and I knew that if I could get to Dad first, I could usually do whatever it was that I wanted to do. Â I took advantage of that like most kids do. Â That doesn't mean that he didn't discipline. Â He did. Â But most times it was not wanting to disappoint my Dad that kept me out of most trouble.Dad has been gone for quite some time now. Â But I still catch myself thinking that I really need to call Dad and tell him about whatever is going on in my life at the moment and to joke with him about mailing me piece of his world famous apple pie. I wish he were still there to answer that phone.I love you, Dad.

title: Grandma's Attic
text: My Grandma Paul's house in St. Paul had the most wonderful attic. Â When I was just a little girl, she would let me play there on rainy days. Â Any cloud that produced more than three drops of rain would send me running to find Grandma and beg her to let me go play in the attic. Â She would smile, take me by the hand and lead me up the stairs. Â She had an old, heavy flat iron that she would use to prop open the door so it wouldn't swing shut and trap me inside.The attic had a dusty, uneven wooden floor and a window in one end for light. Â Some thought it was a sort of creepy, scary place, but I loved it. Â The attic was filled with treasures that would keep me occupied for hours. Â One end of the attic was out of bounds to me, I suppose because the things stored there weren't for little girls to play with and break. Â But the end nearest the window was all mine.There were trunks filled with old clothes, shoes and hats that were perfect for playing dress-up. Â There were toys from when my mother and aunts and uncle were children. Â Wonderful wooden pull toys and building blocks and real china play dishes and wooden puzzles. Â There were stuffed animals and I think I even remember a barnyard set complete with cows and chickens.The most wonderful things of all for me were the picture books. Â I was, at that time, too young to have gone to school yet, and I couldn't read, but I spent hours looking at the books and making up stories to go with the pictures. Â It was like being able to go someplace exciting in my mind. Â I still feel that way when I read a good book today.....like I am transported someplace new, and if the book is an especially well written descriptive one, I can experience the sights and sounds and smells within the pages. Â That must have had its beginnings with Grandma's picture books.It is a shame that houses aren't built with attics any more. Â Attics are a wonderful place for a child's imagination to grow. Â I wish I had been able to spend time in Grandma's attic when I was old enough to appreciate the family history stored there. Â Sadly, Grandma and her wonderful attic were both gone by that time. Â I did not descend from a wealthy family, so I rather doubt that any valuable antiques were in the attic. Â But I remember seeing boxes of papers and books and pictures that probably would be of great interest to me now as I research my family tree. Â Yet, I do have the memories of rainy day play in Grandma's attic, and those memories are priceless to me.

title: Did You Ever Have a Day...
text: when you just didn't feel like doing anything. Â When all you wanted to do was stay in your jammies, read a good book, pet the dog, take a nap or two, and be just plain lazy.Usually, I keep busy. Â Housework needs to be done. Â The hated and despised laundry piles up and shouts at me to get busy and wash it. Â I usually have two or three sewing, crochet or scrapbooking type projects going. Â I spend time with the pooches. Â I like to bake, so I make goodies that I don't need but want all the same. Â I experiment with using my home dehydrated foods to make soups, stews and the like. Â I take trips to the grocery store or sometimes just go to the thrift store to nose around a bit and look for bargains. Â When the weather is nice, I take the dogs out for some air and exercise. Â Seems like there is always something for me to do.But the other day I just didn't feel like doing any of it. Â There was nothing wrong with me. Â I felt just fine. Â No hint of sickness. Â Got up in the morning like I always do. Â Fed and watered my fuzzy buddies, made a pot of coffee and sat down with my breakfast to plan my day.And at that point, everything came to a screeching halt. Â I found that I didn't really want to do anything.So I didn't.Life is good.

title: Farmer's Market Goodness
text: So this morning my phone rings. Â It is Number One Son, and he and Becky are at the Farmer's Market. Â They have found a few things I might be interested in. Â Should he get them for me? Â Well, of course!A while later they are at my apartment with goodies. Â A bag of rhubarb, some parsley, dill and cilantro and (be still my heart) fresh asparagus. Â I dearly love fresh asparagus.After we went to the neighborhood restaurant for breakfast, Duane and Becky left for an afternoon of fishing, and I went to work on the Farmer's Market Goodness. Â I washed the rhubarb, sliced it into one inch pieces and bagged it up for the freezer. Â The rhubarb will go well with strawberries later on, for pie filling, sauce or jam. Â Then I washed the parsley, picked off the leaves and got them to drying in the dehydrator. Â I will dry the dill and cilantro when the parsley is finished.That left the asparagus. Â I cut the spears into one inch pieces, blanched them and bagged those up to go in the freezer. Â But I saved out enough for my all time favorite comfort food, creamed asparagus on toast. Â When my family lived on the farm, we had a patch of asparagus that grew down by the garden. Â Mom and I would always freeze most of it, but sometimes she would make creamed asparagus on toast for supper. Â It was one of my favorite meals, and still is. Â I always thought that she made it because we liked it, and that was probably part of the reason, but as I grew older and was feeding my own family, I realized that this was one way that she made the asparagus go farther. I would have taken a picture or saved you some, but it just didn't last that long!

title: Guardian Protector.....Not So Much
text: I have thought of Lily, my tiny Yorkie, as my guardian protector. Â She barks at trucks that go past my windows. Â She barks whenever someone is in the hallway outside my apartment door. Â She even barks sometimes when the phone rings. Â "What a dog," I thought. Â "Only weighs 9 pounds and protects me like that."I was wrong.I started watching her when she was in protection mode. Â She would bark like crazy and then head straight for her food dish, take a mouthful of kibble, trot off to her little bed in the living room, and hide the food under her blanket. Â When I looked, she had about a day and a half worth of dry dog food hidden among the folds of the blanket. Â Little stinker was in no way protecting me. Â But God help anything that tried to get her food!My landlord, Steve, just laughs at her when she barks at him. Â She sees him once every month when he stops by to collect the rent. Â She knows him. Â And yet she barks at him. Â I told him about what a wonderful protector she turned out to be, and that an intruder could carry me off and it wouldn't bother her in the least, as long as that same intruder didn't mess with her food. Â "Well," he said, laughing, "she may not be much of a protector, but she is a really good early warning system."I suppose there is something to be said for having your very own personal early warning system. Â Guess I'll keep her!

title: I Really Hate Housework
text: That statement would probably send my mother over the edge. Â She was really big on making sure that dust bunnies never had a chance to reproduce under a bed and that every window was covered by snowy white starched curtains and that the glass sparkled. Â Sometimes I think that if I had a quarter for every time as a kid, I scrubbed down the stairs at the farm, using an old toothbrush to get into the corners, I probably could have retired a year earlier than I did.OK. Â You don't have to point out to me that this is an exaggeration. Â I know it. Â It is just that most times when I think about the farm, I see those stairs that I came to dislike with every fiber of my being. Â Saturdays shouldn't have to be spent scrubbing things within an inch of their lives, just in case company might come over. Â When you are a kid, Saturdays are for playing in the woods or a game of baseball or even a game of Monopoly with your sister. Â Not for scrubbing.I very rarely have my TV on any more. Â One of the reasons is that commercials make me crazy. Â Show me just one woman who dances about her kitchen with unrestrained joy because her wine glasses sparkle from being washed in one particular kind of dish washing soap, and I will show you one seriously deranged lady. Â I suppose that the Suzy Homemaker type of commercials are more rare these days. Â Commercials for video games and every electronic gadget known to man have taken over. Â But I can remember when I did watch TV years ago, there were women who crooned over a new refrigerator like it was a long lost lover and, in their high heels and frilly aprons, exclaimed over the kitchen floors so shiny you could see your face in them, or floated about their bathrooms, happily sniffing the air because their favorite cleaning product made the toilet smell good. Â Odd.....I don't ever recall getting all blissfully teary-eyed over a sweet smelling potty.I think that if the truth be known, the only people who don't dislike housework are the ones who have cleaning ladies to do it for them. Â The rest of us would probably rather be doing any number of other things. Â Maybe I am just envious of those who don't have to bother with scrubbing floors or washing dishes or changing the linen on the beds. Â That's more than likely it.OK. I am all done with this rant. Â And I have taken a long enough break. Â Time to get back to what brought this all on in the first place.....washing the walls and woodwork in my bedroom.Mother would be proud.

title: Dance Recital 2012
text: It is a blessing and comfort to me to know that my grandchildren are being raised right. Â All of them know how to say "Thank You" for gifts given them or for attending an event that involves them. Â I am generally given hugs as well, and that is a bonus.I received a card in the mail today from Boston and Maddie, thanking me for attending their dance recital last Saturday. Â The pleasure was all mine. Â It was so much fun to watch those girls dance. Â They danced with style and attitude, and I loved every minute of it. Â And it was fun for me to see several people that I hadn't seen for a while. Photos and videos aren't allowed at the recitals, but this was included in the card.My hat is off to David and Staci for all the work they do so these girls can dance. Â Staci puts in very long days at the competitions and recitals, helping the girls with their hair and costumes, and David works at Twins games to raise money for dance. Â And how many Dads are willing to do cartwheels across a stage for the "Daddy - Daughter Dance!" Â I really wish I could have gotten a picture of that!Thank you, Boston and Maddie, for sending me the card and especially for the picture. Â And for giving your Grandma such an afternoon of fun. Â I am looking forward to the next time I can watch you dance.

title: Eating Peas
text: Sometimes while I am busy doing the daily chores that never seem to do themselves (I don't know why. Â That's the only gripe I have about the way things are in the Universe. Â Unpleasant chores should just do themselves.), I will have a flash of memory. Â Not memory of whole days or weeks, but just of a snippet of time from childhood.Like while washing dishes the other day, I remembered eating dinner at my Aunt Elaine and Uncle Oscar's farm home near Winona. Â I don't recall the specific reason we were there, but I know that my family would go to visit from time to time so my mother could spend time with her sister. Â I don't recall anything about the meal except the peas. Â Oscar had a hired man who took his meals with the family. Â At this particular dinner, I remember watching with fascination as the hired man ate his peas with his knife. Â I just couldn't figure out how he kept those peas on his butter knife long enough to get them into his mouth. Â I tried it a couple of times, resulting in having to sweep peas up off the floor.I suppose that little bit of memory triggered my memory of this poem, recited by my Dad, with a little smile on his face:I eat honey with my peas.I've done it all my life.I don't like honey with my peas,but it keeps them on my knife.Now, I can't remember one single fact that I learned in Algebra class in school. Â But I have total recall about eating peas with a knife and that silly little poem. I think I am scared. Â And if I'm not, I probably should be.

title: National Honor Society
text: Our Boston has been inducted into the National Honor Society.When Boston called to tell me about being accepted into the National Honor Society, she was so excited and was talking so fast that I could barely understand what she was saying. Â I finally understood her to say that when she opened the letter telling her about it, she screamed. Â Now all of us who have raised daughters know about screaming little girls. Â However, in this case, the scream was entirely justified.This goes beyond normal Grandma bragging. Â This is more a quiet pride in a granddaughter who has worked hard to achieve this honor. Congratulations, Boston. Â You earned it.I don't waste time worrying about many things. Â Most things are out of my control. Â Many things I can not change. Â Some things that one tends to worry about may never happen. Â I prefer to remain as happy and positive as possible.But.....now and then I worry a little bit about my fading memory. Â I think this bothers me because several years ago, after a rather nasty illness, I suffered short term memory loss for a while, and still do just a little bit, though now this loss is probably more due to my age. Â Nevertheless, my memory, or lack thereof, tends to bother me from time to time.Like the time I had to call my daughter and ask her to buy a birthday card to give her son for me, as I couldn't remember where I had put the one I bought for him. Â (Note to self: Â Never, ever hide anything away for safekeeping. Â The next time anybody will see it is when your kids are cleaning out your house after you die!)Or like when my keys were missing, only to turn up after a couple of hours of searching, in the pocket of the pants I wore the day before.Or like when I wrote out a detailed grocery list only to forget it on the kitchen table when I left for the grocery store. Â I do that one about half the time.But sometimes memory loss isn't all bad. Â Like one day last week. Â When I was really craving something chocolate, but wasn't about to walk to the store just for a candy bar. Â Decided to clean out some cupboards instead. Â Found a rather large bag of M & M's stuck back behind some canned goods. Â Right where I had put it. Â And then promptly forgot that it was there.Sometimes a bad memory is a good thing. Â Especially when the outcome is chocolate.

title: Turkey, Turkey Everywhere
text: This is a 24 lb. turkey.My daughter and granddaughter were kind enough to go to the grocery for me a few weeks ago. Â I had been there and had seen these turkeys on sale for 88 cents a pound, which is really cheap for our area. Â But they were so big, I didn't think I could fit them into my handy, dandy little old lady shopping cart that I use to haul my groceries home. Â The cart works really well for me, especially since I make use of the local circulator bus to go shopping. Â And for that price, I wanted four turkeys.Right after they picked the birds up for me, (I think it nearly killed them off, hauling those big birds up the stairs to my apartment. Â Two of them weighed in at about 20 lbs. and the other two at about 24 lbs. Â I really appreciate that they did that for me.) Â I canned three of them. Â I cooked them, de-boned them, cut the meat into small pieces and canned it mostly in pint jars. Â I forget just how many I got, but I think I have enough canned turkey to last me a good long time, which is good, because I use it a lot. Â Makes great soup, stew, casseroles, macaroni salads and sandwiches. Â Canned up the broth that it cooked in, too, because I really like using the broth in homemade soup or for gravy.Anyway, I had this one turkey left in the freezer. Â So I hauled it out and set it in the sink in cold water to thaw. Â Once it had thawed, I cut it up into pieces like you would a whole chicken, but with lots more swear words involved. Â Cutting up a 24 lb. turkey is not for the faint of heart. Â Into the stock pots it went. Â Took all three of them. Â Covered the meat with water and set them on the stove.I added some carrot, celery and onion chunks for flavor and let them simmer until the meat was fork tender. Â Took the turkey pieces out, let them cool and took the meat off the bone. Â Strained the broth and set in the fridge so the fat would harden on top. Â Meat went into the fridge, too.The next morning I got the pressure canner going with the turkey breast meat in half-pint jars. Â I have lots of pints already done, and really like the half-pint size for sandwiches or salads. Â Just the right amount for one person. Â Then I skimmed the hardened fat from the broth and put that in a small container to go back in the fridge. Â Really makes fried potatoes taste good, and I use it for that as well as in homemade biscuits or dumplings. While the pressure canner was doing its thing, I peeled potatoes, carrots and onions and thawed out big bags of peas and corn. Â I diced the fresh vegetables and mixed the whole works together.I filled jars about a third full of turkey pieces and topped that with the vegetables. Â Into the canner those went. Â With seasonings that I add when I heat it up for a meal, that's going to make some really good soup or stew. Â Add some homemade biscuits or dumplings and you have a meal fit for a king.I think I may have gotten just a wee bit carried away with the vegetables. Â I was sort of on a roll, so I just kept on peeling and chopping.So I jarred up the rest of the vegetables and canned them, too.This is what I ended up with for canned turkey, turkey vegetable soup and mixed vegetables at the end of two days of non-stop canning.16 half-pints of turkey breast25 pints of turkey soup20 pints and 24 half-pints of mixed vegetablesAnd at that point, I ran out of jars. Â I still had about 12 cups of vegetables left, so I blanched them and onto the dehydrator trays they went, along with two pints that didn't seal. Â The 7 quarts of turkey broth went into freezer bags and into the freezer.I'm thinking that I got a lot of mileage out of that one turkey. Â I had been wanting to can up some jars of mixed vegetables, so that worked out OK as well. Â Will really taste good next winter. Â Or any time.Finding room to store it all in my tiny apartment, however, should be interesting.Noodle is particularly happy when I am canning, because that means that the box I keep my pressure canner in is then empty.Which means that he can crawl into the box and sleep.Or just hang out.Wouldn't it be nice if people were so easily pleased?

title: Mothers Day Happiness
text: I had a wonderful Mothers Day. Â I got a phone call from daughter No. 2, wishing me a Happy Mothers Day.Oldest son came by and took me out for breakfast at our favorite restaurant.Youngest son came by with his family and took me out to lunch. Â And then to the park. Â We watched the kids play and went for a walk through the woods and along the river.Daughter No. 1 and her family came by in the evening.Mothers Day just doesn't get any better than that.

title: Envy Rears Its Ugly Head
text: I am not, as a general rule, envious of people or their possessions. Â I am perfectly happy with my simple lifestyle and don't care much about owning "stuff." Â I feel no need to replace my beat-up furniture or to own a shiny new car. Â The things that I do own serve me well, and I don't need to have a panic attack if the cat sleeps on the couch and leaves a little hair behind or if the dog gets sick on the throw rug. Â Those things can be cleaned and work just fine, but if I had all brand spanking new, expensive stuff, I would probably waste a lot of time worrying about every little spot and hair. Â I have neither the time nor the patience for that.However, lately I find myself growing a little bit green with envy. Â There are several blogs and YouTube channels that I follow fairly regularly, and it seems that most of those folks have planted or are in the process of planting their gardens. Â I am envious.I really enjoyed having a garden. Â I miss it. Â I like digging in the dirt. Â I like watching things grow. Â I love the produce that comes from a garden instead of a grocery store. Â The weeding part.....not so much. Â But the end result is worth the time and effort.My landlord suggested that I plant some tomatoes in pots and put them out on the deck of my building. Â But things that are unattended around here tend to disappear, so I decided against it. Â I may have to start a little kitchen window sill herb garden and see how that works. Â Until then, I will have to control my envy and just enjoy watching other people's gardens grow. Â And wait for the Farmer's Market this summer. Â The produce I get there is as good, almost, as what I used to grow myself. Â My son said he wouldn't take me to the Farmer's Market any more unless he had a truck and a hand dolly for hauling all of the produce I buy. Â Guess what. Â He bought a truck. Â I have a hand dolly. Â Farmer's Market, here we come!

title: Dear Mom...
text: Dear Mom...I know that you are no longer here on this earth to receive this letter, but I am going to write it anyway. Â You see, I find myself talking to you and Dad in my mind every now and then, so I guess a letter isn't all that crazy.I wonder sometimes if you knew just how much I appreciated everything you did for me. Â You lived in a time when mothers rarely worked outside the home. Â Keeping a home for your family, seeing that they were fed and clothed and taken care of was your job. Â And you did it well. Â Much better than I ever could.I know that I didn't always want to learn the things that you were trying to teach me. Â I still can't make a bed with hospital corners and have it look as good as yours. Â And the house cleaning thing...I'm not as good at that, either, as you were. Â I don't live in squalor, and my apartment is relatively clean, but I just don't like scrubbing and waxing and polishing. Â That's not your fault, for you tried. Â That's just me.Some things you taught me though, I learned really well. Â I can sew a straight seam and the things I make turn out pretty well. Â And when I am sitting at my sewing machine, I think about you and about all the pretty clothes you made for me and my sister over the years. Â All those little dresses with white pinafores and the lacy Easter dresses. Â I am guessing that you probably wished that I were a bit more girly than I was, for dresses didn't fare too well with baseball and tree climbing, but I want you to know I remember how good I felt when I was wearing such pretty things that you made for me.I know that I grumbled and whined and complained about having to work so much in the kitchen with you. Â I hope you understood that at ten years old, I just didn't understand how hard it was for you, what with your feet and hands swelling so badly and the pain in all the joints of your body. Â I am glad now that you made me stay at it and taught me so much. Â I am a pretty good cook, and although your gingersnap cookies were better than mine, I make one seriously good apple pie. Â Maybe that is because of the summer that you had me fill the freezer with pies.I wasn't real keen on peeling all those tomatoes from our garden, or canning them all. Â Same for the tons of green beans and peas and sweet corn. Â But now I am really glad that you had the patience to stick with it, for those skills are helping me make it through these times when everything is so expensive. Â I think about you often when I am up to my elbows in Farmer's Market produce and my canner is bubbling away on my stove.I guess what I am trying to say is that, even though I didn't always show it, I appreciated everything you did for me. Â I don't know where I would be now if it hadn't been for your guidance and patience and understanding.I know that I have told you in the past that I love you, but I am going to say it again, just on the off chance that somehow you will hear me and know it to be true.I miss you, Mom. Â And I love you very much.Your daughter.Marjorie Mae Paul Matheny1924 -Â 1996

title: Such a Noise
text: Last evening I was sitting at my kitchen table working on a crafty project. Â In the spring of the year, before the weather gets too hot, I like to keep my front windows open a bit. Â Outside my living room window I suddenly heard an awful racket. Â I knew that it was a bird, but the chirping sounds he was making were so loud that they startled me.When the noise continued for a few minutes, I finally went to see what kind of bird was sitting outside my window and to see if I could tell what he was yelling at. Â I expected to see something the size of a crow, but there on the corner of the ledge outside the window sat an itty, bitty sparrow, yelling for all he was worth. Â He would lean forward and sing like mad, sit back, take a few breaths and do it again.Finally a little female sparrow joined him on the ledge. Â He was quiet for a time and then flew down to a branch in the little tree just outside my windows. Â There he sat, yelling loudly again for a minute or two. Â The little female finally joined him in the tree and the serenade stopped.Ah, spring. Â Love is in the air, even for sparrows.And it seems to take very little to amuse me.

title: I Am Trendy
text: I had to chuckle a bit the other day when I was at our local bakery. Â They have the best 7- grain bread and I treat myself to a loaf every now and again. Â The owner, who is just a bit younger than I am and has a similar country life-style background, was telling me about some homemade mango salsa that she had tasted. Â When I asked where she had gotten it, she said that one of her neighbors had canned it herself. Â I remarked that I was under the impression that I was pretty much the only person around who did home canning any more. Â She said that several younger people she knew had started canning. Â But she said that it wasn't the kind that we did when we were young. Â We did basic vegetables, fruits, jams and pickles. Â Whatever it took to get through the long, cold Minnesota winters. Â She said these people were into canning gourmet salsas, specialty sauces and watermelon pickles. Â But, she said, canning is canning. Â She then said that this canning thing seems to be a new trend, so therefore, we must be trendy, too!Well, what do you know! Â After nearly 66 years, I am finally trendy!

title: It's the Little Things
text: I don't very often get down in the dumps. Â I suppose if I took the time to dwell on all the unpleasant things that have happened over this lifetime, I could work up a pretty bad case of the blues. Â I choose not to. Â Those things are gone. Â I remind myself from time to time to "Look Forward."This has not always been the case. Â There have been times when I have let past hurts and disappointments overwhelm my thoughts. Â This was brought home to me a while back when one of my children told me that all I ever did was say negative things about my ex-husband, her father. Â That hurt me so much that I started to cry. Â Not because of what was said, but because of the fact that she was right. Â And I hadn't realized it until it was pointed out to me. Â And I felt awful about hurting my children with my negativity.From that day forward I made up my mind to do my best to banish that kind of negativity from my life. Â I don't always succeed, but I do try my best. Â And it has helped my whole outlook on life.There are still unpleasant things to deal with. Â There always will be. Â But I think that the trick is to deal with them and then move on. Â I am finding more and more that it is the little things in life that make me the happiest.An excited phone call from my granddaughters telling me all about their latest dance competition. Â That makes me happy.Spending a few days making a surprise gift for my grandson who graduates this year makes me happy.Looking at a huge bouquet of lilacs on my kitchen table, picked from a neighbors lilac bush, makes me happy.Watching Jessie Jane and Lily do their twirling, whirling Yorkie Dance Team dance in anticipation of a treat makes me laugh out loud.Sharing a couple of jars of homemade jam with a neighbor who was delighted to receive them because they reminded her of her days on the farm, makes me very happy.Looking through my old photos makes me happy. Â Sometimes I feel sad, knowing that so many of the people I have loved are no longer here, but the good memories of when we were together overshadows the sadness.I am not a Pollyanna or a Little Miss Sunshine type of person. Â Nor do I bury my head in the sand and pretend that everything is all love and sunshine. Â I am realistic enough to know that there are bad things and bad people out there. Â I know that the economy could go down the tubes in a heart beat. Â I know that the damaged nuclear plant in Japan could collapse in another earthquake, doing horrible damage to the entire world. Â I know that going outside my own door at night these days is not the wisest thing to do in my neighborhood. Â I know that politicians wouldn't know the truth if it bit them in the butt.I can't change any of these things. Â I can only change my attitude. Â I can be aware, but not allow the negativity and the bad stuff to keep me from being a happy person. Â So I find joy in the little things. Â The last time I talked to my brother, he said that I sounded happier than I had in many years. Â I think I will continue to look for the little things to make me smile. Â It seems to be working.

title: Just Ain't the Same
text: I love the Dollar Store. Â You have to watch what you buy, for lots of the merchandise is junk. Â But now and then I find really good deals. Â Coffee is one of them. Â As I go through coffee by the gallon and because I am not a coffee snob, (If it looks like coffee and smells like coffee and sort of tastes like coffee, I'm happy.) I buy my coffee at the Dollar Store. Â Food for my pets is cheaper there as well as some other things I use on a regular basis.So a few weeks ago I was browsing the shelves at my local Dollar Store and saw some canned ham. Â My Dad used to buy a canned ham once in a while when I was a kid. Â It was good. Â He would slice it up and fry it to go with pancakes and eggs or for sandwiches. Â So I bought one. Â Nice to have on the shelf if I had a craving for ham.Today I decided to have ham and eggs for breakfast. Â I opened the ham. Â Didn't really look like the canned ham I remembered. Â Popped it out of the tin. Â Didn't smell like I remembered, either. Â Started to slice it. Â It was sort of like trying to slice canned Alpo. Â So rather than waste it, I decided to try to make sandwich spread out of it. Â I mushed it up, added some onion, pepper, a little sweet relish and mayo. Â Mixed the whole works up. Â Slathered on a slice of bread. Â Took a bite.Dollar Store canned ham makes Spam look like fillet mignon. Â My Yorkie, Jessie Jane, is the consummate trash hound. Â Can't leave anything even vaguely resembling edible within her reach. Â She can tunnel into a trash bag filled with garbage waiting to go out to the dumpster, quicker than you can blink. Â Good thing she is short or nothing on the table or kitchen counters would be safe. Â I dropped a little chunk of the meat (if that's what it was, minus the mayo, etc.) on the floor for her. Â She wouldn't touch the stuff. Â This is the same dog who would dine from the kitty litter box, given the opportunity!I guess I should have known better, but the memories of that canned ham meal my Dad would make were still strong, and hope does spring eternal. Â But sometimes hopes are dashed. Â It just ain't the same.

title: Grandmas Get To Brag
text: It says so.....right there in the contract. Â "When you are a Grandma, you get to brag." Â Now when you are just a parent, it is OK to brag just a little bit. Â After all, when your kids do something awesome, they should be recognized for it. Â But when you become a grandparent, you can pull out all the stops. Â You get to tell anybody who will stop long enough to listen just how marvelous your grandchildren are. Â It is such fun...probably one of the most fun things about being Grandma. Â That, and the part where we get to enjoy our grandchildren without the responsibility of disciplining them. Â I really like this Grandma thing.Now, on to the bragging part.This week I have not one.....not two.....but three (count them.....three) grandchildren that I get to brag about.The first one I get to brag about is Zach. Â Now, I ask you. Â How many eleven year old boys do you know who take their mothers for an airplane ride. Â As the pilot!Zachs Mom emailed me these photos last evening. Â Pretty darned cool. Â I am so impressed by this boy's abilities. Â I just can't imagine what it must be like to fly a plane, much less at his age. Â When I was eleven, the training wheels hadn't been off my bike that long. Â His Mom says that he does an excellent job doing what his instructor tells him to do. Â He does everything himself, including landing. Â Below are some photos that Jill took during the flight.Valter's Aviation from the air.He went above the clouds!View from plane.Marina in Stillwater.Flying over St. Paul.St. Paul.Jill says that Zach wasn't thrilled with the Foshay Tower Observation Deck, but altitude while flying doesn't bother him at all. Â I can relate. Â I get a little bit shaky just climbing on a kitchen stool to reach something in the top cupboard. Â But I love to fly and have no fear of heights while in a plane.Which is something you need to keep in mind, Zach, when you get your pilot's license. Â Your Grandma really does love to fly. Â Hint!Now on to the second part of this Grandma brag-a-thon.Over this past weekend my granddaughters, Boston and Maddie, took part in their first dance competition of the year called "Talent on Parade" at the Minneapolis Convention Center. Â Their Dad tells me that there were between fifteen and twenty teams competing. Â In addition to the regular team competition, both girls performed in special dances, Boston as a solo and Maddie with three or four other girls.Boston's solo dance involved using the bench that her Dad made as a prop. Â I haven't seen them dance yet this year, but I am told that she dances on top of the bench and does a cartwheel off from it.Both Boston and Maddie won First Place Trophys for their special dances. Â This is above and beyond all the practice time they put in for the three dances performed with the dance team. Â I am so proud of these girls. Â They both love to dance and they both work so hard. Â David tells me that both are taking extra lessons at the dance studio to improve their performances, although I think it may be hard to improve on First Place trophys! Â Congratulations, girls. Â You have earned every bit of the pride this Grandma has in your accomplishments.Boston and Maddie's team went on to win first place in their Jazz dance and second place over all. Â You done good!When David called to tell me that they were on their way to the competition, I asked him if he had plenty of Kleenix with him, as he says he has a tendency to tear up while watching his daughters dance. Â I can relate. Â My heart is full watching them on stage.Yep. Â Grandma bragging rights. Â I am so very proud of all of you!

title: A Sad Day
text: Today I received one of those phone calls that nobody likes to get. Â My brother-in-law called to let me know that his Mother had died. Â I knew that she had been in the hospital with pneumonia and that she had been put on a ventilator. Â It had been nearly a week since she was admitted and I had hoped that no news was indeed good news, but it was not to be. Â The decision to take her off the ventilator was made yesterday and she passed peacefully early this afternoon.She had been my mother-in-law for the 20 years I was married to her son. Â After Mike died, she stayed in touch and although it was difficult for us to get together, we talked by phone often. Â She told me all about her great-grandchildren, who were the light of her life, and always asked about my family and laughed at the stories I told her about the things my grandchildren had done. Â She always ended each conversation by telling me that she loved me.I am so very glad that the last words I said to her were "I love you."Rest in peace, Peg. Â I will miss you.

title: The Legend of the Starfish
text: "The Legend of the Starfish"Author Unknown"A vacationing businessman was walking along a beach when he saw a young boy. Along the shore were many starfish that had been washed up by the tide and were sure to die before the tide returned. The boy was walking slowly along the shore and occasionally reached down and tossed a beached starfish back into the ocean.The businessman, hoping to teach the boy a little lesson in common sense, walked up to the boy and said, â€œI have been watching what you are doing, son. You have a good heart, and I know you mean well, but do you realize how many beaches there are around here and how many starfish are dying on every beach every day. Surely such an industrious and kind hearted boy such as yourself could find something better to do with your time. Do you really think that what you are doing is going to make a difference?â€The boy looked up at the man, and then he looked down at a starfish by his feet. He picked up the starfish, and as he gently tossed it back into the ocean, he said, â€œIt makes a difference to that one.â€

title: Christmas Past
text: I'm sitting here this evening remembering the Christmas seasons of my childhood. Â In this world where most folks feel as though they must shop until they drop, it surprises me that I can recall very few gifts of Christmas past. Â I remember mostly other things.I remember when I was very small, while my family lived in St. Paul with my Grandmother, my Dad would take Mother and me downtown to see the Christmas displays in the store windows. Â They were a wonder. Â There were scenes set up in the windows where Santa filled stockings or flew in his sleigh over the rooftops or the elves hammered and sawed in the North Pole workshop making toys. Â These were mechanical moving pieces, as this was waaay before computers were used. Â There were beautifully decorated Christmas trees and all sorts of wondrous things to see. Â It was all magical to a child.When I was older, living in Willmar, Dad would pile the family into the car and take us on a drive around town to see all of the houses decorated with Christmas lights. Â We always drove through a neighborhood that Dad called "Pill Hill," because a number of doctors lived there and that neighborhood always had some of the best light displays. Â I still enjoy seeing all the decorated houses this time of year.Sometime during the holidays we always made molasses taffy. Â Dad would cook it up on the stove, pour it onto a buttered cookie sheet and set it out on the porch to cool, and then each of us would grab some and pull and pull and pull until it was just right. Â We cut the taffy ropes into pieces and wrapped them in waxed paper. Â Then if we were lucky, Dad would make his "World Famous Peanut Brittle." Â I swear that it was so much better tasting than any other. Â I miss Dad and his peanut brittle especially now.Mom made tons of Christmas cookies - gingerbread men, red and white candy canes with real crushed peppermint candy sprinkled on top, date filled cookies and always, sugar cookie cut-outs decorated with red and green sugar. Â She made divinity and old fashioned fudge, enlisting me to beat the fudge with a spoon until it was just right. Â We made popcorn balls, wrapped them in colored cellophane and tied them with ribbon, for treats on Christmas Day with relatives. Â And then there was the smell of baking bread as Mom made buns and cinnamon rolls for our dinner with aunts, uncles and cousins on Christmas Day.We always had a real Christmas tree, with the exception of that unfortunate year when Dad brought home this silver, shiny aluminum tree that looked like rolls of tin foil had exploded. Â There was the smell of pine in the house, what with the tree and Mother's decorating every available space with pine boughs and shiny Christmas balls and red velvet ribbons. Â The tree had some of the old large-sized lights and some lights made to look sort of like candles, but when they heated up a bit, liquid inside the glass tubes would bubble. Â There were beautiful, shiny glass balls and tons of tinsel. Â I think the tinsel was to mask some of the bare spots in the tree, but I loved it.Dad always read the Christmas story from the Bible before we opened gifts on Christmas Eve. Â He and Mother wanted to be sure that we children understood just what it was that we were celebrating. Â I sometimes feel that the reason for our Christmas season has been forgotten, what with news reports about how many of millions of dollars have been spent on holiday shopping, advertisements of some stores staying open for the entire 48 hours before Christmas in order to rake in more money, and the TV commercial that shows people dancing through a mall, shopping bags in hand! Â I guess that the lesson that my parents wanted me to learn was, indeed, learned. Â For it is the memories of family and love and and the shared moments that have nothing to do with gifts, that are uppermost in my mind this Christmas Eve.I pray that my grandchildren, when they reach my age, will remember less about whatever gadget or toy is under their Christmas trees and more about family being together and enjoying each others company. Â David has taken his wife and children to spend Christmas Eve with his Grandmother, and I am so glad that he did. Â I have many good memories of Christmas spent with her and I am happy that his children will also have those memories. Â For no present can compare with the memories made with family.I wish you all a very Merry Christmas with the hope that you all make good and lasting memories with your families, and wish for nothing but good things for you throughout this coming year.

title: Cousin Curt
text: I received word this morning of the death of my cousin, Curt Matheny. Â The news was not unexpected, for he had been very ill for quite some time, but no matter how prepared we think we are, the loss of a loved one still hurts.I had known Curt my entire life. Â He was just a few years older than me, and we played together as children. Â I remember as a small girl, playing in his playhouse in the woods on his parent's farm in northern Minnesota. Â I think his father must have built it for him out of pine slabs, and there was furniture in it that was made from logs. Â I always thought how lucky he was to have such a wonderful place to play.We stayed in touch in our younger years through letters, and I would see him on our family trips to visit relatives, at family reunions and more often when I lived in northern Minnesota for a number of years, for it was his at his family home that I liked to spend time. Â Curt had a talent for woodworking and made some beautiful cabinets and furniture. Â He made his living this way for many years. I guess I am feeling a bit melancholy today. Â Also a bit nostalgic. Â It seems that so many of my father's family have gone on to their reward and there are so few of us left now. Â I understand that this is the natural order of things, but that doesn't make it any easier.Good-bye Curt. Â I treasure the memories.

title: Memory is a Wonderful Thing - When it Works
text: So, this morning I get ready to leave my apartment and head downstairs to see what wonderful advertising junk mail is in my mailbox. Â The box is more than likely full to overflowing by now, as I stayed in all day yesterday and didn't check the mail. Â No wonder my mailman is so grouchy. Â I would be, too, if I had to haul around all of those sale fliers and catalogs this time of year. Â The same ones that I haul out with my trash.Anyway, I reached into the little glass bowl that sits on the buffet next to my apartment door. Â The bowl that holds quarters for the washers and dryers, a stray cough drop or two, some miscellaneous odds and ends and most importantly, my keys.I always drop my keys in the bowl when I return home. Â Always. Â Well, almost always.I reached in and.........no keys. The search was on. Â Turned the bedroom upside down. Â No keys. Â Shoveled various and assorted papers and, yes, junk off of my desk top. Â No keys. Â Did I drop them in the one of the desk drawers? Â Nope. Â Not there. Â Checked cushions on the couch and chairs. Â Nary a key was to be seen. Â Nowhere in the living room did I find them. Â Even checked the little doggie bed that Lily the Yorkie snoozes in. Â She loves to find a scrap of paper or a ball of yarn or a quilt piece that is within her reach and haul it to her bed, where she hides it under a toy or her blanket. Â Nothing there except three toys, a very old used bone, three pieces of kibble and a doggie treat she must have been saving for later.Next was the kitchen. Â Not on top of the fridge (Good Lord - I really need to climb up on a chair and clean that!) Â Not under the table. Â Not behind the buffet. Â Not in the freezer. Â Nowhere.So I poured a cup of coffee and sat down. Â There is no problem that can't be solved with a good cup of coffee. Â Now, what did I do the day before yesterday, which was the last time I saw my keys. Â I walked to the store three blocks away and bought dog food. Â Had the keys when I got back. Â Then I took the dogs out for some air. Â Jesse walked and loved it. Â Lily didn't. Â Typical dog outing - walk one and carry the most stubborn one. Â Unlocked my door with the keys. Â Then I did a couple loads of laundry.That's it!Yep. Â There they were. Â Inside the pocket of the pants I put in the laundry basket that evening.Now I understand why ladies of my vintage wear their glasses on a chain around their necks. Â It has come full circle. Â I used to, Â more years ago than I care to think about, have to wear mittens that were attached to a string, to keep from losing one. Â Never lost two - always one. Â Wonder if the string thing works for keys.

title: Don't Tick Us Off
text: I am in the process of updating my list of blogs that I enjoy. Â When I first started this blog, I was all about quilting, but since that time my priorities and interests have changed somewhat, so within the next couple of days I will be deleting those blogs that I no longer read and adding many that I do.One of the blogs that I enjoy is "Coffee with the Hermit"This morning he had a post that had me giggling like a schoolgirl, particularly since I had just this past week had conversations with the Social Security Administration and the people at Medicare, trying to find out why money had been deducted from my check for the insurance, while at the same time I was not listed on the rolls of the insured through Medicare. Â It was an interesting battle, just getting to talk to someone who might possibly know the reasons for this oversight. Â I really wish I had read the following before starting that journey of telephone insanity!Jim from "Coffee with the Hermit" has kindly given me permission to post this letter, which is a classic."Shown below, is an actual letter was sent to a bank by an 86 year old woman. The bank manager thought it amusing enough to have it published in the New York Times.Dear Sir:I am writing to thank you for bouncing my check with which I endeavoured to pay my plumber last month.By my calculations, three nanoseconds must have elapsed between his presenting the check and the arrival in my account of the funds needed to honour it.I refer, of course, to the automatic monthly deposit of my entire pension, an arrangement which, I admit, has been in place for only eight years.You are to be commended for seizing that brief window of opportunity, and also for debiting my account $30 by way of penalty for the inconvenience caused to your bank.My thankfulness springs from the manner in which this incident has caused me to rethink my errant financial ways. I noticed that whereas I personally answer your telephone calls and letters, --- when I try to contact you, I am confronted by the impersonal, overcharging, pre-recorded, faceless entity which your bank has become.From now on, I, like you, choose only to deal with a flesh-and-blood person.My mortgage and loan repayments will therefore and hereafter no longer be automatic, but will arrive at your bank, by check, addressed personally and confidentially to an employee at your bank whom you must nominate.Be aware that it is an OFFENSE under the Postal Regulations for any other person to open such an envelope.Please find attached an Application Contact which I require your chosen employee to complete.I am sorry it runs to eight pages, but in order that I know as much about him or her as your bank knows about me, there is no alternative.Please note that all copies of his or her medical history must be countersigned by a Notary Public, and the mandatory details of his/her financial situation (income, debts, assets and liabilities) must be accompanied by documented proof.In due course, at MY convenience, I will issue your employee with a PIN number which he/she must quote in dealings with me.I regret that it cannot be shorter than 28 digits but, again, I have modelled it on the number of button presses required of me to access my account balance on your phone bank service.As they say, imitation is the sincerest form of flattery.Let me level the playing field even further. When you call me, press buttons as follows:IMMEDIATELY AFTER DIALLING, PRESS THE STAR (*) BUTTON FOR ENGLISH#1. To make an appointment to see me.#2. To query a missing payment.#3. To transfer the call to my living room in case I am there.#4 To transfer the call to my bedroom in case I am sleeping.#5. To transfer the call to my toilet in case I am attending to nature.#6. To transfer the call to my mobile phone if I am not at home.#7. To leave a message on my computer, a password to access my computer is required.Password will be communicated to you at a later date to that Authorized Contact mentioned earlier.#8. To return to the main menu and to listen to options 1 through 9.#9. To make a general complaint or inquiry.The contact will then be put on hold, pending the attention of my automated answering service.#10. This is a second reminder to press* for English.While this may, on occasion, involve a lengthy wait, uplifting music will play for the duration of the call.Regrettably, but again following your example, I must also levy an establishment fee to cover the setting up of this new arrangement.May I wish you a happy, if ever so slightly less prosperous New Year?Your Humble ClientPS: Don't make old people mad. We don't like being old in the first place, so it doesn't take much to tick us off."I love it!

title: In Praise of Front Porches
text: Front porches seem to be a thing of the past. Â I notice that many of the older homes in the town where I live do, indeed, have front porches. Â Most in the newer developments do not. Â There may be a small covered area by the front door, but not a real front porch. Â A front porch, to be a really truly front porch, needs to cover the entire front of the house and perhaps extend around to one side.My Grandma Paul's house in St. Paul had a front porch across the front of her house and extending a little ways around one side. Â I played there often as a child. Â It was the one place I could play and pretty much stay out of trouble. Â It was when I left the porch that bad things happened, like being enticed by neighbor kids, older than my four years, to sliding down a two by eight board that they had propped up on the fence. Â Sliding down on my belly resulted in a visit to the hospital to have a large sliver of wood removed from the area of my waist. Â Should have stayed on the porch.The first house my family lived in after moving to Willmar had a front porch. Â The landlady who lived in the downstairs of the house allowed my sister and I to play on the porch. Â One winter while we lived there, Willmar was blanketed by a huge snow storm. Â My sister, who was not much older than a toddler at the time, walked off the edge of the porch into the deep snow and promptly disappeared from sight. Â Good thing my Dad was right there to haul her out. Â Should have stayed on the porch.The next house in Willmar where we lived had a kind of half front porch. Â Wasn't much of a porch. Â But then, it wasn't much of a house, being very small. Â But in the summer there were vines growing up wire that Dad strung from the roof to the bottom of the porch rail, which made the front porch cool and kind of dark and a really good place to play on hot summer days.The best front porch of all the houses I lived in as a child was the front porch of the house on the farm. Â It was a wonderful porch that extended all the way across the front of the house. Â It was screened in to keep the bugs out. Â Dad had dragged an old vinyl covered couch that folded down into a bed, out to the porch. Â As a young kid I spent many a summer night sleeping on that old couch out on the porch.From the porch we could see across the fields and Dad and I would stand there, protected from the weather, and watch the black summer storm clouds roll across the sky. Â I still like to watch the clouds on a stormy day.There was an old kitchen table and some chairs on the porch, and in the summer when we had weekend company, Mom would make pitchers of real lemonade and serve them with gingersnaps, out on the porch where it was cool and the breeze felt good out of the heat of the sun.I think that we need more front porches. Â For with a good front porch comes the art of just sitting and watching the world go by. Â Or watching clouds roll in. Â Or just sitting. Â And thinking. Â And remembering. Â And dreaming. Â Which is always good for the soul.

title: Venison
text: My phone rang last evening. Â David called to tell me to check my email as he had sent me a picture.He also said that there was a venison roast or two in my future.Woo Hoo!

title: Almost Done
text: I believe I am nearly at the end of my food preservation marathon using the goodies fromÂ the Farmer's Market. Â I still had apples left to dehydrate and I finished those today. Â ThisÂ is just part of the 60 lbs. of apples. Â I used about 10 pounds earlier - froze 4 quarts, madeÂ me a bowl of fried apples and a pan of apple crisp. Â Tasted so good. Â Sorry, but I didn't saveÂ any for you. Â It was just too delicious. Â Didn't even last long enough for a picture.I had already dried a couple of dehydrator loads of apples when this picture was taken.All total, I got 15 quarts of dried apple slices. I tried vac sealing them in bags, but they tended to break into small pieces, so I put them in quart jars as I wanted slices to use in pies, apple crisp and other apple desserts. Â A few weeks ago I canned a bunch of applesauce and 7 quarts of apple pie filling. Â I will probably do that again next year, but I really like the dried apples. Â They are so versatile and take up much less space than the canned.When Duane and Becky brought me this last load of fruit and veggies they also brought me a surprise. Â The Saturday that I had gone with them to the Farmer's Market I saw something that I really, really love. Â Something that I hadn't had for a very long time. Â Something that I used to buy from a farmer I knew when we lived up north. Â But I had already come close to wrecking my budget so decided I had better not spend the money, although it was way less expensive than in the stores. Â This was my surprise.Yep. Â A half-gallon jar of real, honest-to-goodness, pure honey. Â The last time I bought a tiny little bottle of honey at the grocery, I was dismayed to find that it didn't taste at all like the honey I remembered. Â After reading the label, I knew why. Â It was thinned out with corn syrup. Â Yuck! Â Not this stuff. Â It is liquid gold. Â That night I just had to make biscuits so I could have them with honey. Â Last night I made cornbread for the same reason. Â It is wonderful! Â Thank you for such a nice surprise.So now all I have left to finish up is the rest of the 50 lb. box of potatoes. Â Ten pounds went into the dehydrator this afternoon and there are about another 20 pounds waiting to be dried. Â Then I think I am done for a while. Â It seems like a lot of work, but it is well worth it, especially come winter time when I don't like going outdoors all that much, especially to grocery shop. While I was in the middle of all of this cooking and peeling and blanching and canning, I couldn't help but remember how much of this kind of thing I had done when I wasn't much older than Boston and Maddie. Â By that time, Mother was losing the use of her hands. Â The arthritis in her joints was just too painful for her to do the work involved. Â So as the oldest child, I was the only one old enough to help her preserve food for the winter. Â Back then it wasn't just a trendy thing to do as it seems to be now. Â It was a way of life. Â It was the way we made sure that the family would be fed until the garden produce was ready the next season. Â I remember that I wasn't very happy about spending so much time in the kitchen doing pretty much what I have been doing here lately. Â I wanted to be outside playing. Â Or in my room reading a book. Â Or any of a dozen other things. Â Anything but peeling apples and canning green beans. Â But I find now that I am grateful to my Mother for having taught me not only how to make things like jam and relish and canned vegetables, but for also teaching me the importance of doing it. Â I remember once complaining about all of the work involved and asking her why we had to do so much in the late summer and fall of the year. Â She told me that I should look around me. Â There were ants hauling off food into their ant hills for the winter. Â There were squirrels stashing away acorns for the winter. Â The farmers had put hay in their barns to feed their livestock for the winter. Â She said that if we wanted to eat through the winter, a little hard work now was the way to do it. Â She was right.

title: Potatoes, Peas, Carrots & Onions
text: I had asked Duane to bring me more potatoes from the Farmer's Market. Â I had bought 50 lbs. two weeks before, dehydrated some and canned the rest. Â I really like the canned cubed potatoes for convenience, and as a bag of potatoes from the store will go bad before I use them all, it makes sense to have them in jars in the pantry where they will last a long time.This box of potatoes I wanted to can a little differently. Â I am particularly fond of both beef and chicken stew over homemade biscuits. Â So I wanted to can the vegetables together in the same jar for this use. Â It is kind of my version of convenience food. Â Open a jar of canned vegetables, another of canned beef or chicken cubes, toss in a little tomato and some homemade gravy mix and by the time the biscuits come out of the oven, the stew is ready.Before Duane and Becky left my place on Saturday, Duane asked me if I wanted him to go to the grocery and pick up the carrots, peas and onions that I planned to can along with the potatoes. Â I figured that he and Becky had already done way more than enough for me, bringing me all the goodies from the Farmer's Market, so I said that I would take care of that Monday. Â His reply was, "Mom, would you rather spend Monday on the bus going to the store and hauling your groceries up the stairs by yourself, or would you rather have us do it so you can work on these vegetables!" Â And because I am not a completely stupid woman, I handed him my grocery list.I peeled and cubed some of the potatoes, peeled and sliced carrots and heated two large bags of frozen peas. Â Then I layered the veggies in quart jars and processed them in my pressure canner. Â I got 28 quarts of stew mix veggies, with a little bit of carrots and potatoes left over, which I bagged up and popped into the freezer.I had planned to add chunks of onion in each jar as well, but on thinking it over, decided that the onion would probably turn to mush in the pressure canner. Â So I peeled the 10 lbs. of onions, sliced them thin, crying like a baby the whole time, and filled my dehydrators with the sliced onions. Â This is what 10 lbs. of onions looks like in my big 9-quart stainless steel bowl.That amount of onions filled all seventeen dehydrator trays.I put them on the table in my bedroom and shut the door. Â I like the smell of onions, but I am not too sure that my neighbors do, although I have done this many times without anybody complaining about the smell. Â But an open window near the dehydrators and the closed door help to contain the onion odor. Â I let the dehydrators run all afternoon and overnight, as I like the taste when the onions caramelize a bit while drying.This is what 10 lbs. of dehydrated onions looks like, in my 2-quart bowl.If I want raw onion in a dish, this is not going to work, but for any kind of cooking, I just toss in a handful and they rehydrate really well.I still have probably two-thirds of the 50 lb. box of potatoes left and I will dehydrate them later. Â Right now there are 5 big bags of apples, right around 60 lbs. of them, waiting for me. I really do love the Farmer's Market! Â Duane says that he won't take me there next year unless he has a pickup and a hand truck. Â I wonder why he said that.

title: Cranberry Sauce
text: Yesterday Duane and Becky went back to the Farmer's Market in St. Paul. Â They brought me goodies. Â Lots of them.One of the goodies was a box of cranberries. Â I had seen the cranberries when I went with them two weeks ago, but didn't buy any then as I had already filled the trunk and back seat of Duane's car with produce. Â When I first saw the box they brought me, it ran through my mind that it was awfully small. Â But when I measured out the berries from the box, I found that it held the equivalent of 15 bags of cranberries from the grocery. Â At less than half the price of store berries. Â And they were beautiful berries. Â There wasn't a bad one in the whole lot.So yesterday afternoon I made cranberry sauce. Â Forty-two half pint jars of cranberry sauce.Duane and Becky were still at my place when the first batch came off the stove, ready to go into the jars, and after a taste test, they pronounced it wonderful.I think I will just sit here and admire these lovely jars for a while before moving on to the next project that involves 50 lbs. of potatoes, some carrots, peas and onions.Gotta love the Farmer's Market. Â And those who are willing to shop and haul and carry for me. Â Thank you.

title: Farmer's Market - It's a Good Thing
text: I had never been to a big Farmer's Market. Â There is a small one locally, but the last time I went past where it is set up, there were probably no more than six or seven booths. Â This past Saturday I got to go to a BIG Farmer's Market. Â It was so much fun!Duane and Becky picked me up early on Saturday morning and we went to downtown St. Paul. Â The market takes up one city block. Â There are more varieties of fruits and vegetables than I knew existed. Â And flowers. Â And honey. Â And handmade soap. Â And so much more that I can't remember it all.We walked through and looked everything over and then went back and made our purchases. Â I was afraid that I would do some serious damage to my budget if I wasn't careful, but the prices were good and I was more than pleased with what I bought. Â I am not good at negotiating prices with vendors, but Becky is, so I left that part to her, and she did well for me.We found a bushel of tomatoes at a good price, so into the trunk of the car they went. Â Then there was 50 lbs of potatoes for much less than I have seen them at the grocery store, and way more fresh, just perfect for dehydrating, so those, too got hauled to the car. Â There were bags of mixed apples that were really reasonable, so I took home three big bags for pie filling and dehydrating. Â I needed green peppers for a relish I want to make, and I got a big bag full for only $6. Â The last thing we found was cabbage.
