Â Now, we aren't talking about your puny little grocery store heads of cabbage. Â We're talking big, honkin' heads of cabbage, at only $2 each. Â I bought six heads. Â Becky and I had all we could do to each carry a bag of three heads. Â There is some seriously good cabbage slaw that I like to can and some Chow Chow relish, and the rest will be dehydrated. Â It is so good in soups. homemade chowÂ mienÂ and the like. Â I chopped up one head today to get it ready for the dehydrator, and it filled two and a half gallon zip bags!I'm thinking that Duane will probably think twice before asking me if I want to go to the Farmer's Market again. Â He was my pack mule. Â As I bought vegetables, he hauled them to the car and then came back for more. Â Bless him and Becky for hauling most of it up the stairs to my apartment for me. Â By the time they were done, it looked like a garden had exploded in my kitchen. Â I didn't take any pictures of my loot, but will when I am done canning and drying. Â It will be so nice to have this taste of summer when the snow is blowing this winter.Thanks again, Duane and Becky. Â I had such a good time. Â I'm thinking that by the end of this week there may just be a few jars of home canned goodness waiting for you!

title: Family
text: Earlier this summer I had a phone call from my youngest son. Â He reminded me that my brother, sister and I all had landmark birthdays this year. Â We would be 50, 60 and 65 years old, respectively. Â And he thought that this should be celebrated. Â It had been a very long time since we had all been together. Â Life and distance between homes seem to get in the way. Â Jobs, children's activities and other obligations make it difficult for all of us to be in the same place at the same time. Â My children were determined to overcome these obstacles so they set a date and made plans.We all met a little over a week ago at David and Staci's home. Â I was amazed to see how our family has grown from we three siblings to the crowd that was there! The grandkids made good use of the pool and managed to splash the grandparents as often as possible. Â They swam and ran and played and enjoyed getting to know one another. Â They are such fun to be with and watch.We sat and talked and remembered and compared notes and got caught up on what we had all been doing. Â Everyone contributed to the evening meal and if anyone went away hungry, it was their own fault as there was food enough for an army.The day wouldn't have been complete without our children insisting that we have a picture taken, so we gave in and let them. Â I'm glad that they did. Â It is nice to look at it and remember such a fun day.As I think back, it is hard for me to believe that so many years have passed since we were children. Â And yet, here we are, with a whole boat load of grandchildren between us. Â As a family, we have been blessed. Â Thank you, my children, grandchildren, nieces, nephews and my brother and sister, for making this a truly memorable day.

title: Garden Update
text: David emailed me some more pictures of his garden this past week. Â It seems that although we have been complaining about the heat, his plants love it. Â So much so that the radishes were becoming overgrown with other plants and had to be pulled.He said that the wind had sort of flattened some of the tomatoes, but they are doing well in their new tomato cages. Â I still have dibs on some cherry tomatoes!The corn along side the back of the house - that same corn that I said would never grow in that spot - has made a liar out of me. Â I'm thinking that if you listen really closely, you can probably hear it grow - it has grown that fast. Â It hasn't set on ears yet, but I expect at the rate it is growing, it will soon.And then there is the gratuitous cute grandkid picture! Â Can't leave that one out.I think the kids are enjoying the garden as much as their dad is. Â And I am glad to see David's family growing some of their own food. Â It is so much better than store-bought. Â I hope his garden gives them as much pleasure and mine did for so many years.

title: Gardens
text: Last evening David called and told me to check my email. Â He had sent me pictures of his gardening efforts. Â I think they look pretty darned good.He has sweet corn growing along side the fence in back of his house. Â When he planted corn there last year, I laughed at him because I thought the corn would never amount to anything in that location. Â I wound up eating some crow, as he had enough to use in canning salsa, as many meals of corn on the cob as his family wanted and he even had enough to freeze.This spring he put in this raised bed garden in his back yard. Â I am impressed at how well everything is growing. Â He has a couple of different kinds of tomatoes, some potatoes, onions, peppers and strawberries along with some other things that I can't remember. Â I have dibs on some cherry tomatoes. Â There is very little on this earth better tasting than homegrown tomatoes.There are some YouTube channels that I follow, having to do with food preservation and gardening. Â One of these has videos by a lady in Virginia, who posts a wealth of information. Â One of her videos is about her raised bed garden. Â (See her video Here.) Â I had not heard about this trend until David told me what he was doing. Â Since then I have found that this seems to be a growing trend. Â When David told me about all of the plants he has in his garden, he remarked that maybe he had crammed too much in the space, but it seems that this isn't a problem. Â He was able to get much more in that space than if everything was planted in rows. Â Makes sense to me.I wonder why more people don't have back yard gardens any more. Â I have seen only one vegetable garden in my neighborhood. Â With rising prices at the grocery stores, it seems to me that growing your own produce is a really good idea. Â I remember as a young girl, looking across all of the back yards in my block, there was not one yard that didn't have a garden. Â The only problem with having a garden is that it spoils a person. Â Store-bought vegetables just never taste as good as those that are home grown.And if you don't have a back yard garden, you miss the opportunity of having great memories in later years. Â Like sitting in the middle of the tomato patch with your Dad, salt shaker in hand, eating tomatoes off the vine until you just couldn't eat any more. Â Memories like that!

title: Proud Grandma
text: As you know, I have two granddaughters who dance.Both Boston and Maddie are in competition dance this year. Â And both did very well at their dance competitions the past two weekends. Â Both girls won trophys and Boston won an award for being an "Outstanding Dancer." Â Boston said before that competition that she really wanted to win that award. Â When the girl puts her mind to something, it gets done. Â Congratulations, Boston and Maddie. Â You done good!The things that these two young girls accomplish never ceases to amaze me. Â I guess it shouldn't. Â They love what they do. Â They work hard at it. Â They have the support of their parents. Â But yet it boggles my mind that they should be able to do what they do, and do it so well. Â Yep, this is Grandma bragging on them. Â And they have earned the right to have me brag.David said that he gets choked up every time he watches his daughters dance on stage. Â He says the other parents have found out and give him a bit of a bad time about it. Â But I can understand how this can happen. Â Last week David stopped by and downloaded some photos and video of the kids. Â The video was of Boston dancing at her first competition of the year. Â I gotta admit that I teared up a bit watching her. Â To see your child, or in my case, your grandchild, up on a stage, dancing her little heart out and doing such a fine job of it, just brings tears of happiness and pride to one's eyes.And how can you possibly watch this one dance, knowing how shy she was about being in front of an audience just a couple of years ago, and not feel the emotions of pride and happiness at her accomplishment.I am so very proud of you both, Boston and Maddie.Love, Grandma

title: Well Trained
text: My dogs are at my bedside the instant my feet touch the floor in the morning. Â The bounce about like they have springs attached to their feet. Â They twirl in circles. Â Apparently, twirling in circles helps them get what they want.I grope my way to the bathroom, where the dancing continues. Â Up and down and around they go. Â Worthy of any trained circus dog. Â Any pictures that I have tried to take of this morning dance have been nothing more than brown fuzzy blurs.I stagger into the kitchen, followed by the Yorkie Dance Team. Â Before I get the coffee on, which is the most important part of my day, I grab the jar that holds their treats. Â As I unscrew the top, the dancing and whirling escalates. Â You would think that a ham bone for each was awaiting them. Â But the treats are small. Â Smaller than a quarter.By now, they are standing on their hind legs in anticipation of goodies in their near future. Â I give each of them a treat. Â Jessie runs as fast as her short little legs will carry her back to my bedroom and hides behind my bed to eat her treat. Â And Lily is off and running in the opposite direction to hide behind the coffee table in the living room. Â They don't share well.By the time I get the lid back on the jar and start my morning coffee, both are back in their beds, where they sleep until the middle of the morning. I, on the other hand, am still struggling to get my eyes open all the way.They have me very well trained.

title: Dad and the Monsters
text: When I was a little girl I was afraid of the dark.Monsters lived under my bed.They hid in my closet.I would lay in my bed, perfectly still, making sure thatmy fingers and my toes didn't stray off the edge of the mattress.If they did, the monster under the bed would grab them.When the monsters were at their biggest and meanest,Dad would come into my room.He would sit in the rocking chair.And he would quietly sit and rock until I fell asleep.The monsters never got me.Dad was there.

title: Ode to Spring
text: "Spring has sprung,The grass has riz,I wonder whereThe flowers is."Recited by my Dad every spring as far back as I can remember. Â Usually performed as though he were a little boy who was standing in the front of an old country school room reciting his lessons, and always with a silly little smile on his face.Isn't it funny, the little things that you remember......and miss.

title: It's Official.  Spring is Here.
text: When I got up this morning, I looked out my living room window to see what the weather was doing. Â On a branch of the little tree that grows there, sat a robin. Â First one I have seen this year. Â Spring is here. Â I am so ready for it. Â I want to see green lawns, green leaves and the first spring flowers.I wonder if my kids remember going for a ride through the woods one spring on logging roads with Uncle Bruce and Aunt Etta. Â That was back when going for a ride on a Sunday afternoon was a popular activity. Â Before computers and video games and iPods and cell phones consumed our lives. Â Going for a ride meant piling into the car and driving wherever one felt like going, seeing whatever nature had provided for us to look at. Â This time, Uncle Bruce wanted to show the kids all of the beautiful May flowers that bloom in the north woods in the spring. Â I particularly remember the tiny purple violets among the tall pines, along with many other varieties of flowers. Â And the chokecherry trees in full bloom. I'm not so sure that anyone but me will remember violets, but they might remember the two black bear cubs that wandered out onto the trail ahead of us. Â We watched them for a time while they explored the world that was new to them, and then they scampered off into the woods. Â The kids were young enough so that they wanted to get out of the car and go pet them, but Uncle Bruce said that their mama, although we never saw her, was close by, and she wouldn't be very happy to have anyone close to her cubs.I think that sometime soon, after the river that is now busy flooding the walkway along it, goes back inside its banks, Jessie, Lily and I will have to go for a stroll along it and see if we can find some spring flowers.

title: Some Days Are Better Than Others
text: There are times when I am totally ashamed of myself. Â I had a bad day yesterday. Â Arthritis is not fun. Â It hurts. Â Some days it hurts more than other days. Â I found myself irritated because I couldn't do some of the things I wanted to do. Â I also found myself in the middle of a pity party. Â Shame on me.My brother understands what this is all about. Â Arthritis is our family inheritance. Â How he keeps on keeping on, working in a physically demanding job, is beyond me. Â I admire his strength and courage.So in the middle of my mental whining (Whining out loud around here doesn't mean a thing. Â The dogs ignore me and the cats could care less!) and feeling sorry for myself, I thought about my brother. Â And then I thought about my mother, who was in a wheelchair and in a nursing home at a much younger age than I am now because of this disease. Â I was able to get out of bed yesterday morning. Â Mother could only get out of bed if someone lifted her. Â I was able to take a shower alone, get dressed alone, fix my coffee and my meals without help and my hands still worked well enough to do some sewing. Â Mother was unable to do any of these things. Â What she would have given to have been able to function without help, I can only guess.Today, on the other hand, is one of my Better Days. Â I have been busy doing some of the household chores that were left undone yesterday. Â I have been up and down the stairs in my building a couple of times without much of a problem. Â I am back to normal, whatever normal is. Â But I am left with a sense of shame at letting yesterday's trials get me down. Â I try really hard not to do that. Â Most of the time I succeed. Â And when I don't, I think of those who are much worse off than I am.It is sort of like the person who complained he had no shoes right up until he met a man who had no feet.I think I need to concentrate more on what I do have, and be grateful for it.

title: Food Obsession
text: Yes, I have developed an obsession with food. Â Not so much the eating of it, although I will fight you to the death if you try to deprive me of my chocolate, but of the preserving of it. Â Although I owe nobody any explanations of the way I choose to live, I feel as though I need to address this issue. Â Mostly to give my children an understanding of what their mother is about. Â Especially since some of them think I have stepped off the edge of reality.When I was a young girl, my family had a large garden. Â Every summer and fall we spent hours and hours in the kitchen canning and freezing the produce from this garden. Â Money was tight. Â Mother was ill most of her life. Â She couldn't work outside of our home to provide extra family income. Â Preserving garden produce insured that we would eat over the winter.Later, when my children were young, I had a huge garden. Â I canned and froze as much as possible, for money was very tight then as well. Â Some of my children still remember the jars of food; Â fruit, jam and jelly, pickles and relishes, meat and vegetables, that filled the basement shelves. Â We may have been poor, but there was always enough to eat.Things have changed. Â I now live alone and have nobody to feed but myself. Â I am not rich, but neither am I poor. Â What I am is a widow living on a fixed income. Â Every month that passes, my income is stretched thinner and thinner. Â I am fortunate that I don't need a vehicle and the expense that goes along with it. Â But other expenses like medical and groceries and rent, keep going up. Â My income does not.So I decided to change my lifestyle a bit to compensate. Â I rarely eat out. Â Twice a month I go out for breakfast with my oldest son. Â We have been doing this for the last few years, and although I enjoy our breakfasts at a restaurant, it is more about the company. Â But I get my fix of restaurant food at those times and it is enough. Â I bake most of my own bread. Â I can bake at least four loaves for the price of one loaf of store-bought bread. Â I scoured the internet and found recipes for things like brownie mix, baking mix, cornbread mix, hamburger helper mix and stuffing mix. Â These I can make for much, much less than I can buy them, and they taste good. Â I buy bulk seasonings and spices and make things like taco mix, spaghetti sauce mix, onion soup mix and chicken coating mix. Â All for very much less than the commercial equivalents. Â And I have the added advantage of knowing what is in them as opposed to foods with unpronounceable chemicals included.I don't have a garden as I did in the past. Â Living in a city apartment makes that impossible. Â Stuff just doesn't grow well in an asphalt parking lot! Â So I buy fresh and frozen vegetables at the grocery store when they are on sale. Â These can be either canned or dehydrated. Â The canned vegetables I can use as a side dish with a meal or in casseroles and other dishes (I love creamed peas on toast.) and the dehydrated vegetables work really well in soups and stews. Â If left frozen, they develop freezer burn long before I could use them up. Â There is a Farmer's Market here and I hope to be able to buy tomatoes and other fresh produce there over the summer. Â So much better than supermarket fare.When meat is on sale, I buy as much as I can afford, freeze what I will use within a month and pressure can the rest. Â I am not really good at meal planning. Â It is more like deciding about 3 PM what would taste good for supper. Â Yesterday I defrosted a pork chop, baked it in the oven along with potatoes and carrots that I had canned together just for that purpose. Â The potatoes and carrots browned nicely in the oven and it was really good tasting. Â Another day I opened a jar of chicken, another of peas and carrots, tossed them together with macaroni, dehydrated onion and mayo, and had a chicken macaroni salad for supper, along with a slice of homemade bread. Â This is one reason that I can food. Â I tend to get busy doing other things and forget about meals until I start to get hungry. Â It is nice to be able to open a jar or two and supper is served.Contrary to popular opinion, I have not, nor do I intend to join a survivalist group. Â Not my thing. Â Granted, I would prefer living in a country setting and having a garden and all of the things that go along with country living, but at this stage of my life I am realistic enough to know that this isn't going to happen. Â I am more into preparedness. Â Life has a way of blindsiding us from time to time. Â I am pretty sure that people in Japan weren't aware when they went to work in the morning that their lives would drastically change by late afternoon. Â Not that I think that we will suffer an earthquake, and a tsunami is unlikely to cover Minnesota any time soon, but things beyond our control can and do happen. Â I just believe in being as prepared as I can be. There are things that the hard-core preparedness people do that I don't. Â I have no guns or ammunition stockpiled. Â I haven't invested in a solar oven or propane camp stove. Â I haven't converted savings into precious metals. Â There are many of these things that just aren't practical for me to do or that I would be comfortable with doing. Â But the one thing I can do to be prepared for the unexpected is to have food canned and dehydrated. Â At present, I have probably 4 to 5 months worth of food put by. Â My goal is a years worth. Â I realize that at my present weight and girth, chances are I probably won't starve to death any time soon. Â But I don't want to be one of those elderly people we hear about who have to choose between paying for the medications they need to keep them alive and buying food to eat.I also don't want to have to ask for help, although there are times when a little help is greatly appreciated. Â Being as self-sufficient as possible is particularly important to me. Â It keeps me out of the nursing home. Â It makes me feel as though I have some self-worth when I can take care of myself. Â And by preserving food for future use, I can insure that I won't have to ask any of my family for help with the groceries, with the possible exception of hauling them up the stairs to my apartment.I also really like the part where I don't have to rush to the store to stock up on essentials just before a snow storm. Â I remember doing that in the past and fighting crowds of people doing the same thing. Â I only go to the store now to buy the sale items or to replenish my kitchen pantry when I use the last bottle of ketchup or jar of mayo or need a dozen eggs. Â I have everything I need to get through any storm or other unforeseen disaster.So you all can stop worrying that Mom has gone over the edge or that her mind is going because she preserves food. Â There is a method in this madness. Â Now, if I begin to have meaningful conversations with Elvis, then you can worry.

title: 2 AM Musings
text: One should never fall asleep around suppertime and wake up after 9 PM. Â It really wrecks going to bed at a decent hour.And to make it worse, strange thoughts float around in one's head at 2 AM. Â Well, to be perfectly honest, strange thoughts aren't really all that unusual for me, but I digress.I was wondering, at 2 AM, why my parent's generation was so terribly worried about what people would think. Â Like the time when my Mother's doctor prescribed a shot of brandy at night to help her sleep. Â Mother made Dad get the brandy from the druggist rather than the liquor store, even though he paid twice the price at the drug store for brandy in a prescription bottle, because she was afraid of what people would say if they saw him coming out of the liquor store.As a kid, I went through a stage where I wore mostly jeans and my Dad's old flannel shirts. Â I lived in the country. Â I played in the woods. Â I grubbed around in the garden. Â I did yard work. Â I sat up in apple trees and read books. Â I liked jeans and old comfy flannel shirts. Â But Mother was always after me to change clothes because what would people say if we got company and they saw me dressed like that.My 4-H softball team practiced on Sunday afternoons. Â I loved playing softball. Â I was a pretty fair shortstop. Â But Mother was worried about what people would say if they knew that I was playing ball on Sunday, which was a day of rest.I always wondered who "They" were. Â Who were these people who were just waiting for my family to do something out of the ordinary so they could say whatever it was that they were going to say. Â I probably, in retrospect, shouldn't have posed this question to Mom, for, as I recall, it got me a week of living in my bedroom and a month of Wednesday night Prayer Meeting at the church, no doubt to pray for the state of my rebellious soul. Â I think that having a daughter who was, at that time, a bit of a free spirit, must have been a trial for her.Odd, the things one remembers at 2 AM.

title: Beef Sticks
text: A couple of weeks ago I made beef sticks out of hamburger. Â I have this handy dandy little gizmo that came with the first dehydrator I bought. Â You stuff it full of seasoned hamburger, squeeze the trigger and out pops beef sticks.David had told me that his kids really like beef sticks, so I tried a 3 lb. chub of hamburger in my dehydrator. Â A few days after David picked up the package and took it home, I asked whether the kids liked the homemade beef sticks. Â He allowed as they must, because the package was nearly empty.So Wednesday of this week he dropped off 6 lbs of hamburger. Â Last evening I mixed the spices in and refrigerated it overnite. Â Hamburger goes through the gizmo better if it is cold, and the spices need time to meld with the meat.This morning I made beef sticks. Â Six lbs of hamburger will fill nearly seven dehydrator trays. Â The old towels under the dehydrator are to catch any grease that seeps out of the bottom. Â I learned about doing that with the first batch I made.After about 12 hours, I had beef sticks.I love my gadgets.

title: A Month of Sundays
text: While doing my little stint at the computer this morning, I realized that it has been a month of Sundays since I last blogged. Â Well, OK. Â Maybe not quite that long. Â But it has been a while.I tend to get sidetracked. Â A lot. Â Especially if I have a new toy to play with. Â I have been dehydrating veggies. Â Cub had a sale on frozen veggies, which work really well in the dehydrator. Â Just open the bags, spread them on the trays and let them dry. Â I tried some shredded cabbage, too. Â I like cabbage in soup, and that worked really well. Â I also dried 10 lbs. of onions. Â I use lots of dry onions, and they turned out great. Â The other day, I opened a jar of canned chicken broth and a jar of chicken, dumped them into the crock pot, tossed in a handful of each of the dried veggies and let it all cook. Â All of the veggies rehydrated really well and that was some seriously good chicken veggie soup.I also tried drying a variety of fruit. Â The strawberries turned out OK as did the mandarin oranges. Â The oranges are a good snack. Â But I wasn't thrilled with any of the other fruit, so I probably won't be drying much of that. Â Maybe enough to chop up and use in muffins or quick breads. Â I haven't tried apples yet. Â They might turn out fine. Â We shall see.I have another new kitchen toy that I have been playing with. Â When I got my new dehydrator, at the same time I got a jar sealer attachment for my Foodsaver. Â That is the neatest little gadget since the invention of the bread slicer. Â I wasn't happy with using plastic bags for storing my dried stuff. Â Little creepy crawlers can get into Ziploc bags. Â I know this because I had to toss out a bag of wheat flour that I had in a plastic bag. Â So I put all of my extra dry stuff into glass jars and vac sealed them. Â When I use the veggies, I just pop the lid, take out the amount I want to use, and reseal the jar. Â Cool. Â The dollar store had brown sugar for a buck a bag, so I bought some and sealed that in quart jars and stashed it in the pantry. Â It stays soft and I don't wind up with brown sugar rocks. Â I love it!Then there was the sale at Joann's. Â Flannel for $2.50 a yard. Â That's less than half of the normal price. Â I am in need of blankets. Â I am not fond of blankets from the local big box stores. Â I really like quilts. Â Especially warm, snugly handmade quilts. Â So I bought enough flannel for three new quilts. Â These are not fancy, but are more utilitarian. Â There were lots of little kid prints and not much of a selection of other styles, so I went for bright and happy as opposed to beautiful.This orange quilt top is done and the other two are in various stages of completion. Â I expect that winter will be nearly over by the time I get the backs and batting put together with the tops, but that is OK. Â I will be all snugly warm when next winter comes blowing in on us.So that's what I have been up to for my Month of Sundays. Â Pretty tame stuff compared to your lives, but it works for me.

title: New Play Toy
text: I just love kitchen gadgets. Â My kitchen is small Â and without much storage space, so I am selective about the gadgets I buy. Â But I just couldn't resist this one.Meet my new Nesco Dehydrator.I have been looking at this one online for quite some time. Â But the only store in my area that carried them in stock and not just for online ordering was Fleet Farm. Â I don't do credit cards any more, so ordering online is a hassle. Â I can't get there by bus. Â So Wednesday this week, David picked me up and took me to Fleet Farm. Â I had so much fun. I found my dehydrator, extra trays for it, plastic mesh sheets that fit on the trays to keep tiny pieces of food from dropping into the lower trays, plus another gadget that plugs into my Food Saver for sealing dehydrated foods in glass canning jars. Â I was in heaven!I have a dehydrator that is several years old, and I have used it to dry onions, but not much else, as it had no temperature control on it. Â It had a tendency to cook as it dried, and that made for less than perfect dried foods. Â  The new dehydrator has the temperature control which will make it much easier for me to dry all the foods I want to dehydrate. Â I tested it with some frozen vegetables that I had bought on sale a couple of weeks ago.This is what you get from one pound bags of peas, cauliflower and two bags of broccoli. Â The cauliflower turns white again when rehydrated in water. Â I cook very few big meat and potato meals for myself, but prefer soups, stews, casseroles and the like. Â So now, rather than having freezer space taken up with bags of veggies, or cupboard space crowded with cans of veggies, I have the dried veggies that take up much less space. Â I can just toss a handful of whatever combinations I want into a pot of soup simmering on the stove. Â Or rehydrate them in water to add to a casserole. Â I love it.I am off tomorrow to do a little grocery shopping, and will get a variety of fruits to dry as well as more frozen veggies. Â I love dried fruit, but don't like the prices of the prepared stuff, or the additives in them to give them a longer shelf life. Â And the home dried fruit tastes so much better. Â David requested some beef sticks that can be made with ground beef and spices, so I will make those next week as well. Â I think I like the beef sticks as much as his kids do.Thank you, David, for taking time from your busy schedule to run me over to Fleet Farm. Â It was nice to be able to spend time with you. Â I really love it when we have time to just talk. Â And I am having so much fun with my new play toy!

title: Rocky and Bullwinkle
text: If I let my family know that the other evening I spent a couple of hours watching reruns of the old Rocky and Bullwinkle TV show, do you suppose they might insist on therapy for me? Especially if they knew that I spent a good deal of that time laughing out loud, all by myself, at the silly jokes and puns? Â And that I giggled all the way through the Fractured Fairy Tales and Dudley Doright segments?Yeah, they probably would.I won't tell them.

title: "Slow Down, You Move Too Fast"
text: Simon and Garfunkel had it right with those lyrics in their song. Why is it that we feel the need to move so fast? Â I think, speaking only for myself, it is due to years of this learned behavior. Â It began with my mother, who was a bit of a perfectionist. Â Dust bunnies hopped away in terror. Â Dishes didn't dare sit dirty in the sink for more than 10 minutes after a meal. Â We washed clothes on Monday and ironed them on Tuesday, etc., etc., etc. Â I remember watching my Dad mow the lawn at the farm, on nearly a dead run behind the lawn mower. I understand the need to keep my living space free from dirt. Â I mostly do that. Â But I find myself rushing about to get things done. Â I don't know why I do this when I now have all the time in the world to get things done. Â The dust bunny police are not going to knock on my door. Â I answer to nobody but myself. Â So why, in the name of good common sense, should I rush about like a chicken with no head! Â There is no good reason that I can think of.We live in a fast-paced world. Â It seems to me that so many people try to cram so many things into one 24-hour day. Â I did the same when I was still in the work force. Â I still have trouble slowing down, and if per chance I take a day and do nothing, I blog about it, because it is so unusual. Â That's kind of sad.I believe that the world would be a much better place if we had more rocking chairs on more front porches, and if we used them. Â To sit. Â And rock. Â And cuddle with a kid. Â And remember the good things. Â And hum a long remembered song. Â And sip a good cup of coffee or glass of homemade tangy lemonade. Â And watch the world go by. Â And take time out of busy lives to smell a few roses. Â And enjoy a sunset.I think my rocking chair is calling my name.

title: Grandma's Laundry
text: I have been known to whine about doing my laundry. Â I whine about it a lot. Â Anyone who knows me also knows that laundry is not my most favorite job in the world. Â Did I mention that I don't like laundry?I was thinking about my Grandma Matheny the other day. Â Her first child was born in 1898. Â By 1906 she had six children, including two sets of twins. Â She did lots of laundry.When I wash clothes, I pop them into the washer, go drink a cup of coffee while they wash, toss them into the dryer and drink another couple of cups while the machine does the work. Â Not Grandma. Â She took buckets outside to the water pump in the yard, hand pumped them full of water and hauled the buckets into the house. Â I'm thinking that she made more than just a few trips carrying buckets of water. Â Then she heated the water on her wood burning cook stove and filled a wash tub with the hot water. I don't know for sure what Grandma used for laundry soap. Â I make my own laundry soap. Â I do this because I want to, not because I have to, and because commercial laundry detergents make my skin itch. Â And because I can get six months worth of homemade laundry soap for the price of one small bottle of commercial laundry soap. Â And because my handmade soap gets my clothes really clean and fresh. Â But if Grandma didn't make her own soap, she used a large bar of harsh soap and cut or grated flakes off of it to wash her clothes. Â Soap flakes and soap powder weren't invented until the mid 1900's. Â And store-bought laundry soap would have been expensive. Â She didn't have money for luxuries like laundry soap from a store.When my clothes go into the washer, an agitator swooshes them around in the soapy water and gets them clean. Â I'm pretty sure that Grandma's house didn't have electricity until later years when her children were nearly grown. Â So Grandma did the agitating of clothes by rubbing them on a washboard. Â She had nine children. Â In 1906 she had two sets of twins under the age of four plus two older children. Â That's a whole lot of cloth diapers and overalls over those years to scrub on a washboard. Â To say nothing of the dirty farm clothes and children's play clothes. Â Those kids got dirty. Â They didn't sit in a clean environment playing video games or watching television or playing computer games. Â They played outdoors. Â In the woods. Â In the dirt. Â They worked outdoors as well, in the garden or helping with farm chores. When my clothes have finished washing, they go into the dryer. Â Grandma's clothes went in a basket and were hauled outside to the clothesline where they were hung up to dry. Â I don't know how she managed to dry clothes in the winter. Â Some hung clothes outside to freeze-dry and some hung clothes in the house to dry. Â Either way, it was a whole lot more work than tossing them into a dryer.When my clothes are dry, I fold them or hang them on hangars and put them away. Â I don't own anything any more that needs to be ironed. Â My ironing board stays in the closet until I need to press fabric for a quilt. Â But Grandma didn't know about perma-press. Â The clothes for her family were made of cotton, wool and other organic fabrics. Â They came off the clothesline wrinkled. Â I expect that this didn't matter for work clothes and play clothes, but the dresses she made for herself and her daughters and the shirts that the boys wore to school or church all had to be ironed. Â When I want to press a quilt top, I just plug my iron into the outlet, let it heat up and in minutes, the job is done. Â Grandma heated heavy flatirons on the top of her wood stove and with these she ironed clothes. Â For eleven people. Â Sometimes twelve, if my Great-grandfather was staying with them as he did sometimes. And she did all of this along with the routine cleaning and cooking required to take care of such a large family.I am such a wimp in comparison. Â I do believe that I can not whine ever again about doing my little dab of laundry. Â Or whine about any of the other daily chores that I do. Â I don't have to haul water or scrub clothes on a washboard or haul heavy baskets to a clothesline or iron with heavy flatirons. Â I have it pretty darned good. Â The superwomen of today have nothing on my Grandma.

title: Brothers Are a Good Thing
text: When I was a young girl, I wished for a brother. Â I had a sister already, and that was good, but I always wanted a brother. Â I envied my friends who had brothers. Â I always thought that a brother would be just the neatest thing. Â When I was 15 years old, I finally got my wish.When that brother was about three years old, I lived in a small rented house. Â The landlord was a crabby old man, who refused to turn on the heat, even though the weather was unseasonably cold for the spring of the year and we were sick from living in such cold, damp quarters. Â When he caught me trying to heat the kitchen using the oven, he yelled at me. Â My brother was with me when that happened. Â My mother told me later that my brother went around with rocks in his pockets for days afterward. Â When Mom asked him about the rocks, he said that he was going to throw them at the mean man who yelled at his sister. Â Even then, he was watching out for me.On Saturday afternoon, that same brother and his lovely wife came to see me. Â Kelly was in the area for his job, and Jackie had driven down to spend the weekend with him. Â Kelly is away from home a lot. Â Their time together is limited. Â That they would choose to spend some of that precious time with me just blows me away.We sat at my kitchen table and drank coffee (lots of coffee) and ate cookies and we talked. Â We got caught up on our various kids and grandkids and how everybody was doing. Â We exchanged cute grandkid stories. Â We talked of our parents and of times past. Â We remembered aunts, uncles and cousins and told those stories as well. Â Jackie, bless her heart, listened to all of it, uncomplaining. Â She is a gem.Time always goes by way too fast when I am with my brother, and although several hours had passed, too soon it was time for them to go. Â Saying goodbye is always hard to do, but knowing that we will do this again whenever we can, makes it easier.

title: Aunt Em
text: My Aunt Em was probably my most favorite aunt. Â This was, I think, because there were only 10 years separating us in age and because she was the only one of my aunts who lived close to me while I was growing up. Â But more than that, she loved me unconditionally. Em had graduated from High School in St. Paul, where she had lived with my Grandmother. Â But when she married Ronnie, she moved to his farm near Svea, just a few miles from my family's home. Â We spent holidays with Ronnie and Em and their family the whole time I was growing up. Â There were kids birthday parties and Sunday picnics at the lake and other times when Mom and her sister just got together to talk over a cup of coffee. Â Em and her family were a huge part of my life.I won't dwell on her death, for that is too painful for me. Â I will tell you about the blue octopus she made for me, that lived on my bed until I was out of school and had a home of my own. Â She is the one who gave me a jar of her homemade dill pickles, complete with a big red bow on top, for Christmas one year because I always hounded her for her homemade pickles when we were at her house. Â She is the one who took care of me when my mother was ill. Â She is the aunt who was always there when I needed her.Her sense of humor was second to none. Â She could make me laugh no matter how grumpy I was. Â She told stories, mostly on herself, like about the time she used her big pressure cooker to cook up a big batch of vegetable soup that she canned every fall. Â She set the lid on the cooker, thinking that it was set so that it wouldn't seal, but the lid slipped, sealed and pressure built up, eventually blowing the lid off. Â She wasn't hurt, but she spent the next couple of hours cleaning vegetable soup off of the stove, the floor, the cupboards, the walls, the ceiling.....My family traditionally spent Christmas Day with Ronnie and Em's family, while I still lived at home. Â The funny thing is, I remember very little about the Christmas presents, other than the octopus and pickles. Â What I remember most is sharing a good meal and how much fun it was when we all got together. Â There was laughter and love and good-natured teasing and all of the things that are present when people who love one another are in each other's company.She was one in a million.

title: It's Winter in Minnesota
text: And when it's winter in Minnesota, you just have to go and play in the snow. And after you play in the snow, you come inside and warm up with a cup of hot chocolate.That's just the way it is in Minnesota.

title: Jacob is Three!
text: Our Jacob had his third birthday last Sunday. Â Three Grandmas, one Grandpa and one Great-Grandma were there to help celebrate. There were presents.There was cake.But best of all, there was Jacob. Â He is growing so very fast. Â At least, it seems that way to me. Â Not all that long ago, seems like just the day before yesterday, we were celebrating his birth. Â Now he calls me to tell me what he has been doing, like his big sisters do. Â The best part is when he says, "Love you, Gramma."Happy Birthday, Jacob.Love, Grandma

title: That Darn Cat
text: Ya see that face? Â All innocence and cuteness? Â Don't let him fool you.I suppose he figured that if I wouldn't let him eat the brownies, he would just stomp through them instead.Ya know those bear rugs that people have in front of their fireplaces? Â I can see one like that about the size of a gray tabby cat as a bath mat.

title: Dad's Cars
text: When I was growing up, my Dad usually had two cars. Â One was the family car that we drove to town for groceries and other shopping and drove to church on Sundays, and the other was what he called his work car. Â That one he drove to his job as a Grain Sampler in Willmar.I never cared much one way or the other about the family car. Â But, Oh how I loved his work cars. Â The ones he had when I was old enough to drive were an early 1950's Â faded blue Plymouth and a gray Studebaker, also early 1950's vintage. Â These were not spiffy classic cars. Â These were dirty, rusty and disreputable looking cars. Â They smelled of grain dust and oil. Â They were parked away from the house as they were always leaking some sort of fluid from underneath. Â The only thing he asked from his work cars was that they should run well enough to get him to work and back home again. Whenever I could wheedle Dad's car keys from him, I drove one of his work cars. Â They were great. Â I could go places with friends and not worry about the car. Â I could put a ding in the side of one, and if I covered up the new scratch or dent with a little mud, nobody could tell it from the dents already adorning the car. Â Don't ask me how I know this. Â I think that driving these old cars was reverse snobbery, in a way. Â The kids at school had their highly polished, fancy painted, souped up Hot Rods. Â I had Dad's old work car. Â This appealed to my sense of humor.This was the last of Dad's work cars that I remember.Unfortunately for me, I no longer lived at home when he had this car, but I remember that it was at least as disreputable as his previous work cars. Â It might have been worth living at home yet just to have been able to drive it.Dad told me once that he would sometimes take my sister to school in this car, and that she would have him drop her off a block or so away from their destination so none of her friends would see her in the car. Â I expect that I, on the other hand, would have been more likely to pull right up to the front door, or park it in the first row of the parking lot.I've always been ornery that way.

title: Wrinkles
text: I don't have cable TV. Â I don't watch enough TV to justify paying the high fees. Â I have an antenna. Â It works well enough so that if I do want to watch TV, I have the choice of between 8 and 10 channels. Â More than enough for me. Â Most of the time.This past weekend I was in my living room doing some hand sewing on a quilt. Â Decided to watch a little TV while I worked. Â This was a mistake.Aside from the Public Broadcasting channels, there were mostly a variety of infomercials on. Â At least half of these were for creams and lotions that, should I immediately call to order because operators were indeed standing by, holding their breath waiting for me to pick up the phone, credit card in hand, would take away every wrinkle that ever thought about appearing on my face.I have a news flash for those people. Â I am perfectly content with my wrinkled face. Â The crow's feet around my eyes and the deep lines on either side of my mouth show that my sense of humor is alive and well and that throughout my life, I have laughed much more than frowned. Â The rest of the lines and wrinkles give this face character. Â They show that I have lived, not just existed. Â When I see someone of my vintage whose face is perfectly smooth, I rather feel a bit sorry for them. Â How can you lead a full life and not have it show in your face?My Grandma Matheny had one of those faces that showed that she had lived. Â She was a true pioneer in the northern Minnesota woods, moving to that area with her family when most roads were logging roads or trails. Â Train travel was new to that part of the state and the railroad lines didn't reach as far north as she lived in the log house built by my Grandfather. Â She raised her nine children there, without inside plumbing and without the modern conveniences that we are convinced we could never live without. Â Grandma's face was lined with wrinkles. Â I thought she was beautiful.Grandma with Clarice, Shirley and one of Shirley's childrenSometimes when I was just a little girl, I would sit on my Grandma's lap. Â Once in a while I would sit on her lap while she sat on the heavy, cast iron oven door of her wood-burning kitchen range, waiting for the room to heat in the early morning, just as my Dad had done when he was a little boy. Â I remembering reaching up and touching her wrinkled face. Â It was soft as silk. Â Her smile deepened those wrinkles, and she was all the more beautiful to me. Â I guess that along with that wrinkled face came the unconditional love that a Grandma has for her grandchild.What I wouldn't give to see that wrinkled face again.

title: What Were They Thinking
text: I love going through old pictures. Â Many times they lead me for a stroll down Memory Lane. Sometimes I will run across a picture that puzzles me. Â One in which you wonder what those people were thinking about when the picture was taken.Like this one.This one was taken in 1960, sometime around Christmas. Â The little doo-dad on the coffee table was a decoration that Mom set out only at Christmas time. Â The candles on the bottom were lit and the heat from them made the angels above move round and round. Â Mom and Dad are in the living room of the house on the farm. Â But what on earth could they have been thinking about to have such sober looks on their faces!That's more like it.

title: On Happiness
text: One of the blogs that I read daily had a post recently about happiness and the fact that each of us is responsible for our own state of mind. Â It stated that others can not make us happy. Â We and we alone have the ability to choose whether to live in a state of happiness or in a state of misery.Everyone has people in their lives who could drag us down if we allowed them to. Â And each of us has circumstances, whether it be financial problems, work related aggravations, living situations or a myriad of other things in life, that could make us unhappy. Â Even our long, cold, gray winters can bring us down. Â But only if we let them.The suggestion was made that we make a list of ten things that make us happy, and whenever we start to feel down in the dumps, take out that list and read it. Â Focus on those things that make us truly happy. Â Although I have never actually written down this list, this is a method I have used in the last few years to ward off depression. Â Whenever I feel myself headed toward a pity party, I think about things more pleasant. Â So here is my list of happy things.1. Â Fall leaves make me happy. Â I love that time of year. Â The hot, muggy summer days are gone, the air is crisp but not freezing cold, and the colors of the leaves are spectacular. Â I love being outside this time of year just to drink it all in and enjoy.2. Â Flowers make me happy. Â Flowers are one of God's best creations. Â I love lilacs in the spring and daisies in the summer. Â I love the rich colors of chrysanthemums in the fall. Â My walks in the warm months of the year are made so much better when I see a yard full of flowers. Â Or when I bring home cut flowers from the store. Â They always brighten my day.3. Â Soft spring rains make me happy. Â Spring rains wash away all of the dirty, dreary leftovers of winter. Â They bring on the beautiful green leaves and grass of summer. Â They make the world smell fresh and clean.4. Â Big brown puppy eyes make me happy. Â Dogs are so trusting. Â They love you unconditionally. Â They want to be with you, even when you are grumpy. Â And even if you just went out to get the mail, they act like they are so glad to see you when you come back.5. Â Phone calls make me happy. Â I'm not talking about those calls where someone wants to sell me something. Â Or those bad news calls that we have all received. Â I am talking about the ones where my adult child says that they just called to see how I am. Â Or those calls where a grandchild has something exciting to tell me about. Â Or when a friend or relative calls just because they missed me. Â Those are the phone calls that make me happy.6. Â The smell of homemade bread baking in the oven makes me happy. Â It is not just the promise of the yummy goodness that will be ready to eat soon, but it is also the memories of the smell of bread fresh from the oven when I got home from school, as a child.7. Â Memories make me happy. Â We all have good memories and bad memories. Â The bad ones I have taken out, looked at them and then packed them away on a shelf in the back of the closet of my mind. Â Those things that caused the bad memories cannot be changed, only learned from, and they are not worth dwelling on. Â But the good memories live in my mind, right in front, where I can take them out, remember good times or people who are well loved or places that made me happy. Â Good memories can bring sunshine to the darkest day.8. Â Making things makes me happy. Â It doesn't matter if it is a quilt that I make, or a batch of chocolate chip cookies or a really good supper. Â I get as much pleasure crocheting a granny square for my work-in-progress afghan as I do from making a loaf of bread. Â I come by this honestly. Â My mother was creative. Â She sewed and made crafty things when I was young. Â It is her influence that causes me to be happy while "doing something," no matter what it is.9. Â Woods and water make me happy. Â There is a feeling of peacefulness that goes along with a walk in the woods or along a shore. Â The smell of pine trees, the sounds of bird's songs and the gentle lapping of water on a shore make for a serene soul. Â Whenever I have been unhappy or distressed, a walk in nature has most times brought me back to a place of happiness.10. Â I have saved the best for last. Â My children and grandchildren make me the happiest of all. Â Whether we are spending time together on a family picnic or on a holiday or special occasion, or whether I am just looking at their pictures that I keep in my bedroom, or talking with them on the phone, my family never ceases to make me happy. Â They are my best thing and I love them will all of my heart. I can guarantee that if I were unhappy, reading my list of happy things would turn the most dreary time into one of complete joy. Â It works.

title: How to Survive Winter
text: I have finally figured it out. Â I now know how to survive a Minnesota winter. Â I stay indoors.I don't recall disliking winter when I was a child. Â I remember the fun of building snow forts. Â And snowmen. Â And making snow angels. Â And ice skating. Â And sledding.Going sledding at my Grandma Matheny's house near Blackduck was exciting. Â The cousins would take sleds and toboggans to the hill in the cow pasture across from the house. Â This hill was full of rocks and tree stumps. Â The person who was steering the sled had better be good at it, or we would hit a rock or stump and go flying off into the snow. One year when I was about 8 or 9 years old, my Christmas present was a pair of ice skates. Â Five blocks from our house in Willmar was an outdoor ice skating rink. Â I spent many hours there skating.....pretending I was an Olympic skating star. Â Truth be known, I never did get the hang of skating backwards or doing the fancy steps and jumps, but Oh, how I loved to skate.When my family lived on the farm, sometimes in the winter my Dad and Uncle Ronnie would pack up us kids on a Sunday afternoon and head for the lake. Â They would shovel off an area so we could ice skate. Â Or they would drive the car around on the ice and snow, towing us on skis or sleds. Â I'm pretty sure that the towing part would be frowned upon today, what with all the concern with safety issues. Â But we sure had fun. Â And afterward, there was always hot chocolate and cookies at either our house or at Ronnie and Em's.I guess I really don't hate winter. Â I love to sit in my rocking chair by the window with a cup of tea or coffee and watch the snow fall. Â I love the way the snow makes everything look so beautiful. Â But after years of clearing snow off of sidewalks with a shovel and years of slippy sliding on the ice, walking or driving, I much prefer to watch winter from the comfort of my living room.Works for me.

title: The Great Canning Marathon
text: So, when I shopped for groceries I found ham and beef roast on sale. Â Brought home a ham and two roasts. Â Cut the meat from the ham bone and cubed it. Â Cut both roasts into cubes and browned the cubes in the oven. Â Stuffed the whole shebang into pint jars and canned them.Canned meat isn't pretty. Â Jars of canned peaches are pretty. Â Jelly in jars is pretty. Â Meat is not. Â But it doesn't have to look pretty to go into a ham and scalloped potato dish or into a country beef stew or homemade vegetable beef soup, which is where these jars of meat will wind up. Â I think I need to can more ham and beef the next time there is a sale.I had a little ham left over.....not enough to fill a pint jar. Â So into my pantry I went and dug out a bag of dry split peas and a couple jars of carrots. Â Dumped them into a stock pot along with the broth that I had boiled the ham bone in, the leftover ham and the meat from the ham bone, threw in a handful of dried onion and a little pepper. Â Tossed in a pint of celery that I had canned a while back, just for fun. Â Brought the soup to a boil and then let it simmer on the back burner all day. Â This is seriously good split pea soup. Â Had a bowl for supper and canned the rest.This soup separates during canning, but combines again when heated and stirred.Then I decided to try something just for fun. Â I had found a recipe for canning French Fries. Â I already can potatoes. Â I do this because I can get a pretty good price on a large bag of potatoes as opposed to the smaller bags. Â Trouble is, I can't eat even a small bag before they go bad. Â Canning them solves this problem and I can have canned potatoes boiled, mashed or fried. Â Works like a charm. Â I love French Fries. Â So I decided to try this recipe.I just peeled and cut them lengthwise into fries, packed them in wide mouth pint jars so they would be easier to take out of the jar, covered them with boiling water and ran them through my pressure canner. Â I only had four empty wide mouth pint jars for the French Fries, so I filled enough small mouth jars with cubed potatoes to fill the canner.Of course I had to give the fries a taste test, so the next day I opened a jar. Â These only take a couple of inches of oil to fry, so I heated the oil, dumped the drained fries into the pot and let them brown.I really can't tell the difference between these canned French Fries and those I have made with raw potatoes. Â They are yummy. Â I may have to can up a few more jars of these.And with that, the great canning marathon came to an end.It gives me a sense of accomplishment to see these jars of meat, soup and potatoes on the pantry shelves and knowing that if I get a hankering for beef stew and biscuits, I don't have to run to the grocery store for the ingredients. Â Grab a few jars off the pantry shelves and before long, dinner is served.

title: Favorite Photo of Mom

title: I Have Chihuahuas
text: Actually, I have Yorkies. Â Jessie Jane and Lily. Â Eleven and nine pounds worth of Â Yorkies, respectively. Yorkies coats require constant brushing. Â Their hair grows long and mats up easily. Â After three years of working at a job where I bathed and brushed dogs ofÂ every shape and size and breed, this activity is not high on my list of fun things toÂ do. Â Truth be told, I tend to procrastinate when it comes to brushing my dogs. Â And they hide in their kennels when they see the doggie brush in my hand. This isÂ what they looked like a few of days ago.I hang my head in shame.So I took them to Starla on Wednesday for their grooming appointment. I now have Chihuahuas.

title: It's the Police
text: Yesterday morning my phone rang. Â It was someone downstairs using the intercom to get into my building. Â He said he was the police.Now why is it that when you hear it is the police at your door, your heart stops momentarily and you get a sinking feeling in your stomach. Â You wonder what it was that you did wrong. Â Must be some leftover guilt from being raised by parents who believed that anything that wasn't church related was wrong. Â After all, I haven't robbed any banks lately. Â I don't own a car, so there are no outstanding traffic tickets. Â I'm too old and too tired to get myself into too much trouble these days. Â So why is a policeman calling me wanting to get into my building?As I live alone, I make it a practice not to buzz anyone in that I don't know. Â So I went downstairs and after checking his identification, I let the officer in. Â Turns out, he was a very nice young man who just wanted to know if I had a phone number for my landlord. Â This officer's job is to work with apartment building owners in my area, for the purpose of reducing drug traffic and crime.I am fortunate to live in a building where this isn't a problem as far as tenants go. Â It wasn't always so. Â When Mike and I first moved here 15 years ago, we had a neighbor down the hall from us who was a drug dealer. Â There were a parade of his customers knocking on his door day and night. Â Later on there was, how shall I put this, a lady of ill repute living here, with another parade of men knocking on her door. Â There was an assortment of people who couldn't seem to live together without fighting, and the police were called regularly to referee. Â We continued to live here only because the rent was so reasonable and we were allowed to have our pets.So my landlord first fired the guy who managed the building as this man was only concerned with collecting rent and turned a blind eye to everything else. Â Then my landlord set about to clean out the building. Â He remodeled the apartments and took care to check references when renting an apartment. Â He installed a security system. Â I now have good neighbors and no longer worry about who is wandering the halls.It is nice to know that the local law enforcement is working to help landlords in my area when it comes to crime. Â Makes me feel a little more safe and secure. Â I gave the nice young man a couple of ginger cookies that were cooling on the kitchen table. Â And thanked him for watching out for the residents of this area.So the next time a policeman knocks on my door, I may not jump to the conclusion that it is a bad thing.

title: Another Christmas Has Come and Gone
text: And a lovely Christmas it was.We met at Jill and Joe's house as we have in the past. Â This seems to be becoming a tradition and I like it. Â The weather co-operated this year and everybody was able to be there. Â For me, that is the best part about Christmas......having my entire family with me.We ate and we talked and we played.Someone wanted to take pictures of me with my children and grandchildren. Â I usually would rather be behind the camera than in front of it, but I do love these pictures. Â I wondered, in looking at them later, if my children had gotten taller in the last few years, or if I was shrinking. Â Probably the latter.And this is the reality of trying to take a family picture that includes Jacob!It was indeed a Merry Christmas.

title: Duh!
text: So.....last week I grabbed my camera to take some pictures. Â I love taking pictures. Â I love my camera.I pressed the button that turns the camera on. Â Nothing happened. Â So I tried again. Â And again. Â Nothing.Gotta be the batteries. Â I took out the old ones and put in new. Â Pressed the button. Â Nothing. Â This is not good.Grabbed my jacket and stocking hat and off I go to the local convenience store. Â Bought batteries. Â Trudged home through the snow. Â Put the batteries into the camera. Â Pressed that little button again. Â Nothing.Well, I thought, perhaps the batteries from the convenience store aren't any good. Â They don't do much of a business. Â Maybe the batteries are old and don't work.So yesterday when I was out and about, I picked up more batteries at the grocery store. Â Came home and put the new batteries into the camera. Â Pressed the little button. Â Nothing.Now, I am getting worried. Â Did I mention that I really love my camera?Dug around and found the instruction book. Â When all else fails, read the instructions.Before thumbing through the instruction book, I casually looked at the top of my camera. Â There is a little dial with all of the settings that I can use with my camera. Â The little lever that I move for various functions was sitting between Automatic and the next function. Â Flipped the little lever to Automatic. Â Pushed the little button that turns the camera on. Â Woo Hoo! Â My camera works.I don't expect that I will run out of batteries any time soon.Duh!

title: A Do Nothing Day
text: Today I did absolutely nothing that even resembled work.I stayed in my jammies.I played on my computer.I took a nap.I read a book.I played with the dogs.It was absolutely wonderful.

title: Chicken and Dumplings
text: One of the things I like to do in the morning is read various blogs that I like to follow. Â Some of these have a theme day.....in this case, Way Back Wednesday.....where they blog about early memories. Â Yesterday, Lane of "That Man Quilts?" Â talked about remembering his Grandmother's chicken and dumplings. As sometimes happens, these blog posts send me on my own stroll along memory lane.My Mom could cook. Â Which isn't surprising, because her mother was a fantastic cook. Â But when Mom became too crippled with arthritis to work in the kitchen any more, Dad took over the cooking duties. Â And he was Mom's equal when it came to putting together a good, tasty meal. Â I once asked him where he learned to cook. Â He told me that he had been, when he was young, working in a logging camp in northern Minnesota. Â He said that he had hurt one of his arms and couldn't do the hard, physical work required when working in the woods, so rather than go home and lose the income that was much needed in his family, he started cooking for the logging crew. Â He said that if someone didn't know how to cook, they would learn really fast in that situation. Â A gang of hungry loggers is not a pretty sight.Next to his apple pie, the dish that I loved the most was Dad's chicken and dumplings. Â I have been known to show up on Dad's doorstep, chicken in hand, begging him to make chicken and dumplings for me. Â Dad didn't make dumplings from scratch. Â I tried a couple of times to make dumplings from scratch, but they always turned out hard like white hockey pucks. Â Dad used Bisquick to make his dumplings. Â They were always light and fluffy and wonderful. Â Dad's chicken and dumplings were my all time best comfort food.So last night, after having chicken and dumplings on my mind all day, I decided to make some. Â I didn't have any chicken in my freezer, so I headed to my pantry. Â I opened a quart jar of turkey broth and added a pint of canned chicken and a half pint jar of canned celery, along with dried onion and seasonings. Â While this heated on the stove, I made the dumpling dough from my homemade biscuit mix that I keep on hand. Â It is a good substitute for Bisquick. Â This was dropped by spoonfuls into the chicken mixture and cooked until the dumplings were done. Â I decided to go whole hog and add a vegetable, so I melted a little butter in a pan, added a bit of brown sugar and a pint of home canned carrots. Â A meal fit for a king.I would have taken a picture of this lovely plate of comfort food, but it just didn't last long enough.

title: Yesterday Was Thanksgiving
text: And I have so much to be thankful for.First and foremost, I am thankful for grown children who, along with their spouses and significant others, are willing to take the time and trouble to spend this holiday with me. Â It was such a nice day. Â Good food and good conversation. Â Throw into the mix the grandchildren, and they day couldn't have been any better. Â These are the same grown children who are always there for me. Â Last week I couldn't get to the store and one of them picked up what I needed and delivered it to me. Â I needed a ride to David's for Thanksgiving, and immediately there was an answer to my email, telling me that she would pick me up. Â Another calls me to tell me about his children's good school report cards and sends me pictures sharing what they have been doing. Â Still another shows up every two weeks to take me shopping and hauls heavy bags of groceries up the stairs for me, until his knuckles are dragging on the ground from the weight of them. Â And they do things like this for me often. Â I wonder if they know how much this means to me, how much this eases my mind and how grateful I am that I have adult children who care enough to be there for me. Â Makes my life so much easier and much better than it would be without them.I am thankful that I am able to live alone in my own home. Â I was thinking about my mother and how when she was my age, she had already been living in a nursing home for a number of years due to her health. Â Now at my age, there are occasionally times when my body lets me down and doesn't function the way I would like it to. Â But this has never been serious enough to even consider other living arrangements. Â I can still do what I need to do for myself on a daily basis. Â Sometimes it just takes a little longer. Â But that is OK. Â I am in no big rush.I am thankful for the little apartment that I call home. Â Now some would question being thankful for a tiny apartment in the middle of a city, especially when I have been known to whine about wishing I could live in the country. Â But when the truth is known, I am very thankful that I don't need to mow a lawn in the summer or shovel snow in the winter. Â I have a landlord who lets me paint the walls any color I want to as opposed to the standard apartment white. Â He thinks my dogs are cute. Â He fixes things. Â Right away. Â When I was unemployed for a time, he worked with me on the rent rather than having me put out on the street as many others would have done. Â He is a prince among landlords. Â My apartment is cool in the summer and warm in the winter. Â It is home. Â I like it.I am thankful that I still pretty much have my mental capacities intact. Â Alzheimer's disease has been known to occur in my family history. Â I don't waste time worrying that I will be afflicted with this disease, but it is something to watch for. Â My own little gauge of memory loss is passwords. Â I have a number of things on my computer that require passwords. Â I still remember all of them. Â When the time comes when I don't, then I will think about worrying. Â But not until then. Â Oh, I have the memory loss that is typical of those of my vintage. Â I will put something away for safekeeping and then have to hunt for it later. Â I make lists of things I need to remember, like what I need to buy at the grocery store. Â I write appointments and birthdays on my calendar so I won't forget them. Â But I really do remember most things. Â At least those things that are best remembered.There are so many other things that I am thankful for. Â I am thankful that my mother taught me to cook and bake bread and sew, for these things give me pleasure. Â I am thankful that my dad had the patience to teach me how to fix things and use tools. Â This came in handy not too long ago when I tore apart my sewing machine, put it back together, and it worked again. Â I am thankful for a loving extended family. Â Although we don't get to see one another often, just to know that they are there and that they love me as I do them, is enough. Â I wonder if my brother knows how much it means to me when he says, "I love you, Sister." Â And I am thankful for the ability, whether learned or inherited, to see the beauty around me even in a city, to be able to enjoy a simple life without the stress and complications that so many live with, and to be in general, a happy and contented person.For these things, and so much more, I am truly thankful.

title: First Snow of the Season
text: David called me last week after the snowfall we got on Saturday. Â He said that he was watching his kids who were outside makingÂ a snowman. Â He said that they were really having a good time playing in the snow.This so reminds me of a happy memory.I have no idea why this particular memory stays with me. Â I clearly recall a day when we lived in the old house on the Eddy farm. Â The weather was fairly warm for winter. Â The wind was calm. Â It started, early in the morning, to snow. Â And it kept on snowing. Â Those huge flakes of snow that are so beautiful to watch. Â Just floating to the ground. Â By early afternoon the yard was coveredÂ with lots of snow. Â Just right for snowman building. Â I couldn't stand it any longer, so I bundled my kids up in warm clothes andÂ outside we went. Â We built a huge snowman. Â The kids were rolling snowballs and making snow angels in the fresh snow. Â Ted theÂ dog was running and jumping and burying his head in the snow. Â We had so much fun that day, topped off with hot chocolate whenÂ we finally went back indoors.These days when my memory is sometimes hazy, I love it when I can see a day like that with my children so clearly in my mind.When I checked my email this morning, there was a message from Facebook. Â It seems that they have decided that I am, after all, Me! Â My account has been reactivated. Â I am so relieved. Â Now I can stop wondering who that person is who lives in my bathroom mirror every morning. Â Or maybe not. Â That person still looks more like my grandmother than the thirty year old person I always expect to see.

title: Apparently, I'm Not a Real Person
text: Everyone has their morning routines. Â I make my bed, feed my animals and then sit down at my computer for a while with a cup of coffee. Â There are some online comic strips that I read. Â I like to start each day with a smile if possible. Â Makes for a happy state of mind. Â I check a couple of news websites to keep up with what is going on in the world. Â I check my email. Â Then I look at Facebook to see what my kids and grandkids are doing that day.When I went to log onto Facebook this morning, a message came up that my account had been disabled. Â So, like everybody else who runs into a computer glitch, I tried logging in a couple more times. Â You know, the theory that if you repeat an action often enough, eventually it will work! Â Nope. Â No such luck.So I clicked on their help button to see why I no longer had an account. Â Facebook, in their infinite wisdom, has decided that I am not real.They say that I must provide my real first name and last name. Â Last time I checked, Vicki Matheny Miller was my name. Â Has been for 22 years. Â The Vicki and Matheny parts have been mine for 64 years. Â Nothing wrong there.Then they say that I am prohibited from impersonating anyone or anything. Â I am perfectly happy with who and what I am. Â I have no desire to be anyone or anything else. Â So that's not a problem.Facebook then tells me that I am prohibited from having more than one account. Â I have only one account. Â Now, I do have multiple blogs. Â Blogger doesn't seem to mind. Â But I can think of no good reason to have more than one Facebook account. Â No, that's not the problem.Then I learn that it is "strictly prohibited" to have a profile representing celebrities, pets, ideas or inanimate objects. Â Maybe that's it. Â Do you suppose that while I was sleeping, Noodle or Jessie or Lily opened an account in my name? Â I mean, Jessie and Lily do like to hang out with me when I am on my computer. Â And goodness knows, Noodle can be a bit sneaky at times, and he does like to watch what I do from the back of my computer chair. Â But no, I don't think that's it.Facebook's last reason for getting rid of me concerns spamming and harassing. Â I, to the best of my recollection, have never sent spam. Â I receive a lot of it. Â On any given day offers arrive in my email for all sorts of things that I couldn't possibly live without. Â This morning alone, I can get my very own credit cards, learn to be an ultrasound technician, sign up for tanning sessions, charter a boat, and make my skin clear and clean. Â I can also meet sexy seniors, cast a personal love spell and check the 68 messages now waiting for me on a singles dating website. Â I'm thinking that none of these things are going to happen. Â My children and their siblings harass each other on Facebook more than I ever thought about doing. Â I really don't think that I have harassed anyone lately, with the possible exception of my mailman who has lately given my mail to other residents of my building. Â Perhaps I was a bit premature on that. Â After all, Facebook says that I am not me, so how can my mailman know.So.....if any of you know just who I am, please let me know. Â I would be interested to find out. Â Because, after all, Facebook says that I do not exist. Â And if you see it on Facebook, it must be true.Vicki Matheny Miller (or whoever)
